HEADLINE: For Children Who Have Children

BYLINE: By Lynn Martin; Lynn Martin, who was Secretary of Labor in the Bush Administration, advises the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche on women's issues.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The debate over Joycelyn Elders's nomination as Surgeon General stirred an important discussion on the national epidemic of teen-age pregnancies. But the focus on sex education, condom distribution and abortion rights has left out one critical area: the steady rise in teen-age motherhood. Whatever the Government attempts to prevent teen pregnancy, it must stop sending the signal that unwed teen mothers can, with a few dollars from government, both raise their children and seek a decent future for themselves.
It seems no great surprise that the number of unmarried women having children has increased. From a time not too long ago when a pregnancy without marriage was almost unthinkable and kept hush-hush, we have moved unwed motherhood to prime time and celebrate it on the covers of glossy magazines. 
 I hope all of us are glad to leave a past where a child was branded illegitimate or a desperate marriage ruined two or more lives. But it strikes me as equally damaging to ignore the economic and social realities faced today by single teen-age mothers, and to avoid the policy changes that are needed to discourage unwed pregnancies and help girls who have children get their lives in order.
Mature, educated single women who make a choice for motherhood, though increasing in number, are still a small percentage of the total. The huge increase is among young women -- who usually stop their education, have few economic opportunities and often lack support systems for parenthood. That means problems for them and their babies.
We must leave the old conservative-vs.-liberal arguments behind and discuss instead how to change a failed system. A 15-year-old girl is not a 21-year-old woman, yet we have a system that treats her as one.
Think of your own 15-year-old daughter. You find out she's pregnant. Wouldn't you do more than give her a check on the beginning of every month? Wouldn't you be furious this had happened? Wouldn't you want to know how, when, who? Wouldn't you want to know how your child and her child will survive this trauma?
We would not treat our own daughters the way the welfare system does. Could it be that because many of America's 15-year-old mothers are children of color and are poor, too many of us believe they are not important?
Our welfare system should differentiate and separate the pregnant girl who is not yet 16. I'm saying: Remove her from where she is staying -- whether it is with a boyfriend, sister or parent or, too often, on the streets. We need a system that has a residential base where these young girls can stay, be protected and grow up.
Why not have supervised group housing? Why not provide counselors during the pregnancy and, in cases where the mother keeps the baby, for the first eight months of the infant's life?
Why not require school attendance and nightly check-ins? Why not create a haven where a girl can learn she is truly of value -- a place to learn about her new responsibility?
A girl in a group home can more easily get services that help her and her new child. Only half of teen mothers begin prenatal care in their first trimester. Too many continue using drugs and alcohol. Repeat pregnancies occur more often among teens. Abusive parenting is far too common.
Would group housing foreclose easy access for her boyfriend, give greater authority to the state and infringe on the young mother's right to do anything she wishes? You bet. But if we adults know better and do nothing, we are adults in name only.
Obviously this would cost money. But Washington already spends $25 billion a year for families whose first child was born to a teen-age mother. So we have an enormous economic and moral stake in ending the tragedy of childhood motherhood.
Such a program will require fundamental changes in our welfare, medical and legal systems. But why not risk change? All we have now is failure.

HEADLINE: In America;
No Job, No Dream

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
New York City held its Labor Day parade as usual on Monday, but there was little to celebrate. The bad news about employment just keeps on coming.
The Government reported last week that the number of payroll jobs fell by 39,000 in August, the first net drop in more than a year. 
 At the same time the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group, issued a report that said real wages continued to sink and the quality of existing jobs continued to deteriorate.
And yesterday Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a firm that counsels out-of-work executives, reported that more than 400,000 layoffs had been announced nationwide since Jan. 1. That represents 20 percent more layoffs in the first eight months of this year than in the first nine months of 1991, "at the height of the recession," the firm said.
The problems cited in the Economic Policy Institute's report were found across the board, in all education groups and all classes. Janitors are struggling, and so are C.E.O.'s.
"There is fear in the workplace, tremendous fear," said Harold Robles, a marcher in the Labor Day parade. "Everyone worries that he or she will be the next to go. Everyone knows someone who has been eased out or thrown out of work."
In the U.S., employment is the cornerstone of everything else. It's the concrete reality that sustains the glorious myth of the American Dream. Take away the job and you take away the dream. Right now an awful lot of dreams are vanishing.
The recession was supposed to have ended in 1991, but according to the Policy Institute study, "There have been broad-based wage reductions during the recovery, including severe wage declines for both blue and white-collar men and for both high school and college-educated workers."
The study confirms previous findings that "an unprecedented number of the new jobs created in the recovery have been either temporary or part-time," and that "well over 60 percent of the new jobs created between January and July 1993 were part-time jobs."
The job crisis has been brutal to the poor and is putting a tremendous squeeze on the middle class. But so far it has provoked no sense of urgency in Washington. Neither the President nor Congress has acted as if this were something we need to do something about fast.
For awhile the President seemed to be saying that continued low interest rates would go a long way toward solving the problem. That was nonsense.
Now there are reports that Clinton Administration aides are taking a look at job-stimulation measures similar to those used by President Bush during his re-election campaign. That doesn't sound like a good idea. It's as if a new baseball manager turned to his predecessor and asked, "O.K., how do I get this team out of the cellar?"
Meanwhile, Vice President Gore's proposal for restructuring the Government would more than double the 100,000 Federal jobs already targeted for elimination. And we are told that the North American Free Trade Agreement would cost jobs, at least in the short run; and that health care reform would cost jobs, at least in the short run.
Lawrence Mishel was a co-author of the Policy Institute study. In an interview he said, "The most depressing part about my research is that if you look at the [real] wages of just about every education group over the last 20 years among men -- college graduates, two years of college, high school graduates, dropouts -- the wages are down."
The fall in wages has been more precipitous among non-college-educated workers. Women have achieved some wage growth but the growth is concentrated among those with college or graduate degrees.
Over all, the wage of the average college graduate has already fallen by 1 percent since early 1992. More dreams are about to vanish.
"The only reason the male wage just hasn't plummeted tremendously on average is that more people are educated," Mr. Mishel said. "So education is almost like inoculating us against a just horrific decline. It's sort of like everybody is on a down escalator and we're busy getting more educated so as not to fall as fast."

HEADLINE: N.A.A.C.P. Takes Two Leaves From the Corporate Playbook

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Aug. 31 Business Day article on the pressures the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is putting on corporate America to hire more African-Americans illustrates how the battle for racial equity has changed since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial three decades ago. 
 Under the leadership of the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., the N.A.A.C.P. has torn out the first two pages from the tactical manual of business management and is using them to form a new relationship with corporate America.
Page One: in a competitive environment a negative image can hurt profits. Page Two: never ignore a potential opportunity because your competitor might exploit it.
Ever since the struggle for racial equity successfully challenged institutional racism through the courts, it has relied on activist government to remedy what government-sanctioned racism has wrought. But despite impressive legislative, judicial and executive victories, the residual effects of institutional racism -- the exclusionary attitudes toward race and ethnicity nurtured through generations of legal discrimination -- have kept minorities from achieving equity in the market and the workplace.
During that period, tacit adherence by a comfortable corporate America to a status quo in attitude was relatively risk-free. Aside from the threat of an occasional lawsuit, there was little reason for American business to become activist itself.
Times, however, have changed. America is no longer the single, dominant economic power in the world, and its relative decline has helped usher in a new competitiveness at home and abroad. Once-complacent corporate America has been thrust, kicking and screaming, into the global marketplace, where failure to detect and address potentially embarrassing problems, or to exploit new opportunities, can translate quickly into loss of market share.
Negative publicity denoting corporate arrogance or insensitivity toward racial equity within the organization, quickly transmitted through the communications media, can adversely affect sales. Neglecting the contributions that a creative minority population has to offer can mean losing a good idea or product to a less myopic competitor.
Dr. Chavis has recognized that, though we have made some political progress, activist government alone has not achieved the overall goal of racial equity over the past 30 years. He also appreciates the realities of today's competitive economic environment. The direction in which he is leading the N.A.A.C.P., and the successes he has enjoyed thus far, reflect a growing realization among the minority community that striking corporate America where it is most vulnerable -- in the market share -- is the surest way to convert apathy to advocacy.
 
ALTON R. WALDON JR.
State Senator, 10th District
Albany, Sept. 3, 1993

HEADLINE: Attorney General Abrams to Quit To Join a Law Firm in Manhattan

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
His hopes of winning a Senate seat dashed last year and his prospects for the governorship apparently stymied, Robert Abrams abruptly announced yesterday that he would resign after 15 years as the Attorney General of New York State to become a partner in a Manhattan law firm at the end of the year.
Mr. Abrams, New York's senior statewide official, its chief law-enforcement officer and a popular figure in state and city Democratic politics for more than 25 years, is the second top state official to resign this year. Comptroller Edward V. Regan quit last spring to head an economics study center at Bard College. 
 Before Mr. Abrams's resignation takes affect on Dec. 31, the State Legislature must select a replacement to fill the remainder of his term, which ends next year.
In a telephone interview last night, Mr. Abrams said he had been "all geared up" to run for re-election next year and "there was no question as to the outcome." But, he said, "I guess our lives are always subject to further reflection."
 
Reflecting on Family
 He said that in relaxing during the Labor Day weekend with his family in Dutchess County and looking over college applications with his 17-year-old daughter, Rachel, he had decided it was time for a change.
He called a law-school classmate, Leonard Boxer, a partner at the Manhattan law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, and agreed to join the firm.
Mr. Abrams has not had a banner 12 months. After winning the Democratic Senate nomination by a single percentage point in a bruising primary against former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro last fall, he lost to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato by two points, despite an overwhelming victory for Bill Clinton in New York. His exploratory efforts to win a senior post in the Clinton Administration did not pan out.
Finally, the likelihood that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will run for re-election next year seemed to put higher office out of reach.
Mr. Abrams's announcement, made in a news release early last evening, took the state's political world by surprise. Just a few weeks ago, he said in an interview that he fully expected to run for re-election next year, and yesterday a media consultant based in Washington said he had had recent discussions about working on the campaign. On Monday Mr. Abrams smiled and marched with other politicians in the Labor Day parade up Fifth Avenue.
In a prepared statement, the 55-year-old Mr. Abrams said he would place particular emphasis on developing Stroock & Stroock's international law practice, including environmental cleanup projects in the Far East and Eastern Europe.
He said he had authorized his staff to make all decisions on any matter that might involve the law firm while he remains Attorney General, and not to bring the matters to his attention.
In the interview, Mr. Abrams said his older daughter's situation raised questions about his family life with his wife, Diane, and 7-year-old daughter, Becky. "Is the nest going to be empty?" he asked. How much more time is there to spend with our kids?" The Attorney General, whose state salary is $110,000 a year, said his daughters' educational expenses also raised questions "relating to economic security."
Mr. Abrams's departure also opens up new vistas for a host of contenders for his post, which will be filled by the State Legislature. They include the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes; Assemblyman Oliver Koppell of the Bronx; the Rockland County District Attorney, Kenneth Gribetz, and many others.
The winner would have to stand for election in November 1994.
 
Reputation as an Activist
 Presiding over an office with a budget of $72 million and 1,200 employees, Mr. Abrams built a reputation as an activist and consumer advocate, taking on environmental polluters, charity frauds, discrimination in employment agencies and so on. As chief lawyer for the state, he defended the Governor and commissioners against lawsuits, administered the antitrust laws and regulated the conversion of cooperative apartments.
He is now serving his fourth term, having won re-election three times by overwhelming margins and having set a record as the all-time Democratic vote-getter in New York State.
Mr. Cuomo praised Mr. Abrams in a statement last night as "the nation's leading state attorney general for years, a political leader of total integrity, complete commitment and high principle" and said he would be "missed for a long time."
Calm, cautious, genial, his bald head and glasses lending him a professorial air, Mr. Abrams made few enemies in a career that began in the mid-1960's as a State Assemblyman from the Bronx, where he grew up the son of a candy-store owner near Pelham Parkway. His seatmate in Albany was a freshman from Manhattan named David N. Dinkins, with whom he formed a friendship that was sealed in 1989, when Mr. Abrams offered early and strong support for Mr. Dinkins's mayoral candidacy.
He also handled one especially ticklish assignment with aplomb, when Mr. Cuomo directed him in 1988 to investigate the claims of Tawana Brawley, a black teen-ager, that she had been abducted and raped in upstate Dutchess County by a gang of whites. A lengthy grand jury inquiry supervised by Mr. Abrams's office later concluded that she had fabricated her story.
 
Began Race With High Hopes
 Mr. Abrams began his race for the Senate in 1991 with high hopes, anticipating that repeated investigations into Mr. D'Amato's conduct in office would leave him badly weakened. But then the Clarence Thomas-Anita F. Hill hearings galvanized support for female candidates, and Ms. Ferraro, making a comeback from 1984, when she was Walter F. Mondale's Vice-Presidential running mate, swiftly became the front-runner in the polls.
Mr. Abrams, together with City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, sharply questioned Ms. Ferraro's ethics and personal finances, producing the narrowest of victories and leaving her so bitter over what she regarded as anti-Italian slurs that she declined to endorse him against Mr. D'Amato until the eve of the November election.
By then, Mr. Abrams had already made his own missteps, at one point calling Mr. D'Amato a fascist and refusing for several days to apologize. Ultimately, he was both outspent and outmaneuvered by the Republican incumbent at every turn.
Mr. Abrams's friends said the defeat had shaken him, but that he had rebounded strongly this year, traveling upstate 38 times in the last eight months, renting a campaign office, putting out a newsletter to 25,000 contributors and generally rejuvenating himself to run for re-election for a fifth term.
"I have every expectation of making a run for re-election," he said in a midsummer interview. "I'll be ready for any and all comers. If anybody thinks that this last loss by a hair means that I'm going to be a pushover, they've got another guess coming."
He added: "I mean, I'm resilient."

HEADLINE: Study Says Half of Adults in U.S. Lack Reading and Math Abilities

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Nearly half of the nation's 191 million adult citizens are not proficient enough in English to write a letter about a billing error or to calculate the length of a bus trip from a published schedule, according to a four-year Federal study of literacy in America.
The study, released yesterday by the Education Department, presented a bleak statistical portrait of the nation's literacy. 
 The department tested more than 26,000 Americans, in a representative sampling of those above the age of 15, with questions involving practical matters that people face every day, like gleaning information from a newspaper, reading a bus schedule, making out a bank-deposit slip and understanding instructions for prospective jurors.
Like previous studies, this report said nearly 10 percent of Americans say they have difficulty reading and writing: the usual gauge of illiteracy. But it went deeper by assessing how well people understand English and by including questions that require addition and subtraction.
 
Growing Language Barrier
 Insufficient education and a growing number of adults whose first language is not English were important reasons that the scores were so low, according to the study, conducted by the Educational Testing Service, the New Jersey company that administers the Scholastic Aptitude Test for college admissions and other standardized tests.
The study did not draw any conclusions about intelligence; rather, it assessed reading skills needed for the workplace and for civic activities like voting or jury service. Because the test was given only in English, there was no way to gauge whether native foreign-language speakers would have got higher scores in their first language.
In releasing the study, the Education Department called for a comprehensive remedy, involving businesses, schools and community groups. Just as the Education Department of the Reagan Administration used "A Nation at Risk," a 1983 study of the shortcomings of education in America, as a manifesto for change in the public schools, the Education Department under President Clinton hopes the 150-page study will become a similar impetus. The department, in collaboration with the Labor Department, has begun a study on improving job skills and literacy in the workplace.
"The results are very sobering and they indicate the need for a much greater effort than has been expended until now," said Madeleine M. Kunin, Deputy Secretary of Education, whose office oversees the research and statistical arm of the department. "The overall education level of Americans has increased in terms of schooling and even in fundamental literacy. But the demands of the workplace simultaneously have vastly increased. We simply are not keeping pace with the kinds of skills required in today's economy."
The study found that older people tended to have lower test scores and attributed this trend to the fact that they generally had less education than younger people.
 
New Efforts Expected
 At a minimum, the findings are certain to prompt renewed efforts to bolster adult education and literacy programs across the country, which typically are run by community colleges, churches or service organizations in a fragmented way, reaching only a small fraction of adults who have trouble reading. Until now, corporations have taken the lead in literacy programs through worker retraining programs.
"This is a national problem," Ms. Kunin said. 'We cannot be competitive as a nation or improve the standard of living unless we are able to improve the literacy rate."
Perhaps not surprisingly, the study found that participants with higher incomes did better on the test. Those with the lowest scores earned median weekly salaries of $230 to $245; those with the highest scores had median incomes of $620 to $680.
Businesses estimate they lose $25 billion to $30 billion a year nationwide in lost productivity, errors and accidents attributable to poor literacy. "We have estimated that only about 25 percent of the adult population is highly literate," said Brenda Bell, vice president of marketing for the National Alliance of Business, a group of 3,000 businesses engaged in training and education issues.
A growing number of companies, she said, have put together programs with local community colleges in which professors come to offices and factories to help workers with a variety of skills from basic tasks to more complicated computer skills.
 
Businesses Try to Help
 But corporate efforts to date, as well as those sponsored by local community groups, pale given the size of the problem. "This is clearly disappointing in terms of where we are and where we want to be as a society," said Irwin Kirsch of the Educational Testing Service, who led the project. "It is not a singular problem and points to a complexity of literacy problems and challenges we face as a nation as we move into the next century."
The test takers were measured in three different areas of literacy: reading comprehension, filling out documents and answering questions that require simple arithmetic. The questions on the 50-minute test were weighted for difficulty. Five levels of proficiency were established.
The test results indicate that 40 million to 44 million Americans perform at the lowest level: unable to to calculate the total of a purchase, determine the difference in price between two items, locate a particular intersection on a street map and enter background information on a simple form. It also indicates that an 40 million perform at the second-lowest level: unable to answer a specific question about facts in a newspaper article or write a paragraph summarizing information on a chart about schools. According to the test results, 61 million American function with middle-level skills, 11 million function at the next level and up to 40 million function at the highest literacy level.
In the study, 13,600 people ages 16 years and older were randomly selected and interviewed in the first eight months of last year. An additional 12,000 adults were interviewed from selected states that chose to participate in a separate study comparing their states with the national data and 1,100 inmates from 80 prisons nationwide were interviewed.
As in standardized tests for college admission, white adults posted the best test results with most of them scoring at least in the third of five levels. White adults outscored black and Hispanic adults in all three of the literacy categories. Nearly 60 percent of Hispanic adults who scored in the lowest level were born in other countries. Asians also scored lower than white adults, largely because a majority of Asian adults who scored in the lowest level also were born overseas.
One reason for the lower scores for blacks, the study said, was that they were more likely to attend public schools that were poorer than those attended by whites.
Mr. Kirsch acknowledged that the preponderance of foreign-born adults would depress the overall literacy rate. But he said that regardless of where the adults in survey the were born, they were now residents in the United States and as such represented a fair appraisal of the nation's level of literacy.

HEADLINE: Gore's Efficiency Plan Draws Nods in Congress (for Now)

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
While the Clinton Administration's call to streamline Government produced sympathetic echoes in Republican and Democratic cloakrooms, members of Congress predicted today that their most senior colleagues would still try to pick it apart.
In the glare of the attention paid to the announcement of the White House plan, no one in the House or Senate is daring to defend red tape at the Food Safety and Inspection Service. Congressional supporters of mohair and wool subsidies are lying low. And everyone is praising the Administration's objective of quickening Internal Revenue Service refunds. 
 Besides, much of the plan can be carried out by executive orders without Congressional approval, legislative leaders are quick to point out. As many as 70 percent of the proposals offered by Vice President Al Gore on Tuesday do not require Congressional action. They include a plan to review Federal regulations with the goal of slashing them in half, and a recommendation to streamline procurement by buying more supplies from retail stores.
But as the individual proposals take shape, Congressional enthusiasm is likely to cool, especially when it comes to items like consolidating or closing more than a thousand Agriculture Department field offices, dozens of local bureaus of the Housing and Urban Development Department and the Army Corps of Engineers, and offices of other agencies as well.
"With every one of these programs you are going to have to knock out benefits for somebody," noted Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat who heads the Government Operations Committee. "That's not going to be easy."
Both Republican and Democratic lawmakers are sure to protect the programs that bring their states jobs or services, which is, after all, part of their job. Western and Midwestern lawmakers, for example, will probably fight an Administration proposal to cut back on subsidies that support rural airport service. And important committee chairmen fiercely protect the programs they enact and oversee.
Democrats are normally more disposed to back the President of their own party, but the Republicans appear most supportive on this issue.
Not only are the Republicans naturally more enthusiastic about reducing the size of Government. But as members of the minority party they also have less patronage than the Democrats and are less reliant on the political good graces of organized labor, which represents many Federal employees and often supports expanding the Government.
With union membership declining in most sectors of the economy other than the Government, Democratic lawmakers with strong labor ties are not expected to support Administration proposals to cut back on thousands of Government jobs or loosen restrictions on using nonunion labor for many public works projects.
Additionally, several of the Administration's proposals fly in the face of the long-held positions of powerful committee chairmen.
For instance, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, has promised to move mountains to stop the line-item veto that is an important part of Administration plan. And Representative William H. Natcher, the Kentucky Democrat who heads the House Appropriations Committee, is expected to deploy his considerable powers to stop an Administration proposal to move the Government from one- to two-year budget cycles because it would reduce his panel's year-to-year authority.
 
Turf Wars Are Tough
 "We all know that the toughest thing in Washington are the turf wars," warned Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Delaware Republican who has praised the Administration's intentions. "No committee likes their authority cut back."
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, said that because committee chairmen would try to save the status quo, success or failure "is going to go based on whether the President will knock heads or not."
Lawmakers, who typically praise the outlines of the Administration's proposals, also typically express reservations about changes in their own pet programs or programs they oversee. Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Crime and Criminal Justice, is a case in point. Though an avid supporter of the Administration, the Brooklyn Democrat said he would oppose the Administration plan to transfer many law enforcement functions of the Drug Enforcement Administration to the F.B.I.
"Fighting drugs needs focus and long-term follow through," Mr. Schumer said, adding that the F.B.I. had not demonstrated sufficient commitment in the war on drugs in the past.
The failure of similar Government consolidation plans in the past at least partly explains why beneath the rave reviews on the surface, both Republican and Democratic members quickly turn skeptical.
Mr. Glenn said it was very important that Mr. Clinton quickly sign executive orders to put his proposals into effect. "Let's not see six months go by," the Ohio Democrat said. "I don't want this to be the 12th such reorganization plan in line since Teddy Roosevelt that is not implemented."
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said if Mr. Clinton actually followed through, "it would be like President Nixon going to China."
"The difference," he added, "is President Nixon actually went to China."
Mr. Gramm said that to make the Administration's proposals stick, he would propose an amendment capping Federal employment and guaranteeing a cut of 252,000 Federal jobs by the year 2000.
Representative Scott L. Klug, Republican of Wisconsin, summed up the Congressional mood this way: "There's a scramble by members like lemmings saying they want to cut things. That's good, but that was the climate in 1980 also, and not much happened."

HEADLINE: Clinton Rebuffs Bosnian Leader In Plea for Help

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The President of Bosnia came to the White House today to appeal to President Clinton to set a deadline for the use of force against the Bosnian Serbs if they do not lift their siege of Sarajevo. But Mr. Clinton's answer was essentially that the Bosnian leader should go back to the bargaining table and cut the best deal he can, because Washington is not coming to the rescue, officials said.
Mr. Clinton explained that Washington is willing to use diplomatic and economic sanctions to keep the pressure on the Serbs and Croats to be more conciliatory at the bargaining table, aides said. But Mr. Clinton added that there is simply no support among the Western allies for an armed intervention in Bosnia at this time, and Washington is not inclined to go it alone, officials said.
 
Invokes Congressional Approval
 The Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, reportedly told Mr. Clinton that his big worry is that even if he does return to the peace talks in Geneva and strikes a deal with the Croats and Serbs -- something he was not sure he could sell politically at home -- the Western allies would not come to monitor its provisions and he would be left on his own. 
 Officials said Mr. Clinton said he is still committed "in principle" to contributing American troops to monitor a Bosnian peace settlement, provided that it is a fair, enforceable deal. But Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher also cautioned that such an American commitment would have to be approved by Congress, which would not be easy, officials said.
Before the talks began, Mr. Clinton told reporters that he would seek the approval of Congress before agreeing to let American troops participate in a peacekeeping force for Bosnia -- the first time he has ever made such a vow. Mr. Clinton also stressed that such peacekeeping forces would have to be under NATO command and not United Nations control. Because NATO's top commander is an American general, NATO control would avoid the confusion of command and control that has arisen in Somalia, where American troops are serving under United Nations command, aides said.
"If we can get the Congress to support it, I think we should join in," Mr. Clinton said during an Oval Office picture-taking session with Mr. Izetbegovic (pronounced ih-zett-BEH-go-vitch). "It has to be able to be enforced or guaranteed by a peacekeeping force from NATO, not the United Nations, but NATO."
 
Defining U.S. Policy
 Mr. Clinton's remarks were the most definitive statement of American policy: an inching away from the hopes the Administration may have raised in July when it pressed its NATO allies to agree to use air strikes if the Bosnian Serbs refused to lift the siege of Sarajevo. The allies balked and since then the focus has been on achieving a negotiated settlement to halt the fighting without outside military intervention.
As one senior official said in a briefing for reporters after the Clinton-Izetbegovic talks, "We think now is the best moment for a negotiated solution."
Meanwhile, a tug-of-war appears to have broken out between the Pentagon and the White House over Defense Secretary Les Aspin's planned trip to Sarajevo. The Pentagon announced earlier this week that Mr. Aspin was considering a brief visit to Sarajevo as part of a three-day trip to Europe he is planning for this weekend. Mr. Aspin wanted to get a first-hand assessment of the situation there.
But White House officials said Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, was not informed ahead of time about Mr. Aspin's planned Sarajevo visit and was irate when he read about it in the newspaper. This afternoon, a senior White House official said that there was "no final decision yet" as to whether Mr. Aspin would go to Sarajevo, which could be dangerous, raise the visibility of an issue that is considered a political loser at home and possibly raise unrealistic expectations among the Bosnian Muslims.
A few hours later, a senior Pentagon official said, "it looks like Aspin won't be going to Sarajevo."
 
Keep Balkans on Back Burner
 The White House is not eager to give the fighting in Bosnia a high-profile status at the present time. Both the White House and the State Department treated Mr. Izetbegovic's visit -- which he requested -- in as low a key as possible.
Before going in to see Mr. Clinton, Mr. Izetbevovic met with members of the Congressional Helsinki Commission, which monitors compliance with the 1975 Helskini human rights accords, where he explained what he wants from Washington at this time.
"The United States should put a deadline to the Serbs to remove the artillery around the city," he said. "If they don't do that, then they will have air strikes. We need the support of the U.S."
 
Clinton Rebuffs Plea for Support
 But Mr. Clinton rebuffed such a suggestion, telling reporters: "I believe all that has to be a part of the negotiating process. I don't think that the United States can simply impose an element like that."
While Administration officials would not say so publicly, their attitude toward the Bosnian Muslims is that they should learn a lesson from the Palestinians: strike the best deal they can with their stronger foes at the peace table, because Washington and its allies are not going to commit the military resources to fundamentally change the balance of power.
Although Mr. Clinton said last week that air strikes were still an option he would consider if conditions worsen in Bosnia, the White House is now focused on Mr. Clinton's fall agenda of health care reform, the North American Free Trade Agreement and "reinventing government." Aides say he is not about to get distracted with bombing raids against the Bosnian Serbs.
 
No Consolation for Muslim
 The State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said there was not much "consolation" Washington could offer the Bosnian Muslim leader.
"We can help him understand the nature of the commitments we have made," Mr. McCurry said, "and the nature of the commitments NATO has made and his -- help him understand, you know, our view as it relates to the negotiations in Geneva, which is that they do need to return to the bargaining table and get an agreement."
Asked if he could spell out the commitments the United States had made as far as its willingness to send American troops to enforce a peace agreement in Bosnia, Mr. McCurry said: "I can't. I mean, there's . . . that's a question I think you've seen various senior officials in the Government address from the President on down in recent days, and I don't have anything to add to their commitment."
Mr. McCurry added: "It's not what we're prepared to do, it's what we have done, which is to urge flexibility on the part of the other parties negotiating there. We've actually acted already to, you know, in a sense, assist and improve the positions of the Muslims at the negotiating table itself."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD;
Palestinians Seen in Need Of Billions in Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
However the Palestinians and Israelis solve their diplomatic differences, the success of any peace plan could depend in large measure on whether the Palestinians get billions of dollars of aid from the United States, Europe, Japan and wealthy Arab nations.
Worried that continued poverty could cause explosive political tensions even with a peace accord, the United States is leading an effort to round up pledges of large-scale assistance even before the Israelis and Palestinians complete a deal that would grant limited self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. 
 The Administration's efforts make clear that help for the Palestinians could become the next major aid issue for the wealthy industrial nations, just as assistance to Russia was last year.
 
Need Put at $3 Billion
 A World Bank report that will be released later this month estimates that the occupied territories will need $3 billion over the next eight years to meet basic needs like improving water and health care.
But several Palestinian economists who have seen the report say this amount is inadequate: they argue that an additional $6 billion is needed to build housing and develop Palestinian industry.
"If we don't get this help from the outside, it will be very difficult for our economy to survive the transition period," said Samir Abdullah, an economics professor at An Najah National University in the West Bank and a Palestinian representative in international talks on the region's economic development.
 
Washington Needs Help
 American officials said they planned to provide immediate aid to help put the fledgling Palestinian entity on its feet and longer-term aid to improve basic services for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza.
But these officials said Washington was too hamstrung by budget deficits to provide all the assistance itself.
And aid to the Palestine Liberation Organization, long considered a terrorist organization by Washington, could be an even more ticklish proposition politically than aid to the former Communist nations. Congressional approval of such aid is far from assured.
Oil-producing Arab nations like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait might not rush to aid the Palestinians because they have their own financial problems and are angry at the P.L.O. for backing Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.
State Department officials said Secretary of State Warren Christopher had conferred with Japan, several European nations and the wealthy Arab oil producers about providing aid. One official said there had been "positive responses, including some from the Nordic countries."
Administration officials say they are not ready to estimate how much the United States would contribute, adding that they first want to discuss this sensitive subject with leading members of Congress.
The countries involved in the Middle East peace talks asked the World Bank to prepare a study of the economic needs of the occupied territories, which are plagued by high unemployment, poor roads and a shortage of water, arable land and other natural resources. Per capita income in the territories is just $1,350 a year, one-eighth the level in Israel.
As was the case with aid to the former Soviet Union, the Clinton Administration hopes that much of the Palestinian aid will come from the World Bank and other international financial institutions.
 
Obstacles to Lending
 But World Bank officials say they face several obstacles to lending to the Palestinians. The bank lends only to members, and the occupied territories do not belong to the World Bank. In addition, the bank wants sovereign governments to guarantee its loans, and the peace accord does not envision a sovereign Palestinian entity administering the Gaza Strip and Jericho, the areas to which Israel has agreed to grant self-rule.
Palestinian economists said they thought that if the $3 billion proposed by the World Bank starts flowing, it would go not just to Gaza and Jericho, but also to all of the West Bank with an eye to minimizing tensions.
The 600-page World Bank report states that under self-rule, the West Bank and Gaza would need $1.3 billion in the first three years, and $1.65 billion in the subsequent five years to establish satisfactory basic services. These include water, schools, health care, sewers, roads and electricity.
"We badly need this amount because we have a very poor infrastructure," said Samir Hazboun, chairman of the economics department at Bir Zeit University in the West Bank. He estimated that the territories need an additional $3 billion to help build more than 50,000 housing units, and another $3 billion to spur economic development.
"Unless the economic situation in the Gaza Strip is raised significantly, you will have a lot of radicalization and instability there which might endanger the whole peace process," said Ephraim Kleiman, an economics professor at Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
Besides the need for money, other concerns were raised in a separate report prepared by 34 Israeli, Jordanian and Palestinian economists along with 7 American economists. They said foreign aid might not be effective unless an efficient government is developed in the West Bank and Gaza, free trade is permitted throughout the region and the current strict regulations on Palestinian businesses are reduced.
"The world wants to be nice and supportive, but a lot has to be done before aid starts pouring in," said Leonard J. Hausman, a Harvard economist who was director of the report, which was sponsored by the Kennedy School of Government's Middle East Institute.
In addition to the worries, economists also pointed to gains the peace agreement would produce for the economies of Israel and the occupied territories. Reduced tensions would no doubt encourage new investment, they said. The Palestinians would also benefit from greater access to the Israeli market, while Israel should gain because the Arab boycott might slowly be ended.

HEADLINE: U.S. Businesses Eager For South Africa Trade

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 8

 BODY:
After the negotiators sealed their deal on Tuesday night on South Africa's transition to democracy, the euphoria spread quickly from the political conference room at the World Trade Center to a neighboring hall where 200 American companies have come to appraise the new African Klondike.
For the participants in what was billed as the continent's largest American trade show ever, peddlers of trucks and shampoos, software and body armor, gaskets and encyclopedias, pinball machines and electric wheelchairs, it was a giddy confluence of political and economic opportunity. 
 The Government's agreement to share power with its rivals in the months leading up to an election means that the African National Congress will soon call for the end of the economic sanctions deployed against apartheid.
 
Mandela Seeks Investment
 Nelson Mandela, who spent an hour on Tuesday hobnobbing with the American prospectors and pleading for investment, predicted today that the call to reopen trading would come in "a matter of weeks."
But while the end of sanctions will bring an immeasurable psychological lift to a country that has been the world's polecat, few here expect the economic payoff to match the euphoria.
"There may well be an anticipation that the lifting of sanctions will see the whole of the Fortune 500 here within weeks, and prosperity flowing six weeks later," warned J. Michael Judin, a trade lawyer and director of the South African American Chamber of Commerce. "Clearly we know in the real world that's not true."
 
Reminders of Violence
 To begin with, less adventuresome business people are deterred by the violent image of a country where every political advance seems to be followed by a slaughter, like the machine-gun massacre of bystanders waiting at a black taxi depot east of Johannesburg today.
David Altman, director of the Made in USA Expo here, said half a dozen exhibitors dropped out after a white American Fulbright scholar was slain by a black mob outside of Cape Town two weeks ago.
Then there is lingering wariness of Mr. Mandela's professed faith in free markets and private property, owing in part to his alliance with the South African Communist Party.
And most American companies, after nearly a decade of sanctions, know little about South Africa. Mr. Judin said some come in expecting easy pickings, only to encounter stiff competition from local producers.
"I think a lot of them arrived here thinking we were still on horseback, and they would just sell things by the container load," Mr. Judin said.
 
A Powerful Lure
 Despite these misgivings, Mr. Altman and others here said South Africa will prove irresistible to many Americans once the sanctions are lifted.
"These people are here today for only one reason," he said. "This is a $20 billion market for them, and their factories in the United States are not running to full capacity."
Most of those interviewed said they see South Africa, with its efficient airports and ports and functional phones, as the well-appointed springboard into the subcontinent.
"For us as a black company, this could be our biggest market outside the United States," said Reginald Maynor, sales manager for Chicago-based Luster Products Inc., which sells black hair care products. He said his company expects to begin producing in South Africa for distribution to countries south of the Sahara.
Dozens of American companies have already entered South Africa with tacit approval from the African National Congress, and scores more never left.
 
Sanctions a Barrier
 But for many major companies sanctions against companies that trade with South Africa -- imbedded in more than 100 state and local statutes and countless corporate stockholder resolutions -- remain a formidable barriers.
Mr. Altman said despite his exhibit's blessing from the African National Congress and the United States Government, most of the corporate giants he approached turned him down rather than risk a consumer or shareholder protest.
Some, like Polaroid, told him even the congress's formal call for the lifting of sanctions will not be enough. They will wait for the restrictions to be repealed, which will take months or years.
"Polaroid sells drivers' licenses to all these different states, and their drivers' license business is bigger than their potential business in South Africa," he said. "So they weren't prepared to make any move to jeopardize it."
 
Little Hope for Jobless
 So far the companies venturing into South Africa are out to sell, not manufacture, so they will have little effect on an unemployment rate estimated at nearly 50 percent.
"We've got to educate, clothe and house," Mr. Judin said. "As welcome as the distributors are, and the franchisers, we do need the manufacturers."
Still, Mr. Judin said, South Africa's readmission to the international business world will increase the confidence of local business, increasing their willingness to invest, and possibly bolstering the country's weak currency.
And the euphoria, he added, however ephemeral, is enjoyable.
"It's only now that we're being accepted back as part of the world that one really appreciates what it was like to be the pariah," he said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
The Road Show, Part II: Reinventing Bill and Al

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Va., Sept. 8

 BODY:
The fellow on the left in the navy suit was the Vice President, the keeper of all the cryptic details.
The one on the right was the President; his role was to empathize, to talk about trust and to radiate sincerity while discussing belief in Government. 
 Welcome to the Bill and Al Show, Part II, this time on the road to "reinvent" Government.
Bill Clinton and Al Gore, who discovered their political strength as a sales team during last year's Presidential campaign, plan to take their road show around the country this week to California, Ohio and Texas, sharing stories of overpriced file folders and the dedicated Federal employees who would like to spend less.
They began the cross-country trip today at a cavernous Government warehouse that distributes toilet paper, paper clips and yellow legal pads to the Supreme Court, Congress and most agencies of the executive branch. Striding into camera range side by side, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore seemed almost jaunty about their task.
 
Pitching Trust to Skeptics
 Mr. Gore, who has spent six months thinking about overpriced ashtrays and voluminous civil service regulations, has been stumping the television news and talk-show circuits, happily lecturing on the stimulating topic of Government procurement. In one 24-hour block, he appeared on C-Span, "Today," the "Late Show" with David Letterman, "Donahue," the "MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour" and "Larry King Live."
Mr. Clinton's job is more sober and goes to the core of this effort: countering the lack of trust many Americans have in their Government.
"The central tenet of every democracy in the end is trust," Mr. Clinton told the Federal workers, many of whom had been bused in for the warehouse event. "The profound sense of alienation so many people feel in our country has got to be healed, because we've got to do a lot of things to get America into the 21st century, to restore a sense of opportunity, to be able to create jobs and to be able to support incomes again that justify the hard work people do."
Mr. Clinton said reorienting Government was about establishing a partnership between leaders and the people who elect them. "And a partnership, whether it's marriage, a business, a government-private partnership, requires trust," he said.
 
'Wrenching Encounter'
 But no matter how high-minded the President's words, the discussion always comes back to the somewhat clunky subject of what things cost and how those costs affect government reinvention.
Today the President spoke of "a particularly wrenching encounter" he had with a military worker in Alameda, Calif., when he toured an air station slated to be closed.
Was the discussion about impending unemployment? Lapsing health care benefits? Hardly. The two men talked about the waste in paying $4,500 for a $2,500 computer.
Mr. Gore mostly left the high-minded appeals to the President and focused on presenting his latest detailed examples of Government waste.
There was the "designer bug spray" ordered to Federal specifications, the computer diskettes that cost $1.38 more than the discount store price and the bottles of aspirin that cost more because of paperwork.
 
2 Shows, 1 Script
 "There are 142,000 people who work full-time just complying with all of these requirements and regulations and red tape," he said. "No wonder we need aspirin."
The Vice President did it again an hour later when Republican and Democratic leaders of the House and Senate arrived at the White House for their weekly meeting with the President. There, lined up on the table in the Cabinet room were the bug spray, the diskettes and the aspirin. With little prodding and to the bemusement of his former Congressional colleagues, Mr. Gore launched into virtually the same speech.
When reporters asked about free trade and health care, not procurement and personnel regulations, Mr. Gore was not crazy about the change of subject and seized the President's prerogative.
"Thank you," he said repeatedly, effectively ending the exchange.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Delay Effort for Trade Pact

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton's plans to make a personal sales pitch on behalf of the troubled North American Free Trade Agreement have been delayed until late this fall as Mr. Clinton prepares for the fight over health care that his advisers have judged to be more critical to his longterm political health.
The trade agreement has accumulated an unenviable list of enemies in the labor and environmental movements and among Democratic leaders in Congress and the supporters of Ross Perot and Ralph Nader. 
 So instead of raising the fight on behalf of Nafta to the same fever pitch of publicity that he has reserved for issues like his economic package, his plan to streamline government and health care, Mr. Clinton is taking a quieter approach.
 
Timing and Votes
 And Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, said in an interview that political reality may force the Administration to stretch beyond a Jan. 1 target date for putting the agreement into effect.
"Timing is one thing," he said in an interview. "Having the votes is another. They may or may not have any effect on each other."
Mr. Kantor said he was not concerned that the trade pact would suffer because of the other initiatives on Mr. Clinton's plate. All will complement each other, he said.
But this approach could make it harder for the White House to sway skeptical Democrats on Capitol Hill. Without the support of these reluctant lawmakers, like Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the prospects for passage of the agreement would fade.
White House aides said that the President remained committed to Nafta but that he was more likely to stake his personal political capital to the issue later this year, after the health-care reforms had been introduced.
 
'Good News and Bad News'
 But the President's allies in Congress who support the trade pact have been sending up unmistakable signals asking the White House for help.
"I'm here to tell you that there's good news and bad news," Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican who supports the agreement, said today. "The good news is that we've advanced the ball to the 5-yard line. The bad news is that it's our 5-yard line, not their 5-yard line."
Mr. Clinton is scheduled to spend Thursday, Friday and Saturday traveling to Ohio, California and Texas on behalf of Vice President Gore's proposals to streamline government. And Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, have invited Mr. Clinton to address a joint session of Congress on Sept. 22 regarding health care.
But for the free trade agreement, the President has scheduled only a single event, a Rose Garden ceremony at which he will sign related pacts on labor and the environment. Aides have said the event will feature Lee Iacocca, the Chrysler consultant and former chairman, as the latest Administration spokesman for the agreement, but it is clear that Mr. Clinton himself will have other things on his mind for the immediate future.
"Nafta is a process that will come to a head in November or December," said Stan Greenberg, the President's pollster. "I assure you you'll see the President join that issue when it's appropriate."
Other political advisers warned against reading too much into the President's decision to travel the country on behalf of issues other than the pact.
"I don't know if Nafta is a traveling kind of a thing, you know?" said James Carville, a political consultant.
 
Under Fire From Democrats
 Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said today that the peripatetic President's decision to soft-pedal the politicking for Nafta next week should not be construed as any weakening in his support for the trade agreement, which has drawn fire from Democrats in Congress and labor groups.
"We don't have exactly the same strategy for every issue," she said.
But several of the President's advisers have offered little more than a lukewarm and pro forma statement of continued support for the agreement, which threatens to alienate Mr. Clinton from some of his most vital supporters just when he needs all the backing he can get to win passage of a critical and wide-ranging plan for health-care reform.
And privately, these same advisers tacitly concede that they would be happy to see the trade pact languish on a back burner if it meant that health care could proceed unimpeded.
"You can love all your children the same, but some just require more attention than others," said Mr. Carville, who predicted that both measures would pass.
 
Devoting Time to Mideast
 In addition to working on health care, Mr. Clinton is expected to spend some of his time next week staking out a place for himself in the emerging Middle East peace process. Carrying the fight for the trade accord will be left to members of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet, who are scheduled to testify at Congressional hearings next week.
One of those officials, Mickey Kantor, the trade representative, said that all uphill battles are not necessarily bad.
"When you're on the 5-yard line, you have a lot of room to maneuver, and that's exactly what we expect to do," Mr. Kantor said at a Capitol Hill news conference with supporters of the trade agreement today.
And Bill Frenzel, the former Republican Congressman who is now helping lead the Nafta lobbying effort for the Administration, also acknowledged the extensive speculation that has begun about the depth of the President's commitment to the trade issue.
"I realize there has been some discussion up till now, partly because the President had his hands full of budget for a good portion of the first part of his term, but that's behind, and Nafta is out front and center, and it's going to be a strong campaign," he said. "The President is going to push it."
But it is clear the push will not be an explicit one coming from the White House. Mr. Iacocca's arrival is expected to counteract some of the opposition mounted by the plain-spoken Mr. Perot, who has taken his new anti-Nafta book to the talk-show circuit.
And, in the end, Mr. Clinton and his advisers are convinced that health care will do more for the Administration than involving the President in a divisive and potentially bruising fight over the trade pact.
"There has to be a special connection between the President and the public if he is going to venture down this course," said Stan Greenberg, the poll taker. "It's different than Nafta, which is a trade agreement that almost half the public has never heard of."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Finding a saner way to regulate health and safety risks.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
STEPHEN BREYER'S 15 minutes of fame may appear to have ended with the choice of Ruth Bader Ginsberg for the Supreme Court. But in Washington, Mr. Breyer, the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, will long be remembered as the legal adviser to the Senate Judiciary Committee who converted suspicious liberals to the cause of airline deregulation. And now Judge Breyer is back in the bully pulpit, this time attempting to bring sweet reason to the overwrought world of health and safety regulation.
His new book, "Breaking the Vicious Circle" (Harvard University Press), may not convince those who have dedicated their careers to stamping out risks ranging from aflatoxins to X-rays. But this lucid, nontechnical essay on risk regulation will intrigue pragmatists in search of a bigger bang for a regulator's buck. 
 "The notion of tying shifts in resources to a specific commitment to saving more lives is brilliant," said Alfred Kahn, a former Carter Administration official and specialist in industrial organization and airline deregulation.
Health and safety regulation costs Americans about $120 billion a year, and there is good reason to believe that the figure is rising rapidly. Is there anything wrong with that?
Maybe not. A rich country can afford the luxury of investing heavily in reducing risk. But there is a near consensus among scientists that the spending priorities, public and private, are grotesquely distorted.
Judge Breyer notes, for example, that panic over asbestos has led to a cleanup effort costing an estimated $250 million per life saved -- and may actually kill dozens of asbestos-removal workers.
Or consider abandoned toxic waste sites. Most, it is widely agreed, pose little threat as long as people do not build day-care centers or graze cows on them. Yet the bill for restoring the sites to pristine condition may exceed $100 billion. Meanwhile, a host of cost-effective health measures, everything from requiring home smoke alarms to subsidizing early cancer detection, are anemically financed.
Like others, Judge Breyer links this failure to a reinforcing circle of irrationality. The public is ill informed, easy prey to the disaster of the month. Congress usually reacts to public opinion with legislation that leaves little room for adjusting priorities within limited budgets or balancing costs against benefits. Regulators, for their part, are locked into a perpetual better-safe-than-sorry mode, further distorting perspectives.
The standard prescription (bromide) for saner risk regulation is a more knowledgeable public. But Judge Breyer is pessimistic about the prospects for making common sense of technology. "To speak of the need for improved communication," he concludes, "is to call spirits from the vasty deep. One can call them, but will they come?"
His alternative: regulators with greater flexibility and credibility. Judge Breyer reckons that most people would prefer lower levels of risk at current levels of expenditure. He thus suggests the creation of a super-regulator, an agency staffed with career civil servants with a mandate to transfer funds from one program to another, if and only if the transfer would save lives and prevent illness.
The idea, he suggests, would be to start small -- say, with an interagency committee able to throttle back stringent toxic waste standards and apply every dollar saved to reducing identified health risks to children. Once the regulators had earned the public's trust, their mission could be expanded.
Judge Breyer's proposal is a lightning rod for criticism. One charge -- that the delegation of authority would be undemocratic -- hardly seems relevant in a nation that already assigns bureaucrats the job of deciding how many rodent hairs are permitted in a box of brownie mix. But other criticisms have more substance.
Lester Lave of Carnegie-Mellon University believes Judge Breyer concedes too much by implicitly accepting the idea that the current reach and total expenditures on health and safety regulation are reasonable. Most of the risk of premature death, he points out, now comes from individual habits like poor diet and smoking, not environmental hazards controllable by government.
Robert Hahn of the American Enterprise Institute worries that the mandate to save lives fudges critical questions. Should regulators have the power to shift funds from, say, air pollution standards that reduce asthma deaths to preschool education that makes children less likely to murder each other as teen-agers? Should blood-pressure-screening dollars that save 10 poor black males be reshuffled to save 30 middle-class women from breast cancer? "Where and how," he asks, "do you draw the lines?"
Almost everyone agrees, though, that Judge Breyer is on to something. Risks linked to technology, particularly those involving life and death, are too complicated to be analyzed by professional politicians or electronic town meetings. And if we do not become cleverer about the process of delegating decisions, the economy (and thus the society) will choke on public distrust.

HEADLINE: Expansion Plan for Tennis Center in Queens Wins Approval From Council Committee

BYLINE: By LARRY OLMSTEAD

 BODY:
Expansion of the National Tennis Center, the site of the United States Open tennis tournament, was approved yesterday by a City Council committee, all but insuring an official go-ahead for the $172 million project.
The Council's Land Use Committee voted 10-3 in favor of the proposal, which will be considered by the full City Council on Sept. 23. If approved, the United States Tennis Association could begin construction in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park as early as next spring, tennis officials said. 
 The vote came after neighborhood opponents won concessions on parking and the possibility of further funding for youth programs.
"This is the best deal of its kind between a city and a sporting event anywhere in the country, generating approximately $130 million into our economy every year," Mayor David N. Dinkins said in a statement. "I appreciate the strong support of the Land Use Committee."
Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone of Queens, who had kept a low profile during the debate, yesterday called it "a very, very good deal for the city."
 
A Triumph for Mayor
 The committee vote was a victory for the Mayor, who ran into opposition over a proposal that administration officials had expected would win wide support because of its apparent benefits for the city.
Administration officials were enthusiastic over the proposal because it would guarantee that the U.S.T.A. would keep the prestigious tournament in the city for at least 25 years. If the U.S.T.A. exercised a series of lease options, the agreement could run as long as 99 years.
The tennis association also agreed to finance the expansion, and to continue into maintain and operate the center, even though the facility is owned by the city.
 
Neighborhood Objections
 But some neighborhood residents objected to leasing 42 acres of parkland to the U.S.T.A., more than doubling the size of the tennis center. Others criticized the plan as catering to the elite, and took issue with the U.S.T.A.'s insistence that air traffic from La Guardia Airport continue to be diverted away from the center during the Open, even though many Queens residents are forced to put up with noise from planes each day.
The proposal also ran into complaints about terms of the lease, which some community activists and Council members called a sweetheart deal favoring the tennis association.
In giving its approval yesterday, the committee adopted several modifications intended to resolve some of the objections.
 
Compromise on Penalties
 One change would provide 200 free parking spaces for the public when the center is in general use. Another offered a compromise on a provision penalizing the city up to $325,000 annually if there are excessive flyovers from La Guardia Airport during the Open.
Under the compromise, the city could still lose up to $325,000 a year if the flyover provision is violated. But for the first five years of the lease, 25 percent of that penalty would be diverted to youth recreation programs, and 10 percent thereafter.
The flyover penalty would be triggered only after several violations of a provision that bans more than six flights during any hour of Open play, or 18 in a day. The rule exempts flyovers necessary for safety.
The Federal Aviation Administration has diverted planes during the Open since 1990, and has agreed to do so indefinitely. But the U.S.T.A. successfully bargained for language in the lease that requires the city to continue to lobby the F.A.A. to maintain the diversions, saying top players would skip the Open if they had to contend with aircraft noise.
Mr. Vallone said the modifications, which still must be reviewed by the City Planning Commission, should sweeten the deal for community residents and "has resulted in a better agreement with the U.S.T.A."
Opposing the proposal in the committee vote were two Queens Council members, Michael J. Abel and Walter L. McCaffrey of Woodside, and Thomas K. Duane of Manhattan.
Mr. McCaffrey, who offered a series of amendments to the proposal that were voted down by the Land Use Committee, said: "There is much that is wanting. The City of New York could have done much better in negotiating the provisions of this lease."
His amendments would have eliminated the flyover penalties, raised the base rent from $400,000 to $500,000 and changed the lease to guarantee the U.S.T.A., not the city, would pay for any cost overruns on construction of the new center. The tennis association gave its assurances it would be responsible for overruns in any case.
 
'Part of the Community'
 David Markin, past president of the U.S.T.A., who negotiated the deal, said the controversy had been good for the association in making it examine what some call its elitist image. It also will look at the issues of ticket price and availability, Mr. Markin said. Outreach programs would be increased. "We want to be part of the community," he said.
The expansion plan calls for construction of a new 23,500-seat stadium at the tennis center and renovation and scaling down the size of the current stadium and grandstand.
The tennis courts would increase from 39 to 47. Eleven courts would be available to city tennis permit holders to use free on a reservation basis; the rest, as now, would be rented to the public at below-market rates.
The U.S.T.A. would have exclusive use of the center for up to 60 days each year, including the two-week period during the Open.
Carl Weisbrod, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the city expected to gain $1 million each year from the U.S.T.A. in rent and the city's share of tennis revenues, and $3 million in taxes.
The tennis association also is contributing $8 million to a fund that will finance improvements in Flushing Meadow-Corona Park. The Open now generates about $112 million a year in economic activity for the city, That, Mr. Weisbrod said, will jump to $130 million with the construction.
