HEADLINE: A Steel Town's Rescue Mission

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

DATELINE: MANSFIELD, Ohio

 BODY:
In this smokestack city halfway between Cleveland and Columbus, a group of business people and merchants give a weekly bagpipe concert in a downtown parking lot at dusk. Fritz's, the local hangout, lets diners pay for their meals on the honor system.
And out-of-towners who park illegally find "parking tickets" on their windshields with a cartoon of a smiling meter and the message, "This one's on us!" 
 But the biggest thing that is "on us" for civic-minded Mansfield right now is the local steel mill, a unit of Armco Inc. The fight to save the mill -- and 1,100 high-paying jobs in this town of 50,000 people -- united Mansfield in a long-shot battle, which it won when the Armco board agreed late last month to keep the arthritic mill alive.
The mill's new lease on life is all the more remarkable in view of American industry's fervor to grow lean and competitive by laying off workers by the thousands and jettisoning obsolete plants.
Mansfield, too, has suffered its share of corporate cutbacks. In recent years, the city has lost a Westinghouse appliance factory, the world headquarters of Tappan and a Peabody Barnes pump facility, to name a few.
Each departure swept smaller businesses along with it. A few months ago the H. L. Reed & Company department store closed after 129 years, and the Mansfield airport no longer receives passenger flights. Money magazine's September issue places Mansfield fourth from the bottom in its annual survey of 300 places to live.
Mayor Lydia J. Reid, a 55-year-old grandmother who was the finance director until four months ago, is fighting to halt the slide. Local politicians, community leaders and Armco executives said they had no choice but to fight for the old mill, a plant that progress and competition long ago transformed into a relic, because they cannot afford to build a more advanced plant from scratch.
Ms. Reid twisted arms until the city and county each agreed to lend $500,000 to save the mill, then offered to reduce water and sewer rates and waive some taxes for 10 years.
The state made nearly $15 million in low-interest loans available -- roughly $10,000 per job. Local electric, telephone and gas providers promised the company a break on rates, and the electric company, Ohio Edison, cobbled together another $8 million in loans.
The United Steelworkers of America union agreed to concessions in June under a new labor contract that gives management more flexibility to assign work and gradually reduce employment by 25 percent. That and the collective contributions had the desired effect. Armco decided to invest $100 million on a continuous caster that may make the mill viable.
 
Old-Fashioned Methods
 Empire-Detroit, as the Mansfield mill is known, is one of the few steel plants in the country that still makes steel in old-fashioned, heat-resistant brick-lined molds. It melts down scrap metal in huge furnaces, ladles the concoction into ingot-shaped molds, cools the ingots, reheats them to clean them and works the ingots into flat sheets that are rolled into the thin coils customers prefer.
Newer mills, in contrast, use continuous casting to eliminate many costly steps. Often called mini-mills, they manipulate the molten steel so it travels directly from the furnace to the rolling mills.
No one can be sure that the city's frantic efforts will protect Empire-Detroit from its more nimble rivals forever. Armco is "throwing good money after bad," said Michael Cygler, a senior sales engineer with SMS Concast, an equipment supplier.
 
A Big Taxpayer
 But Mayor Reid is not about to let the naysayers derail her mission. Empire-Detroit contributes $900,000 a year in income taxes -- $1 of every $16 the city collects -- and nearly $10 million in state and county taxes.
Further, it spends $40 million on electricity and gas each year, $96 million on other operating expenses and $9 million on health care. Since many of the plant's employees live in Mansfield, much of the company's $57 million payroll is recycled back into the local economy.
Aware of the stakes, the residents have rallied around the rescue mission. "They've got to do something to keep this town above water," said Budd Meyer, a 30-year-old vending machine repairman whose wife, Shelley, earns more than him by working at the plant.
A few seats away at Fritz's, Danny Eichler, the owner of a small upholstery business, chimes in with his support. "The bigger businesses employ more people, so you've got to give them more slack," he said.
Cindy M. DeVore, a single mother who used to assemble washers and dryers at the Westinghouse factory, is another fan of the plan to save the mill. She makes good money as a waitress, but she never knows what it will be from week to week. She said she feared that if Empire-Detroit shut down, the uncertainty would get worse. "People lose their jobs; they don't spend money," she said.
 
A Community Makeover
 Named after Jared Mansfield, a surveyor who etched its boundaries into the hills of north-central Ohio, Mansfield has faced the knife before.
When the job drain began in 1990, the town flaunted everything it had. To build traffic in the central business district, it tore down some taverns and spent nearly $3 million on a hand-carved carousel that attracts 300 riders a day.
It also successfully bid on a new state penitentiary and convinced three Hollywood filmmakers to use the old prison in movies.
That connection to fame gave Mayor Reid unlikely ammunition in her fight to save Empire-Detroit as she horse-traded, wheedled and bartered for any possible edge.
Take the state controlling board, which must approve the state's $15 million loan to Empire-Detroit. Over spaghetti dinners at Mama's Little Touch of Italy on Park Avenue, the town's main street, Edward T. Meehan, the president of the Richland County economic development arm, told Ms. Reid that one of the members would like a favor: Could she arrange for his kids to visit the set of a prison movie?
"How'd they like to ride horses with Morgan Freeman?" she asked, recalling that one of the movies being shot in Mansfield stars the actor. "Maybe they'll give us more."
 
A Succession of Owners
 The mill, which started about the turn of the century and has had a succession of owners, has seen potential suitors give its antiquated machinery the once-over and leave shaking their heads.
Its president, Charles G. Kennedy, said he was advised to reject the sales manager's job in 1981. His friends warned him that the plant lacked a continuous caster, which was fast becoming a vital part of any modern steel plant, and would not survive. He accepted the job, which paid $75,000 a year, but kept his house in Pittsburgh to be safe.
He managed to keep the mill afloat and even profitable in the 1980's. He moved to Mansfield and in 1988 became the president of the plant. But as his competitors upgraded their plants and nonunion mini-mills gained ground, the mill's operating costs -- the highest in the industry -- threatened its survival.
"We weren't getting worse," he said. "Everyone else was getting better. The world was passing us by."
 
A Community Effort
 Rather than watch the plant close, he became determined to organize the community to save it. He has coaxed $27 million in equipment financing from vendors who are vying to build the new caster. He has helped the utilities realize the folly of letting one of their largest customers sink.
And he got Gov. George V. Voinovich of Ohio to see that if Empire-Detroit succeeded in grafting a new $100 million caster onto old rolling equipment, other ailing steelmakers could be saved for far less than the $600 million or more it can take to build a new mill.
His biggest sales job was reserved for the union. Some members who were making $50,000 a year with overtime had trouble believing that the plant was desperate.
Others, like Ted Hardy, 58, whose job reducing the size of the ingots would be eliminated by the new caster, doubted that Armco would close the shop and leave its small customers in the lurch.
Younger employees like Steven Norris, 26, have needed less convincing. He said he was grateful to land a job in the plant. At a computer keyboard in a comfortable office, he was recording the temperatures of 15-ton steel ingots immersed in the soaking pits where they are reheated.
That job, too, will vanish the day the caster is installed, and yet he favors the plan. "It's hard to compete without it," he said.
Much of the union's membership eventually came around. "All those mini-mills are nonunion," Mr. Kennedy said. "We have a chance to show that unionized steelworkers can do this as well as nonunion. That's a big ticket for the union."
The Armco board recently approved the caster, which could take 18 months to install. It expects the investment will put the mill, which could lose $25 million in 1993, at least $50 million in the black in 1995.
Leaving in place the Bible that has been in the company's reception area since the day he arrived, Mr. Kennedy calls his attempted bail-out, Project Genesis, because he hopes it will provide everyone who depends on the plant with "a new beginning."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Unilever to Gain Breyers In Kraft Ice Cream Deal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Unilever P.L.C., already the world's largest marketer of ice cream products, has fattened its presence in American markets with an agreement to acquire the ice cream division of Kraft General Foods, the largest maker of ice cream products in the United States.
In the deal, which was announced yesterday, Unilever would acquire the nation's best-selling brand, Breyers, giving the British and Dutch consumer products company a major presence in American grocery store freezers with cartons of ice cream and making it a leading force in the highly competitive $2.2 billion ice cream industry. 
 Unilever would also gain Sealtest and the license to two additional Kraft ice cream brand names, Light n' Lively and Knudsen. Kraft, however, has retained the Breyers and Sealtest names for existing non-ice cream products, like frozen yogurt, as well as its super-premium line of Frusen Gladje ice creams.
 
 
American Acquisitions
 The acquisition would also continue a strategy by Unilever to expand its involvement in American ice cream through acquisitions. In 1989, Unilever bought Gold Bond Ice Cream Inc. of Green Bay, Wis., makers of an assortment of novelty ice cream products. In January, Unilever bought the Isaly Klondike Company, makers of Klondike bars, and Popsicle Industries from Empire of Carolina Inc. Unilever has made Good Humor ice cream products in the United States since 1961.
While neither Kraft nor Unilever would disclose the terms of the acquisition, the companies said in a joint statement that Kraft's ice cream division had annual sales "approaching $500 million." In the 52-week period ending July 18, according to Information Resources Inc. of Chicago, sales of Kraft ice creams reached $356.9 million, a 15.6 percent share of the market, eclipsed only by the combined sales of all private label brands, $737.1 million, for a 32.3 percent share.
 Yet even such a level of sales for Kraft might have contributed to a decision by the Philip Morris Companies, Kraft's parent company, to sell the division. The company's market share has declined in recent years. The most recent figures reflect a 2.1 percent drop in sales for Kraft, while the next three companies -- Haagen-Dazs, Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Company and Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. -- have improved at least 13.6 percent each in the same period.
For marketing purposes, ice creams are separated into categories determined primarily by butterfat content: usually, the higher percentage of butterfat, the higher the cost (not to mention calories and cholesterol). Super-premium brands like Haagen-Dazs and Frusen Gladje contain as much as 16 percent butterfat, while premium brands, like Breyers, have 14 to 15 percent. Regular brands like Sealtest have about 12 percent. An economy category, which includes mainly private-label and store brands, has a butterfat content of about 10 percent.
 
 
Market 'More Competitive'
 "At least since last year, Kraft has seemed to be struggling with their brands as the market has gotten much more competitive," said Howard Waxman, the editor of the Ice Cream Reporter, an industry newsletter.
Data compiled by Nielsen Marketing Research for the 52-week period ending June 12 show Breyers as the leading single brand in sales, with $265 million after combined private label sales ($610 million), with Haagen-Dazs in third place ($136 million) and Ben & Jerry's sixth ($105 million). Frusen Gladje was below the top 10, with sales of $2.4 million and a market share of a tenth of 1 percent -- about half its performance for the previous 52-week period.
"Kraft has clearly fumbled the super-premium category," Mr. Waxman said.

HEADLINE: Baptists Raising Their Voices in Song at the Garden

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
In a hallway off the main floor of Madison Square Garden, Angelique Banks Coleman was having a difficult time explaining why music was such an integral part of the nation's black churches and of the 8.5 million-member National Baptist Convention, which is holding its annual meeting this week in New York City.
Mrs. Coleman was certainly not at a loss for words, including biblical phrases about "singing to the Lord" and "making a joyful sound" from the Psalms. 
 But she was repeatedly interrupted by people congratulating her for the concert she had directed on Tuesday evening. A 350-member choir, specially assembled for the Baptist meeting, had filled the Garden with solemn church anthems, a piece from Mendelssohn's "Elijah," traditional spirituals and, increasingly as the evening went on, with foot-stomping, hand-waving Gospel music.
No session of the Baptist gathering, which has brought about 50,000 people to the city, goes without song.
 
28 Musical Offerings
 Yesterday, the convention officially opened with welcoming speeches from Mayor David N. Dinkins, Secretary of Commerce Ron Brown, New York State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and the Rev. Al Sharpton, and talks by Baptist leaders and the Rev. Conrad Raiser, who heads the World Council of Churches in Geneva.
But the day's program was laced with at least 28 musical offerings at Madison Square Garden and at simultaneous meetings of church associations being held at several hotels.
Today's program will feature a similar number, before, after and between such events as a ceremony honoring Mayor Dinkins and Benjamin Hooks, the recently retired president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and a speech by Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois, the first black woman elected to the Senate.
 
'An Earthy Kind of Music'
 There was even a choir to perform last Thursday when the church body's president, the Rev. Theodore Judson Jemison, was presented with a check from local donors to help defray the convention's expenses.
The span of Tuesday evening's concert, stretching from Mendelssohn to the spiritual, "Ezekiel Saw de Wheel," was carefully planned to exhibit a wide range of music and talent to the thousands of church leaders in the Garden.
"We've had an earthy kind of music" in the black church, Mrs. Coleman said, "and we're trying now to educate people so they can incorporate a wide range of music in their services."
"We have lawyers and corporate presidents in our congregations, and we have to cater to their broad tastes," she said, even while keeping alive the heritage of spirituals and Gospel music.
Mrs. Coleman is minister of music at Burke Baptist Church in the Bronx where her husband, the Rev. Norman Coleman, is pastor. Besides directing the choir and singing solos, she was the arranger for a medley that intricately interwove the hymns "Amazing Grace," "Blessed Assurance" and "It Is Well With My Soul" to make a point, she said, of Christians' assurance of resurrection.
 
Months of Rehearsal
 Volunteers for the special choir, who came from New York's five boroughs and as far away as Newburgh in Orange County and Long Island, began rehearsing in March.
They met once a week, then twice and more recently three times weekly. "Ninety-eight percent of them don't read music," Mrs. Coleman said. Mrs. Coleman herself has a degree in music. Derrick James, the minister of music at Grace Baptist Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y., who helped direct the choir and also sang one of his own compositions on Tuesday, has two.
But both musicians said they first started singing in the church as children and knew early that religious music would be their life's work.
The concert on Tuesday featured the same active response from the audience that many black congregations traditionally give to their preachers.
Listeners -- and even choir members -- did not wait until the end of songs to applaud. They clapped and shouted in admiration for a particular note or phrase when soloists pushed their voices to the limit or demonstrated some vocal derring-do.
 
Call and Response
 The exuberant directing of Gregory Hopkins, the music director of Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Manhattan who shared the podium with Mrs. Coleman and with Mr. James, not only sent the music flying from the music stand at one point but also sent the music stand itself flying.
"Our music is enveloped in emotion," Mr. James said, "from all the trials and tribulations of slavery, Jim Crow and economic depression."
The black church's hymns, Mrs. Coleman and Mr. James said, were tightly linked to the church's preaching. Music and preaching shared the same rhythmic style, the call and response of the leader and the congregation and finally, they said, the same theology, not of a nebulous belief, but of a personal tie to Jesus.
"We cease to be Baptists if Jesus is not central and focal," Mrs. Coleman said.
"He's the center of the joy," Mr. James added.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 18.17 Points in 2d Day of Selling

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Growing concerns over the future of corporate profits caused the stock market to plummet yesterday for the second straight day, before it recovered somewhat, easing a wave of anxiety about the end of the bull market of 1993.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down nearly 35 points from its high for the day before being rescued by a 3 P.M. wave of buying. It finally closed at 3,588.93, off 18.17 points for the day, after a drop of 26.83 points on Tuesday. 
 "The market's beginning to understand that lower inflation means lower growth rate and nominal G.D.P., and that in turn will mean a lower growth rate for corporate profits," David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, said.
Because low interest rates are no longer being viewed "as a complete blessing for the stock market," Mr. Shulman said, stocks and bonds have ended a long period in which they moved in direct inverse relation to each other. He predicted that the market's movements would continue to reflect worries about earnings.
 
'The Market Is Overreacting'
 The market's performance seems to reflect a belief among some investors that the economic recovery is beginning to wane, said Robert Walberg, senior equity strategist with MMS Equity Market Analysis.
"It's our impression now that the market is overreacting, and using recent economic reports as an excuse to take profits after having been through a fairly strong rally," he said. "As we look at the third and fourth quarters, the numbers look pretty good. but there's been a lot of anxiety over the last several months or so of weak numbers."
The Nasdaq suffered what Mr. Shulman described as "real carnage," yesterday with the composite index falling 8.62 points, to 730.73, while the American Stock Exchange composite index dropped 5.20 points, to 451.08. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 1.87 points to 456.65. Trading volume was 283.1 million shares, up from 229.5 million on Tuesday.
Mr. Shulman said skittishness about the economy was worsened by two big waves of futures selling that drove down the cash market, one around 11:30 A.M. and another around 12:30 P.M., before the buying wave began late in the day.
Mr. Walberg said the market had been due for "at least a modest correction," and added: "We've gone approximately 200 days without even as much as a 4 percent correction in the market, which is abnormally long. As far as length of rallies is concerned, this ranks up with one of the longest."
 
Selloff in Health Care
 Health care stocks led the fall. Baxter International, the world's largest supplier of medical products, said after trading ended Tuesday that the Government's new health care plan would hurt third-quarter earnings, and the company said it would carry out a restructuring, layoffs and a hiring freeze. Baxter closed at 23 a share, off 3 3/8.
Health maintenance organizations also dropped, following news that the Clinton Administration would trim Medicare and Medicaid spending to help finance its health care plan. Oxford Health Plans plunged 6 3/4 a share, to 63 3/4; United Healthcare dropped 3 3/4, to 56 1/2; U.S. Healthcare slid 2, to 44, and FHP International fell 2 3/4, to 21 1/2. Pacificare Health Systems, a California H.M.O., which said it had received a rate increase for Medicare patients that was lower than expected, saw its class B stock fall 5 1/2 a share, to 29 1/2.
Another group under pressure was the telecommunications equipment group, sagging under profit taking. DSC Communications, fell 2 1/8 a share, to 62 1/8, while Newbridge Networks, dropped 4 5/8, to 62.
After I.B.M. forecast its 1993 minicomputer revenue would be about the same as in 1992, citing weak European demand, the company's stock fell 1 1/8, to 44 3/8.
Traders said shares of Microchip Technology fell 2 1/4, to 49, on news that the maker of specialty semiconductors plans to sell 1.8 million common shares.
Though second-quarter earnings of 43 cents for Circus Circus Enterprises, the casino company, were higher than the 41 cents a share for the period a year ago, it was below analysts' median forecast of 44 cents. The stock dropped as much as 1 1/4 before closing down 1/8, to 41 5/8.
Shares of Genetic Therapy rose by 2 to close at 17 1/4, after the biotechnology company said it was encouraged by early results of human tests of an anti-tumor treatment.
YPF Sociedad, the Argentine oil company, yesterday received buy recommendations from analysts at Oppenheimer, Paine Webber, and Goldman, Sachs. The company's American depository shares, each respresenting one class D share, rose 7/8, to 23 1/2, in active trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Amid Signs Of Foreign Rate Reductions

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar recaptured some lost ground yesterday amid signs that Japan and Germany would cut interest rates to spur economic growth.
In New York, the dollar rose to 105.50 yen, from 104.23 yen on Tuesday. It also rose to 1.6140 marks from 1.6095 marks. 
 Dealers suspect the Bank of Japan might cut its official discount rate to 2 percent, from 2.5 percent, as part of a plan to stimulate the Japanese economy. They said the central bank's quarterly report on business conditions, known as the "tankan" survey, could spur an easing in Japan's monetary policy if it proves to be disappointing when it comes out tomorrow.
Lower interest rates make a country's currency relatively less attractive to investors.
Speculation has also been growing that the Bundesbank will take advantage of the mark's strength to trim the German discount rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 6.5 percent, at its council meeting today.
There was no reaction to a Federal Reserve banks periodic survey, known as the "beige book," which found that the American economy grew slowly in most parts of the country during the summer, with inflation muted and job growth slight.
"The survey is neutral," Marcos Douer at the Commercial Bank of New York said. "People are happy to wait for the Bundesbank meeting and Friday's Japanese tankan report."
The dollar staged a brief rally after the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., said that he saw no reason to lower American interest rate further at this time and that economic growth in the second half could attain 2.5 percent to 3 percent. But the gains were quickly whittled away.
Edward Cook at NatWest Markets attributed the dollar's modest recovery to dealers' cashing in profits by buying back the dollars they had sold. The dollar lost five pfennigs during last week's decline.
Meanwhile, the British pound rose to $1.5420 in New York, from $1.5369 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Recent Dive in Oil Prices Slows to a Slight Decline

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices ended slightly lower yesterday but pulled out of the steep drop that carried them to three-year lows this week.
Other inflation-conscious commodities contracts also steadied after steep declines on Tuesday, with gold rising slightly. 
 After an up-and-down session, crude oil for delivery in October closed just 4 cents lower at $17.03 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The oil contract has fallen about $1.80, or 10 percent, in the last six trading sessions, including 66 cents on Tuesday.
Traders said oil's long-term trend remained down.
"Yesterday's price action suggests a renewed price downtrend, which will likely be maintained into the Sept. 25 OPEC meeting," said Jim Ritterbusch, an oil industry consultant in Chicago, referring to the quarterly meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
"It should be kept in mind, however, that the possibilities of a successful or cohesive OPEC meeting tend to increase as crude prices decline," he added.
OPEC members may agree to cut their production to bolster sagging oil prices.
Among other energy contracts, October unleaded gasoline recovered 0.11 cent, to 49.05 cents a gallon, while October heating oil dipped 0.01 cent, to 51.12 cents a gallon.
 
Gold Up, Silver Down
Gold managed a slight rebound from Tuesday's wild selling, which pushed the October contract down $14.50 an ounce. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, October gold gained $1.10, to $351.90 an ounce. December gold, the most actively traded futures contract, also gained $1.10, to $353.60 an ounce. But December silver sank 4.3 cents, to $4.257 an ounce.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean and corn prices rebounded ahead of an important crop report estimate by the Agriculture Department scheduled for release late today. The report is expected to show the impact of flooding in the Midwest and unusually cool summer weather.
November soybeans rose 2 cents, to $6.42 1/2 a bushel, while December corn gained 1 1/2 cents, to $2.34 1/2 a bushel.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, hog and pork belly prices turned sharply higher, as commodities funds bought heavily based on chart patterns and other technical factors. October hogs rose 0.9 cent, to 48.775 cents a pound, and February pork bellies jumped 1.65 cent, to 52.775 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Yield Continues to Drop

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell again yesterday as the rally in the long end of the bond market continued. But short-term interest rates moved a little higher.
The yield on the 30-year bond has plunged a quarter of a percentage point in just five trading days and many traders and analysts are still reluctant to say the run is over. 
 In late trading, the price of the 6.25 percent, 30-year bond was up 19/32 of a point. The yield dropped to 5.86 percent, from 5.90 percent Tuesday. This is the lowest level for yields on 30-year issues in 25 years. The Treasury has been regularly issuing 30-year bonds since May 1977.
 
 
10-Year Note
 The yield on the 10-year note was also off sharply, dropping to 5.22 percent, from 5.26 percent, and at its lowest level since 1968. One measure of how far the yield has fallen recently is that on Aug. 19, the yield on the Treasury's 7-year note was 5.22 percent.
The spread between the yield on the Treasury's 2-year note and the yield on the 30-year bond narrowed yesterday to 2.12 percentage points, down from 2.45 percentage points a month ago. This is the lowest spread since October 1991 and indicates that the bond is outperforming the 2-year note.
The prices of shorter-term issues dropped slightly and their yields rose after comments by David W. Mullins Jr., the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. The price of the two-year note was off 1/32 as the yield rose to 3.74 percent, from 3.73 percent Tuesday.
In an interview with Reuters, Mr. Mullins said there was little to gain from a further cut in short-term interest rates.
 
 
'Only Marginal'
 He said the benefits of a reduction in short-term interest rates to help stimulate the economy "seem at best only marginal." The Fed's target for short-term interest rates has been 3 percent since last September.
Despite recent data indicating that the economy may be growing a lot slower than many analysts had forecast, Mr. Mullins said he believed the economy was on a path of moderate growth.
"We don't have a speedboat, but it's as if we have an ocean liner -- the longer it moves at that pace, the less likely it is to falter," he said. He forecast that the economy would grow at a 2.5 percent to 3 percent pace in the second half of this year.
But Fed officials have not proved to be good forecasters recently. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, predicted in July that data would show the economy in the second quarter quarter grew at a 2.5 percent to 3 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation. The most recent Commerce Department report set the growth rate at 1.8 percent.
 
 
Committee Questions
 Mr. Mullins comments come the day after Mr. Greenspan indicated that short-term interest rates would have to rise sometime in the future if the Fed was going to continue with its anti-inflation stance. His comments came in answers to questions from the Senate Banking Committee and were released by the committee.
Together, the comments seem to head off for now any further speculation about the Fed cutting short-term interest rates below their current level to help the economy. The recent weak economic data, including Friday's report that nonfarm payroll jobs dropped 39,000 last month, had pushed short-term interest rates lower, indicating that some investors and speculators may have begun betting on another easing by the Fed.
Stephen R. Ricchiuto, chief financial economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said that two things have surprised him in the recent rally. One is that there had been so little issuance by corporations trying to lock in these low long-term interest rates. To him, this indicates that maybe some of these companies think the economy is still very weak and that long-term rates will move even lower.
"That is telling me that the economy is not as good as the Fed thinks it is," he said. "If corporates felt this was the lowest level for interest rates and the economy was growing, corporations would be issuing a lot."
 
 
Pace Seen Picking Up
 Steve Carter, an analyst at MCM/ CorporateWatch, said that the pace of new corporate issues had been slow recently but that he expected them to pick up next week.
The other surprise, Mr. Ricchiuto said, is that the spread between the yield on the 10-year note and the yield on the 30-year bond had widened recently rather than narrowed as many analysts had expected. This means that the yield on the 10-year note has come down just about as fast as that on the 30-year bond. For Mr. Ricchiuto, this is another indication of how weak many investors think the economy is.
The next test for this rally will come tomorrow, with the release of the Producer Price Index for August. Forecasts expect the increase to be a moderate two-tenths of 1 percent, which would support the perception that inflation is remaining in check. But a surprisingly large increase could upset the rally.

HEADLINE: Credit Cards and Car Loans Spur Consumer Borrowing

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing rose by $5.1 billion in July amid hefty increases in credit card use and auto loans, the Federal Reserve said today.
It was the second consecutive monthly gain and the largest one-month increase in nearly four years. 
 Analysts said the data suggested people were responding to the lowest interest rates in two decades by taking loans to replace aging autos and other items.
Consumer installment credit includes all household debt not secured by real estate. It does not include home equity loans or mortgages.
July's gain meant borrowing was increasing at an annual rate of 8.1 percent a year, while total credit outstanding climbed to $759.740 billion. The July advance was the largest monthly gain since credit grew by $5.27 billion in October 1989, the Fed said. It was the 11th increase in the last 12 months. Credit fell by $752 million in May. June borrowing, however, was revised downward to a gain of $3.8 billion, from an earlier reported increase of about $7.7 billion.
 
Auto Loans Increase
 The Fed report showed that automobile loans grew by $2.03 billion in July, a 9.2 percent increase at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. These loans have grown each month since falling $498 million in April, including a $918 million advance in June.
Revolving credit, which includes credit cards, increased $2.81 billion in July, at a 12.8 percent annual rate. It was the biggest gain since a $3.66 billion advance in March 1991. Revolving credit grew $1.08 million in June.
Other kinds of consumer credit rose by $265 million, a 1.4 percent annual rate, after rising $1.77 billion a month earlier. This category includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations.
Not all analysts see increases in borrowing as a positive sign for the economy.
"Weak retail sales, consumption and confidence suggest consumers are still unable to pay down past borrowing," said a report by Gary Ciminero, chief economist at Fleet Financial.
In addition, a lack of cash is finding many people "unwilling to forgo liquidity, allowing balances on credit cards to continue accumulating," Mr. Ciminero said.
Still, the pace of borrowing has slowed from the buying binge of the 1980's. "Consumer credit use has been a smaller propellant to consumption growth," said a report by Michael Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank.

HEADLINE: Fed Economic Study Shows Striking Regional Contrasts

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The economy displayed "slow to moderate" overall growth in midsummer but was marked by striking differences among geographic areas and industries, a Federal Reserve survey said today.
"Economic growth appears weaker on the East and West Coasts while central areas such as Cleveland, Dallas, Kansas City and Minneapolis report stronger than average growth," said the Fed's so-called beige book, an anecdotal survey of business conditions in late July and August. 
 While this follows the general pattern of recent years, contrasts such as the Chicago district's report of the highest orders for heavy trucks for any July in 15 years and a severe slump in tourism in Hawaii, seemed unusually acute.
Even within individual districts, some areas were robust while others sank. The New York district, for example, cited layoffs by the International Business Machines Corporation as having begun to damage the real estate market in the Hudson Valley while the solid price Morgan Stanley paid for a nearly vacant 42-story office building suggested a firming in mid-Manhattan.
Except for lumber, which was rebounding because of rebuilding in the flood-stricken Midwest, the economy shows little evidence of inflationary cost pressures, the survey found. The floods themselves did not cut crop production enough to have much effect on food or livestock prices, though corn and soybeans in northern areas were described as vulnerable to an early frost.
The survey, compiled this time at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, was based on information supplied by Fed contacts before Aug. 31. It is one of the many sources used to aid deliberations when the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee, its main policy body, meets next on Sept. 21.
The preceding survey, published Aug. 4, found the economy expanding "slowly to moderately," in most districts, almost identical to today's characterization. The job market, however, appears not to have held its own, based on last Friday's weak Labor Department report for August and on various comments in the survey.
Employment growth suffers from continued restructuring by corporations, the survey said. Philadelphia, for example, reported that despite expectations of improved conditions, about 75 percent of the area's manufacturers were keeping payrolls "steady" while 25 percent were cutting them.
The Fed banks noted these developments in their regions:
*San Francisco -- Recovery continues to elude California but hefty expansion marks the intermountain West. The motion-picture business, posting double-digit gains, is one bright spot. Tucson booms on the relocation of aerospace activity to southern Arizona. Home sales slump 18 percent in Hawaii from levels a year earlier but the median sales price in Honolulu jumps 5.6 percent, to $358,000, highest in the country.
*St. Louis -- Estimate of flood damage for the district is estimated at $2 billion to $3 billion as the economy continues to grow slowly. One concern is a possible Mississippi River traffic snarl in the autumn as many boats and barges head for New Orleans at the same time.
*Cleveland -- Makers of sheet steel report operations at virtual capacity but those making plate steel find orders softening because of deferrals of barge and rail cars orders until facilities destroyed by floods can be rebuilt.
*Boston -- The economy seems to be expanding only marginally but some retailers fear progress may have stalled. Suppliers of medical equipment have cut prices by as much as 15 percent.
*Atlanta -- Consumer spending slowed unseasonably in July and August, with apparel and other nondurables especially sluggish and recent gains among furniture, appliances and cars have been more muted than earlier in the year.
*Minneapolis -- South Dakota is in a mini-boom, with construction employment at near-record levels, but sales taxes in Minnesota are running behind projections.
*Dallas -- The main source of growth at accounting firms was for consulting on ways to raise productivity. Home building remains strong.
Richmond reported that tourism was strong but activity at the main ports of Baltimore, Hampton Roads, Va., and Charleston, S.C., was only mixed -- exports lower and imports higher in July than in June and in the period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: BOXING;
A Title, and Pride, at Stake for Chavez

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 8

 BODY:
In the cantinas and garages that anchor the gritty, working-class neighborhood here called Tepito, the talk is all of Mexican guts and battered gringos, of past and future glory.
For all of the hype about a Mexican fighting an American on Friday night in the Alamodome in San Antonio, no one here seems to be remembering the Alamo much. But ask them about Julio Cesar Chavez, Pernell Whitaker and the symbolic precedent, and the men of Tepito are of a single mind: history will repeat itself. 
 "The Americans have always dominated us in everything," said Jose Luis Villagran, a 25-year-old clerk in an auto parts store. "But we can win with Julio Cesar. He has a very Mexican heart."
It is much the same elsewhere in the country as its superlightweight and spiritual champion -- a slight man with small, hard fists and a smiling, steel jaw -- prepares to defend the national honor against yet another voluble American.
 
Trade Is Trade; Sports Is Sports
 As Mexico has embraced a new partnership with the United States under President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, fastening its economic hopes to the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Government has worked with some success to push aside the prickly, defensive nationalism with which Mexicans have long looked northward.
This morning, though, the inky sports tabloids that hang like shingles from kiosks around Mexico City suggested that trade was trade and sports was sports. Anyone wondering about the pride at stake needed only to hear from Chavez.
"I'll never go down on points," the fighter was quoted as saying. "If he knocks me out, I'll retire."
For the Chavez camp, the intended conquest on Friday night will be more than the welterweight champion Pernell Whitaker, who is as elusive as any of the 87 men whom Chavez has fought and beaten, 75 by knockout. The fight will be the third in which Chavez will be putting on weight in search of another championship.
The other goal will be for the five-time world champion, a man of low-key charisma and little English, to hammer his way to a larger American audience and the sort of international star status that a fighter often called the best pound for pound in the world might expect.
"This is to get to another level," said Daniel Castro, the 45-year-old former high school math teacher and track coach who has trained Chavez for the last seven years. "We want to break into the whole American market."
The thought of it seems to have seized Chavez's promoter, Don King, by the nose.
 
Let the Hype Begin
 The fight has been marketed and publicized like none of Chavez's before, with public workouts from Mexico to Los Angeles to New York. The event seems to have outhyped even "the Grand Slam of Boxing," the four-fight card on which Chavez whipped Greg Haugen in February before 110,000 extremely partisan fans in Mexico City's Estadio Azteca. (And that promotion was enough to start King learning Spanglish.)
In a conversation last month in Toluca, a city just west of the Mexican capital where he has gone for years to train in the crisp, thin air, Chavez bubbled with good humor at the prospect of beating up another fighter who lays claim to his unofficial pound-for-pound title. But he seemed somewhat defensive at the notion shared by his trainer and others that his international fame had not yet caught up to his stature as a boxer.
"I am satisfied with what I've done in boxing," he said. "I think the American public knows me better than Whitaker. I sell more tickets than he does. This is just one more fight for me."
In Mexico, product endorsements and other secondary markets for his fame have multiplied with each fight. In Mexico, he promotes everything from potato chips to supermarkets and banks. And he seems to wonder: isn't that enough?
As he thought about it while preparing for an afternoon sparring session, he even seemed tired of the fame, of the people who surround him wherever he goes in Mexico, of all the people who wait outside his home in the northwestern city of Culiacan as they might wait for a priest or a mafia don.
"How could I enjoy that?" he asked. "I don't have privacy. I don't have anything.
"Tons of people come to ask me for things, to ask me for money. I help a lot of people. But I can't help everybody. I don't mind when people who really need you come. But some of them -- it bothers you."
 
'A Real Ugly Style'
 Still weeks before the fight, he even seemed a bit tired already of Pernell Whitaker and the King-orchestrated selling of their fight.
"I don't like to watch him fight," he said of Whitaker. "He's got a real ugly style."
Sure, he was in the best shape of his life, Chavez said. After 10 years of telling his wife, Amalia, that the next year will be his last, he said he was sure he has a couple of good years left in his career.
But there was a note of fatigue in his voice.
"I really don't like to do all the promotion so much," he said in an interview last month at his camp in Toluca. "I am a happy person. But I don't like to act like a clown. Boxing is something serious."
In the musty amateur gyms that dot Tepito, it is something almost religious.
"The gringos have always beaten us in everything else, but not in boxing," said Cesar Bazan Perez, an 18-year-old who hung onto the ropes of a ring at the Deportivo Tepito, a gym where pink and blue squiggles of neon on the wall illuminate a shrine to the Mexico's patron saint, the Virgin of Guadalupe. "This is Mexico against the United States. Like a good Mexican, I think Julio Cesar is going to win."
Chavez, of course, said he was sure of that.
"I know he is a fighter who is very difficult to connect with," he said of Whitaker. "He can be dangerous in the first few rounds. But I don't think he can knock me out."
 
Always More Rivals
 Was Chavez already thinking ahead to a rematch with Meldrick Taylor, the one fighter who, in 1990, came within seconds of beating him?
"Every time you turn around there are more rivals," he said. "There's always going to be another one."
But who would be next?
Well, next would be a fight in Mexico, he said, describing the habitual Chavez warm-up bout that led Haugen to complain unwisely before their fight that the Mexican had padded his undefeated record against "Tijuana taxi drivers."
"I don't know exactly who I will fight," Chavez said. "They will pick someone."
He smiled the steel-jawed smile. "Some taxi driver."

HEADLINE: For City Council: Bronx, Queens

 BODY:
The shortage of plausible challengers in next week's Democratic primary elections for New York City Council in the Bronx and Queens means that many undistinguished members will glide to re-election despite lackluster records. Voters in the Bronx's 18th Councilmanic District have particular reason to feel cheated by the non-contest in their district.
With the borough's Democratic Party organization helping to clear the field of potential contenders, and with no dissent from the Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, the incumbent, Lucy Cruz, has an unobstructed path -- notwithstanding her alarming pattern of ethical abuses. 
 Here are The Times's endorsements in some of the competitive races.
12th District (Co-op City, Williamsbridge, Baychester, Edenwald and parts of Wakefield): The incumbent, Lawrence Warden, faces an active challenge from Samuel Burke, a Democratic district leader in Co-op City who is an associate manager at Montefiore Medical Center.
Mr. Burke has served as a legislative aide to a former State Senator and as a member of a local community planning board -- normally valuable training for someone who aspires to the Council. But he has yet to acquire a reassuring grasp of citywide issues, and his candidacy seems more inspired by infighting among different political factions in his district than by any clear vision of what he would do in office.
First elected in 1991, Mr. Warden has not emerged as a serious legislator. Though he's a hard-working presence in the community, he has not devoted equal attention to legislation, oversight and the related responsibilities that all Council members share. We endorse him with the hope that he will begin to take his citywide obligations as a lawmaker more seriously.
17th District (Mott Haven, Longwood, Crotona): This district has not been well served by the incumbent, Rafael Castaneira Colon, an 11-year veteran. Mr. Colon was recently indicted on charges of stealing nearly $400,000 by cashing payroll checks made out to phantom employees.
His legal troubles lost him the support of the Bronx Democratic political establishment, which pushed Assemblyman David Rosado to run against him. Mr. Rosado needs to broaden his vision to encompass more than his South Bronx district; even so, he seems to have a slightly better sense of his community's needs than Andrew Eatmon Jr., a Legal Aid Society investigator whom we endorsed last time in preference to Mr. Colon.
27th District (St. Albans, Hollis, Cambria Heights, parts of Jamaica, Queens Village, Rosedale and Springfield Gardens): Archie Spigner, a career politician and an integral part of the Council leadership, faces a challenge from Garth Marchant, a freelance reporter. Mr. Marchant is energetic but does not offer sufficient experience to unseat Mr. Spigner, a 19-year veteran who heads the Council's housing committee in a workmanlike manner.
 28th District (Jamaica, Rochdale Village, South Ozone Park and Richmond Hill): This contest pits Thomas White Jr., a one-term incumbent who directs a state-funded drug treatment program, against Allan Jennings Jr., a Democratic district leader. Mr. White has often paid more attention to his drug program than to his Council duties. But he played an important role in pushing the solid waste management plan and has tried forcefully to heal racial tensions among Council members. Mr. Jennings, 26, shows promise, but needs more political seasoning.
31st District (Far Rockaway, Arverne, Edgemere, Bayswater, Laurelton, Rosedale, parts of Springfield Gardens, Cambria Heights and Ozone Park): The incumbent in this large and economically diverse district is Juanita Watkins, who had been a longtime community activist. She's been less of an activist during her one term on the Council, seeming to concentrate more on constituent services.
But her ability to work effectively when she chooses to do so -- lending her support to a compromise proposal to create a separate city agency for the homeless, for example -- earns her our endorsement over her opponent, Edward J. Lewis, who shares Ms. Watkins's devotion to the community but does not match her political experience.

HEADLINE: Don't Strangle the U.N.

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk; Leonard Silk, former economics columnist of The New York Times, is co-editor, with Uner Kirdar, of the forthcoming "A World Fit for People."

DATELINE: HULLS COVE, Me.

 BODY:
Forty-eight years ago, as a correspondent for an Army newspaper, I covered the founding conference of the United Nations in San Francisco. In the pressroom in the basement of the Opera House, I met the great essayist E. B. White, who was there for The New Yorker.
One day he posed a riddle. "Sergeant," he said, "what is the most important thing for a marriage?" "Love?" I asked. "No," he said. "The ring." 
 He meant the ring as symbol of commitment: if the 50 founding nations were committed to the new world body, it could survive the kinds of crises that had killed the League of Nations and brought on a world war.
But now, as 183 member nations prepare to convene for the 48th regular session of the General Assembly on Sept. 21, the state of the marriage is alarmingly shaky. Even as the agenda lists a mind-numbing array of problems -- from the fate of Bosnia to the control of Antarctica, from apartheid to the arms race in outer space -- the members seem unwilling to do the hard work needed to keep this union healthy.
As George Bush once said in another context, it's a matter of will and wallet. United Nations peacekeeping forces are engaged in no fewer than a dozen wars, civil and cross-border, around the world. The cost of peacekeeping has risen tenfold in the last six years -- to $3.6 billion in the past fiscal year from $364 million in 1987.
But the U.N. is strapped for funds to carry out the tasks it has been given by member governments. Few countries pay their bills in full or on time; only 10 of the 183 have done so.
The worst offender is the United States. At the end of August, the U.N. was owed more than $2 billion, with the United States owing $786 million, followed by Russia ($505 million) and Japan ($108 million).
Much of the American debt dates to the cold war, when the U.S. deliberately underfinanced the United Nations to show disapproval of its actions. These obligations are being wound down under a program approved by Congress in 1991, but at the present rate they will take years to pay off. To make matters worse, the former Soviet republics have no money to pay their back dues.
The U.N. is not allowed to borrow money; it is constantly delaying payment of its own bills and juggling accounts, a demeaning business.
To withhold support at so crucial a time is unwise and self-defeating. The lack of resources is severely constricting the U.N.'s ability to carry out its missions.
To deal with conflicts already on its agenda, the U.N. has only 80,000 peacekeepers among the 12 wars. These forces are not large enough to enforce the peace. Without the much larger national military forces of the United States and other nations involved, U.N. peacekeepers can only function as observers, mediators, aid dispensers, hostages or victims -- all roles they have played in Bosnia, Cambodia and Somalia.
Neither the United States nor any other nation could take on the job of global policeman on its own. Yet the member states, including the United States, are not ready to give the U.N. the control over military forces and the financing to head off conflicts.
With the end of the cold war, the neglect and disparagement of the United Nations by the United States and other countries cannot safely continue. The U.N. must be rebuilt as an organization capable of fulfilling its original purposes and dealing with the dangers that have grown up during its nearly half century of existence -- not just wars, but the economic stagnation and poverty that underlie so much of the world's conflicts.
"Forty years of neglect," as the American delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, has said, "have left this institution flabby and out of shape." Indeed. But if it is to be strengthened, it is up to the United States to take the lead.

HEADLINE: Time to Lift the Ban On Travel to Lebanon

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Beirut Reborn," your Aug. 29 front-page special report, updates the world on a country that used to have "war-torn" unofficially part of its name. Yet while Lebanon revives, Washington hinders it by maintaining a travel ban to Lebanon on United States passports, putting Lebanon in the company of Libya and Iraq. 
 The original travel ban to Lebanon followed the kidnapping of Americans by terrorist groups operating in a then-lawless nation. Yet the last American hostage, Terry Andersen, was freed Dec. 4, 1991, and Lebanon is today under the firm control of the Lebanese Army, with help (wanted or unwanted) from the Syrian Army.
Why hasn't the travel ban been lifted? In my view, it is simply because the "safe" course of action is to do nothing. The real problem is that if a single American was kidnapped or harmed, those responsible for lifting the ban could pay the political price.
More than $1 billion has been pledged for Lebanon's reconstruction, with participation from the World Bank, the European Economic Community, and European and Middle East countries and institutions. The total expenditure is estimated at $3 billion at least. American companies deserve the right to compete for their share of that business.
The State Department could downgrade the ban to a travel advisory and warn people not to go, as it does in the cases of Bosnia, Somalia and Afghanistan.
 
PETER J. TANOUS
Washington, Sept. 1, 1993

HEADLINE: Why Family Leave Makes Good Business Sense;
Allowing for Sickness

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Women's Work -- and Men's, Too" (editorial, Aug. 17), you note that the provisions of the Family and Medical Leave Act are widely misunderstood. Contrary to popular belief, the law gives a man the same opportunity as female co-workers to spend time with his new baby or take his sick mother to the doctor. The sooner employers learn that the family leave act makes family leave available to both sexes, the closer we'll be to a nondiscriminatory workplace. 
 But you further a common misperception of this law by stating nothing about its medical leave aspect. Medical leave -- formerly known as disability leave -- allows an employee to attend to his or her own illness. Although disability leave is a mandated benefit in New York and New Jersey, even for small companies, these states are the exception. Most United States workers have no job-guaranteed right to take time off when sick. Without the Family and Medical Leave Act, a heart attack or a broken leg can mean the loss of a job.
By providing these two types of leave together, the law reconfigures our notion of the typical worker. Public policy has traditionally treated employees as identical individuals whose needs and family obligations are their private problem. The family leave act marks the beginning of a policy that acknowledges wage earners come in many guises and with diverse responsibilities.
We are women, as well as men, fathers, mothers, members of big families and people without close relatives. We have new babies, sick children and aging parents. And sometimes, we fall seriously ill ourselves.
American workers are human beings whose needs should be recognized in the workplace. Whether the Family and Medical Leave Act is justified on ethical grounds or to increase productivity in a competitive global economy, it takes an important step in this direction.
 
LISE VOGEL
Brooklyn, Aug. 27, 1993
 
The writer is the author of "Mothers on the Job."

HEADLINE: A Mudslinging Democratic Match;
On L.I., a Race Grows Ugly on Who Will Challenge the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Four years ago, it would have been almost unthinkable that Democrats in Nassau County, home of one of the last great Republican political machines, would be fighting among themselves over who would challenge the incumbent Republican County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta.
The Democratic nominee, one top party official said of previous county executive races, was "basically the last person to leave the room," often someone who agreed to be sacrificed at the polls after preferred candidates opted for safer electoral climes. 
 But with the county's economy faltering and voters angry about some of the highest county taxes in the nation, the Nassau Republican Party is believed to be vulnerable, and the Democrats have responded with one of the most intense primary battles in the county's history.
After months of trying to avoid an ugly campaign between two of the county's best-known Democrats, the candidates, Richard M. Kessel and Benjamin L. Zwirn, have turned the race into a mudslinging match that has many Democrats fearing that neither candidate will be standing after the primary on Tuesday.
"At least it's generating some excitement," mused Lewis J. Yevoli, the Democratic Supervisor of Oyster Bay, who originally endorsed Mr. Kessel and is now neutral. "I just hope they don't kill each other before next Tuesday."
The primary comes as the political landscape in the suburbs has changed in recent years. While the suburbs were once viewed as Republican territory, in the 1992 Presidential election President Clinton did well in Republican enclaves like Nassau and Westchester Counties, as well as the suburbs of Chicago and Philadelphia.
It is not clear whether such national trends translate to local politics, though Nassau Democrats have recently won some top elected offices for the first time in decades, such as the county clerk's office last year, Mr. Yevoli's as supervisor in Oyster Bay in 1991 and Mr. Zwirn's position as supervisor of North Hempstead in 1989.
The race between Mr. Kessel, executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, and Mr. Zwirn represents a struggle over the best path to winning the county's highest office, the position that serves as chief executive of an area with a population larger than Arkansas (1.3 million) and a budget of almost $2 billion. For many voters, it is not a question of ideology -- both men promise "change," meaning cutting taxes and trimming government -- but one of who will be the better candidate against Mr. Gulotta.
The two men have starkly different images. People commonly refer to Mr. Kessel as a "nice guy" and he proudly wears the label of a "progressive, traditional Democrat." In contrast, Mr. Zwirn, who was a registered Republican for several years in the 1980's, is known as a combative maverick who touts his independence from the Democratic Party and brags of his ties to supporters of Ross Perot and other independents.
 
'Clean Water and Apple Pie'
 "There are no issues at all," said Bruce Nyman, Supervisor of Long Beach. "Both are for lower taxes, clean water and apple pie. People will be voting on personalities, not policies."
Hank Morris, a political consultant who is not involved in the race, said: "Kessel symbolizes the Democratic Party that, as a first order of business, cares about helping people and fighting big powerful interests that are allied with rich and powerful people. Zwirn symbolizes a new kind of Democrat that is less rooted in those traditions, is less ideological and has a track record of winning elections."
Mr. Kessel, who has never held elected office, bills himself as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's "point man" on Long Island: acting as Mr. Cuomo's representative, he was a major player in the deal that led to the closing of the Shoreham nuclear-power plant. A self-styled gadfly in the mode of a Ralph Nader, Mr. Kessel campaigns as a consumer advocate who says he lowered water rates, improved the service of Long Island Railroad and helped in successful fights against proposed sewage pelletization plants and in the closing of a landfill.
At the county's Democratic convention last spring, about 75 percent of the party regulars endorsed Mr. Kessel, and since then, Mr. Kessel has argued that his ties to the party and Mr. Cuomo made him the stronger candidate to run against Mr. Gulotta. Indeed, as of last Friday, he had raised about $311,000, more than twice as much as Mr. Zwirn, with a substantial portion coming from out-of-county contributors.
Mr. Zwirn has emphasized his accomplishments in trimming North Hempstead's work force by 43 percent and cutting the town's taxes to what he contends are the lowest of any town on Long Island.
 
Repeating Campaign Theme
 His literature heralds how in 1989 he became the first Democrat to be elected Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead in more than 70 years and how in 1991 he was re-elected along with the North Hempstead Town Board's first Democratic majority.
When asked his plan for the county, Mr. Zwirn responds with what has become his campaign's theme: "Just look at my record in North Hempstead." His supporters maintain that he will be the better candidate to defeat Mr. Gulotta, because of a proven track record of reaching out to independents and disaffected Republicans. It is Mr. Zwirn's record of winning elections that has some party insiders wavering in their loyalty to Mr. Kessel.
Almost every Democrat grants that the toughest part of the campaign is still to come. Mr. Gulotta has won every race he has ever run, and he already has accumulated a war chest of more than $1 million. While the Republican machine here has suffered some setbacks recently, it is still the operation that served as the base for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's successful campaigns, and it can mobilize hundreds of county employees who owe their jobs to Republican patronage. And Republicans still outnumber Democrats here 3 to 2.
 
Charges and Countercharges
 For this reason, the divisive primary battle has worried Democrats. Mr. Zwirn last week in a debate on station WGBB-AM declared that he would run as an independent if he lost the primary, a move that Mr. Kessel said would almost guarantee Mr. Gulotta's re-election and that also showed that Mr. Zwirn was not a "true Democrat."
The disarray among Democrats has been compounded in the last few weeks, as the campaign has grown increasingly negative. In a debate Tuesday night on Cablevision's Channel 12, Mr. Kessel accused Mr. Zwirn of being a "rubber stamp to Mr. Gulotta" and charged that he has proposed one of the largest tax increases in county history, ignoring that Mr. Zwirn's recommendation was accompanied by a proposal suggesting spending cuts and was intended to provide financing to hire 1,000 more police officers.
In turn, in the same debate, Mr. Zwirn referred to Mr. Kessel as "rate-hike Richie," blaming him for the county's high utility rates because of the deal that shut down the Shoreham plant. He also ridiculed Mr. Kessel's work as a consumer advocate to put into effect unit pricing, saying, "You're my man for tuna fish."
One top Democratic official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "This primary has really deteriorated. The charges from both sides have no basis in reality. Both camps are in outer space."
It is not clear what ramifications the negative campaigning will have in the primary on Tuesday. Democratic primaries in the past here have had poor turnouts, and several party stalwarts said a projected turnout of 20 percent of the registered Democrats, about 43,000 voters, by John Matthews, the chairman of the Nassau Democratic Committee, was optimistic.
If that is the case, the election will very likely be decided by which campaign has the better get-out-the-vote effort, and it is difficult to assess if one organization is decisively stronger. While Mr. Kessel has more money, Mr. Zwirn has mobilized voters before in North Hempstead.
"Nobody has a handle on this race," said Mr. Nyman, the Long Beach Supervisor, who endorsed Mr. Kessel last spring before Mr. Zwirn entered the race and has not been involved in the campaign. "There are so many intangibles here, and neither candidate's organization has ever been tested in a countywide race."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 10, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the Democratic primary for Nassau County Executive compared the county's population incorrectly with that of Arkansas. While Long Island's total population of 2.6 million is greater than that of Arkansas, with 2.4 million, Nassau's population of 1.3 million is not.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Tandem Appoints a Chief For Ungermann-Bass Unit

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
Tandem Computers Inc. yesterday named Roel Pieper, a multilingual computer executive, as president and chief executive of its struggling Ungermann-Bass Inc. computer networking subsidiary.
Mr. Pieper succeeds Ralph Ungermann, 51, who resigned from the company he co-founded on July 28. The same day, Tandem Computers started a cost-cutting and streamlining drive that surprised industry analysts and led to a $550 million third-quarter loss. Ungermann-Bass, acquired by Tandem in 1988, was not spared in the corporate overhaul, a company spokesman said. In the first nine months, the unit had $269 million in revenue, 18 percent of Tandem's total. 
 Only last week, Mr. Pieper, 36, departed from the software maker Novell Inc., which in June acquired Unix Systems Laboratories from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. He had been president and chief executive of the A.T.& T. spinoff. His departure was expected because he was left without a leading role to play at Novell.
 
Efforts to Renew Growth
 In a statement, James G. Treybig, Tandem's president, said in part that he expectedMr. Pieper to return the unit to profitability and renew its growth.
Ungermann-Bass "struggled because it focused on the high end while growth has been at the low end," said Thomas Rooney, a computer analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin. "Clearly, new management and new direction was needed. Now, it's a question of repositioning."
Tandem stock lost 25 cents a share yesterday, closing at $9.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.
In an interview, Mr. Pieper (rhymes with beeper) said, "I look for things that are a new challenge, need work and have a lot of potential."
Mr. Pieper, a Dutch computer scientist who is fluent in English, German and French in addition to Dutch, said he was particularly intrigued with being part of a company at the brink of interactive technology, where some envision a myriad of services emerging from the overlay of cable television, computers and telephones.
"Here's where it will happen," he said. Mr. Pieper said his most important task would be marketing the company's networking software, possibly through new partnerships.
Tandem, based in Cupertino, Calif., makes fault-tolerant computer systems, which are designed not to fail even under extreme conditions. The company has been hurt by weak economic conditions, price cutting by rivals and by a shift away from expensive mainframes.
Mr. Treybig, Tandem's president, declined to say what Mr. Pieper would be paid, except that his salary, like that of all Tandem employees, includes an unspecified amount of stock. Mr. Pieper will also be a senior vice president of Tandem.
