HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: The Overview;
P.L.O. AND ISRAEL ACCEPT EACH OTHER AFTER 3 DECADES OF RELENTLESS STRIFE

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Enemies to the death for three decades, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization opened a new era in their blood-soaked history today by recognizing each other's legitimacy and the rights of both to represent their people's dreams.
Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, said in a letter to Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin that his group recognized Israel's right "to exist in peace and security," renounced "the use of terrorism and other acts of violence," and was ready to discipline any of its loyalists who break this pledge. 
 And in a separate letter to Norway's Foreign Minister, who had served for months as an intermediary in secret talks between the two sides, Mr. Arafat called on Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to begin "the normalization of life." Israeli officials took that as an Arafat appeal to end the Palestinian uprising known in Arabic as the intifada, although that was not spelled out.
 
Rabin Stood Firm
 The Israelis said Mr. Rabin was adamant that the intifada be curtailed. It was a measure of Mr. Arafat's determination to reach an agreement that he yielded on this point even though most Palestinians in the territories consider the uprising an indispensable tool to resist the Israeli occupation.
For his part, Mr. Rabin wrote a terse letter to Mr. Arafat saying that in light of these Palestinian commitments, his Government "has decided to recognize the P.L.O. as the representative of the Palestinian people and to commence negotiations with the P.L.O. within the Middle East peace process." Unlike Mr. Arafat, who closed his letter with the word "sincerely," Mr. Rabin dispensed with such pleasantries and simply put his name. [Texts of the three letters, page A12.]
Mr. Arafat signed his letter to Mr. Rabin behind closed doors late tonight in Tunis, where the P.L.O. is based. When Mr. Rabin follows suit at a signing ceremony in Jerusalem on Friday morning, it will clear the way for yet another agreement on a plan to transfer authority in the territories from Israeli to Palestinian hands, starting with a form of self-rule in Gaza and the West Bank city of Jericho.
 
Breathtaking Change
 That accord, the product of months of secret negotiations conducted mainly in Norway, is to be signed at the White House on Monday by high-ranking officials on each side. No names have been announced, but the Israelis said they would probably be represented by Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, and the Palestinians are expected to send Mahmoud Abbas, the P.L.O. official who supervised the negotiations. Farouk Kaddoumi, the P.L.O. foreign minister, opposed the agreements.
Washington has been the locale of the most recent Middle East peace talks, and both sides seem to want United States involvement in the peace process.
No amount of protocol or formal language, however, could obscure the breathtaking change that has now swept across this land for which Jews and Arabs have fought and died across the last century.
For Israel, recognition of the P.L.O., formally endorsed by the Rabin Cabinet this evening, means that it is prepared at last to come to terms with a detested Arab leader whose followers have taken countless Israeli lives and whose name is uttered by many Jews in the same breath as Hitler's.
For the P.L.O., it means that it has come at last to accept that Israel is here to stay and that this fact will not be altered by killings, resistance or its 1964 covenant calling for armed struggle to "destroy the Zionist and imperialist presence." In rejecting that part of the covenant now, Mr. Arafat acknowledges that if he is to obtain the state he hopes to lead in a few years, he must settle for the territories of Gaza and the West Bank and he is not about to "liberate" all the land that used to be called Palestine.
The leap that has been made is so large that the normally phlegmatic Mr. Rabin told members of his Labor Party today that he had "butterflies in my stomach."
 
Coming to Terms
 It does not mean that he likes dealing with the P.L.O., he said, and aides added that none of this means the Prime Minister puts his trust in Mr. Arafat. But if there is to be peace with the Palestinians, the only negotiating partner available is the P.L.O., Mr. Rabin asserted.
"You don't make peace with friends," he said. "You make it with very unsavory enemies."
Mr. Peres, who guided the secret talks in Norway and who met with a senior P.L.O. official in Oslo last month, spoke more positively about the shift that has taken place, insisting that the Government had remained true to longstanding principles and to its commitment to Israeli security.
"We haven't changed -- it changed," he said, referring to the P.L.O. "Arafat is announcing that he opposes terrorism and will fight the terrorists. He recognizes Israel and its right to exist in peace."
 
From Clinton, Praise
 On a visit to Cleveland, President Clinton added his endorsement, saying after a phone conversation with Mr. Rabin, "This is a very brave and courageous thing that has been done."
Still, as momentous as the breakthrough is, Israeli officials say with somewhat nervous sighs that now comes the difficult part, including hammering out essential details for Palestinian self-rule and contending with hard-line resisters on each side.
Although there were signs of rallying 'round the P.L.O. in the territories, including a march today in Gaza City by several hundred Arafat supporters, widespread opposition remains among Palestinians who believe that they got too little from the Israelis and that self-rule will not lead to a state.
In Damascus, a radical Palestinian leader, Ahmed Jabril, said that 10 Syria-based opposition groups would seek to upend the agreement, adding, "We are capable of finding ways and means to do it." Moreover, no pledge by Mr. Arafat to curb violence is binding on militant Islamic groups like Hamas, a serious threat to the P.L.O.
 
Weary of Conflict
 On the Israeli side, Government officials say that the people will support them, for they are tried of decades of conflict. But the officials acknowledge that they must persuade Israelis that the new course will not undermine their security.
After decades of viewing Mr. Arafat as a scraggly bearded devil, many Israelis will not easily negotiate the mental U-turn now required to treat him as a partner in peace. A widely shared opinion was expressed on television tonight by Ariel Sharon, the former general and opposition Likud Party elder. "There is room for reconciliation with the Palestinians," he said. "There is room for peace with them. There is no room for peace with Arafat."
Given such emotions, officials say it is not clear whether they will allow Mr. Arafat to move into Gaza and Jericho with other P.L.O. leaders expected to arrive in a few months.
As a further complication, Mr. Rabin is threatened with a possible walkout by Shas, the only religious party in his governing coalition. A day after its leader was forced to resign as Interior Minister in a corruption scandal, Shas was still on the Prime Minister's side today. But if it leaves, Mr. Rabin will lose his assured majority in Parliament and may have to depend on Arab votes to win approval for his peace plan. While that would be legally valid, the absence of a clear Jewish majority could be politically damaging, Government officials acknowledge.
 
Problems for Arafat
 Mr. Arafat has legislative problems as well. Technically, he must have more than just the approval of the P.L.O. executive committee, which he received today after days of delay caused by internal disputes over the wording of the mutual recognition accord. To alter the P.L.O. charter on this score he must also get a two-thirds majority of the Palestine National Council, a parliament-in-exile for the Palestinians. That is likely to involve still more delays and bitter fights.
With the clock ticking and convinced that time lost works against them, Israeli officials agreed to a short cut in the form of a solid commitment by the P.L.O. leadership to recognize Israel's right to exist, to resolve disputes through negotiations and not bombs, to assume responsibility for P.L.O. elements that resort to acts of violence and to discipline them.
But in return, the Israelis drove a hard bargain. Mr. Rabin, who was Defense Minister when the uprising erupted in 1987 and who vowed to crush it by breaking bones, was said to be especially insistent on curbing the uprising, which has ebbed considerably on its own. "It's almost a personal thing with him," one official said.
In response to this demand, Mr. Arafat said in his letter to the Norwegian Foreign Minister, Johan Jorgen Holst, that after the self-rule agreement is signed he will call on Palestinians in the territories to "take part in the steps leading to the normalization of life, rejecting violence and terrorism."
An even thornier problem delaying mutual recognition, Israeli officials said, was the language of the P.L.O.'s renunciation of offending sections of its covenant. The wording was finally nailed down only today. According to the Israelis, the P.L.O. had wanted to dispense with these sections by calling them "obsolete." In the end, it agreed to the more forceful construction of "inoperative and no longer valid."
All this was set down on pieces of paper lacking letterheads -- a protocol requirement that Israelis officials considered necessary because, they said, they are not on an equal plane with the stateless Palestinians.
Once the documents are signed, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators must flesh out their outlined agreement on Palestinian self-rule, or autonomy, in Gaza and the West Bank.
For the Palestinians, the goal is clear: a state of their own. The Rabin Government opposes a state, however, and says that it envisions eventual confederation between the Palestinian "entity" and Jordan.
 
A Pilot Project
 The "declaration of principles" that is expected to be signed on Monday at the White House provides for immediate autonomy in Gaza and Jericho as a pilot project, tentatively to start in six months. Soon after, the Israelis say, they will hand the Palestinians responsibility for many functions of daily life elsewhere in the West Bank, but they will not pull back their forces, as they plan to do in Gaza and Jericho.
After an anticipated nine months or so, Palestinians, including those living in East Jerusalem, will elect a council to administer this autonomy in the territories. Israel, while withdrawing its troops from populated areas, will remain in charge of overall security, foreign relations, Israeli settlers living in the territories and the safety of Israelis who may pass through. In addition, the highly delicate question of Jerusalem's future will be left for later.
But much needs to be worked out on basic matters, such as how large the Jericho district is and what sort of cooperation will exist between the Israeli army and the "strong local police force" that the Palestinians are to create. Details must also be arranged on plans for economic cooperation.
"The signing of documents is only the beginning of a very difficult task and the daunting challenges that lie ahead," said Hanan Ashrawi, spokeswoman for the Palestinian delegation to the peace talks that have continued in Washington while the real agreements were reached elsewhere.
Mr. Rabin also said that the agreement is only "a test case" and that much more remains to be done. But he said of the deal with the P.L.O., "I see this as the lowest risk in order to give peace a chance."

LENGTH: 1348 words

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

SoHo's Grand Reopening
In these precarious economic times, SoHo dealers are betting there is safety in numbers (not to mention increased visibility). Tomorrow, to inaugurate the fall art season, more than 30 galleries and nonprofit spaces in lower SoHo will have simultaneous openings from 5 to 8 P.M. The dealers have decided to make the event a virtual block party, with Wooster Street closed to traffic between Grand and Broome Streets.
"Last year we called each other in order to plan our openings on the same day; this year we decided to formalize it," said Ann Philbin, the director of the Drawing Center, a nonprofit exhibition space at 35 Wooster Street. "It's really a way to break open the season and not be depressed about it," she added, alluding to several recent seasons of poor business. 
 Many dealers said the block party was also an attempt to attract an audience beyond the usual art crowd. "This has become such a diminished community," said Lisa Spellman, the owner of the 303 Gallery on Greene Street. The block party, she said, is "aimed at getting people who don't normally visit art galleries, so SoHo won't seem so insular and myopic." Jay Gorney, another dealer, added, "The industry has taken a lot of bashing lately, and the block party is proof there's still life in SoHo."
The event may also make people aware of the number of galleries (now 17 in all) that have clustered around the block bounded by Wooster, Broome, Grand and Greene Streets. A majority are run by dealers in their 30's, although there are also some older, established presences like Brooke Alexander, whose Brooke Alexander Editions gallery at 476 Broome Street will open with an exhibition of work by John Baldessari, probably the best-known artist involved in tomorrow's event.
 
Indoors and Out
 Other artists include Alexis Rockman, who will show his macabre images of nature at Jay Gorney Modern Art; Lorna Simpson, whose politically acute photo-works will open at the Josh Baer Gallery at 476 Broome Street, and Raymond Pettibon, who is inaugurating the Feature Gallery's new space at 76 Greene Street. Solo debuts include those of Cheryl Donegan, a video artist, at the Elizabeth Koury Gallery, 89 Greene Street, and Jason Rhoades at David Zwirner, 43 Greene Street. Andrea Zittel (at the Andrea Rosen Gallery, 130 Prince Street), Tony Feher (at Wooster Gardens, 40 Wooster Street), Peter Nadin (at Brooke Alexander), Maureen Gallace (at the Nicole Klagsbrun Gallery, 51 Greene Street) and Stephen Westfall (at the Daniel Newburg Gallery, 43 Greene Street) are all making return engagements.
An independent curator, Simon Watson, has organized an outdoor evening of music and poetry readings from 8 to 10 in a space he calls "the lot," on the southeast corner of Broome and Wooster Streets. James Elaine, the assistant director at the Drawing Center, has organized the entertainment, which will include a folk group, the Murmurs, and Billy Basinski, a singer and saxophonist, both from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, as well as two downtown poets, Bobby Miller and Todd Colby.
"Because there will be so many people milling around on Saturday evening gallery-hopping, we thought it would be fun to also show off the downtown talent of poets and performing artists," Mr. Watson said.
Besides these galleries, at least two dozen others in SoHo are opening tomorrow, so the entire neighborhood could become one large party.
 
The Newcomers
 The SoHo gallery merry-go-round, which started this summer, continues unabated. By far the splashiest name in the group is that of John McEnroe, whose inroads into the professional side of the art world became known last winter when he went to work for the Salander O'Reilly Gallery on East 79th Street in Manhattan. Now, the tennis star is opening a by-appointment-only contemporary-art gallery on Greene Street, the John McEnroe Gallery.
Helping Mr. McEnroe run the operation is Robin Zindell, who was also at Salander O'Reilly. While Ms. Zindell declined to comment on the particulars and Mr. McEnroe was unavailable while serving as a television commentator at the United States Open in Queens this week, word in the art world is that the gallery will open in October. Whether this is a preliminary step to becoming a public gallery or just another back room resale space for blue-chip art remains to be seen.
Despite the poor market of recent years, other brave folk have decided to open galleries, despite the slump. Peter Blum, a print publisher who has been running a private gallery for prints and art books on West 10th Street since 1980, is opening a space this month at 99 Wooster Street where he will show one-of-a-kind works as well as editions and books. "I think this is a good time," he said. "There is certainly interest out there." His first show, "The Collinasca Cycle," will feature a series of 12 wood block prints by David Rabinowitch. Mr. Blum said he would continue working on print editions with artists like Louise Bourgeois, James Turrell and the Japanese artist Yukinori Yanagi.
Another newcomer is TZ'art, which opens on Sept. 28 at 28 Wooster Street. Described as a cross between a commercial gallery and an alternative space, TZ'art is run by Frederieke Sanders Taylor, formerly the director of the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture in Skowhegan, Me., and Tom Zollner, the former director of Gallery Three Zero on Bond Street. The two dealers plan to hold regular six-week shows, beginning with an exhibition, "Naturalunnatural," featuring contemporary artists like Mel Chin, Carol Hepper and Eve Andree Laramee. "We see ourselves as different from the blockbuster arena of the 80's," Ms. Taylor said, adding that the gallery planned to hold lectures and panel discussions around each exhibition.
 
Keeping Their Day Jobs
 Two other new spaces are being run by dealers moonlighting from full-time jobs at established galleries. Frederick Petzel, the director of Metro Pictures, is running a gallery out of his home at 591 Broadway, between Houston and Prince Streets. It is open Tuesdays through Fridays from 2 to 8 P.M., and the shows will change every four weeks. Opening next Friday is an exhibition of six sculptures and a video by Paul Myoda, an American of Japanese descent. "I wanted a space to show younger artists," Mr. Petzel said, "ones who don't have a chance to show at bigger spaces."
More temporary is Basilico Fine Arts, run by Stefano Basilico, a co-director of the Sonnabend Gallery in SoHo. Mr. Basilico doesn't have a permanent space, for the moment, so he is working out of 21 Mercer Street, where the gallery Fiction/Nonfiction was before changing its name to Jose Freire and moving to 130 Prince Street. On Oct. 1, Mr. Basilico's temporary gallery opens with a monthlong show of work by the sculptor Michael Rees. The gallery is open Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays only, from noon to 6 P.M.
For November, Mr. Basilico plans a group show, "Ghost Limb," which will include works by Ronald Jones and Haim Steinbach (both Sonnabend artists), Matthew Antezzo and Laura Stein. While he hasn't nailed down a location for the November show, the dealer doesn't seem fazed by the peripatetic nature of his venture. "Different artists require different spaces," he said. "This way I can find the proper venue for shows."
Meanwhile, two permanent galleries will soon be found in new locations. James Danziger, the photography gallery, is moving from 415 West Broadway to a bigger space at 130 Prince Street, where the Rubenstein/ Diacono gallery abruptly closed this summer. Mr. Danziger's new gallery opens on Sept. 22 with a show of portraits taken by Judith Joy Ross at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, to be followed by "Short Stories: Celebrating 25 Years of Vogue Fashion by Grace Coddington." And Richard Anderson is moving to larger quarters, too: from 63 Thompson Street to 2,100 square feet on the second floor of 476 Broome Street, near Wooster Street. His first show, opening on Oct. 6, will be paintings and works on paper by Hugh Steers.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wall Street Welcomes Settlement Plan on Breast Implants

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Wall Street saw good news yesterday in the possibility of a $4.75 billion settlement of the breast implant cases plaguing a number of big companies.
Shares of Corning Inc., the company that has been most hurt on Wall Street by uncertainty surrounding the litigation, rose $1.625, to $32.25, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Corning is a diversified manufacturer of industrial and consumer products and a leading operator of medical testing laboratories. Along with the Dow Chemical Company, it owns Dow Corning Inc., which was the longtime market leader in breast implants. Dow Chemical's shares edged up 12.5 cents, to $59, on the Big Board.
Shares of the two other former manufacturers of implants involved in the negotiations showed mixed results. Bristol-Myers Squibb rose 25 cents, to $57. Baxter International Inc.'s shares fell $1.125, to $21.825.
Analysts said Baxter's slump should not be attributed to the implant negotiations. The price drop continued a sharp decline that began Wednesday when the hospital supply giant, based in Deerfield, Ill., warned Wall Street that third-quarter earnings would be disappointing and announced several cost-cutting measures. Baxter is the parent company of Baxter Healthcare, a party to the settlement.
 
Ending the Uncertainty
 Wall Street's upbeat view on the breast implant settlement was probably based more on the prospect of ending the uncertainty hovering over the defendants' balance sheets than on any notion that the individual companies would benefit. All of the companies involved stressed that the negotiations had not yet approached the issue of how the $4.75 billion liability would be shared among them, their insurers, and other potential contributors, including suppliers of their manufacturing operations and the plastic surgeons who did the implants.
The impact on any company is unclear until the companies pin down when during the 30-year period covered by the settlement they would make the payments. Such a schedule is crucial in determining the financial impact because inflation makes liabilities to be paid in the future less costly than those due now.
Bristol-Myers said it was premature to make any comment on the negotiations. Corning, Dow Chemical and Baxter all said that the settlement could have a "material" effect on earnings in the quarter in which liabilities are recorded but would not affect their overall financial condition.
The Securities and Exchange Commission normally requires any unusual expense amounting to more than 10 percent of operating earnings in a quarter to be classified as material and reported separately.
Dow Corning said terms of the proposal were likely to result in a material loss in the quarter in which they are recorded and might result in a substantial impact on its overall financial condition. The latter caution was necessary because S.E.C. rules on how unusual expenses affect overall financial health are vaguer than those governing quarterly reports, said Gary Anderson, a Dow Corning spokesman.
Analysts said they were unaware of any insurance companies that would be threatened by the settlement. Exel Ltd., a Bermuda-based insurance company, has announced that it has a reserve fund for this liability.
Judge Sam C. Pointer Jr., the Federal judge overseeing the litigation in Alabama, yesterday approved a $21 million settlement of all claims against the Mentor Corporation. The settlement was reached early this year.
Mentor is the only company still making the implants. It is obligated to exit the business in 18 months under the terms of the agreement.
Approval of Mentor's settlement was announced shortly before the close of trading, sending its shares up $1 each, to $14 in Nasdaq trading.

HEADLINE: In Debate, Dinkins Ties Innis to Giuliani

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Looking past Tuesday's Democratic primary to the general election, Mayor David N. Dinkins used the first formal debate of the primary campaign last night to accuse one of his two challengers, Roy E. Innis, of being a "stalking horse" for the Republican-Liberal candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
In a wandering debate that ran from fiscal policy, to gun control, education, crime and race relations, Mr. Dinkins did his best to dismiss or ignore Mr. Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, and Eric Ruano Melendez, a real-estate broker and civil engineer in the New York City Department of Environmental Protection. 
 Halfway through the hourlong live debate on WABC-TV, Mr. Dinkins diverged from a question and said: "We know Roy Innis is the stalking horse for Rudolph Giuliani. We know that. They have stood together on the steps of City Hall." He added that Mr. Innis had supported Mr. Giuliani in 1989 and another Republican, President George Bush.
He later sought to discredit Mr. Innis in his closing statement by accusing his challenger of being a supporter of Idi Amin, the Uganda dictator, and of Lyndon LaRouche, a political extremist. Though Mr. Innis protested, and called out for "personal privilege of a response," he was cut off without the opportunity to answer.
But earlier, he laughed and dismissed Mr. Dinkins's move to diminish his candidacy. "This question had to come, I guess," he said chuckling, and pointed out that two other Democrats, Andrew J. Stein and Herman Badillo, had dropped from the mayoral race -- Mr. Badillo to run as comptroller on a "fusion" ticket with Mr. Giuliani.
"If there's a horse, it has to be Herman," he said. "I'm still on the Democratic ticket running for mayor. Andy Stein is gone. It's my brother David Dinkins running against me. Rudolph Giuliani is a Republican-Liberal. I'm not competing in that area. I'm competing in the Democratic primary one-on-one, mano a mano."
When one of the three panelists also said that many of Mr. Innis's positions resembled those of Mr. Giuliani, he said playfully, "Oooh, that's a low one."
The debate came five days before the Democratic primary, which in a sharp break with New York tradition, has been overshadowed by the rematch between Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani. Neither Mr. Innis, 59, nor Mr. Melendez, 45, has been able to raise enough money to mount a serious campaign against the Mayor. And until last night the candidates had appeared in a smattering of citizens forums, but never in a full-scale debate. Having accepted $1 million in public matching funds for his primary campaign, the Mayor was under some pressure to debate his challengers.
A poll of registered voters released by Quinnipiac College last week showed Mr. Dinkins the choice of 58 percent, Mr. Innis of 11 percent and Mr. Melendez, 3 percent. Political analysts say the question is not whether Mr. Dinkins will win, but by how much.
But last night's debate covered a wide range of topics that will continue to be key issues in the general election campaign, including such issues as race relations, the Mayor's handling of the 1991 racial disturbances in Crown Heights and of the 1990 black-led boycott of Korean-run grocery stores in Brooklyn.
At one point, Mr. Melendez, who repeatedly stressed his Hispanic heritage, said that he as a Hispanic was best suited to lead the city. "There is not a black person at this moment who is going to be a mayor," he said, "who is going to lead the city in the right direction. It's a lot of hate between white and black at this moment. And I think that I'm the best candidate right now because I'm in the middle." Both Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Innis are black.
Mr. Innis accused Mr. Dinkins of being "not a racial fireman but a racial arsonist" and at one point, as Mr. Giuliani has done in the past, referred to the Crown Heights violence as a "pogrom," using a Russian word that applied to violence against Jews in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Dinkins said his administration had learned from the errors of Crown Heights and had kept the city calm after the verdict in the racially charged Rodney G. King case that led to rioting in Los Angeles. "With respect to 'pogrom' I note that Roy Innis has adopted the language of the person for whom he stalks in this race," he said.
The ideological differences between the three men showed up most pointedly on issues such as gun control and education, with only Mr. Dinkins speaking out in favor of gun control and Mr. Innis ridiculing the "fourth and fifth R -- rubbers and rainbow" that have dominated the recent Board of Education debates in the city.
But Mr. Dinkins often seemed the most assured and in command of details of governance. Mr. Melendez in particular showed the signs of a political novice, rarely looking at the television camera, stumbling and asking for questions to be repeated.
Asked about the loss of jobs and whether onerous taxes contributed to it, Mr. Dinkins again sought to blame the Republican administrations in Washington for the city's fiscal problems.
Mr. Melendez said the city had to cut taxes drastically and called for 50 percent cuts over the next four years. "In the beginning, we have to suffer," he said. "But in the coming years the level of business will increase and that will create jobs."
He also said the city could boost its economy by promoting tourism, including building a casino in the Rockaways.
Mr. Innis said, "We have a business-unfriendly environment in New York City," and he called for re-examining "all kinds of taxes" to revive the city's economy.

HEADLINE: Clinton Adds to Government to Help Him Subtract

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Sept 9

 BODY:
In his first official act of "reinventing government" into a quicker, slimmer, smarter creature, President Clinton today created -- a new Government entity.
"I am going today, as soon as I finish talking, to sit down here and sign a new order to my Cabinet, to create a Community Enterprise Board from my Cabinet," Mr. Clinton told several thousand people gathered in the parking lot of an inner-city shopping center here. "Not a domestic policy group to tell people what to do, but a Community Enterprise Board." 
 A few minutes later, with the stroke of a Presidential pen, the deed was done. The Community Enterprise Board, led by Vice President Al Gore and peopled by 17 Cabinet Secretaries and Presidential assistants, joined the 1,250 commissions, committees, boards, councils and advisory groups that already sit in various nooks and corners throughout the vast enterprise of Government.
But the birth, as it turned out, may have been a trifle premature. The announcement was intended as today's example of what White House aides call a "Rego event," a public relations spectacle to build support for the White House's campaign to reinvent, that is streamline, the Government. But the explanation of the new board did not make clear what it would actually do or how it would do it. The concept, as Marla Romash, Mr. Gore's press secretary, acknowledged, is a work in progress.
The President said his announcement signaled "a new era in the relationship with the national, the state, and the local governments." But beyond that, Mr. Clinton was vague.
"What is the practical impact of all that?" he said. "It will be for us to identify neighborhoods in trouble all across America. They will say what they want done. Then my Cabinet will sit down and work together and figure out how to do it, not how to tell them to comply with our rules, but how to do what people need done at the local level."
A Presidential memorandum, issued by the White House in coordination with the speech, was only slightly more elaborate. In it, Mr. Clinton said the first task of the board would be "to assist in the successful implementation" of "empowerment zones," economically needy areas that are eligible under the 1993 budget act to receive special Federal aid.
Pressed further, Ms. Romash said the board's overall task would be to "carry the ideas of reinventing Government to the streets." It would serve, she said, as "an enforcement tool," pushing recalcitrant bureaucrats into line with the sweeping goals outlined in the National Performance Review that Mr. Gore announced on Tuesday.
But while the board's mandate is couched in grand terms, its actual design is modest. It has no enforcement powers, no staff, no statutory power to force other entities of the Government into concrete actions.
"There is no money appropriated here, no staff assigned, no physical space involved," Ms. Romash said. "The Cabinet Secretaries will rely on their own staffs."
Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and one of the architects of the new board, described it as a gathering of Cabinet Secretaries and top economic advisers that would meet once a month to coordinate ways to "force" interdepartmental cooperation between Federal agencies on problems as large as housing the homeless and as specific as a 10-square-block redevelopment program in Brooklyn."
"We've found that something like the homeless, for instance, is not solvable just as a Housing problem," he added. "You've got to bring other departments into the mix, Justice and Health and Human Services for mental health and so on."
If this sounds like a lot of work for a once-a-month group with no staff or budget, it is, Mr. Cisneros said.
But not to worry. "I didn't say there's no staff," he hastened to clarify. "I said there would be no new hiring. But my understanding is that the Vice President will take some people from his office who worked on the National Performance Review and apply them to this, and we will have some people from H.U.D. we will dedicate to different projects on this." Indeed, he said, "I think every department is going to do this, assign people to the board's projects as needed."
But, he clarified further, it would be nevertheless wrong to think that this would result in something like a new layer of bureaucracy. "This is just a way to facilitate, to coordinate, to make the departments do things together that they are incapable of doing without some direction," he said. "That should be obvious."

HEADLINE: Where Trouble Is Rare And Governing Is Easy

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUNNYVALE, Calif., Sept. 9

 BODY:
If the Clinton Administration has its way, all of America will operate like this highly computerized, relentlessly self-evaluating city in the heart of Silicon Valley.
Like the kind of efficient and results-oriented operations the Soviet Union failed to achieve with its rigid and often-mocked five-year plans, Sunnyvale's city departments work to meet precisely calculated goals, with the lure of a 10 percent bonus for managers who exceed their targets. 
 By all accounts, the system is working. While the rest of California's economy is foundering, this city has avoided tax increases and municipal layoffs while improving the quality and lowering the costs of public services.
For example, the city promises to remove graffiti in parks or public buildings within two days. It processes building permits within 24 hours. It sets goals for the numbers of miles traveled by city traffic each year without an accident.
 
Administration Recognition
 On Friday, President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore will come here to draw attention to the city of 120,000 that was a model for their plan, presented this week in an effort to streamline government by making it work better and waste less.
The question is whether the huge and unwieldy Federal Government can succeed where the Soviets failed in operating Sunnyvale-style. Here the mantras are "performance-based budgeting" and "results-oriented management," with a network of computers watching in the background.
 
Cautionary Voices

Even the program's boosters, like David Osborne, co-author of "Reinventing Government" (Addison-Wesley, 1992), which serves as a blueprint for the Administration's plan, cautions that it calls for a philosophical shift in governing that will not be easy.
"This is going to be a long, tough slog, even if Congress cooperates," Mr. Osborne said.
Or as City Councilman Larry Stone told The Mercury News in neighboring San Jose: "I fear that people are going to expect that you can take the Sunnyvale model, apply it to the Federal Government, and, zappo! Overnight success. That's not going to happen."
Some residents point out that this is an affluent city with a minimum of the kinds of economic and social ailments that hobble many communities. The city's operating budget this year is $119 million, and projected revenue from taxes, permits, rents and other sources is $149 million. The surplus will go for a variety of projects, including water and parks improvements.
The overwhelmingly white, mostly Democratic city has a median family income of about $53,000. Fewer than 6,000 families were listed as living in poverty.
In this well-tended city with broad green lawns, an elegant community center, a gigantic library and ample parking everywhere, the government seems almost as unobtrusive as the computers that monitor it.
The Sunnyvale model begins with a thorough analysis of the goals of every department and every one of the city's 750 employees. These goals are broken down into "units," which form the basis for departmental targets and are the raw data for the computerized analyses of government operations.
From 1985 to 1990, according to Mr. Osborne's book, as a result of constant re-evaluation and refining of government operations, the cost per unit of city services of all kinds dropped by 20 percent. In 1990 the city's staff was leaner than those of similar cities by 35 to 40 percent, and employees earned more, while the budget was smaller than most and taxes were lower. At the same time Sunnyvale managed to spend $5,200 for each schoolchild, compared with $4,500 in nearby San Francisco.
Long-range planning is another key to the Sunnyvale model, said David Vossbrink, the city's community relations officer. Annual budgets are calculated using 10-year projections, and these are constantly revised, serving as what he called an early-warning signal for fiscal problems ahead.
If, for example, police response time on emergency calls begins to fall, the city can analyze whether an increase in the numbers of calls or other factors are to blame.
 
Seed From Washington
 A Federally sponsored experiment in managing emergency service operations in Sunnyvale about 20 years ago was the seed from which the city's governing style evolved, Mr. Vossbrink said. In an approach that is typical of government operations, from road repair to library services to refuse recycling, he said, the police pledge to respond to 90 percent of emergency calls within five to six minutes.
"The budget has hundreds of examples of such specific service targets," Mr. Vossbrink said. "Our operations are measurable. Managers are held accountable. If they do not meet these goals, explanations are necessary."
Mr. Vossbrink said most of the city's department managers had earned 10 percent bonuses.
One of them is Beverly J. Simmons, director of libraries and information services, who two years took on the added responsibility of heading the city's Information Management Services Department. In the library, operations had been streamlined by automation and had absorbed a 50 percent increase in public use without additional hiring.
Now Ms. Simmons also oversees the production of the computerized analyses of all the other city departments. The four-inch-thick budget that results is a portrait of government services as painted in computer-digestible "units."
For the library, according to the budget printout, a unit can be a borrowed book returned. For the Human Services Department, a proposal evaluated. For the Fire Department, a rescue. Ms. Simmons emphasized that these units were "proxy measurements" for analytical use that were not intended to cover every action of city workers. And she said pains were taken to assure that the paperwork did not become an end in itself, as it did in the Soviet system.

HEADLINE: Germany, Heeding Appeals, Lowers 2 Rates

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Germany's central bank, widely blamed for Europe's monetary chaos and deepening economic recession, went some way toward appeasing its many critics today by lowering its two influential interest rates by half a percentage point each.
The Bundesbank cut its discount rate, which is the cheapest rate for loans to commercial banks, to 6.25 percent from 6.75 percent and it lowered its Lombard rate, the rate for lending emergency funds to banks, to 7.25 percent from 7.75 percent 
 Central banks in Belgium, Italy, Spain and Austria immediately followed the German lead by cutting their main interest rates. France left its key intervention rate, which acts as a floor on money market rates, unchanged at 6.75 percent, but cut its 5-to-10-day lending rate to 7.75 percent from 10 percent
These reductions should help encourage a long-awaited European economic recovery, which is, however, not expected to materialize until next year.
The German central bank said the long-awaited cuts were justified by indications that inflationary pressure in Germany was easing. Concerns over inflation -- which are particularly deep-rooted in Germany because of the trauma of hyperinflation under the Weimar Republic more than 60 years ago -- have been the main reason advanced by the Bundesbank for its reluctance to lower rates more quickly.
 
 
Signs of Diminishing Inflation
 "There have recently been signs of a gradual easing of price increases," the bank said in a statement. Inflation has stabilized in recent months and stood at 4.2 percent in August -- still about double the Bundesbank's medium-term target.
The German rate cuts came six weeks after the Bundesbank precipitated the collapse of the European Monetary System by declining to reduce its discount rate, which effectively sets a floor for loan rates, ahead of its August vacation.
After its decision, the narrow bands under which European currencies had been allowed to fluctuate since 1979 were sharply relaxed and a 15 percent fluctuation margin introduced. In effect, European currencies are now floating.
High German rates, attracting investors to the mark, have placed an acute strain on European economies over the last year by obliging other central banks to apply rates competitive with the Bundesbank's. They have had to follow this policy at a time when many economists argued that a lingering European recession and soaring unemployment necessitated the sort of sharp rate cuts that helped the United States emerge from its last recession.
The German Government, which has repeatedly countered appeals from the United States and its European neighbors for lower rates by pointing to the fact that the Bundesbank is an independent authority, welcomed the cut.
 
A Helping Hand
 "The decision will help to strengthen resurgent powers in the economy that have already become more apparent," Economics Minister Gunter Rexrodt said in a statement.
Finance Minister Theo Waigel went further, suggesting that the Bundesbank was at last extending a helping hand to neighboring countries. "With this decision the Bundesbank is supporting efforts to restore economic growth within and outside Germany," he said.
This week, the Government said that German gross domestic product grew five-tenths of a percent in the second quarter, the first growth since the first quarter of 1992. Because Germany is the world's third-largest economy and by far the largest in Europe, its recovery from the strains created by unification is widely regarded as essential to any wider resurgence of economic activity in Europe.
The discount and Lombard rates have now fallen a total of 2.5 percent since their peak in August 1992. But the reduction has been far slower than Germany's European Community partners had hoped.
 
Stocks Discount Move
 Stock markets in France and Germany, which have soared to record levels in recent months on expectations of lower rates and of a European recovery next year, fell today. Analysts said the German cuts had apparently been discounted. Moreover, they said, no further cuts are expected for some time.
Lower interest rates tend to push investors toward the stock market in search of higher returns. They also tend to spur corporate activity, leading to improved results that should be reflected in higher stock prices.

HEADLINE: Insurers Face Up to Reality on Real Estate Assets

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
When Travelers sold $643 million in real estate to a partnership headed by George Soros two days ago, a little wave of excitement washed over the insurance industry.
Travelers is not alone: The Equitable Companies sold $393 million of real estate in the first six months of this year, almost twice what the company sold in all 1992. The Prudential Insurance Company of America is getting ready to sell up to $700 million of real estate, company officials say. 
 These sales, and others like them, represent a new chapter in the insurance industry's attempts to clean up its collective bottom line, an effort that is being speeded by a new set of regulations that penalize insurers for holding many kinds of real estate and threaten regulatory action if the companies fail to deal with their problem properties and mortgages.
 
New Rules, New Buyers
 While it has been clear for some time that insurers' real estate problems match or even surpass the anguish suffered by the nation's big banks over real estate, many companies that have been unwilling or unable to sell are being pushed in that direction by the new rules. The sales are being further encouraged by another change: the appearance of willing buyers of distressed real estate.
"It's the beginning of a slow-motion shakeout of some of the major players," said Dennis Yeskey, a principal at the accounting firm Kenneth Leventhal & Company who specializes in the insurance industry's real estate assets. "It's happening slowly, but it will accelerate soon because of the new rules."
Insurance companies have $206.7 billion in commercial property loans outstanding, of which $12.7 billion are classified as delinquent, according to the American Council of Life Insurance, a Washington-based industry group. Delinquency rates fell in the second quarter to an average of 6.14 percent, down from 6.86 percent in the first quarter, the council said, but the picture is not all rosy.
Restructurings, which are usually carried out because the borrower cannot pay, were up to 8.32 percent of all commercial loans, from 7.57 percent in the preceding quarter and 5.83 percent in the similar quarter a year earlier, the council said. Foreclosures by life and health insurers in 1992 were up 39.6 percent over the 1991 numbers, according to figures collected by Weiss Research of West Palm Beach, Fla.
While the crash in real estate that followed the overbuilding in the 1980's has already caused an enormous amount of pain at savings and loan institutions and banks, insurance analysts say most companies have yet to disclose the depth of their problems. Exceptions include well-known cases like the Newark-based Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, which was taken over by New Jersey in 1991 after it became insolvent with a portfolio that showed real estate holdings making up a startling 63 percent of its assets.
Many insurers have not been hurt by their strategy of holding real estate and hoping that values come back. But Mr. Yeskey and others say the new nationwide regulatory standards that were adopted in December by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners attach penalties to problem real estate. The rules, known as risk-based capital requirements, require life and health insurers to calculate how much money they need to offset the risks from their assets and operations.
The system assigns the highest risk, and therefore the highest capital requirements, to common stock and to junk bonds, which life insurance companies generally do not hold in great quantities, and to mortgages that are delinquent or in foreclosure. Beyond that, high risk is assigned to any kind of real estate -- foreclosed, investment property or even company-occupied. The least risky assets are investment-grade bonds and performing mortgages. Thus the rules in effect encourage insurance companies to sell real estate or accumulate extra capital to show that they have enough money to cope with risks. The risk-based capital formula must be computed by the end of the year.
Peter Harrington, the spokesman for the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, foresees a move toward sales. "Under the risk-based capital rules, you really get your clock cleaned for investing in real estate," he said.
Many insurance company officials say the new rules will not prompt them to sell unless sales make economic sense, but they also say they expect the rules to affect their competitors' real estate decisions.
At Prudential, John J. Divers, senior vice president and controller of the Prudential Realty Group, said the company's portfolio of foreclosed real estate had risen to around $800 million at midyear, from $543 million at the end of 1992 and $275 million at the end of 1991. Prudential's mortgage and real estate investments total about 32 percent of the company's $108.3 billion in invested assets.
While Prudential is planning a bulk sale, Mr. Divers said: "Our strategy was to lower the level of equity real estate even before the regulations. If we think an investment is good regardless of the risk-based capital requirement, we will hold onto it."
 
'Some Haircuts'
 At Equitable, one of the most active real estate lenders in the life insurance industry, Jerry de St. Paer, the chief financial officer, said, "Yes, there are some haircuts to take" on the risk-based capital rules in real estate. Despite other companies' bulk sales, he said: "We've watched what other people are doing with interest, but we have made a conscious policy not to pursue that strategy. We will lighten our percentage of real estate as economic opportunities present themselves and only that way."
Equitable has a real estate portfolio of $11.7 billion, representing 39.8 percent of its general account assets.
At New England Mutual, mortgages and real estate accounted for 39 percent of assets at the end of 1992, down from 47 percent in 1987 but still above the industry average, which Mr. Harrington said is about 30 percent but which is almost certainly shrinking. He said that the mortgage portfolio had been reduced, but that it had been difficult to bring down the percentage of real estate holdings because sales have been sluggish while foreclosures have continued.
And, while he said that New England plans "to continue to sell property where it makes sense," he added: "It's very hard to bring down your real estate equity in the market unless you engage in a fire sale."
While the New England, like many other companies, is writing no new loans, Principal Mutual, a Des Moines insurer, is picking up the slack. Principal Mutual has $9.1 billion in real estate and mortgages, for a total of 31 percent of assets, with about 50 percent of that in warehouse loans and just 30 percent in the very hard-hit office building market.
Craig R. Barnes, second vice president for commercial real estate at the Principal Financial Group, said the company had about $1 billion in new real estate loan commitments that were not yet on the books. "We think the risk-return opportunities in the mortgage asset class today are as strong as they've ever been," he said.
Another big real estate investor is the Travelers Corporation, which had a $12.7 billion portfolio of mortgages and real estate at the end of June, about 32 percent of its total invested assets. With the Soros sale, Travelers said, the company is left with $4.3 billion in foreclosed real estate and underperforming assets.
 
Willing Customers
 Robert W. Crispin, chief investment officer of Travelers, pointed out that a big factor in the sale was finding a willing buyer. More and more buyers are showing interest in buying distressed real estate. "We believe that liquidity exists in the market," Mr. Crispin said, "and we would like to continue to try to take advantage of it. Therefore you can expect to see additional dispositions."
This process of finding a buyer who gives a price the seller can accept has also affected the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York. Kenneth Levine, chief investment officer, said the company was not planning to sell anything right now but "that could change at any minute."
Mr. Levine said Mutual of New York had entertained presentations from investment bankers who offered to sell real estate and said they had buyers, but he said the company had decided not to sell because "the prices weren't what we wanted."
The regulations have not only caused insurers to look hard at their real estate portfolios but have also raised a debate among industry executives. While few say the rules are bad, some question the process.
"One of the concerns I would have about the whole risk-based capital process is that our customers and our regulators and even ourselves may begin to look at and manage our companies based on how our R.B.C. formula may be generated," Mr. Barnes of Principal said.
Some industry analysts, on the other hand, say the formula is lacking. Martin D. Weiss, president of Weiss Research, pointed out that size was important: a larger company can diversify its risk more effectively than a smaller one. Also, he said, the risk-based capital number does not show trends over time, but rather a snapshot that would not demonstrate things like too-rapid expansion.
Mark Puccia, a senior vice president at Standard & Poor's, said the new rules do not collect enough information. Problem mortgages, for example, are described as those that are 90 days past due, he said, but S.& P. uses a 30-day past-due standard. Further, he said, mortgages that are modified because the borrower cannot pay are not tracked.
Mr. Yeskey, the expert in real estate accounting, said he expected the rules to have effects more far-reaching than just sales of real estate by insurance companies. He predicted that there would be more capital-raising by companies like Travelers; more moves by shareholder-owned mutual companies to go public, as Equitable did last year, and more mergers of smaller, poorer companies with bigger, richer ones.
"I don't believe you are going to see huge insolvencies," he said. "I think you'll see many companies that are on the edge right now, but I don't think they're going to drown."

HEADLINE: Rohatyn to Leave City Watchdog Post

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped engineer New York City's recovery from the brink of bankruptcy 18 years ago and has played Cassandra to free-spending public officials ever since, has submitted his resignation as chairman of the state board that oversees the city's finances and borrows money on its behalf.
Mr. Rohatyn's resignation from the panel, the Municipal Assistance Corporation, came in a letter to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and he took the step on the eve of today's meeting, at which Mayor David N. Dinkins's $30 billion budget for 1993-94 will be reviewed. The agency's board is expected to pronounce the budget balanced, but repeat its periodic reservations about looming deficits. 
 Barring an unexpected change of heart, his resignation will bring to a somewhat anticlimactic end an unusual stint of public service in which Mr. Rohatyn, an unelected private businessman, loomed large over the city's finances and politics.
 
18 Years Is Long Enough
 Three years ago, after a spat with municipal labor leaders, Mr. Rohatyn announced his intention to resign, but was persuaded by Mr. Cuomo not to relinquish the chairmanship. Yesterday, Mr. Rohatyn, 65 years old, declined to comment publicly, but his message to Mr. Cuomo, who appoints the nine-member board, appeared to be unequivocal. There is never a perfect time to step aside, he suggested, but 18 years is long enough and the agency might now be better served by a chairman who -- as Mr. Rohatyn has put it in the past -- still harbors illusions about what is possible in government.
He also suggested that announcing his resignation before the mayoral election makes sense. Mr. Rohatyn has endorsed Mr. Dinkins for a second term. He reasoned that to resign after the November election, if Mr. Dinkins won, might suggest that his endorsement had been disingenuous. If Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, defeated Mr. Dinkins, a resignation then might imply that Mr. Rohatyn was unable to work constructively with Mr. Dinkins's successor.
Mr. Rohatyn cited another reason: the agency board is about to be reconstituted. One member, George M. Brooker, has died; another, Robert C. Weaver, has submitted his resignation, and four new appointees recommended by the Mayor are awaiting confirmation by the State Senate.
 
To Remain an Adviser
 Mr. Cuomo said that Mr. Rohatyn would remain an adviser to the Governor. Asked to assess Mr. Rohatyn's legacy, Mr. Cuomo said: "It would be difficult to exaggerate it. He literally saved the city from bankruptcy."
Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's spokesman, said, "All of us regret that he's going."
For a private citizen, Mr. Rohatyn wielded enormous influence over municipal government, particularly in the years immediately after he was recruited from Wall Street by Gov. Hugh L. Carey when wary bankers closed the credit markets to New York City in 1975. The city's inability to borrow for operating expenses and public works threatened the solvency of the state.
More than a decade later, in 1990 and again in 1992, he remained so much the personification of fiscal stability and the embodiment of the Municipal Assistant Corporation that his very threat to resign was viewed as a verdict on the city and state's creditworthiness. His soft-spoken but unsparing warnings of fiscal doom became as routine as the city's recurring deficits.
Mr. Rohatyn (pronounced ROH-ah-tin) helped create the state-chartered Municipal Assistance Corporation to borrow on the city's behalf, then transformed the agency into a cash cow that generated upward of $3.5 billion, through surpluses and refinancing, for education, mass transit and economic development. It was an agenda that he largely set himself.
Critics sometimes assailed his approach as high-handed and questioned whether Mr. Rohatyn, as an unelected fiscal monitor, should have so large a role in determining public priorities and dispensing public funds.
As a result of his periodic criticism of city budgets and his efforts to hold sway over how the money was spent, built-in friction with one mayor after another occasionally flared into open warfare, particularly with Edward I. Koch, who said that Mr. Rohatyn was usurping mayoral prerogatives.
Few critics ever questioned Mr. Rohatyn's motives, but he often expressed frustration in understanding their criticism. "When people ask, 'Who elected Felix?' " he once said, "The answer is that the politicians did, because they needed somebody to do this."
For a glib and debonair Wall Street financier, a senior partner of Lazard Freres & Company, he forged an unusual if episodic alliance with the gritty leaders of New York's public employee unions, who also were skilled at negotiating but, in the agency's early years, were not bargaining from strength.
When he last announced his resignation, he said he hoped to fulfill a personal commitment to the city by pursuing other civic ventures, helping to advance the public-education agenda set by his wife, Elizabeth, through her roles as the vice chairwoman of Thirteen/WNET and as a trustee of the New York Public Library.

HEADLINE: Fight Vowed By Giuliani On Narcotics

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Returning to his campaign theme of a city out of control under an administration that is out of touch, Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that if elected mayor, he would crack down on small-time drug dealers, create safe zones around city schools and do away with "swirling masses of garbage" left behind by illegal vendors whom he accused of turning city streets into "vast flea markets."
Using the theme of "term of indifference," he elaborated on issues he has raised throughout the campaign and then said Mayor David N. Dinkins's nearly four years in office had been marked by "a detached reaction to the disorder that is driving the city down." 
 As a result, he said, New Yorkers' lives have become infused with "a sense of dread."
 
Angry Reaction
 His remarks, made at a speech at the Sheraton New York in midtown, immediately drew angry reaction from the Dinkins campaign. The Mayor's aides said the speech ignored steps the administration had taken -- like toughening measures against illegal street peddling. They called Mr. Giuliani's program "arrestonomics" and said the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor lacked compassion.
"Blinded by the prospect of residing in Gracie Mansion," the Dinkins campaign said in a statement, "Mr. Giuliani is unable to find anything positive in this city to talk about."
Mr. Giuliani suggested that he would step up law-enforcement efforts in such areas as arresting aggressive "squeegee" men. He also reiterated that he would push for capital punishment for major drug dealers convicted of murder.
In his third major address on city problems, he spoke at length about the daily irritations faced by most New Yorkers and criticized Mr. Dinkins as a Mayor "who to this day has said nothing of what he is going to do differently than what he is doing today."
In Mr. Giuliani's earlier speeches he had touched on the city's economic problems and on its educational failures. As in those speeches, however, Mr. Giuliani yesterday was more thorough in detailing problems than in offering answers. He skirted some of the more difficult and costly social issues facing the next city administration, choosing to speak only briefly on the problems of homelessness, for example, to emphasize instead a vision of a city with raised morale and a higher set of standards.
Praising the Cuomo Commission report on homelessness, he said the city should be "steering people to the correct programs in the not-for-profit, private, religious sector."
Under Mayor Dinkins, he said mockingly, "the commission did the report -- then a panel was appointed to study what the commission had already recommended." Then, he said, the Mayor "seized on the one point of the report that I guess to his administration made sense, a new agency."
 
To Follow Recommendations
 Mr. Giuliani said he would immediately follow the recommendations of the report. "I just need the people I appoint to government to implement what has to be done," he said. "And we will start on Day One."
Mr. Giuliani did not say a word about what those programs would cost or precisely how they would be structured. Nor did he say whether new programs would be needed. He also said nothing about the ticklish question of local resistance to homeless shelters and services, a problem that has scuttled several major projects in the past. He spoke of "mutual obligations" borne by the homeless, like participation in drug treatment programs.
The Dinkins campaign said Mr. Giuliani was out of touch. It said the administration has already moved toward using nonprofit organizations to deal with the homeless.
As a general campaign strategy, Mr. Giuliani has used these addresses to reiterate city failures and elaborate on continuing campaign themes. Yesterday he made more promises than usual.
Among them were these:
*To sign an executive order on Jan. 1, 1994, that would instruct the police to arrest any person selling or buying drugs on city streets.
*To shift responsibility for school safety from the Board of Education to the city's Police Department and then charge the police with creating a two-block crime-free, drug-free zone for children entering and leaving each of the city's schools.
*To arrest panhandlers and "squeegee men" if they use intimidation and threats of bodily harm that could be legally classified as assault.
He also pledged to fine and then confiscate the goods of about 10,000 illegal vendors choking city streets and sidewalks.

HEADLINE: Stocks Halt Two-Day Slump; Dow Up 0.56

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The stock market staged a modest recovery yesterday on some good economic news, including a drop in first-time unemployment claims, ending two days of bloodletting that had knocked 45 points off the Dow Jones industrial average.
Stocks of banks, auto makers and technology companies did well. The recovery was particularly strong in the over-the-counter market, where the companies are generally smaller. 
 The Dow industrials gained a scant 0.56 point, closing at 3,589.49, but some other indexes fared better. "The Dow doesn't really tell the picture of what happened today," Stephen Van Brunt, head of trading at Nikko Securities, said.
The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks closed up a strong 6.98 at 737.71, while the American Stock Exchange composite was up 2.30, to 453.38. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 0.85, to 457.50.
Trading volume on the Big Board was 258.1 million shares, down from 283.1 million on Wednesday.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the number of Americans filing first-time unemployment claims last week fell to the lowest level in more than four years. In response, bond prices -- which tend to react negatively to news of an improving economy -- fell for the first time in eight sessions. The Government also reported yesterday that American companies planned to increase spending on new plants and equipment this year by 7.1 percent, which would be the biggest gain in four years.
Mr. Van Brunt said the jobless claims report offered "the first decent number we've had in a long time, although it's not confirmation that the economy's coming back." He said the bond market's decline also affected the stock market.
Robert G. Freedman, president and chief investment officer of John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston, noted that the summer rally has been particularly strong for over-the-counter stocks, and that they were hit hard in the two days of selling. Yesterday's recovery was also stronger for the Nasdaq, Mr. Freedman said, adding that he expects more to come.
"I'm still very strong on the stock market, especially growth-oriented stocks," he said.
 
Good News for Banks
 Among the biggest gainers were bank stocks, which rose on expectations of strong third-quarter earnings and sunny assessments from several analysts. Citicorp gained 1 3/4, to 35 3/8; J. P. Morgan was up 1 3/4, to 77 5/8; Chemical Banking was up 2 1/8, to 43 1/8, and Bankers Trust was up 1 1/2, to 81 3/4.
Technology issues also rose, led by Intel, up 1 3/4, to 64 3/4, on an announcement that it would work with MCI Communications on integrating personal computers and telephones. Applied Materials, which makes wafer fabrication equipment for the semiconductor industry, gained 2 3/4, to 68, after it announced a 2-for-1 stock split. Microsoft was up 1 3/4, to 76 1/4.
Among the auto makers, Ford announced that it planned to raise its vehicle prices by an average of 2.2 percent for 1994. It closed up 1 3/8, to 52 7/8. Chrysler gained 3/4, to 43 1/2, and General Motors was up 1 1/4, to 46.
Some drug stocks also rose. The American depository receipts of Glaxo Holdings, the British pharmaceutical company, were up 1 3/8, to 19 1/2, on better-than-expected earnings.
Some gold stocks recouped losses of a few days ago, including Sunshine Mining, up 3/8, to 2 1/2; Newmont Gold, up 1 1/8, to 41, and Newmont Mining, up 1 3/8, to 46 3/4.
Airline stocks also gained, with UAL, the parent of United Airlines, up 1 5/8, to 142 5/8, and Southwest Airlines up 1 3/4, to 34 1/8. Federal Express gained 1 1/8, to 56 3/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Yield Jumps To 5.96% as the Rally Pauses

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After a stunning rally that took the yields on long-term Treasury securities to their lowest levels in 25 years, the bond market paused yesterday for a bout of selling that knocked the price of the 30-year bond down almost one and a half points and sent its yield up to 5.96 percent.
But traders and analysts said this retreat was not yet a signal that the rally was over. Instead, it appeared to be just a chance for investors to catch their breath and lock in some profits. The selloff also sent short-term and intermediate rates higher. 
 "The fundamentals are still in place for lower bond yields," Edward McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. These fundamentals include low inflation and slow economic growth, as well as a strong demand for Treasury bonds and notes by investors seeking higher yields and by cities and towns that need them for the escrow funds used to pay off the old high interest rate debt they are refinancing.
The price of the 6.25 percent 30-year bond was down 114/32 points. The 5.96 percent yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped up from 5.86 percent Wednesday. The yield on the 10-year note climbed to 5.34 percent, from 5.22 percent, while the yield on the 2-year note ended at 3.86 percent, up from 3.74 percent.
 Yesterday's selling was not set off by anything that would disturb the positive economic backdrop for interest rates. Instead, it was started by a rumor, which was then denied, that the Clinton Administration was considering imposing a withholding tax on the interest earned by foreigners on United States securities. The rumor, which some traders said began circulating in Tokyo, apparently grew out of an announcement that Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York City, was holding a hearing on such a bill in two weeks.
The fact that a rumor of legislation, which many traders quickly dismissed as unlikely, could spark such selling is an indication of the nervousness of many traders and investors, with prices this high and yields this low. But it does not mean that the buying will not resume. "We are already starting to see buyers at these levels for two- and five-year notes," Ronald Connors, Government trading manager at Bear, Stearns & Company, said. The rumor, he said, "was just an excuse to sell."
The selling, most of which occurred in the morning, was accelerated when the Government reported the initial unemployment claims dropped by 10,000, to 316,000, last week. Market forecasters were expecting an increase, and the 316,000 level was the lowest since June 1989.
"And all of a sudden, we had a good old fashioned selloff," Mr. Connors said.
 
 
Healthy Spin
 Many traders and analysts put a healthy spin on the selloff, saying that it was a natural correction that a market needs after a big rally. In addition, with prices lower, it will give some investors who may have missed part of the price rise an opportunity to get back into the market at a lower cost.
But the spin will continue to sound good only if today's inflation report on producer prices in August is as positive as forecasters expect it too be. The fact that inflation, which was rising at a 4 percent pace earlier this year, is now up just 2.8 percent through July, is one of the main reasons that the yield on the bond fell to a 25-year low of 5.86 percent on Wednesday.
Forecasters are predicting a two-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Producer Price Index for finished goods. If the increase is much larger, then the nervousness that prompted selling on a rumor yesterday could get worse when confronted with a shift in the economic fundamentals that have been underlying the rally.
 
 
Foreign Bonds
 Bonds prices were down and yields were up in European bond markets yesterday after the German central bank cut its two key interest rate benchmarks by half a percentage point each.
In London, the yield on the 10-year gilt was up to 6.80 percent, from 6.77 percent Wednesday, while the yield on the 10-year note in Paris was up to 6.14 percent, from 6.11 percent. The French Government only made a minor cut in rates in response to German move. In Frankfurt, the price of the 10-year bond future was was down 0.13 point at 98.39.
John Beck, an assistant director at Fiduciary Trust International in London, said that there was no rally yesterday because prices had already moved higher in anticipation of an interest rate cut by the Bundesbank.
"Bond markets have been doing so well recently that it was buy on the rumor and sell on the fact," he said.
He added that the sharp selloff in the United States also probably had some impact in Europe.
As for what happens next, it is possible that markets will consolidate for a while. With this cut now history, the next move by the Bundesbank is off in the future, giving traders and investors little to focus on. There were also indications in both Germany and France that the downward trend in interest rates would continue to be slow.
But Mr. Beck added that a pause did not mean the European rally was finished. "There is not as much to look forward to in the near future," he said. "But that does not mean it's over."

HEADLINE: Capital Spending Rises While Productivity Falls

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
American companies plan to increase investment spending on new plants and equipment by 7.1 percent this year, the best showing in four years, the Government reported today.
But in a separate report, the Government said the productivity of American workers fell at a 1.3 percent annual rate from April through June, marking the first back-to-back declines in nearly three years. 
 Businesses surveyed by the Commerce Department in July and August said they would spend $585.2 billion in 1993 on erecting and modernizing buildings and factories, installing new computers and installing new equipment and machinery.
That number represented a slight upward revision from an April-May survey, which found companies planning a 6.4 percent increase in spending. If the companies' plans are realized, it will be the best showing for investment spending since an 11.4 percent jump in 1989.
 
 
Doubling Last Year's Gain
 A 7.1 percent increase would be more than double last year's increase of 3.4 percent. In 1991, when the country was pulling out of a recession, plant and equipment spending fell by eight-tenths of a percent.
The latest survey confirmed other statistics that showed business capital spending as one of the bright spots in the economy this year.
Companies, trying to meet global competition, have been quicker to increase spending on new equipment to improve productivity than to rehire laid-off workers.
Employment in the manufacturing sector has been falling steadily for most of this year. But today's report showed that manufacturers of durable goods still planned to increase investment spending by a sharp 10.4 percent this year.
 That gain was paced by a huge 39.5 percent increase in investment planned by auto makers.
 
 
Weakness in Oil and Rubber
 Manufacturers of nondurable goods -- items not expected to last at least three years -- were forecasting a 1.7 percent decline in investment this year, with the weakness led by a planned 17.1 percent drop by rubber manufacturers. Oil companies were forecasting a 3.2 percent decline in investment. Over all, manufacturers of both durable and nondurable goods planned a 3.4 percent increase, up from a 2.5 percent projection in the April-May survey.
Meanwhile, the Labor Department said the seasonally adjusted 1.3 percent drop in productivity -- defined as output per number of hours worked -- followed a 1.8 percent decrease from January through March. It was the first back-to-back loss since productivity fell during the final two quarters of 1990.
Productivity in both quarters this year was revised in today's report. It was estimated earlier to have fallen 1.6 percent in the first quarter and 2.5 percent in the second.
The productivity drop in the first quarter had been the first since a drop of six-tenths of a percent in the final quarter of 1990.
Bucking the overall decline, manufacturing productivity jumped 5.2 percent, including a 7.7 percent jump in factories that make long-lasting goods like automobiles and appliances. Productivity in the nondurable sector rose 1.9 percent. Total business productivity, including farming, fell 1 percent, compared with a 1.6 percent drop in the first three months.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Sinks Despite Cuts In German Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar sank against the German mark and other currencies yesterday, even though Germany's central bank cut interest rates. The long-awaited move by the Bundesbank raised expectations of an economic recovery in Germany.
In New York, the dollar fell to 1.6000 marks late yesterday from 1.6128 marks on Wednesday. It also slipped to 105.33 Japanese yen from 105.50. 
 Gold continued to bounce back a bit from Tuesday's sharp selloff. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery gained $2.90 an ounce, to $354.80.
The Bundesbank announced yesterday that it was cutting its discount rate, the cheapest rate for loans to commercial banks, to 6.25 percent from 6.75 percent, and its Lombard rate, the rate for lending emergency funds to banks, to 7.25 percent from 7.75 percent.
 
Spurs Mark Buying
 Normally, such a move might prompt a selloff in the mark, since mark-denominated investments will earn less. But instead, the rate cut spurred investors to buy marks and sell dollars.
"You're going to have better numbers coming out of Germany, and more reason to buy the mark," said Arnold Sherrer, chief trader at the Royal Bank of Canada's office in New York.
He and other traders said the lower interest rates could further stimulate Germany's economy, which appears to be emerging from recession. As confidence in the German economy rises, investors will probably buy more marks because investment opportunities in Germany will increase. That makes the mark more valuable.
At the same time, prospects for a strong American recovery appear to be slipping after a series of weak economic data released recently, they said.
"There was a 180-degree turn" in investors' expectations recently about the United States and German economies, said Angelo Evangelista, a vice president at the Bank of Boston. He said large investment funds contributed to the selloff of the dollar as they hedged their European stock and bond investments.
Central banks in Belgium, Italy, Spain and Austria also cut rates, following the Germans. European currencies rose across the board against the dollar, following the mark, the dominant European currency.
