HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
As the gay and lesbian market grows, a boom in catalogues that are 'out, loud and proud.'

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AS more gay men and lesbians become open about their sexual identities, they are being asked to fill their recently vacated closets with merchandise from an increasing number of catalogue marketers addressing them as homosexuals.
Offerings aimed at gay men and lesbians are developing into a nascent niche in the nation's estimated $54.7 billion catalogue industry. Slick brochures with names like Made in Gay America, Proud Enterprises and Shocking Gray carry items from leather jackets and "pride" flags to K. D. Lang recordings and T-shirts bearing such slogans as "I can't even think straight." 
 "It's merchandise with a message," said Paula Xanthopoulou, who with her life partner, Wendy Reiner, operates Proud Enterprises in New York.
Sean Strub, president of the Strub Media Group of New York, which specializes in the gay and lesbian market, said: "Part of 'coming out' is self-expression. And part of self-expression in 1993 is wearing caps and T-shirts and jewelry that say who you are."
"Yet while you now can come out in North Liberty, Iowa, you can't go to the Younkers department store and find" gay- and lesbian-related products, he added. "So a lot of people come out in their mailboxes."
The catalogues typify two trends. One is the continuing segmentation of the once-mass consumer market as advertisers aim sales pitches at narrower groups for reasons of economy and efficiency.
The other is the growing appeal of an affluent, educated gay and lesbian market to consumer-product companies. For instance, the October-November issue of Out magazine will carry an Apple Computer Powerbook advertisement by BBDO Los Angeles -- the first for a high-tech marketer in a publication aimed at gay men and lesbians.
"When it comes down to the dollar, a lot of homophobia disappears," said J. Michael Boone, who publishes Made in Gay America in New York, a catalogue featuring models like Norman Korpi, the gay roommate on MTV's "The Real World," and Joseph C. Steffan, the midshipman forced to resign from the Naval Academy after acknowledging his homosexuality.
Most companies involved in the embryonic catalogue boomlet are small gay- and lesbian-owned businesses, mailing a fraction of the millions of brochures produced by the mainstream catalogue titans.
Some giants, though, are making forays into the field. Hanover Direct Inc. of Weehawken, N.J., a leading catalogue marketer with titles like International Male, Gump's and Essence by Mail, has tested H.I.M., a self-described "out, loud and proud" catalogue "where closets are for clothing." And Time Warner Inc. is selling Triangle Classics -- a series of books with gay and lesbian themes -- in fliers that accompany mailings to members of its Book-of-the-Month Club and Quality Paperback Book Club.
By coming out of the closet, gay men and lesbians identify themselves. That brings sales pitches aimed at homosexuals in the same way ads are aimed at bowlers, collectors of Coca-Cola memorabilia and dog breeders.
"The availability of mailing lists is the No. 1 most important thing to having a successful catalogue," said David Alport, publisher of Out & About, a New Haven travel newsletter for gay men and lesbians. "And now there's a growing resource of viable names for lists available in data bases." Mr. Strub estimated that about a million gay and lesbian households could be reached through various lists.
For all that, the fledgling field has its problems.
"There are people who totally freak out if they get something and they're not gay," said Mr. Strub, who has compiled a sort of reverse mailing list of almost 100,000 complainers.
And finding the right product mix can be tricky. Virtually all shy from sexually explicit merchandise because of its potentially offensive nature (or, more practically, because hundreds of established mail-order marketers specialize in adult films and sex toys). So in most catalogues, so-called visibility items -- freedom rings, which have pink triangles and lambda symbols, "queer pride" refrigerator magnets, his and his (or hers and hers) towels -- predominate.
"But you can't fill up a closet with pink triangle T-shirts," Ms. Xanthopoulou said. She and Ms. Reiner are considering an even more narrow specialty: selling merchandise in conjunction with Stonewall 25, next year's 25th anniversary of the riots at the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village, which are considered the start of the gay-rights movement.
After catalogues, what? Several gay and lesbian entrepreneurs are considering home-shopping programs on local cable television systems.
That could bring a whole new meaning to the "Q" in QVC.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims at a Low

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly dropped by 10,000 last week to the lowest level in more than four years, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 316,000, down from a revised 326,000 for the week that ended on Aug. 28. The original Aug. 28 estimate was 324,000. 
 It was the lowest level of initial claims since 314,000 were filed for the week that ended June 3, 1989. Many economists had predicted before the report that claims would be up last week by about 6,000.
The less volatile four-week moving average of claims, which analysts prefer to track because it more accurately reflects the labor situation, also fell to a four-year low. The average totaled 324,250, down from 328,000 for the period that ended Aug. 28 and the lowest since the average was 322,500 for the period ended Sept. 23, 1989.

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Sales of United States Savings Bonds tumbled 44 percent, to $818 million, in August from $1.47 billion in August 1992, reflecting lower interest rates. For the year to date, savings bond sales are up 43 percent, at $16.52 billion, compared with a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Posters: Populist Art For the Collector

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
THE poster started out in life in humble circumstances. Before the age of radio and television, it was an important medium for getting a message across to the broad public, especially on the streets of large cities. The mandate was clear and simple. "They were designed specifically to appeal to people," said Jack Rennert, a poster dealer in Manhattan and the author of more than 20 books on poster art. "They had to have a graphically interesting way of grabbing your attention, otherwise they couldn't sell that beer, or fill that concert hall."
The values of simplicity and immediacy continue to attract poster collectors a century after the dynamic, colorful posters of Jules Cheret, the father of the poster, first appeared on the streets of Paris. They are a populist art form that somehow never learned to be snooty, even in the hands of masters like Pierre Bonnard, Henri Toulouse-Lautrec, Leonetto Cappiello, A. M. Cassandre or Alphonse Mucha. 
 "There's a wonderful egalitarian spirit about them, even those that were done by the best artists of the day," said Bret Marcus, a news producer at ABC. "It really was an art for everyman."
The prices remain reasonable. Although it is no longer possible to pick up a Toulouse-Lautrec for $300, as was the case before 1960, it is possible to buy posters by important artists for $400 or $500, a tiny fraction of the cost of paintings of comparable quality.
And the poster market is steady and sensible. When the market for paintings boomed in the early 1980's, posters showed healthy increases in value. When the painting market crashed, in the late 80's, posters, again, showed healthy increases in value.
"I must say, during this whole recession, it never occurred to us that there was a recession," said Louis Bixenman, a co-owner of Posters America, a gallery in Chelsea. "We picked up business, in fact."
Gary Fishbein, a 39-year-old jewelry designer who lives in Manhattan, is a fairly typical collector. Several years ago he walked by the Chisholm Gallery in Manhattan and saw some 1890's posters by the illustrator Sargent Kendall advertising an issue of Scribner's Magazine. The price was less than $100. He bought two. Now he has 14 posters, many of them by Edward Penfield, the art director of Harper's in the 1890's, who produced an advertising poster every month to promote the magazine.
"What drew me to them is that they were immediate and direct, but they are also very evocative, and not just stylistically," said Mr. Fishbein. "You really get a sense of what people aspired to. It's almost like looking into the heart of an era."
David Samuels, the owner of the Blue Ribbon Fish Company, a wholesaler in the Fulton Fish Market, began looking at posters after taking some optional art classes in college. Then, like virtually every poster collector, he chose his theme: fish.
His collection of 30 posters includes a fish-filled Art Deco poster by Cassandre for Le Prunier, a Paris restaurant, and a 1926 poster by Jean Carlu for the Monaco Aquarium, featuring a simplified, almost childlike rendering of an ocean sunfish. Most of his posters cost less than $1,000, although the Cassandre is now worth about $45,000.
Mr. Samuels is picky. He does not like posters showing fishermen, especially fishermen holding up huge salmon. "I sell five tons of salmon a day, so I'm not interested," he said. "I have an interest in fish for eating, so I tend toward restaurant posters or travel posters that stress the culinary aspect of fish."
Fish is an unusual category, and Mr. Samuels has been able to find some real bargains as a result. More established catgories include bicycles, motorcycles, trains, airplanes, racing cars, Shell oil advertisements, travel and the circus.
"I have people that ask for posters of feet or shoes," said Philip Williams, the owner of Philip Williams Posters in SoHo. "There's a tank collector, who actually has tanks on his farm, and now, because of the 50th anniversary of the Normandy invasion, I'm getting interest in war posters and airborne posters."
 
Look, Study, Learn
 Dealers and collectors have the same words of advice for beginners who want to make an acquisition: look, study and learn before buying a first poster. In this respect, New Yorkers operate at an advantage.
Twice a year, in the fall and spring, Mr. Rennert holds a poster auction in which about 500 posters are put on public view and then sold. The auction, which will be held on Nov. 14 in Manhattan after two days of public viewing, presents high-end material, with an average sale price of about $3,500. Three years ago, Toulouse-Lautrec's 1891 poster for the Moulin Rouge fetched $220,000, a record auction price for a poster.
"That sale is not an entry point," said Mr. Williams, "but it is a place to buy the catalogue, see the posters, check the prices, and see the differences in conditions."
For each auction, Mr. Rennert produces a catalogue with a photograph of each poster, accompanied by a brief description and a complete sales history. Virtually every serious collector acquires a complete set of the catalogues, which now total 16 volumes.
 
Dealers From Abroad
 Another opportunity to take a comprehensive look at the poster field is the International Vintage Poster Fair, held twice yearly at the St. Moritz Hotel in Manhattan. The event, which takes place on Oct. 30 and 31, attracts about 20 dealers from all over the world, with posters in a wide range of styles and prices.
Generally, collectors can find a poster with artistic merit, usually contemporary, for $40. In the $400 to $500 range, it is possible to buy a poster with some age and historical interest, and at $2,000 recognizable names begin to pop up, although prime examples by the finest artists run in the tens of thousands of dollars.
The would-be collector who wants a good overview of the subject runs into difficulties when it comes to reference works. There is no single book that provides a comprehensive survey of the history of the poster. Rather, books tend to concentrate on the work of a single artist, or on a specialized subject area, like bicycle posters or Swiss hotel posters.
A third way to learn is to make the rounds of the poster galleries, and to talk to the dealers. Manhattan has a good half-dozen poster galleries, each with its own specialties. La Belle Epoque Gallery concentrates on French posters of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, as does the Park South Gallery at Carnegie Hall. Posters America specializes in avant-garde posters of the 1920's to the 40's, while Meehan Military Posters, as the name suggests, is devoted to recruiting and propaganda posters of the two world wars.
 
Posters vs. Prints
 Collectors who are familiar with the print market often make a fundamental error about posters. They assume that because posters were printed in the tens of thousands they are less rare than, say, a signed and numbered run of 100 prints.
This is seldom the case. Virtually every poster in a run wound up pasted to a wall or kiosk and eventually was destroyed. When posters did survive, it was because a printer or the printer's client saved extra copies, or a collector approached either the printer or the client for copies.
The Art Nouveau poster is well represented today because Paris and London were gripped by poster fever -- affichomanie in French -- in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when Europe, especially Paris, abounded in dealers, collectors and printed references works and magazines.
The fever cooled after World War I, and as a result, an Art Deco poster from 1930 can be a rarer find than a poster from 1895.
In general, value depends on the rarity of the piece, the reputation of the artist and the artistic merits of the poster. Condition is an important factor, and most dealers, following the practice of Mr. Rennert's auction catalogues, will refer to a poster's condition as being between A (very fine) and D (bad). If a poster is rare enough, rarity will outweigh condition in establishing a price.
 
Star Power
 The major exception is American film posters, a category in which value is determined by the popularity of the star and the film rather than graphic quality. The poster for "Casablanca" is not an artistic triumph, but it will fetch $20,000.
Some dealers find this annoying. "The guy who would pay $20,000 for the 'Casablanca' poster would pay $35,000 for the shoes Humphrey Bogart wore during the filming," said Mr. Rennert.
For those who share Mr. Rennert's feelings, there are dealers who ferret out European and Latin American posters of American films. The Chisolm Prats Gallery in Chelsea currently is devoting one of its two front windows to a display of foreign posters of Elizabeth Taylor movies.
Some collectors proceed methodically, cultivating a network of dealers they trust, staking out a subject area and then acquiring, step by step. The tennis star Ivan Lendl decided he liked the work of Alphonse Mucha, a fellow Czech, and set about building a major collection of the artist's work.
Marvin R. Shanken, the president of Shanken Communications, the publisher of the Wine Spectator and the Cigar Aficionado magazines, began collecting turn-of-the-century Champagne and liqueur posters. In the past 10 years, he has built one of the world's top collections of Art Nouveau posters, totaling 1,000 works.
The prize is an 1899 poster by Jacques Villon for the American bar at a Paris cafe called Le Grillon (The Cricket). The poster, which shows an angular, vampirish-looking patron of the bar, glass in hand, hangs in Mr. Shanken's office next to a celebrated poster of the cancan dancer Jane Avril by Toulouse-Lautrec.
"Much as I like the Lautrec, I could live without it," said Mr. Shanken, who bought the Villon at auction in 1989 for $75,000. He was prepared to pay $300,000. "It was a sickness," he said. "I had to have an assistant walk me around the block several times before the auction so I could calm down. I mean, if I hadn't gotten that poster, I might have killed myself."
 
Leisurely Approach
 Other collectors proceed in more leisurely fashion. Mr. Marcus, for example, bought his first poster in the mid-70's to fill space on a blank apartment wall. "I was ready to move up from first-apartment art but didn't have money for really serious art," he said. Like many first-time buyers, he gravitated to Art Nouveau.
About eight years ago, however, he began collecting posters of the British railways and the London underground, but he has made room for a couple of bicycle posters as well.
"My collection has certainly increased a lot in value, but that's not why I put it together," he said. "You have to love the art."
The art still lives, although radio and then television dealt the poster a powerful blow.
 
Bargain Hunting
 Collectors looking for bargains can find them in the contemporary market. "For a really good contemporary poster, a couple of thousand would be the top in the postwar period," said Susan Reinhold, the co-owner of the Reinhold-Brown Gallery in Manhattan. "As little as $50 can buy a very good poster."
The gallery recently mounted a show of posters by the Swiss designers Siegfried Odermatt and Rosemary Tissi, who created a limited-edition poster for the exhibition that sold for $75.
Bannin & Associates has posters by the German Conceptual artist Joseph Beuys for as little as $150.
"There are interesting things as cheap as $40 or $50," said Mr. Williams, "and I've got lots of things at $15 or $20."
A persisent collector can do even better. Mr. Rennert, who started out collecting advertising posters for Levy's rye bread, always keeps an eye out for an arresting image in the subway, or plastered on plywood at a construction site. If he finds one, he'll look for the name of the printer, the artist or the advertising agency on the poster and make a few inquiries.
"Usually, they'll give you a couple of copies for free just to get rid of you," he said. "It's all well and good to collect posters from the turn of the century and the 20's and 30's," he added, "but at the same time you ought to look around you."

HEADLINE: Baker Could Play for Jets

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Approve Realignment Of Divisions

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Barring a breakdown in negotiations with the union over the players' share of playoff money, major league baseball will sport a new look for 1994: three divisions in each league and a new round of playoffs in October.
The alignment of the National League remained unsettled, but the owners of both leagues voted, 27-1, today to adopt the new format and replace the two-division setup that has existed since 1969. The Texas Rangers, who don't like the three-division setup, an extra post-season round or their placement in the American League's new Western Division, cast the lone dissenting vote. 
 "We're hoping it will enhance and maintain fan interest through the end of the season," said John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, chairman of the schedule format committee.
 
'Plusses Far Outweigh Minuses'
 Asked whether the new system could hurt fan interest, Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers, the acting commissioner, said: "Time will tell. We believe our research, which is ample, shows that the plusses far outweigh the minuses."
The American League alignment will have the Yankees, Baltimore, Boston, Detroit and Toronto in the East Division; Chicago, Cleveland, Kansas City, Milwaukee and Minnesota in the Central and California, Oakland, Seattle and Texas in the West.
The only set division in the National League is the West: Colorado, Los Angeles, San Diego and San Francisco. Chicago, Cincinnati, Houston and St. Louis will be in the Central with one other team, and the Mets, Montreal and Philadelphia will be in the East with two other teams.
The unsettled teams are Atlanta, Florida and Pittsburgh. The Braves want to be in the East, but the Pirates won't budge from that division. At the owners' meeting at the Four Seasons Hotel today, Wayne Huizenga of the Marlins offered to have his team move to the Central. But one of the primary reasons the Braves wanted to be in the East was to develop a rivalry with the Marlins.
 
A Week to Decide
 The Marlins will most likely wind up in the Central with the Braves and the Pirates in the East, but the league has a week to decide the alignment.
During that time, too, Harrington and Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, will begin negotiations in earnest with the Players Association, which must approve the new format and new playoff round. They have had one meeting and one conference call, but they have not discussed how and what the players will be paid for the post-season games.
"We still have the matter of economics to resolve, but I'm optimistic," Harrington said.
Eugene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, who has led the negotiations, said the basis for an agreement is in place, but he added: "Obviously, we have to discuss economics and there may be some stumbling blocks there. But I don't think that will be a major problem."
 
Both Sides Optimistic
 Because advertising revenue in the new television contract will be based on the number of games played in each post-season series, the union may ask for the players' pool to include revenue from each game instead of the first four games of each series, which has been the practice.
Because more teams will be in the playoffs, the two sides will most likely have to adjust the way shares are computed for the competing teams. Despite the optimism expressed by both sides, the owners have yet to hear the players' proposal on shares.
Harrington said that once the negotiating committee reaches agreement with the union, the 28 club owners will have to approve the final deal.
To make today's vote official, the clubs had to agree unanimously to waive the provision that requires 20 days' notice for this type of matter to be acted on at an owners' quarterly meeting. The Rangers went along with the other 27 on that vote.
The resolution called for the new alignment to be used for a minimum of four years or for the length of the next collective bargaining agreement, whichever term is longer. The format also is to be based on a balanced schedule, under which each team plays two home series and two road series against each other, regardless of division.
 
Veto Right Waived
 In the two four-team divisions, teams will play only about one-fourth of their games against division opponents and the remaining three-fourths against teams in the other divisions.
The three unsettled N.L. teams waived their veto right to block realignment, meaning they will not object wherever they wind up. It seemed highly unlikely that the league would bump the Pirates from the East.
"We have mutual competitive alliances with Philadelphia, Montreal and New York," said Douglas Danforth, the Pirates' board chairman. "We feel it would negatively impact our gate and our television revenue."
Huizenga left the hotel before his offer to change divisions was disclosed, and he was not available for comment. However, his thinking very likely was similar to that of Richard Jacobs, owner of the Indians, who Wednesday agreed to switch to the Central Division and allow the Tigers to remain in the East.
The new playoff format will consist of three division champions and a wild card team, the non-championship team with the best won-loss record, in each league. In the first round, the wild-card team would play the team with the better record of the two champions not from its division.
The first round will be a three-of-five series. The first two games will be played at one site, the wild card team's park in one instance and the other determined by a rotation system. The last three games will be played at the opposing team's park.
 
TV, Radio Pacts Approved
 Major league club owners approved a six-year, $255 million cable deal with ESPN and a six-year, $50.5 milliondeal with CBS Radio.
The agreement with ESPN, down from four years for $403 million, calls for a reduction in games from 175 to about 75. The schedule provides for Wednesday night doubleheaders and Sunday night single games. It adds a Sunday night game as the season opener, ahead of the usual Monday openers. That game next season will be scheduled for April 3.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 576 words

HEADLINE: Only the Multinationals Win in Free Trade Pact

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The North American Free Trade Agreement will be a disaster for this country and especially its working people if the Clinton Administration insists on supporting what is basically a flawed investment agreement. 
 The American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations believes that international trade can benefit the American economy. But we don't believe in the free trade agreement because, even with the collateral agreements negotiated by the Clinton Administration, it would undermine wages and working conditions in the United States and Canada, and do little to improve the condition of Mexican workers.
A trade agreement should recognize economic disparities, anticipate the likely human impact and advance the well-being of citizens in each country. This one does none of those.
The agreement would help United States companies invest more freely in Mexico, essentially to allow multinationals to exploit that country's cheap labor and lax environmental and safety enforcement. It is an investment agreement, not a trade agreement, that would destroy jobs and depress wages in the industrialized United States and Canada, while doing nothing to advance the poverty-level wages and living conditions paid by United States employers to workers in Mexico.
The trade agreement represents a high-risk experiment in which countries at far different stages of economic development and democratic rights attempt to merge their economies. Mexico's poverty rate is 40 percent, its unemployment rate in excess of 20 percent, and its gross domestic product a 20th of that of the United States. Average Mexican families simply cannot afford to purchase the products they make, much less buy goods made in the United States.
The North American governments agreed to address the overlooked issues of labor rights and standards and the environment only after the 2,000-page trade agreement was signed -- and only after a change in United States Presidents.
But the "side agreements" are woefully lacking. They would provide no effective remedy to protect worker rights and labor standards, in contrast to specific provisions to protect holders of patents and copyrights. The side agreements limit labor complaints to three issues -- child labor, minimum wage, and job health and safety -- effectively scuttling remedies available under United States trade laws. And they create a bureaucratic nightmare that would keep labor and environmental complaints tied up in endless consultation, with no remedy in sight.
The voices that should be heard are the people who will be most affected by this proposed treaty. They are the United States workers who will lose their jobs; the communities worried about the spread of diseases they once thought were eliminated; citizens worried about maintaining standards for food inspection and the use of toxic chemicals, and human rights activists on both sides of the border concerned about child labor and insufferable living conditions.
Instead of a government that worships at the corporate bottom line and leaves working people undefended in the jungle of the international marketplace, we are calling for a government that is on the side of the workers -- one that fights to rebuild the country's economic strength and provides fair opportunities and equal justice for all.
 
EDWARD J. CLEARY
 
President
New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O.
New York, Sept. 2, 1993

PUB-DATE: September 10, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 414 words

HEADLINE: Only the Multinationals Win in Free Trade Pact;
Commitments Lacking

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In many respects, Mexican law is more than adequate to protect workers. Child labor laws, comparable to those in the United States, are mandated by the Mexican Constitution. Mexican occupational safety and health standards for many toxic substances in the workplace (based on 1983 scientific data) are more stringent than outdated standards used in the United States (based on 1968 scientific data). But even with the best of efforts, Mexico lacks sufficient numbers of trained safety and health professionals, and the Mexican Government lacks the resources, equipment, research capacity and personnel to keep pace with its industrial base -- not to mention the expansion that the North American Free Trade Agreement would bring. 
 I have tried unsuccessfully for years, individually and with other nongovernmental, academic and public health organizations to get the most rudimentary commitment from industry to adhere to even minimal labor standards. Our supposedly most enlightened companies have refused to pledge that they will comply with Mexican laws on child labor and occupational safety and health; that they will assist with data collection and research; that they will support efforts to train more occupational physicians, nurses, industrial hygienists and other health professionals.
The sole faint response from a few companies is that they will engage in a "self-evaluation" of conditions -- all the while asserting that the working conditions at their plants in Mexico are the same as at their plants in the United States.
Many Americans and Mexicans have legitimate concerns that Mexican workers could be exploited and that competitive pressures could cause a general lowering of labor standards in the United States and Canada as well. The multinational corporations that stand to gain much by the passage of the trade agreement must not be allowed to remain silent. Even the most stringent treaty language will be of little value without a genuine commitment by the companies to insure at least minimum levels of labor standards.
Without private sector cooperation with government, universities and other entities on both sides of the border to improve employment conditions of all workers the legitimacy of the free trade agreement will be in doubt, and any aggregate economic gains it brings may not be worth the price.
 
MARK A. ROTHSTEIN
 
Director, Health Law & Policy Inst.
University of Houston
Houston, Aug. 30, 1993

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
AST to Build PC Factory Near Beijing

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9

 BODY:
AST Research Inc., the fourth-largest American personal computer maker, today announced a joint venture with China to build a $16 million computer factory near Beijing that would make 100,000 PC's a year.
The deal, which will include efforts to develop China's nascent market for computers in schools and homes, could help AST solidify its position as China's best-selling computer maker. AST is so popular in China, where its PC's have been sold since 1985, that rivals promote their machines as "AST compatible" and clone makers turn out counterfeits of AST products. 
 "Establishing a leadership position in an early stage market has proved very key here," said Richard Zwetchkenbaum, a computer analyst for the International Data Corporation. "If they can do well in that country, they can do well in other countries in the region."
In addition, he said China's low labor costs could help AST remain competitive in the PC business. "This has implications for AST as a worldwide vendor."
Part of AST's strategy in Asia will be to capitalize on a recently acquired technology that permits data to be entered by pen on a screen. The Tandy Corporation's pen-based Grid system was part of a $160 million acquisition made by AST in July.
Currently, up to four keystrokes are needed to create a single Chinese character on AST machines.
"Clearly, Chinese can write far faster than they can use a keyboard," said Howard Elias, AST's marketing vice president. "We will be taking advantage of that technology."
AST stock rose 37.5 cents today, closing at $15.50 in Nasdaq trading.
AST, which was founded by three Asian immigrants, had 25 percent of China's $440 million market in 1992.
This year, International Data forecasts that 250,000 PC's will be bought in China, compared with 13.5 million in the United States, where growth is below 12 percent a year. China, the world's fastest-growing economy, will be snapping up PC's at a 22 percent annual rate through 2000.
"China represents the world's most promising market for PC's and other high-technology products," Safi U. Qureshey, AST's president, said in a statement.
AST declined to specify China's contribution to the venture. The plant will have 400 employees and open in September 1994 in a special economic zone in Tianjin, 60 miles southeast of Beijing. AST will retain 90 percent ownership.
Based in Irvine, Calif., AST had more than $1 billion in sales for the first time in 1992. In the next 12 months, China could generate 10 percent of the company's revenue, Mr. Elias said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 962 words

HEADLINE: Bulls, Bears And Us

BYLINE: By Joseph Nocera; Joseph Nocera is completing a history of personal finance in modern America.

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
Welcome to the bull market, the fifth of the century. It's been a strange one, though, hasn't it? The bond market is going crazy, the Dow Jones industrial average has risen 600 points in just over two years, yet only recently has anybody paid much attention. By contrast, the bull market that began in August 1982 was widely heralded within months of its start.
The other thing that's so different about this bull market is that it is so plainly ours. It is we -- we who make up the great body of middle-class Americans -- who started this thing, and who have been feeding it these past two years. 
 It's never happened this way before. In the 1920's bull market, and again in the early 1960's, we got played for the sucker; we were the ones leaping in just as the smart money was leaping out. Indeed, the smart money sold us its shares. By the end of the 1980's bull market, we had become major players but not the dominant ones; that was a market driven by the big institutions, and ultimately brought down by them. This time, if we get burned, we won't be able to blame the smart money.
How did the middle class gain control over the nation's financial markets? The simple answer is that for the past three years we've been pouring money into mutual funds, our preferred investment vehicle, at astonishing rates. A decade ago, the nation's mutual funds held just over $100 billion; today they're closing in on $2 trillion. A decade ago, 11 percent of households had mutual fund accounts; today 27 percent do. This is the money that is sustaining the bull market.
But the wholesale rush to mutual funds is only a symptom, the most visible manifestation of an enormous cultural change in American life over the past 20 years. During that time, we have gone from being primarily savers -- people who kept our money in the bank, accepting our federally regulated 5 1/4 percent interest with equanimity -- to being primarily investors, people who move their money from place to place, in a never-ending search for decent yield.
The change in our financial behavior was largely a response to changing economic conditions. The skyrocketing interest rates and debilitating inflation of 15 years ago -- so different from the stable economy of the 1950's -- reduced bank passbook rates to rubble. For the first time in our lives, we were forced to look around for alternatives -- places where we might get market rates of interest and protect our money from the corrosion of inflation.
At first, we found money market funds, which were run by the mutual fund companies, and which we eventually began to view as a kind of turbocharged savings account. (They even came with checks!) Over time, we found other things as well, all aimed at us: municipal bond funds, zero-coupon bonds, discount brokerages.
A kind of financial democratization was taking place: finally the middle class had access to the financial tools used by the wealthy. When Fidelity Investments opened the first municipal bond fund in 1976, it pointedly advertised the fund as a middle-class equalizer. "Municipal bonds," the brochures stated. "They're not just for the wealthy anymore." In this new world, it was only a matter of time before the stock market itself became one of the financial tools the middle class would be forced to rely on.
Now that time has arrived. Just as rising interest rates forced middle-class Americans out of old and comfortable patterns, so has the drop in interest rates completed the process. Now it's money market funds (and bank certificates of deposits) whose yields fail to satisfy, so we've turned to the market. We know there are risks -- we saw what happened in October 1987 -- but we now live in a world where middle-class Americans have to take some risks with their money, whether they want to or not. Just like the rich.
And there is the rub. The democratization of personal finance has been, by and large, a good thing. But as they say on Wall Street (and increasingly on Main Street), there is plenty of downside.
It has made American life immensely more confusing, almost paralyzingly so, as not just financial products have proliferated but financial newsletters and commentators and magazines, all shouting their conflicting advice at us. It has made us anxious; we're being forced to make decisions that will affect our future, and we feel unsure of ourselves.
It was easy being a saver. It's hard being an investor. Even the current bull market hasn't done much to ease the anxiety level. Here in my own little corner of Main Street, I get the distinct impression that people aren't having much fun in the market, even as it makes its steady gains.
Lately I've begun to ask people I know whether they're in the market. Always their answer is yes; always they've gone the mutual fund route; always they have a worried look when they talk about it. "When's the crash coming?" one woman asked me. We don't like having our hard-earned money at risk, even if the risk is paying off, as it is right now. We keep expecting the worst.
Sometimes I wonder what Charles Merrill would make of all this. The flamboyant, prescient, dominating co-founder of Merrill Lynch spent his life imploring the middle class to put "the modest sums of the thrifty" into the market. He was the first person who genuinely attempted "to bring Wall Street to Main Street" -- a phrase he coined, by the way -- and though his firm became prosperous, he did not, in the end, attain his goal. When he died in 1956, in the middle of what still ranks as the greatest bull market of the 20th century, only 6 percent of the country was in the market.
My guess is that he wouldn't be too happy. Charlie Merrill, you see, had one huge blind spot. He hated mutual funds.

This is the money that is sustaining the bull market.
But the wholesale rush to mutual funds is only a symptom, the most visible manifestation of an enormous cultural change in American life over the past 20 years. During that time, we have gone from being primarily savers -- people who kept our money in the bank, accepting our federally regulated 5 1/4 percent interest with equanimity -- to being primarily investors, people who move their money from place to place, in a never-ending search for decent yield.
The change in our financial behavior was largely a response to changing economic conditions. The skyrocketing interest rates and debilitating inflation of 15 years ago -- so different from the stable economy of the 1950's -- reduced bank passbook rates to rubble. For the first time in our lives, we were forced to look around for alternatives -- places where we might get market rates of interest and protect our money from the corrosion of inflation.
At first, we found money market funds, which were run by the mutual fund companies, and which we eventually began to view as a kind of turbocharged savings account. (They even came with checks!) Over time, we found other things as well, all aimed at us: municipal bond funds, zero-coupon bonds, discount brokerages.
A kind of financial democratization was taking place: finally the middle class had access to the financial tools used by the wealthy. When Fidelity Investments opened the first municipal bond fund in 1976, it pointedly advertised the fund as a middle-class equalizer. "Municipal bonds," the brochures stated. "They're not just for the wealthy anymore." In this new world, it was only a matter of time before the stock market itself became one of the financial tools the middle class would be forced to rely on.
Now that time has arrived. Just as rising interest rates forced middle-class Americans out of old and comfortable patterns, so has the drop in interest rates completed the process. Now it's money market funds (and bank certificates of deposits) whose yields fail to satisfy, so we've turned to the market. We know there are risks -- we saw what happened in October 1987 -- but we now live in a world where middle-class Americans have to take some risks with their money, whether they want to or not. Just like the rich.
And there is the rub. The democratization of personal finance has been, by and large, a good thing. But as they say on Wall Street (and increasingly on Main Street), there is plenty of downside.
It has made American life immensely more confusing, almost paralyzingly so, as not just financial products have proliferated but financial newsletters and commentators and magazines, all shouting their conflicting advice at us. It has made us anxious; we're being forced to make decisions that will affect our future, and we feel unsure of ourselves.
It was easy being a saver. It's hard being an investor. Even the current bull market hasn't done much to ease the anxiety level. Here in my own little corner of Main Street, I get the distinct impression that people aren't having much fun in the market, even as it makes its steady gains.
Lately I've begun to ask people I know whether they're in the market. Always their answer is yes; always they've gone the mutual fund route; always they have a worried look when they talk about it. "When's the crash coming?" one woman asked me. We don't like having our hard-earned money at risk, even if the risk is paying off, as it is right now. We keep expecting the worst.
Sometimes I wonder what Charles Merrill would make of all this. The flamboyant, prescient, dominating co-founder of Merrill Lynch spent his life imploring the middle class to put "the modest sums of the thrifty" into the market. He was the first person who genuinely attempted "to bring Wall Street to Main Street" -- a phrase he coined, by the way -- and though his firm became prosperous, he did not, in the end, attain his goal. When he died in 1956, in the middle of what still ranks as the greatest bull market of the 20th century, only 6 percent of the country was in the market.
My guess is that he wouldn't be too happy. Charlie Merrill, you see, had one huge blind spot. He hated mutual funds.

LENGTH: 2370 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
CLINTON OFFERING HEALTH PLAN WITH GUARANTEE OF COVERAGE AND CURB ON PRIVATE SPENDING

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
After seven months of secret deliberations, President Clinton has settled on a bold plan to guarantee health insurance for all Americans while vastly expanding Federal power to control private spending on medical care.
Lobbyists and lawmakers feasted on fresh details of the proposal today as they pried loose a bootleg copy of the closely guarded document on which Mr. Clinton has staked his Presidency. The document, which had been available for inspection only by key staff members on Capitol Hill, is an authoritative compilation of ideas embraced by the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who supervised development of the plan and has been selling it in Congress. [Major sections of the final draft are on page 8.] 
 The proposal is breathtaking in its sweep, its complexity and its ambition. But the financing remains murky, and the whole plan depends on extremely optimistic assumptions about the savings that can be achieved through a combination of Government regulation and free-market competition.
 
Phased in Over the Decade
 In the latest draft of his plan, Mr. Clinton says his proposal "enhances the security of the American people" by guaranteeing that they will never lose health coverage, even if they become sick or lose their jobs.
Unauthorized copies of the proposal, which is still subject to refinement, circulated today among health-care experts and news organizations, including The New York Times.
Mr. Clinton predicts that his health plan, which would be phased in over the rest of the decade, will shave $91 billion from Federal budget deficits over the next seven years, even as he tries to provide prescription drug coverage for all Americans and comprehensive health benefits for the 37 million people who are now uninsured.
Many parts of the proposal have leaked out over the last few months, but the full text became available today from lawmakers and lobbyists, just 12 days before Mr. Clinton intends to make his case to a joint session of Congress. The entire proposal is subject to approval by Congress, which is likely to insist on major changes.
 
Cutting Growth Rates
 The document describes how the Federal Government would enforce a national health-care budget by regulating the annual increase in premiums that could be charged for private health insurance. From 1994 to 2000, Mr. Clinton says, the rate of growth of private health spending would be cut in half. The annual rate of growth of Medicare, the Federal program for the elderly, would be slashed by 65 percent, while the explosive growth of Medicaid, the program for the poor, would be cut by 75 percent.
The Clinton proposal would provide more extensive coverage than most existing insurance policies, and it would require most consumers to pay a portion of the cost. The Clinton plan would cover medically necessary hospital and doctors' services, dental care for children and limited amounts of mental health care. Benefits would be expanded in the year 2000, when routine check-ups would be covered for all people.
Under the proposal, "it is the obligation of every eligible individual to enroll in a health plan," the document states.
The Clinton plan would set stringent limits on health spending. But there is no explicit allowance for the costs attributable to new technology or the increased volume and intensity of medical services -- factors that have accounted for a large share of recent increases in health spending.
The formula for computing the allowable increase in health spending would take no account of such special variables, which make health care different from food, clothing and gasoline, for example, but it would reflect inflation and population growth.
The effort to revamp the nation's health-care system has been a perennial theme in American politics for the last half-century. The groundswell of support for such change helped elect Mr. Clinton last year, but in Congress, as in the nation, there is no clear consensus in favor of specific proposals.
 
Born in Academe
 Members of Congress and hundreds of lobbyists for consumers, business, labor and the nation's vast health-care industry have begun to pick apart the Clinton plan even before he formally unveils it.
This is a proposal born in the groves of academe, not in the halls of Congress or the wards of America's hospitals. It would go far beyond correcting the flaws of the American health-care system, remaking and redesigning the system from the top down.
The heart of the Clinton plan is a proposal to establish huge consumer groups, known as regional health alliances, that would buy care from competing networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies.
Mr. Clinton would require employers to buy health insurance for all their workers. But for political reasons, he insists that these payments are premiums, not taxes -- a contention vehemently disputed by Republicans and many business lobbyists.
Mr. Clinton's proposal would give states broad new power to regulate and tax the health-benefit plans of the nation's biggest corporations, which have long been exempt from state regulation. Such companies could continue serving as their own insurers, but they would lose much of the discretion they now have in designing and operating health plans.
 
No Mention of Abortion
 On offering his plan to Congress, the President will urge doctors, hospitals and drug companies to limit price increases, but he has apparently not decided what the amount should be. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala, would systematically monitor medical prices and spending, and she would have new authority to obtain financial data from companies, the document says.
The Clinton plan does not mention abortion, though it promises coverage of "pregnancy-related services." It says little about taxes. The document is not a concrete legislative proposal; it reads more like a report from a management consultant.
Nevertheless, the document vibrates with a sense of urgency. As part of his proposal, Mr. Clinton is seeking authority to issue dozens of emergency regulations to carry out the plan, once passed, with little or no opportunity for public comment. A 1946 law, passed to prevent a repetition of the blizzard of rule-making unleashed by the New Deal, normally guarantees the opportunity for such comment.
Here is a summary of Mr. Clinton's proposal, as described in the document sent to Congress for review this week:
 
Financing
One significant feature of the last version of the plan, prepared in early August, has been dropped: a proposal for a new Federal trust fund through which billions of dollars in private health insurance premiums would be channeled. This proposal smacked of big government and would have strengthened the hand of critics who said Mr. Clinton was imposing new taxes.
Still, the distinction between premiums and taxes is debatable. Referring to the mandatory premiums, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said in an interview: "It's a Government-imposed decrease in your take-home pay. You can call it whatever you want. I'm sure people will be glad to know they can send their money to a Government-approved insurance company, rather than to the Internal Revenue Service."
Under the latest version of the Clinton proposal, the regional health alliances would keep billions of dollars of premiums in local bank accounts and in secure investments, but would not send the money to Washington.
 
Budget
Mr. Clinton says his proposal "brings growth in health-care costs in line with growth in gross domestic product by 1997" -- a feat regarded as nearly impossible by experts on health care and economics.
Under the plan, "the Federal Government is responsible for enforcing the health-care budget" for America, the document states.
Just days after saying he wanted to streamline Government and reduce Federal regulation, Mr. Clinton now says he wants to establish a new Government agency to regulate the $900-billion-a-year health industry, which accounts for one-seventh of the nation's economy.
The proposed new agency, the National Health Board, would calculate and approve health insurance premiums for most people. Health plans would submit bids to the huge regional alliances of consumers. But if the bids exceeded the target set by the Government, the regional consumer alliance could levy a special assessment on health plans, doctors and hospitals whose bids were deemed excessive.
 
Employers
Employers would have to buy health insurance for part-time workers, just as for full-time workers. The employer's mandatory contribution is prorated, based on the assumption that a 30-hour week is full-time. Thus, for an employee who works 20 hours a week, the employer must pay two-thirds of the usual premium.
Premiums for the standard package of benefits are expected to average $4,200 for a family and $1,800 for one person. Employers would have to pick up a substantial share of the cost of health care for low-income workers now covered by Medicaid.
Companies with more than 5,000 employees may run their own health plans. But states may impose taxes and other assessments on such self-insured companies. Under a Federal law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, known as Erisa, companies serving as their own insurers are now generally exempt from state taxes and from regulation by state insurance commissioners.
Mark J. Ugoretz, president of the Erisa Industry Committee, a trade association of big companies, said: "I am dumbfounded. The Administration is proposing that states be permitted to levy taxes against corporate health-care plans, which will substantially increase the cost of care. It's an admission that this proposal will be costly because it relies on states to administer health-care reform."
 
Medicare and Medicaid
A state could bring Medicare beneficiaries into the large purchasing pools that would buy insurance coverage for state residents under the age of 65. But the state would have to assure the Federal Government that elderly people would not lose any benefits.
The Federal Government would increase Medicare premiums for individuals with incomes above $100,000 a year and for couples with incomes above $125,000. The premium is now $36.60 a month. The document does not specify the amount of the increase.
For a premium of $20 a month, Medicare beneficiaries could get a new benefit, covering long-term care outside a nursing home.
Most people who are now covered by Medicaid would enroll in regional health alliances, choosing from the same health plans as other citizens.
Medicaid and Medicare would no longer make special payments to hospitals serving disproportionately large numbers of low-income patients. The Administration says such payments will not be needed if all Americans have insurance. The Government would reduce the payments now made to teaching hospitals for the costs of training doctors.
 
Consumers
Every American would be required to enroll in a health plan. Every consumer would get a "unique identification number." The National Health Board would establish standards to protect the privacy of medical information in patients' records. The nation would move rapidly toward greater use of computers to keep medical records and to pay insurance claims.
Consumers would, for the first time, be able to get access to information in the National Practitioner Data Bank, which keeps track of professional misconduct and malpractice payments by doctors. The American Medical Association strongly opposes disclosure of such information, saying the data are often inaccurate.
 
States
"A state may establish a single-payer health-care system," in which the state or its representative pays standard rates to all doctors, hospitals and other suppliers of medical care. Such states might require big self-insured companies to take part in these arrangements -- a prospect opposed by many employers, who contend they can cut a better deal for their workers if they negotiate directly with doctors and hospitals.
Most care would be provided by health maintenance organizations and other health plans formed by doctors, hospitals and insurance companies. But health plans would not be able to provide insurance or medical care to regional health alliances unless the health plans had been certified by the state.
 
Transition
To protect consumers during the transition to the new system, the Administration would prohibit employers and insurers from reducing coverage for any illness, injury or treatment costing more than $5,000 a year.
The Federal Government might organize a national insurance pool to cover uninsured people until states established their own programs.
The existing health insurance program for Federal workers, sometimes described as a model for the nation, would be ended. Federal, state and local government workers would be required to get coverage through consumer purchasing groups in the areas where they live.
 
Enforcement
Under the latest version of Mr. Clinton's plan, the Secretary of Labor -- not the Secretary of Health and Human Services or the Treasury Secretary -- is primarily responsible for enforcement, to make sure that employers buy coverage for their workers.
There were two reasons for this choice. If the premiums are not taxes, then the Treasury Secretary does not have to collect the money and dun delinquent employers.
Equally important, Administration officials say the White House wanted to minimize the role of the Senate Finance Committee in reviewing its proposal. This committee has authority over tax legislation, but it appears that a majority of committee members oppose the idea of a Federal mandate for employers to provide health insurance for their workers. The mandate is the bedrock of Mr. Clinton's proposal.
Mr. Clinton assumes that states will move swiftly to establish health-care programs for their citizens. Under his plan, If a state failed to act by Jan. 1, 1997, the Federal Government might impose a payroll tax on all employers in the state to finance care under a program run by Federal authorities.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Ira C. Magaziner, a senior adviser, meeting on the health care plan yesterday with the Senate Finance Committee. (Associated Press) (pg. 9)
 
Chart: "How It Would Work"
 
FOR THE CONSUMER:
 
Who Is Covered; Who Pays?
 Everyone, working or not, would have to carry health insurance and to contribute to its cost, with subsidies to help the poor. Companies would have to contribute for workers and their families; employers would pay 80 percent of the cost of premiums and workers 20 percent.
 
How Good Is The Care.
 Administration officials say the proposal would promote high quality care by collecting information about the performance of health plans, and because consumers would vote with their feet, shunning poor plans. Some critics fear that medical groups would have incentives to scrimp, or that cost controls will force medical rationing.
 
How Much Choice.
 Financial incentives would push more people into health maintenance organizations that place limits on the selection of doctors. Freedom to choose one's doctor is one of the hottest issues raised by the proposal. The White House argues that its approach would open more choices to most Americans.
 
FOR THE PROVIDER:
 
Doctors
 Constraints would have a huge effect on their professional lives. The report says insurers may still offer insurance that lets a doctor bill for each procedure. But since such plans are expected to be the most expensive, planners expect most consumers to chose from the managed care plans. If doctors want patients, they will have to join as well.
 
Hospitals
 Much of the hospital industry has already been shaken by having to get rid of excess beds and lower their costs. As hospitals foundthat they, too, had to affiliate with managed care networks, the process will certainly speed up. The draft suggests easing regulations to encourage hospital to mergers.

Insurers
 Health economists predict that a limited number of operators of medical plans will remain in every medical market supervised by an alliance. In urban areas, experts say it could be as many as 15 or more, in more rural areas, perhaps one or two. (pg. 1)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1090 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Consumers;
A Benefit for Some Patients, Difficult Choices for Others

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
For the 37 million Americans who now lack health insurance, and the tens of millions more who may find themselves without it in the next few years when they lose or change jobs, the appeal of the Clinton proposal is obvious: guaranteed coverage regardless of employment status, age or illness.
But the majority of Americans who are already decently insured and happy with their own doctors may have a harder time deciding about their own prospects. 
 The Administration's goal is to reorganize the way health care is paid for and delivered so that nearly everyone would be better off. Officials say most people would pay little, if any, more than they do now in return for generous benefits and lifelong peace of mind.
 
Continuing to Have a Choice
 By bringing order and efficiency to a chaotic system, officials say, the new system would enhance the quality of care despite stringent new limits on the growth of medical spending. Americans would continue to have a wide choice of doctors and health plans, they insist.
But the heart of the Clinton strategy for holding down medical spending is to make people acutely aware of the true cost of their health care. And that may be jarring for many Americans who have long received generous benefits at work.
In the structure outlined by the White House, many people may find themselves choosing among unfamiliar new health plans and accepting new limits on their freedom to choose doctors or hospitals, or paying extra to use the system as freely as they are accustomed to.
The question remains whether the lower-cost health maintenance organizations into which many people might be pushed will offer long lines and second-class medical care, as some critics fear, or efficient, prudent, top-flight care, as officials predict.
 
How Much for Coverage?
 Under the Clinton proposal, everyone would be required to have health insurance and to contribute to its cost. All companies would be required to contribute for workers and their families, with the employers paying 80 percent of the cost of premiums and workers 20 percent.
Officials estimate that the average premium would be $1,800 a year for individuals and $4,200 for families; so an employee would pay an average of $360 for individual coverage and $840 for family coverage. The self-employed and unemployed would be responsible for the entire amount, but depending on income, could be eligible for subsidies.
Individuals and most companies would no longer directly buy their own health insurance. Instead, they would sign up with large cooperatives, or regional health alliances, which would present their members with a choice of health plans that have the same basic set of benefits. These plans would be made up of groups of doctors and hospitals, often organized by insurers.
A company employing at least 5,000 people could function as its own alliance or join the regional alliance.
The proposal envisions three basic kinds of plans. They are:
*"Low cost-sharing" plans, H.M.O.'s in which patients pay $10 per office visit to affiliated doctors.
*"High cost-sharing" plans, which allow patients the familiar freedom to visit any doctors and health centers on a fee-for-service basis, but require families to pay a deductible of $400 and 20 percent of all subsequent bills, to a maximum of $3,000 per family per year.
*"Combination" plans in which patients pay little to use affiliated doctors and more to use others.
In more populated areas, an alliance might offer several plans with varying premiums. Any patient could choose any plan; the idea is to force plans to compete for customers by offering the best price and quality.
In turn, financial incentives would be used to nudge more people into the most cost-effective H.M.O.'s. Through stiffer deductibles and co-payments consumers would pay heavily for the ability to choose any doctor -- an amount, officials say, that fairly represents the extra cost of unmanaged care.
Thus, while many Americans might be able to choose more generous plans that cost them little more than they have paid in the past, others might find themselves spending more to keep the same freedoms they have enjoyed.
 
Choices
One of the hottest issues raised by the Clinton proposal is freedom to choose one's doctor. Critics attack the plan as restricting choice, while the White House says it will be opening more choices to Americans. Both are right.
More than 41 million Americans are already in H.M.O.'s. But to the extent that more Americans feel pushed against their preference into H.M.O.'s, they will face new limits. These groups usually allow a choice of primary physician among affiliated doctors, but patients must go through this "gatekeeper" to visit specialists, who must also be in the group.
Critics raise the specter of chronically ill patients ripped from a trusted doctor. This might happen, but the chances would be reduced if virtually all doctors sign up with health plans, as the proposal envisages.
Administration officials also point out that large numbers of Americans do not now enjoy the hallowed freedom of choice. Some 37 million are uninsured and the 30 million people on Medicaid, the program for the poor, often have trouble finding decent care. And a growing number of workers are offered only a single H.M.O. by their employers.
 
Quality
Health maintenance organizations save money not only by negotiating lower fees with doctors, hospitals and other suppliers but also by scrutinizing medical decisions and discouraging wasteful, costly services.
At best, this could produce fine care and weed out useless and harmful procedures. At worst, doctors' groups and H.M.O.'s could be tempted to scrimp on costly but useful care, jeopardizing health, and on personnel and equipment, producing long waits.
Administration officials say their proposal would insure high-quality care. As they make their annual selection of health plans, consumers would vote with their feet, shunning plans that perform poorly. Equally important, according to the proposal, a national program would develop ways to measure the quality of care offered by health plans.
Annual performance reports, covering both consumer satisfaction and medical indicators for all health plans, would be made available to consumers, which officials say would create a higher level of public knowledge and accountability than now exists in the health system. But critics question how consumers can adequately compare medical performance.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1374 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: CLINTON OFFERING HEALTH PLAN WITH GUARANTEE OF COVERAGE AND CURB ON PRIVATE SPENDING;
Clinton's Roll Of the Dice

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's health care plan is imposing, not just in its intricacy and command of detail but also in its political audacity, which history may judge as courageous, or reckless.
The program would stir up and reorganize the medical business and shake up imperfect but familiar relationships, from those in family doctors' waiting rooms to those in the corridors of Congress. It would also promise security for individuals and deficit control for the country. It would try to do all this when the public's trust in the Government is near a low point and when Congress is divided by partisanship. 
 It is an enormous political undertaking. No President in decades has bet so much on a single issue. As a political gamble, it ranks with Woodrow Wilson's advocacy of the League of Nations.
 
Risk for Congress, Too
 But Mr. Clinton is risking not only his own capital but also that of Congress. By defining health care as the most important task of his Presidency, he is making the issue a crucial test for Congress, already the least-loved branch of the Government.
Congress, after all, blocked the efforts of two earlier Presidents, Harry S. Truman and Richard M. Nixon, to institute national health insurance.
There is no way to predict how this Congress will deal with this President's proposals. After all, most of its members do not have them yet. Even the 246 "privileged and confidential" pages that lawmakers and aides are being shown behind closed doors contain what the Senate majority leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, described on Thursday as preliminary conclusions. They are subject to adjustment if strongly resisted on Capitol Hill, although they have not surprised those who followed the months of development of the Clinton plan.
 
Unusually Cautious Reaction
 So far, the Congressional reaction has been remarkably tentative. Some of that must encourage Mr. Clinton, especially after the Republicans denounced his economic plan from February through August.
For example, for a meeting with Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday, Congressional Republicans put forth the blandest and mostly generalized statement of their views that they could prepare. With few exceptions they have been following the advice of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas to keep their powder dry so that they will be able to compromise and legislate in good faith.
And, indeed, the Clinton proposal reflects a number of Republican ideas, or at least ideas Republicans have found appealing. One is the attempt to control fees less by Government directive than by limiting insurance premiums, and thus making private enterprise do the price fixing.
But there is also some significant hesitance on the Democratic side. Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, worries that the Administration is overconfident about the Democrats. "They are in a fog with regards to how much enthusiasm there is for health care," he said. "They are very enthusiastic and I don't see it among the members."
Mrs. Clinton, for one, only recently abandoned the hope that a plan could be enacted this year. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said on Thursday that there was a consensus "that it will be done in this Congress" by the end of 1994. Mr. Rostenkowski is less confident. He said a few days ago: "Doing the job right is more important than doing the job. I don't know that we're going to finish the job" by next year.
 
Plenty of Obstacles
 There are plenty of obstacles, aside from important but purely local constituent concerns, like the Congressional district with an insurance company headquarters, or one with very few doctors.
Republicans worry about requiring small businesses to buy their workers insurance and about excessive controls. So do conservative Democrats. Some liberal Democrats regard the plan's reliance on private insurers as untested, needlessly complex and inefficient compared with a Government-paid system, and they are also concerned that Medicare and Medicaid will be shorted to help pay for the system.
Whether or not to pay for abortions, a word that does not appear in the 246 pages but is subsumed under "pregnancy related services," promises to incite a fierce fight that will cost a final bill votes however it turns out.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, one of the handful of veterans of earlier Congressional battles on the issue, is hopeful that debate can produce "a formulation that is acceptable, or tolerable, to all the groups." He contends that "not since Medicare was enacted in 1965 have the political constellations been so clearly in the right place for fundamental health reform."
The Massachusetts Democrat, the leading Congressional advocate of universal health care over the last quarter century, said Mr. Clinton faced a "once-in-a-generation opportunity." His own efforts and those of President Nixon failed in the 1970's because neither labor nor the medical industry felt the urgency that compels compromise. At that time, he said, health care cost only 6 percent of the gross national product, and private insurers were expanding coverage. Today, health care consumes 14 percent of the economy and much insurance coverage seems uncertain.
He said: "You have the health business as the fastest failing business in America. Its burden on families is out of sight, measured in the cost of doctors and the cost of hospitals. And its cost to American business is out of sight. Its bureaucratic nightmare to the providers is out of sight. So the major interests in the health care all demand change."
There is one very important difference in the political lineup between 1993 and the Truman Administration's effort in 1949 to combat what Mr. Truman called the real costs of inadequate health care: "the shattering of family budgets, the disruption of family life, the suffering and disabilities, the permanent physical impairments left by crippling diseases and the deaths each year of tens of thousands of persons who might have lived."
As Prof. Richard E. Neustadt, the retired Harvard scholar of the Presidency, recalled today from his days working on health care in the Truman White House, "Not one single scintilla of support did we get from the big business community in 1949." Big business, whose health costs are soaring, is one of the biggest boosters of the President's approach today.
Professor Neustadt said the President would still have a hard time winning passage and argued that the emphasis on the plan as a way to reduce the deficit might just produce popular disbelief. "The man's in an awful box," he said. "But at least he's not just sitting in it."
At any rate, he added: "It's an appropriate issue for the Democratic Administration. Nobody should be left out in this country."
Mr. Clinton campaigned on health care legislation as essential to reducing the nation's deficit and making individuals feel secure. In his inaugural address he lamented that "the cost of health care devastates families and threatens to bankrupt our enterprises, great and small." Among all his campaign promises, it stood out as one the public thought he could, and would, keep.
 
Political Realities
 And the program has been structured with a serious eye on political realities, avoiding serious new taxes, stressing competition as a way to curb costs, even skirting large trouble spots by assuring labor that workers retired before 65 would not lose the coverage their union contracts now provide.
Stephen E. Ambrose, the Nixon biographer at the University of New Orleans, recalled President Wilson's failure as a comparable big issue. He said there were major political risks in the Great Society program of Lyndon B. Johnson and the variety of domestic programs Mr. Nixon planned for his second term before Watergate sank him. But each involved a variety of subjects, not just one like health care.
Mr. Wilson and Mr. Nixon, however, were taking risks in second terms, chancing history, not re-election, as Mr. Clinton is. And Mr. Johnson had an immense Congressional majority that Mr. Clinton lacks.
As Mr. Ambrose said of the President, "He is gambling everything on it, even his wife's reputation."

 BODY:

Clinton's Health Plan
The Administration has settled on a bold plan to guarantee health insurance for all Americans while vastly expanding Federal power to control private spending on medical care. A bootleg copy of the closely guarded proposal began to circulate. It shows a plan that is breathtaking in its sweep, complexity and ambition, but murky in its financing. [Page 1.] President Clinton's health care plan is imposing not just in its intricacy and detail, but also in its political audacity. News Analysis. [1.]
The appeal of the proposal is obvious to the 37 million Americans who lack health insurance. But Americans who are insured may have a harder time deciding about their own prospects. [1.]
The proposals could throw into fast forward trends that are already reshaping the fates of doctors, hospitals and insurers. [10.]
 
The Economy
The Producer Price Index fell 0.6 percent in August, the Government said, in a report showing surprisingly low inflation. Plunging tobacco prices were largely responsible. [37.]
 
Companies
 Paramount and Viacom may announce a merger as early as this weekend, industry executives said. The deal, estimated at $6.2 billion in stock and $1 billion in cash, would be the biggest media marriage since Time wed Warner four years ago. [35.]
Microsoft will begin charging large customers for some of the technical support it provides. [39.].
Rhone-Poulenc Rorer consolidated its top management in the wake of an executive's departure to Metpath Laboratories. [39.]

 Eager buyers moved back into stocks, erasing most of the week's previous losses. The Dow industrials rose 32.14, to 3,621.63, and gained 12.30 points for the week. [37.]

Canary Wharf administrators agreed with bank lenders on a $1.7 billion financial rescue package for the London complex of office buildings, which fell victim to the British recession and contributed to the collapse of Olympia & York. [37.]
Representative Bonior retreated from his plan to use the resources of his office, as House majority whip, against the North American Free Trade Agreement. [7.]
