HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Providers;
Changes Would Transform Worlds Of Doctors, Hospitals and Insurers

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
If the health care proposals of the Clinton Administration become law, they would throw into fast forward trends that are already reshaping the fates of doctors, hospitals and the insurance companies that pay them.
Doctors would win a victory that leading medical organizations like the American Medical Association have long sought: guaranteed insurance coverage for tens of millions of the uninsured. 
 But physicians would find that, under the plan, they would have even less autonomy than they do now. The market, under the plan, could be expected to force doctors to find patients by signing up with health care networks run by insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Even when they treat patients who are not members of such networks, they would be required to charge them according to a schedule of fees approved by regulators for every service, the type of arrangement that has applied to Medicare and Medicaid.
The impact of the plan would probably be just as great on the hospital industry. As hospitals and treatment centers are drawn into managed care networks, they, too, would be put under ever-growing pressure to cut costs. Experts say the Clinton program would probably speed the pace at which such institutions are already shutting down wards, merging with other hospitals or closing their doors.
In addition, the plan says teaching hospitals would be forced to stop turning out so many highly paid specialists and to redirect their efforts to training lower-paid, primary-care physicians. And the plan is expected to bring changes in the medical marketplace that would force a significant number of specialists to retrain.
Some of the most drastic changes, however, would be seen in the health insurance industry. Most of the nation's 500 or so health insurers are expected to be driven out of the field, and among the likely beneficiaries would be the five giants of industry -- Prudential, Cigna, Aetna, Travelers, and Metropolitan Life -- as well as the more than than 70 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
The draft proposal offers a bit of relief to insurance companies that sell workers compensation and automobile insurance. The Clinton plan would merge the $40 billion in medical coverage now offered by workers compensation and automobile policies into standard health care plans. But it assures property-casualty insurance companies that now sell such coverage that they will be allowed to stay in those lines of business by providing their coverage through the alliances.
What ties together the future of all sorts of medical providers, doctors, hospitals, health maintenance organizations, pharmacies and laboratories, is the requirement under the Clinton plan that Americans receive their health coverage through the yet-to-be-created purchasing groups.
These health alliances, region by region, perhaps metropolitan area by metropolitan area, will tell insurers and health maintenance organizations what minimum requirements they must meet before they will be allowed to offer coverage to the public.
 
Doctors
By assuring that all Americans have complete medical insurance coverage, the Government is guaranteeing that millions more patients and tens of billions more dollars will flow into doctors offices. In addition, by permitting the 30 million people who are now covered by Medicaid to be covered by the alliances, the Clinton Administration would create legions of patients who are suddenly more lucrative to treat.
But the plan also spells out major constraints on doctors.
The draft report says insurers may still offer the current type of insurance that lets a doctor bill for each procedure performed. Since such plans are expected to be by far the most expensive, however, planners say the vast majority of consumers will chose managed care plans. As a result, doctors searching for patients will find themselves joining managed care plans as well.
Such plans vary greatly, but one common element for doctors is that they have to agree to work under the rules of an insurance company or a health maintenance organization that closely supervises how much care and what kind of procedures should be given.
In addition, they are often paid by a system designed to motivate doctors to think twice before they go ahead with expensive and time consuming procedures.
Under this "capitation" system, an insurer might offer a doctor a fixed fee for treating 100 patients. If the patients need less care than the average for such a group, the doctor makes more profit, but if the group needs more care than the average the expense comes from the doctors pocket.
Doctors may decide to join one or many such networks, but executives some of the nation's largest health insurance companies say that over time, they expect more and more doctors to affiliate with one network or another.
In some specialized fields that now have many practitioners in a given area, like hematologists in New York City, there may not be enough spaces in networks for all the doctors. The result may be that many such highly trained and well-paid physicians will have to retrain in a lower-paying field of primary-care medicine to be able to join a network and get patients.
 
Hospitals
Much of the nation's hospital industry has already been shaken in the past five years by the need to get rid of excess beds and lower their costs. As hospitals, too, find that they have to affiliate with managed care networks, the process will certainly speed up. The draft suggests easing regulations in an effort to encourage hospitals to merge.
Another section of the report suggests a five-year phase-in period in which academic hospitals would try to decrease the number of specialists they train. The goal would be to increase the proportion of primary-care physicians they train to 50 percent of the new doctors. The plan suggests achieving that goal by reducing the financing of specialty training programs.
But Dr. William T. Speck, the president and chief executive officer of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, said last night that changing the financing of residency programs alone would not be enough. He said the average medical student graduates with tens of thousands of dollars of debt and would not be attracted to lower-paying fields.
"There is now not enough incentive to bring doctors into primary care," he said.
 
Insurers
For the nation's $300 billion health insurance industry the future is one of transformation.
The vast majority of the hundreds of health insurance companies in the United States offer the old-fashioned fee-for-service plans. Those plans are already losing customers to managed care networks, and under the alliance system, economists say, most would have to leave the business entirely.
What would remain, health economists predict, would be a limited number of H.M.O.'s, insurance health plans and similar networks run by doctors and hospitals in every medical market supervised by an alliance. In urban areas, experts say, it could be as many as 15 or more, in more rural areas, perhaps one or two.
Those most likely to survive and flourish are networks that signed up physicians, hospitals and other providers early.
In dozens of markets many local H.M.O.'s and groups of hospitals or physicians have banded together to form networks of their own and many of these smaller players may grow in their individual markets under the Clinton plan. In addition, analysts say some multistate H.M.O.'s like Kaiser Permanente, and U.S. Healthcare are well positioned to grow under the Clinton plan.
But experts say that among insurance companies the five biggest players, led by Cigna and Prudential, are most likely to flourish nationally.
Each of them, along with Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, have made large capital investments and already signed up large numbers of doctors and hospitals in dozens of markets around the country. Their market share, analysts say, appears destined to grow if the Clinton plan passes.
Not surprisingly, the five biggest insurers have broken away from their smaller competitors, to form a insurance lobbying group in Washington that is working for the Administration's proposals.

HEADLINE: Parents Scramble for Day Care in Asbestos Delay

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
With New York City's public schools closed, the Stewart sisters -- Alexandria, 11,; Vanessa, 9, and Amber, 6 -- stayed home alone much of this week and will again next week while their working mother hustles off to the office.
Patricia Stewart couldn't afford a baby sitter, so her daughters have passed the last days of summer since camp ended by acting in make-believe plays on the stage of their Washington Heights living room, usually with only an imaginary audience to applaud them. Their original production of "Two Princess Cats" typically opens with a frenzied dance of hopping, jerking and leg-flapping and unfolds with the sisters tumbling onto the green-carpeted floor like kittens. 
 But while the girls frolicked at home, their mother worried. "I call them 90,000 times a day," she said. Ms. Stewart looks to the schools to provide a safe, free haven for her children.
With more than 1,000 city schools scheduled to open Thursday still closed by inspections for exposed asbestos, a potential health hazard, parents have been scrambling. What they have found are makeshift, sometimes creative ways to look after a mind-boggling million schoolchildren who are already bored and at loose ends as summer wanes and planned activities have petered out.
 
Hired the Teacher
 Ms. Stewart's solution to the school closings was one that many working parents of limited means had to settle for. But others with money to spare had better options. Molly Fermaglich, a scriptwriter, and Laura Pologe, a molecular biologist, hired last year's public school teacher to instruct 10 neighborhood children in a sunny living-room-turned classroom in lower Manhattan. Classes would begin on Sept. 20 -- if schools don't open as promised. Parents will pay the teacher $15 a day per child for several hours of instruction.
On the Upper West Side, a group of parents are sending about 40 of their children to Ramapo Country Day Camp in Monsey, N.Y., to enjoy languid, late-summer days of swimming, arts and crafts and sports. Cost: $199 per child per week, paid by the participating parents at Public School 199.
David and Catherine Evans put their 5-year-old son, Joe, ("I'm 5 and three-quarters years old," Joe complained) on the bus to Ramapo to avoid what his mother described as "organizational hell."
"We work out of the house, so we need time," Mr. Evans said. "And Joe was eager to go back to school. It's been a pretty long summer."
But Joe said he'd choose swimming over school any day, and, with a peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwich packed in his bag, he was eager for the bus to leave so that he could get to the pool.
 
Range of Financing
 Still other parents have found places that would look after their children, with the city or an employer paying the bill. Jimmy Lanza, the co-op board president at Boulevard Gardens in Woodside, Queens, helped organize a day-care center in the co-op's playroom, with funds from the city's Department of Youth Services. It is one of many such programs the department is supporting.
Bankers Trust has offered its workers free child care in an improvised day care center fashioned from the employee cafeteria -- an offer snatched up by financially hard-pressed clerks and secretaries.
Rheedlen Centers for Children and Families, a nonprofit group, is running Public School 194, a school in Harlem with a clean bill of health on asbestos, as a place where parents can drop off their children for the day at no charge. The city is paying to staff the program. "It helps you stop from being on the streets and stuff like that," said Teaner Arnold, an 11-year-old on the school's playground.
And Bronx Community College has arranged day care for its hundreds of students who have children. Samuel Genao, 7, has tagged along with his mother to her classes this summer. He was disappointed that school did not start on time, but relieved that his mother could drop him off at the college's child care program. "I didn't want to stick to my mother like gum," he said.
 
Hardship Varies by Income
 The delay of the schools' opening has been an aggravating inconvenience for parents who can afford baby sitters, camps and day care -- and for those lucky enough to find such services for free. It has been a headache for the 294,000 single parents on welfare, who are watching out for children in neighborhoods often infested with guns and drugs. But it has been a real hardship for working parents who are barely paying the bills.
State law does not specifically prohibit parents from leaving children of any age at home alone, but rather sets general guidelines about what conditions constitute neglect or abuse. The city's Human Resources Administration makes the decisions about abuse based on each situation.
"There is nothing in the law itself which can give you a hard and fast rule -- how old, how long," said Martin Baron, an associate general counsel with the agency. "It's a case-by-case determination."
And life, Ms. Stewart said, sometimes forces difficult choices. "But you have a whole society that has no choice because the cost of child care is astronomical," she said. "What are they going to do, put half the population of New York in jail?"
Fourteen-year-old Shawanna Boyd is forbidden to set foot out the door in the four hours that both her mother and grandmother are at work. "I call her every half-hour to make sure she's in the house," said her grandmother, Julia Boyd, a home attendant to an elderly man. "These are troublesome times in my neighborhood. We have shootings night and day. And with all the children out of school . . . " Her voice trailed off ominously. "You try to keep your teen-agers off the street."
Maria Guadalupe, an office worker in the Bronx, is paid $12,000 a year. Her mother, who has had several operations on her legs, looks after her three boys, but is too infirm to chase after them. So the children are not allowed to play outside, where their mother fears the traffic, guns or drugs could hurt them. Bored and stir-crazy, they fight all the time now, turning on their dueling radios simultaneously.
The oldest boy, Carlos, who is 11, said he is very sad to be stuck at home. He watches cartoons, scrubs the bathtub and plays Nintendo. "I only go outside to throw out the garbage," he said, sounding down-in-the-mouth.
Ms. Stewart, whose three young daughters have stayed home alone, playing Old Maid, Candyland and make believe, says she does not earn enough to pay for child care. She started leaving the girls home alone from time to time three years ago, when she separated from her husband.
"I worry about the kids, of course," she said. "I call them during the day, and they call me asking, 'Mommy, where's this? How do you cook this?' Or there's a fight and they need a mediator. Amber lost a tooth once and called me panicky. I told her to wash her mouth out. They get all excited when they see blood."
The girls went to camp for most of this summer, but that ended in mid-August. Since then, they've been home while she works as the office manager for Harlem Churches for Community Improvement. She wants the schools cleaned of asbestos, but is angry is wasn't done by the time the schools were supposed to open.
The outrage among parents of all economic stations seemed to transcend the usual cynicism about city government. State and city investigators have concluded that the asbestos inspections, as done in the last four years by the school system were so flawed as to be useless, either through incompetence or fraud.
The closed schools -- and the governmental failure they symbolize -- have not only hit many parents in the pocketbook, they have struck at something more fragile and important, their aspirations for their children. Ms. Fermaglich and her husband, Alan Levy, a public relations consultant, are the parents of 7-year-old Jenna. They had a fantasy that 100,000 parents would show up with their children on the lawn of Gracie Mansion on Thursday morning and say to the Mayor, "Here, you deal with it.
"Take my money," Mr. Levy said, "break my axles, but don't betray the trust of our children."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Excerpts From Final Draft of Health Care Overhaul Proposal

 BODY:
Following are sections of the final draft of a Clinton Administration proposal to guarantee health coverage for all Americans. The plan, being circulated on Capitol Hill, is to be unveiled on Sept. 22 in a speech by the President. The Administration's statement of the problem and its overview of the proposed American Health Security Act of 1993 appear in full below, with excerpts from the document's detail sections.
 
The Problem
All Americans, those who have health insurance and those who do not, understand that serious problems exist in the health care system: 
Americans lack security. One out of four people, or 63 million people, will lose health insurance coverage for some period during the next two years. Thirty-seven million Americans have no insurance and another 22 million lack adequate coverage.
Losing or changing a job often means losing insurance. Becoming ill or living with a chronic medical condition can mean losing insurance coverage or not being able to obtain it.
Health care costs are rising faster than other sectors of the economy. Precipitous growth in health care costs robs workers of wages, fuels the growth of the Federal budget deficit and puts affordable care out of reach for millions of Americans.
Left unchecked, rising health care costs will consume almost two-thirds of the increase in Gross Domestic Product for each American for the rest of the decade.
Health care costs will grow from 14 percent of G.D.P. to 19 percent even without an expansion of coverage to insure all Americans.
Bureaucracy overwhelms consumers and health providers. Excessive paperwork confuses and frustrates doctors, nurses, patients and their families. Bureaucracy also drives up costs. Studies document that administrative costs contribute a steeply rising portion of the expenses involved in running a typical doctor's office or hospital.
Quality is uneven. Because no clear standards define best medical practice, lack of information and inadequate attention to prevention make the quality of health care across America uneven. Consumers have no reliable information with which to measure the quality of their health care or coverage.
Coverage for long-term care is inadequate. Many elderly and disabled Americans enter nursing homes and other institutions when they would prefer to remain at home. Families exhaust their resources trying to provide for disabled relatives.
Many Americans cannot obtain quality care. In many rural and inner-city areas, shortages of doctors, clinics and hospitals form barriers to care.
Fraud and abuse cheat everyone. Many Americans believe that exorbitant charges, fraud and abuse undermine both quality and access to care.
 
The Overview
The American Health Security Act guarantees comprehensive health coverage for all Americans regardless of health or employment status. Health coverage continues without interruption if Americans lose or change jobs, move from one area to another, become ill or confront a family crisis.
Through a system of regional and corporate health alliances that organize the buying power of consumers and employers, the American Health Security Act stimulates market forces so that health plans and providers compete on the basis of quality, service and price.
Under the act, health plans must meet national standards on benefits, quality and access to care, but each state may tailor the new system to local needs and conditions. Thus the program encourages local innovation with a national framework.
It frees the health care system of much of the accumulated burden of unnecessary regulation and paperwork, allowing doctors, nurses, hospitals and other health providers to focus on providing high-quality care.
 
Creating Security
The American Health Security Act enhances the security of the American people by extending universal coverage in a environment that improves quality and controls rising costs:
All employers contribute to health coverage for their employees, creating a level playing field among companies.
Everyone shares the responsibility to pay for coverage.
Limits on out-of-pocket payments protect American families from catastrophic costs, while subsidies ease the burden on low-income individuals and small employers.
A comprehensive benefit package with no lifetime limits on medical coverage guarantees access to a full range of medically necessary or appropriate services.
Elderly and disabled Americans receive coverage for outpatient prescription drugs under Medicare for the first time.
Guaranteed choice of health plans and providers enhances choice for many Americans.
No health plan may deny enrollment to any applicant because of health, employment or financial status or may they charge some patients more than others because of age, medical condition or other factors related to risk.
All health plans meet national quality standards and provide useful information that allows consumers to make valid comparisons among plans and providers.
Separate programs increase Federal support for long-term care and improve the quality and reliability of private long-term care insurance.
 
Controlling Costs
The American Health Security Act brings growth in health care costs in line with growth in Gross Domestic Product by 1977. It accomplishes this goal by increasing competition in health care, reducing administrative costs and imposing budget discipline:
A standard, universal package of health benefits and reliable information about the price and performance of health plans encourages informed choices.
Consumers pay less for low-cost plans and more for high-cost plans, creating incentives for cost-conscious choice.
Health plans receive fixed premiums based on risk characteristics of their patients. Working under a fixed budget, they have incentives to spend resources cost effectively.
If savings attained through effective competition and reductions in administrative costs do not achieve the spending goals, the national health care budget provides a backstop, ensuring that health care spending is in line with economic growth.
Like the private sector, major government programs, including Medicare and Medicaid, also operate under a budget restraining the growth of Federal and state spending for health care.
 
Enhancing Quality
The American Health Security Act improves the quality of health care by creating standards and guidelines for practitioners, reorienting quality assurance to measuring outcomes rather than regulatory process, increasing the national commitment to medical research and promoting primary and preventive care.
Explicit quality goals and standards shape the health care system.
Health plans are held accountable for quality improvement.
Regular publication of accessible information about quality and cost allows consumers to make informed choices among health care plans.
Increased investment in research advances medical knowledge.
A special funding mechanism insures that academic health centers continue their vital role in research, training and specialty care.
New investments support training for primary care physicians and other health professionals; Federal action helps remove artificial barriers to practice that hinder nurses and other non-physicians.
Investments in public health enhance the level of protection for all Americans.
Changes in Medicare rate schedules and in the allocation of Federal funds supporting graduate medical education provide new incentives for primary care physicians.
Pre-emption of state laws limiting the scope of practice and new funding for the education of health professionals who are not physicians enhance opportunities for nurses, social workers and other non-physician providers.
 
Expanding Access to Care
The American Health Security Act invests in the development of an adequate health care system in areas with inadequate service. Those investments hold the promise of improving the availability and quality of health care in rural communities and urban neighborhoods.
Health alliances assume responsibility for building health networks in rural and urban areas with inadequate access.
National loan programs support the efforts of local health providers to develop community-based plans.
Investments in new health programs such as school-based clinics and community clinics expand access to care for underserved populations.
Financial incentives attract health professionals to areas with inadequate care.
 
Reducing Bureaucracy
The American Health Security Act reduces the burden of paperwork and administration; regulatory, billing and reporting requirements decline, and consumers experience a streamlined and simpler system:
A single, comprehensive benefit package that covers every eligible person eliminates confusion about coverage.
Administrative costs caused by multiple policies with different benefits and risk selection disappear.
Standard forms for insurance reimbursement, the submission of claims and clinical encounter records simplify paperwork and reduce administrative costs.
The cost of administering coverage in small companies declines because they purchase through health alliances that benefit from economies of scale.
Federal regulatory requirements for Medicare, Medicaid and other programs are simplified.
Health care services covered by workers' compensation and automobile insurance merge into the new health system, reducing duplication and waste.
Malpractice reform reduces incentives in the current system to perform excessive tests or unnecessary procedures.
 
Reducing Fraud and Abuse
The American Health Security Act cracks down on health care providers and institutions that impose excessive charges or engage in fraudulent practices, setting tough standards and imposing stiffer penalties including:
New criminal penalties for fraud related to health care and for the payment of bribes or gratuities to influence the delivery of health services and coverage.
New civil monetary penalties against providers who submit false claims.
Tighter restrictions eliminate referral "kickbacks" in the private sector, and new standards prohibit physicians from prescribing services delivered at institutions in which they hold financial interests.
Accountability standards make provider fraud and other misbehavior automatic grounds for exclusion from all health plans.
 
Details of the Plan
 
Who Is Covered
A health security card provided to each eligible person entitles him or her to obtain coverage through a health plan that delivers services covered in a nationally defined, comprehensive benefit package.
Eligible individuals enroll in a health plan through a health alliance unless they are covered under government-sponsored health programs that continue, including Medicare; military personnel covered by the Department of Defense; Department of Veterans Affairs; Indian Health Service. Individuals eligible for those programs continue to receive care through them.
Employer Obligation: All employers contribute to the purchase of health coverage for their employees. All employers pay 80 percent of the weighted-average premium for health insurance coverage in the regional alliances which serve their employees or in their corporate alliance. The required employer contribution in regional alliances is capped at a percentage of payroll, with lower caps for small and low-wage employers. . . .
Firms that employ more than 5,000 workers insure that their employees are enrolled in health plans that meet Federal guidelines and report information about enrollment. Employers with more than 5,000 employees that choose to operate corporate alliances may be required to continue to pay for health insurance coverage for their terminated employees for six months following termination or may have to pay 1 percent of payroll to cover unemployed workers.
Large employers may fulfill their obligation to provide coverage by operating a program of self-insurance through a corporate alliance, contracting with a certified health plan or joining the regional alliance. . . .
Individual Obligations: Families and individuals pay 20 percent of the weighted-average premium for an average cost health plan chosen through an alliance. An individual or family who chooses a less expensive plan pays less, and someone who chooses a more expensive plan pays more.
An employer also may elect to pay some or all of the employee's portion of the premium.
Self-employed and unemployed individuals are responsible for paying the family share of the premium as well as the employer share, unless they are eligible for assistance based on income.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Undocumented Persons: Undocumented persons are not eligible for guaranteed health benefits. However, employers are required to pay health insurance premiums for all of their employees, regardless of immigration status. . . .
Territories: Individuals who reside in territories of the United States receive the comprehensive benefit package through their existing health care systems.
Others: States with migrant labor populations are required to address the needs of migrant workers and their families in state plans for the implementation of health reform. . . .
Students who are not dependents enroll in the regional alliance where their school is located.
Employers make contributions toward health care premiums for part-time employees (generally individuals working more than 10 hours but less than 30 hours per week) on a pro-rated basis.
Prisoners remain the financial responsibility of the various prison systems.
 
Benefits
The health benefits guaranteed to all Americans provide comprehensive coverage, including mental health services, substance-abuse treatment, some dental services and clinical preventive services.
The guaranteed benefit package contains no lifetime limitations on coverage, with the exception of coverage for orthodontia.
Each health plan must provide coverage for the following categories of services as medically necessary or appropriate with additional limitations and cost sharing only as specified in the American Health Security Act of 1993 or by the National Health Board. Covered health services are:
*Hospital services
*Emergency services
*Services of physicians and other health professionals
*Clinical preventive services
*Mental health and substance abuse services
*Family planning services
*Pregnancy-related services
*Hospice
*Home health care
*Extended-care services
*Ambulance services
*Outpatient laboratory and diagnostic services
*Outpatient prescription drugs and biologicals
*Outpatient rehabilitation services
*Durable medical equipment, prosthetic and orthotic devices
*Vision and hearing care
*Preventive dental services for children
*Health education classes

 	 	 		. . .	 	Clinical preventive services: Targeted screening tests and immunizations required for high-risk patients, as defined by the National Health Board, are covered under outpatient laboratory and diagnostic services and outpatient prescription drugs and biologicals. Periodic medical examinations: every three years for individuals ages 20 to 39, every two years for adults ages 40 to 65, and annually for adults ages 65 or more.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Home health care: Same services as under the current Medicare program (including skilled nursing, physical, occupational and speech therapy, prescribed social services) with the addition of prescribed home infusion therapy and outpatient prescription drugs and biologicals.
Limitations: Only as an alternative to institutionalization (i.e., inpatient treatment in a hospital, skilled nursing or rehabilitation center) for illness or injury. At the end of each 60 days of treatment, the need for continued therapy is re-evaluated. . . .
Extended care services: Inpatient services in a skilled nursing or rehabilitation facility.
Limitations: Only after an acute illness or injury as an altemative to continued hospitalization; maximum of 100 days per calendar year.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Mental Health and Substance Abuse: By the year 2001, all states are required to submit to the National Health Board a plan detailing steps it is undertaking to move from the traditional two-tier structure for separate public and private mental health and substance abuse services and develop an integrated, comprehensive managed system of care.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Exclusions
The benefit package does not cover services that are not medically necessary or appropriate, private duty nursing, cosmetic orthodontia and other cosmetic surgery, hearing aids, adult eyeglasses and contact lenses, in vitro fertilization services, sex-change surgery and related services, private room accommodations, custodial care, personal comfort services and supplies.
 
National Health Board
The American Health Security Act creates an independent National Health Board responsible for setting national standards and overseeing the establishment and administration of the new health system by states.

 	 	 		. . .	 	In the event that a state fails to meet the deadline for establishing regional health alliances or fails to operate the alliance system in compliance with Federal requirements, the National Health Board insures that all eligible individuals have access to services covered in the comprehensive benefit package.
To induce a state to act, the National Health Board informs the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services of a state's failure to comply. The Secretary has the authority to order the withholding of Federal health appropriations.

 	 	 		. . .	 	When the National Board notifies the Secretary of Health and Human Services that a state has failed to comply with Federal requirements, the National Board shall also notify the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury will impose a payroll tax on all employers in the state. . . .
 
Establishment of Alliances
No later than Jan. 1, 1997, each state must establish one or more regional health alliances responsible for providing health coverage to residents in every area of the state. . . .
States may not establish boundaries for health alliances that concentrate racial or ethnic minority groups, socioeconomic groups or Medicaid beneficiaries.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Fee-for-Service Plans
Each alliance includes among its health plan offerings at least one plan organized around a fee-for-service system. A fee-for-service system is one in which patients have the option of consulting any health provider subject to reasonable requirements. Reasonable requirements may include utilization review and prior approval for certain services but do not include a requirement to seek approval through a gatekeeper.
Under certain conditions, with approval from the National Health Board, a state may waive the requirement for each alliance to offer a fee-for-service health plan.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Budget
The American Health Security Act organizes the market for health care and creates mechanisms to control costs through enhanced competition, consumer choice, administrative simplification and increased negotiating power through health alliances. A national health care budget serves as a backstop to that system of incentives and organized market power. The budget insures that health care costs do not rise faster that other sectors of the economy.
The national health care budget centers on the weighted average premium for the nationally guaranteed benefits package in regional health alliances, establishing a target for how much that average premium may increase each year. The Federal Government assumes responsibility for enforcing alliance budgets. . . .
Health care expenditures covered by the budget include premiums paid to cover the guaranteed comprehensive benefit package whether paid by employers, employees, or individuals. Medicare and Medicaid expenditures are included under separate budgets.
Supplemental benefits beyond the comprehensive benefit package, as well as workers' compensation and auto insurance benefits, are not included in the budget. Premiums for insurance policies providing coverage for cost sharing are not included.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Drug Pricing
The case of new drugs that the Secretary [of Health and Human Services] determines are excessively or inappropriately priced, the Secretary has the authority to negotiate a special rebate with the manufacturer. Such a determination by the Secretary would be based on such factors as prices of other drugs in the same therapeutic class, cost information supplied by the manufacturer to the Secretary, prices of the drugs in other comparable counties, and other relevant factors. If a manufacturer refuses to negotiate or the Secretary is unable to negotiate a price that the Secretary determines to be reasonable, the Secretary may exclude the new drug from coverage under Medicare.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Medicaid
Under-65 Medicaid recipients who are not receiving either A.F.D.C. [Aid to Families with Dependent Children] or S.S.I. [Supplemental Security Income] cash payments will no longer receive insurance through Medicaid. They will enter regional and corporate alliances based on their employment status.
An exception to this policy is that undocumented persons will continue to receive Medicaid coverage for emergency services.
The Medicaid program will continue to make payments on behalf of A.F.D.C. and S.S.I. recipients.


GRAPHIC: American Health Security Act -- The name of the legislation that President Clinton will propose to Congress to overhaul the nation's health care system.
Chart: "THE LANGUAGE OF HEALTH CARE"
Employer mandate -- The Clinton plan's requirement that employers pay at least 80 percent of the cost of health coverage for their workers.
Guaranteed national benefit package -- The standard comprehensive coverage that would be guaranteed all Americans as a result of the President's proposal.
Health alliances -- Purchasing groups that, under the Clinton plan, would each buy health care services for thousands of consumers. The alliances would be of two types: regional health alliances, whose creation would be the responsibility of the states, and corporate health alliances. A corporate alliance could be established by any large employer (in general, one with more than 5,000 workers). But such an employer would have the option of joining a regional alliance instead.
Health plans -- The insurers that would provide coverage through contracts negotiated with regional or corporate health alliances.
Managed competition -- A health care policy, largely embraced by the President, that combines free-market forces with Government regulation. In this concept, large groups of consumers buy health care from networks of care providers. The aim is to create business competition among those networks, thereby restraining prices and encouraging quality of care.
Medicaid -- The existing Federal-state program of health coverage for the poor. Under the Clinton plan, Medicaid beneficiaries are to be folded into the health alliance system.
Medicare -- The existing Federal program of health coverage for the elderly and the disabled. Under the Clinton plan, a state could apply to the Government for permission to include Medicare beneficiaries in the alliance system, and a person who was already included in an alliance upon turning 65 would have the option of remaining.
National Health Board -- A seven-member Federal panel that would be appointed by the President to oversee the states' creation of regional health alliances, interpret the guaranteed benefits package, enforce a national health care budget, monitor the quality of health care and investigate pharmaceutical companies' prices for new drugs if evidence suggested that the prices were unreasonably high.
National health security card -- An identification card that would serve as proof of a person's eligibility for the Government-guaranteed package of benefits. All citizens and legal aliens would be eligible.
Single-payer option -- A provision of the Clinton plan that a state would be allowed to enact as an alternative to the system of regional health alliances. Under this alternative, the state would make direct payments to health care providers, with no intermediaries.

HEADLINE: Salvador Journal;
In Brazil, a City Has Its Own Harlem Renaissance

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALVADOR, Brazil

 BODY:
Welcoming patrons to his stylish new restaurant here, Elon Carneiro Coelho's eye was caught one recent evening by the bust of an ancient Greek healer brooding in a wall niche across a narrow cobblestone street.
"My father studied medicine there," he said, waving toward Brazil's first medical school, a decaying neoclassical landmark of Salvador's historic center, the Pelourinho. "But my generation always avoided coming here. Despite the historic buildings, we always saw the Pelourinho as ugly, rundown, dangerous." 
 But in a turn of the generational wheel, Mr. Coelho returned to the Pelourinho in July to open his Catarina Paraguacu restaurant in a restored colonial-era town house.
No risk-taking pioneer, Mr. Coelho is capitalizing on Brazil's growing movement for historic preservation.
 
Back from the Future
 In the 1960's, Brazil promoted itself as "the country of the future" and turned boldly to its interior wilderness to build Brasilia, a modernistic capital for a young nation. Today, after decades of helter-skelter industrialization, Brazilians are looking to their past, seeking to restore the colonial cores of their coastal cities.
"There has been a big change -- suddenly there is nationwide concern for historic preservation," Ciro Pirondi, president of the Institute of Architects of Brazil, said recently at Sao Paulo's Second International Architecture Biennial. Critics said Brazil's strongest entries included restoration projects for Rio de Janeiro, Sao Luis, Florianopolis and Salvador.
Salvador, a city of red roofs on a bluff overlooking a sparkling blue bay, is the site of the most ambitious project. Galvanized by growing tourism and a conviction that its cultural patrimony is crumbling, the government of Bahia State is investing $30 million to renovate 350 colonial-era buildings in the city's historic center.
For Americans, the Pelourinho, or Pillory Square, is perhaps best known as the setting for "Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands," a movie based on the novel by Jorge Amado, a former resident of the Pelourinho, a sloping triangle of cobblestones.
 
A Colonial Treasure
 Brazil's fourth largest city, Salvador has the richest raw material for preservationists: the nation's largest collection of colonial architecture.
When the English Pilgrims landed at Plymouth Rock, Salvador was a 71-year-old city that already ranked as a colonial capital. Second only to Lisbon in Portugal's far-flung empire, 18th-century Salvador was the busiest port in the South Atlantic.
But in 1763 the colony's government shifted to Rio, and in the 19th century Brazil's economic locus shifted to Sao Paulo. By the end of the 19th century, Salvador's moneyed families started to abandon the city's colonial heart, and by the 1920's, it was officially designated the city's red-light district.
Without maintenance, historic buildings fell to ruin.
"The government had two choices: restore the area, or let people continue living in subhuman conditions, where they risked dying in collapsing buildings," said Adriana Castro, restoration director for the Institute of Artistic and Cultural Heritage, the state agency that is overseeing the renewal of Pelourinho.
 
A Transformation
 One year after the work began, the transformation is startling.
Overhead cobwebs of electrical wires have disappeared underground. Crumbling facades pocked by empty window frames have been replaced with stucco painted in colonial pastels. Backyard outhouses have disappeared as sewer lines have been installed.
In alleys once patrolled by prostitutes and pickpockets, young tourists and Bahians crowd the tables of piano bars and sidewalk cafes.
In Brazil as elsewhere, historic preservation often means gentrification. Community leaders estimate that as many as 500 people were forced to move.
"If the building was important they just gave the people living there $300 and said, 'Get a new house,' " said Dimitri Ganzelevitch, a French art dealer who lives there.
 
Afro-Brazilian Showcase
 But others see an Afro-Brazilian renaissance in a neighborhood that has been a stronghold of black culture. Over the centuries, the Pelourinho has been closely identified with the trajectory of Salvador's black-majority population: in the 18th century as slave market and pillory, in the 19th century as the site of city's most powerful black church, in the late 20th century as the home of thriving Afro-Brazilian restaurants and reggae-samba music groups.
Several black political and cultural groups have opened offices and boutiques in the Pelourinho.
"I don't think that tourists are 'whitening' Pelourinho," said Joao Jorge Santos Rodrigues, president of Olodum, an Afro-Brazilian drum corps that long lobbied for the neighborhood's renewal. "Restoring our Harlem doesn't mean whitening it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brazil once promoted itself as "the country of the future," but has recently turned to a movement of historic preservation. Bahia State is investing $30 million to renovate 350 colonial-era buildings in Pelourinho, the historic center of Salvador. Construction crews restored an old church. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bonds Soar on Producer-Price Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices roared back yesterday on news of an unexpected plunge in August producer prices. The gains nearly erased Thursday's steep losses. Leading the rally were long-term bonds, which are most susceptible to inflation pressures.
The Treasury's 30-year bond, which plummeted 17/16points Thursday, gained 1 1/4 points, or $12.50 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield dropped to 5.87 percent, just above the record low of 5.86 percent set on Wednesday. On Thursday, the yield closed at 5.96 percent. 
 The drop in interest rates helped stock prices, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 32.14 points.
Bond traders searching for confirmation that inflation remains low said they were pleasantly shocked by the Labor Department's report of a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent in wholesale prices last month. Moreover, the so-called core rate of wholesale inflation -- excluding the volatile energy and food components -- dropped a huge 1 percent. Most economists had expected a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in both figures.
 
'A Big Roar'
 "There was a big roar that came out of everyone's mouth" when the report was released at 8:30 A.M., said Frank Marchetti, a bond trader at Fuji Securities Inc.
The drop was so steep that most traders overlooked the fact that the fall in producer prices resulted mainly from plunging tobacco rates. Bond investors often dismiss inflation figures that are overly influenced by price changes in one commodity.
The numbers reassured investors that the low inflation that has sent interest rates plummeting to their lowest levels in 25 years remains firmly in place.
Also reinforcing that notion were falling prices for commodities, including gold and oil. The Commodity Research Bureau index, a measure of daily price changes and a barometer of inflation trends, fell 1.70, to 213.17.
The August price data also reinvigorated speculation that the Federal Reserve has room to ease short-term interest rates to help stimulate growth. Those expectations were hurt earlier this week after Federal Reserve officials suggested the central bank did not intend to reduce short-term rates any further.
Prices of short-term Treasury securities rose 5/32 point to 1/4 point yesterday and intermediate maturities rose 3/8 point to 9/16 point, the financial information service Telerate Inc. reported. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 5.07, to 1,338.43.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 3.01 percent as the discount dropped 2 basis points, to 2.95 percent. Six-month yields fell to 3.14 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points, to 3.05 percent. One-year yields dropped to 3.29 percent as the discount fell 5 basis points, to 3.18 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 2.94 percent, down from 3 percent late Thursday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10519/32 , up 1/4 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.47 percent, up from 5.46 percent.

HEADLINE: Inflation Report Gives Stocks a Rebound

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Eager buyers flooded back to the stock market yesterday, erasing most of the week's previous losses on the strength of surprisingly good news about inflation and a subsequent drop in interest rates.
Technology, banking and oil stocks were among the strongest sectors of the market, which took off early in the day after the Government reported that wholesale prices declined six-tenths of a percent in August, the biggest drop in two and a half years. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,621.63, up 32.14 points, apparently indicating that investors had lost their nervousness about soaring stock prices. For the shortened post-Labor Day week, the Dow industrials had a net loss of 12.30 points.
It was a week in which stocks made some unusual movements. In the first two trading days, the Dow lost a total of 45 points despite rising bond prices and lower long-term interest rates, which usually make stocks more attractive to investors. Thursday was a flat day. And yesterday stocks moved higher along with bond prices, which rallied on the news of low inflation and the prospects for lower interest rates.
 
'Financial Market Heaven'
 Richard J. Hoffman, the chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company, said the buyers yesterday were drawn by the conviction that interest rates would drop further, and by corporate profits that were a little better than expected, given the slow growth of the economy.
Looking back on the week's roller-coaster trading, Mr. Hoffman said, "Economic purgatory has turned into financial market heaven."
He added: "The main characteristic of this market ever since the inception of the bull market has been the question, 'When is it going to end?' The higher it gets, the more anxiety there is."
Contributing to the activity yesterday was a flurry of buying by investors seeking to cover their short positions, or bets that the market would fall. "This bull market has taken no prisoners," Mr. Hoffman said. "And if you've been short this market, you've been in trouble."
The Standard & Poor's 500 ended up 4.22, at 461.72, and the American Stock Exchange composite was up 2.68, at 456.06. The Nasdaq composite was up a strong 6.60 to finish at 744.31.
 
Technology Stocks Gain
 Four program trades raised the Dow by a total of more than 9 points, according to Philip H. Smyth, who tracks program trading for Birinyi Associates. He called the impact "fairly significant."
Technology stocks again were among the strongest gainers, with semiconductor issues leading the way. National Semiconductor was up 1 3/8, to 20 5/8, on a good earnings report and upgrades from financial analysts. Kyocera finished up 1 1/4, at 118 3/4, and Applied Materials closed up 3 5/8, at 71 5/8.
Other technology gainers included Lotus Development, up 1, to 36 3/4; Microsoft, up 1 3/4, to 78; Texas Instruments, up 1 1/8, to 78 5/8, and Intel, up 3/4, to 65 1/2.
Among the interest rate-sensitive stocks that climbed yesterday were bank issues, which continued a rise that began on Thursday on the predictions of good third-quarter earnings. Big gainers were Wells Fargo, up 2, to 121 5/8; First Chicago, up 3/4, to 48; and J. P. Morgan, up 1 3/8, to 79.
Oil stocks also did well, with Royal Dutch Petroleum up 2 1/8, to 103 3/4, Chevron up 1, to 89 3/8, and Texaco up 1 5/8, to 66 1/8.
Other big gainers were Manufactured Homes, a real estate investment trust based in Chicago, which closed at 41 5/8, up 3 7/8, on the news that it was holding talks on a big acquisition. Paramount closed up 4 1/4, at 61 1/8, on rising earnings and news of its potential merger with Viacom.
One of the day's biggest losers was Media Logic, a maker of computer testing equipment that predicted disappointing second-quarter sales. It was down 4 1/2, to 6 5/8, losing 40 percent of its value to wind up as the biggest percentage loser for the day on the American Stock Exchange.
In Tokyo yesterday, stocks ended mixed. The 225-share Nikkei average was down 7.60 points, or 0.04 percent, to 20,817.98.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Post 0.6% Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
In a report showing surprisingly low inflation, the Government said today that plunging tobacco prices drove the Producer Price Index down six-tenths of a percent in August, the fourth straight decline and the biggest drop in two and a half years.
In the latest 12 months, prices received by American producers have risen a scant 1 percent or less at all stages of processing, a performance that delights the Federal Reserve and other policy makers. But it also raises concerns because sluggish business activity is largely responsible for the low inflation. 
 "It's a sign of the times," Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Chemical Banking Corporation, said of the results. "The economy is not strengthening, and it may be weakening."
 
Difficult to Charge More
 John M. Albertine, a Washington consultant who is increasingly fearful of recession, said, "If you're not selling anything, it's hard to raise prices and make them stick."
The four-month decline, which was registered after the figure for May was revised to a drop of one-tenth of a percent from unchanged, represents the first time wholesale prices have declined four months in a row since the beginning of 1986.
Analysts hailed the inflation news and bond prices headed back toward record peaks. [Page 46.] But examination of the figures disclosed that inflation has not quite disappeared, nor is it likely to do so even if oil prices continue to fall.
Excluding tobacco, a sector marked by price wars, prices at the producer level rose a modest two-tenths of a percent for both the overall rate and the so-called core rate, which excludes the gyrating food and energy components.
The prospect for the coming months, suggested Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley, is for an underlying rate of about 2 percent at the producer level and about 3 percent for the Consumer Price Index, which is also expected to show favorable results for August when it is reported on Tuesday. He said the price war in tobacco was a one-time phenomenon, though brand loyalty had faded among other products, too.
 
Possible Shift by Fed
 Still, the Federal Reserve was thought today to be even more likely to subtly shift its monetary stance at a Sept. 21 policy meeting from a bias toward tightening credit to a position of neutrality.
The six-tenths-of-a-percent decline in the finished-goods index in August resulted from an unprecedented 25.6 percent dive for tobacco products, one that could not be dismissed as a statistical aberration because it was even steeper before adjustment for recurring seasonal patterns.
Energy prices fell eight-tenths of a percent, also the fourth straight decline, but this was offset by food prices that turned up five-tenths of a percent, while automobiles rose 1 percent. Prescription drugs advanced five-tenths of a percent, half the July rise but twice June's increase.
For the 12-month period ended in August, finished goods -- those ready for sale to the consumer or final business user -- rose six-tenths of a percent.
Today's report by the Labor Department also showed that without food and energy, the Producer Price Index for finished goods dropped in August by 1 percent, the biggest monthly drop on record.
This reflected the collapse in the price of tobacco, which according to Kathryn L. Kobe, an economist at Joel Popkin & Company, accounts for only about 3 percent of the Producer Price Index and may be even less important than that in today's economy because there are fewer smokers.
 
Across Production Levels
 Inflation at the earlier stages of production also was firmly under control last month.
For intermediate goods, like a bolt of cloth, prices were unchanged over all. Construction materials turned up, energy items fell a bit less than in July and the rise in foods and feeds slackened considerably.
Nondurables for manufacturing, like chemicals, edged down a tenth of a percent, but factory durables climbed two-tenths of a percent. This durables category showed big jumps for plywood and for hot-rolled sheet and strip steel and big declines for copper and brass ingots and other mill shapes. Silver, gold, zinc and hardwood turned down after rising in July.
For crude goods, like raw cotton, prices fell five-tenths of a percent last month, somewhat less than the declines of June and July. Basic industrial materials turned down for the first time since November, the Labor Department's report also showed.
Prices of crude energy declined 1.8 percent after skidding 4.9 percent in July. Foods and feeds rose 1.6 percent, up from 1.2 percent.
Crude goods other than energy and food fell 2.6 percent after a fractional July rise. Iron and steel scrap tumbled 7.2 percent, and softwood logs and copper and aluminum scrap also fell. Leaf tobacco, however, rose again.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Against Yen But Falls to a Low vs. Mark

BYLINE: The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained on the Japanese yen yesterday but fell to a 14-week low against the German mark as investors interpreted a drop in producer prices in the United States as further evidence that American interest rates would stay lower than those in Europe.
The dollar continued to fall in Europe a day after Germany cut interest rates, prompting several other European countries to follow suit. Traders said it appeared that Germany was not planning any further rate cuts soon, leaving European interest rates higher than those in the United States, a condition that weakens the dollar's value. 
 "There seems to be a feeling that European stock and bond markets will give you better returns than the U.S. at this point," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank.
That sentiment was persuading investors to buy European currencies rather than the dollar.
 
 
Inflation Not a Concern

Traders also said a decline of six-tenths of a percent in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index in August meant that inflation would not be of concern to the Federal Reserve, which would have little reason to raise interest rates.
Meanwhile, the dollar rose against the yen as investors anticipated a Japanese cut in interest rates and progress in talks on reducing Japan's trade surplus with the United States.
The yen has soared this year, in part on market perceptions that Washington wants a strong yen to reduce the surplus. A strong yen makes Japan's exports more expensive and its imports cheaper.
 
 
Yen Is Not the Issue
 "The markets have finally come to realize the yen is not really the core matter when the U.S. and Japan get together at the table," said David Gilmore of MCM Currency Watch, an analysis service in New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar settled at 105.63 yen, up 0.25 yen from Thursday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 106.15 yen, up from 105.00. In New York, the dollar traded at 106.10 yen, up from 105.33 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.5500, down from $1.5510 late Thursday. In New York, the pound was trading at $1.5520, up from $1.5510 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Acts To Show He Is Candidate For Change

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Striving to invigorate his campaign on the eve of a desultory Democratic primary and counter criticism that he lacks a vision for the future, Mayor David N. Dinkins is taking a flurry of actions to argue that he, not just Rudolph W. Giuliani, can be a candidate for change.
This week the Dinkins campaign sent a mailing to more than 100,000 households in liberal swing neighborhoods like the Upper West Side and Park Slope, Brooklyn, highlighting his efforts to start new programs despite tough times. The eight-page flier invites voters to "Give Mayor Dinkins a Piece of Your Mind" by returning the back page with their own views on whether the city should keep building housing for the homeless, place tolls on the East River bridges and other questions.
 
Outlining His Priorities
 On Monday Mr. Dinkins plans a speech to outline a broad range of programs in fields like education, crime and the economy that would be among his top priorities should he win a second term. His proposals -- a mix of old and new ideas -- range from a longer school year to a new core curriculum of educational basics to neighborhood business centers, financed with the help of computer companies, that would provide access to office equipment for the owners of small shops who could not yet afford their own. 
 "It's him saying this election is about substance, choices and differences," said Peter Johnson Jr., a Manhattan lawyer, informal Dinkins adviser and occasional speechwriter who helped draft the plan. "In essence, the Mayor says we must provoke the future, not invoke the past."
That is a not-so-veiled dig at Mr. Giuliani, who has issued a range of comparable plans in recent weeks, often invoking the city's past glories and complaining that Mr. Dinkins has presided over a slow decline that will only grow worse if he is re-elected.
 
Focusing on Giuliani
 For his part, Mr. Dinkins is doing all he can to keep the focus on Mr. Giuliani and not on Tuesday's Democratic primary, in which he is assured of victory but hoping to hold down a potential protest vote for Roy E. Innis, the conservative chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, or Eric Ruano-Melendez, a civil engineer and real-estate broker from Queens who has said he is making a symbolic run as a Hispanic candidate. Aides said one point of the flier, for example, was to let voters vent anger at the Mayor by writing to him rather than by voting against him.
The Mayor used a televised debate with the two on Thursday night to accuse Mr. Innis of being a "stalking horse" for Mr. Giuliani and to stress his own experience in presiding at City Hall.
Yesterday Mr. Dinkins attacked Mr. Giuliani for running a campaign of sound bites and slogans as he backs a conservative agenda "learned at Ronald Reagan's knee." Mr. Giuliani made almost the same charges against the Mayor, complaining that Mr. Dinkins was using "selective statistics" to show that crime is down in the city and accusing him of waging a campaign that amounted to "a slogan a day."
 
Countering Criticism
 By making the speech -- the result of several months of consultation with top aides and local academic experts -- the Mayor hopes to counter widespread criticism that his administration has often drifted from crisis to crisis without a blueprint for the future.
Many of the proposals, to be delivered to an invited audience of supporters at the Sheraton New York, would require state legislation or City Council approval. Most of the specifics and financing remain to be determined, and the city is already facing multibillion-dollar budget gaps in the coming years.
Mayoral advisers said the plan grew out of their conviction that most of the Mayor's term has been dominated by responding to the overwhelming budget gaps and a recession that have forced him to trim city services.
 
'From the Ground Up'
 "We have to make people believe that when you vote for David Dinkins the next four years are going to be better and different," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University and a campaign adviser. "Giuliani doesn't have any great ideas, but people want a promise of action."
"The era of the big project, the mega-solution, is gone," Mr. Moss added. "The future is in building from the ground up."
Among the proposals that have been discussed and rejected in the past is one to merge the city's three police forces. Mr. Dinkins will also call for expanding the use of computer technology to cut down on arrest times and paperwork to free up more officers for patrol, and targeted investments in local industries from biotechnology to jewelry, retailing and recycling.
Mr. Dinkins planned the speech even as his campaign sent a flier aimed especially at liberals in heavily gay and Jewish neighborhoods like Riverdale and Greenwich Village.
 
'If You're Not Satisfied'
 The mailing begins with the words: "If you're not satisfied with everything in New York City, join the club. Neither am I." over Mr. Dinkins's name, and it goes on to say: "Not everything has gone right; I am a human being and I make mistakes -- as any Mayor would. But I'm a man who learns from his mistakes and moves to rectify them."
The flier lists the Mayor's efforts to open schools in the evenings, start neighborhood health centers and expand the police force. Finally, it asks voters to tear off the back page, which lists six questions on their views on topics from cutting back garbage collection to changing the property tax system, and to send their answers to the campaign. They are also asked to write an essay on the single thing the Mayor has done that most upsets them, and the thing that most pleases them.
Andrea Bernstein, a deputy campaign manager, said the flier was the first in a series and had so far prompted about 75 responses, with most citing hiring more police officers, extending library hours and recycling and support for gay rights as the things that had most pleased them and the Mayor's handling of the Crown Heights disturbances and a general sense that he was not tough enough as the things that had most bothered them.

HEADLINE: Japan Seems to Ease Stand On Setting Trade Targets

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Japan's Foreign Minister, in what appears to open the way to a loosening of this nation's stance, suggested today that it might be acceptable for Japan and the United States to discuss setting numerical targets for reducing Japan's overall trade surplus.
The minister, Tsutomu Hata, did not clearly call for such targets and his remarks were disavowed by some other officials, including Chief Cabinet Secretary Masayoshi Takemura, the official Government spokesman. 
 Nonetheless, his remarks mirror a groundswell of opinion here in favor of numerical targets, an idea that Japan has resisted.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, welcomed Mr. Hata's comments.
"Japan's huge global trade surpluses represent the major asymmetry in the world economy today," Mr. Kantor said in a statement this evening. "A commitment to a specific numerical reduction in that surplus will help in maintaining the health and the credibility of the global trading system."
In July, during negotiations for a basic trade framework between the two nations, the United States asked Japan to agree to cut its current-account surplus with the rest of the world, suggesting a figure of 1 to 2 percent of Japan's economic output, within a few years, from more than 3 percent now.
But Japan insisted that such a target would violate free trade and that the surplus depended on factors beyond the Government's control. It also feared it would set itself up for punishment by the United States if it set goals and then did not reach them.
 
Bold Steps Urged
 But just this week, leaders of two prominent business lobbying groups urged the Government to consider agreeing to such targets. They contended that unless bold steps were taken to improve relations with the United States and cut the trade gap, the upward pressure on the yen would continue, crippling Japan's blue-chip companies.
Mr. Hata made his remarks as Japan and the United States began negotiations this week to flesh out the trade framework signed in early July by President Clinton and Kiichi Miyazawa, who was then the Prime Minister.
The new Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, is to meet Mr. Clinton in New York later this month . At that meeting Mr. Hosokawa is expected to present Mr. Clinton with an "omiyage," or gift, consisting of new plans for Japan to reduce its trade surplus and stimulate its economy.
The trade framework signed in July calls only for Japan to take actions to bring about a "highly significant" reduction in the trade surplus. The new Hosokawa Government has said it would honor the trade agreement.
 
Room Left for Argument
 The wording in the agreement, however, leaves room for argument and debate. The United States has been insisting that "highly signficant" means the surplus should drop below 2 percent of economic output. Japan has been rejecting this interpretation, but may now be warming up to it.
At a news conference today, Foreign Minister Hata said: "Regarding the total surplus, it will be hard for us to get an understanding unless we set up a target. There is a common-sense range for what kind of a level should be permissible. I think it is possible for us to debate such things as a target."
But he did not specify a figure and also said that any goal should not be binding and should be easily modifiable if economic conditions changed. He also said he remained opposed to targets for specific industries or products, like how large a share of Japan's market should be held by foreign automobile or computer manufacturers.
 
Distinction Is Drawn
 The business leaders who favor setting a target for the trade surplus also draw a distinction between such a broad goal and goals for specific industries or products, which they said would constitute unacceptable government interference in the purchasing decisions of private companies and individual consumers.
On Thursday, Takeshi Nagano, the chairman of the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations, said that it would be "appropriate to bring the surplus down to within 2 percent of the gross national product."
His remarks echoed those of Masaru Hayami, chairman of the Japan Association of Corporate Executives, who proposed a target when he met with Prime Minister Hosokawa on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Wild Day for Commodities: Oil, Gold and Soybeans Fall

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Bearish economic news touched off a wild day in the commodity markets yesterday, with crude oil prices falling to their lowest level in three years, gold prices to the lowest in four months, and soybeans to the lowest since June.
Analysts said gold prices might stabilize, but crude oil and soybeans should be in for more losses. 
 Frenzied trading was seen in all these markets, with selling initially motivated by a Government report showing that wholesale prices fell in August.
"Inflationary pressures are not building and the economy has been sluggish," said Steve Platt, vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Sluggish inflation is bad news for commodity traders, who bought a variety of commodities over the last few months on the expectations that prices would rise.
Traders said a two-week collapse in energy futures would continue unless OPEC stitched together a realistic accord at its Sept. 25 meeting to stem the world oil glut.
 
Crude Down 21 Cents
 Crude has lost about $2 a barrel, or 10 percent, since Aug. 27. At yesterday's close at the New York Mercantile Exchange, October crude settled down 21 cents, at $16.76 a barrel.
Gold prices, which commonly mirror the rise and fall of inflation, tumbled from the three-year high set in August. At the close at the New York Commodity Exchange, October gold was at $350.70 an ounce, down $4.10 from Thursday. September silver plunged 17.5 cents, to $4.065 an ounce.
Selling hit soybean prices on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department raised its crop estimate to 1.909 billion bushels from the 1.902 billion estimated in August.
Vic Lespinasse of Dean Witter Reynolds said that if weather forecasts predict beneficial weather in Midwest growing areas for the next 10 days, soybean prices should fall again on Monday.
The November soybean contract closed down 21 1/4 cents a bushel at $6.20 1/4 - a sharp move considering the maximum allowable drop is 30 cents.
The one exception to the lower prices was cotton, which rose sharply. The Agriculture Department estimated that American production would exceed China's for the first time since 1981.
The December cotton contract at the New York Cotton Exchange rose by the 2-cent-a-pound limit, to 59.34 cents.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Liens by Contractors
Q Can you explain what the term "mechanic's lien" means?
 
MARK SCHROEDER, Bronxville, N.Y.
A A mechanic's lien gives a contractor or subcontractor who has performed work on your home the right to collect a debt upon its sale. The method of enforcing such a lien varies. In some states, the contractor can force the property to be sold immediately to satisfy his claim; in others, collection cannot begin until the house is sold or used as collateral for a loan. 
 If materials or services used to improve the property are not paid for by either the homeowner or the contractor, a mechanic's lien might be filed at the local courthouse. Depending on the state, a homeowner may or may not be notified. If you are notified, you may have the right to dispute the lien's amount and validity.
"One danger is that even if you pay the contractor, the contractor may not pay the subcontractor," said Margot Saunders, managing attorney of the National Consumers Law Center in Washington. "A good way to protect yourself is to require a waiver of lien from the contractor, if your state law allows."
 
Floaters
Q What are floating-rate notes?
 
SHELAGH DALY, Hoboken, N.J.
A Floating-rate notes, or floaters, are debt instruments with a variable interest rate. Adjustments are made periodically, typically every three months, with the rate based on a predetermined spread above a benchmark, like the rate on three-month Treasury bills.
"A floating-rate note allows holders to gain by rises in interest rates, but pays lower yields than fixed-rate corporate notes of the same maturity," said Joseph Bencivenga, head of corporate bond research at Salomon Brothers. "Usually the interest rates are subject to caps and floors, which insure that they will not go above or fall below certain predetermined levels."
These notes are generally more attractive to investors when rates are poised to advance and less attractive when the outlook is for falling rates.
 
Value Averaging System
Q How does value averaging differ from dollar-cost averaging?
 
JACK D. SOLOMON, Forest Hills, Queens
A With both value averaging and dollar-cost averaging, you invest in stocks or mutual funds every month or quarter. But with value averaging, you adjust the amount of your investment according to how the security has performed. The goal is to increase the value of the investment by the same amount each month or quarter.
"The value-cost averaging method of investing is more subjective than dollar-cost averaging," said Kenneth S. Janke Sr., president of the National Association of Investors Corporation. "The amount of money increases as the price of the stock drops and decreases as the price rises."
Value averaging requires more time and discipline than dollar-cost averaging. And since the market has an upward bias, you would invest fewer dollars than through dollar-cost averaging.

HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
Fulfilling a Dream While Paying Off Hefty Student Loans

 BODY:
Sharon Gass-Simpkins knew in college that she wanted to be a dentist, but decided after graduation to sample other fields first.
 Starting with a short stint as a flight attendant, she earned a master's degeree in public administration and held a marketing position at the Xerox Corporation for nine years.
 
 In 1984, at age 36, she returned to her original goal -- and entered the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. When she received her degree in 1988, she had taken out $78,000 in student loans. When payments were deferred for nore than three years, interest rates raised the total debt to $150,000.
 In 1992, Dr. Gass-Simpkins started a $55,000-a-year job as director of dental services at the Camden County Health Services Center, which serves low-income and indigent patients. "I find providing care to patients who otherwise can't afford it extremely rewarding," she says, The job also qualified her for a loan-forgiveness program that will pay $70,000 of her debt.
 Here is a look at the paymnent plan, and how it will help her ahcieve her long-deferred goal.
