HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
Highlights of the Clinton Health Plan

 BODY:
All Americans and legal residents would be guaranteed a package of minimum benefits that would continue despite any illnesses or changes in employment.
 
UNIVERSAL COVERAGE
A range of services would be covered, including hospital care, emergency services, doctors and other health professionals, pregnancy-related services, hospice and home health care, ambulances, outpatient laboratory tests and prescription drugs. The Administration describes the coverage as equal to that offered by the nation's largest companies.
 A new long-term care program would be created for disabled people that would provide expanded home care services.
 Coverage of dental, eye and mental health care would be initially limited, but be expanded in the year 2000. Items considered not medically necessary, like cosmetic surgery, would not be covered.
Free preventive care, including periodic medical exams, immunizations and screening procedures like mammograms, pap smears and readings of cholesterol levels would be provided in accordance with a schedule set by the Government.
 A Medicare benefit for prescription drugs would be created. Beneficiaries would pay 25 percent of the program through their Part B premium, a $250 deductible and 20 percent of the costs beyond that to an annual maximum of $1,000.
 A choice would be offered between enrollment in a traditional fee-for-service plan, a health maintenance organization or a plan that combines elements of each.
Employers would be allowed to provide benefits that are more generous than the standard package, although after the year 2000 the extra benefits would be treated as taxable income for employees.
 Illegal immigrants would not be covered, although they would continue to be eligible for emergency and other services; institutions that serve many uncovered patients would continue to receive Federal reimbursement.
 
HOW IT WOULD WORK
 Most Americans would be enrolled in regional entities called health alliances, which would negotiate the price of coverage with health plans, offer a range of plans to members and collect premiums from employers and individuals.
 States would insure that alliances exist in areas where coverage would otherwise be insufficient.
 Companies with more than 5,000 employees would have the option of providing care to their workers by creating a corporate alliance and contracting directly with a health-care provider.
 People now enrolled in Medicare would continue in that program, but could later join the regional alliances. States would have the option of integrating Medicare recipients into their alliances so long as their coverage is as good or better.
 Medicaid recipients would be enrolled in regional alliances and receive the standared package of benefits, as well as supplementary services.
 All Americans would be issued a national health identification card that would guarantee them access to needed services.
 
WHO WOULD PAY
 The average premium for the standard package would be $1,800 a year for individuals and $4,200 for families. Businesses would be required to pay 80 percent of the average premium. Families and individuals would pay the difference between that amount and the full cost of the plan they select, meaning that those enrolled in cheaper plans would pay less, or more for plans more expensive than the average. Employers would have the option of paying more than 80 percent. The plan also suggests that a worker would be able to buy an average health policy for just $360 a year and a family policy for $840. The employer would pay four times that much.
 No business in a regional alliance would have to pay more than 7.9 percent of its payroll. Companies with fewer than 50 employees and those with many low-wage workers would be eligible for Government subsidies and for caps ranging from 3.5 percent to 7.9 percent of payroll, depending on their average wages.
 Families and individuals could pay their share of the premium directly or through withholding; alliances may require withholding to avoid bad debt.
 The self-employed and unemployed would be responsible for the entire amount of the premium, unless they were eligible for assistance based on income.
 Retired workers under 65 would be responsible for 20 percent of the premium.
 Employers would pay for part-time workers on a pro-rated basis.
Out-of-pocket costs would depend on the kind of service chosen. Alliances would be required to offer high-cost, low-cost and combination plans. The terms appear to refer respectively to traditional fee-for-service coverage, HMO's, and preferred provider networks.
 A high-cost plan would allow the use of any doctor but calls for deductibles of $200 an individual and $400 a family and 20 percent co-payment after that.
 In a low cost plan, the patient would see only doctors approved by the plan, but pay no deductible besides a $10-a-visit fee for outpatient services.
 In the combination plan, the patient would agree to pay 20 percent of the cost whenever using a doctor outside the plan.
 Out-of-pocket expenses are capped annually at $1,500 for each person and $3,000 for a family under all three plans.
 
CONTROLLING COSTS
 A National Health Board would be created to oversee the system and set a national health budget with the goal of limiting the rate of increase of health care spending to that of the general rate of inflation by 1999. Health care expenses are now growing at more than twice the inflation rate.
 If the competitive process does not reduce growth to that level, the board would impose mandatory limits on the growth of annual premiums, forcing health plans to spend less.
 Upon introducing the plan, the President would urge all sectors of the health care industry to limit price and spending increases to a specific amount not yet disclosed. Prices and spending would be monitored by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
 The National Health Board would make public declarations about the costs of new drugs and could investigate the costs of existing drugs it considers overpriced. It would have no authority to set drug prices.
 The rate of increase of Medicare and Medicaid would be reduced.
 
WORKERS COMPENSATION
 The separate insurance systems that now exist to cover the costs of injuries suffered at work or in automobile accidents would be continued. But the care would be provided through the health alliances created under the plan through contracts between them and the insurers.
 
TAKING EFFECT
 States could begin implementing the system by Jan. 1, 1995, and would be required to have it in place by Jan. 1, 1997.

An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. CRAZY IN ALABAMA, by Mark Childress. (Putnam, $22.95.) Southern American humor yet again, but in a novel that pounds every convention of the genre into submission; not even the dead bodies interfere with the funniness.
"DADDY'S GONE TO WAR": The Second World War in the Lives of America's Children, by William M. Tuttle Jr. (Oxford University, $30.) A historian finds that some "home front children" still feel indoctrinated in fright and hate, while others believe the war enhanced their understanding of this country and its culture.
EPSTEIN: Artist Against the Establishment, by Stephen Gardiner. (Viking, $35.) This polemical book defends at every point a major artist who all his life defied bourgeois conformity yet managed to die the proprietor of a knighthood.
HENRY JAMES' MIDNIGHT SONG, by Carol De Chellis Hill. (Poseidon/Simon & Schuster, $23.) A grand, ebullient novel, set chiefly in 1890's Vienna, where James, Freud, Jung and Edith Wharton are up to some naughty conduct.
THE KOMMANDANT'S MISTRESS, by Sherri Szeman. (HarperCollins, $17.50.) A powerful novel, forged from refractory materials: the personal narratives of a death camp commander and the Jewish woman he chose as his mistress.
LET THE SEA MAKE A NOISE . . . : A History of the North Pacific From Magellan to MacArthur, by Walter A. McDougall. (Basic Books, $30.) Lively narrative, bold analysis and prodigious research adorn this popular history of a vast sea surrounded by mutually mistrustful peoples.
NEW YORK DAYS, by Willie Morris. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Mr. Morris's memoir of his star-crossed romance with Harper's Magazine, where he became editor in chief in 1967, just in time for the weirdest part of the 60's, and held on till 1971.
SADE: A Biography, by Maurice Lever. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) A life of the French aristocrat and novelist (1740-1814) so wicked they renamed wickedness in his honor, so to speak.
SECOND SIGHT, by Robert V. Hine. (University of California, $20.) A splendid, highly literate personal account by the fortunate recipient of a miracle, a distinguished historian who slowly lost his eyesight and suddenly got it back.
SIGNS OF DEVOTION: Stories, by Maxine Chernoff. (Simon & Schuster, $19.) Smart, antic short stories in which people understand new experiences by recalling old ones, and the trivial is examined until its importance transpires.
SLEEPING BEAUTIES, by Susanna Moore. (Knopf, $22.) This eloquent, disturbing novel, concerned with personal and historical identity, squeezes its heroine between outdated notions of femininity and repulsive exemplars of womanhood.
THEIRS WAS THE KINGDOM: Lila and DeWitt Wallace and the Story of the Reader's Digest, by John Heidenry. (Norton, $29.95.) A hugely detailed, engagingly written history of a single bright idea and the preacher's kids who ran that idea into a multibillion-dollar global enterprise.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 36; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1290 words

HEADLINE: Science Fiction

BYLINE: By Gerald Jonas

 BODY:
Is William Gibson mellowing? The initiator of cyberpunk, who brought a new stylistic bite to science fiction with his 1984 novel "Neuromancer," has not quite turned into a futuristic Pollyanna. But compared to his earlier work, VIRTUAL LIGHT (Bantam, $21.95) offers more likable characters, a more subdued style, a less claustrophobic setting and a more upbeat ending.
Cyberspace -- Mr. Gibson's term for that amorphous computer-generated realm where information becomes geography -- plays a relatively minor role in his new novel. Instead of focusing on hackers obsessed with surfing the binary waves, he places at the center of his story two young people in a near-future San Francisco, a bike messenger named Chevette and a security guard named Rydell, who may actually have a flesh-and-blood future of their own, together. 
 Chevette, whose bike is moderately high-tech, gets her hands on a pair of super-high-tech sunglasses, which contain secrets that some powerful people are willing to kill for. Rydell, who discovers to his regret that he is working for the same people, eventually calls on a shadowy band of hackers for help. Mr. Gibson can write lean, mean action scenes, and his plot is so economically constructed that a reader who is not paying close attention may miss a crucial lead or two. Not to worry. Mr. Gibson's main interest, as always, is in creating a near-future world that can hold its own with the mind-bending reality of the present.
If the text of "Virtual Light" reveals the precise year in which the story is set, I missed it. But Mr. Gibson has other ways of delineating time and place. On hearing his new employer mention that his grandmother is Vietnamese, Rydell thinks to himself: "Saigon was where rich people went on vacation." You are invited to fill in the date for yourself. It may help to know that California has split into two states -- SoCal and NoCal -- and that since an earthquake known as "the Little Grande," the Bay Bridge linking San Francisco and Oakland has been closed to traffic and the still-intact center span has become a squatters' paradise, home to thousands of ex-hippies and formerly homeless people who have built themselves a new self-governing community: "At night, illuminated by Christmas bulbs, by recycled neon, by torchlight, it possessed a queer medieval energy."
Through a steady accretion of clearly imagined detail, Chevette's and Rydell's world comes to seem no queerer than our own. When Rydell gets into his employer's expensive car, his keen eye takes a quick inventory: "Four-wheel drive. Ceramic armor. Goodyear Streetsweepers you'd need a serious gun to puncture. There was a cardboard air freshener, shaped like a pine tree, hanging in front of the heater vent." I was especially taken with the Fallonites, a religious sect who believe that watching old movies on television is a form of meditation and that if they watch long enough "the spirit will sort of enter into them."
The final word on this latest installment of Mr. Gibson's speculative future belongs to a sociologist named Yamazaki, who maintains his scientific detachment even when he gets caught up in the action. Yamazaki's study of the unique society taking shape on the bridge prompts this reflection:
"We are come not only past the century's closing, he thought, the millennium's turning, but to the end of something else. Era? Paradigm? Everywhere, the signs of closure.
"Modernity was ending."
Undaunted, Yamazaki continues his research, "feeling for the new thing's strange heart."
William Gibson is a dewy-eyed optimist compared to Elizabeth Hand, whose ICARUS DESCENDING (Spectra/Bantam, paper, $5.99) is set in the mid-25th century but whose point of view is chillingly fin-de-siecle. As one character says to a talking ape who represents innocence incarnate: "There's always a war, Scarlet!" When mutated viruses are not literally raining down from the skies and radiation is not seeping into bones and genes, mad scientists are creating mutant clones and half-mechanical warriors in a Human Engineering Laboratory that more than earns its acronym of HEL.
"Icarus Descending" is set in the same shattered America that formed the background of Ms. Hand's earlier books "Winterlong" and "Aestival Tide." Although the publisher says that the new novel can be read independently, and Ms. Hand interpolates copious synopses throughout her narrative, I cannot imagine a reader who is unfamiliar with the earlier novels making much sense out of the complicated plot and intricate cross-references. And without a grounding in that shared history, it might be difficult to work up any anxiety over the threat posed by an onrushing meteor called Icarus to a world "that has already been twisted and burned and poisoned beyond all hope."
Ms. Hand occasionally strains for a poetry of decadence, interrupting the litany of scientific horrors with such archaisms as "fulvous" and "rubeous" in the manner of Gene Wolfe's "New Sun" series. But these touches serve only to remind the reader of all that has been lost in a future so dark that the impending annihilation of "civilization" seems more like a deliverance than a punishment.
Poul Anderson has been writing science fiction for over 40 years. In 1989 he published one of his most successful novels, "The Boat of a Million Years," an adroit study of the mixed blessings of immortality. HARVEST OF STARS (Tor/Tom Doherty, $22.95) reads like something salvaged from a drawer of old rejects. Anson Guthrie is the irascible but lovable founder of Fireball Enterprises, a company that dominates space travel in the solar system. Unlike all other monopolies in history, Fireball is neither inefficient nor corrupt, possibly because Guthrie, who has achieved a kind of immortality as a computer "download" after his body gives out, commands not just loyalty from his staff but a literally feudal devotion in which Fireball employees "plight troth" to their chief as he battles government baddies to win personal freedom and humanity's passage to the stars.
If this is Mr. Anderson's attempt to re-create the simple pleasures of the pulp magazines of the 1950's, he has only succeeded in proving that you can't go home again. "Harvest of Stars" is overwritten, underimagined and fatally flawed with self-satisfied musings on life-according-to-Guthrie that read suspiciously like the author's own self-justifications: "Back then, I too did my share of reading. It wasn't the fashionable stuff, no. Shakespeare, Homer, Cervantes, they might be acceptable, if outmoded, but Kipling, Conrad, MacDonald, Heinlein, that ilk, they were insensitive reactionaries. Or racists or sexists or whatever the current swear word was. You see, they dealt with things that mattered."
CORE, by Paul Preuss (Morrow, $23), is a savvy, hard-science techno-thriller about the hardest science of all. Cyrus Hudder, a maverick geologist, discovers a new substance, dubbed hudderite, that is so hard it can be used to drill into the molten core of the earth. When Cyrus disappears, his disaffected son, Leiden, is left to carry on the family tradition of brilliant if erratic applied science.
Mr. Preuss has obviously done his homework, as evidenced by dialogue in which Leiden Hudder's patent attorney notes: "But the fraction of elements in the plasma beam has not been the same as the stoichiometric fraction. . . . I mean, aren't the non conducting elements generally underrepresented?" Fearful perhaps that readers will not stick around for the answers to such questions, the author stuffs his plot with enough political intrigue and earth-shaking perils to plump out a big-screen movie script, which this novel seems all too eager to become.

LENGTH: 1127 words

HEADLINE: ENDPAPER/Life and Times;
Seductive Smallness

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger; Paul Goldberger, the culture editor of The Times, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1984 for criticism.

 BODY:
If you write about art you can collect it, at least to the limits of your wallet. If you are a music critic you are assumed to have an ample supply of CD's. A book critic accumulates a serious library. But an architecture critic? There is architectural drawing, but it has always seemed so much art manque. That's why I began to collect tiny toy buildings -- what other way short of investing in real estate is there to build a collection of architecture?
That's the story I would tell an interviewer if I were the sort of person who gets interviewed. The truth is that the whole thing never had so considered a purpose. It was born of necessity. A while ago I lived in a small apartment that had an odd little niche in the wall, and lying around on my desk was one of those cheap, eight-inch-high miniatures of the Empire State Building that you can buy in any souvenir shop. Better a toy Empire State Building than a vase of dried flowers, I said to myself, and into the niche it went. That was to be the end of that, until a neighbor saw it and said he had a souvenir World Trade Center that he would like to give me, and then somebody else said you can't have an Empire State Building without a Statue of Liberty, and not too long after that I got married and a friend from California gave us his miniature lead Woolworth Building and then my wife was browsing in an antiques shop and found an RCA Building in the form of an ashtray and it was all over. The RCA Building cost a lot of money -- $85 -- and it meant that there was no turning back. 
 Now I have something like 150 buildings, most of them three or four inches high, generally of metal, though some are ceramic, and a few recent ones, alas, are made of plastic. It's true that they don't make buildings the way they used to. You can compare my Empire State Buildings -- I have six, which includes the Empire State Building pencil sharpener but not the three Empire State erasers -- and the older ones invariably have finer detail, more solid construction, a surer sense that they were made to last. That I could write that last sentence with a straight face is a sign that I have become unnaturally attached to my toy buildings. My collection now fills not only the niche and some shelves we added but also an entire counter top, where the skyscrapers and the churches and the banks and the monuments line up row upon row like a miniature city, although I am not sure just what sort of vision of urban glory is represented by putting Chartres Cathedral across from the Nutley Savings Bank.
There is not much architectural scholarship to these miniature buildings; in fact, there isn't any. The five-inch lead Flatiron Building for which I paid dearly last Christmas may be a semivaluable antique, but it is an almost crude representation of the building, more an abstraction than a reproduction. There are better ways to learn about the Tower of Pisa than through my nine-inch ceramic version of it, better ways to study the United States Capitol than through any one of my Capitols, though I have to admit that the metal one whose dome opens up to reveal a jewel box is pretty nifty.
But collecting souvenir buildings has nothing to do with being serious about architecture. It has a lot to do with affection for buildings, and with the curious joy that comes from seeing anything you like in miniature. In its surprising tininess it becomes containable, manageable, in a way that the real thing is not. If children find order in the world they are coming to know through their play, adults can order the world they already know through collecting, which is really a form of play, too.
And yet I remember once saying to an architectural model maker that his craft was dangerous because he had the power to make any building likable. A model of the worst skyscraper on Third Avenue is benign, even appealing. As an architecture critic I have seen hundreds of buildings I couldn't stand, but I don't know when I've ever seen a model I didn't like. The worst building in the world is cute when turned into a model. Indeed, it is more than cute: it is seductive.
Is it the desire to be seduced again by buildings, to see them as objects of fantasy rather than as the difficult and challenging things that they are, that motivates me to collect all these little souvenirs? Perhaps. On my counter top there are no real issues of urban context to think about, no concerns about the social imperatives of architecture, no need to take into account the realities of economics or zoning. The buildings become shapes to be manipulated for amusement, and how good they look is the only thing that matters. Since when could a responsible architecture critic justify making that kind of judgment on a real building?
SO I PLAY ON, MOVING my Towers of Pisa and Woolworth and Sears and John Hancock back and forth, and wondering why my forays to flea markets and back-roads antique shops (which is where you find the good miniatures, the ones too old to be in the souvenir shop at the airport) haven't yet turned up a Chrysler Building, which is the rare object I covet most of all. Indeed, I only learned that there were Chrysler Buildings a couple of years ago, when I ran into David Weingarten and Margaret Majua, a couple in Northern California whose collection of souvenir buildings makes me seem a rank amateur. They crossed the 1,400 mark not long ago, and they keep acquiring. David and Margaret, of course, have two Chrysler Buildings. I know this because they told me, and also because they have created a computerized inventory, copies of which they have circulated to the small circle of souvenir building collectors that has grown up around them. Last year they played host to this group for a weekend of conversation and trading, and this year Dixie Trainer, who gives every indication of being a normal housewife but for the fact that she has 700 miniature buildings, decided to reciprocate. I went to Dixie's, partly to see who else would show up and partly to see her collection, which also has two Chrysler Buildings, neither of which she would part with.
It was a strange combination of social event and bazaar. First, a lovely summer lunch with about a dozen of us who, like occupants of a nudist colony freed at last from the normal social conventions, could blather on about early Bunker Hill Monuments and toy classical banks with no fear of embarrassment. I had brought nothing to show and nothing to trade, my collection being too small to have duplicates and too uneven to justify winnowing out the less distinguished examples. I came away with two shopping bags full of miniatures, not a one of which, of course, looked anything like a Chrysler Building.

HEADLINE: The World Capital of Whatever

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER; HAROLD FABER contributes to The Times from the Hudson Valley. His latest book is "From Sea to Sea: The Growth of the United States" (Scribner's).

 BODY:
AS I was driving along Route 5 in central New York State, my eye was caught by a sign outside Geneva: "Lake Trout Capital of the World."
"Write it down," I called to my wife. And another city was added to the growing list of world capitals I have visited or heard about. 
 Anybody can go to capitals like Washington, London, Paris, Rome, Madrid or Beijing. But how many have been to the world capital of apples, artichokes, barbed wire, charcoal, chili, dandelions, ferrets, garlic, horseradish, pretzels, seafood, spinach or toothpicks?
I have, either in person or vicariously, by clipping newspapers and magazines. My latest tabulation includes 465 world capitals, ranging from accordion (Castelfidano, Italy) to youth unemployment (New York City).
What makes world capitals? It's rather who makes them. They are named by chambers of commerce and writers who use the phrase "world capital" as a shorthand device for describing a place's major product or attraction.
I have done it myself, creating some world capitals in writing for this newspaper. Among them are Chazy, N.Y., the world capital of McIntosh apples; Hurley, N.Y., the sweet corn capital of the world, and Rhinebeck, N.Y., the anemone capital of the world.
It would be impossible to visit all the world capitals, so I also rely on tipsters and publications for reporting new ones. My older daughter, for example, while driving along Interstate 10 near Gulfport, Miss., glimpsed a billboard reading "The Root Beer Capital of the World." Even though I have been to Gulfport, I still have not found out why it has that title. Do they make root beer there or just drink it?
Just recently, my younger daughter sent me a clipping from The Hartford Courant calling Connecticut the witch hazel capital of the world. There was an explanation in this case: it said that every drop of witch hazel produced in the United States comes from two companies in that state.
That seems justified. But there are other claimants to the identical titles of world capital that are disputable even after my research.
How can anyone judge which of the following is entitled to the singular honor of being the catfish capital of the world: Des Allemands, La, or Belzoni, Miss.?
Or the golf capital of the world: Myrtle Beach, S.C., or Palm Springs, Calif., or Pinehurst, N.C.? How about the horseradish capital of the world: Tule Lake, Calif., or Collinsville, Ill.?
Or the watermelon capital of the world: Weatherford, Tex.; Rush Springs, Okla., and Hope, Ark. The last is well known these days, of course, because it is the birthplace of President Clinton, but no articles so far have described him as a watermelon fancier.
I feel more comfortable, though, about choosing the seafood capital of the world because my wife and I have eaten in both -- Crisfield, Md., and Calabash, N.C.
On balance, I would give the nod to Calabash, a town of about 150, where we had a choice of 21 seafood restaurants. Second prize to Crisfield, which is also called the oyster capital of the world. Despite that, the best oysters I can remember eating were at Murrells Inlet, S.C., and Apalachicola, Fla.
In the quest for superior seafood, we obviously have been to Rockland, Me., the lobster capital of the world. And we have even traveled to Bayou La Batre, which modestly boasts of being only the seafood capital of Alabama.
In the various subdivisions of seafood, how could I forget visits to Baltimore, the crab cake capital of the world? Or the salmon capital of the world, Ketchikan, Alaska, which is also the canned salmon capital of the world. I haven't found any canned tuna fish capital of the world yet, although that is one of my favorite foods, but Galilee, R.I., claims to be the tuna capital of the world, based on fishing, not canning.
Other fish capitals, in addition to Geneva, N.Y., include Birchwood, Wis., the bluegill capital of the world; Waterville, Minn., the bullhead capital of the world; Breaux Bridge, La., the crayfish capital of the world; Fort Thompson, S.D., the paddlefish capital of the world, and Okeechobee, Fla., the speckled perch capital of the world.
For meat lovers, mecca is Lincoln, Neb., the steak capital of the world. But you'll have to go to Owensboro, Ky., to reach the barbecued mutton capital of the world or Memphis, Tenn., for the barbecued pork capital of the world or either Sheboygan, Wis., or Bucyrus, Ohio, each of which claims to be the bratwurst capital of the world.
Sheboygan gets my vote because it also boasts that it is "the wurst city in the world."
That distinction might be disputed by some city in Germany, but I have not found any citations on that. I did, however, find one surprising capital in Germany -- Hamburg is the world capital of chicken salad. It was thus crowned by Mimi Sheraton in The New York Times on Aug. 27, 1983.
Speaking of capitals abroad, I can show documentation that London is the bathtub capital of the world; Qiaotao, China, the button capital of the world; Grand Manan Island, New Brunswick, the dulse capital of the world (and I had to go to the dictionary to find out that dulse is an edible red alga that grows on rocky oceanic shores); Dijon, France, the gastronomical capital of the world, and Pont-d'Ouilly, France, the kayak polo capital of the world.
But my records show that the United States is truly the capital of world capitals. Where else could you find capitals like these:
Apples, Wenatchee, Wash., and Winchester, Va.; barbed wire, De Kalb, Ill.; charcoal, Salem, Mo.; chili (cooked), Terlingua, Tex.; chili (peppers), Hatch, N.M.; crutches, Rumney, N.H.; dandelions, Vineland, N.J.; ferrets, Meeteetse, Wyo.; frogs, Rayne, La.; pretzels, Reading, Pa.; pork rind, Westminister, Ohio; purple martins, Griggsville, Ill.; roses, Tyler, Tex.; Spanish peanuts, Dawson, Ga. and spinach, Crystal City, Texas.
As a serious compiler of capitals, I soon found out that California is the (uncrowned) food capital of the world. Look at the list:
Almonds, Chico and Sacramento; asparagus, Isleton (disputed by Hadley, Mass.); artichokes, Castroville; avocados, Fallbrook; blackberries, McCloud; broccoli, Greenfield; dates, Indio; garlic, Gilroy; lettuce, Salinas; lima beans, Oxnard; raisins, Selma and Fresno, and strawberries, Watsonville (disputed by Plant City, Fla.).
Many cities and states have dual claims to being world capitals, but New York City outdoes them all. Not only is it truly the world capital as the home of the United Nations but it is also the world capital of capital because of Wall Street. More than that, though, it also bears the title of world capital in the following categories:
Advertising, art, the arts, art theft, bagels and lox, communications, corruption, credit card crime, dance, entertainment (disputed by Las Vegas, Nev.), food stamp fraud, glamour, herring (many European cities would certainly question that), jazz (New Orleans would differ), media, noise, pop music, private schools, publishing, skyscrapers (but Chicago has the tallest building in the world), theater (I, however, would opt for London) and youth unemployment.
To end this smorgasbord of cities with dessert, why not a trip to these capitals: cherries, Traverse City, Mich.; chocolate, Hershey, Pa.; fruit cake, either Corsicana, Tex., or Clayton, Ga.; coffee, Seattle, Wash., and Champagne, Rheims, France. For those so inclined, add the toothpick capital of the world, Strong, Me.
And I have citations to prove all of the above.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 55; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1285 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Craftsmanship, American To the Core

BYLINE: By VERLYN KLINKENBORG; Verlyn Klinkenborg is the author of "The Last Fine Time," a nonfiction work about Buffalo in the 1940's.

 BODY:
It's not uncommon to grow up in America believing that home is the graveyard of esthetics, a place where the numbing, comforting everydayness of family life covers even beautiful objects with a pall of invisibility. It can be hard to see the furnishings of domestic life for what they are simply because they are so thoroughly put to use, more palpable to the hand than to the eye. That may be why at museums you often find the largest crowds in the gift shops and cafeterias, places where deeply familiar transactions like shopping and eating occur, rather than in the galleries, where the vital strangeness of art is evidenced once more.
And yet the vital strangeness of high art, as well as an oddly moral, almost political appeal, marks the extraordinary objects -- furniture, pottery, silver, textiles -- created for domestic use by the artisans of the American Arts and Crafts movement in the first two decades of this century. Some 200 of the finest of those objects, drawn from public and private collections across the country, will be gathered at the American Craft Museum for an exhibition, opening on Oct. 21, called "The Ideal Home: 1900-1920," the first of a series of annual shows in the museum's proposed decade-long retrospective of crafts in the 20th century. 
 The polarities of the Arts and Crafts movement -- and of the objects gathered in "The Ideal Home" -- are as extreme as the polarities in American society itself. The movement encompassed the stained glass of Louis Comfort Tiffany, largely intended for his wealthy patrons, as well as the crafts made in urban settlement houses, like Chicago's Hull-House, and in craft communities like the Byrdcliffe Colony in Woodstock, N. Y.
At the heart of the movement was a vision of creative, individual handwork, supported by fraternal or sororal fellowship. Yet its designs were also disseminated to a mass audience in the form of sewing kits, for instance, and in product lines by Gustav Stickley, among others, that ran all the way from blueprints for Craftsman houses to trademark Stickley linens, several of which appear in "The Ideal Home." The movement revived traditional arts, often enlisting the aid of recent immigrants and American Indians, and it had an essential conception of the healing quality, the wholeness of craft-work, its capacity to reintegrate one's identity, that survives to this day in home woodshops and therapeutic craft courses across the land. As Charles Lummis, an early devotee of Southwestern culture, said, "Any fool can write a book, but it takes a man to dovetail a door."
We're used to the idea of art as manifesto, but the idea of craft as manifesto comes as something of a surprise. The meaning of craft appears to be contained in the functionality of the objects it creates and in what Janet Kardon, director of the American Craft Museum and curator of "The Ideal Home," calls the craftsperson's "homage to the hand, to material, to process." There seems to be no room left for didacticism in the spare design, the transparency of purpose, of such objects in "The Ideal Home" as the furniture of Gustav Stickley, the pottery of Adelaide Alsop Robineau or Maria Longworth Nichols, or the embroidery of the Deerfield Society of Blue and White Needlework. Yet the philosophical lineage to which such work belongs can be traced to Emerson and Whitman in the United States and to Carlyle, Ruskin and William Morris in England. It's a lineage steeped in the sanctity of labor and deeply opposed to the social and psychological fissures caused by the Industrial Revolution.
A good machine, wrote William L. Price, the founder of a crafts colony at Rose Valley, Pa., "remains a tool that a thinking man may work, shaping the product by his volition. A bad machine is . . . automatic in its operations, requiring only a human feeder, who must with deadly regularity supply it with the material from which it, not he, makes the product." Price's description of the bad machine, written in 1904, sounds like an image of Odysseus in the cave of Polyphemus, watching his men being eaten one by one.
From an economic standpoint, whatever the principles of the movement, Price, like other craftspersons, was forced to compete with bad machines everywhere. Arts and Crafts designs were rapidly appropriated by commercial firms, and the history of the movement is littered with financial failures -- men and women who discovered that true handcrafts in a (bad) machine age were simply too expensive for the market -- the American home market -- they had in mind.
Alongside the simplicity of furniture by Stickley or Frank Lloyd Wright or the plainness of ceramics by Mary Chase Perry, the founder of the Pewabic Pottery in Detroit, also in this exhibition, there was a vein of medievalism, a Gothic strain, running through the American Arts and Crafts movement. What lies behind that medievalism is the assumption that there was a wholeness to life in the Middle Ages, that it was a time when a man's labor had not been appropriated from him, though this seems romantic at best and naive at worst. Such a belief belies the obvious fact that the very craftsmen admired by William Morris and his followers were individuals of highly refined skills, whose labor had already been separated from the mass of ordinary workers.
Part of what inspired this devotion to medieval objects is the apparent interpenetration of moral message and art in medieval crafts, the doctrinal force that permeates such art. But this is a narrow view of the Middle Ages, very much a product of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In a way, the work produced by the Arts and Crafts movement is less playful, less tolerant of the wide range of human experience -- more didactic, in fact -- than medieval art itself.
One of the most important precepts governing the movement was "total design," as James D. Kornwolf, professor of fine arts at the College of William and Mary, calls it in the catalogue for "The Ideal Home," which will be published by Harry N. Abrams. Everything, he writes, "from dinner fork to regional state plan, was made to conform to the same design principles." We live in an age of rapacious eclecticism. To a modern eye, the "total" designs of Wright or Stickley, the esthetic coherence, the unifying inspiration -- borrowed, as it were, from nature's own unceasing ability to weave variations on a master theme -- can seem either refreshing or stultifying, almost repressive.
TODAY, WHETHER FOR GOOD OR bad, we're more concerned with style than with design in the way that Wright might have used the word. The works of the Arts and Crafts movement are not about style but about some deeper bond between ethics and esthetics, a connection that derives directly from Morris. Style is the loosening of that bond, a liberation or a loss of seriousness, depending on your point of view.
World War I brought an end to the American Arts and Crafts movement. One of the ironies of that movement is that it served, quite unwittingly, as a precursor for total design in the machine age that followed the war, when the idea of handcrafts came to seem precious at best and when the repressive power of totalitarian design first made itself felt. It's the eclecticism of our own post-industrial period that has brought Stickley's furniture, for example, back into vogue during the last decade, decontextualized. The communal craft societies have largely gone, the settlement houses have disappeared, but there is a familiar feel to the objects they left behind because they are now part of the American vernacular, the polyglot language our homes speak from time to time, when we choose to hear them.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Among the household objects that will be displayed in the exhibition "The Ideal Home: 1900-1920" at the American Craft Museum are, top left, a lamp of copper and abalone shells by Elizabeth Eaton Burton; above left, a vase designed by Anna Marie Valentien and made at the Rookwood Pottery; at right from top, a linen table runner by Gustav Stickley; a cypress table by John Scott Bradstreet; a vase designed by William Bryce Mundie, and an oak clock by George Washington Maher. HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Terence Neilan

 BODY:

The Trains Down Under
Q. I will be visiting Australia in October and I would like to know if there are any cross-country trains there and if tickets for them can be bought in the United States. -- Nino Giaco, Howard Beach, Queens. 
 A. Australia is home to some of the most interesting train trips in the world, taking travelers through a continent of vast contrasts along thousands of miles of track.
Many long-distance trains offer first-class, deluxe and economy-class compartments, sleeping berths and reclining seats. Some have entertainment cars, in which a piano, video games and even slot machines are provided. And the Queenslander, which goes from Brisbane to Cairns, even has a disco car called Club Loco offering dance music.
For Americans traveling to Australia there are a variety of multi-trip passes available, which must be bought in the United States. Tickets for single trips can be bought before leaving, too.
The Austrailpass gives unlimited first-class and economy travel anywhere on the Australian rail network, including electric metropolitan trains. Prices range from $339 in economy for 14 days ($565 in first class) to $877 in economy for 90 days ($1,377 in first class).
The Austrail Flexi-Pass is good for 8 days' rail travel within a period of 60 days for $250 in economy and $413 in first class or 15 days within 90 days for $370 in economy and $585 in first.
The Kangaroo Road n'Rail Pass is good for unlimited first-class and economy travel anywhere on the Australian rail network plus selected bus travel with Australian Coachlines (one class only). Passes run from $511 in economy for 14 days ($811 in first class) to $897 in economy for 28 days ($1,193 in first class).
All tickets can be ordered through Rail Australia, ATS Tours, 100 North First Street, Suite 301, Burbank, Calif. 91502; telephone (800) 423-2880 or (818) 841-1030. The agency can also arrange hotel packages.
These are some of the train trips you might want to consider:
The Indian Pacific from Sydney to Adelaide to Perth, a 65-hour journey that runs every Monday and Thursday (Tuesday and Friday in Adelaide) through most of the year.
The Ghan, from Adelaide to Alice Springs, is a 22-hour trip that runs every Thursday all year and every Monday from April to January. Named after Afghan traders whose camel trains were at one time the only link between Australia's interior and Adelaide, the 908-mile journey takes you straight to the heart of the outback.
The Queenslander goes every Sunday from Brisbane to Cairns in 32 hours, a 1,044-mile journey that stops after 19 hours at Proserpine, gateway to the Great Barrier Reef.
 
Florida Keys Houseboats
 Q. We are interested in renting a houseboat in the Florida Keys this winter. Can you give me any names and addresses of rental agencies and some idea of the cost? -- R. John Currie, Somers, N.Y.
A. Three companies in the Key Largo area would probably provide what you are looking for.
Coral Bay Houseboat Rentals, Post Office Box 1414, Islamorada, Fla. 33036, (305) 664-3111, is at mile marker 81.5 at the Coral Bay Marina on the bay side of Islamorada. Boats are restricted to a cruising radius of around 25 miles (Key Largo to the north and Long Key to the south). The 34-by-12-foot houseboats, which sleep six, have a dining booth with a couch and table that each convert into a double bed, a stateroom with a closet, a bathroom with a shower, and a hand-pumped toilet. A week's rental is $850; three weekdays are $450 and a three-day weekend (either Friday to Sunday or Saturday to Monday) is $500. Rates apply all year.
Smilin' Island Houseboat Rentals, Post Office 3003, Key Largo, Fla. 33037, (305) 451-1930, is at mile marker 99.5 on the bay side at Key Largo. The boats come in two sizes, 42 feet and 52 feet. The 52 footer sleeps 10 and has central air-conditioning, television and a VCR, a microwave oven and an 11-foot Boston Whaler runabout. Rates from Sept. 15 to Dec. 15 are $850 for a three-night weekend, $950 for four nights at midweek and $1,450 for seven nights. From Dec. 15 to May 15 rates go up by $200. The rate for the 52 footer does not include fuel, which is about $100 a week. The 52 footer can be docked only at its home marina or anchored in Florida Bay. Cruising is restricted to an area roughly within the southern boundary of the Everglades National Park. The 42 footer sleeps six and overnight docking at nearby marinas is permitted. From Sept. 15 to Dec. 15, rates, which include fuel, are $600 for a three-night weekend, $700 for four midweek nights and $1,000 for seven nights. From Dec. 15 to May 15 rates go up by $200.
Houseboat Vacations of the Florida Keys, Post Office Box 1202, Islamorada, Fla. 33036, (305) 664-4009 is at mile marker 85.9 on the bay side. Houseboats are available at 40 feet, 42 feet, 45 feet and 46 feet and cruising is permitted within 40 miles of the marina. The boats are permitted to dock at any of the local marinas or to anchor in the bay. Rentals, which are for a minimum of two days, range from $350 to $550 depending on the size of the boat. Weekly rates are from $860 to $1,550.
 
Island Weather
 Q. I will be cruising at the end of December in the Azores and the Canary Islands. What sort of weather can I expect? -- A. Sheinin, Long Beach, L.I.
A. The Azores, about 800 miles west of Portugal, have a very mild climate throughout the year, with no great extremes of temperature.
In December the high averages 62 degrees, with precipitation at 4.4 inches (compared with 3.6 inches in New York City, for example). Average lows are 55 degrees.
The Canaries, some 60 miles off North Africa, are even more agreeable. Average highs are 72 degrees (dipping to 60) with only 1.6 inches of precipitation.

HEADLINE: City's Colleges Add $2 Billion In Facilities

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
NO ONE is going back to school at the College of Staten Island this month. Rather, its 12,000 students are traveling to a place they have never been before: a 204-acre campus with 19 buildings, new and old, on the grounds of the infamous Willowbrook State School for the mentally retarded.
Although this $374 million campus is easily the largest academic property under development in New York City, it is by no means the only one. Major colleges and universities have either launched, planned or recently completed more than three dozen projects -- about $2 billion worth of construction, renovation and acquisition. 
 These include what may become the tallest academic center in town: the 50-story former G.E. Building, at Lexington Avenue and 51st Street, which General Electric gave to Columbia University in July. Columbia has several other big projects in the works, as do New York University, St. John's University, Fordham University, Brooklyn Law School and Mount Sinai School of Medicine.
But the private efforts are dwarfed by the City University of New York, where a construction pipeline that opened in the 80's is now disgorging enormously ambitious projects, including the Willowbrook campus, by some of the city's leading architects. Once that pipeline empties in 1994, however, it is likely to stay rather dry for several years.
"We're at a peak in terms of opening things," said Donal E. Farley, who retired in January as senior vice chancellor of City University for facilities planning, construction and management. "We have stopped in terms of new initiatives, but we still have momentum with the projects that were financed two or three years ago."
Almost every City University project is financed by the New York State Dormitory Authority, which also underwrites private projects -- and not just dormitories, despite its name -- through the sale of tax-exempt bonds. It has paid some $850 million to contractors statewide this year, up from $450 million five years ago, said Sam R. Davidson, deputy executive director for construction.
"I'm doing more construction than ever," Mr. Davidson said. "We're building like crazy and spending a lot of money. But within a year, things are just going to be lopped off. And there's a lot of stuff that we won't be doing in the future."
At a time when commercial development is all but frozen, schools, hospitals, courthouses and other institutional or government work becomes even more critical.
"Public construction programs are basically keeping the construction industry going in New York City," said Rudolph J. Rinaldi, who left his post last week as the city's Buildings Commissioner to become executive director of the Dormitory Authority. "It's essential. Without it, the economy would have been hit in a tremendous way."
The senior vice president of Columbia, Joseph P. Mullinix, said: "We have not retreated the same way you see many private developers at this point. On the other hand, we've certainly adjusted our sights. We've slowed down a lot of renovation projects largely for the tightness of funding."
And public projects have their own logic, said Arthur Zabarkes, dean of the real estate institute at New York University's School of Continuing Education. "The pipeline is so slow for public projects that they're there whenever they're there -- independent of interest rates, construction needs and the business cycle in general."
The Chancellor of the City University, Dr. W. Ann Reynolds, described this logic: "When the country's economy slumps, our enrollments are still very strong. People choose that time, when they see what's coming at them, to train themselves for different careers. Or, if you lose that job, you take more hours to get through school." She said City University's enrollment had grown to 203,000 from 197,000 in three years.
"We create jobs in the building of these facilities," said Robert E. Buxbaum, acting vice chancellor for planning and construction, "and then these facilities produce students who go out and get jobs."
There are distinct advantages to building during a slump. Fordham's residence hall at the Lincoln Center campus cost $39 million -- about $13 million less than was budgeted. Some of the savings were used to rebuild an arid plaza as a more verdant, inviting academic quadrangle, said Dr. Brian J. Byrne, the vice president for administration.
"It is not a good time economically for any institution of higher education," Dr. Byrne said. "On the other hand, we have to make investments in the future and it happens to be a good time for capital investments."
Dr. Reynolds said, "I'm just taking a breath and rejoicing in the facilities that have come on line." These include new academic centers for Hostos Community College in the Bronx and Baruch College in Manhattan, a new athletic center at Lehman College in the Bronx and extensive renovations and a new sports field at City College.
For sheer size, none of these rivals the College of Staten Island. Said to be the largest campus in New York City, public or private, its grounds are ordered along a formal north-south axis that bisects two broad quadrangles, skirts a mature stand of oak and pine trees and leads to the high ground from which a copper-domed library rises. Echoing the library at the lower end of the axis is a domed student center, whose airy rotunda serves as the student cafeteria.
The college had been split between St. George and Sunnyside. "We've been working out of two separate campuses five miles apart," said the president, Edmond L. Volpe. "It has been exceptionally difficult and expensive." He credited State Senator John J. Marchi with the idea of reusing Willowbrook, after that institution closed in 1987. "Turning this national symbol of degradation and pain into a symbol of hope is something we're very proud of," Mr. Volpe said.
As many as 2,400 more students may be attracted to the new campus, Mr. Volpe said, with most probably coming from Brooklyn. But the college's newfound grandeur may also have drawbacks for those accustomed to more cramped quarters. Raymond F. Pavia, the dean of administration, demurred when asked the length of Alumni Walk, the broad axial allee that ties the grounds together. "We don't like to emphasize it," he explained, "because students complain about having to walk so far between classes."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Analyzing Trends;
The Only Thing That's Clear Is the Lack of Clarity

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
"COMMERCIAL real estate activity continues to improve." -- Julien J. Studley.
"Office market shows signs of revitalization as leasing activity picks up." -- Newmark Real Estate. 
 But then there's this:
"Despite sharp increase in lease activity, negative absorption rate continues." -- Williams Real Estate.
"New York commercial real estate market remains volatile." -- CB Commercial.
Whom to believe?
Getting a fix on New York's commercial real estate market is rough these days. And the reports spewing forth from the large brokerages don't make a would-be analyst's life any easier.
Indeed, depending on whom you ask, rents are up, rents are down, rents are stagnant. Concession packages are niggardly, concession packages are generous. The rent gap between downtown and midtown is widening, is narrowing. Tenants are expanding, are contracting, are doing lateral arabesques into same-sized but better space. Brokers are doing well, brokers are fighting to survive.
It's all reminiscent of the old joke about the accountant who, when asked what certain numbers meant, replied, "Well, what do you want them to mean?"
"No one's ever seen a market like this, so no one knows what to make of it," said Stephen B. Siegel, chief executive of Edward S. Gordon Company. "The lack of job growth, the shrinking of Corporate America, the drying up of construction funds -- there are just no historic parallels to draw on."
Some things do seem clear. Leasing activity is frenzied throughout Manhattan, and rents have stopped their downward plunge. Large blocks of contiguous space in prime buildings are scarce. Overall vacancy rates are down a few tenths of a percent, hovering around 16 percent. Since there's been virtually no new construction, that should mean more absorption of space.
But even that seemingly obvious extrapolation does not go uncontested. Take Morgan Stanley's recent purchase of 1585 Broadway, near 48th Street. On the surface, it removed 935,000 square feet -- what's left in the 1.3- million-square-foot building after subtracting the 365,000 square feet occupied by its only tenant, the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn -- from the market, and put a stamp of approval on the Times Square area.
"This transaction gave people confidence that the financial community is staying in New York, it took a huge building off the market and it extended midtown's western end to Broadway," said Charles R. Borrok, a vice chairman of Cushman & Wakefield.
BUT there's a dark side, too. Morgan Stanley is tossing the million-or-so square feet it now rents back into the swollen space pool. And 1585 had been so tied up in squabbles among its owners that few brokers or tenants ever considered it viable space.
"The Morgan Stanley deal is adding space to the market, not taking it out," said Michael T. Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate. Added Lizann Galbreath, vice chairman of Galbreath Riverbank:
"It's just another sign of space-shuffling activity."
The glass-half-empty, glass-half-full debate doesn't stop at 1585 Broadway. If anything, the real estate market has grown so polarized that generalities are specious.
"If you have a post-1968 building on Avenue of the Americas, your market is getting better," said Mr. Cohen. "If you've got a post-war cookie-cutter building on Third Avenue, nothing's improved."
The same dichotomy exists for tenants, he continued. "If you want huge chunks of space in a Class A building, your choices are dwindling," he said. "But most tenants still have a bewildering array of alternatives."
The leasing volume certainly gives the appearance of a healthy market. But there's a lot of smoke and mirrors at play. Many tenants are signing leases now because their leases are expiring and because they can still get huge concessions and low rents.
"Today's deals are wonderful for tenants, and brokers are making money, but owners are still struggling," said Mike Solomon, a vice chairman of Julien J. Studley.
Still, with real estate, perception is often more important than reality. And many landlords are viewing the heightened interest from tenants as a sign that the buyer's market is finally turning.
Many are becoming less willing to give away the store.
"In the better buildings, tenants are asking for $60 or $65 in contributions to work, but they're settling for $40 to $45," said Steven J. Riker of Abrams, Benisch, Riker.
Landlords may soon be better able to stand their ground with retail tenants, too.
"Broadway is hotter than a pistol and you have to shoehorn your way into SoHo," reports Faith H. Consolo, a managing director of Garrick-Aug. Benjamin Fox, an executive vice president of New Spectrum Real Estate, makes a similar point about 34th Street. "The vacancy rate between Fifth Avenue and Eighth Avenue is less than 4 percent," he said. "A few years ago it was triple that."
But the two part ways on cause and effect. Ms. Consolo says that increased demand has led to a "tremendous firming" of retail rents in the last two months; Mr. Fox says that chains like the Gap and Duane Reade, which already have dozens of stores in Manhattan, are the ones doing the leasing these days, and they have the clout to drive hard bargains.
"RENTS have come down 30 percent on average all over town, and that's what's spurring leasing activity," he said.
Not much is spurring leasing in the B-building market, though. In the height of the recession, many B-building tenants took the so-called "flight to quality," replicating their space in a higher quality building for the same rents. That flight continues.
"One of the biggest problems in the B-market is that tenants can afford to move back to midtown," said Fred I. Adlman, executive director of Winoker Realty.
Few B-building landlords can take a hard stance on concessions. The first new tenants in several years at 360 Lexington Avenue, a bankrupt Class B building on 40th Street, got $40 a square foot, much more than previously offered, to customize the space. Similarly, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, a B building near 40th Street, leased six of seven vacant floors only after the landlord put in a concierge desk and other amenities.
"We have to work 10 times as hard to make a deal today," said Mr. Adlman, whose firm manages both buildings.
But the gloom is not unanimous even among B-building owners. Jeffrey Gural, who co-owns or manages some 40 B-buildings in various parts of Manhattan, notes that his buildings are nearly fully rented and that rents are inching up. Even more important, his tenants are finally all paying their rents.
"The tenants who were going to go broke already have, and everything seems pretty stable right now," he said.
AMIDST all the disagreement, there are some undisputed positive signs. The decisions by Mastercard and the Associated Press to stay in Manhattan gave apsychological boost to the New York market. Morgan Stanley's purchase of 1585, whatever its impact on available space, did so as well.
"If you can renew your space in a Class A building for $32, and you don't have to pay for moving, it really doesn't cost a lot more to stay than to go to Connecticut," said Arthur H. Lerner, a Newmark vice chairman.
The upsurge in building sales also bodes well for New York City's economic recovery.
"The three most significant transactions in the last year were Morgan Stanley and 1585, Bertelsmann and 1540 Broadway, and Mutual of America and 320 Park Avenue, and all of those represented companies locking in their futures by buying their headquarters," said Peter Riguardi, executive vice president of Koeppel, Tener, Riguardi.
Sales of smaller buildings, like the sale of 4 East 54th Street to Banco Di Napoli, are even more numerous. "This sales trend normally precedes an upturn in leasing," said James S. Meiskin, senior managing director of Wm. A. White/Grubb & Ellis.
Still, few real estate experts expect a real market turnaround without job growth. And no one really sees that happening yet.
"This market is like a patient that's been running a real high fever," said Mr. Riker of Abrams Benisch Riker. "Once the fever breaks, you know the patient will recover. But for now, he still feels lousy."

Borrok of Cushman & Wakefield: "This transaction gave people confidence that the financial community is staying in New York." (Photographs by Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/The 1931 Whitney Museum;
'Rebels on Eighth Street' Redux

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
OVER the last generation the 1931 Whitney Museum of American Art, at 8 West Eighth Street, has slowly sunk from raffish bohemianism to a neglected decay.
But now the New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture, which owns the building, is making the first repairs in a multiyear restoration project that will sand down, but not off, the rough edges of one of New York's art monuments. 
 The museum was founded by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney. Though her grandfather was Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt and her husband was the playboy-financier Harry Payne Whitney, she did more than just bounce around the New York-Newport society circuit.
According to Avis Berman, author of "Rebels on Eighth Street" (Atheneum, 1990), within a few years of her marriage in 1896 Gertrude Whitney discovered that her husband was unfaithful, and she decided to become a sculptor. She took up with a group of artists who formed the Ashcan School -- Robert Henri, John Sloan, William Glackens and others. They were fighting to establish artistic realism in a conservative atmosphere of society portraits and soothing landscapes.
In 1907 she took a studio on Macdougal Alley, a street of stables serving the flanking rows of houses on Washington Square North and Eighth Street. She proved to have only moderate talent as a sculptor but excelled as an organizer.
In 1914 she took over the adjacent rowhouse at West Eighth Street for a meeting place and gallery for other artists on the outs with the establishment.
Gradually, she added the houses at 10, 12 and 14 West Eighth Street -- as well as their corresponding stables on Macdougal Alley -- and what had become the Whitney Studio Club became a center of advanced thinking in American art.
John Sloan and Reginald Marsh had their first one-man shows there and in 1924 the club mounted the first exhibit of American folk art, a complete reversal of the old-master theory of collecting that had dominated the 19th century.
Mrs. Whitney also directly supported artists with gifts, loans and purchases, and by the late 1920's she had amassed a collection of about 500 works by Hopper, Bellows, Prendergast, Sloan and others.
In 1929 she offered these to the Metropolitan Museum of Art along with $5 million for a new wing.
The Met, long criticized for collecting dead artists but ignoring the living, rejected the offer and, says Ms. Berman, Mrs. Whitney and her assistant, Juliana Force, concocted the idea of their own museum, specifically to serve American artists while they were still alive.
Mrs. Whitney retained the architects Noel & Miller, who in 1931 rebuilt 8, 10 and 12 West Eighth with a coating of salmon-colored stucco and a modernistic entranceway. The stucco veneer was by then a standard solution for redoing old houses, but the doorway shouted out with the novelty of a brave new post-Crash architecture.
Severe white marble columns support a giant entablature, itself topped by an eagle in white metal designed by Karl Free, a painter and curator at the new museum.
Aluminum strips are bundled into giant, reed-like columns and the sidewalk is in diaper-shaped sections of pink and gray tints. Aluminum outer doors, with American-flag stars and Art Moderne details set in red Numidian marble, were removed when the Whitney left the building in 1954.
The interior, designed by the decorator Bruce Buttfield with the architects, began with a striking, almost surreal, vestibule with a vibrant terrazo floor, a double staircase with strange, tendril-like balusters and sculpture niches with starkly realistic figures of nymphs.
IT is difficult to document, but the rest of the interior changed repeatedly over the next decade. The changes showed how architects and designers were starting from scratch with the advent of modern design.
Baseboards have a strange, angular top molding. The mahogany hand rail on a stairway ends in a supremely exaggerated curlicue.
Rectangular light fixtures mix the Federal-era symbols of five-pointed stars with blue glass and metal casing recalling several periods.
Douglas Morgan, development director of the New York Studio School, calls this synthesis "Early American Deco Empire."
Indeed, the controlling personality of the museum building is its furious mixture of styles and periods. A 19th-century pier mirror faces a nightclub-modern rest-room entrance.
Italianate door and room moldings co-exist with sophisticated 1930's gallery lighting. Ancient wooden stair balusters run past Art Moderne doorways.
The old Whitney is rich with the presence of artists. To close off a hidden staircase, Robert Locher painted a trompe l'oeil doorimitating a staircase.
A fragment of Thomas Hart Benton's mural series on American arts survives in the original library -- an arc with the words "She'll Be Wearin' Red Pajama."
AND Gertrude Whitney's studio, on Macdougal Alley, is eye-popping, one of the great unknown interiors in New York, designed by Robert Chanler. In a high, whitewashed space of plain brick walls a blaze of sculptured flame encases a chimney. As it reaches the ceiling, the flame changes into waves and clouds, spreading out over a ceiling sea of fantastic figures -- dragons, sea horses, demons, mermaids, angels and octopi.
The Whitney Museum opened in 1931 with George Bellows's "Dempsey and Firpo" painting of a boxing match as a centerpiece symbolizing its challenging stance.
"There may be pictures here that you do not like, but they are here to stay, so you may as well get used to them," Mrs. Force declared at the opening.
In 1932 came the first of the Whitney's Biennial exhibitions, pilloried in the press, according to "Rebels on Eighth Street." The museum -- for another decade largely reflecting the personalities of Gertrude Whitney and Juliana Force -- continued to join in controversy without reservation.
Active in helping unemployed artists in the Depression, it got criticism that much larger (and less helpful) institutions were spared.
Mrs. Whitney died in 1942 and Mrs. Force in 1948. In 1954 the Whitney moved up to West 54th Street, behind the Museum of Modern Art, finally relocating to its present site at 75th Street and Madison Avenue in 1966.
The old building remained, however, bought by the New York Studio School in 1967. It is now a picturesque gaggle of studio spaces, with ancient linoleum coming up off even more ancient pine floors and with puddles of clay, paint and other materials everywhere.
But when skylights leak and walls shift, the possibilities move from the artistic to the catastrophic.
With a historic-structures report by Li/ Saltzman Architects and Wesley Haynes, the school is beginning to make $600,000 in emergency repairs on the gutters, exterior walls, roofing and skylights.
At the same time it is planning to raise $5 million more to restore the dingy facade and make other interior repairs. Mr. Morgan said the result would be not spotless and museum-like, but still an art school awash with dribbled paint and the baggage of artists who are living, not dead -- very close to the spirit of the original institution.

(F.S. Lincoln); Building's entry today. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Music of Many Lands at Grace Church's 'Noonday Getaway'

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN

 BODY:
THIRTY years ago, chamber music was the province of the listening elite. Record companies and presenters avoided it because it didn't sell and classical radio stations reserved it for late evening hours when it wouldn't drive away most of their audience.
All of that has changed, thanks in part to the pioneering work of groups like the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, to the high cost of presenting larger ensembles and to sundry other considerations that would make an interesting doctoral thesis. Whatever the causes, chamber music today occupies an important and much-loved segment of our musical awareness. 
 As the new season beckons, we note with delight the abundance of listening pleasures in store countywide.
Friends of Music, which was ahead of its time in anticipating the new public acceptance of chamber music, is about to begin its 40th season, bringing us some of the finest soloists and ensembles in the country. In the Ossining High School auditorium on Sept. 25, in fact, two superb string quartets will be on hand, the Cleveland Quartet and its protege, the Ying Quartet, winner of the 1993 Naumburg Award. The groups will top their individual Beethoven and Bloch performances with the Mendelssohn Octet.
The renowned pianist Richard Goode gives a solo recital in October, and a similarly high standard continues with later visits from the New York Chamber Soloists, the Lark Quartet and the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio. Those wishing more information may call 271-4657 or 271-4800.
What Friends of Music is doing in Ossining, the Westchester Chamber Music Society does in Rye, with a world-class five-recital series at Congregation Emanu El.
Four elegant performers -- Christopher O'Riley, Pamela Frank, Paul Neubauer and Carter Brey -- join forces Nov. 14 to present piano quartets of Mozart, Brahms and Aaron Jay Kernis; in December, it is a meeting of the musical minds between Oscar Shumsky and the Emerson Quartet (a rescheduling of a program that had to be canceled last year because of the violinist's illness); and in the new year, the Hagen and Tokyo Quartets and the Mannes Trio. The reservations numbers are 948-6533 or 723-0222.
The Pleasantville Chamber Music Society has once again made tickets unnecessary for its Sunday afternoon series, beginning Nov. 21 at the Presbyterian Church. How the wizards at the society have been able to maintain this no-admission-cost policy through 17 years of inflation is a wonder, but we can be grateful.
Appearing at the Nov. 21 opener is a new group, L'Estro Harmonico, with a promise of an old favorite, Schubert's "Trout" Quintet; later concerts are by the Arden Trio, the Manhattan String Quartet and, in March, a Baroque finale with the flutist John Solum and friends. No reservations are required, but for a flier call 769-1827.
Chamber music, as the phrase suggests, originated in intimate, often private surroundings, rather than the churches, schools and other large halls in which it is most often found today. Performers of Westchester is based on the premise that sonatas, quartets and so forth are still best served by being in a warm, intimate atmosphere, so all of its programs take place in private homes.
"When you attend our concerts," said the publicity director, Linda Caigan, "you are one of a small audience and experience an unequaled intimacy with the music and musicians. Following each performance, refreshments are served and you have an opportunity to talk with the artists."
High on the list of those artists is Stanley Drucker, first clarinetist of the New York Philharmonic, who opens the season on Oct. 1 and 2 with his wife (and fellow clarinetist), Naomi Drucker, and the pianist Miriam Brickman.
Later on the Orion String Quartet and the standout violin-piano team of Maria Bachmann and Jon Klibanoff will perform, among others. Those interested in locations and reservations may call 693-1151.
Among concert offerings this week is the season opener of Music at Concordia at the College in Bronxville at 8 P.M. Friday when Susan Deaver and David Allen Coester present what they describe as "a quiet evening of chamber music" (337-9300).
Another opening follows at 8 P.M. on Saturday when the Greenleaf Chamber Players, an ensemble chartered to explore the repertory beyond that usually performed by string quartets and piano trios, begins its second season at SUNY Purchase with Schonberg's super-romantic "Transfigured Night" for String Sextet, and Mozart's Serenade No. 10, with its offbeat scoring of double bass and 12 wind instruments. The box office is at 251-6200.
Also at 8 P.M., the Philharmonia Virtuosi unveils its "Baroque With a Twist" series at the Peekskill Paramount, with Anton Nel, the Naumburg Award winner, playing Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 9, K. 271, and the ensemble's new concertmaster, Mela Tenenbaum, featured both in a Locatelli violin concerto and one by Vivaldi for viola d'amore, all with Richard Kapp conducting. The program will be given again next Sunday afternoon at the State University. For subscription or single-ticket reservations, call 693-5595.
While the Greenleaf and Philharmonia ensembles occupy the smaller halls at SUNY, the New Orchestra of Westchester begins its season in Theater A with two concerts, at 8 P.M. Saturday and 3 P.M. next Sunday.
Tedd Joselson, a Westchester native, is the featured soloist, with the music director, Paul Lustig Dunkel, surrounding his performance of the Prokofiev Second Piano Concerto with two symphonic staples, Berlioz's Roman Carnival Overture and the Beethoven "Pastoral." Credit card reservations are accepted at the orchestra's offices, at 682-3707.
Most local choirs are just beginning rehearsals, so it will be two months before the musical results are available. Not so the 30-voice Coro Laboratorio, from Fano, Italy, which has included the Rye Presbyterian Church on its first American tour. Under the direction of Paola Urbinati, the ensemble will present works of the Italian Renaissance and Baroque periods, plus choruses of Rossini and Verdi, at 8 P.M. Saturday.
There is no admission charge, but donations will be accepted at the door. For details, phone the church office at 967-0842.
