HEADLINE: World Markets;
Curious Wrinkle in the Mexican Play

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
TO show how closely Mexican stocks mimic the ups and downs of the pending North American Free Trade Agreement, financial analysts point to a chart that plots stock values with Nafta news.
Check Oct. 4, 1992, the day then-candidate Bill Clinton announced his conditional support for the agreement. The Mexican market index -- then at 1,250 and sliding -- suddenly turned skyward. Then look at Jan. 20, 1993, Inauguration Day for President Clinton, when he gave his mixed message that he would support the agreement, but only if side accords were reached. In Mexico, the stock index lurched up a bit, then sobered to turn sharply downward. 
 The past two years have been a roller-coaster ride for the Mexican stock market -- the Bolsa Mexicana de Valores -- and for United States investors enticed by relative bargains to stay the bumpy course. Many believed that by now everything about Nafta would have been wrapped up, or nearly so.
But even though the Bolsa index reached a new high of almost 1,950 on Tuesday, the steam ran out again. Congress's apparent reluctance to pass the historic deal before the Jan. 1 deadline set by the Mexican President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, has even diehard Nafta supporters trying to hedge their bets -- even by just a bit -- to get over the next few rocky months.
"People are looking for something that gives some downside protection if Nafta fails, without giving up all the upside benefits if Nafta goes through," said Eduardo M. Cabrera, manager of Latin American equity research at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Analysts suggest hedging bets by shifting stocks or moving more heavily into bonds, but no strategy manipulates risk more completely than the warrants, or options, now being offered by groups like Serfin Securities, the New York broker-dealer for Grupo Financiero Serfin, a large Mexican banking and financial services company.
For a 20 percent premium, Serfin is offering a kind of Nafta insurance policy to limit losses to no more than the 20 percent premium in a basket of five industrial Mexican stocks. Of course, Serfin also keeps 20 percent of the gain if the value of the basket spurts beyond 20 percent.
"In that sense you can hedge yourself against the good and the bad," said Hernan Sabau, executive director of derivative products for Grupo Serfin in Mexico City.
The basket comprises shares from five of Mexico's largest companies: Telefonos de Mexico; Cemex, a cement producer; Cifra, an operator of supermarkets; Femsa, a brewery and bottling company, and Vitro, a glass manufacturer. Telmex is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. The other companies are traded in the United States as American depository receipts.
Each share in the basket is a bet that the trade agreement will cause prices to fluctuate enough on the Bolsa this fall to make back the premium Serfin is charging. Investors can pledge a minimum of $10,000 for a share in the five-company basket. The initial installment on the premium is $6.65 per $100 invested with the balance due on Jan. 3, the first working day of the new year. The basket will reflect stock values as of last Friday.
Mr. Sabau said that on Jan. 3, investors who made the downpayment will have several options. If the value of the basket rises or falls by more than 20 percent, Serfin pays investors the difference between the current value and the Sept. 10 value, if investors exercise their option. Because of the 20 percent premium, using the option provides a gain only if prices rise or fall by more than the price of the premium.
Investors also have the option of simply backing out and forfeiting the initial premium.
"This is an instrument where people are hedged against good times or bad times," Mr. Sabau said. Investors are hurt, he said, only if stocks do not move up or down, and they lose their premium.
He said Serfin Securities is willing to grant $50 million worth of the stock warrants based on prices as of Sept. 10.
Some analysts said such a financial rabbit's foot carries too steep a premium for average investors. Mr. Cabrerra of Merrill Lynch believes that the time for hedging bets is past and that now investors have to decide for themselves whether they believe the trade agreement will or will not pass.
William Truscott, a portfolio manager in the Latin America group at Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc. of New York, said the continuing uncertainty hasn't caused him to change his view that the trade agreement is "of minimal significance," to the Mexican market over the long run. Thus, he is not planning to hedge.
The analysts at Bear, Stearns & Company have devised their own strategy. They recommend shifting away from higher performing but riskier stocks like those in the infrastructure, retail, banking, tourism and communications sectors and moving toward slower, steadier performers like food companies and mining and industrial suppliers dependent on overseas sales that would not be overly hurt by defeat of the trade agreement.
Analysts at the emerging markets unit of Lehman Brothers, increasingly worried about Nafta's prospects, have reduced their estimate of the chance for Nafta passage to 65 percent from 80 percent. "The way to hedge the market in general," said Lawrence D. Krohn,chief Latin American economist at Lehman Brothers, "is to back away from it now and see what happens."

HEADLINE: Higher Grazing Fees Have Ranchers Running Scared

BYLINE: By DOUG McINNIS; Doug McInnis, who has lived in Wyoming and Colorado, is a reporter for The Columbus (Ohio) Dispatch.

DATELINE: LOST CABIN, Wyo.

 BODY:
WITH a cattle ranch 10 times the size of Manhattan, Rob Hendry might be expected to make a comfortable living. Instead, he worries about going broke, even though he often works from early morning until dark, seven days a week.
His future, he says, depends not on his own labor, but on Washington, where the Clinton Administration and Congress are reshaping Federal land policies that have long fueled the West's economy. Last month the new Administration moved to more than double grazing fees on Federal land, while imposing new environmental restrictions on its use. 
 These policies are of intense interest to Mr. Hendry and those who run 18,000 other Western ranches because they all pay to graze more than 30 million head of cattle and sheep on 260 million of the Government's acres. Many ranchers run on such a slim margin that any large increase in grazing fees would cut deeply into profits and even plunge some into losses. If, in response, ranchers cut back their operations, beef prices could rise and imports could begin to fill the void, he warns.
When Federal grazing fees are low, well-watered private land and large tracts of Federal land complement each other. It takes huge amounts of land to run cattle in a region where annual rainfall of six to nine inches is less than the Midwest may get in a week, and forage is extremely thin. But if grazing fees rise too high, the system may not work, ranchers say.
For their part, environmentalists have complained for years that ranchers were paying cut-rate fees, while damaging land by overgrazing. During 12 years of Republican Presidential rule, those charges got little attention. Bill Clinton's election changed matters. The stakes are huge. Government land in 12 Western states, including Alaska, equals all land east of the Mississippi, and much of that is vital to Western industries.
Wyoming, for example, ranks first in coal production, third in sheep, fifth in natural gas, and sixth in crude oil. Each industry relies on Federal land, which makes up 49 percent of the state. Those industries -- along with cattle ranching and timber -- provide many of the best-paying jobs and support service employment in cities like Casper, center of the region's petroleum industry. "If we lose oil and gas, mining and ranching, Casper dries up and blows away," Mr. Hendry said. "There's nothing else in town."
Traditionally, the Government has let ranchers use its land on favorable terms, and more than half of Wyoming's 5,000 ranchers do so. Federal lands make up nearly half of Mr. Hendry's 150,000-acre ranch, the Clear Creek Cattle Company.
Like other Western ranchers, Mr. Hendry, 36, considers the Federal land part of Clear Creek, which was begun by his Scottish immigrant grandfather in 1912 as a sheep ranch. During the Depression, Clear Creek survived only because its banks chose not to repossess it. After World War II, Mr. Hendry's father, Jim, 71, took it over and switched to cattle. Today, three generations of Hendrys -- Jim and his wife, Mary Helen, and Rob, his wife, Leslie, and sons James Wayne, 9, and Jarrod, 4 -- live in adjacent houses on the ranch 75 miles from Casper, the nearest city.
But changing Federal policies could tear up the age-old economics of ranching. Take Mr. Hendry's operation, which is larger than many Western ranches, but typical of the financial pressures these ranches face.
Mr. Hendry's land and livestock are worth roughly $5 million. After a string of losing years in the 1980's, the ranch turned profitable with an upturn in beef prices. It now makes about $60,000 a year after taxes, or a slim return of just over 1 percent on assets. And that profit is crucial to the ranch's survival because it pays for capital expenditures, like new trucks. (Mr. Hendry's salary is $850 a month, plus he gets free use of his house, which is owned by Clear Creek.)
The proposed grazing fee would cut deeply into those profits. Mr. Hendry now pays $1.86 a month for each "animal unit," which consists of a cow and calf, or five sheep. In the Clinton proposal, that would rise to $4.28 over three years. Mr. Hendry's total fees would rise from $13,450 to $30,450, and the $17,000 difference would come straight out of profits.
The new environmental rules are expected to add more costs. Those proposals would, among other things, shorten grazing seasons and curtail the use of pesticides for grasshopper control. They would also make it easier for the Government to terminate leases to ranchers who abuse the land.
In addition, the higher Federal gas taxes in the recent budget bill will cost the ranch about $700 a year. Down the road looms the possibility of Federally mandated health insurance for Clear Creek's four hired hands and their families. (The ranch offered health insurance once, but stopped as costs soared.)
IT would take little to put Clear Creek in the red. Mr. Hendry fears that a downturn in beef prices -- averaging $1.03 a pound for a 500-pound calf -- would be the final blow, leaving the ranch unable to pay interest on loans taken out in the 80's, when, like many Western ranches, Clear Creek expanded.
Just a nickel-a-pound drop would cause income to fall roughly $50,000 on the 2,100 calves Mr. Hendry markets each fall. Though no one can say where prices will go, big fluctuations are not unusual. In 1992 calf prices dropped about nine cents before rebounding this year, according to Cattle-Fax, a Denver research group.
Frank Shepperson, a rancher near Casper, is prepared to use less Federal land and run a smaller herd. If others follow suit, beef production would shrink and prices could rise, which would benefit ranchers elsewhere. Only about 20 percent of production is in Federal land states. Some Western cattle-producing states, like Texas and Nebraska, have little or no Federal grazing land.
Environmentalists are not impressed by these arguments. "This will not drive all the ranchers out of business," said June Rain, executive director of the Wyoming affiliate of the National Wildlife Federation. Nor, she said, will it result in $10 Big Macs, though she conceded that it could lift costs. "Every industry and citizen has to face the rising cost of a clean environment," she said.
THE federation said that more than two-thirds of 95 million acres of grazing land it studied was in unsatisfactory condition and that some areas should be off limits to grazing, but other parts can accommodate it if ranchers don't overdo it.
Environmental groups assert that overgrazing destroys vegetation along stream banks, and creates siltation, which damages trout populations. As cattle tromp through streams, they widen stream beds, which quickens evaporation, drying up a water supply on which wildlife depend.
Moreover, overgrazing causes grasslands to give way to sagebrush, mesquite and nonnative exotic grasses, environmentalists contend. In some cases, native wildlife won't eat these new grasses. And some invading plant species are not deeply rooted, and thus less effective in holding soils in place.
Two years ago, the General Accounting Office studied 20 million acres of Federal desert grazing land in Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico and Utah, and concluded that current levels of grazing risked long-term environmental damage. And, the G.A.O. said, grazing fees do not generate enough funds to manage the region properly.
Some middle ground may be found. Although the President's planned grazing fee may be cut back, ranchers say some increase is coming. "It's inevitable, and may be justified," Mr. Hendry said. "But to more than double it is pretty radical." Senators Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, and Ben Nighthorse Campbell, Democrat of Colorado, have proposed lifting fees only about 25 percent -- a plan recently endorsed by five Wyoming ranching organizations.
Mr. Hendry said Clear Creek could survive a modest fee increase. But Western sheep ranchers might not. They are losing money because lamb prices -- at 65 cents a pound -- are about five cents a pound below the break-even point, said Jim Magagna, a third-generation sheep rancher. Mr. Magagna runs 5,000 head on 500,000 acres in extremely arid southwestern Wyoming, all but about 4,000 acres of which is owned by the Government.
Mr. Magagna is contemplating something that was once unthinkable. "If they double it right now, and land prices stay in the range they've been in the last four years, I wouldn't even try to make money," said Mr. Magagna, past president of the American Sheep Industry Association. "My sheep would be sold."
If he quits ranching, the only other prime asset Mr. Magagna can salvage is the land he owns, which includes 2,500 acres at the foothills of the Wind River Mountains. If he must, he will sell it for ranchettes -- small parcels with vacation homes. For years, environmentalists have complained that cows and sheep compete with wildlife for scarce resources. They do not relish the idea of vacationing humans competing for those resources, too. "We do not want ranchettes," said Ms. Rain of the Wildlife Federation.
THE idea of using less Federal land is based on the nature of that land, which is the worst for grazing, less fertile than private land, and often without water. When settlers took homestead allotments they left marginal properties for the Government.
Mr. Shepperson is angered at the prospect of shrinking a ranch he expanded through winnings on the professional rodeo circuit. The Clinton Administration cares "more about a wolf and a spotted owl than they do about hungry children," he said.
Ranchers are also bitter because they say that their land is in much better shape than critics admit. As the elder Mr. Hendry drove the dirt roads of the ranch he built, he described practices intended to keep the land healthy. No land is grazed for more than one season. Herds are moved from range to range, summering as high as 9,000 feet, wintering in the lowlands. "If we destroy the land, we're out of business," he said.
Despite all the difficulties they face, Jim Hendry believes Western ranching will survive. "You have to believe that common sense will prevail," he said. "America simply cannot allow this to be turned into a recreation area and nothing else."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2308 words

HEADLINE: Missing Out on a Glittering Market

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
LES MUSIAL assumed that Malaysians lived in "straw huts or something" when the Chrysler Corporation dispatched him to Southeast Asia last year to help open its first manufacturing operation in the region in more than a decade.
Chrysler made him feel no more comfortable about the assignment when a company doctor presented him with 10 pounds of medicines -- "for malaria, for tropical diseases" -- apparently in the belief that local supplies might be lacking. 
 But Mr. Musial's qualms about Malaysia were upended the minute he landed at the marble-lined international airport here in the capital and began driving into one of the most modern cities in Asia, with residential neighborhoods that could be mistaken for California suburbs.
"I saw the skyscrapers, lots of skyscrapers, and the manicured lawns," he said. "There were good, new cars on the road. I thought that the technology and the industry would be in the beginning stages. But then you see the factories, and they are so advanced that you could put them anyplace on earth."
Mr. Musial was seeing for himself what many American business leaders have not yet seen, or have chosen to ignore -- that Southeast Asia is in the midst of an economic revolution that in several nations is creating glittering wealth where once there had been only abject poverty, and that Americans are welcome to profit from it.
Over the last decade, Southeast Asia has been the fastest-growing economic region on earth. Collectively, the major non-Communist nations of the region -- Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the Philippines -- already have a vast manufacturing base, and they are quickly creating a market here for imported goods. Among the more than 400 million people of Southeast Asia, a large and growing middle class is clamoring for American goods -- even as the market for American products has faltered in Japan and in Europe.
So why aren't more American companies here?
American businesses offer several answers to that question -- from the perception of widespread corruption among government bureaucrats in the region to the frustrations of doing business halfway round the world from the home office. But the larger reason that Americans shy away may be simple ignorance about the opportunities here.
 
An Ambassador's Plaints
 "We've really had to beat on American companies to get them out here," said John Wolf, the United States Ambassador to Malaysia, recounting his frustration in trying to persuade American companies to open marketing offices here and to bid on big government infrastructure projects, including this city's new $3 billion airport. "The place is in the chokehold of the Japanese, even though there is a fantastic potential for Americans."
To be sure, American investment in Southeast Asia has grown substantially in recent years, but the pace of Japanese investment has been much faster.
According to the Japanese Finance Ministry, that nation's cumulative investment in Asia, most of it in Southeast Asia, has tripled from $20 billion in 1985 to $60 billion at the end of last year. The latest total is almost double the $32.2 billion that the Commerce Department shows American companies have invested in the region, although the figures are not perfectly comparable because of different statistical methods.
The companies that account for most of the new American investment in the region are the same giants -- including Exxon, I.B.M., Coca-Cola -- that have been operating in Southeast Asia for years. More than 40 percent of American investment in Southeast Asia is in a single industry: petroleum.
In July, Chrysler began manufacturing right-hand-drive Jeep Cherokee utility vehicles in a plant just outside Kuala Lumpur, the company's first manufacturing operation in Southeast Asia since it pulled out in the late 1970's to deal with a severe domestic slump. Kmart announced last month that it would open stores in Singapore in its first large venture in Southeast Asia.
Yet Chrysler and Kmart are the exceptions to what American diplomats and members of the American business community here say is a distressing rule.
"There is an amazing lack of understanding as to the potential of Southeast Asia," said Roger Bertelson, general manager for Malaysia for Motorola, which has four factories in Malaysia and employs 12,000 people. With high-technology investments like Motorola's, Malaysia is now the world's largest exporter of computer chips.
"There needs to be a swift kick in the rear end for American businesses," said Robert D. Orr, the former American ambassador to Singapore, the futuristic city-state that functions as the hub of Southeast Asia's economic miracle. "I just don't think they understand what has happened in Southeast Asia."
 
Impressive Numbers
 The numbers bear out the opportunities. The economies of the six nations that make up the Association of Southeast Asian Nations -- Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines and Brunei -- have collectively experienced annual growth of 7 percent over the last decade. They grew 5.3 percent last year -- still impressive in light of the recession among Asean's large Western trading partners.
With 328 million people and a gross domestic product of more than $350 billion, the six Asean nations are already the fifth-largest export market for the United States, after Canada, Japan, the European Community and Mexico. Adding neighboring Taiwan and Hong Kong, Southeast Asia is a $600 billion economic powerhouse.
The export markets for American goods in Japan and Europe have stagnated since 1990, but the export market to the Asean nations has grown by more than 26 percent, reaching $24 billion last year.
There is still wrenching poverty in Southeast Asia. Cambodia, Laos and Myanmar (formerly Burma) remain among the poorest nations on earth and after years of upheaval, the Philippines has fallen far behind its non-Communist neighbors. But the overall trend in Southeast Asia is one of solid growth, stable governments and open markets.
The region's largest nation, Indonesia, home to 184 million people, has seen per capita income rise from $250 in 1985 to nearly $650 today, and seems likely to see it double again within a decade.
Despite concern that Indonesia could someday fragment along ethnic lines -- there are scores of major ethnic groups and hundreds of languages among Indonesia's 13,000 islands -- American investors already in the country say the risk seems far off, and they speak with enthusiasm about the Government's prudent economic planning, vast natural resources and cheap labor.
Malaysia is poised to become one of Asia's next economic tigers, notably through the development of high-technology industries. Singapore, with its enlightened economic planning and rigid social engineering, has emerged as the region's financial and technological center. Thailand's economy continues to grow rapidly despite political upheavals and a succession of recent governments.
And Vietnam, with 70 million people and a well-educated, low-wage labor force, is widely thought by foreign investors to be on the verge of an economic boom that will accelerate if President Clinton follows through on hints that he will lift, at least partly, an American trade embargo that dates from the Vietnam War.
In a few stretches of Southeast Asia, incomes approach, or even surpass, those of Western European nations. In Singapore, the per capita income is more than $15,000. In tiny, oil-rich Brunei, it is more than $17,000 -- wealth for buying imports.
Robert E. Driscoll, president of the U.S.-Asean Council, a Washington-based trade group that represents American companies doing business in the region, said that among Southeast Asians, "There is a cachet to owning American." Still, American business has largely ceded the market to Japanese competitors.
 
Detroit's Regret
 In Bangkok, Jakarta and Singapore, Southeast Asia's yuppies crowd expensive department stores bearing the names of Japanese retailing giants. The upper end of the small appliance market is virtually monopolized by Japanese brands, as is the auto market.
Detroit's decision in the 1970's to shut down Southeast Asian manufacturing operations just as the automobile market here was about to explode "was a shortsighted decision made on the basis of huge domestic losses and a need to restructure at home," Mr. Driscoll said. And now the price is being paid, as a generation of newly affluent Asian carbuyers buy Japanese.
The reluctance of more American businesses to establish operations here perplexes the Southeast Asians. "You have to be an absolute fool not to make money here," said Noordin Sopiee, director of Malaysia's Institute for Strategic and International Studies. "Our markets are open to you. Many people speak English. We watch your television shows."
He attributes the American absence from the market to a basic American ignorance about Asia, particularly Southeast Asia. "They don't think of us," he said of Americans.
Mr. Orr, the former ambassador to Singapore, recalled attending a March 1992 dinner in Manhattan held to drum up interest in Southeast Asian investment among prominent New York bankers and executives. "The dinner became a little testy because many of the people in the room were quite defensive," he said. "They kept saying they were wary of Southeast Asia after getting their fingers burned in South America and in other third-world countries."
 
No Latin America
 Comparisons between the prudently planned economies of today's Southeast Asia and the disastrous, debt-laden economies of South America in the 70's and 80's are distressing to those who know this region. The dinner was evidence to Mr. Orr that "people just don't understand the indigenous wealth of Southeast Asia and what is happening there."
The reasons for the absence of new American investors go beyond simple ignorance. Widespread government corruption in the region has frightened away many potential American investors who are justifiably wary of violating American laws that forbid the payment of kickbacks and bribes abroad. Few large government projects in Indonesia, the Philippines or Thailand are won by foreign contractors without at least the whiff of corruption or insider connections.
Still, American executives operating here say that the corruption is no more prevalent in Southeast Asia -- and may actually be less so -- than in other parts of the developing world.
"An awful lot of American companies refuse to engage in corrupt practices and succeed in Southeast Asia," said Mr. Driscoll of the U.S.-Asean Council. "It may take a little bit longer to get business done. You may lose a couple of contracts. But once you've learned the business system, it's a problem that can be overcome."
Other potential investors shy away because of the inconvenience of doing business halfway around the world from most of the United States. It is easier for a New York investor to search out business opportunities in Brussels, seven hours flying time, than in Bangkok, 19 hours, and most Americans have ancestral ties with Europe, not Asia.
"It is not as difficult to do business in Asia as some potential investors seem to think it is," said Mr. Bertelson of Motorola. "But in Asia it does take patience. Relationships are very important here. And the relationships take time. Unfortunately, Americans are not the most patient people."
As a result of their impatience, many American businesses are missing out on what is in general a liberal, welcoming climate for foreign investors and exporters. In the larger nations of Southeast Asia, foreign investors can own 100 percent of a business in most industries; there are government guarantees that foreign-owned businesses will not be nationalized; the governments are flexible about allowing foreign companies to send their profits home.
When they do consider Asia, many potential American investors think not about Southeast Asia but about China or Japan.
But investment in China carries risk. While the Chinese economy's annual growth rate is now approaching 13 percent, many economists warn that it may be on the verge of overheating. Corruption is a growing problem. And the protectionist barriers are far higher in Japan than in the large nations of Southeast Asia.
"Japan is a huge market, but there are many more obstacles to getting into it," said Phil Curran, managing director for the Thailand division of Digital Equipment, the computer maker. "The argument you can make for Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore is that you can hit the ground running, you can get productive quicker, and you can start taking your money out quicker."
In contrast to Digital's upheavals at home in the United States, its operation in Thailand has grown phenomenally since it began in 1988. Business in Thailand grew 46 percent last year, reaching $70 million. A recent survey of 3,000 Asian business people, most of them in Southeast Asia, found that more than 50 percent had invested in desktop computers in the last year.
 
Why No Eastern Europe?
 The commercial counselor in the American Embassy in Kuala Lumpur, Paul Walters, said that among many Americans, "there is almost a fear of the unknown about Asia."
In the United States, he said, he encountered companies that were moving quickly in Eastern Europe, where there is only a small fraction of the industrial capacity and affluence of Southeast Asia.
"I see these companies spending all of their time in Eastern Europe, even though there's no money in Eastern Europe to speak of," he said. "And in the end, nothing comes of it. If these same companies came to Southeast Asia, they'd find the people here are ready to deal with them -- and have the money to spend."

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
The Competition Gives Away Its Product. What, Him Worry?

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Scott Cook may soon be keeping track of your money from the time it enters your hands until it is pried from your fingers by the Internal Revenue Service.
Mr. Cook is chief executive of Intuit Inc. of Menlo Park, Calif., which makes Quicken, the most popular personal finance program for personal computers. Intuit recently announced it would merge with Chipsoft Inc., maker of Turbotax, the leading PC tax preparation program. 
 Mr. Cook's career began at Procter & Gamble, where he once helped recruit Steve Balmer (now the billionaire vice president of Microsoft). Later, while at Bain & Company, a business strategy consulting firm, he and Tom Proulx moonlighted to start Intuit, which shipped Quicken in 1983. We caught up with the Cooks early one morning last week.
Question: Describe your feelings in the first 10 seconds after you heard that Computer Associates, a billion-dollar software giant, had decided to give away a million copies of Simply Money, a Windows program designed to kill Quicken.
Answer: [Yawns.]
Q: Yawn? Really?
A: No, I just had the 4 A.M. feeding. Actually, my reaction at the time was that it was just like being back at Procter & Gamble. In packaged goods, virtually every major brand is launched with a free trial promotion or a giveaway, and the truth is that most new brands fail. Demand dries up when they stop giving it away and start charging for it. The product quality has to be there. It all gets down to the product.
Q: And now that you've seen the product?
A: I breathed a sigh of relief. It doesn't have legs.
Q: So far Quicken has fended off assaults from Microsoft Money and the Computer Associates giveaway. Isn't there a risk of hubris, of becoming the next Visicalc, which owned the spreadsheet market before Lotus 1-2-3 arrived?
A: We wanted to make sure that if there was a way to beat Quicken, that we made every effort to find it before someone else did. So we assembled a team of outside renegades -- brave, wild thinkers, including the guy who invented Harvard Graphics, and the woman who designed Hewlett-Packard's Dashboard interface for Windows -- and told them to go out to beat Quicken. We said, 'Use none of our learning, ignore our work, and figure that what we've done is wrong or has holes in it.' They worked for a year.
Q: Did they find the killer?
A: They came up with great ideas, but ideas that were not the germ of a new product. Instead, they were great extensions and improvements to what we were already doing, which will be incorporated into the next version of Quicken. This research did show us that there is a huge class of customers that we were not speaking to. Financial software was doing a great job of helping people plan for retirement, but these guys were just trying to get to the next paycheck, and we were doing nothing for them.
Q: [In background.] Dwoo, ack! Aiyyy?
A: Why, thank you, Karl. A toothbrush is exactly what Daddy wanted.
Q: Ah, we're in domestic mode. Your company went public, and as a co-founder your household finances probably became, shall we say, more complicated? And now the Chipsoft deal will double the company's size to $200 million. Do you still use Quicken to balance your own checkbook?
A: Oh, absolutely. I was just catching up this weekend. I kind of ignored it for a month while we were doing this merger. You know, in Japan, household finances are done exclusively by the women, and banking is done by so-called bank ladies.
Q: [From Signe.] No wonder they're so well run!
A: She uses it on a Mac to keep track of her horse business, and I use it on a PC, the Windows version, for my accounts.
Q: A mixed marriage!
A: I've got to be where the volume is, and the volume is with Windows.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Reform in Mexico: Now You See It, . . .

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
NOW that Mexico is being auditioned for a major role as a trading partner of the United States, the country may be more in the world's spotlight than at any time since Hernan Cortes sent word back to Spain that Moctezuma had rooms full of gold.
What makes Mexico so interesting now is that for the first time, a developed country like the United States is thinking of joining hands so firmly with a developing country like Mexico, and Mexico is determined to show that it is worthy of its new status. 
 Debate on the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would lower or eliminate most tariffs on goods moving into the United States from Mexico and Canada, officially began in Washington last week. Besides jobs, the discussion is expected to turn on Mexico's internal situation and on the attempts of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his cabinet of United States-trained technocrats to reverse some of the country's old habits: repressing democracy, neglecting poverty and encouraging corruption.
Many economic and social reforms have come out of Los Pinos, the Mexican White House, and at least on the surface it appears that Mexico is truly re-inventing itself. But while substantial changes have been made here, recent examples suggest that parts of the new Mexico may be little more than a Potemkin village, consisting of impressive but hollow structures built by officials who are overly eager to please.
Take, for example, part of the recent electoral reform passed by the Mexican Legislature, in which the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party has an overwhelming majority. The party has never shown much inclination to change the election procedures that have locked it into power for six decades; this is one reason why United States Congressmen like Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey have been saying that the free trade agreement should be a "democracies-only club" and have been pressing for more democratization here.
After a long debate, legislators this month approved a change in the Constitution that would make Mexicans eligible to run for president as long as one parent is native-born. Until the change takes effect, both parents must be native-born.
The change could have allowed a popular opposition party leader -- Vicente Fox Quesada -- to run for president next year. But the ruling party delayed the effective date of the reform until the year 2000. "It's just a response to internal political pressure that's been raised," said Mr. Fox, whose mother was born in Spain.
To Mr. Fox and others who are tired of the old Mexico, such goings on prove the country is not yet a democracy. But what Mexico actually is at times seems uncertain. It can be hard to tell the difference between the Government and the party -- which with the fall of the Soviet Communists now is the most durable ruling party on Earth. The Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa has called Mexico "the perfect dictatorship," and is now persona non grata here.
There are plenty of other examples of how the new Mexico seems to be the old Mexico in disguise. Education Minister Ernesto Zedillo has boasted of overhauling the country's schools and universities, and the public school year has just been extended 20 days to 200 days. But some 20,000 children in the central state of San Luis Potosi are reportedly not able to attend class this year because of a shortage of school buildings that is likely to continue for five more years.
Millions of photo identification cards have been issued as a safeguard against fraud in the 1994 elections. But the election commission is still controlled by the ruling party, and opinion polls indicate that only 34 percent of Mexicans believe the vote will be clean.
Even something as seemingly straightforward as the new superhighway connecting Mexico City and Acapulco may not be all it appears to be. When it was opened in July, Mr. Salinas called it a work of national pride. The only problem is that traveling it is so expensive (a round trip costs $158 in tolls) that most Mexicans cannot afford to use it.
Critics of the free trade agreement say that the lobbying for it is twisting Mexico's sensibilities. Questions are arising about Mexico's identity, and no wonder. Wal-Mart is opening a store in Mexico City. Bread is gaining popularity over tortillas. Gov. Ann Richards of Texas has accepted an invitation to attend independence day ceremonies on Wednesday in Mexico City. She is said to be the first Texas governor to attend since the Alamo.
Robert Pastor, a Mexico expert at Emory University in Atlanta, said "Nafta is a watershed event" that represents "the first time the United States and Mexico have consciously decided to manage" the economic and social integration that has been going on for decades.
But with so much about Mexico being reconsidered on both sides of the border, even history seems to have become hard to pin down. Last year, there was an outcry over the Government's new public school history textbooks; one criticism was that they gave incomplete explanations of an incident in 1968 when the Mexican Army was ordered to open fire on student demonstrators in Mexico City.
This year, the winning entry in a contest to come up with new books ended its treatment of Mexican history in 1964 and invited students to write their own version of what has happened since.
That seemed to solve the problem. But the Education Minister has decided not to publish the books anyway and will hold another contest next year.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1034 words

HEADLINE: Clinton's Big Gamble;
Spreading the Pain of Health-Care Reform

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the end, governments have a limited number of tools available to fix things domestic. They can regulate, they can tax, they can spend and their leaders can exhort. And they are assured of tremendous grief anytime they do any of the first three. So they sometimes follow a normal human impulse and look for some way to share the burden.
The 246 pages of health-care proposals that were made unofficially public last week represent the promise, the gamble and perhaps the measure of Bill Clinton's presidency are also a textbook example of how to share these unpleasant tasks. The plan's vision is health care, at reasonable cost, for all. Its structure reflects its essential gamble: that the despised tools of taxation and regulation have been camouflaged in enough different ways to make the proposal politically palatable. Understand this, and it is easier to understand why President Clinton's effort to exercise new control over one-seventh of the nation's economy seems so complex. 
 Take the new entities that will work on the front lines, squeezing down health-care costs. They will not be Federal regulators but regional-health care alliances, perhaps state agencies or nonprofit organizations, as each state government sees fit. These will negotiate the price of coverage with networks of doctors, hospitals and insurers.
Or take the Administration's call for all employers to ante up money to furnish health insurance for their employees. The Administration insists that this is not an ugly new tax, but an innocuous premium. Most business lobbyists disagree.
Now step back and imagine trying to control a series of interlinked industries that employ 15 million people -- doctors, insurance adjusters, research chemists, even hospital janitors. Then think of applying the principle of proxy regulation and taxation on top of it all. That's complexity.
The sweeping proposal to remake this $900 billion industry would be the Government's biggest intervention in the economy since President Richard Nixon imposed wage and price controls in 1971 and arguably the largest since the Roosevelt Administration's industrial mobilization asserted control over more than a third of the economy during World War II.
However much the Clinton Administration may assert that the plan will create a more efficient health-care industry, worries abound that the changes could create huge inefficiencies and lots of losers. Many people -- not just conservatives -- fear that whenever the Government wades deeply into economic affairs, it messes things up. One cynic said the Government might do for health care what it did for the savings and loan industry.
Small-business organizations argue that the plan's requirement that small businesses provide health insurance for their employees will push thousands of mom-and-pop companies out of business, and force the layoffs of more than a million workers. The Administration has sought to cushion the blow by phasing in this requirement and proffering subsidies to small business. But Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, an association of 610,000 small businesses, said, "No matter how you try to sweeten the taste, arsenic is arsenic."
Administration officials say that wholesale Government intervention is the only way to rein in health-care costs, which are draining the economy and pushing up the Federal budget deficit. Without a Government overhaul, the Administration notes, health-care costs are expected to jump to 19 percent of the nation's gross domestic product within a decade, up from 14 percent at present. That would be 2.5 times the level in many other industrial countries.
The plan "should improve our international competitiveness," said Kurt Karl, an economist with the WEFA Group, an economic consulting firm.
"It should enable large companies to hire more people. Their cost per worker should go down, so their demand for labor would go up. But for smaller companies that do not have health-care coverage, this should raise their costs. They would then tend to reduce the size of their workforce."
Small businesses' worries will find a ready audience among many in Congress, especially those Republicans interested in overhauling the President's overhaul.
The plan's intricacy has not kept industry experts from making some early calculations about who wins and who loses.
To brake cost increases, the President's plan would limit the amount that health-care premiums could rise each year. This cap would limit the of money in each health alliance's till, encouraging alliances to squeeze doctors and hospitals to hold down their costs.
For instance, an alliance might contract with the health maintenance organization that made the lowest bid to provide care for 20,000 of the alliance's members. The H.M.O. might try to hold down costs by paying doctors a set amount -- perhaps $35 -- for each patient visit or by paying a hospital less for doing an appendectomy than it paid last year.
In this way, the Clinton plan would create a new universe of losers and winners. Specialists who charge $200 a visit may be squeezed, while demand for lower-cost nurses should jump. Hospitals able to cut costs could prosper; those that can't might have to close.
Companies that develop money-saving medical devices see their stocks soar. Drug companies specializing in generics should do well, while researchers who develop new drugs may see their big budgets slashed.
But President Clinton's system of health alliances might not create all the competition he hopes for -- and thus might hardly hold down costs. If he loses this bet and health costs keep rising at twice the inflation rate, Mr. Clinton could turn to hands-on, no-proxy regulation: he could set a global cap on health spending. This, many economists fear, could lead to price controls.
"If you try to jam one-seventh of the economy inside a fixed budget, one of two things happens," said Donald Moran, senior vice president at Lewin-VHI, a health-policy consultant. "You won't be successful in jamming it inside that budget or if you're successful, you create all sorts of distortions in the way the system works."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Congress Opens the Larder, and Ducks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REMEMBER Fibber McGee's closet? In every episode of the classic radio comedy "Fibber McGee and Molly," McGee would absent-mindedly open a closet door, unleashing an avalanche of pent-up junk -- shoes, bowling balls, maybe skis -- that would cascade onto the floor, raise an immense clatter and make the audience bray with laughter.
Washington has such a closet: it's known as Congress. Every spring, lawmakers stuff great mounds of bills into its maw , and then ignore most of them until autumn, when Democratic leaders in both chambers realize that the year is about to end with little to show for it. As distinguished from the radio comedy, the trick in Congress is to open the door just enough to free the political winners, but not so much as to get bonked by the legislative version of bowling balls. 
 Autumn is about here, and the lawmakers have their hands on the doorknob again. The anticipation is delicious.
At this moment, which bills will reach the House or Senate floor, and in what venue, is a matter of some deliberation, not to say scheming, among Democratic and Republican leaders and lesser members.
It is "almost like a game of chicken on the highways," former House Speaker Jim Wright recalled last week, describing the year-end competition to pass and kill bills.
Since January, Washington politicians have proposed 4,494 new laws and enacted exactly 81, including a $504 billion economic package and a measure that enables armored-car guards carry guns across state lines. If history is any guide, Congress will enact at least a couple hundred more bills by Turkey Day, when it ardently hopes to adjourn for the year and go home.
A few items, however, will not wait. Congress must pass 13 separate appropriations bills, prescribing 1994 budgets for the panoply of Government agencies, preferably before the new fiscal year begins on October 1. (It will miss the deadline, but only by a few weeks.)
Nafta, the contentious free-trade pact with Canada and Mexico, must land in the Congressional hopper by year's end, before the expiration of a crucial law that guarantees it an expedited, non-amendable trip through the legislative mill.
President Clinton wants to carve into law some of the governmental reorganization plan Vice President Gore proposed last week, partly because that might enable him to keep his promise to Congress and come up with another $10 billion in budget trims. Congress should take that up. The President wants votes on a $3.4 billion crime bill proposed last month, so mark that down, too.
But the last days of a legislative year are more jitterbug than minuet, and there are other ways to force votes on -- or, for that matter, to deep-six -- any of the 4,413 bills still vying for attention.
First, there is the power of public opinion. Despite it, most lawmakers would prefer to delay votes on three do-good measures: bills to tighten the campaign-finance and lobbying laws, already passed under some duress by the Senate, and a more sweeping blue-ribbon plan, not yet in bill form, to tighten Congress's rather sedentary management practices and its ethical constraints.
Still, House Democrats, who are are naturally wary of campaign-money reforms that would hurt incumbents and management reforms that would erode their privilege, will likely take them up anyway, mostly because an angry public and an assemblage of talk-show hosts have made them priorities. Making necessity a virtue, the House can be expected to pass parts of all three measures and pound itself on the back for a job well done.
Thomas Mann, a longtime student of Congress at Washington's Brookings Institution, advises against taking this too seriously. Note that in the dying days of last year's Congress, House Democrats pushed a positively Calvinist version of campaign-spending reform to passage, utterly confident that George Bush would veto it. Without a sure veto on t5he horizon, the same bill is barely treading water this year.
A second trick of late-year scheduling: Voting on an unpopular bill enables lawmakers to brag during the next election campaign that they supported it.
A third rule: wily legislators can force even the balkiest leadership to give their bill its day. Take Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat, who is guaranteed a Senate debate and vote, probably next month, on legislation his superiors detest -- a proposal for a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.
Mr. Clinton is curiously silent on the bill, a sure sign he dislikes it. For two years, George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, stiffed Mr. Simon's pleas for a floor debate on the proposal. But Mr. Simon extracted the promise of a vote when he began threatening to attach the measure to other bills as an amendment. This summer, the Senate Judiciary Committee quietly voted by a 15-to-3 margin to endorse the amendment. Leaderships ignore bipartisan support at their own peril.
A fourth ploy: adopt protective coloration by hiding a bill among similarly nondescript bills. There is always a chance that it might be passed without much scrutiny. This is the way most bills pass at year's end -- under suspension, a procedure by which lawmakers vote on a flock of bills, weeding out only those that cannot muster, say, two-thirds of the vote in the House.
It's also surprising how time flies while you're dodging bowling balls.
"What's really amazing, when you look at the legislative calendar" says Lawrence O'Donnell, the staff director of the Senate Finance Committee, "is how few in-session days there are in a year. When you throw into that a little arithmetic about the number of hours a piece of legislation can tie up the Senate floor, you can think of it as something akin to the way our court dockets are clogged.
"I used to think a year was a long time," he added. "But Senate floor time is a precious thing."
So is space in Fibber McGee's closet.

HEADLINE: Conversations/Douglas A. Fraser;
He Always Gets Restless When the Union Is Bargaining

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
"THEY have no sense of strategy!" thunders Douglas A. Fraser, former president of the United Automobile Workers and a skilled negotiator, watching the Big Three negotiate new three-year labor contracts with auto workers in this country and Canada.
The immediate object of his ire is his longtime employer, the Chrysler Corporation, which, he argues, frittered away a precious bargaining chip by announcing before negotiations began that it would expand a plant in Canada. 
 "They gave that away six months ago," he grumbles, then laughs his long, gravelly laugh. "You wonder how the hell that industry survives."
At age 76 and out of the fray for more than a decade, Mr. Fraser finds himself restless when negotiations roll around every three years. Now a professor of labor studies at Wayne State University here -- a "concocted" title, he says, because of his spotty academic credentials -- he clearly misses the give and take, or at least the take, of bargaining for U.A.W. members.
"It's only once every three years that you have the opportunity to address their concerns and their worries and their goals and their aspirations," Mr. Fraser says.
But workers' priorities, and with them the bargaining process, have changed, he says. Mr. Fraser, an immigrant from Glasgow, Scotland, with a high-school education, was first hired in the plants in 1935, then fired for trying to organize workers, then rehired, then fired again, then rehired again; eventually he climbed through the U.A.W. ranks to negotiate with the giants of American industry, as well as with senators and vice presidents. Over that period, the U.A.W. improved the lives of hundreds of thousands of men and women, revolutionizing the idea of what blue-collar workers could achieve -- second homes, fishing boats and the paid vacations to enjoy them.
Now there are as many retired auto workers as there are active ones, however -- and the active ones' average age is 46. At the same time, the auto industry is aging, hampered by foreign competition and no longer the engine of prosperity it was.
"As you become older, your interests change, and now you're concentrating on security, particularly in an industry that's so volatile and so threatened," Mr. Fraser says. "So I think that what happens is that the members have become more cautious."
Now, he says, "the goals and aspirations almost coincide with the concerns and worries. When you think about it, they're one and the same. They used to be completely different things."
 
Question of Strategy
 As a result, the big issues at the bargaining table are preserving health benefits, improving job security and fattening pensions, rather than bolstering wages or -- as the younger workers in Canada are hoping to do -- shortening the workweek. The current U.A.W. contract, which covers about 700,000 workers and retirees, expires at 11:59 P.M. on Tuesday.
In the old days, Mr. Fraser negotiated some of the union's more inventive contract provisions, including free legal advice for auto workers. As president of the union (1977 to 1983), he helped save Chrysler by rewriting the contract two times between negotiations in the late 1970's and early 1980's. He made financial concessions, but they were not for nothing: in exchange, he got the union a profit-sharing plan and a seat on the company's board of directors -- anathema to the companies and puzzling to many members, but for Mr. Fraser a way to gain greater influence over company policy, including plant-closing strategy. The union later lost the seat.
At times, Mr. Fraser sounds wistful about what the union could be achieving.
"I suppose if we were in normal times, prosperous times, they might be thinking about something like having an educational fund to send their kids to college," he says. "That would be a goal and aspiration. Wouldn't be a bad one, either."
As the goals of the workers have changed over the lifetime of the union -- which is to say, over Mr. Fraser's career -- so have the tools of the negotiators, their understanding of each other's needs and their relative strength.
In the past the negotiators used to rely on one calculator; today they have batteries of computers and economists. In the 1930's, Mr. Fraser recalls, a foreman told him -- when the sweat in a stamping plant turned his shirt brown -- that lead was good for him; today the companies work with the union to design safer working environments.
In the past, company negotiators used to call quality a "management prerogative"; today labor-management cooperation has become an advertising theme. And in the past the Big Three, in particular General Motors, were the undisputed leaders of the industry, able to dictate price and style; today they are running scared.
"You know, they say, 'Well, the union doesn't have as much power as they used to' -- the hell they don't," Mr. Fraser says. "Maybe it's not so much the union has gained strength as the companies have become more fragile, so the contest isn't as even as it used to be."
A strike now, he said, would devastate the target company, as the Big Three slowly regain market share from Japanese automakers.
 
A Certain Caution
 The same circumstances that give the union more power, Mr. Fraser says, force it to be more cautious about exercising it. In the old days, the workers felt more free to pressure management. Around 1940 Mr. Fraser worked with a team of men hammering the wrinkles out of about 14 fenders a day, for use in the Chrysler. The foreman kept exhorting the group to raise their output to 16. Mr. Fraser told the men to cut output to 12.
"So we did, for a week, and they were going crazy," he says. "I remember the foreman coming to me and saying, 'Lookit, starting Monday, it's 14 a day.' "
Now workers view management as less of a combatant.
"It sounds simplistic, but I think there's a higher level of understanding on the part of our members that they can't survive unless the corporation survives, and they can't prosper unless the corporation prospers," he says. "You know, in the auto industry we just rolled along. There were a few bumps in the road, but every time there was a downturn you knew somehow it was going to come back. That's no longer true."
As a result Mr. Fraser says, "I suppose, if you had a company-wide strike, the American public would probably question our sanity."
Despite such considerations, Mr. Fraser believes the union will strike if the auto makers try to roll back health benefits -- which is why he thinks the companies, their protestations notwithstanding, won't really try. Personally, he favors changing the union's benefit plan to charge workers if they choose to go to more expensive doctors and nurses.
"If I could reach back over the decades, I'd do it that way," he says. "But it's late now. The system is so embedded, and the workers so cherish it."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
South Africa Sanctions May Have Worked, at a Price

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
IN the arsenal of diplomacy, economic sanctions are crude weapons, slow-acting and unpredictable. When they work, innocents suffer. The bad guys, after all, are usually the ones with the bunkers and gas masks -- or, in this case, the power and cash -- to endure a war of attrition.
But as the use of real force has become less politically palatable, the world has increasingly turned to the trade embargo, the investment ban, the credit blockade or the assets freeze as a way of punishing a misbehaving state. The United States now monitors official sanctions of one kind or another against a dozen countries. Do they work? 
 South Africa now presents one case study of sanctions that have run their course. With the white Government's agreement last week to submit to the oversight of a multiparty council in the months before next April's election, making the transition all but irreversible, the African National Congress is on the verge of calling off the economic penalties the world imposed against apartheid.
In hindsight, few now question that the sanctions had powerful consequences, but there is no consensus that the results were quite what the sponsors intended.
The United Nations imposed an arms embargo against South Africa in 1977 after a massacre of schoolchildren in Soweto, but the real economic siege of South Africa began in 1985 when Chase Manhattan Bank, under pressure to sever its ties with the apartheid rulers, called in its loans. Other banks in America and Europe followed suit. The following year Congress voted, over President Reagan's veto, to restrict trade, investment and lending by American companies in South Africa. Scores of state and local governments enacted their own anti-apartheid statutes.
It is impossible to isolate the effect of sanctions from the other pressures that finally drove the white Government towards surrender: the riots and nettlesome guerrilla war waged by the African National Congress, the ascent of a more sophisticated and pragmatic generation of Afrikaners like President F. W. de Klerk, the collapse of the Communist bogy man that so terrified South African whites, the shame of sports and cultural boycotts and, perhaps most of all, the sheer, self-defeating folly of an ideology that tried to make foreigners of the country's black laborers and customers.
The African National Congress contends, and some independent economists agree, that sanctions helped hasten the end of apartheid through a combination of psychological and economic pain.
"Sooner or later, probably later, the Government would have had to face up to including blacks," said Edward Osborn, chief economist of Nedbank, who has studied the impact of sanctions. "But I think the short answer may well be, yes, sanctions accelerated the process."
Critics of sanctions counter that sanctions worked, but economic growth would have worked better, and would have left the next, democratic Government with a healthier country to run.
Such apartheid practices as reserving certain jobs for whites and forbidding blacks from living in cities, most experts agree, were abandoned because the state simply could not hold back the tide of job-seeking blacks. A booming economy, with more jobs, the critics argue, might have brought down those barriers faster.
"Sanctions have slowed down change," said David Steward, the chief Government spokesman. "They slowed down the big engine that was already breaking down apartheid."
Some sanctions hurt worse than others. The trade restrictions, by most accounts, had limited effect on a country rich in gold and diamonds. When America and Europe refused to buy South African goods, exporters scrambled to find new markets in the East and, except for a few industries like winemakers in the Cape region, they succeeded. South African consumers, in turn, had little trouble finding new sources of oil and other imports, using devious channels and paying a premium to middlemen.
 
Tight Money
 The most devastating blow was the loss of easy credit from foreign banks. While most developing countries are big borrowers, South Africa became an exporter of capital, rationing out its cash to satisfy foreign creditors. Tight money helped push the country deeper into recession and, Mr. Osborn and other economists are convinced, helped persuade Mr. de Klerk to reverse course in February 1990.
Critics of sanctions, including the Government and the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party, contend that the main victims of this economic punishment were destitute blacks, who make up most of the country's nearly 50 percent unemployment rate. Poverty, in turn, bred violence.
"Violence doesn't take place among the middle-class suburbs," said Peter Smith of Inkatha. "It takes place among the poorest, the marginalized, and blacks are poorer and more marginalized as a result of sanctions."
Trevor Manuel, the head of the A.N.C. economics department, conceded that blacks shared in the suffering, but not disproportionately. In part because of sanctions, white South Africans, who were less accustomed to economic hardship, experienced a startling drop in their living standards, and newspapers began reporting the eye-opening novelty of whites lined up at soup kitchens.
The sanctions ricocheted with many unpredicted effects.
One, many economists agree, was that by slowing the most advanced economy in southern Africa, sanctions also retarded development in neighboring countries, including outspokenly anti-apartheid (but economically dependent) countries like Zimbabwe and Zambia.
Another, Mr. Steward observed, was that South Africa, cut off from foreign military supplies, built up "one of the seven or eight largest armaments industries of the world."
Another was to convert many South African business executives into grudging lobbyists for political reform. Alarmed by the prospect of endless isolation, bankers and corporate executives privately urged Mr. de Klerk to move faster, and publicly entered into their own dialogue with black leaders.
 
Better to Stay or Go?
 Some of the impetus came, paradoxically, from American companies like Colgate Palmolive and I.T.T. that decided, despite public vilification, to remain in South Africa. To justify their decision, they signed pledges that committed them to programs for black advancement, and a number of South African companies followed their example.
Yet another unplanned result of sanctions was to help fatten a few South African corporate giants. As American and European companies disinvested, titans like the Anglo-American mining conglomerate bought up the abandoned automakers and paper companies and banks, consolidating a hold on the economy that critics contend has thwarted competition.
The stunted economy that sanctions helped create now becomes the inheritance of the A.N.C., assuming it wins elections next April. Blacks will take over an economy that is shrinking, that is not adept at competing in the world, that is lagging behind in research and modernization, that is inbred and dominated by a few corporate pyramids.
And the United States, having helped bring the South African economy to its knees, is now being called upon to help get the country back on its feet.
"I believe that clearly American sanctions played a major role in the dismantling of apartheid," said Michael Judin, a lawyer specializing in United States-South African trade. "And we feel that it's now incumbent on the American people to play a major role in rebuilding the country."

HEADLINE: Mideast Accord: U.S. Policy;
Clinton Seeks to Buoy Israelis, Saying U.S. Backing Is Firm

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton today promised the Israeli public the unflinching support of the United States at this critical time in an effort not only to make Israelis comfortable about striking a deal with Yasir Arafat but also to obtain their backing for a future peace accord with Syria.
In his first interview since the breakthrough toward peace in the Middle East, Mr. Clinton said King Fahd of Saudi Arabia told him in a telephone conversation on Friday that despite the lingering wrath of the Saudis over Palestinian support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, they would be ready to contribute funds and raise money from the other Arab nations of the Persian Gulf to insure that the new Palestinian entities in the Gaza Strip and Jericho get on their feet. 
 Mr. Clinton said he expected the American economic contributions to be modest. He said he saw Washington's job as providing seed money while most of the aid would be contributed by Japan, the European Community, Scandinavia and the gulf Arabs, all of whom have given him indications of support.
 
In an Ebullient Mood
 Dressed in a track suit and gripping a mug of coffee in the early hours of this morning as Air Force One carried him from California to Texas, the President was in an ebullient mood. He alternated between expressions of amazement at what was happening in the Middle East, analyzing the different actors almost as though he were watching the most unusual play, and pragmatic discussions of his strategic plans that underscored the central role he feels he too must perform if the whole thing is to work.
"I think even some of the leaders are still adjusting to it," Mr. Clinton said, explaining that he was not the only one stunned by the recent events. Recounting his telephone conversation with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel on Friday, Mr. Clinton quoted him as saying: " 'Can you believe, Mr. President, that I am signing this letter to Yasir Arafat? I fought him for decades.' "
Asked how he felt about playing host to Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, at the White House, Mr. Clinton said: "I guess I sort of feel the way Rabin does. I never thought I would be in this position, but then I never thought Arafat would be doing what he is doing.
"First of all," he went on, "I would tell him that I think he has done the right thing and that he has given the next generation of Palestinian children a chance to have a normal life -- that they don't have to grow up first throwing rocks in the intifada and then learning how to use guns and then wondering whether they could wreak more violence or endure it."
 
Assad's Cautionary Words
 Among the other points made by the President in the 70-minute interview in his private cabin were these:
*President Hafez al-Assad of Syria is ready to endorse the accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization but had cautioned Mr. Clinton in their telephone call that it could not stand alone, but had to be followed up by a breakthrough on the Syrian-Israeli track.
*The Administration still opposes the creation of an independent Palestinian state, but his view is that Israelis and Palestinians should decide such issues and that his policies will be strongly influenced by what they decide.
*He hopes Iran will use the Middle East breakthrough not to isolate itself further by opposing it, but to "change course" and thereby create the possibility of a different relationship with Washington and the West.
Time and again, though, the President hammered at a single point: Israeli public opinion. That was the key, he said, because Israel is the country that will have to trade tangible security assets for promises. He said the people of Israel had to be made to feel secure about that, since otherwise the opposition there would block the deal, there would never be progress on the Syrian track and the whole thing would unravel.
"The pivotal question is what the traffic can bear in Israel and in Syria," Mr. Clinton said. "And that is a function of how well this initial agreement is received in Israel. One of the things that I really hope to do -- and I mean this in no way that I am trying to interfere in internal Israeli affairs -- by hosting the event on Monday is to reassure the people of Israel that the United States is committed to their security, that we see this as a huge, emotional, psychological as well as practical step toward giving them a more normal life. And that it is possible because they have been willing for the first time to get a normal life to give the Palestinians some measure of normality and that if we are still with them maybe we can in sending that clear message generate more support for this deal in Israel."
 
No Promise on Aid
 Asked to be more specific, Mr. Clinton did not promise an increase in American aid to Israel -- already about $3 billion a year -- but sought to assure the Israelis that just because they signed a peace agreement the United States was not going to start reducing aid or military support. Clinton aides said later, though, that the President was considering an increase in military assistance to Israel to help it defer the costs of redeploying its troops from the Gaza Strip and Jericho.
"Plainly we have to be part of any ultimate resolution of the Israel, Syria, Lebanon negotiations," Mr. Clinton said. "But I think that they have to deal with it and I think what we have to do is to create the strongest possible conditions in which they deal with it and I think right now what that means is making the Israeli people as comfortable as they can be with this -- that they are more secure not less secure because this is done and that the United States is still there. I think that is the most important thing now as they absorb this."
The President continued: "Each successive day that the agreement builds up in strength I think that that enables the Government in Israel to engage Syria. I personally believe that is a lot more important than the details of this piece of land on the Golan Heights or anything else."
Mr. Clinton went on at great length about his phone conversation with President Assad of Syria, which lasted 30 minutes. That conversation seemed to underscore the challenge Mr. Clinton faces in trying not to overload the political circuits in Israel -- by asking Israelis to withdraw from the Gaza Strip and the Golan Heights at once -- while also keeping the Syrian leader interested in supporting moves that might not reward him immediately.
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Assad had told him: "I think you are right. It is a positive thing, this agreement, for all of us. I just want to know that you are committed to the whole process."
"I said, 'I am, strongly,' and I said, 'I think you should be committed to the whole process.' I reminded him the issue in Israel is security, and the opposition to the agreement are people who believe that it will weaken rather than enhance their security, and if we are going to see this all the way through, which I really believe we have to, you got to solve these inter-state conflicts.
"Monday has to be a signal to the people of Israel that this is about security. I said if your Ambassador is there it will be a pretty clear signal that you are serious about it, and he said, 'Yes, I think that is right.' "
 
'A Huge Deal'
 "But he also said he really wanted my commitment to continue," Mr. Clinton added. "He said, 'You know, the people on our side are restless too and they don't want to feel that our part of this will be abandoned.' "
According to an Administration official, the Syrian leader added: "If there is no comprehensive peace this will not stand on its feet. If there are long periods of time with no progress these difficulties will grow greater. We should not let time go by without serious work."
Mr. Clinton said he was most relieved by the willingness of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to support the Israel-P.L.O. accord, despite the P.L.O.'s support for Iraq against Saudi Arabia in the gulf war.
"I think he has very strong feelings about that gulf war -- very strong feelings about this," Mr. Clinton said. "I said to him: 'Your Majesty, you have been a great ally of the United States and a great force for peaceful resolution of this conflict for a long time. This is not like Camp David where the United States basically had to assume financial responsibility because of the interplay of world politics.' He said, 'You take the lead in organizing it and tell us what we're supposed to do.' But he said, 'I will be there.' He said, 'This is too important.' He said this is a huge deal."
Mr. Clinton indicated that he wanted Palestinians to understand that in emphasizing the importance of the Israelis' feeling secure, so the deal would go ahead, he was not trying to diminish the Palestinians' needs.
"The beauty of this moment is that each of them, in a funny way, has given the other the chance to have a normal life," Mr. Clinton said, "and while they are nowhere near agreement on what the end of Palestinian self-determination looks like, still they have given each other a sense of place. No matter what you say, there is a sense of roots, of place."
 
Depth of Yearning
 The President added: "The one thing I think that we tend to underestimate, those of us who are away from it, is the depth of the yearning of the Palestinians for peace, and a normal life, to know their kids will always be able to go to a school without getting beat up, and never have to provoke an Israeli soldier again. I think underneath that's the bedrock thing here."
Again and again, the President returned to the notion that the moment unfolding in the Middle East was something beyond diplomacy -- that peace there is like peace nowhere else in the world. It evokes something larger than two enemies simply signing treaties.
"This whole thing is immensely interesting for Christians," he said. "Well, I mean, it's our Holy Land too. I never will forget, the only time I went to Israel was with my pastor, who told me after I got back that he thought one day I would be President, and since at that time I was the youngest ex-governor in America -- I was 34 -- I didn't think he knew what he was talking about. And he said, 'Just remember, God will never forgive you if you turn your back on Israel.' It was an amazing thing."
