HEADLINE: CLINTON SCRAMBLES TO FIND FINANCING FOR HEALTH PLAN

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Just days after sending a detailed description of President Clinton's health plan to Congress, Administration officials scrambled today to find new ways to pay for it, as they acknowledged that Congress would probably not accept deep cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid.
The officials said they were considering several options, including a new Federal tax on hospitals, if they are forced to scale back the proposals on Medicare and Medicaid, the programs for the elderly and the poor. 
 Ira C. Magaziner, the President's health policy coordinator, said in May that such a tax could be justified because many hospitals would get a financial "windfall" under the Clinton plan. All Americans would have insurance coverage, so hospitals would be paid for services now written off as bad debt or charity care, he said.
 
Seeking Savings in Medicaid
 The hospital tax was not in the plan that Mr. Clinton sent to Congress for inspection this week. But Administration officials said today that the idea was still under consideration as a backup if Mr. Clinton could not get all the savings he wanted in Medicare and Medicaid.
The President wants to cut $238 billion, or 12 percent, of the projected growth of Medicare and Medicaid over five years. He would use the savings to help finance coverage for the uninsured and to expand benefits for the elderly.
Administration officials say they are also seeking other sources of revenue. One option is some form of tax on big companies that operate health insurance plans for their own workers, outside the regional health alliances that would buy coverage for most consumers under the Clinton plan.
 
Doubts in Congress
 The question of how to finance Mr. Clinton's ambitious program still vexes many Administration officials and members of Congress, who doubt that the latest proposals will produce all the revenue envisioned.
"I don't know anybody who thinks it's fully funded," said Representative Jim Cooper, a Tennessee Democrat who reviewed the President's proposal this week. Gail R. Wilensky, an economist who was in charge of Medicare and Medicaid from 1990 to 1992, under President George Bush, complained today that the Clinton Administration had "punted on the question of how to finance" the program. "It's not hard to be benevolent if you're not worried about how to pay for it," she said, asserting that Mr. Clinton had avoided "hard choices."
The Administration's 11th-hour struggle comes just days before Mr. Clinton is to unveil the health plan in a speech to Congress on Sept. 22. For months, as he and his aides tried to design a generous, comprehensive package of health benefits for all Americans, they deferred tough decisions about how to pay for it. After a long fight over his budget package, which included many tax increases, Mr. Clinton is skittish about proposing new taxes for health care.
For now, in addition to the savings in Medicare and Medicaid, Mr. Clinton expects to get $105 billion from new taxes on cigarettes and perhaps liquor over the next seven years. He will propose $47 billion of savings in other Federal health programs.
In addition, the White House says the Treasury will collect $51 billion more because businesses will have higher profits and workers higher incomes if medical costs are controlled as Mr. Clinton proposes. C. Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, said that "if the costs constraints really work," such increases in revenue are plausible. But he observed that doctors and hospitals often find ways of circumventing such controls.
And the prospects for other financing tactics are uncertain. Many Congressional Democrats and some Administration officials say the proposed cutbacks in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid are too big, and lobbyists for the elderly note that Medicare was already trimmed in the budget package just enacted. On Thursday, Hillary Rodham Clinton told Congress that the White House was willing to reconsider these proposals.
 
Capping Health Costs
 The premise for many of the numbers in the plan is the assumption that the Federal Government can, by law, curb the growth of health spending. The Clinton plan includes a formula that would put a tight lid on the growth of private health spending, as well as Medicare and Medicaid.
Under this formula, in the year 2000, the Government would not allow any increase in medical spending beyond that needed to keep pace with inflation and population growth.
Hospital officials say the health-care industry probably cannot curb costs so fast, and many Administration officials agree.
In recent weeks, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and her staff have raised questions about the validity of numbers being used in the President's plan. But Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mr. Magaziner insist that Medicare, Medicaid and private insurers can save huge sums by cutting waste and limiting payments to doctors and hospitals.
Some Administration officials say they worry that abrupt cutbacks could have devastating effects on the quality of care and access to care. Other officials say such concerns are unfounded and cite the experience of manufacturing companies that have become stronger after cutting costs.
James D. Bentley, senior vice president of the American Hospital Association, said his group was willing to consider a national budget that set limits for spending on the standard package of health benefits to be guaranteed to all Americans under Mr. Clinton's plan. But, he said, the budget should not be fixed in advance by a rigid formula. Rather, he said, the budget should be set annually, "in view of actual experience, the state of the economy and the needs of the population."
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said, "We should focus first and foremost on total national health expenditures, not on the share of health expenditures that flows through the Federal budget."
 
Premium Cap or Price Control?
 Under Mr. Clinton's plan, the Government would control health spending by limiting the premiums that could be paid for private health insurance. Insurers, he assumes, would then have to limit payments to doctors, hospitals and other health-care providers.
Mr. Clinton insists this type of regulation is not price control. But insurers disagree.
Terrence C. Burke, senior vice president of Aetna Health Plans, a unit of Aetna Life and Casualty Company, said: "They can call it what they want, but premium caps are price controls. The minute you put price controls on the industry, you will choke off the capital needed to create competitive health-care systems."
The premise of Mr. Clinton's proposal is that competing networks of doctors, hospitals and insurance companies will control costs to win business. But such networks require large amounts of capital, for medical equipment and computers to analyze the use of care. Federal regulation of premiums would dry up such capital, Mr. Burke said.
 
Spouses' Insurance
 Much, but by no means all, of the money for Mr. Clinton's plan would come premiums paid by workers and employers. He would require employers to pay at least 80 percent of health insurance premiums for their workers. And he would end the current practice of allowing a worker to get coverage through a spouse's employer.
White House documents say that employers would pay "a fixed contribution for each employee." The contribution for a married worker would be the same whether or not the employee's spouse worked.
Dallas L. Salisbury, president of the Employee Benefit Research Institute, said this proposal was intended to "eliminate an incentive for employers to shift health costs to other employers."
Some companies now provide no health insurance for their workers. To save money, some companies that offer health benefits refuse to provide coverage to an employee who can obtain coverage through a spouse.
When husband and wife both work, the coordination of their insurance benefits is complicated. Typically, a worker submits a medical claim to his or her employer. The worker may then ask the spouse's employer to pay amounts left unpaid under the first policy. The spouse's employer may pay some or all of these amounts.
 
Proposal First, Financing Later
 The Administration's scramble today for financing sources stands in contrast to a speech in April by Mr. Magaziner, in which he seemed to minimize the political difficulty of getting Congress to raise taxes.
"Often," he said, "our friends in the media focus their whole attention on health-care reform as if what specific piece of money might have to be raised next year to help us insure the uninsured is the most important thing in health care.
"We know better," he said. "We know that what is really going to matter to the American people five years from now, 10 years from now, is not what amount of money was raised initially to get over the hump of getting the uninsured insured. What's really going to matter is what happens when I go to my doctor. What happens when I get ill? How does my insurance coverage look? Does it really protect me or not?"
That was before Congress, as part of a huge deficit-reduction bill, imposed new taxes on affluent people, Social Security recipients, corporations and gasoline.
From the moment he took office, Mr. Clinton talked of the new health benefits he would guarantee all Americans. His health policy advisers initially gave far less attention to the question of financing than to the design of the standard package of benefits.
But Mr. Steuerle of the Urban Institute says, "Tax policy and health policy are flip sides of the same coin, two sides of the same accounting ledger."

HEADLINE: CHRISTIAN GROUP KEEPING TO RIGHT

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
This was to be a conference where the Christian Coalition broadened its political image, but today Pat Buchanan brought 2,000 Christian conservatives to their feet with a vow to rebuff Republican moderates and never "raise a white flag in the cultural war."
After George Bush lost the Presidential election last year, many moderate Republicans said Mr. Buchanan and the coalition, led by Pat Robertson, had given the party an image of intolerance and were in part to blame. 
 Since then, the Christian Coalition has expanded its issues portfolio beyond its traditional opposition to abortion and homosexual rights, and it has sought to shake its image as an arm of the Republican Party, going so far as to invite the chairman of the Democratic National Committee to speak here at its annual conference.
But the chairman, David Wilhelm, received hisses when he spoke Friday, and the warm reception afforded Republican speakers has left no doubt of the audience's partisan preference.
 
'Our Culture Is Superior'
 "If a political party would turn its back on the 4,000 unborn children doomed to death every day in this country, then it is time to find a new party," Mr. Buchanan said, prompting a standing ovation. "We are a pro-life party, and we are going to keep our party pro-life."
The conservative commentator, who mounted an unsuccessful primary challenge to Mr. Bush last year, won rousing applause again with an attack on "multiculturalism," scoffing at those who say the world's many cultures are equal.
"Our culture is superior," Mr. Buchanan said. "Our culture is superior because our religion is Christianity and that is the truth that makes men free."
It is such talk that moderates claim drove many suburban middle-class voters away. "It cost us the election," said Elsie Hillman, a moderate Republican National Committee member from Pennsylvania.
 
Dole Shows Broader Focus
 Ms. Hillman's view was common among Republicans after the election, and even many conservatives said their movement needed a softer image. But eight months into the Clinton Administration, many Christian conservatives are less worried about taking defiant stands, believing they have gained strength thanks to President Clinton.
Still, not all of the potential Republican Presidential candidates were as eager as Mr. Buchanan to plunge into the party's internal debate over abortion and other social issues.
In speeches on Friday, Senators Bob Dole of Kansas and Phil Gramm of Texas focused on economics and health care.
The closest that Mr. Dole came to talking about the abortion debate was when he said, "We don't need any litmus tests in the Republican Party." Mr. Gramm also avoided social issues.
Former Housing Secretary Jack Kemp said tonight that it was a "false choice" to pit social conservatives against economic conservatives, in a speech that skirted any direct reference to moderates or the abortion feud.
Mr. Buchanan showed no such reluctance and was by far the best received of the four.
 
'God Is an Independent'
 In contrast, the Democratic chairman received a chorus of hisses when he tried to persuade the delegates that the Democratic Party and President Clinton shared their commitment to faith, family and tax fairness.
"Let me say it plainly: the Democratic Party is and always has been a party of values," Mr. Wilhelm said.
He also said the coalition had tried to characterize Clinton supporters as unchristian and said it was wrong to use faith "as a weapon to divide."
"God and faith are not and cannot be the province of one political party or movement," Mr. Wilhelm said. "God is an independent. And no single entity can claim to speak for all persons who believe in Christ and consider themselves Christians."
Today, the executive director of the Christian Coalition, Ralph Reed, said the economic focus by Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm showed the wisdom of diversifying the organization's issues portfolio. "Taxes and health care and government are of paramount importance to our members," he said. "We've moved beyond the days when someone has to talk about abortion when they come before us."
Yet even as he talked of "casting a wider net" to expand the coalition's reach, Mr. Reed was careful to make it clear that he was not advocating a retreat on abortion or other cultural fronts.
"To do anything that would be perceived as backpedaling from that position would be a disaster at the ballot box," Mr. Reed said of the party's antiabortion stance. But he said he believed there was a way to "use different words to convey the same principle," perhaps in a way that also recognized that not all Republicans agreed on the issue.
That delicate maneuvering on the abortion issue was just one example of the challenges the coalition faces as it tries to become more involved in other issues, topics in which its core supporters are not as unified as they are over abortion and gay rights.
Mr. Reed, for example, wanted to put the Christian Coalition's grass roots strength behind the North American Free Trade Agreement. But Mr. Buchanan's opposition to the treaty drew sustained applause, and Mr. Robertson said, "I don't think we are going to be beating a drum on it."

HEADLINE: Tribe Plans to Develop Blighted Area of Bridgeport

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Golden Hill Paugussetts today announced a three-phase urban redevelopment plan for the Bridgeport area that includes building a 250,000-square foot casino.
The tribe said its plan could change a blighted section of Bridgeport into a crime-free, picturesque area. 
 "This tribe has always lived in the Bridgeport area. They are members of the community. They believe in the area and want to see the greater Bridgeport area become more productive, more economically viable," said Rodney Doran, a spokesman for the tribe.
The tribe, which has state recognition, said it would build the casino, an attached bingo hall, two hotels, a 20,000-seat arena and parking garages at a cost of $1 billion if its application for Federal recognition was successful, Mr. Doran said.
 
Land Claimed in Lawsuit
 In the first phase of the plan, the complex would be constructed within a year on land that the tribe has claimed in a lawsuit, which was dismissed by a Federal judge and is under appeal. The tribe said it would also buy more land if necessary.
The second phase would involve building a tribal community home on Pleasure Beach Island, which once housed an amusement park off downtown Bridgeport.
In the third phase, which would take up to 20 years, the tribe would work with the city and state to redevelop the entire east side of Bridgeport. The area has many dilapidated houses and abandoned buildings.
The Paugussetts said they would tear down the buildings and construct multifamily homes to be connected to schools via parks. The plan also calls for the construction of a technical training center, a community college, a performing arts center, an outdoor amphitheater and several retail centers.
 
10,000 to 12,000 Jobs
 Office buildings would be constructed along Interstate 95 as a buffer from highway noise. The tribe, which would police its own complex, would help expand and improve security to deter crime on the east side.
The projects would generate 10,000 to 12,000 new jobs and use mostly small minority- and female-owned businesses, Mr. Doran said.
Based on the success of the Mashantucket Pequots' casino in Led yard, the Paugussetts said they estimated that their casino would make $3 million a day. The tribe said it would come up with a tax-sharing plan with the city and state even though Federal recognition would give it a tax-exempt status.
The tribe would use casino profits to help implement phase three of the urban redevelopment plan, Mr. Doran said.
"The tribe has clear, well-defined, meaningful contributions that it will make to the state and to the greater Bridgeport area," he said. "We're not talking about a pie in the sky dream; we're talking about reality."

HEADLINE: Mideast Accord: The P.L.O.;
Finally, After Several of His Nine Lives, Arafat Is Going to the White House

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUNIS, Sept. 11

 BODY:
It has been a long voyage to the White House for Yasir Arafat.
Several times, the Palestinian leader was counted out in Middle East politics, but each time he has shown extraordinary resilience. In the Arab world, they call him the "cat with nine lives." No leading Arab figure has survived more setbacks than Mr. Arafat, whose latest exploit has been to strike a deal with Israel that has revived his bankrupt, nearly defunct Palestine Liberation Organization. 
 On Monday, unless there is another sudden change, Mr. Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, the man who survived a civil war in Jordan in 1970, an Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982, several assassination attempts, a plane crash, and countless bad decisions of his own will be standing with President Clinton and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel on the White House lawn.
 
End of a Search
 Whether or not he actually signs the document in which Israel will recognize the P.L.O. or shakes anyone's hand, his very presence will mark the end of an incredible search for prestige and for recognition of an organization that Washington refused to deal with for years.
His birthplace is a mystery. There is no official biography, but informed Palestinians say that while Mr. Arafat's family is from Gaza and he spent his youth between the strip and Jerusalem, he was born in Cairo, where he returned for high school and college.
Mr. Arafat has hinted a number of times that his mother shares the ancestry of Faisal al-Husseini, the Palestinian negotiator, who comes from an ancient well-known family, but this account has been disputed.
Ever since he began his tortuous road as a student at Cairo University's prestigious school of engineering, he moved from exile to exile.
After forming the first cell of his own guerrilla group, Fatah, in Kuwait in 1959, he abandoned what he said was a very successful career as a contractor to devote himself fully to the Palestinian revolution.
In the late 1960's, he moved to Jordan. Soon after he was elected president of the P.L.O. in 1969, he built it into an umbrella organization that encompassed military, political and social organizations.
As his power base in Jordan grew, he became embroiled in a struggle with King Hussein of Jordan, who became concerned that the P.L.O. was planning to take over the country.
What ensued was a bitter nine-day civil war in 1970 that has become known as Black September. Thousands of Palestinians and hundreds of King Hussein's Bedouin soldiers fought street-by-street battles that ended in Mr. Arafat's first big strategic defeat by an Arab army. He fled to Lebanon.
Quickly, however, he began to make his first comeback, building a much bigger, more influential state-within-a-state in Lebanon than he had in Jordan.
 
Golden Age in Beirut
 In the early 1970's, thousands of young Palestinians flocked to join Abu Ammar, as Palestinians call Mr. Arafat. Beirut saw the golden age of Mr. Arafat's P.L.O. and Lebanese and Arab politicians looked to him for political consultations, photo opportunities and deals. Millions flowed into the organization's coffers from the Gulf Arabs as well as other oil-rich states like Libya and Iraq.
In the 1970's, the P.L.O. fast became one of the international left's most romantic organizations. When it began to sponsor the hijacking of airplanes, it became one of the most famous. While its aim was to wage a war against Israel, Mr. Arafat's grandiose schemes cast it against much of the West with support from much of the Communist world.
 
Accumulating Power
 By that time, Mr. Arafat was also commander in chief of an estimated 15,000 Palestinian troops, chairman of the P.L.O. and president of Fatah. That marked the beginning of his pattern of accumulating power in his hands. He now also has the title of President of Palestine and has received ambassadors like the Pakistani envoy who presented him with his credentials on Thursday.
It was also in Beirut that Mr. Arafat developed his flair for theatrics and costume: the neatly pressed olive-drab fatigues and the kaffiyeh, a Palestinian headdress, and matching ascot.
But the secret of his success remained as always his fine sense of what his people want. Wrong or right, he rarely went against the instincts of most Palestinians, even when, as in the case of the Palestinians' support of Iraq during the Gulf crisis, the instincts led to catastrophe.
Palestinians may criticize Mr. Arafat bitterly, but all it takes is the sight of him to make them melt in admiration. He cultivates personal loyalties the way a farmer tends to his field. He has been known to astonish visitors with his memory of previous encounters.
He is a dictator who always speaks of the Palestine Liberation Organization as a "democratic organization." In fact, he does allow a margin of freedom to his fellow leaders that permits an extraordinary amount of dissent, far more than any other Arab ruler.
 
Biding His Time
 In the last few days here, for example, while the world awaited the P.L.O.'s decision on the final text of two agreements with Israel, he let dissenters vent all their poison against him, against Israel and against the proposed accord. All he had to do was call for a vote. But he took his time and said little. When the vote came, it was when none of his associates had anything further to add and, more significantly, after he had let the whole world know that his answer was going to be yes.
Among his closest associates he is referred to as "Al Khityar," or "the Old Man," a term he likes. One of his strengths is that he is, among all Palestinian leaders, by far the one who has a reputation for the greatest personal integrity.
Unlike many of his dissenting lieutenants and colleagues, he has always managed to convey to his estimated five million compatriots the notion that while he is far from perfect, he is unequivocally devoted to fight for their cause. He lives simply. He does not drink or smoke, and has never been known to have a good time, go to a party, or do anything but work.
Until his marriage three years ago to Suha Tawil, 32, a Christian who is a graduate of the Sorbonne, he lived with excessive frugality, remaining, as he said many times, "married to the Palestinian revolution."
 
Venom Over Marriage
 Mrs. Arafat had worked as one of his personal assistants for economic affairs in his office after they met in Paris in 1988. She is the daughter of Raymonda Tawil, a member of the Palestinian movement who founded a news agency in the Israeli-occupied territories and was repeatedly harassed by Israeli authorities who eventually shut her business down. The family moved to Paris more than a decade ago.
Mrs. Arafat is known to be a fervent supporter of the Palestinian movement. Mr. Arafat took more than a year before confirming the wedding, and the fact that his wife is a Christian inspired venom in Muslim fundamentalist movements.
The marriage tempered his wildest excesses, but it does not appear to have changed his life style much. One night about two years ago, after an interview that ended at 3:00 A.M. here, he invited a reporter to dinner. On the table there was nothing more than a dozen hard-boiled eggs, stale bread, mineral water and cheese in plastic wrappers.
While Mr. Arafat is one of the Arab world's most notorious wheelers and dealers, most of his followers who remain devoted to him, admire him particularly for preventing Arab countries from trying to control and manipulate Palestinians. This long-held bitterness against fellow Arabs has finally come to fruition in his deals with Israel.
There is little doubt that one of the cherished byproducts of the accord was to signal that Palestinians, who have long suffered humiliating treatment by other Arabs, can move on their own.
 
Farther From Home
 The Israeli invasion of Beirut, during which he became the object of man-hunt by Israeli commandos aided by spies and technically advanced gear, was his second major setback. He successfully evaded his pursuers, developing his remarkable ability to take care of his personal security. He was eventually expelled and moved here to Tunis, still farther from Palestine.
In Lebanon, where he lived for years, he fine-tuned his knack for personal security. He has been known to trust a tiny circle of personal guards, to sleep in cars parked in empty lots guarded by his personal security agents and to spend each night in a different apartment. He always moves without warning, flying in private planes, borrowed from Arab governments but with his own pilots. He keeps departure time, routing and sometimes the destination strictly to himself until after takeoff.
When his Russian-made plane crashed last year in the Libyan desert, he stood in the back of the plane as it went down murmuringaccording to associates on the flight: "I am coming to join you Abu Jihad. I am coming to join you."
Abu Jihad, whose real name was Khalil al-Wazir, was a founder of Fatah and the P.L.O. He was assassinated by Israeli commandoes in 1988 in his home in Tunis.
 
2 Best Friends Slain
 Now, Mr. Arafat is said to be planning upon his entry into Jericho, anticipated for the first of January, to take the coffins of his two best friends, Abu Jihad and Salah Khalef, otherwise known as Abu Ayyad, who was also assassinated, here in Tunis by a dissident Palestinian faction, the moment he steps back into "Palestine."
It is difficult to predict what will happen from now until then, given the threats against Mr. Arafat's life and the evident malaise widely shared by many Palestinians -- and even more by other Arabs -- about the meager gains the agreement provides compared to the grandiose dreams of 45 years of struggle.
But the words he told an interviewer 10 years ago still seem to reflect his own position: "Oh, if only the Palestinians and the Jews unite. The resulting genius, the pooling of material and intellectual resources of our two people are enough to overcome the duplicity, selfishness and corruption of most Arab regimes."

HEADLINE: COUP ANNIVERSARY IS MARKED IN CHILE

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 11

 BODY:
On Thursday, students began throwing rocks and Molotov cocktails and burning tires. On Friday, hundreds of supporters of Gen. Augusto Pinochet staged an all-night vigil outside his home.
Today, Socialists and Communists marched on the presidential palace and skirmished with the police; three bombs were deactivated at headquarters of right-wing political parties; two other bombs exploded at power pylons, and two McDonald's and one Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet -- symbols of American business presence here -- were targets of attempted bombings. The police reported at least two deaths today, an elderly man who was struck by a police water-cannon vehicle and a young boy killed by a gunshot wound. 
 Chileans are looking back in anxiety to 20 years ago today, when the military, led by General Pinochet, swarmed into this city and bombed the presidential palace.
 
17 Years of Military Rule
 President Salvador Allende, a Socialist, died in the coup in what a medical team concluded was a suicide, and Chile entered 17 years of military rule and the so-called dirty war to systematically eliminate the leftist opposition. In the end, more than 2,000 people were killed or made to "disappear," and thousands were imprisoned and tortured. That ended in 1990, when General Pinochet stepped down as President after losing an attempt to be elected and was succeeded by the victorious Christian Democratic candidate, Patricio Aylwin.
The anniversary of the military coup is a day that divides Chile, which now enjoys one of the most stable democracies in Latin America and a booming economy.
"There is a fight for history going on here," said Jaime Esteves, a Socialist Party member of Congress. "Pinochet wants to pass into history as the man who modernized Chile, the great Jefferson of Chile. We want to say that bloody period was not a positive thing."
Many here dispute that point. In fact, what surprises observers is the strength of the conservative streak, the support for the general, who at 77 still runs the military, and the sentiment that stability and economic prosperity take precedence over righting the wrongs of the past Government.
Though Pinochetistas, as they are called, do not wish the general to return to politics, they point to the economic and social convulsions brought on by the Allende Government -- the food lines, the hyperinflation, the seizure of land and factories by workers and the political closeness to Moscow and Havana -- and say the coup was worth it.
 
Prosperity Amid Rights Abuses
 The military re-established order, these people say, and left a vibrant economy.
Last year, with an inflation rate of 12.7 percent, Chile grew more than 10 percent. Its fruits, wine, salmon, lumber and copper are exported to the world, and the country has become a focus of intense foreign investment.
"Pinochet marks the beginning of the modernization of Chile,"said Domingo Arteaga Echeverria, secretary general of the United Democratic Union, a right-wing party. "Someday people will look back at Sept. 11 and see it as a key date."
But others remain deeply troubled by the human rights abuses and by the fact that no officer has been imprisoned for murder or torture. More than 800 cases remain unresolved, and the military has refused to provide information about the victims.
"This is an open wound in our society that cannot be closed," said Genaro Arriagada, secretary general of the Christian Democratic Party.
Under an amnesty law instituted by General Pinochet, no member of the military can be sent to prison for human rights abuses committed from 1973 to 1978, but the Government has still permitted court investigations of the abuses.
General Pinochet is considered an embarrassment in the international political arena, but he also leads the finest army in Latin America and is guaranteed the position as commander in chief of the army until 1998; thus he remains a major political force.
 
Pinochet Answers to Himself
 He does not openly defy civilian authority, but seems to enjoy reminding the public that in the end, he answers only to himself.
In May, disturbed by an investigation into the financial dealings of his son, he called out the army's black berets in a show of force. And the military recently threatened to bring one senior politician before military courts for every officer asked to testify in a human rights case.
Today, General Pinochet referred to the coup, saying, "He who has been in battle knows what the noise of bullets means, knows what it is like to face enemies, knows when someone falls at one's feet. All this produces a mental uncontrol which many times leads to unjustified excesses."
"Those who have done nothing, can fear nothing," General Pinochet said.
Ands this week at Chile's Union Club, where the army was honored, he said "We did not move against disarmed people, against unprepared or innocent people. Here in Chile there were 15,000 guerrillas."
Despite the fear of violence on the anniversary of the coup, no one fears military intervention and Chileans seem to expect continued stability. But many say that it may take decades to bring the military under full civilian control and that most human rights cases will never be resolved.

HEADLINE: Fewer Tickets As Goal Shifts From Revenue

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
After climbing steadily for several years, the number of parking tickets issued by traffic agents in New York City plummeted to 6.6 million from 8.9 million, or by 26 percent, in the fiscal year that ended in June.
The unexpected drop has provoked and puzzled the city's budget officials, who are concerned about a significant loss of revenue at a time of severe economic pressure. 
 But the Department of Transportation says the decline, while attributable to a number of factors, nonetheless fits in with its own shifting philosophy: moving away from infractions that merely milk a municipal cash cow and focusing instead on violations that cause traffic congestion and present safety hazards.
The city's Transportation Commissioner, Lucius J. Riccio, has responded to the decline in tickets issued by agents in the Bureau of Traffic, which his department oversees, with internal and independent reviews for the underlying causes. "We're looking at this phenomenon from all different aspects to find the source of the drop-off," he said.
 
Deliberate Change of Approach
 The decline can be attributed in part to a deliberate change of approach. "We're trying to de-emphasize summonses that do not have a direct impact on traffic flow and quality of life," Mr. Riccio said. "Not cutting your wheels to the curb is a classic example of a summons that doesn't greatly contribute to the traffic mission of the department."
The Department of Transportation points with pride to the average traffic speed in midtown Manhattan: 7.7 miles an hour. It sounds laughably low, but is actually the highest average in a decade.
Other examples of "low-hanging fruit" that agents are encouraged to ignore, according to a department memo explaining the decline in tickets, are illegally parked cars in residential areas during early-morning hours on Sundays, expired inspection stickers, cars faced the wrong way on dead-end streets and wheels aligned more than 12 inches from the curb. (This last violation was removed from the books altogether last year, replaced by one that prohibits a car from blocking a moving lane.)
Officials of the Office of Management and Budget question whether the price tag on the Transportation Department's new approach is one the city can afford. Mark Montgomery, an assistant director at O.M.B., estimates that the shortfall in 1993 will cost the city $53 million over two years. "It's a drop in the bucket in terms of the overall budget but that's not how I look at it," he said. "Fifty million dollars is a lot of jobs and a lot of services."
 
Hope Seems Optimistic
 Budget officials were hoping that the decline would be reversed in the current fiscal year, returning to 8.2 million summonses. But preliminary data from tickets issued in July and August indicate that that projection is overly optimistic.
The brown-clad traffic agents issue about two-thirds of all parking tickets, with most of the remainder handed out by the police and a small part given by workers at some 30 other agencies, from the Department of Sanitation to the Parks Department. The budget office said there was only a slight decrease in the number of tickets issued by the police.
Transportation officials have some strong hunches about causes of the decline. In fact, there is a virtual laundry list cited by the department to account for the sudden plunge in tickets, which reached the lowest level since 1987.
Apart from the Department of Transportation's change in emphasis, other opportunities for the nearly 2,000 traffic agents to catch a violator were removed.
 
Alternate-Side Suspensions
 There was more frequent suspension of alternate-side parking, both because of the elimination of Wednesday and Saturday street cleaning regulations and because of the addition of six religious holidays. With steeper fines accompanying parking tickets, more and more motorists are avoiding summonses by "sitting" in their cars as they double-park or occupy a space next to a fire hydrant. And deferred maintenance on street signs has reduced the number of blocks where tickets can legally be given.
The December northeaster and the March blizzard also led to the suspension of alternate-side parking, and one-time events like the Democratic National Convention and the World Trade Center explosion diverted agents from issuing summonses to directing traffic.
On the Bureau of Traffic's end, there was a high absentee rate of 23 percent among agents, partly because a less-than-expected turnover rate in the last two years meant that more workers had accrued greater vacation time and sick leave.
City officials say, too, that the productivity of individual agents has been hurt by the effects of rising confrontations with the public, including violent assaults. One agent had some fingers blown off by a cherry bomb. Another was whipped with a chain. Others have been shot.
 
Confrontations More Likely
 With a new focus on commercial areas, where officials say it is vital to keep cars from blocking bus stops and traffic lanes and to insure turnover in front of businesses and stores, there are more chances for confrontations. "In residential areas, vehicles aren't watched as closely," said Michael Primeggia, Deputy Transportation Commissioner for Traffic. "In a commercial strip, people park for a shorter period of time."
The department has also recently and emphatically told its agents that they are not subject to any ticket quota. That reminder, plus the reduced emphasis on certain summonses, might have made agents less aggressive by giving them more discretion, the department memo said.
The average number of tickets issued per shift by agents on foot patrol fell from 37 in 1992 to 34 in 1993. For agents in cars, the average ticket number per shift dropped from 54 to 51 during the same time.
"Cooping," or slacking off on the job by agents, was identified as a problem two years ago in a Department of Investigation report, but officials say they have cracked down on popular hangouts and have weeded out the worst violators. Other problems were the writing of fraudulent tickets and the dumping of summonses on abandoned vehicles, practices that may have arisen from a sense by agents that they had to meet quotas.
 
'Integrity' Training for Agents
 As a result of those findings, the Department of Transportation started a campaign called the "total commitment to integrity," which beefed up training for agents, stressed professionalism and sent supervisors into the field to make random inspections. "We wanted to make sure the agents understood that just writing large numbers of tickets was not our highest order," Mr. Riccio said.
The Office of Management and Budget says it recognizes that the main objective for the Bureau of Traffic is traffic management, not revenue generation. But the agency has still asked transportation officials to re-examine their plans.
"We don't want to balance the budget over the backs of motorists, but clearly the financial implications are great," Mr. Montgomery said.
"If there's an indication from the agency that parking enforcement is going to encounter fewer violations on the street," he said, "it would make sense to cut some positions. And if they feel the parking rules are inappropriate, they should advocate change."

HEADLINE: President Appeals for Trust From Bastion of Skepticism

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Traveling to an area where many voters have been skeptical of some of his Administration's more ambitious initiatives, President Clinton told Texas officials today that his plan to streamline Government would be the first step in persuading Americans that he can be trusted to expand North American trade, overhaul health care and even promote peace in the Middle East.
The theme of impending grand challenges was a constant today, in the President's weekly radio address and in his appearance with Vice President Al Gore at a state surplus property warehouse, where the two leaders talked about how Government can be made more customer-friendly and trustworthy. 
 Even as he completed a four-day tour promoting a plan to streamline government, White House officials in Washington were scrambling to prepare for the signing of a Middle East peace agreement and to put the final touches on an extensive plan to restructure health care.
"We're living in truly revolutionary times, with profound changes sweeping the entire world," the President said in the radio address. "Reforming, indeed, reinventing government is essential to make our economic health care and trade efforts succeed."
 
Goodwill Over Strategy
 Reminders of the challenges that await him after Monday's foreign policy celebration were everywhere. A group of about 100 supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement were summoned by Mayor Bob Lanier to the President's hotel for what they thought would be a meeting about Nafta strategy. It turned out to be an informal round of handshaking with Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton.
Even these Nafta supporters seemed nervous about Mr. Clinton's commitment to an agreement that several said would help Texas businesses. "I don't think it has been addressed yet," said Fan Dorman, president of the Houston Interamerican Chamber of Commerce, speaking of the Administration's selling of the pact.
But nothing detracted the President in his effort to showcase the sweeping recommendations for streamlining the Government that were made this week in the National Performance Review.
 
Clinton Signs 3 Orders
 Gov. Ann W. Richards and several other state officials joined Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore in a sweltering government warehouse today to ask public officials for their ideas about how to make Government work more efficiently. With some minor fanfare, the President also signed three orders that he said would help achieve the aims of the performance review.
The orders would direct Government agencies to cut regulations in half, prepare reports on how to cut Government jobs by 12 percent across the board and develop new customer service initiatives.
Mr. Clinton said that such steps had to be taken before the Administration could hope to win support for proposals like the trade agreement. The accord has divided Democrats in Congress and angered labor leaders who argue that the pact will make it easier for companies to move jobs to Mexico.
Mr. Clinton has been stung in recent days by complaints in Congress and murmurings among his own staff about the relative importance of the Nafta agreement, which has already sown seeds of dissent within the coalition the White House needs to approve the sweeping changes he will recommend in health care.
To counteract the impression that the President is backing away from Nafta, the Administration has planned a White House signing ceremony on Tuesday for labor and environmental side agreements to the pact, with former Presidents George Bush and Jimmy Carter in attendance.
But Mr. Clinton said today that he could not hope to whip up support for free trade or any other issue unless Americans could be convinced to take the plan to streamline government seriously.
"Texas is the probably the only state in America right now where there's overwhelming public support for the trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, which I strongly support," he said.
The agreement, he said, would increase spending for environmental cleanup along the borders and raise wages in Mexico.
"Nobody has ever agreed to that in a trade agreement," he said. "And it's a blip on the screen. Why? Because a lot of people in this country whose jobs are at risk do not trust the national Government to do anything right."
"So what we've got to do with this reinventing government is not only save money and give you better service, but restore the trust of the American people that together through our elected officials, we can actually solve problems," he said.

HEADLINE: Rochester Retrenches as Kodak Cuts Work Force

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company had always been there for Mark Assini, even paying his college bills 13 years ago.
But the investment that Kodak made in his education was not enough to save his job. Mr. Assini's election to the Monroe County Legislature last fall did not help either. 
 This spring, he was laid off, sent home to face a future that included three young children and a wife recovering from a stroke.
"It was not so much a shock because I had seen others get laid off," said Mr. Assini, 34 years old, who had worked in finance and marketing and who had tried to protect himself from a layoff by sticking to Kodak's core product: film. "It was this feeling that after 13 years, after always working hard -- I can't remember ever working only a 40-hour week -- I was out of a job."
 
Down From 60,000
 He is far from alone. The Kodak work force here in Monroe County has shrunk to 40,000, down from more than 60,000 people in the early 1980's. The company has announced its intention to cut another 10,000 jobs worldwide by the end of 1995, it is searching for a new chief executive officer and there has even been talk that it might move its headquarters from Rochester.
The only thing that people here say is certain is the inevitability of change.
"It's just a reality we have to live with," said the Monroe County Executive, Robert L. King.
Thomas T. Mooney, president of the Greater Rochester Metro Chamber of Commerce, said: "It's not just the downsizing but it's changes in the way Kodak produces things. It is highly unrealistic to think any company will get up to that level again in a community our size."
The most immediate concern is the impact that the cuts will have on consumer spending, both by people who have lost jobs and those uncertain whether their paychecks are secure.
"I think there will be a natural slowdown in consumer spending," Mr. Mooney said. "I think there will also be a natural rush of properties on the real estate market. Uncertainty is the biggest reason."
 
Drop in Sales Tax Income
 Mr. King said he was concerned that the county's sales tax income, which has already been lower than expected, will drop even more.
"The uncertainty over how big and how soon will cause everybody to be restrained in what they might do," Mr. King said.
Tony Agostinelli, vice president and director of advertising at Charlotte Appliance, said customers at his store's Labor Day sale seemed to be doing more comparison pricing than ever before.
"I noticed people seemed to be a lot more cautious," Mr. Agostinelli said.
"I have an advantage," he said. "If your refrigerator breaks down, you have to get another one. You may stay home more, but you're still going to watch television. Other industries that don't deal with the essentials are going to be hurt a lot more."
Some business owners are taking an aggressive approach.
John Holtz, a car dealer, has confronted the uncertainty head on. His advertising has been stressing that his dealership will work to develop payment plans buyers can live with.
"I'm not telling people anything they don't already know from the headlines," Mr. Holtz said. "Everybody in Rochester is well aware of the situation."
 
Jobs in Smaller Companies
 Many former Kodak employees have found jobs in smaller companies and the local unemployment rate has not risen above the statewide rate.
"We do have an ability to absorb a substantial number," Mr. Mooney said. "It's difficult to know how much we can absorb, but we do know the economy is very elastic."
Of course, many of these jobs provide paychecks much smaller than those from Kodak.
Mr. Assini, for example, saw his income fall from $40,000 a year while he was working for Kodak to just under $20,000, mostly his salary as a legislator.
"It hasn't been a picnic," he said.
Mr. Assini vows never to become so dependent upon a large company again. He has taken office space in a former motel to work as a travel agent while he looks for employment.
"If I get offered another job," he said, "I will not be left out in the cold because someone at the top made a bad decision."

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Proposes Free Bus-Subway Transfers for Commuters

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who have to take the bus to the subway have long cursed both geography and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which makes them pay for both trips.
Now, with ridership sagging, the M.T.A. has proposed something that will save commuters money, if not time: free transfers. 
 What the M.T.A. is calling for in its four-year business plan, to be presented to its financial committee tomorrow, would do away with so-called two-fare zones, meaning that riders would pay only one fare for both legs of their commute, the way a bus rider can now get a transfer ticket to head uptown after a crosstown trip.
If approved, the change would affect about 400,000 city residents, or 14 percent of the New York City Transit Authority's ridership, and would mark the biggest shift in fare policy since Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia united the three separate subway systems with a single nickel fare in 1940.
 
Good News in Sheepshead Bay
 "It's something that people in Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn and Queens Village and Williamsbridge in the Bronx have wanted for generations," said Gene Russianoff, a staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a transit riders' advocacy group. "If you were to go into my old neighborhood in Sheepshead Bay and ask people what they don't like about New York, on their top-five list would be that they live in a two-fare zone. It's up there with crime and lack of services."
The free transfers -- something the M.T.A. had resisted for years -- are being embraced by its chairman, Peter E. Stangl, as a way to increase ridership, which fell to 1.44 billion in 1992 from 1.56 billion in 1988, largely because of the recession.
"The issue is obviously one of satisfying customers, but it's also trying to provide the type of transportation that this region needs," Mr. Stangl said in an interview. "We need to increase our ridership and deal with the increasing problems of air quality and congestion that will ultimately determine whether this area remains a terrific place to be."
But it is uncertain whether the proposal will survive a vote by the board later this month, primarily because of concerns about cost. And even if the proposal passes, it will not be feasible until the new fare-card machines are installed throughout the bus and subway system, which is expected to take at least three years.
Nonetheless, city officials and commuters alike welcomed its inclusion in the business plan. "It reflects a new movement on behalf of the M.T.A., a dramatic step in the right direction," said Janette Sadik-Khan, the transportation adviser to Mayor David N. Dinkins. "This is something he's called for ever since he's been Mayor."
 
Now to Find the Money
 Last year's four-year business plan, which also anticipated the possibilities of automated fare collection, called for a 50 percent discount on the second leg of a combined bus-subway trip. Since then, the M.T.A. has conducted research indicating that such a discount would cost $50 million a year and increase ridership by only 0.4 percent. A free connection, however, while costing $89 million a year, would increase ridership by 3.2 percent.
The big question is money, and it is not clear how this proposal would be financed. The M.T.A. has already said that it will need some increase in the $1.25 fare for subways and buses in 1995. Whether that will be enough to finance the free transfers, or whether an infusion of state and city money would also be necessary, is unclear.
"The discussion of eliminating two-fare zones is a terrific thing because we're trying to encourage people to get out of their automobiles and use mass transit," said Lucius J. Riccio, the New York City Transportation Commissioner. "But you have to really consider the total economic package to make sure that we can do this and pay for it."
Mr. Riccio, one of four mayoral appointees to the M.T.A. board, raised the thorny issue of how income from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is distributed. Half the tolls collected by the Authority now go to the bus and subway system and the other half to the railroads. "The distribution of the T.B.T.A. tolls puts a lot of money into commuter rail, which runs surpluses, and not enough in the subway, which is in deficit," he said.
M.T.A. officials say that a fare-card system would prevent the abuse of a free connection. A fare card would be encoded with the time and location of a trip, and give a rider only a certain amount of time to get on a connecting subway from a bus.
A plan announced last year under the M.T.A.'s Fare Deal program to sell monthly passes for unlimited trips would also allow free transfers between buses and subways. But the current proposal goes beyond that and would apply to those who wanted to buy a week's worth of fare cards or a card for a single trip.

HEADLINE: Mideast Accord;
World Bank Says West Bank and Gaza Need Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The West Bank and Gaza Strip could face a long economic slide, with political tensions continuing to fester, unless they receive large-scale foreign aid and adopt sound economic policies, the World Bank warns in a new report.
Describing a grim situation of low per-capita income, sewage in the streets, interruptions in electricity and a contaminated water supply, the World Bank said the West Bank and Gaza urgently need at least $3 billion in aid over the next decade to improve schools and other services. 
 "The economy of the Occupied Territories is currently in turmoil," the report said. "Income levels have stagnated over the past decade; unemployment and underemployment are rising rapidly; public infrastructure and social services are grossly overstretched."
 
Report Hastily Completed
 The report, which was drafted over the past year and rushed to completion after the Israeli-P.L.O. mutual recognition, said the Palestinians' economy is at a crossroads now that Israel is about to agree to limited self-rule in Gaza and the West Bank town of Jericho. Thanks to the Palestinians' high education levels and entrepreneurial flair, their economy could be poised to expand, the World Bank said, but it could just as soon deteriorate if the new Palestinian administration adopts poor policies and receives little aid.
An important factor helping to fuel tensions, the report said, is that the impoverished Palestinians live in such close proximity to Israel, which has a far higher standard of living.
In recent years, the territories' economic problems have been aggravated by the exclusion of many Palestinian workers from Israel as a result of attacks against Israelis and from the Persian Gulf states because of the P.L.O.'s support for Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. This drying up of job opportunities coupled with the fast population growth in the occupied territories could keep tensions high, the report said.
The World Bank undertook the report at the request of Israel, the Palestinians and other parties to the Middle East peace talks for a study to help guide the West Bank and Gaza to a stronger economy in the hope that this would help assure prosperity and peace among Arabs and Israelis.
 
Lack of Phones and Electricity
 The report said the economy in the occupied territories is in shambles because it has so little industry, its trade is so heavily dominated by Israel and its infrastructure is in such poor shape. There is just one phone for every 46 people and in the West Bank, just 80 of 400 villages even have telephone service. About 140 Palestinian villages have no electrical supply or a part-time supply, while a lack of waste-water treatment facilities means that sewage is often discharged into streams.
A major indication of the territories' economic weakness is that such a high percentage of its labor force works outside. Until Israel tightened entry as a result of the Palestinian uprising, almost 40 percent of the territories' labor force worked in Israel.
Industry accounts for just 8 percent of the territories' output, a percentage that is one-third the level of many African nations.

HEADLINE: Mideast Accord: New Calculations;
For Arab Lands, a Raft of Questions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
For decades, the Palestinian cause has been the most sacred in Arab politics, even if the relations between Arab countries and those Palestinians who sought refugee inside their borders were often strained and even violent.
In the 1970's, Palestinians became embroiled in rebellion and civil war in Jordan and later in Lebanon. More recently, Palestinian workers were the target of reprisal and expulsion in Kuwait and other Persian Gulf nations as a result of suspicions that they had conspired with Iraq in the 1991 gulf war. Today, fewer than 150,000 of a prewar population of about 400,000 Palestinians remain in Kuwait. 
 Now, with an accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization on limited self-rule in the Gaza Strip and in the West Bank town of Jericho, Arab governments and Palestinians alike have some new calculations to contemplate.
 
Three Million in Diaspora
 What happens, for example, if the accord does not provide room within the occupied territories for the 800,000 Palestinians who fled after the 1967 war, or the hundreds of thousands who left between 1948 and 1967? In all, there are an estimated three million in the Palestinian diaspora, the bulk of them still in the Middle East.
And with this and so much else still unclear, just how far should Arab countries go in offering political and economic support to the Palestinian experiment?
So far, the agreement has won the support of most Arab governments, who seem to have regarded it, pragmatically, as an investment in regional stability. But there are risks too.
"Already a lot of Arab countries are coming to face questions they never imagined considering before," a senior Egyptian Foreign Ministry official said. "In particular, if the agreement cannot absorb all those who left, these Arab governments must decide whether they will then be willing to integrate them into their own populations at last. From the beginning they have refused because the defining mythology until now was that someday the Arabs would win and everyone would go back."
 
U.S. Aid an Issue
 Even Egypt, despite its helping in brokering the agreement, concedes its anxieties. Since 1979, when it signed the Camp David accords, exchanging peace with Israel for the Sinai peninsula, Egypt has received $2 billion a year in American military and economic aid.
"We have to ask ourselves too: are we supporting an agreement that will be made at our own expense?" the official said. "We know the U.S. and other Western nations have limits on how much they put into the region, and there is no way we can be certain the same levels of economic assistance will continue in the future"
Among the wealthy oil-exporting nations of the Arab gulf, who have strengthened their strategic ties to the United States since the gulf war, the agreement has received initial approval.
Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Oman, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Qatar declared this week that they would support the agreement, even though they cut off aid to the P.L.O. and most contact with it when its chairman, Yasir Arafat, sided with Iraq in the gulf war.
Western diplomats in the region say the money to make the agreement work will be there when it is needed, but no one has spelled out what they will contribute.
 
In the Vanguard
 The gulf nations have always been in the political vanguard of the Palestinian cause, which burns with special intensity in Saudi Arabia because as the appointed guardian of Islam's holiest shrines it says it cannot accept Israeli control of Jerusalem.
But while the sparsely populated gulf countries have also relied on Palestinian workers imported from elsewhere in the Middle East to help staff their offices and schools, they have regarded them as aliens and refused them permanent settlement.
According to the agreement, the refugee issue could be raised in negotiations on the final status of the occupied territories, which will begin two years after self-rule. Until then, the matter remains unclear.
Abed Rabbo, a P.L.O. official, said last week that the accord would allow all 800,000 refugees who left after 1967 to return. But Israel's Deputy Defense Minister, Mordechai Gur, said Israel would not allow it, denying any Palestinian right of return.
It is in Syria, Jordan and Lebanon that the resettlement question is most sharply drawn, as most of the Palestinians who fled after the 1967 war live there, many still in refugee camps.
 
Reassured, King Says
 King Hussein of Jordan, who has fully supported the agreement, said he was reassured that Jordan would be fully consulted on all matters that concerned it directly, including the question of what will happen to those who fled after the 1967 war.
After the war, Israel occupied an area of the West Bank of the Jordan River that had been under Jordanian authority. Many of those who fled resettled in Jordan, where they now hold Jordanian passports and make up an estimated 60 percent of Jordan's 2.5 million people.
The harshest debate over resettlement has been in Lebanon, which was torn by civil war in the 1970's, when armed Palestinian commandos sided with Muslims, upsetting the careful balance that divided power in the country among Christian and Muslim groups.
So far, the Lebanese have kept a wary distance from the accords, although they said they would do nothing to block them. On Friday, a member of the Lebanese Cabinet declared that no matter what happened, none of the more than 350,000 refugees still in Lebanon would be allowed to settle there.
 
Syrian Support Grudging
 "What lies after Gaza-Jericho?" Foreign Minister Faris Bouez asked last week, giving voice to the question being asked in every Arab capital.
Syria has also given the Israeli-P.L.O. agreement only grudging support, It is home to some 300,000 refugees, including the most militant Palestinian organizations opposed to the accords. President Hafez el-Assad told Mr. Arafat he should do what he believed was best for the Palestinians.
Both Lebanon and Syria are conducting separate negotiations with Israel under the auspices of the formal Middle East peace talks. The 11th round of talks just ended in Washington.

HEADLINE: Germany Finds That Spies Are Still Doing Business

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Fair game for Communist spies during the cold war, Germany has not let down its counterespionage defenses since the collapse of Communism in Europe. German counterspies have caught more agents in the last three years than during most of the time East Germany and the Soviet Union existed, the authorities say.
"The Federal Republic of Germany remains one of the primary targets for foreign intelligence services," said the annual report issued late last month by its domestic security and counterintelligence service. "Simply because of its economic strength and its scientific-technical resources, it offers plenty of opportunities for espionage activities." 
 This week, the counterespionage authorities let it be known that they were hot on the trail of about 30 high-ranking diplomats and career Government employees who had spied for Communist East Germany.
 
Second-Oldest Profession
 Communism came in 1917 and went between 1989 and 1991, but spying -- the world's second-oldest profession, according to the novelist John le Carre -- goes on. Both Russia and Poland have kept open fully staffed spy "residencies" in their embassies and consulates in Germany, the report says, although Russia and Germany now consider each other friends and Poland is clamoring to join NATO. (The report says nothing about whether the United States, France or any other country allied with Germany is spying on it, but it is common knowledge that friends do spy on one another.)
 
Economics the Priority
 Getting an economic edge over their Western competitors, particularly in the international arms trade still so important to many Eastern European countries, is apparently the main reason for cloak-and-dagger activities these days.
But some countries -- particularly from the developing world -- also use secret services to settle political scores with their enemies on German soil. Four Iranian Kurdish leaders were assassinated in Berlin last September, possibly by Iranian intelligence operatives, the Germans believe.
Romania and Bulgaria are still busy gathering political, economic and especially scientific and technological secrets by means both fair and foul, according to the German spy-catchers, and Iran succeeded in infiltrating two intelligence agents, both Iraqis, into Bonn's Federal Press and Information office until they were arrested in the spring of last year.
Almost three years after disappearing into the dust bin of history, East Germany is still keeping Bonn's counterintelligence service fully employed catching up with moles and former agents whose covers are being blown by the discovery of their names in the files of what used to be the State Security Ministry in Berlin.
Last year, the agency -- whose full name is the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, based in Cologne -- conducted 1,737 investigations into suspected treason or other intelligence activities, and arrested 56 suspected spies, including 38 from the former East Germany, one from Poland and one from Iran. Prosecutors convicted 22 people.
The agency said it had opened investigations on more than 2,200 so-called "traces," former East German agents mentioned in files inherited from the old Ministry for State Security. These files have enabled the agency to catch agents it could not track down during the cold war. So far, 972 have been identified through the files, the agency said, and the end is not yet in sight.
"The removal of the threat from world Communism has not made the domestic security service superfluous," said Interior Minister Manfred Kanther.
 
'Never Had So Much Work'
 Sounding like a man defending his agency's budget, which has remained roughly constant over the last two years despite staff cuts, one of his officials said, "The counterespionage division has never had so much work as it does today."
Bonn's security services have never been so shrouded in official secrecy as Britain's. In fact, the reverse was true; they were so open that the standing joke in the 1970's was that they leaked like a sieve. One head of the counterespionage service, Hansjoachim Tiedge, defected to East Germany in 1985.
After the Berlin wall came down in 1989, the federal office in Cologne was reduced from 2,500 people to about 2,200, but the reductions were suspended in 1992 as the threat of violence from right-wing militants grew. A spokesman said the counterespionage division, whose size has never been disclosed, had shrunk while the sections responsible for investigating militant groups had absorbed a greater share of the agency's $139.4 million budget in recent years.
The counterspies have been busy. This summer, investigators arrested Rainer Rupp, a high-ranking member of the German mission to NATO, and charged him and his wife with having supplied the Communists with top-secret alliance documents for many years.
Investigators also questioned Karl Wienand, a former opposition Social Democratic leader in Parliament, and Wolfgang Luder, a Free Democratic legislator from Berlin, but later cleared both men of suspicion of having been East German agents.
 
Markus Wolf on Trial
 Markus Wolf, who headed the East German foreign intelligence service until 1986, has been on trial in Dusseldorf since May on charges of treason and bribery. Bonn's counterspies are still worried about some of his legacies, particularly informants his agents tricked into thinking they were working for German industry or a "friendly" intelligence service.
One such case, of a German woman who worked for the United States military, was recruited this way by being misled into thinking she was actually supplying Dutch intelligence with information.
Her control officer went to work for the Soviet K.G.B. after East Germany vanished, and she kept supplying him with information for the Dutch until she was stopped in the spring of 1992, after the Soviet Union had broken up.
"Agents recruited and run under 'foreign colors' this way could be taken over by the K.G.B. relatively simply," the German agency said.
 
Four Agencies Succeed K.G.B.
 The K.G.B. was dismantled after the country it served went out of existence at the end of 1991, but Russia now has four separate intelligence-gathering services, and judging by Bonn's experience they are still up to many of the K.G.B.'s old tricks.
"Illegals" -- spies who do not work out of embassies but run networks of agents under cover and, often, false identities -- still find Germany a magnet, but some of the Russian ones operate with all the subtlety shown by Boris and Natasha in the old Bullwinkle cartoons.
The agency's report said that on April 23 of last year, for instance, a man and a woman, claiming to be named John David A. and Elizabeth Anne G. and born British, emerged from an Aeroflot plane in Helsinki, Finland, where the authorities became suspicious because both ostensible Anglo-Saxons had heavy Eastern European accents. They also were carrying $30,000 in cash, a modified short-range radio receiver, and materials used for writing coded messages.
After questioning, the pair finally admitted to being not Britons but Russians, and Finnish officials expelled them to Russia.
"All the circumstances indicate the two were either going on assignment for a foreign intelligence service as 'illegals' or were on their way back from a consultation in Moscow," the report said. "Articles in their luggage that were made in Germany strongly indicated that this could have been their operational area."
 
Spy Gets Suspended Term
 Stephen Laufer, a German citizen who was working as press officer for the United States Mission in Berlin, was arrested as a spy for the K.G.B. in 1991 and was convicted and given an 18-month suspended sentence last year. The German agency said Mr. Laufer, who now reportedly lives and works in South Africa, had asked his Russian control officer to let him fade into the woodwork after the Berlin wall fell in late 1989. But he did not turn himself in to the German authorities; they had to catch him.
Most present-day Russian intelligence activity against the Germans is concentrated on prying out industrial and economic secrets, with a special division of the main Russian service run by Yevgeny Primakov dedicated exclusively to collecting information on economic conditions and developments in Germany, the United States and other leading industrial countries.
"Western companies, banks, think tanks and economic journals enjoy the status of top priority targets," the German counterintelligence agency reported, adding that the aim was to acquire information that could be used to modernize Russian enterprises and improve their ability to compete on world markets.
"It has been observed that since 1991, numerous Russian intelligence officers assigned to Germany have 'left' the service and tried to establish themselves in private enterprise in Russia or in Germany," the German report said. "It can be assumed that not all of these persons have broken with their former employer."
 
Spy Chief Interviewed
 Mr. Primakov, the agency noted, had even acknowledged his service's new priorities in an interview with The Sunday Times of London last September. In the interview, he announced that Russia was cutting back intelligence activities in Africa and the Far East.
Mr. Kanther said the Russian services had reduced their "legal" agents in consulates and the embassy here by about a third during the last year. But those that remain are still believed to be working hard.
"Both services are continuing their intelligence work in the classic fields of espionage -- politics, science and technology, the economy and the military," the annual report said. "But the readiness to take operational risks that was observed in earlier years has diminished markedly."
Many Germans, the counterintelligence agency warned, were under the impression that all Russians were their friends now. Sounding wistful for the days when everybody knew that loose lips could sink ships, the counterspy service reported, "In contacts with official Russians there is a growing tendency to be frank and ready to disregard the still-appropriate need for caution in communicating information."
