HEADLINE: Why the Cars In Japan Look Just Like New

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
One of the first things an American motorist might notice about Japan is that the automobiles here all seem so shiny and new, without smashed headlights, dents, rust or even dirt.
The reason is only partly that Japanese fastidiousness extends to the maintenance of cars. Rather, experts say, there really are relatively few old cars in Japan, because of an automobile inspection system that is so onerous and expensive that many people prefer to trade in a perfectly good three- or five-year-old car rather than spend hundreds or even thousands of dollars for the inspection. 
 The inspection system, critics say, is a case study of the regulations in Japan that benefit businesses at the expense of hard-pressed consumers. It is the type of regulation that Japan's new Government is promising to relax as part of a major effort to improve living conditions.
 
Consumer Group Complains
 "The people who profit from this are maintenance shops and car makers," said Fumio Matsuda, head of the Japan Automobile Consumers Union.
Japan's 83,000 garages obtain 44 percent of their roughly $60 billion in annual revenues as a result of mandatory inspections. Automobile companies benefit because people replace their cars frequently.
Inspections are required when a car turns 3 years old, then every 2 years until the car turns 11, then every year. The inspections, which cover more than 100 items from brake function to headlight orientation, are done by a Government test center or by an authorized service station.
Other nations and many states in the United States also require inspections, either of emissions alone or also of the car's functioning, but Japan also requires car owners to have certain items checked or serviced every 6 months, 12 months or 24 months.
Another big difference is that Japan's Government asks the owner to have the car repaired before it is inspected, so that it will pass. Faced with this requirement, most owners give their car to the dealer or a service station to prepare it for inspection.
"You take it to the garage and they will just change everything, even if there is nothing wrong with the car," Kenichi Ohmae, organizer of Heisei Reform, a movement that advocates less Government control over Japan's economy. said. "If they keep fiddling with the car, there are more problems after the inspection."
 
Inspection Itself Costs $12
 A typical bill for this pre-inspection inspection is $600. The actual inspection at a test center costs only about $12.
Government officials defend the inspection system as necessary to keep traffic flowing. In Japan, where congestion is horrendous and highways often have only two lanes in each direction, a vehicle breakdown is far more disruptive than in the spacious United States, they say.
"Inspection actually contributes to the situation where most of our automobiles run in good condition," said Takashi Shimodaira, director of the maintenance service division of the Transport Ministry.
He said that only 1 in 2,000 car accidents in Japan were caused by mechanical failure, compared with between 1 in 200 and 1 in 20 in the United States and Europe.
In the United States, 64.1 percent of passenger cars in 1991 were at least five years old. In Japan, only 46.8 percent were. In the United States, 30.5 percent of cars were at least 10 years old, versus 9.6 percent in Japan.
With little demand for used cars, cars here lose their value quickly. "A car more than six years old and in very good condition you can easily see in a junkyard," said Hiroshige Hanabusa, who makes a living helping people with the administrative chores associated with their cars.
Many of the used cars find their way to other nations, where they are considered bargains. In New Zealand, used Japanese cars are cutting so heavily into sales of new cars that auto dealers and assemblers have complained to the Government. And Russians can't get enough of old Japanese cars.
 
Taking Cars Home to Moscow
 Last year, when a Russian circus returned to Moscow after a tour of Japan, 93 animals, including bears, leopards and parrots, were abandoned on the dock at Yokohama. There was no room for them because the ship was full of used cars bought by the crew.
In June an advisory committee to the Transport Ministry recommended several changes to the inspection system to be carried out in the next two years.
The periodic 6-month checks would be abolished and the number of items in the 12 and 24-month checks would be reduced. Cars more than 11 years old would need inspection every 2 years, instead of every year. And consumers would have the option of going for their inspection first and then doing the maintenance found to be necessary.
Even without the committee's plan, things are changing. The recession is causing Japanese consumers to hold on to cars longer. And a growing number of people, though still only 1 percent of the car owners, are doing the pre-inspection inspections themselves rather than take their car to a garage.
"I started checking the items one month ago, so I did it gradually," said Toyokazu Yamada, who had just run his Toyota pickup through the Government testing center in Tokyo.
The inspection showed his brakes to be a little loose, and he was told to have them repaired and come back. He left, drove around, came back and entered a different lane. This time, he passed.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Whitman Calls a Florio Plan 'Right-Wing'

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
It is as though the two major candidates for governor followed Alice down the rabbit hole.
Even by the frequently wild swings of New Jersey politics, the first week of all-out campaigning by Gov. Jim Florio and Christine Todd Whitman was topsy-turvy. It began with the candidates clashing over guns, legal threats and the First Amendment. It ended with an angry debate over welfare that presented a curious role reversal: Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, accused Mr. Florio of "extreme right-wing radicalism" and Mr. Florio, a Democrat, staunchly defended sweeping new regulations on welfare recipients. 
 With the election barely seven weeks away, each candidate began the revved-up, post-Labor Day phase of the campaign slamming the other while prospecting for issues to lure the sizable bloc of middle-income voters who are believed to be still undecided and who control the outcome of the race.
As the last weeks of the campaign unfold, the driving issues for Mrs. Whitman continue to be her now-familiar attacks on a bitter tax increase and a sour economy, both of which she attributes to the Governor.
The strategy for Mr. Florio is largely unchanged, too: Find anything to distract voter attention from the record $2.8 billion tax increase he orchestrated three years ago, and keep Mrs. Whitman's campaign off-stride.
For Mr. Florio, the issues of the moment are welfare and guns, the two points on which he is most highly regarded in the polls, although it is unclear just how big an impact either is having with the electorate.
Following up on a year-old state welfare reform program that he has championed as a national model, Mr. Florio on Thursday proposed further reforms, including requiring mothers to provide the name of the father and other information about him for the child to be eligible for welfare benefits. The timing of Mr. Florio's announcement and his recent calls for preservation of the state's mandatory sentencing laws are both seen as efforts to court middle-class voters.
 
'Demeaning and Degrading'
 But Mrs. Whitman immediately fired a broadside at the Florio welfare plan, accusing the Governor of political pandering.
"The Governor is playing to the most vicious stereotype of a welfare recipient in the most demeaning and degrading way possible," Mrs. Whitman said. "What is the Governor's next idea in his headlong rush to embrace extreme right-wing radicalism? A program of tattoos for welfare mothers? A badge sewn on to their clothing identifying them as welfare recipients? Creation of colonies, like leper colonies, where welfare recipients would be forced to live? How about an involuntary re-location program into camps?"
On Friday a stern-faced and testy Mr. Florio called a news conference to respond to Mrs. Whitman's attack and to breathe another day of life into the story.
"I am disturbed that Mrs. Whitman would react to this by firing off such a knee-jerk, intemperate statement before she even had a chance to study my proposals," the Governor said.
"And it insults the victims of the Holocaust to make allusions to Nazi Germany in the context of welfare reform that brings families together and makes parents meet their obligations to their children."
 
Warning on N.R.A. Ads
 Days before welfare ballooned into an issue, Mr. Florio set the pace for the final weeks of campaigning with a two-pronged attack. One prong was a television ad that tried to link Mrs. Whitman to the National Rifle Association's efforts earlier this year to overturn New Jersey's ban on semiautomatic weapons. The other was a bit of legal maneuvering intended to disrupt an N.R.A. campaign against the Governor.
The legal maneuvering began with a letter that the Florio campaign sent to all commercial television stations in New Jersey, New York City and Philadelphia and all New Jersey radio stations. Citing a slew of court cases and Federal Communications Commission regulations, the letter warned the broadcasters against accepting from the National Rifle Association or its affiliates or front groups "distorting ads designed to smear Governor Florio."
"We warn you that the N.R.A. or its agents may misrepresent or distort the issues in an attempt to mislead the public about Governor Florio's records and positions," said the letter, which was signed by the chief counsel for the campaign, Angelo J. Genova. "We appeal to your best editorial judgment as well as your interest in providing the voting public with accurate and truthful information about issues of concern to them, and urge you not to accept these commercials."
Mrs. Whitman demanded that Mr. Florio disavow the letter "or admit publicly that he thinks the First Amendment to the Constitution was written in disappearing ink."
"The Governor apparently feels very strongly, to the point of threatening legal action and broadcast license challenges, that his record shouldn't be criticized or that he shouldn't be called to account for it," Mrs. Whitman said.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Dinkins Safe in Primary, But Not in November

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's certain victory in the Democratic primary on Tuesday reveals a paradox of black New Yorkers' political power: His race has helped him stave off any real challenge to renomination, but it remains one of his greatest vulnerabilities as he fights to avoid becoming the first black mayor of a major American city to be defeated in his quest for a second term.
The demographics of the city's Democratic primary electorate -- in which blacks account for about one-third of the vote and a candidate needs just 40 percent of the total vote to avoid a runoff -- drove away otherwise serious contenders, who could not hope to crack Mr. Dinkins's base despite his rocky term. He is left facing a negligible challenge from two political gadflies, one of whom happens to be black, the other Hispanic. 
 But that very strength among black Democrats counts for much less among the general electorate because no single ethnic or racial group predominates . And even though registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by 5 to 1, whites showed their willingness to defect in droves four years ago, leaving Mr. Dinkins with not quite 30 percent of the white vote (which was still a national record for a first-time black victor in a racially diverse city).
In short, historians and political analysts agree, this election could prove to be just as great a transitional moment in the city's coalition politics as Mr. Dinkins's victory in becoming the first black mayor. Polls show that Rudolph W. Giuliani has peeled away some of the liberal white and Hispanic voters who helped make the Mayor's two-point margin of victory. Black population growth is declining in relation to waves of new Asian and Hispanic immigrants, many of whom are not yet citizens or registered to vote. All of this could eventually lead to an environment of shifting coalitions, whether Mr. Dinkins wins or loses this year.
 
Iffy Alliances
 "What happened in '89 was in some respects premature, reflecting more the Democratic primary electorate than the electorate as a whole," said Chris McNickle, the author of the current book "To Be Mayor of New York" (Columbia University Press), a study of the changing ethnic alliances of the last 50 years. "In the Democratic electorate, a black candidate has a terrific base of support, but in the city as a whole, the electorate is still quite evenly split."
Of course, any incumbent has a presumed advantage in winning his party's renomination. But the last Mayor to face a term as tempestuous as Mr. Dinkins's, Abraham D. Beame in the mid-1970's, fell to a crowded field of challengers. Mr. Dinkins won the nomination four years ago on the strength of sentiment against Edward I. Koch, who had come to be seen as racially divisive, and he began the campaign for the general election in November well ahead of Mr. Giuliani in the polls, borne on by his promise of racial healing.
But his coalition was always wispy, connected more by a general sense of hope than by clearly defined and shared priorities, and the Mayor has had big trouble consolidating that coalition in office. Polls show that a clear plurality of New Yorkers believes that Mr. Dinkins has not managed to make much of a difference in race relations, and that a bare majority now believes that any mayor could, compared with nearly 6 in 10 surveyed four years ago.
"It was an alliance based on the good will of whites and Hispanics, but it was held together with spit and toothpicks," said Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College and the author of "Two Nations: Black and White, Separate, Hostile and Unequal" (Scribner's, 1992). "It was so iffy, and clearly in the last four years that alliance didn't become any stronger."
 
Promise Unfulfilled
 Mr. Dinkins's race has always been a distinctly double-edged sword. Four years ago, he won in no small measure by appealing to whites' sense that it was time for a black candidate, and also to a pragmatic sense that a black mayor might be specially equipped to deal with racial tensions, while Mr. Giuliani was often seen as a candidate of white resentment.
"People liked Dinkins precisely because of his nonracial appeal, somebody who was black and showed us that this city was big enough to elect a black Mayor, and yet doesn't go around saying, 'We've got power' and 'In your face,' " said Thomas H. Kessner, a history professor at the City University of New York. "That was a great deal of his promise, and now much of the opposition to his candidacy is the feeling that that has not worked out."
Mr. Giuliani has worked to soften his hard-edged image and to couch the election as a referendum on competence and management of the city, to convince skeptical liberal voters that they can comfortably vote against the Mayor on the basis of his record in office and not his race.
That rankles many of the Mayor's supporters, who argue that he has managed to hold the city together in the face of a deep recession, and that if he were white, his re-election would be all but certain, given his party's advantage.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, one of the Mayor's oldest friends, gave voice to that sentiment last week when he said that "Giuliani's best asset is that he is white and not an incumbent," and noted the statistical reality of white voters' reluctance to support black candidates.
The Giuliani camp immediately complained that Mr. Rangel's statements were racist, and Mr. Giuliani himself called them "desperate." The Mayor hastened to say that he disagreed with Mr. Rangel and that he would do better among white voters than his doubters expected, but several of the Mayor's aides said Mr. Rangel had simply stated an unpalatable truth.
 
Competing for Rewards
 One reason many of Mr. Dinkins's supporters, especially among blacks, care so deeply about his success is that the potential for succession should he lose is unclear. There is no well-developed group of second-generation black politicians waiting in the wings, and there are strong obstacles to overcoming schisms between blacks and such vital elements of Mr. Dinkins's coalition as Jewish and Hispanic voters.
Mr. McNickle, the mayoral historian, contrasts the fragile entente between the competing interests of black and Hispanic voters with the alliance of interests between Jews and the Irish that long prevailed in the city's Democratic politics. While Jewish voters traditionally wanted protection from anti-Semitism, safeguards against corruption and expansive social programs, Irish politicians were driven more by social ascendancy, patronage jobs and the prestige of office.
Now, Mr. McNickle said, black and Hispanic New Yorkers both want the same basic political rewards: the prestige of office, jobs for their communities and social services in the face of dwindling economic resources.
None of this is easy for the Mayor's campaign to voice openly, but in the end, the same appeal to fairness that helped elect him may remain a potent tool, as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo elliptically suggested last week.
 
Blaming the Record
 Four years ago, Mr. Cuomo predicted that the primary would be won by the candidate who could bring the city together. After marching in the Labor Day parade on Monday, he said that he was not sure what the defining rationale would be this time, but that Mr. Dinkins deserved to win because of his record and because Mr. Giuliani had failed to present any compelling alternative programs.
"I was asked recently, 'Why do so many of the Democrats in Queens County, your borough, Mario -- and a lot of them white Democrats -- why are they polling that they're for Giuliani?' " Mr. Cuomo said. "Now this is a touchy question. People don't like questions like that. I don't like them, but it's a vital question. And I said, 'That's not the real question.' The real question is why were they against Dinkins in '89?"
This year, Mr. Cuomo went on, voters can say they do not like the Mayor's record, that they gave him a chance and things did not work out.
"But what happened in '89?" the Governor repeated. "Why didn't we vote for him in '89? That's a troublesome question for me."
Typically, Mr. Cuomo did not answer his own question, but his meaning was clear.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
13,800 Masochists See Mets Fall Again

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
Plans for future expansion? Crowds of 60,000 a game at Mile High Stadium? The decision to add an extra round of playoffs as of the 1994 season? Title races in three of the four divisions?
Want perhaps the single greatest evidence that, whatever the cries of poverty from the owners and cries of everything else from the players union, the baseball industry is safe from economic peril? 
 Here it is: 13,800 people showed up at Shea Stadium yesterday.
Why ask why? Because one has to. Why come? Why stay? The Mets began the afternoon 40 games out of first place. Dwight Gooden is hurt and probably won't pitch again in 1993. Bobby Bonilla is done. Even Anthony Young, the loser in yesterday's 4-3 loss to the Cubs, has to have lost his attraction as a phenomenon of failure.
 
It's Boo Franco Day
 Why?
The reasonable answer for the fact that anyone came is the reasonably fresh air available at the stadium.
The cynical response is that there was a promotion in place for kids to run the bases at Shea after the game.
The difficult-to-ignore possibility was that many of the 13,800 came waiting for the chance to boo John Franco, which they did with striking vehemence in the ninth inning.
The hardest-to-fathom answer is that the crowd came to see the Mets.
"Typical," Manager Dallas Green said of the defeat.
Here, in succinct summation, are the familiar specifics. Young had mistakes made behind him and committed sins of his own as he allowed four runs in five innings of work to fall to 1-16 for the season. The Mets, 18-54 at the day's start in games decided by one or two runs, wound up 18-55.
"We could have won last night's game, we could have won today's," said Green. "We just don't do it. We get to the edge of the precipice and never go over."
The metaphor seemed a bit misguided. The Mets, it certainly can be argued with greater literalness, went over the edge and into the abyss long ago. It's climbing back onto the edge that the Mets can't seem to do.
And so the 13,800 yesterday at Shea were left to ponder all sorts of calamitous calculations as they prepared to run the bases afterward. Could Randy Myers, who gained his 44th save with a scoreless ninth for the Cubs, wind up with more saves than the Mets will victories (the club is stuck on 47)? Will the Mets, with 95 defeats, lose 100 games for the first time since 1967? Will the Mets, who have lost eight straight and have the Phillies and Braves coming up next, ever win again this season?
 
And Franco Responds
 Can the Mets soon be eliminated from contention for sixth place in the National League East? Will Sid Fernandez, who retires from his matches faster than Natalya Zvereva these days, go more than five innings Sunday against the Cubs? Can it really be that the rotation breaks down so that, if the Mets continue to lose, Young is the scheduled starter for what would be their 100th defeat?
"There wasn't much to keep the faith in as it was," said Green.
Evidently, Shea has lost all faith in Franco. The closer, who has been hurt or ordinary or awful for three seasons, lost three straight games last week and came into yesterday's contest serenaded by tons of boos.
"I don't care," said Franco. "Doesn't bother me. You deserve it when you don't perform. They are entitled."
Franco then felt entitled to return some of the bitterness in kind.
"You lose three games, you get booed," he said. "You lose 27, you get cheered."
The allusion, of course, was to Young, who set a major league record with 27 straight defeats earlier this season. Young certainly was never in position to win yesterday. He yielded a run in the first. He then was sabotaged by a Jeff Kent error, a pair of singles, a sacrifice fly and a bomb of a run-scoring double by Mark Grace in the fifth. Young then hurt his thumb falling while covering first to end the inning, and he was pulled for a pinch-hitter in the bottom of the fifth.
"We made mistakes," said Green. "And A. Y. wasn't able to get through the inning with the mistakes."
The season has been a mistake from its outset. But the attendance was no mistake.

 
 
INSIDE PITCH
 Manager DALLAS GREEN's description of DWIGHT GOODEN's recovery from shoulder trouble seemed to hint that the right-hander would not return in 1993. "They are not real happy with what's going on," Green said of the club's medical personnel. "It hasn't responded real good." Gooden had hoped to throw off the mound today. That plan has been killed. . . . EDDIE MURRAY's two-run homer in the sixth was the 438th of his career and he is now four runs batted in behind TONY PEREZ for 17th place on the career list.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mets catcher Todd Hundley confers with pitcher Anthony Young, whose record fell to 1-16 yesterday. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Health Care: A Historic Journey

 BODY:
Humane. Visionary. Complex. Overreaching. Those are just a few of the adjectives that leap to mind when plowing through President Clinton's 250-page health care plan that was leaked to the press by members of Congress a week before the President was to unveil its contents. There will be plenty of time over the next few weeks to scrutinize the details. But this is the moment to savor the noble ambitions of this plan and to ponder the politics and history of the moment.
The Administration's overriding goal is that no American will ever go to bed at night fearing that medical catastrophe will lead to financial ruin. Every Republican and Democrat in Congress ought to reflect on the need for a bipartisan commitment to this goal. If President Truman's plan for universal care or President Nixon's effort to create national health insurance had passed, the country would almost certainly be healthier today, both physically and economically. 
 With the release of the entire plan, some tentative answers are now possible to basic consumer questions about coverage and costs to individuals. All residents will be required to buy a basic benefits package that would be more generous than most private policies. It would cover hospital and physician services, preventive care, pharmaceuticals, dental care for children and a limited amount of mental health benefits.
For the uninsured and underinsured, the plan is a big plus. But it also provides something valuable to the insured: peace of mind about chronic illness and loss of coverage. For the poor, who have little choice now, health cooperatives will provide a larger set of choices. But to many middle-class families, the choice of doctors, especially specialists, would be diminished. Doctors too will find themselves more closely supervised, if not salaried, by health plans. In other words, Mr. Clinton proposes to change not only the economics but the sociology of health care in America.
That will -- and should -- bring furious debate in the days ahead. But the most obvious immediate problem is that Mr. Clinton has decided to mask the cost, pretending -- against the counsel of several of his financial advisers -- that the $700 billion program can be paid for without a major tax hike. That decision, in turn, forced him to clamp down hard on Medicare and Medicaid and to limit the rate of growth of private insurance premiums. If these clamps are applied too hard, the Administration will do harm to the quality of care as providers respond by rationing access or cutting treatment corners.
Rationing, consumer choice, quality of care, cost -- these will be the buzzwords of the autumn debate. The public portion of that debate begins months later than we would have liked. Even so, Mr. Clinton deserves credit for starting the country again on a journey too long delayed.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Mr. Perot Attacks Nafta

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
Ross Perot's book attacking the North America Free Trade Agreement is an inept diatribe that misstates facts, misleads readers and misunderstands trade. "Save Your Jobs, Save Our Country," written with economist Pat Choate, piles one tendentious assertion atop another.
Serious-minded people can disagree about the wisdom of Nafta, which would phase out trade barriers among the U.S., Mexico and Canada. And those who like Nafta can disagree over President Clinton's efforts to muscle it through Congress when his health care reform hangs in the balance. But Mr. Perot's writing isn't a fair sifting of pros and cons. He ominously asserts, by ignoring evidence to the contrary, that Nafta will "pit American and Mexican workers in a race to the bottom." 
 Many economists don't like regional trade pacts because they discriminate against nonparticipants. Under Nafta, Mexican exporters would gain privileged access to the U.S., driving out exports from the Caribbean.
Yet there are good reasons for this pact. Neighbors like Mexico may warrant special consideration. Nafta's path-breaking provisions could serve as worthy precedents for future trade pacts. And Nafta would lock in Mexico's market reforms and encourage the rest of Latin America to follow suit. Careful studies also show that the agreement would have a positive, though minuscule, impact on U.S. living standards and give a small boost to the Mexican economy.
Sadly, Mr. Perot's book dismisses foreign policy implications and runs rough-shod over economics. Factual errors and misleading statements litter nearly every page. He correctly cites testimony by a former Cabinet official that Nafta would cost some Americans their jobs, but he conveniently forgets to mention that she testified that Nafta would create more jobs than it would eliminate. The authors estimate that Nafta would threaten 6 million American jobs, but their calculations ludicrously assume that high-wage jobs in industries like aerospace could lose out to low-paid Mexicans.
The accord would, Mr. Perot warns, open U.S. borders to unsafe Mexican trucks. But Mexican truckers would have to obey every U.S. safety regulation. He claims Nafta would allow Mexico to challenge U.S. environmental regulations as unfair trade barriers. But he conveniently forgets to say that for Mexico to win, it would have to prove that the regulations lacked any scientific merit and unfairly blocked Mexican exports.
Mr. Perot's book makes a muddle of economics. Using bogus measures, it alleges that low wages give Mexican employers an unfair advantage. But if that were true, U.S. employers would be racing to relocate even without Nafta. And if low wages are the villain, why does America's fiercest competition come from high-wage Germany and Japan? Low Mexican wages largely reflect low productivity and don't serve as a huge magnet for American employers.
Mr. Perot ignores the fact that Nafta knocks down Mexican tariffs a lot and U.S. tariffs -- which are already low -- only a little. That's no threat to most American employers. Under Nafta, numerous industries from agriculture to insurance will export more to the newly opened Mexican market.
However, Nafta will force some U.S. firms to close. That's the process by which each country will specialize in what it produces best -- the key to lifting living standards. But Mr. Perot hysterically exaggerates the negatives. Studies predict that Nafta will add only a little to the tens of millions of Americans who will lose their jobs over the next decade for reasons unrelated to Nafta.
After weighing the pros and cons, I expect Nafta will prove a plus for the U.S. But critics cite reasonable grounds for reaching the opposite conclusion. They denounce doing deals with a Government that they regard as politically oppressive and that can't be trusted to enforce its labor and environmental laws. And they don't trust Washington to help out dislocated workers.
Serious people can disagree. But Mr. Perot's sweeping denunciation is not a serious analysis.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: In America;
On Spelling Kat

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
So now we find that a whole lot of us can't spell kat, or read a bus map, or add two and two on a kalculator.
Apparently there are even people who don't read newspaper columns. 
 The nation's reading and math skills are in sorry shape, according to a four-year study released by the U.S. Department of Education.
As if that weren't bad enough, most of the people who are poor at readin,' writin' and kalculatin' have deluded themselves into thinking they are good at it, or even very good.
I handed a map to a man the other day and asked if he could determine the approximate distance between Kansas and New York. He said yes, he could. After studying the map for a moment, he confidently announced, "About 4,000 miles."
I don't think there are 4,000 miles between here and Oz. I asked the man how he had come up with that answer. He threw me an annoyed look and snapped, "Just trying to help you out, pal."
The study found that some 40 million Americans are incapable of handling anything more complex than signing their names or reading the expiration date on a driver's license. Many of them fake it when looking at a menu in a restaurant.
Twenty percent of those who scored worst were high school graduates. That means an awful lot of fraud went on in an awful lot of schools. What happened to the idea that if you get a diploma you ought to be able to read it?
The study was a gauge of adult proficiency. So it's logical to wonder what's happening now in the public schools, which should be busily shaping the skills of a new generation of Americans.
It's not pretty.
There are many fine school systems in the United States. But there are others that are so farcically inept they look like they were designed by Laurel and Hardy and run by the Three Stooges.
These, of course, are the systems with the youngsters most desperately in need of help.
In New York and Chicago, officials haven't even been able to get the schools open. In Michigan, the property tax has been scrapped as the primary means of financing public schools, but the Legislature and the Governor haven't been able to come up with alternative financing. In Los Angeles, the schools are so short of qualified teachers that administrators are practically dragging substitutes in off the street.
These are not great ways to get the nation's literacy levels up.
Public schools were supposed to open in New York, the nation's largest system, on Sept. 9; and in Chicago, the third largest, on Sept. 8.
Neither city could meet the deadline.
In New York, school officials have been unable to determine for years whether the students are being exposed to dangerous levels of asbestos in the schools. Previous tests were found to have been incompetently and possibly fraudulently conducted. So a million kids remain out of classes while the schools are retested.
In Chicago, more than 400,000 students have been shut out of classrooms while teachers, school officials and state legislators argue over money. The school system has a budget deficit and so far the politicians and bureaucrats have been unable to close it.
Some schools are just plain dangerous. While Los Angeles managed to get its schools open, a 15-year-old boy was shot and wounded on the very first day when a gang fight broke out in an auditorium where students had lined up to enroll.
The shooting exasperated Sid Thompson, Superintendent of the nation's second-largest school district. "You can't secure this place with anything less than the 101st Airborne," he said. "It takes that many troops to cover it."
There are two main reasons for trying to overcome budget problems, gunfire and other obstacles in the way of improved literacy. One is to maintain the nation's economic vitality. The other is to provide citizens with as many opportunities as possible for personal fulfillment.
I thought about that on Friday when I asked a 16-year-old New Yorker if he understood why the schools were closed.
"Yeah," he said, " 'bestos."
I asked if he knew how to spell asbestos.
He said sure. "B-E-T-O-S."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Can't Just Do It

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
After reading Bill Keller's "Where Kids Don't Jump" (The Times, Aug. 28), my skepticism turned to dismay about the movement to introduce basketball as a model sport in South Africa's black townships. Keller wrote that the former National Basketball Association star Bob McAdoo was there "pushing basketball as an engine of black excellence and pride." 
 In addition, he quoted Dikembe Mutombo, of Zaire and now of the Denver Nuggets, as saying, "We did it in America, and they can do it here in South Africa."
Did what? While the outrageous salaries and endorsement contracts of a few N.B.A. stars are well-known, it's also widely recognized that opportunities for black youth in the United States have increased little if at all. The N.B.A. stands for an anomaly, not a model, and South Africa needs serious solutions, not pipe dreams.
I would feel more hopeful about the future of young South African blacks if the N.B.A. and other organizations instructed them that they have a better chance of achieving excellence, pride and economic growth through education than through slam dunks.
 
AMBY BURFOOT
Emmaus, Pa.
 
The author is the executive editor of Runner's World magazine.

HEADLINE: A New 10-Year Plan to Prevent Water Pollution

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
New York City will spend $750 million in the next 10 years to protect its reservoirs from pollution, Mayor David N. Dinkins has announced, as the city seeks to avoid a Federal requirement for a water filtration plant that would cost $5 billion.
Mr. Dinkins last week promised strict enforcement of new pollution rules for the 2,000-square-mile region upstate where the city gathers its water. 
 "It is absolutely asinine to let people pollute the water we're going to drink, and we're not going to have it," he said.
The program he laid out includes hundreds of millions of dollars to pay for improvement of sewage treatment plants owned by upstate towns and assistance for towns to develop planning and zoning standards.
 
A One-Year Exemption
 Nearly all big cities filter their water, a trend the Federal Government is trying to encourage. But New York City has argued that its water from upstate reservoirs is of such quality that it can meet Federal water-quality standards by taking steps to prevent the introduction of pollutants.
In January, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency gave New York City a one-year exemption from the filtration requirement, and the city is seeking a 10-year exemption.
The city's program was widely applauded by environmental organizations. But some, notably the Natural Resources Defense Council, have said the most important question is how well the city carries out the program.
Art imitated life in that detail on Thursday at an event at the South Street Seaport that was part campaign rally and part environmental celebration. The organizers raised a 180-foot-tall mural painted by Mike McNeilly, depicting the Statue of Liberty and a wave of clean water, on the wall of the 32-story New York Telephone building on Pearl Street in lower Manhattan facing the East River.
 
New Regulations
 A major part of New York City's effort to protect the water was to draft new regulations, the first since 1954, governing land development and water emissions near upstate reservoirs owned by the city. State law gives New York City the authority to do so, and city officials are now holding a series of public hearings upstate to receive comments on the new rules.
The rules cover everything from where new buildings or landfills may be situated to what materials may be spread on icy roads in winter. Some rules have drawn opposition from people upstate who fear that the rules will block economic development.
But the Mayor said the city's approach was "a conscious repetition of the confrontation of the past" between downstate and upstate interests.
The program announced last week is to be financed mostly with water and sewer charges for city residents. The spending has already been approved as part of various capital and operating budgets, but city officials said they had not previously been laid out as a comprehensive program.
 
Highlights of the Plan
 Among the most important elements are these:
*The city will buy 80,000 acres of environmentally sensitive land in the next seven years at a cost of $250 million to $270 million, including $47 million this year. In some cases, the city will buy "conservation easements," leaving the land in private hands but making a payment to forbid future development.
*The city's Environmental Protection Department will hire 500 to 600 people, from lab technicians to enforcement agents, and add laboratory capacity, at a cost of $250 million over 10 years.
*New York City will improve several upstate sewage treatment plants it owns, for $100 million to $150 million.
The city also plans to enter a "partnership" program with towns and cities in the watershed, to help them develop community planning standards and improve their sewage treatment plants, at a cost of $120 million.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 14, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about New York City's 10-year plan for protecting its drinking water quoted Mayor David N. Dinkins incorrectly about the city's contacts with communities in the watershed upstate. The Mayor said the city's approach was "a conscious rejection of the confrontation of the past" between downstate and upstate interests.

HEADLINE: VOTERS GUIDE;
Races By Borough

 BODY:

MANHATTAN
 
BOROUGH PRESIDENT
There is no primary. Ruth W. Messinger (D-L) is the incumbent.
1st COUNCIL DISTRICT
MARGARET S. CHIN (D) Director, Chinatown Center of La Guardia Community College; member of Community Board 1; a candidate for City Council in 1991.
KATHRYN E. FREED (D-L) City Council member elected in 1991; tenant lawyer and former counsel to New York State Assembly Consumer Affairs Committee.
JUDITH JOICE (D) Businesswoman; co-owner of the Lion's Head, a restaurant and bar on Christopher Street; member, Greenwich Village Chamber of Commerce; member, Mayor's Small Business Advisory Board; former member, Community Board 2.
THE CAMPAIGN: Lower Manhattan Democrats have a rematch from 1991, but with strategic realignments. Councilwoman Freed won a four-way race two years ago by nearly 1,000 votes. Ms. Chin, the runner-up, is renewing her bid to become the Council's first Asian-American member. But 1991's two other losing candidates support Ms. Freed, a veteran party official and legislative aide who won many endorsements from political clubs, unions and elected officials. Ms. Chin's base is Chinatown. Ms. Joice, the new entrant, draws support from Greenwich Village. All are spending heavily. In their Aug. 13 financial filings, Ms. Chin led with $63,910 raised to $45,913 for Ms. Fried and $39,371 for Ms. Joice.
2d COUNCIL DISTRICT
MIRIAM FRIEDLANDER (D) Former City Council member who served for 18 years until 1991; created and was chairwoman of the Council's Committee on Women.
SYLVIA M. FRIEDMAN (D) Housing policy analyst with the Department of Housing Preservation and Development; former teacher; member, Community Board 6; chairwoman, Housing and Homeless Committee, Community Board 6.
ANTONIO PAGAN (D-L) City Council member elected in 1991; former executive director of Coalition Housing, a nonprofit developer of low- and moderate-income housing; former member, Community Board 3.
THE CAMPAIGN: At the age of 79, Ms. Friedlander is fighting to regain her seat from Mr. Pagan. She was the only Council member to lose in the 1991 primary, by barely over 100 votes out of 12,000 cast in the ethnic and political cauldron of Gramercy Park, the East Village and Lower East Side. While Mr. Pagan is gay, the city's other two gay legislators, Councilman Thomas K. Duane and Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick, pointedly backed Ms. Friedlander. Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan also mobilized support for her. Mr. Pagan also has a long list of endorsements, and benefits from popularity with Hispanic voters. By Aug. 13, Ms. Friedlander had raised $64,960, compared with $56,509 for Mr. Pagan. Sylvia Friedman, a newcomer to the race, who could siphon votes from Ms. Friedlander's base as a liberal Jewish woman, raised $41,530.
3d COUNCIL DISTRICT

BARBARA W. KLOBERDANZ (D) Political consultant; former teacher; former member, Community Board 8.
SAMUEL D. MORELL (D) Liquor sales, wine imports; former salesman in wholesale and retail clothing; a candidate for City Council in 1980, 1982 and 1985.
 No Republican primary. Charles Millard (R-L) is the incumbent.
THE CAMPAIGN: The Democratic winner here faces the unenviable task of running in November's election against Charles Millard, the Republican-Liberal incumbent. Ms. Kloberdanz, City Council President's liaison to the Council, is backed by several political clubs and legislators. She stresses quality of life issues and Council oversight powers. Mr. Morrell, who proposes a medical van for the elderly, Upper East Side jitneys and using vacant lots for parking, has run several times before.

8th COUNCIL DISTRICT
WILLIAM DEL TORO (D) Minister, Chapel of the Sacred Heart of Jesus; chairman of the Community Housing Anti-Crime/Anti-Drug Task Force; a candidate for City Council in 1991.
FRANCISCO DIAZ JR. (D) District Manager, Community Board 11; former Housing Development Adviser for Homesteading Coalition; community organizer in East Harlem.
ADAM CLAYTON POWELL 4TH (D-L)City Council member elected in 1991; son of Adam Clayton Powell Jr., the late Harlem Congressman; former assistant district attorney in the Bronx; worked for Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
THE CAMPAIGN: Adam Clayton Powell 4th, 31, is struggling to keep his seat in this district that encompasses part of the South Bronx. In 1991, William Del Toro squeezed by Mr. Powell with 34 votes in the first tally but lost to him in a court-ordered runoff after hundreds of voting irregularities were found. Mr. Del Toro has returned to challenge Mr. Powell. The Del Toro name carries clout in East Harlem, where most of the district's residents live. Mr. Del Toro is a minister and the brother of State Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro.
A wild card in the race is a third candidate, Francisco Diaz Jr. Mr. Diaz, who is on leave from his job as district manager of Community Board 11, has the backing of Congressman Charles B. Rangel.
All candidates claim to have toiled in different arenas to help solve the district's most pressing problems: drugs, crime, poor services and a housing shortage. But the outcome may be decided less on issues than on political alliances and the influence of the candidates' supporters.

LAWRENCE A. WARDEN (D-L) City Council member elected in 1991; former health care administrator; member, N.A.A.C.P.

Councilman Warden was first elected in 1991 with the help of the Bronx Democratic chairman, George Friedman, but then backed an insurgent bid led by Larry Seabrook to oust Mr. Friedman. That failed, and now Mr. Warden now finds his renomination challenged by Mr. Burke, a party district leader endorsed by Mr. Friedman. Both candidates are black, but Mr. Burke's home base is Co-op City, which has a heavily voting white population. But Mr. Warden also has support in Co-op City, the advantage of incumbency and the Seabrook faction's backing.

CARMELO SAEZ JR. (D) Community advocate; management consultant; President, School Board 9; former member, Community Board 4; former director, Development of Youth Inc., a private nonprofit center for youth; former executive director, Alianza, a federation of Hispanic organizations in the Bronx.
THE CAMPAIGN: This contest pits a longtime minister against the chief of a scandal-ridden school board. The Rev. Wendell Foster has served on the Council 15 years. His challenger, Mr. Saez, was removed as school board president in District 9 last year, accused of mismanaging funds and using school equipment for private business.
The district suffers from low reading scores. Nine board members have been arrested in cases involving theft, extortion, kickback and abuse of office. Denying wrongdoing himself, Mr. Saez won re-election to the board this year. Mr. Foster raised a hefty $76,088 campaign chest by Aug. 13. Mr. Saez did not file a financial report by the deadline.
17th COUNCIL DISTRICT
RAFAEL CASTANEIRA COLON (D) City Council member elected in 1981; Chairman, Civil Service and Labor Committee.
DAVID ROSADO (D-L) New York State Assemblyman (74th Assembly District), elected 1990; former district leader; former member, Community Board 2 and Area Policy Board 2; former member, Community Board 1; Youth Coordinator, New York City Youth Bureau; administrative, alcoholism rehabilitation program; former machinist and garment worker.
ANDREW EATMON JR. (D) A Legal Aid lawyer.
THE CAMPAIGN: Despite a 704-count indictment accusing Councilman Colon of stealing $389,000 in city funds, he proclaimed his innocence and continued his reelection bid. Prosecutors said he cashed paychecks for phantom employees and also voted from a false home address.
Before being indicted, his career was already troubled. Democratic leaders and Ramon Valez, the powerful local head of private social service agencies, abandoned Mr. Colon after his girlfriend accused him of assault in a child support dispute. There were accusations that he lived outside the council district. Earlier, Mr. Colon's ex-wife said his failure to pay alimony forced her onto welfare. The new candidate backed by the party and Mr. Velez is Assemblyman Rosado.
Andrew Eatmon Jr. ran for this seat in 1991, but Mr. Colon prevailed.
A fourth contender, Rafael Mendez, a perennial candidate from the radical New Alliance Party, was removed from the primary ballot for lack of sufficient signatures in August, but he remains on the ballot in November as an Independent. Financial filings on Aug. 13 showed Mr. Colon had raised $39,1756. State filings showed that Mr. Rosado had $1,300 in loans and contributions.

MIGDALIA RIVERA (D-L) President, New York Paralegal School, a private school she co-founded; interior designer.
THE CAMPAIGN: This strangely shaped district was designed to give Hispanic voters a majority and a Council member. But nine contenders crowded the 1991 ballot, including three Hispanics and a black who split the minority vote. The upshot was that Ms. McCabe, who is white, won with 22 percent.
This time the contest's ethnic makeup is reversed. Hispanic groups unified behind a single candidate, Ms. Rivera, who also has important union support. The second challenger, Mr. O'Hara, competes with Councilwoman McCabe's ethnic base. He drew 10 percent of the 1991 vote. Party organization leaders also oppose Ms. McCabe, who says she is too independent for their liking. Despite the odds, she is running hard, has her own organization and by Aug. 13 had raised $47,979, more than double the total for her two opponents.

THE CAMPAIGN: This is shaping up as one of the city's most contentious Council battles. Carved out two years ago to encourage minority candidates, the largely working-class district is 75 percent black. Susan D. Alter, who is white, managed to keep the seat in 1991 by capturing the Jewish vote in the primary; she is abandoning her seat to run for Public Advocate and is endorsing Ms. Robertson, a black American-born community advocate.
Colin Moore, a 52-year-old Guyana-born lawyer who has developed a citywide reputation through his involvement in high-profile cases, came in second to Ms. Alter in 1991 and considers himself the logical heir to both the seat and the support of Democratic Party officials in Brooklyn. But the party has instead backed Lloyd Henry, a 45-year-old Belize-born Episcopal minister and newcomer to politics. An unusually wide array of elected officials are stumping for Mr. Henry, including the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, a United States Representative, Edolphus Towns, and Mayor David N. Dinkins.

THE CAMPAIGN: Councilman Samuel Horwitz's retirement set off a brutal fight to succeed him. For 21 years Mr. Plotnick served on the community board and as school board president and local party leader. For 21 years, Mr. Lasher served as the local Assemblyman, gaining seniority to head committees.
Both sides are slinging charges: That Mr. Plotnick used the schools for patronage and nepotism, including a job for his mother and promotions for his wife; that Mr. Lasher took donations from insurance companies when he headed the Insurance Committee, and that he keeps a one-bedroom apartment to qualify for the Council district but his four-bedroom home is a few blocks over the border.
Although their Aug. 13 filings showed that Mr. Plotnick outspent Mr. Lasher by nearly double, $55,017 to $28,213, Mr. Plotnick said Mr. Lasher used his Assembly apparatus for mailings to voters. The third candidate, Mr. Michaels, said the others represent the abuses of entrenched politicians. Brooklyn's Democratic chairman, Clarence Norman, calling the contest "a slugfest all the way," made no predictions or endorsements.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 5-10

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Sending the Government Bureaucracy to Weight Watchers 
 
This is an earthshaking idea: show taxpayers "that their tax dollars will be treated with respect." No, that's not Ross Perot talking, it's a young man named Al Gore. Is he dreaming? Is there ever a taxpayer who, writing that painful check to the I.R.S., doesn't envision $1,000 toilet seats and "Star Wars" sinkholes? But Mr. Gore was dead serious last week when, against a backdrop of mountains of printed regulations on the White House lawn, he vowed to streamline "outdated Government," save $108 billion and cut 252,000 jobs. If companies can "downsize," why not Washington? Congress will have something to say about the plan, which was six months in the making. But much can be done by executive order, so Mr. Gore and Bill Clinton just might make a dent. And Mr. Clinton's first step to a slimmer Government? Adding one more tentacle to that sprawling monster, something called the Community Enterprise Board.
 
Medicare? How? Tell You Later.
 
In the last five years of this millennium, the way things are growing, the Government will spend $1.9 trillion on Medicare and Medicaid. The Clinton team thinks it can cut 12 percent from that, and told Congress last week that it planned to slash $238 billion in those years. "Politically unacceptable," pronounced Representative Henry Waxman. Medicare, after all, serves 36 million elderly and disabled people, and politicians mess with it at their peril. But the Administration says its new health system will pick up some slack, because when everyone has insurance, the drain on Government money will ease. And when will we be told how, precisely, this will work? "At the appropriate time," said Mr. Clinton.
 
Price Controls, by Another Name
 
Because Medicare and Medicaid account for half of all prescription drug sales, drug makers would probably be out of business without them. So when the Administration said last week that it wanted to deny Medicare coverage for any drugs it deemed too costly, it was understandable that the drug industry raised cries of "price control." President Clinton had recently ruled out specific price controls, but this policy would have the same result. How would such a policy affect the elderly? That's unclear. Prices would surely fall, but on the other hand, people might be denied coverage for some high-priced drugs that have no substitute.
 
Those Post-Labor Day Blues
 
The party ended, then began again. While the cats were at the beach in August, Wall Street's mice played, sending the Dow to record after giddy record. Maybe it really was low interest rates, maybe it was the heat. But when Labor Day barged in and told everyone to wipe away those vacation grins, the market, waking to a feeble economy, beat a hasty retreat, with the Dow dropping 45 points in two days. No surprise, really. The tireless statisticians -- like the tennis pundits who intone, "That's the 14th time Sampras wiped his brow this set" -- were quick to point out that in the last 21 years, the Dow has fallen two-thirds of the time the day after Labor Day. The gloom didn't last, though, as the Dow bounced back 32 on Friday, to 3,621.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Lorenzo's Flight Is Canceled
 
Frank Lorenzo, it seems, made some lasting enemies in airline unions in his stormy days at Continental and Eastern. When he said he wanted to get back in the business, sketching visions of a low-cost East Coast carrier, unions roared into action, placing ads telling lawmakers that that would be like letting Michael Milken and Charles Keating "return to the scenes of their crimes" and vowing to picket any Lorenzo operation. Last week a judge appointed by the Transportation Department gave the pilots their way, grounding Mr. Lorenzo's airline, perhaps for good. In a marvelous bit of legalese, the judge said that Mr. Lorenzo's company "lacks the proper compliance disposition" -- or, in English, that it seemed highly likely that Mr. Lorenzo would cause trouble.
 
It's Small. It's American. So?
 
Here are some Detroit axioms: 1. People in their 20's, who buy a lot of small cars, don't buy American cars. 2. Detroit can't make money on small cars. But Chrysler is out to rewrite the rulebook, introducing its Neon subcompact last week as a peppy, almost totally recyclable car aimed at those in their 20's. And, yes, aimed at turning a profit.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Signs of Life in Germany
 
Germany's deep recession has rippled to its neighbors, just as Europe is battling to transform itself into a strong, unified force in the global economy. And it has rippled across the world, since it's such a big potential market for goods from, say, the United States. But there was a glimmer of hope last week that the worst could be past, as the Government reported that western Germany's economy was growing for the first time in 15 months. "The first signs of light for overcoming the recession are unmistakable," one official said. . . . And later in the week the Bundesbank, perhaps emboldened by this economic news, took another step that could ease Europe's woes, lowering its key interest rates another half-point notch.
 
Cadbury Will Buy A & W . . .
 
What could be more British than Cadbury Schweppes? (It's hard to say the name without lapsing into a British accent.) What could be more American than A & W root beer? And what could be more a sign of the times than having all such distinctions blasted away? For Cadbury is about to become America's No. 4 soft-drink company. Having recently bought a big chunk of Dr Pepper, it agreed last week to buy A & W Brands for about $335 million. The gains are clear: Cadbury gets a solid distribution system, and A & W gets a strong foreign partner and access to markets abroad.
 
 . . . and Volvo Looks South
 
And here's a sign of Europe's times. Volvo, Swedish to the core, is merging with Renault, which couldn't be more French. The linkup announced last week reflects, most simply, the hard times that are facing Europe's auto industry, because by joining research, distribution and other such matters, the joint company -- which will be the world's sixth-largest car company -- is expected to save billions. But the move is also a symbol of Sweden's moving closer to its neighbors, hoping to join the European Community as a full member in 1995. Such European togetherness will be all the more important down the road, because in 1999 all restrictions on Japanese auto sales in Europe will be lifted.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 26, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Business Diary column on Sept. 12 about prescription drug prices misstated a provision of Medicare. The system does not cover outpatient drugs.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Taking New York Home, Bric by Brac

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
RALPH SARWARI can tell when the economy is turning sour in Germany or Japan, perking up in Brazil or taking off in Taiwan. He can tell when the French franc is falling and the Swiss franc is soaring. And he can do all of this without leaving his place beneath the fluorescent lights of Xanadu.
 Not Kubla Khan's domed domain, not the too-opulent-for-words mansion in "Citizen Kane," but the casbah of kitsch, the Monte Carlo of mementos, the Shangri-La of souvenirs: a store at 1528 Broadway, at the northern edge of Times Square, that, under Mr. Sarwari's management, sells everything from Statuettes of Liberty to "I<heart>NY" cigarette lighters, "I<heart>NY" pencils and "I <heart>NY" T-shirts. Not to mention the $899 denim jackets with lower Manhattan hand-painted on the back under a sky of glittery spangles. One day, a Japanese man bought 12. 
No one, not Mr. Sarwari, not even Scott C. Borowsky, publisher of Souvenir and Novelty magazine, knows what part of the $1 billion-a-year national souvenir business is rung up on the cash registers of New York. In 1991, the most recent year for which figures are available, state economic development officials counted 693 gift, novelty and souvenir shops in the city.
 It's a competitive business, at least in midtown. Between 34th and 57th Streets are more than a dozen shops that sell only souvenirs, T-shirts and postcards. Then there are several dozen others that also sell what Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, calls "items of real use," from cameras to luggage -- merchandise that makes the souvenir business here different from most other places.
 Mr. Sarwari has other kinds of competition -- street vendors who sell identical-looking but less-expensive T-shirts. He says his, at $14.99 apiece, are all cotton, while the $5 ones on the street are a cotton-polyester blend.
 IN such a crowded marketplace, some retailers might try glitzy window displays or splashy marketing campaigns to set themselves apart. Not Mr. Sarwari, who spends less than $10,000 a year on advertising. Xanadu's secret, he says, is its location.
 "How," he asks, "can a tourist miss Times Square?"
 But like a hotel manager who sees red ink when bookings suddenly fall off, Mr. Sarwari is all too aware when consumer confidence 5,000 miles away hits an air pocket: foreign tourists buy the $2.99 Statue of Liberty ballpoint pen instead of the $99 replica the size of a soft-drink bottle.
 Mr. Sarwari said he has to take in $400 a square foot to break even. By most retailers' standards, that's a lot. Macy's toted up an average of $203.80 a square foot at its 110 stores last year, according to the Blackstone Group, an investment firm. Of course, department-store dynamics are different from the impulse buying that brings in big bucks at Xanadu, but both share the bad news. "When the recession hit, I saw it," Mr. Sarwari said. "The food industry, people don't stop eating, but they stopped traveling."
 Still, merchandise that says "New York" sells. "New York, there's that excitement," Mr. Sarwari said. "Coming from a small town somewhere, they want to be part of it. They don't want to live here." Xanadu's 16-member staff does; this showcase of American kitsch is totally run by immigrants. Mr. Sarwari, who was born in Afghanistan 35 years ago and arrived from Pakistan in 1982, can't imagine himself anywhere else.
 "I have relatives in Chicago, Virginia and California who say, 'How can you live here?' " he said. "But I love it. I was in Chicago for a sporting goods show last month. Very clean, very nice, but I'm sorry, it was boring."
 And no Statue of Liberty. It is the consummate New York icon (available at Xanadu in six sizes and three colors), but it took him years to visit the big one in the harbor. "I had out-of-town guests," he said. Did he like it? "Yeah. It had some meaning. As an immigrant myself, I felt the power."
 Ditto the World Trade Center, whose popularity surged after what Mr. Sarwari calls "the incident" -- the bombing in February. Postcards and T-shirts with the twin towers have been selling faster than tiny replicas, Mr. Sarwari said.
 "The Japanese love them. With Japanese, they don't buy one or two. Any piece they buy, they buy 20. They are great customers, but they all want different bags. They want 40 plastic bags so they can present the gifts individually."
 There is more.
 "Germans? Not like Japanese," he said. "French, they're cheap, I can tell. I speak the language, I overhear things. The sales tax is shocking. In France --even at 30 percent or 45 percent in Scandinavia -- they don't feel it, it's built into the price. But 8.5 percent? They never get used to it."
 In all kinds of languages. One customer, Giovanna Caprini, an 18-year-old university student from Milan, was buying a dozen pencils. "Piace," she said. A friend, Doris Pizzino of Floral Park, L.I., explained that this meant she liked Xanadu very much, despite the sales tax.
 INCREASINGLY, the souvenirs as well as the customers come from far away. Mr. Sarwari sells a made-in-Korea-or-Taiwan piggy bank that looks like a giant penny, and the ballpoint pens with King Kong climbing the Empire State Building are Danish imports. "Somebody came in wanting an American-made pen, a regular pen," he said. "I don't sell that."
Xanadu is not where Mr. Sarwari expected to end up. As a child, he wanted to be a doctor. He was in medical school in Afghanistan and Pakistan, but when his United States visa arrived in 1982, "I said, 'Hey, American dream,' " and he left. He was a stock manager at a midtown electronics store before moving to Xanadu and its monstrous 2,000-item inventory, from the green street sign that says "Times Square" to the key chain with a subway-token holder. Mets jackets? Of course, but there is a but.
 "The Yankees always sell, regardless of whether they are doing well," he said. "I sell more Florida Marlins and Colorado Rockies jackets than the Mets. Anything more than the Mets."
OFF THE SHELF (The Can Is Not Included)
Bottoms Up ($9.99) provides the one thing a pop-top lacks: a handle. A pliable plastic statuette, it clips snugly onto the can. The manufacturer sold 9.9 million in six months. "I wish I could come up with something like that that I could market," said Ralph Sarwari, Xanadu's manager. He sold 48 last week.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;
At Pier 62, Start of Plan For Riverfront

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
It doesn't look like much: a bleak stretch of asphalt with volleyball and basketball courts, picnic tables and an information kiosk. But the new playground on Pier 62 at 23d Street is the first sign that after two decades of controversy, including the killing of Westway, plans to revitalize this section of the Hudson River waterfront are moving closer to reality.
 The Hudson River Park Conservancy, which will eventually manage the redeveloped waterfront from the Battery to 59th Street, installed the playground. And as limited as it is, it still attracts residents of the area, people who work nearby and summer campers from the local Y. 
Every Sunday afternoon, Tom Schuler, armed with beach chair, newspaper and fruit, heads for the playground. "It's my favorite all-purpose park where you can meet neighbors, play Frisbee or just sit and watch all the boats go by," said Mr. Schuler, who lives at 23d Street and Ninth Avenue.
 If the last hurdle -- approval by the State Transportation Department -- is cleared this fall, a privately financed $50 million rebuilding of the Chelsea Piers could start in November. On Piers 59, 60 and 61, now home to parking lots and the film studio where the NBC television series "Law and Order" is shot, plans call for two glass-enclosed ice skating rinks, film and television studios, an urban golf club, indoor jogging track and gymnasium, three waterfront retaurants, a two-and-a-half-acre park and a long public esplanade.
 But the Chelsea Piers project still faces opposition. Marcy Benstock, the environmental advocate who led the successful fight against Westway, does not support the plans. Her chief objection is that management of Chelsea Piers --along with the whole riverside project -- would be under the supervision of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the state Urban Development Corporation that she says is an autonomous agency "not accountable to the public." Her Clean Air Campaign and three other civic groups are suing to shift responsibility to public agencies.
 But many Chelsea residents who supported Ms. Benstock on Westway disagree with her about Chelsea Piers. "Any presence is better than the present wasteland," said Sybil Taylor, a writer, who now bikes to Battery Park for a waterfront view. MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Reborn Brownstones: Phase I

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The first stage of the Bradhurst redevelopment plan, one of the largest neighborhood-renewal projects ever undertaken by the city, is nearing completion. Starting this week, people with low and moderate incomes may request applications for the 236 apartments in renovated brownstones on Frederick Douglass Boulevard between 145th and 147th Streets and east along 145th Street.
 The renovations, which also include 60 apartments for people being displaced by the construction and five for superintendents, are part of a comprehensive plan to rehabilitate a troubled area that stretches from 139th Street to 155th Street and from St. Nicholas Avenue to Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. It is planned that by the year 2000, the city will construct or renovate more than 80 buildings, housing a total of 2,200 families. The project, being developed by a consortium of political, business and spiritual leaders, is being overseen by the Housing Preservation and Development Department. 
Almost 90 percent of the $24.5 million the city spent on Phase 1 went to architects and contractors from racial or ethnic minorities.
 The first apartments are for families with total incomes $13,120 to $47,000. They will be chosen by lottery, and neighborhood residents will have priority for 30 percent of the units. Sixteen studios are reserved for artists. The rents range from $350 a month for a one-bedroom apartment for a low-income tenant or family to $675 for a three-bedroom apartment for a moderate-income family.
 Phase 2 of the plan is near the construction stage. Anyone who wishes to apply for an apartment must request an application in writing -- enclosing a self-addressed, stamped envelope -- from Bradhurst Redevelopment Project, Morningside Station, P.O. Box 1588, New York, N.Y. 10026. Completed applications must be postmarked by Oct. 25. E.B.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
In Chinatown, A Food Fight

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
The Silver Palace, which in 1981 became Chinatown's first unionized restaurant, is writing another new chapter in its labor relations. It has locked out the union and is being picketed.
 The popular restaurant, which opened in 1976 as New York's first Hong Kong-style dim sum mega-parlor and banquet hall, says it must cut costs because of the recession and new competition from banquet halls. 
On Aug. 19 the managers locked out 40 waiters, cart-pushers and busboys from Restaurant Workers Union 318 after they refused to give up paid health insurance, some paid time off and part of their tips.
 "The workers are fighting just to keep what they had," said Wing Lam, a union adviser.
 A waiter, Ming Wong, recalled the union's initial struggle.
 "This is like history repeating itself," he said. "We want to get our jobs back."
 Chinatown has the city's biggest concentration of restaurants, with a reputation for tasty food at modest prices.
 But those bargains are possible because the restaurants usually pay very low wages, often to illegal immigrants who have few other chances for employment and do not protest.
 In an advertisement in Chinatown newspapers, Silver Palace complained that while it has a 40-hour workweek and pays more than the minimum wage, all its competitors are nonunion and have 60- to 70-hour weeks, minimal pay and no health coverage.
 "I'm not asking for anything anyone else doesn't have," said Richard Chan, Silver Palace's executive director.
 And to attract business discouraged by picketing, the restaurant, which seats 900, has cut its prices by 30 percent. B.L.
