LENGTH: 1888 words

HEADLINE: Learning to Cope With Hard Times

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
MATTIE CREECH lives in a ground-floor apartment in the Newhallville section of New Haven. Outside her front door, city buses sit idling and the blare of car stereos rattle the dishes in her cupboard. While sitting next to a window seat filled with herbs, Mrs. Creech said she reckoned that the country has been going downhill since the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
"But let me add," said the 73-year-old, who retired in 1987 after working 20 years repairing guns for the Olin Corporation, "in the past five years, it's gone completely crazy." 
 She includes among her litany of contemporary ills the fact that the banks are always changing their names, the residents are overtaxed and, of late, the thieves in her neighborhood are stealing air-conditioners from people's windows. Such developments stand in stark contrast with the days when she first moved to Connecticut from rural Virginia in the 1940's.
"That was when everybody had a job and some respect," Mrs. Creech said. "There was always a park where a kid could play and everybody watched out. Now they've torn down all the parks to build condominiums and no one can buy them. And the young people are toting guns and selling drugs. That tells you how far we've come."
In recent interviews with residents across the state one thing became clear: these are confusing times for Connecticut. The recession that began around four years ago still lingers. The state's cities have become more impoverished and dangerous. AIDS, teen-age pregnancy, drug abuse and other social problems continue to take their toll. And the dream of finding a lifelong job that includes good benefits with a stable company has died.
No matter where people live and what their standard of living, the turmoil and economic difficulties of the past few years seem to have in some way altered their lives. For many, the period marks a time of financial and philosophical readjustment. While some say the worst is yet to come, others are hopeful, given the resourcefulness of the state's residents, that Connecticut's economy will revive. Over all, everyone agrees that things will never be the same. When it comes to stories about the pain of losing a job, Susan Troup Tolhurst of Waterbury said she had heard them all. She knows of one Bridgeport man who lost his printing business after 30 years and a former Hartford bank manager who now makes $15,000 working at a pharmaceutical laboratory scrubbing bottles. She knows people who have received exemplary evaluations from their employers one day and a pink slip the next.
 
Unemployment Problems
 In 1990 Ms. Tolhurst was laid off from her job as a computer trainer the same week her husband was laid off from his job as a computer engineer. "When you're both unemployed at the same time, it's no vacation," she said, "and I knew the worst thing would be to isolate myself."
After a thorough search she found only two support networks for people who had lost their jobs and decided to begin her own group. She sent out news releases to churches, unemployment centers, libraries and civic groups. In the spring of 1991 she held the first meeting at Silas Bronson Library in Waterbury. The group now draws 20 to 50 people weekly, most of whom are professionals over 40 who come from as far away as Danbury, Fairfield and New Haven. The two hours are spent sharing interviewing experiences, resume tips, job leads and listening to speakers.
Ms. Troup, 44, also publishes a brochure distributed by the State Department of Labor listing 55 similar support groups, which have emerged in the last three years. As a result of her contacts with thousands of unemployed people she said she had become an astute observer of the state and national economy.
"Most economists agree that because Connecticut was the first to be hit with the recession, it will be the last to come out of it," she said. "What we've got is a huge mismatch between our labor pool and what's needed to succeed in a global economy." She would like to see a state task force created that would be made up of jobless workers and employers; they would sit down together and redefine the types of skills workers need, and determine if businesses plan to hire more temporary as opposed to permanent, full-time employees.
 
Saw Recession Coming
 In addition, Ms. Troup suggested that the state finance a program to help unemployed people with similar talents form business cooperatives. Earlier this year she began a part-time job as a vocational trainer at Brookfield High School. Though there was no pay for her work on the brochure and outreach project, she did receive a letter from Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. commending her efforts.
"There's a book called 'If You Do What You Love Then the Money Will Follow,' " she said. "I'm keeping my fingers crossed and hoping that'll come true."
In 1989 Thomas Febbraio, sensed that the economy in the Fairfield area was beginning to crumble. As an owner of three restaurants -- Tommy's, Sidetracks and Arizona Flats -- he said he had kept in touch with the Welcome Wagon organization and had begun to notice that housing sales in Fairfield had dropped substantially.
"That was the real barometer," he said. The following year, Mr. Febbraio, 40, started to see a decline in the number of customers. Other businesses in the area were also struggling. At that point he began to analyze his business. He spent long evenings at his office on the Post Road calculating ways to reduce his expenditures and increase his revenues. He revised the menus and strengthened the style of each restaurant, which are completely distinct.
"I looked at everything down to how much it was costing us to put oil in our table lamps," Mr. Febbraio said. "I thought I was going to lose everything."
 
Difficulties of Self-Employed
 Substantially cutting costs and redefining goals has paid off, said Mr. Febbraio, who has been a restaurant owner for 16 years. Last year he and his partner, Thomas Sargent, a Westport lawyer, had their best year, he said. Although the number of customers has not reached the peak of the mid-1980's, he said, the financial adjustments they made have compensated for other shortfalls.
"In the 1980's restaurants did business by default because business was flowing," Mr. Febbraio said in a recent interview at Sidetracks, a family-style restaurant with a railroad theme. "In the 1990's you have to be more creative in your thinking. You have to know how to invest in what you already have."
In Cornwall, near the banks of the Housatonic River, Todd Piker, 41, uses an old chicken barn as his pottery studio. With a wood-fired kiln he turns out dishes, mugs and bowls, birdhouses and lamps, mostly in rich shades of red and brown. A self-employed artist for the past 20 years, Mr. Piker said he was no stranger to recessionary times. He and his family run the Cornwall Bridge Pottery store, where he sells his works along with Mexican blown glass, kitchen items and children's toys.
Because of its location, the flow of traffic is steady, yet in the past five years, Mr. Piker said, "There's so little discretionary income around, it's been harder and harder to convince people that a bowl of pottery will enhance their lives."
 
Impact on Tourism
 Mr. Piker said the challenge of generating new ways to make ends meet has become the only way to survive. He has expanded his merchandise to include cutting boards, post cards and children's games and makes sure his prices are reasonable.
Because the northwest corner of the state is so susceptible to the ebb and flow of tourists, he said, the recession has placed a strain on most businesses. The tax bases for some towns are eroding, the town roads are not as well maintained and "the schools are crying for every dollar they can get," he said. But despite it all, he said he would not trade his life style for another.
"You're a self-employed person for a reason," said Mr. Piker, the president of the Society for Connecticut Crafts. "And nowadays the economy is so fleeting, I wouldn't want to give up what I'm doing to try and work for some corporation."
Gina Dituzzi, 47, said that if she won the lottery, she would buy all the empty factories in Bridgeport and turn them into shelters for homeless people, complete with a cafeteria and medical staff. As a caseworker for the city's Spanish American Development Agency for the past six years, she has watched the lives of most of her clients deteriorate.
 
'My Heart Gets Broken'
 More and more of them have to collect cans and bottles to supplement their incomes, she said, and to ask for food vouchers, which are in limited supply. Elderly people are especially hard hit, she said, referring to one woman who lives on cat food and crackers because she needs the money from her meager pension to pay for her medications. Many of her clients have succumbed to AIDS, tuberculosis and drug overdoses.
"Every day my heart gets broken," Ms. Dituzzi said. She has fond memories of growing up in the Bullshead section of Bridgeport in the 1950's. "Those were the days when you could walk out and sleep on a bench with all your money on you and nobody bothering you," she said. "Some day I'd like to see it go back to that, but I know that'll never happen."
She raised three daughters on her own by washing people's clothes with a glass washboard in her bathtub, she said. Today she makes $300 a week as a caseworker helping people fill out their welfare forms, teaching English and lending a compassionate ear.
Instead of giving money to the drug addicts or alcoholics that cluster on corners and in boarded up buildings outside her office on East Main Street she will often take them to get something to eat. "People are doing what they're not supposed to be doing and that's why it's all going down the drain," she said. "That and the fact that there's no money. And in this world, it all comes down to money."
 
Wildflowers Amid Debris
 On a weekday afternoon, Ms. Dituzzi described her neighborhood as she walked past Julio's Furniture Store, two Spanish food markets and a stretch of boarded-up buildings sprayed with graffiti. The farthest from Bridgeport she has ever been is New Haven, she said, and she would not change that for anything.
Near a cluster of men swapping liquor bottles beneath the awning of an abandoned warehouse, Ms. Dituzzi talked about how unfairly people outside Bridgeport talk about the city. "To most people," she said, "Bridgeport's the place you go to get killed."
Farther down the street, past an empty lot strewn with broken bottles and litter, she paused to point out the clusters of Queen Anne's lace. Like the wildflowers sprouting amid the debris, Ms. Dituzzi pointed out that Bridgeport has a beautiful side that is often ignored. But unless everyone faces up to the realities of urban life, she said, the conditions are going to get much worse for the whole state.
"Everybody in Connecticut has to open their eyes and try to put our world back together again," she said. "Instead of being afraid of crime and poverty, I tell people not to be afraid. It's here, let's cope with it. Instead of running, we've got to start rebuilding. Instead of avoiding, let's try to reclaim at least some of what once made us a strong community."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Lego Blocks Keep Building a Growing Enfield

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHILE much of the economy languishes, parents still buy toys for their children at a phenomenal rate, and in this country they buy more than anywhere else in the world. The toy industry estimates that the United States accounts for 25 percent of worldwide spending on toys.
Few companies take toys more seriously than Lego Systems, the Enfield subsidiary of the Lego Group, a Danish company. From its opening in 1975 until last year the company has expanded its manufacturing plant six times, the last time to 525,000 square feet. 
 This year it opened a $25 million, 225,000-square-foot high-technology warehouse on its 147-acre Taylor Road property and has begun construction on a 100,000-square-foot, $14 million office complex.
Peter Eio, the subsidiary's president and chief executive, said he was also in the market for 75 or 80 acres to build a 150,000-square-foot injection-molding plant to make the company's famous plastic interlocking building blocks, and the company's long-term plans call for "other new facilities in Enfield," although he would not elaborate.
"We've been in the United States 20 years, and we've had 20 years of steady growth, and we hope to continue that," Mr. Eio said. Although the privately owned company does not disclose its annual revenues, Mr. Eio said sales had increased 13 to 14 percent annually for the last several years.
John D. Pagini, Enfield's director of planning and community development, said Lego, Phoenix Home Life, U.S. Shoe, and Hallmark Cards are the town's top employers, each with 1,000 to 1,200 employees, but Lego's growth rate will soon put it out in front.
Mr. Pagini said with the development of the office building, however, Lego will have used most of its available space.
"If they have plans to expand it will have to be in another location," Mr. Pagini said. "There's a lot of available land in the general area, though, so that won't be a problem."
Town Manager A. Louis Hayward said a recent survey showed 1,200 to 1,300 acres of industrially zoned land available for development. Most industrial land sells for $30,000 to $100,000 an acre.
Enfield, a Hartford bedroom community of 46,300, has come into its own because of its available industrial land and its highly skilled work force, Mr. Hayward said.
"Just in the last year, we've had something in the neighborhood of 22 businesses either move into Enfield or expand, with an estimated 1,000 new jobs," Mr. Hayward said. The new enterprises have ranged from Dairy Mart, which recently took over the old Digital Equipment Corporation building, to New Ventures Technology, a startup company manufacturing computer components.
Jacqueline S. Horner, administrative assistant at the North Central Connecticut Chamber of Commerce, said Enfield's access to Interstate 91 and Bradley International Airport in neighboring Windsor Locks are also selling points for foreign investors. Two other European companies, Jagenberg, which makes machinery for the paper industry, and Leybold Vacuum Systems, have come to Enfield since Lego arrived, she said. But the star of Enfield's corporate community is obviously Lego.
"One of the things we rely on is that having something like Lego in town will attract other companies," Mr. Hayward said. "If a corporation of that stature is here, it's an indication Enfield is a good place to do business."
"We use Lego as an example for other foreign companies considering an investment in the United States," said Joseph Cohen, a spokesman for the state's Department of Economic Development. "It's a good selling point when you can show a foreign-owned company is succeeding and is pleased with the business climate in Connecticut."
EGO was begun by Ole Kirk Christiansen in 1932. The name came from the Danish "leg godt," for "play well." He didn't know it at the time, but lego also means "I put together," or "I assemble," in Latin. His nontoxic and nearly unbreakable blocks were introduced in this country in 1961.
The company says that six of its basic eight-stud blocks can be combined in nearly 103 million ways, and its quality control program allows a maximum variation of 0.0008 inches, less than one-thousandth of an inch, in its bricks.
Lego sells more than 11 billion bricks a year in nearly 120 countries. Mr. Eio said Lego blocks were in 70 percent of the homes in the United States, a market penetration other toy companies envy.
In Europe, though, 80 to 85 percent of homes have Lego blocks. But all that means is that Lego has not realized its potential in this country, Mr. Eio said. And if the North American Free Trade Agreement is ratified, he said, the company hopes to begin distributing its toys to Mexico from Enfield.
Next to its warehouse is a 30-foot-long Lego-brick model of the Capitol in Washington. The visitors' waiting room has Lego sculptures of Donald Duck, and his nephews Huey, Dewey and Louie, and a glass-topped treasure chest filled with the bricks.
But it is not all games at Lego. Its new distribution center has 50-foot ceilings, so the company can stack 40,000 pallets in its 10 million square feet of space. Dozen of loading docks are usually occupied by the familiar bright yellow trucks bearing the red and white Lego logo.
Inside, wire-guided turret trucks can unload trucks automatically, record on a central computer where each load is stored, and retrieve it without searching through paper records. The company also has an arrangement with its largest corporate customers so they can order via computer modem, and the confirmation comes back the same way.
"It's basically a paperless system," Mr. Eio said. "And they're notified the minute the truck leaves the distribution center, so they can immediately plan to receive it."
The new office building, scheduled to open in 1994, will house Lego's sales and marketing staff on two floors.

HEADLINE: Along Arkansas's Pristine Waterway

BYLINE: By DYAN ZASLOWSKY; DYAN ZASLOWSKY lives in Colorado and writes frequently about the outdoors.

 BODY:
AROUND 1979, the slogan on Arkansas license plates changed from "The Land of Opportunity" to "The Natural State," in a tribute to Arkansas's beautiful scenery and unsullied backwoods.
During the 1970's, Arkansans themselves seemed to be awakening to the native splendor of their state. There were a number of good reasons for raised consciousness; possibly the best of them was the establishment of the Buffalo National River in 1972. The Buffalo is a 132-mile free-flowing waterway that drains the 2,500-foot-high Ozark Mountains in the northwest portion of the state. As a result of a highly publicized alliance between Justice William O. Douglas and local preservationists, the Buffalo became the first river in the country to be proclaimed a National River. 
 Federal recognition hinged on its having miraculously remained undammed and unpolluted for its entire length. In a monumental effort to keep it that way forever, a 94,000-acre portion of the Buffalo's watershed was purchased in the 1970's by the Government from private landowners. The Buffalo National River is now administered by the National Park Service, and the United States Forest Service administers the one-million-acre Ozark National Forest where the river begins.
The Buffalo, a river the color of pale jade and with similar smoothness in some portions, has always appealed to canoeists in the region. But until the 1970's, when the Park Service began trail development, boaters were mostly confined to the river and its banks since the land around the river was privately owned and few, if any, public trails had been blazed cross-country. In the last 10 or 15 years, hundreds of miles of trails have been constructed, owing to the zealous efforts of volunteer builders and park employees. One example of their industry was the blazing of the 187-mile Ozark Highlands Trail through the dense heart of the Ozark National Forest in the 1980's. The route is now counted by Backpacker Magazine as one of the country's best long-distance trails. Dozens of trails ideal for day trips have also been constructed. Those of us who love to hike can now explore deep into the Arkansas woods -- countless waterfalls, swimmable oxbow-shaped pools, caverns, bluffs, hollows and old homesteader cabins -- as a result.
The 200-foot-high Hemmed-In-Hollow falls, which the National Park Service says is the highest waterfall between the Appalachians and the Rockies, is one of the big surprises of Arkansas's back country. I had heard about the falls 14 years ago from a man my husband and I often hiked with. Born and raised in Arkansas, our friend pressed us to go and see some of the beauty of his home turf.
I did so last April for four days, a month when my own home in Colorado is locked in interminable snow and cold, but the Ozarks are mild and leafing out. Covering the Ozark Mountain flanks down to the Buffalo National River were dark entanglements of oak, hickory, umbrella magnolia, beech, sassafras and maple etched against the infant green. Moon-white dogwoods and the magenta florets of the redbud trees spangled the understory -- in another week the dogwoods would saturate it with their light -- while the ground was dappled with wild iris, violets, fire pinks and buttercups. For all its delicate beauty, spring may well be surpassed by autumn, according to our friend, who married in late October because he loved the palette of the Arkansas foliage at least as much as he loved his bride. The trees begin to turn brilliant shades of red in late September, and are saturated in red, yellow and orange by the end of October. The days are dry and blue-skied, with daytime temperatures rising into the 70's and a touch of frost crisping the nights.
To reach the Buffalo National River one cool, clear morning, we drove east from Fayetteville for about an hour, through countryside that alternated between dense forest and undulating sward. The vistas were green, clean and downright prosperous judging from the appearance of the stout houses and barns. An indication of rural Arkansas's current economic vitality is the number of long, low chicken ranches that have been started up across the state, making it the top chicken producer in the nation.
We also drove through pretty, pre-Civil War towns and settlements the size of a heartbeat; though northwest Arkansas is the birthplace of the Wal-Mart juggernaut, tranquil Kingston, Possum Trot, Boxley, Ponca and Compton are not only pre-Wal-Mart, they look pre-20th century as well. Indeed, in the Boxley Valley you can spot a few iron kettles the Confederates used to manufacture gunpower from the saltpeter they mined in nearby caves. Farmers feed and water livestock from the enormous pots.
We pulled into the nearly empty Compton Trailhead to begin the five-mile round trip into Hemmed-In-Hollow.
After a rather steep descent through the forest, we turned off the main trail to see Wild Vic's Cabin, one of the original home sites and historic landmarks near the river that the Park Service has preserved. The cabins offer a glimpse of old hillbilly life, and provide minimal shelter when the weather turns foul -- a downpour can drive a hiker into one of them but so can the unexpected cold of a winter night.
Wild Vic's Cabin was built of hand-hewn logs in the early 1900's. A dead tree stands in the middle of the cabin's lower room and had been rudely fashioned into a spiral staircase leading to the loft. Wild Vic or his successor had presumably subsisted here into the 1960's, when the Government paid him to move out in preparation for the national river park.
We hiked for another hour or so -- crossing swift Sneed's Creek on a fallen tree trunk no wider than the width of our feet -- to reach Grandma Henderson's Cabin. It surprised me how few hikers we encountered along the creek, which flows out of the Buffalo, though the weather was fine and canoe traffic on the river was moderately heavy.
The corrugated tin roof of the empty cabin gleamed above a meadow carpeted with pale reindeer moss. The ground looked like foam and felt like pillows where we stepped on it. At Wild Vic's and at Grandma's, naturalized jonquils yellowed the ground around the cabins, providing gentle anthropological testimony to the gardening efforts of the former inhabitants.
While the flowers succeeded, the crops probably did not, since soil in these parts tends to be thin and easily sapped by cultivation. Left to its own devices though, the land yields trees.
Grandma Henderson's place, another landmark on the route, must have been a fine house for the neighborhood, handsomely shingled and with a wide veranda staring out the front and a root cellar in the back. Even in these backwoods she had cared enough about appearances to decorate with wallpaper and cover the floor with vivid linoleum. We studied her changing taste in color and pattern as they peeled away from the walls, and went outside to picnic on smoked turkey and croissants bought in Fayetteville. (The towns closest to the Buffalo River offer little in the way of accommodations or food. Before heading into the area, it is best to stock up at grocery stores in bigger towns like Harrison or Jasper.)
After leaving Grandma's, we walked beside the Buffalo for about two miles, then followed a stony finger of it into Hemmed-In-Hollow. About a dozen boaters had beached their canoes and were also proceeding on foot, their paddles slung over a shoulder or deployed as walking sticks.
The air had warmed up but was still on the cool side of comfortable, and even by the river it was too early in the season to be nattered at by mosquitoes and other winged pests. Bugs and humidity are the twin banes of summer, leaving the other nine months in which to hike in pleasant conditions.
Hemmed-In-Hollow, configured like a natural amphitheater recessed into the limestone bluffs, is probably the best known of Arkansas's secluded pools. The noise of the waterfalls at the very back of the hollow tumbling from a semicircular array of fissures in the sheer rock walls drowns out all normal conversations. Refreshing spray danced out and back, freighted with the pungent scent of juniper when the breeze was right. We stayed a while and watched two men rappelle down the face of the hollow, then disappear into caves hidden from our view.
All exits out of the hollow go up. We chose the steepest and therefore the shortest way that did not require a technical climb. The footing was so narrow that it occurred to me that I had not negotiated such a precarious ledge since hiking in the Swiss Alps two summers before.
Understandably, the Park Service discourages that particular route. At the far side of the hollow we clambered straight up a rock chimney, scrambling hand over hand until the ground leveled off.
The two hikes we took the next day, after spending the night in Ponca at the Buffalo Outdoor Center, afforded no such thrills. They were both easy, and very rewarding considering our low expenditure of energy.
The first was along three-mile Clark Creek. The hasty creek eventually empties into the Buffalo, and on its way has carved a jewel of a canyon called Lost Valley out of 50-foot limestone bluffs honeycombed with caves. Eden Cave is a wonderful one for neophyte spelunkers because it is so accessible and considered quite safe, though a stream flows through it and a waterfall pours out of its mouth.
The second hike was to Hawksbill Crag, which juts out 400 feet above the river, and provides exhilarating views of the vast, untrammeled Upper Buffalo Wilderness Area.
To get there, we drove a short distance through the Boxley Valley, briefly stopping by an old church cemetery to read the moldy gravestones.
Considering its fame, Hawksbill is poorly marked and trailed. I was puzzled to find that the one-mile path from the car pull-off to the outcrop was scarcely better than a game trail. While the terrain is flat, without some markings to show the way hikers new to the country could have found themselves perilously close to the forested edge of the mountain.
The difference between the Hawksbill Crag trail and the others I had hiked in the area lies, I suppose, in the philosophical difference between the National Park Service and the United States Forest Service. One agency throws open the lands it administers to all comers, the other is reluctant to promote its recreational resources. It might encourage more people.
Hikers from outside Arkansas have already begun to arrive in larger numbers, judging from how seldom we met people who spoke like natives.
Fortunately, my hiking companion was homegrown and spoke in the soft, melodic accents that I've come to appreciate. When we passed the sign on the highway for the Possum Trot turnoff, I chuckled over the town's colloquial spelling. He averred that by Arkansas standards the spelling was correct. I responded, "Then what about that opossum we saw squashed by the side of the road back there?"
"We don't have opossums down here," he said, lingering over the first o. "Just possums. Since you Northerners don't have any possums where y'all live, how come y'all the ones who get to decide how we have to spell the critters?"
 
 
 
TRAILS, CANOE RENTALS, LODGING AND HEARTY MEALS
If You Go
 The best seasons to visit the Buffalo National River are spring or fall, when the forest is aflame in color. Yet despite the heat, summer is still the most popular season. Hiking is possible throughout the mild winter, but winter canoeing, which requires wetsuits, is only for the hardiest recreationists.
For hikers, the trail guides by Tim Ernst, a local photographer and trail builder, are indispensable. "Arkansas Hiking Trails" is the most comprehensive of his guides. "Ozark Highlands Trail Guide" is for those planning a trek across the national forest. Both are published by Norwegian Wood in Fayetteville, Ark. They cost $12.95 plus $2 shipping and can be ordered from Ernst Wilderness, 411 Patricia Lane, Fayetteville, Ark. 72703; (501) 442-2799.
Canoes or river rafts can be rented in Ponca at the Buffalo Outdoor Center, at the junction of Highways 43 and 74 (501-861-5514), or Lost Valley Canoe and Lodging across the road (501-861-5522). Canoe rentals run about $25 a day, $15 a person a day for rafts. Charges may be higher on weekends. Guides can be arranged through both places.
 
Where to Stay
 Overnight camping does not require a permit from the National Park Service, and is allowed close to the Buffalo National River. Contact the Buffalo National River Office of the National Park Service for maps and information at Post Office Box 1173, Harrison, Ark. 72602, (501) 741-5443.
A limited number of log cabins are available in Ponca and other nearby towns, so reservations are recommended. The Buffalo Outdoor Center at its Ponca and Silver Hill locations offers new deluxe cabins that sleep up to six starting at $70 for two and $15 for each additional person and a Presidential Cabin that sleeps up to four in Ponca, including Jacuzzi, fireplace, full-service kitchen, large bathrooms, $125 a night for two. Other cabins are $70 a night for two.
Lost Valley Canoe and Lodging in Ponca has three fully-equipped cabins that rent for $5 a person a night and a bunkhouse that sleeps 16 that rents for $70 a night for two, plus $5 a person a night up to 16 ($140).
Cliff House Inn, on Highway 7 six miles south of Jasper, has four rooms with private baths, for $40 a night, and a two-room suite that is $50 a night; (501) 446-2292.
 
Where to Eat
 Dining out on a Sunday in the Buffalo National River Country is next to impossible. Only fast-food establishments in Harrison, 19 miles from Ponca, are open, so if you are renting a cabin, plan to cook that night.
Other days, there are several locally colorful places to try.
The Valley Cafe on the square in Kingston is open Monday to Friday 7 A.M. to 3 P.M., Saturday 7 A.M. to 9 P.M., for breakfast, lunch and dinner. A full breakfast runs about $3.75. (501) 665-2277.
The Cliff House Inn is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner in the summer (between Memorial Day and Labor Day), and 8 A.M. to 3 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday in the spring and until Nov. 1, when it closes for the winter. The dining room has fabulous views of Big Creek Valley. The Cliff House is known for its angel flake biscuits, and the dish proclaimed the official Arkansas state pie, Company's Coming, with meringue, pecans and pineapple. Entrees include grilled or fried chicken, country fried steak, mashed potatoes, trout and catfish, about $4.95.
Devito's, Highway 65 North, in Harrison (also in Eureka Springs), (501) 741-8832, is open for lunch Tuesday to Friday 11:30 A.M to 2 P.M. and dinner Tuesday through Saturday 5 P.M. to 9 P.M. It serves excellent pasta, with seafood fettuccine and chicken Parmesan specialties. Entrees are $5.95 to $13.50.
Rockhouse Barbecue, 416 South Pine, Harrison, (501) 741-1787, serves hickory-smoked pork loin ribs, steakburgers and catfish. Open Monday to Thursday 11 A.M. to 9 P.M., Friday and Saturday 11 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. A full rack of ribs with cole slaw, cornbread and baked beans for two costs $15.95.
 
What Else to Do
 There is a picturesque water-operated grist mill, the War Eagle, on the War Eagle River. It is also the site of the Ozark's largest art and craft fair, scheduled for Oct. 14 to 17; (501) 789-5343.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 58; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: What the Navy Taught Allen Schindler's Mother

BYLINE: By Jesse Green; Jesse Green is the author of "O Beautiful," a novel.

 BODY:
Not far from the laminated portrait of Elvis, high on a shelf in her tumbledown house, sits the only photograph Dorothy Hajdys has of her father, who died in prison when she was 5: a dashing sailor with faraway eyes serving his country in World War II. The pictures of her first husband -- a man named Allen Schindler who decided he was John the Baptist and, she says, nearly drowned her in the bathtub to prove it -- are not on display. Water is a running theme in the family: Frank Hajdys, her second husband, was a Navy man as well; before he died in 1985 he regaled their young son, Billy, and his three stepchildren -- Dorothy's two girls and one boy -- with tales of his adventures aboard the battleship Arizona. The stepson, "little Allen," so called to distinguish him from his biological father, must have taken Frank Hajdys's stories to heart because in 1988, at the age of 18, he signed up and shipped out. "I thought I was the most proudest mother in the nation," Dorothy has said.
"I THOUGHT I WAS THE MOST PROUDEST MOTHER IN the nation," Dorothy was shouting into a microphone set up in front of the Capitol last April. A sad curiosity to the general public, which might have caught her on the evening news, Dorothy Hajdys (pronounced HAY-jiss) was a hero to the hundreds of thousands of people gathered before her at the gay-rights march on Washington. Earlier in the day they had cheered her wildly, this 47-year-old grandmother with the door-hinge voice and battleship proportions, marching at the head of a contingent of veterans and clutching a photograph of her son like a shield. 
 "Cheering me!" she said later. "Me who didn't even know a homosexual until January!" Yet that seemed to be what the crowd was responding to -- not the tragedy of her son's brutal murder but the swift education that had opened her eyes, opened her mouth and brought her here. If the Salvation Army bookkeeper from Chicago Heights, Ill., was scandalized by the Dykes on Bikes gunning their engines and the Gays in the Millinery prancing in fancy hats, she kept her disapproval to herself. Still, she seemed frozen, as if bracing for a blow; when the crowd started roaring, she just stared back, until a friend had to prompt her: "Wave, Dorothy, wave!" Which she immediately did, as if to a ship.
"I AM FINALLY GOING TO A SPECIAL PLACE," radioman Allen Schindler wrote on the first page of a pale green notebook he bought two years after entering the Navy. The special place was the aircraft carrier Midway -- "the mighty, mighty Midway," he called it -- and the notebook was to be a record of his happiness on board. Evidently he expected an abiding happiness, for he numbered the bottoms of the pages from 1 to 192. But in 1991 he was transferred to the Belleau Wood, a smaller ship with a reputation for mayhem. As his progressively less legible entries attest, Allen was miserable. At Christmas Dorothy saw he had removed stitches from the logo on his cap, turning the B in Belleau into an H. What she didn't know was that the hell he was suffering was the hell of a gay man in fear for his life.
Indeed, Allen Schindler would never get past page 64 of his journal. Two months before his 23rd birthday, on Oct. 27, 1992, while on shore leave in Sasebo, Japan, he was followed into a park bathroom shortly before midnight by two drunken shipmates, one of whom, Airman Charles Vins, watched and occasionally joined in while the other, Airman Apprentice Terry Helvey, kneed Schindler in the groin, struck him in the face and then, cradling his head in the crook of his arm, punched him repeatedly while lowering him to the floor. There, Helvey began stamping on him with the heel of his foot, striking blows from head to crotch that resulted, according to the pathologist who performed the autopsy, in abrasions, contusions and lacerations of the forehead, eyes, nose, lips, chin, neck, Adam's apple, trachea, lungs, liver -- which was pulped "like a smushed tomato" -- and penis. The pathologist compared the damage to that of a "high-speed auto accident or a low-speed aircraft accident" and said it was the most severe trauma he'd ever witnessed -- even worse than a case he'd seen of a man trampled to death by a horse.
A sailor who happened upon the scene but could only make out shadows through a window in the bathroom door described Helvey's footwork another way: "It seemed like he was dancing."
DOROTHY HATED TO LIE. SHE would teach her children never to lie. But with Allen Sr. unemployed because of a mysterious back problem, she needed a job to help pay the mortgage. And John's frozen pizza, a girlfriend told her, would not hire the mother of a newborn -- little Allen was just 1 month old. So Dorothy lied and got the job. But it wasn't enough. Two years later, with money still short, she took on another, at Burger King. Now she could fry fries from 10 A.M. to 2:30 P.M., change uniforms and dash across town to John's, where, from 3 P.M. to 1 A.M., she tossed pepperoni onto frozen pizzas as they whizzed past relentlessly. In the little time remaining she slept, and kept dreaming this image: Allen's bottle of milk emerging frozen among the pizzas on the endless conveyor belt.
His real bottle she rarely saw; it was her aunt Marie, living in the small apartment at the back of the house, who took care of Allen. Marie helped him through Dorothy's divorce from Allen Sr.; through Dorothy's marriage to Hajdys, her Burger King boss; through Allen's disappointment that his stepfather had plenty of time and money for Billy but none for his stepson. And so it was an understandably miserable 12-year-old who, upon Marie's death, lashed out at his mother, blaming her for ruining the family. "I said, 'If you think this is so terrible, go stay with your father for a week,' " Dorothy recalls. "But Allen Sr. slammed the door in his face, saying, 'You're her problem now.' That did the trick! Allen and me weren't real, real close, but after that I was his mother and father and we never had a problem again."
WHEN DOROTHY GOT HOME from the Salvation Army at 6:30 on Oct. 27, 1992, Billy had already left for his job at the Haunted House in nearby Park Forest. "I figured I wasn't going nowhere," she remembers. "So I just put on a nightshirt and did some work for this lady at church." What happened next, as she sat on the floor cutting crosses out of plastic to make bookmarks, she would hardly be able to relate if she hadn't at once begun dictating a journal of each day's events to her daughter Kathy. "Two sailors came to my door in dress blues," the log begins that night. "They told me that my son had been assaulted by two men in a park in Sasebo, Japan, and that he was dead." Ten pages and seven months later, it ends with "Allen's stone was put in at the cemetery." In between, in homely prose, it records Dorothy's struggle to bury her son and understand why he died -- a pursuit in which the Navy all but abandoned her. "Oct. 30: Heard nothing." "Nov. 1: Still heard nothing."
Waiting for answers, or even the body, she barely slept. It wasn't until the arrival, on Nov. 4, of the coffin -- bearing a corpse unrecognizable except by tattoos on its pale arms -- that Dorothy was finally told her son's assailants were shipmates. "But why would shipmates want to beat him so badly?" she wanted to know. "Nov. 9," the journal records, "No new information." It was left for a reporter from Pacific Stars and Stripes, an independent military newspaper, to tell her that Allen was gay, that he had met with a legal officer in hopes of getting off the Belleau Wood and that, according to a letter sent to the paper by three gay men who knew him in Japan, Allen's death was the result of violence encouraged, if not permitted, by a climate of bigotry aboard ship.
Dorothy at first denied her son was gay but soon realized that the reporter's scenario was credible, and that the Navy, in its stonewalling, was not. Previously she'd tended to be submissive in the face of mistreatment. "Oh yeah, anybody could do anything to me," she now says. It's a part of family folklore that as a child she had allowed some cousins (who, by a trick of remarriage, were also her half-brothers) to tie her to a homemade stake and set her on fire. And then there were the men in her life, who jilted her, sponged off her, told her lies to get their way. Frank Hajdys, it turned out, was not sterile from a "Navy injury," as Billy's birth proved. "And Allen Sr. wasn't all that faithful," Dorothy adds. "The night little Allen was born, he was in a tavern with a girl, and she actually came and stayed in our house!" She pauses. "But I will say she cleaned up." Allen Schindler Sr. could not be reached for comment.
But within weeks of the murder, Dorothy's reserve of humility was spent. The pronouncements of her Government and its agencies, which she had formerly either ignored or accepted, she now treated with suspicion bordering on scorn. When, in November, the accomplice, Vins, was tried without her knowledge and sentenced to what amounted to only four months in the brig, she was angry but not surprised. Nor did it surprise her to learn, in March, that a senior Navy official was leaking a story, later disproved, that her son's murder was the result of a romance with Helvey gone bad.
By then, Dorothy knew about disinformation. She had begun her own inquiry, working the phone and filling scrapbooks with relevant articles. When the first reporter had called, she was barely able to speak, but now she cultivated the press, prodding them to follow up on inconsistencies and feeding them pieces of one another's stories. "If one more reporter calls me with information before you do," she told the Navy commander in charge of the case, "you haven't even heard me scream!" It wasn't long before Dorothy began wondering who cared more about her son: the Navy, in which three generations of her family had served, or the gay community, which she had not until recently even known she was part of.
HE ORGANIZED GAY community is no more organized -- and no more a community -- than any other affiliation of people who have, at best, only one thing in common. A dysfunctional family, its various representatives spend a lot of time backbiting and defending their turf. But they all recognized a useful symbol when they saw one, and immediately began squabbling for Dorothy's attention like a brood of 7-year-old boys.
Dorothy, having lost a son, responded to the attention, albeit warily. When Michael Petrelis, an organizer for the voluble gay-rights group Queer Nation, called her six weeks after the murder, she was still uncomfortable with the word homosexual. Was she aware, he asked in his New Jersey honk, that gay activists were rallying around her son's cause, hoping to make him the gay Rodney King? "He scared the living daylights out of me, with his voice and all," Dorothy recalls. "There was no way he was getting me involved in no queer nations." But soon representatives of more polite groups began calling. The Human Rights Campaign Fund asked if it could fly her to a candlelight vigil in Washington. Not knowing it was a gay organization -- or that the vigil had been organized, in part, by Petrelis -- she said yes. Soon, the Campaign for Military Service, whose goal was to lift the ban on homosexuals, asked if she would sign a letter telling her story, as part of a mass-mail fund-raising effort. Yes, she said; and yes to the news conferences, the memorials, the crystal awards and sympathy plaques. After all, she brought home only $190 a week; she could never afford the kind of publicity these groups were willing to pay for. If they wanted to fly her and Kathy and Billy to some city they'd never seen, put them up in a nice hotel, pay for meals, let her say her piece, why should she refuse? It was more attention than she'd ever gotten from anyone in her life. And if they were using her only to further their aims, as some claimed, she would use them to further hers.
"I WAS LIKE A REFRIGERATOR who didn't want to be moved," Dorothy recalls of her first meeting with Jim Jennings, whom press reports, to her horror, had identified as her son's onetime lover. "I hate that word lover," she says. "And I didn't want to go. Meet all these gay people? I figured they were weird, like Klinger from 'M*A*S*H,' dressing like women, with their pinkies in the air." But Jennings had invited her to a memorial service in San Diego in honor of Allen, and Dorothy decided she had to attend. "And guess what? They were nice! None of them looked like Klinger."
In the months following Allen's death, Dorothy achieved what parents of living homosexuals often fail to, even after years of effort: an acceptance of her child's sexuality. Unfortunately, she now lives with the regret that it took a brutal murder to do it. For Allen had told her, in a phone call from San Diego long before he died, that he was gay. "I thought it was just him trying to get me," she says. "He was always doing things to drive me crazy. He sent a picture of himself in a white tux with some girl from the Philippines in a white dress and told me they got married -- he had me going for a long time with that, and it wasn't until later Kathy told me the girl was a guy. So I didn't believe him when he said he was gay. I thought if I just didn't take the bait, he'd give up. But right after, we went to Kings Island near Cincinnati, a really neat amusement park. We were in line to get on the roller coaster and this guy behind me said, 'Look at the faggot up there with the tattoos on his arms trying to make people think he's a macho man.' That really hurt me. And I didn't understand."
How could she understand? Allen looked nothing like Klinger: he was well built, handsome, with thick blond hair and blue eyes. He wore an earring, "but doesn't everyone?" Dorothy says. She ignored the incident, and over the next few years, if Allen mentioned men he liked, she didn't respond. But reading his journal, she knew she'd been wrong. The final entry, in purple ink, describes Allen's crush on a man he had met while on shore leave in Sasebo a few days before his death. Eric Underwood, who danced on Broadway in "La Cage aux Folles" and was now performing at a theme park commemorating the first Dutch settlement in Japan, was apparently everything Allen wanted. Everything except single; Underwood had a lover stateside. Still, their hours of conversation over several days left the enamored sailor feeling a bit less lonely. "I guess that means we are everywhere," he wrote, and for the last time closed his journal -- which bore on its cover a heart-shaped sticker and the legend "Be Kind to Me, I Gave Blood Today."
"TERRIBLE THINGS WENT ON on that ship," Dorothy believes. "Gay sailors being lost at sea, which really means thrown overboard." Dorothy has constructed a version of her son's last weeks aboard the Belleau Wood from the sometimes contradictory accounts of shipmates, reporters and her new gay friends. In Dorothy's mind it is better that Helvey be assigned the likely, if unprovable, motive of gay-bashing than that he have no motive at all, as the Navy seems to hold. It is better to think that Helvey was acting out a Navy-wide hatred than to think that, in essence, he acted alone.
One of Dorothy's best new friends -- and major informants -- is Eric Underwood. It was Underwood, along with two other performers at the theme park, who wrote the letter to Pacific Stars and Stripes. In his five months in Japan, he had heard plenty of stories about gay sailors being punched in the face while sleeping, or doused with lighter fluid and ignited. According to him, the Belleau Wood was the worst ship of all. "So bad," he says, "that Allen, after we talked, had a hard time going back to that environment. I'd have to coax him to the door. He said that people harassed him 24 hours a day."
The Navy says Schindler never reported any harassment, but harassed or not, he was scared. "More people are finding out about me," he wrote three weeks before he died. "You never know who will want to harm me or cease my existence." Still, in the struggle between circumspection and revelation, revelation had won. He now ate with a group of gay sailors who called themselves the Fab Five. He told the chaplain he was gay and wanted a discharge. And then, apparently desperate to announce the truth, Radioman Schindler broadcast what the Navy calls "an unauthorized statement" over the Pacific Command: "I'm too cute to be straight."
Whoever else may have heard the comment on the wide ocean, Schindler's shipmates now knew, if they hadn't before, that he was gay. One month later, he had his last talk with Underwood. Now Underwood has long talks with Dorothy instead. "She's like another mom to me," he says. Certainly she brags about him like a mother, showing visitors a photo he uses for modeling auditions. "Look at him in the bathing suit," she says a bit lubriciously. "He says he would have went for Allen." With that match impossible, Dorothy has dreamed up another: in the TV movie about her life -- now in development at Quest Entertainment -- she hopes Underwood will play her son. "He's a knockout," she says. "Blond and blue-eyed like Allen." Or, she might have added, like Helvey.
IN THE BEGINNING I wanted nothing but to go to Japan and stomp Helvey's head as he had stomped my son's, but I didn't want his mother to have to go through what I'm going through." Dorothy was speaking at the Fourth Annual Homicide Memorial, a day of sermons and singing and light politicking sponsored by the Cook County State's Attorney's office. It was a blistering day, threatening rain, but Dorothy had made the trip to Grant Park in Chicago, on the shores of Lake Michigan, because talking about her son has virtually become her profession. (Having flown only twice before Allen died, she has since racked up more than 40,000 miles.) The Salvation Army hadn't seen a full week of her since kettle-counting time at Christmas. And now that Dorothy had expanded her venues to include non-gay events, it didn't seem likely that her schedule would abate. She didn't want it to: it scared her when a week went by with no calls from the press or requests for her presence. "You need to release your anger or it can build inside you," she told the hangdog audience of survivors, who sat at picnic tables, sobbing into their soft drinks. "And if that happens, you can become something terrible. Thanks to the media, I was able to tell my anger over and over and over."
It does sometimes seem that Dorothy has only a half-dozen phrases to describe her feelings and beliefs -- phrases that roll out of her in rotation, as identical as bullets, or pills. "The Pledge of Allegiance says justice for all," goes her brief for gay civil rights, "not justice for all except homosexuals." Another favorite is: "You can mess around with a lot of things, but don't mess around with my kids!" Simplistic as they are, these unscripted formulations, expounded by a woman who calls herself "the stupidest person on earth," always hit home. Certainly no one is intimidated by her vocabulary, her manner or her attire. "If she were a New York sophisticate and wore clothes by Galanos," says Thomas Stoddard of the Campaign for Military Service, "it wouldn't have the same effect."
Ellen Meyers, who arranged for Dorothy's appearance at the memorial, puts it more bluntly. "Dorothy's spectacular," she says. "I mean, her child is dead from a hate crime. And down in Springfield she's been lobbying for the state gay-and-lesbian-rights bill. Usually we have professional queers spouting statistics, but to have a mother! And a mother from a white, working-class Republican town -- how could you beat that?"
It was hard to beat. Hearing her testimony -- "Allen was my son but he could have been the son of any of you here" -- the Judiciary Committee of the Illinois House of Representatives, wiping back tears, approved the bill for consideration on the floor, where it also passed. "It was like maybe Allen's death had finally done some good," Dorothy exulted. Two months later, however, the bill was killed by a State Senate committee.
ON MARCH 30, William Bracken, a lawyer Dorothy retained on the advice of Miriam Ben-Shalom, a lesbian veteran, filed a Federal tort claim of $8 million against the Navy for the wrongful death of Allen Schindler. Bracken likens the atmosphere aboard the Belleau Wood to "willful endangerment." The Navy, which must deny or accept the claim by Sept. 26 or risk a full-blown lawsuit, has not yet responded, though it has conducted an investigation into the "conditions and attitudes which prevailed at the time of the murder." The investigators concluded that "the ship, the command and those senior personnel responsible for the ship actively discouraged violence, threats and illegal discrimination of any type, including against homosexuals."
If the Navy nevertheless agrees to a settlement, Dorothy may find herself a rich woman. She says the TV movie, if it is made, will bring her $100,000; an agent has dangled before her the prospect of $2,000 per night on the lecture circuit. In anticipation, Kathy has urged her mother to move to a nicer house, but, planted in her armchair, glancing first at her curio cabinet crammed with dolls, then at a boomerang and a black velvet map brought back from one of Allen's adventures, Dorothy appears unable to move.
Not that she loves Chicago Heights, a woeful town of 36,000 some 30 miles from Chicago. Once, when the steel mills prospered, there was probably a good side of the tracks, but that was long ago. In any case, Dorothy lives virtually on the tracks, 50 yards from the railroad's deafening rattle. There she has tried to make a home of a grimy 100-year-old frame house that cost $10,900 in 1969 and might not fetch much more today. A rainbow banner flies from the porch; a plastic goose and a miniature windmill stand sentry in the pebbled front plot. Inside, the house hardly seems large enough for Dorothy and 18-year-old Billy to move around in, but hovel or not, it's the only house Allen knew. To leave it would erase him further. His tiny room has been preserved as it was, except for the emptying of the fish tank, the "adopting out" of the parrots and the removal of the huge cage in which Allen kept his three-foot-long monitor lizard, Junior -- named, it would seem, after himself. "Allen wanted to work in a zoo, or at Sea World," Dorothy says. "When he got home from the Navy." She spends little time in his room -- unnerved, perhaps, by the photographs of the Midway lovingly arranged on the sea-blue walls.
VISITORS ATTENDING Terry Helvey's court-martial last May at the Naval base in Yokosuka, Japan, were directed to opposite sides of a small gallery in the courtroom, as if for a wedding. On the left sat the defendant's party: Helvey's mother, Regena, and aunt Sheryl Sarchette. On the right, the victim's: Dorothy, Kathy and, not incidentally, most of the press. Separated from onlookers by a partition, Helvey and his lawyers on one side were not quite mirrored by the prosecutor and an empty seat on the other -- a seat that seemed to stand for the absent victim himself. Also absent from the ceremony were any of the many fathers, stepfathers and paternal surrogates associated with the event. Allen Schindler Sr., who according to Dorothy's sworn testimony never paid child support, took no interest in the case beyond attempting to claim half of his son's life insurance. As for Helvey, his father, a tattoo artist, had long since decamped. So had his stepfather; Regena Helvey testified at the court-martial that, among other disciplinary acts, he had forced Terry to eat his own excrement and amputated half of his left middle finger by slamming it in a door when the boy was 6.
Dorothy was painfully aware of the symmetries and asymmetries in the room. Her background was strikingly similar to Regena Helvey's: small towns, hard lives, bad men. Like Dorothy, Regena had scraped by with factory and fast-food jobs (in her case, at Kentucky Fried Chicken); she had left her son in the care of Aunt Sheryl. But Regena Helvey was clearly a different kind of woman from Dorothy; slim, almost sultry, refusing all interviews, she seemed to be trying to take up as little space on earth as possible, but to take it up attractively. Reporters were thrilled by the prospect of the mothers meeting, but Regena wasn't about to let that happen; during recesses, she rushed outdoors to smoke, making herself scarce before Dorothy lumbered into the hall. And Dorothy wasn't keen on meeting Regena, either. As the trial began and the defense outlined its intention to pin the blame on Helvey's terrible upbringing, Dorothy turned toward the reporters behind her and, only half whispering, said: "We had a bad life too, but my son wasn't a murderer."
Although the press was literally on Dorothy's side, it was hard not to sympathize with Regena Helvey and even to some extent with her son, who shaved neatly for each day of the trial, occasionally wore glasses and looked utterly bereft. When he rose to speak on the third day -- the court permitted him to make an unsworn statement -- he virtually decomposed before the jury's eyes, stuttering, crying, choking back yelps of pain, spitting out pieces of apology until, collapsing back into his seat by the window, he ducked his head under the Venetian blinds. His defense was barely more coherent: some mumbo jumbo about steroid use from a robotic psychiatrist, a photomontage of Helvey's high-school sports team, a two-hour testimonial video from his hometown. "Our little dog, who didn't like anyone, loved Terry," said a girlfriend. "Well groomed," said a minister. "Shared his pizza."
By the time the eight-officer panel began deliberations, Helvey's fate no longer seemed to be the dominant issue. Having avoided the possibility of the death penalty by pleading guilty to a lesser charge, the defense suggested a sentence of 21 years -- since, at 21, this was all of life Helvey knew. But whether 21 years or 60, his life was ruined. Something else was on trial: the American family, and all in all the proceedings did not constitute much of a vindication. Marriage had brought happiness to no one; men were "lazy rats," as Dorothy put it; mothers were left to mourn and fight and pay the consequences. Regena Helvey took the stand to corroborate the defense's contention that she had been an inadequate mother -- even admitting she had tried LSD while pregnant with Terry -- hoping that her confession would somehow mitigate his sentence. Dorothy took the stand to describe again her son's ruined body, hoping to earn Helvey a life in prison. In the end, the court-martial was indeed a kind of marriage, for the two families would forever be locked together in regret, one mother participating in her owncharacter assassination in order to save her son's life, the other reliving her son's murder over and over in order to save her own. And Helvey, if there was any justice, would spend a long time dreaming of the man he had danced upon.
THE MOTHERS, AS it turned out, did meet. Minutes after the jury sentenced Helvey to be confined for the length of his natural life, Dorothy was led into a small room where the convict was waiting behind a table. Once inside, she began screaming. He had destroyed her life. He had destroyed her family. Her 8-year-old granddaughter could not fall asleep without clutching her picture of Uncle Allen. "I'm sorry," Helvey stammered, over and over, unable to look at her directly. It was then that his mother came into the room; Helvey motioned her away, but she stayed and put her arm around his waist -- "like she really cared," says Dorothy sarcastically.
The three of them remained in the room a few more minutes, Dorothy yelling, Terry repeating his two pathetic words. Regena Helvey, perhaps aware that words are sometimes worthless, said nothing.
DOROTHY SITS IN HER chair at home, sorting through the blue nylon knapsack returned to her at the end of the trial. Inside it, her son's belongings have been stored in plastic sandwich bags, as evidence. "What kind of evidence is this?" she asks, holding up a bottle of shampoo. Also in the knapsack are keys and a checkbook, snapshots and loose change, some drawings of lizards and a pink-triangle pin with the caption "Non-Breeder." She begins to tremble. Not that Dorothy hasn't gotten what she wanted: back in Yokosuka she had been so elated that she even embraced Queer Nation's Michael Petrelis. "If there's a place in the Guinness Records for the woman kissed most by gay men, I'm it!"
She has embraced Petrelis's methods, too. She has learned the lessons of the loudmouths: without them, justice would not have been done. Having become a loudmouth herself, however, she is faced with the realization that she can never stop. She spends her days waiting for more chances to "tell her anger" -- to broadcast unauthorized statements, as Allen did. The subject doesn't matter much: how the military ban helped kill her son, how gay marriages would be beneficial. What matters is that she is at war, and will be at war, one way or another, for the rest of her life. After all, Helvey's mother still has Helvey; he might even be paroled someday. Allen is now just a bag of mementos -- another man gone.
Billy clomps into the house on a new pair of Rollerblades. Dorothy points her thumb at him. "The Navy called here trying to recruit him -- can you believe it?" she snorts. "Weeks after Allen was killed. But no way are they going to get their hands on him."
Perhaps it was once possible to think of the Navy as a substitute father for America's lost boys, but no longer. In this regard, the Navy failed Helvey as much as Schindler. In his unsworn testimony at the court-martial, Helvey said that all he had ever wanted was a family, and that the Navy, with all its "fights, typhoons and hurricane warnings," provided it. But what kind of family, Dorothy likes to ask, would reject a loving son merely for being what he is? And that's how the Navy failed Allen Schindler. He loved the Navy, and died of unrequited love; it shipped him back, an anonymous pulp, unrecognizable even to his mother, except for the insignia tattooed on his right arm -- of the U.S.S. Midway.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 12, 1993

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1718 words

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Galveston

BYLINE: By GEOFFREY LEAVENWORTH; GEOFFREY LEAVENWORTH is a freelance writer based in Galveston.

 BODY:
Galveston lies just 32 miles from Mission Control and the Johnson Space Center, but its towering Greek Revival palaces and abundant magnolias, oleanders and pecan trees evoke the Old South. The city -- the place is too densely populated and the structures too vertical to be called a town -- seems to have one foot in the past and one in the present.
Galveston began life as a safe haven for pirates, most notably the privateer Jean Lafitte around 1820. Confederate forces were more vulnerable -- the island was captured by Union forces in the Civil War. By the end of the 19th century, Galveston was the commercial center of the State of Texas, full of banks, cotton traders, shipping companies and merchants. A powerful hurricane, most often called the 1900 Storm, destroyed a large part of the city and killed 6,000 people. The island was rebuilt and thrived again for almost two decades after the Depression as a sanctuary for illegal gambling and other vices. 
 Galveston's misfortunes, as well as its size -- it is a narrow, 32-mile-long barrier island -- meant that its economy languished while neighboring Houston grew exponentially. However, Galveston's setbacks served to leave much of its Victorian architecture untouched. It is this large collection of buildings, including many lacy Carpenter Gothic homes, iron-front commercial buildings and abundant interpretations of Greek Revival style , that is the heart of Galveston's appeal for tourists. Juxtaposed with the historic districts are several new attractions, including a harbor development, a 10-story glass pyramid filled with tropical flora and fauna and a flashy IMAX Theater.
Galveston's readily accessible beaches also draw visitors. While river drainage and the prevailing currents of the Gulf of Mexico conspire to create brackish surf most of the year, autumn does bless the island with some days of clear blue water.
The island also has more than its share of tourist traps, unsightly motels, blighted neighborhoods and seedy buildings. But Galveston's tawdriness is often perceived as part of its charm.
 
Events
 This season marks the reopening of the Strand Street Theater, 2317 Ship's Mechanic Row, (409) 763-4591, an Actors' Equity house and a pioneer in the Strand Historic District. The theater will open its newly restored Victorian building on Oct. 7 with "The Immigrant," by Mark Harelik, running through Nov. 7. Performances on Thursday, Friday and Saturday are at 8 P.M., Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Tickets are $16, students and the elderly $14.
The Grand 1894 Opera House, (409) 765-1894, a splendid red brick pile at 2020 Postoffice Street, will open its performing arts season with national touring companies offering the musicals "Brigadoon" on Oct. 2 and "Once on This Island" on Oct. 16. Steve Allen, with Louis Nye, Bill Dana and Marilyn Maye, appears on Oct. 17. Tickets for each event are $30.
One of the most pleasant ways to spend an evening is to attend the Galveston Artwalk, a free monthly art opening held simultaneously at about a dozen galleries near the Strand. Visitors can stroll through the historic district, check out the art, eat free Brie and meet the artists. The October Artwalk is from 6 to 9 P.M. on Oct. 16. The center of activity is the Galveston Arts Center, (409) 763-2403, a nonprofit foundation with galleries in a handsome old bank building at 22d Street and the Strand. "Observations/Notations," a mixed-media exhibition of seven artists' work runs through Nov. 21.
Two festivals celebrate the influence of the island's large immigrant populations. The Octoberfest Heritage Festival, Oct. 2 and 3, will be celebrated at the Garten Verein, 27th Street and Avenue O, an octagonal dancing pavilion that served as the center of German social life in the 19th century. Food, music, dancing and crafts of various ethnic groups will be featured, and admission is free. For more information call (409) 763-5326. The Greek Festival, sponsored by the Assumption of the Virgin Mary Greek Orthodox Church, 19th and Ball Streets, offers Greek fare, gifts and entertainment on Oct. 16 and 17, noon to 8 P.M. For tickets ($2, or $8 including dinner) and information, call (409) 762-3930.
 
Sightseeing
 The Strand Historic District is the place where most visitors begin. Imposing 19th-century banks and merchant houses have been transformed into restaurants, taverns and museums that coexist with fruit markets, marine suppliers and other workaday endeavors. The Strand Visitors Center, 2016 Strand, (409) 765-7834, offers information, books and gifts. It also sells tickets for the Galveston Trolley ($2, students $1), which provides rail service between the Strand, downtown and the sea wall.
A block north of the Strand is Galveston harbor, home to the tall ship Elissa, an iron-hulled barque built in 1877 that is fully restored and open for tours. Adjacent to the tall ship is the 1991 Texas Seaport Museum at Pier 21, (409) 763-1877, with exhibits, a theater and a boat shop used for crew training and ship maintenance. The museum is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and tickets are $5, $4 for students. The ship will be unavailable for touring Oct. 13 to 19, because it will be plying the Gulf under full sail, usually within sight of the sea wall.
Pier 21, a waterfront development that opened early this summer, includes restaurants, a hotel, shops, a marina and a theater. Showing at the latter is "The Great Storm," an excellent multi-image documentary of the 1900 hurricane. The feature is shown on the hour 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sunday to Thursday, until 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Tickets are $3.50, $2.50 for students. Information: (409) 765-7834.
Midway down the island is Moody Gardens, a vast oasis of flowers, palms and lush greenery. Its most conspicuous structure is the Rainforest Pyramid, a 110-foot-tall glass pyramid opened in March that contains more than 1,000 species of tropical plants, birds, butterflies and fish from Asia, Africa and South America. Tickets are $6. Next door is the IMAX 3-D Theater, showing "The Last Buffalo" hourly 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. and at 8 P.M. and "Behold Hawaii" at 7 and 9 P.M. Tickets are $6 and include the use of glasses to achieve the three-dimensional effect. The Colonel, a replica of a 19th-century paddlewheeler, departs daily for a one-hour cruise from Moody Gardens at 2 P.M. Tickets are $6. The 800-passenger vessel also makes dinner cruises on Saturdays at 7 P.M. ($27.50, $15 for children). For more information about Moody Gardens, call (800) 582-4673 or (409) 744-1745.
All Galveston's beaches are open to the public and access routes are marked. The city, county and state operate a variety of beach parks. For directions and information, call the Convention and Visitors Bureau, 2106 Seawall Boulevard, (409) 763-4311.
The Silk Stocking Historic District and the East End Historic District, which include some 700 historic residences representing Greek Revival, Carpenter Gothic, Queen Anne, Italianate and other architectural styles, are good places for walking and cycling. The Bishop's Palace, (409) 762-2475, a monumental Renaissance Revival fortress at 1402 Broadway, can be toured Wednesday through Monday, noon to 4 P.M. Admission is $3.50, $2 for students; children under 12 are 50 cents. Another excellent house museum is the 1890's Moody Mansion, 2618 Broadway, (409) 762-7668, where a tour and film are offered Monday through Saturday 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and Sunday 1 P.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission is $6, children $3.
 
 
Where to Stay
 For a view of the waterfront, there's Harbor House, (409) 763-3321, a new and tasteful 42-room hotel on Pier 21 in a building intended to resemble an old warehouse. Doubles are $105 and boat slips are available.
Because it is built atop a World War II artillery bunker, the San Luis, 5222 Seawall Boulevard, (409) 744-1500, has a good view of the Gulf, even when you're poolside. This is a high-rise 244-room resort. Doubles are $89 to $119.
Tucked away in the quiet Silk Stocking Historic District is the Virginia Point Inn, 2327 Avenue K, (409) 763-2450, a bed and breakfast where the five guest rooms have private sleeping porches. Doubles are $85 to $125.
Budget: With its proximity to the beach, Gaido's Seaside Inn, 3828 Seawall Boulevard, (409) 762-9625, is a particularly good value: with 108 rooms, doubles with Gulf views are $49 on weekends and $39 on weekdays; rooms without a view are less.
Luxury: The Tremont House, 2300 Ship's Mechanic Row, (409) 763-0300, is an elegant 117-room hotel one block off the Strand. The exterior dates from 1879 but the interior is entirely rebuilt with soaring ceilings, brass beds and tile and marble in the bathrooms. Doubles are $130 to $175.
 
Where to Eat
 Gaido's, 3828 Seawall Boulevard, (409) 762-9625, is a local landmark serving Gulf seafood. Charcoal-grilled red snapper ($16.50) is a favorite entree, and crab bisque, seafood gumbo and pan-grilled snapper are all excellent. Dinner for two, around $60 with a modest bottle of wine.
Nash D'Amico's Pasta and Clam Bar, 2328 Strand, (409) 763-6500, is a popular Strand spot. Seafood specials like red snapper with crabmeat and peppers are delicious ($18). Dinner for two, about $55 with wine.
For shrimp and oyster poorboys ($4.25) and cold beer on the waterfront, stop by Hill's Pier 19, 20th Street at the harbor, (409) 763-7087. Dining rooms on three levels provide views of the fleet of shrimp boats. Lunch for two, with beer, about $15.
 
Shopping
 The Strand is full of shopping opportunities and possesses an entire Victorian row devoted to factory outlets. Here are two of the more eclectic possibilities:
Hendley Market, 2010 Strand, (409) 762-2610, specializes in 19th-century Mexican retablos, religious images painted on tin. A painting of Madonna and Child ($300) looks stunning in a contemporary hand-tooled tin frame ($125). Also: antique ribbon and lace, Mexican folk art and tin pins starting at 50 cents.
Russian army jodhpurs ($9.95) and a World War II China gravy boat ($9.95) are among the finds at Colonel Bubbie's Strand Surplus Senter, 2202 Strand, (409) 762-7397. Quartered in a huge yet oddly claustrophobic Victorian warehouse, Colonel Bubbie's houses surplus goods from the armies of more than 60 countries.
