HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: The Overview;
Arafat Arrives in U.S. to 'Make Peace'

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
After a lifetime of violent struggle for a Palestinian homeland, Yasir Arafat set foot on American soil today and expressed hope that an agreement with Israel would bring peace to the Middle East.
There was no red carpet or military brass band for Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, who smiled broadly as he greeted about 70 P.L.O. officials, Arab ambassadors and Palestinian-Americans with kisses on both cheeks. 
 Banned from the United States for nearly two decades, he arrived at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington today to visit the White House Monday for the 11 A.M. signing of an accord that will usher in Palestinian self-rule in the Israeli-occupied territories.
 
No Private Talk With Clinton
 Mr. Arafat will not have a private meeting with President Clinton, although Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel will.
But in the first formal American diplomatic contact ever with the P.L.O. leader, Edward P. Djerejian, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, shook hands with Mr. Arafat.
"Mr. Chairman, on behalf of the United States Government, I welcome you to the United States on this historic occasion which we hope will lead to peace throughout the Middle East," Mr. Djerejian said.
 
'We Can Make Peace'
 Mr. Arafat replied, "I thank you and I too am hopeful that this will lead to peace."
Mr. Arafat spoke briefly to reporters before climbing into a black limousine and leaving in a motorcade to his hotel. "We are very happy to come in this historic moment when we can make peace, a real peace," he said.
Shortly before midnight, Mr. Arafat appeared on a stairway in the lobby of the ANA Westin Hotel, where he is staying.
"This is the beginning of the future," he said in Arabic, according to a supporter who translated. Flashing a V-for-victory sign with his fingers, he told a large crowd of cheering Palestinian-Americans and a few Jews: "This is just the interim phase because the Palestinian flag will fly over Gaza and Jericho. In the end it will be on top of East Jerusalem and we will be living side-by-side with the Israelis."
After Mr. Arafat said, "This is the first time the Palestinian state has a geographic map," someone in the crowd yelled: "What about Jerusalem?"
"You will have to be patient," Mr. Arafat responded.
At another point, a person in the crowd shouted: "Arafat sold out!"
Mr. Arafat responded: "I never stopped anybody from freeing Palestine. If they thought they could do better, why didn't they?"
A few minutes later, he returned to his tightly guarded suite.
Neither Mr. Arafat nor Mr. Rabin, who left Israel for Washington this evening, will actually sign the accord. Instead, the two aging warriors will appear together as witnesses to an experiment in peace that will change the shape of the Middle East.
 
They May Shake Hands
 The general who led Israel's armies on their lightning conquest of the West Bank and Gaza Strip 26 years ago and the guerrilla leader who fought to liberate them from Israeli rule may even shake hands.
When a CNN interviewer in Jerusalem asked whether the two enemies will shake hands, Mr. Rabin said tersely, "If it will be needed."
Even though he is not signing the document himself, Mr. Rabin said, "I am behind it full-heartedly, knowing the chances, the prospects, at the same time the difficulties and the dangers in which we embark."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher was more upbeat about the handshake issue today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," saying, "This is going to be a monumental occasion, and I expect everyone present will act as statesmen."
The agreement will actually be signed by Shimon Peres, Israel's Foreign Minister, and Mahmoud Abbas, the P.L.O. official who conducted the secret negotiations that led to the breakthrough.
Mr. Arafat's fortunes and the course of Middle East relations have been transformed since his only other visit to the United States, when he came to the United Nations in 1974, his black leather pistol holder on his hip, and said, "I come with an olive branch in one hand and a freedom fighter's gun in the other."
Although Mr. Arafat wore military fatigues and his pistol as he boarded a Moroccan Government Boeing 707 in Tunis today, he emerged wearing an olive military dress jacket and trousers, a tan open-collared shirt and his trademark black and white kaffiyeh and ascot. No pistol was visible.
Mr. Arafat had been advised by friends not to wear his pistol, and Washington informed him to come unarmed to the White House for the ceremony, a senior Administration official said. "It is a longstanding policy of the White House that firearms are not allowed," the official said. "That applies to everybody."
After the ceremony, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Rabin will meet at the White House, and Mr. Christopher will receive Mr. Arafat at the State Department.
"An awful lot of taboos are being broken in the last few days," said Mr. Christopher, whose closest encounter with Mr. Arafat was passing him in a motorcade in Alexandria, Egypt, last month. "We're all blinking our eyes at how much is new."
The White House and State Department insisted that Mr. Clinton's decision not to meet privately with Mr. Arafat was not intended to be a rebuff.
"Given our special relationship with Israel, it is natural for the President to see Rabin, a head of state with which we've had long and important relations," a senior Administration official said. "We're just beginning our dialogue with the P.L.O., and we are doing it in a dramatic way."
President Clinton, in an interview in Monday's Washington Post, called on Mr. Arafat to condemn the attacks by Palestinian militants who killed four Israelis earlier today.
Former President Jimmy Carter met with Mr. Arafat soon after he arrived at his hotel, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the civil rights leader and a long-time champion of the Palestinian cause, also visited him.
 
Some Hatchets Unburied
 Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin dispelled any notion that they had buried all their hatchets.
While praising the agreement before leaving Tunis, Mr. Arafat also told reporters that it would pave the way to "an independent Palestinian state, with Jerusalem as its capital."
"He can forget about it," Mr. Rabin retorted when told of Mr. Arafat's prediction. He said that "Jerusalem will remain always united under Israel's sovereignty and our capital forever."
The White House went into protocol overdrive today as hundreds of bureaucrats and Secret Service agents struggled to complete arrangements for a ceremony that White House officials describe as an ever-moving target and the largest security challenge in American history.
 
3,000 Folding Chairs
 Three thousand white plastic folding chairs were positioned on the South Lawn of the White House, where the 535 members of Congress and their spouses, Cabinet members, 10 Foreign Ministers, the Washington diplomatic corps, former Presidents and Secretaries of State, leaders of American Jewish and Arab groups and other dignitaries from around the world have been invited to witness the ceremony.
Mr. Carter, who brokered the agreement that brought peace between Israel and Egypt in 1979, will attend, as will former President George Bush, whose Administration succeeded in creating a framework for peace talks that began in Madrid 22 months ago.
 
Dinner Plans Change
 The White House initially had planned to hold a black-tie dinner Monday night for about 120 people, who would have included the Israeli and Palestinian delegations and the Foreign Ministers. But Mr. Rabin and Mr. Peres, who are trying to weather a political crisis at home, declined, saying their presence was needed at a Parliament session on Tuesday. That means that Mr. Arafat will be left to make his own dinner plans.
The White House dinner will now exclude the delegations and will honor the former Presidents and Secretaries of State instead, a senior Administration official said.
Before Monday's ceremony, Mr. Arafat and Mr. Abbas on the P.L.O. side and Mr. Rabin and Mr. Peres on the Israeli side will sign the White House guest book before Mr. Clinton greets them in the Blue Room along with Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia, co-sponsor of the American-led peace talks, Mr. Christopher, Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Carter Mr. Bush.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, after landing at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington yesterday. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A1)
 
Chart: "Highlights of the Peace Agreement"
 The main points of the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord, which is to be signed in Washington today:
 
PALESTINIAN AUTONOMY
 The agreement calls for a five-year period of limited autonomy for Palestinians in the occupied territories, beginning in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho. Before the beginning of the third year, the two sides are to begin negotiating a permanent accord.
 
ISRAELI WITHDRAWAL
 Israeli forces are to withdraw from Palestinian areas of the Gaza Strip, from the town of Jericho, probably defined along municipal borders, and from population centers in the West Bank within four months of the signing of the agreement. The extent of the troop withdrawal, and the spheres of control between Israel and the Palestinians, are vague.
 
ELECTIONS
 Within nine months, Palestinians are to hold elections for a municipal council to oversee education, economic development, environmental protection, taxes, and social welfare.
 
SECURITY
 The Palestinians are to form a police force. Its responsibilities, including its relationship with Israeli forces, is to be determined.
 
RESOLUTION OF DISPUTES
 Disputes between Israel and Palestinians are to be settled by a joint committee, or referred to an arbitration committee if both sides agree.
 
SETTLEMENTS
 Israel is to continue to provide protection to Israeli settlers living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The agreement is vague on how Israelis will protect settlers, particularly when they are outside of their settlements.
 
REFUGEES
 The agreement provides for discussion of the method of return for the nearly 200,000 Palestinians who fled the West Bank and Gaza during the 1967 war. It does not guarantee their return, and it puts off discussion of refugees who left in 1948 until the final negotiations on a permanent accord.
 
JERUSALEM
 The future of Jerusalem, claimed by both Israel and the Palestinians as their eternal capital, was postponed until the final negotiations.
 
ECONOMIC AID
 The agreement calls for the establishment of a joint Israel-Palestinian Economic Cooperation Committee to carry out economic development programs for the Gaza Strip and West Bank.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
INDUSTRY SEES HINT OF SLOWER GROWTH IN HEALTH SPENDING

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
After years of startling increases, the growth in health spending unexpectedly appears to have relented somewhat over the last 12 months, according to unpublished data from insurance companies, employers and hospitals.
The signs of a slowdown in medical costs, which have surged by about 11 percent annually over the last five years, are scattered and too recent to show up in official national statistics. And despite new evidence of restraint, the growth remains head-turning, certainly far above the growth in total spending in the economy, which is now around 5 percent. That means health care will continue to consume an ever-greater share of the gross national product. 
 While the country has seen health spending dip temporarily before, only to resume wild growth, many health industry officials and economists say the current slowdown at least partly reflects long-term changes in the way medical care is organized, changes that are pulling down prices and boosting efficiency.
 
Advantage for Clinton
 Other factors may be the recession and self-imposed restraint on price increases by doctors, hospitals and drug companies hoping to forestall severe Federal restrictions.
If the slowdown proves lasting it would be a boon for President Clinton, in helping him keep his vow to tame a health-care dragon that is expected to consume more than $900 billion this year. The rise is driven mainly by higher prices, increased use of medical services, new technologies and the growth and aging of the population.
Federal agencies have projected that medical spending in the next several years will grow 10 percent to 15 percent annually. But the emerging data are raising questions. "What I'm seeing suggests that those projections may be unduly pessimistic," said Charles T. Bell, senior vice president of Aetna Health Plans in Hartford, who described the decline in growth within his company's health plans as several percentage points.
Still, health economists warn that medical inflation has proved to be tenacious. "I've been in the field long enough to be rather skeptical" about such short-term declines, said Daniel R. Waldo, deputy director of the Office of National Health Statistics in the Department of Health and Human Services. The most recent figures on health spending his office has are for 1991.
"But we're also on the verge of a sea change," he added. "And sea changes sometimes fool the experts."
Mr. Clinton hopes by late in the decade to bring growth in health spending in line with growth in the economy. His proposals would encourage competition among health providers and, if that fails to do the job, would impose Federal caps on insurance premiums. To the extent that health expenses are already slowing, the task should be easier, though a wide gap remains between his goal and even the most encouraging recent data.
 
Signs of a Slowdown
 But already, it appears certain that many buyers of health insurance will face less steep rate increases in the coming months than they have become accustomed to.
The signs of a slowdown come mainly from private insurance companies and employers who pay for health benefits, which collectively cover about one-third of the country's health costs. Private plans have long faced much faster price escalation than the average. This is in part because doctors and hospitals heap extra charges on the privately insured to make up for the lower payment they get for patients in the Medicaid and Medicare programs and to pay for patients without insurance at all.
Using the past as a guide, many employers who offer health benefits had budgeted spending increases of 15 percent to 18 percent for 1993, said David Wilson, chief actuary for health with Foster Higgins, a consulting firm that advises major insurers and hundreds of employers around the country.
But since early 1992, costs have instead grown at about 8 percent to 12 percent, he said, and as little as 6 percent in a few cases where workers have joined health maintenance organizations. "I think the downward trend has accelerated in the last 12 months," he added.
Many large insurers have also seen a recent, unexpected drop in claims for hospital and doctor fees and prescription drugs. Early last winter, actuaries at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York projected that the percentage growth in benefit claims in 1993 for its one million individual and small-group contracts would be in the "mid teens," in keeping with several previous years, said Michael Blumenfeld, a company spokesman. But in the first seven months, claims have been running "roughly half that, in the high single digits."
"This should bode well for the size of rate increases for our customers," Mr. Blumenfeld said.
Aetna, a national insurer that covers 13 million people, has experienced a less steep but significant falloff in the total cost of claims since early 1992. "The decline has been consistent and gradual," Mr. Bell said. "I think it's been particularly evident over the last 9 months."
For most of its clients, the company was used to seeing annual percentage increases in claims in the "low 20's," Mr. Bell said, but over the last 18 months that has fallen to the "high teens." For the four million clients in its health maintenance organizations, percentage growth in spending that had been in the "low to mid teens" has declined to the 10 to 12 range, and in some cases lower, he said.
Prodded by insurers and squeezed by government programs, many hospitals have begun reorganizing to save money by sharing costly equipment, using cheaper drugs and shortening hospital stays. In the first three months of 1993 average hospital expenditures per patient, adjusted for the kind of care provided, rose by 6.2 percent over the same period in 1992. In recent years the growth was 8 percent to 10 percent, according to data compiled by the American Hospital Association.
"Let's be clear: we're still going up, but it's moderating quite a bit," said James Bentley, senior vice president for policy with the hospital association. "The question is whether this is long-term or a blip."
 
H.M.O.'s and a Slump
 Experts attribute the slowing to three major factors. First, with politicians and patients alike glaring at medical costs, many doctors and hospitals appear to be holding down price increases; leading drug companies have pledged publicly to do so. As Mr. Blumenfeld put it, "They all want to stay off of Hillary's list of who is responsible for high costs."
Whether these self-imposed restraints represent a lasting commitment is unclear, and there are doubters. But experts also say that a multitude of changes in the way doctors and hospitals are organized and paid, under the heading of managed care, is wringing waste from the medical system and forcing providers to be more frugal.
By 1992, 41.4 million Americans were enrolled in health maintenance organizations, and many more were in plans involving some oversight. "The world is changing to managed care and it's proving to be effective," said Mr. Bell of Aetna.
A third factor of unknown importance is the sluggish economy, which may to some degree have reduced elective medical procedures and deterred some construction by hospitals.
The recent experience of Federal medical programs, which account for 4 in 10 of the nation's health dollars, has been mixed. Medicare and Medicaid, the main programs, pay preset prices to doctors and hospitals that are already below the average in the private sector, and their short-term spending trends are less a reflection of the marketplace than of government policies.
Spending for doctors services by Medicare, which serves the elderly and disabled, has been lower than projected in the 1992 and 1993 fiscal years, for undetermined reasons. But those gains have been offset by a climb above projections in hospital bills.
Spending this year for Medicaid, the program for the poor, appears likely to come in under the projected amount, congressional analysts said, but for reasons more to do with changes in law than medical practices.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: Doctors and Insurers Say Program Would Tread Too Heavily on Their Turfs;
Cap on Premiums Is Seen as Stifling Real Competition

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
The nation's big health insurance companies, who would be central players in President Clinton's plan for overhauling the health care system, say the Administration has taken a perfectly good idea called managed competition and turned it into something more like managed condescension.
In their first reaction to a working draft of the Clinton plan, executives of leading health insurance companies said last weekend that two crucial elements of the plan -- ceilings on insurers' premiums and the powers given to the insurance purchasing groups at the center of the plan -- would leave lumbering government agencies, rather than consumers, to choose what kind of health care Americans receive. 
 Even the large companies that were expected to benefit most, like Prudential, Cigna, Aetna and Metropolitan Life, say the purchasing groups, or health alliances, as envisioned, would make real competition impossible.
 
'Wolf at Their Door'
 Such criticism of the Clinton plan is arguably self-serving, since insurers' profits depend on how much they can charge in premiums. But several experts on the subject said yesterday that the criticism reflected a concern shared by economists that excessive regulation on insurance premiums would make innovation in the entire health care marketplace impossible.
"What might happen if you have too tight a cap on insurance company premiums is that their profit margins get wiped out," said Uwe D. Reinhardt, a professor of political economy at Princeton University and a medical economist. "The whole health care sector is the biggest wolf crier you have ever seen. But every so often there is really a wolf at their door."
Paul Ellwood, a physician and health economist who is considered the father of managed competition, said he found many aspects of the plan workable and found it a good basis for discussions with Congress. But he said he, too, was troubled by the ceilings on premiums.
"What I am afraid of is that the Government becomes the market and not the public, and that ceilings on premiums set by Government will become the floor that everyone will charge," he said. "I think it is appropriate for Government set a certain date for health costs to be growing at the same rate as the rest of the economy. But this plan makes it too soon."
The health insurers' concerns were not shared throughout the industry. Spokesmen for leading providers of automobile and workers compensation insurance, including the largest, State Farm, generally praised the plan's final draft, which was disclosed Friday.
 
Corporations Divided
 The plan left other sectors of corporate America divided, as it has been for months over the effort to overhaul health care.
The National Federation of Independent Business, representing tens of thousands of small companies, many of whom do not provide health insurance for their employees, has emerged as the major opponent in the business community.
The federation is mainly opposed to the requirement that all employers would have to insure their workers. John Motley, a federation vice president, said that to offset the costs employers would have to cut wages, shrink other fringe benefits, raise prices, cut profits or do a little of each.
The National Association of Manufacturers, on the other hand, favors the Clinton proposal, with some reservations, as the best way to lower the health insurance premiums of its 12,000 members, most of whom have company policies for their workers.
Gerald Mossinghoff, the president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, which represents more than 100 drug companies, said he was disturbed by a provision giving the Secretary of Health and Human Services the power to deny reimbursement for a new drug by Medicaid if the price was deemed excessive. He said it would have a devastating effect on the biotechnology industry and a "chilling effect on venture capital."
The draft of the plan says the Federal Government would enforce a national health care budget by regulating the annual increase in premiums that could be charged for private health insurance. From 1994 to 2000, the President says the growth of private spending would be cut in half.
The regional health alliances, which would bargain on behalf of consumers with insurance companies and other operators of health networks, like health maintenance organizations, would decide which health plans would be offered in a form of a menu mailed out once a year.
The variety of choices, according to the theory of managed competition, would allow the public to determine which health networks provide the right combination of high quality and low price. Operators of the networks would figure out new ways to force prices down and quality up.
Wall Street analysts say that among the biggest winners under such a system of alliances would be five giant insurance companies that have invested most heavily in managed care systems, Prudential, Cigna, Aetna, Metropolitan Life and Travelers, as well as the nation's 69 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
But leading insurance executives said yesterday that certain aspects of the draft caused them great dismay.
The Administration would give the alliances the power to exclude health care networks whose proposed premiums exceeded the average of all other plans in their region by more than 20 percent. The draft also envisions that the alliances would limit annual premium increases. Beginning in 1996, the limits on increases would be that of the Consumer Price Index plus population growth and 1.5 percent. The allowable increase above the index would decline by 0.5 percent for each of the next three years.
"If you believe in the market, you believe customers will make the trade- offs between how much they will pay for quality care and how much they will be willing to go to the low-cost plan," said Michael Stocker, the president of Cigna Health Plans. "There are so many good ideas in the Clinton proposal, but this shows a fundamental distrust of the market."
 
Frozen Out of Market
 Thomas O. Pyle, the chief executive of Metropolitan Life's health care division, said the proposal would mean that plans that are initially expensive would simply be frozen out of the market and would die. But a company with a brilliant new idea for delivering care might have high capital costs in the first few years, he added, on its way to becoming the least expensive.
It could also put a chill, executives said, on investment into new managed care systems.
Mary Nell Lehnard, the senior vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association in Washington, said the budgets of some alliances would be bigger than those of some state governments. Since the alliances would require huge Federal subsidies, he said, the temptation of Congress would be to ratchet down premium increases ever further as it struggled to reduce the Federal deficit.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
AN UNUSUAL PRIMARY CAN SHAPE NOVEMBER
New York City headed into an unusual Democratic primary, the first time in decades that the battle for the Democratic mayoral nomination has been overshadowed by November's general election. As the candidates raced through last-minute appearances, campaign managers and political strategists predicted a desultory Primary Day with a turnout so low as to confound predictions in the races for Comptroller and Public Advocate, whose outcome could affect the dynamics of what is expected to be a bruising confrontation between Mayor David N. Dinkins and the Republican-Liberal candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani. A1.
 
COMPTROLLER UNDER FIRE
Two days before a Democratic primary that has emerged as the most contested race in the city, and at the end of a week in which she broke down in tears when asked to sum up her career, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman found herself under fire from former Representative Herman Badillo and Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi in the final debate of the campaign. Questions focused on her refusal to allow the lease of an official city report on a loan to her Senate campaign. B3.
 

BADILLO: SUCCESS EVEN IN LOSING
On the final weekend before the Democratic primary, Herman Badillo can afford to feel light-footed. He is guaranteed a spot on the November ballot as part of the fusion ticket led by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for Mayor. For Mr. Badillo, there can be success even in losing if he draws loyal Democrats, the type who typically vote in the primaries, into Mr. Giuliani's fold. "We feel the better Herman Badillo does, the better it is for the whole ticket," said Mr. Giuliani, who has invested a lot of money and staff time in the Badillo campaign, hoping that it will swing Hispanic voters away from Mayor David N. Dinkins. B3.
 
WORDS, FEELINGS AND RACE
"More Than Words," the title of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's latest book, might also sum up the 1993 mayoral campaign in New York City, except that the candidates' words have been less eloquent or consistent than Mr. Cuomo's. Most of their words may prove to be much less vital in this election than the unspoken way that people feel. And some of those feelings, political observers concede, reflect the race of the voters and the candidates. Metro Matters. B2.
 
A TROUBLED FAMILY MEETS
The annual gathering of the National Baptist Convention, which brought almost 50,000 pastors and church members to New York City last week, has the mood of a gigantic family reunion. But it was a family burdened with a sense of urgency. Virtually no session or sermon at the meeting, which opened Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, passed without pleas for action on the ills troubling black America: inner-city crime, drugs, AIDS, teen-age pregnancies and unemployment. B4.
 
FATAL STABBING IN SUBWAY STATION
A man was fatally stabbed and robbed in a subway station in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Saturday night in full view of a token booth clerk and other witnesses. The Transit Police said the victim had just pocketed the winnings from video gambling games in a grocery store above the station, and his assailant had followed him into the subway. A suspect was arrested. B4.
 
REGION
 
GREAT HOPES IN WESTCHESTER
This should be a time of great expectations for the Democrats of Westchester County. As they cast their votes in the primary tomorrow, they can take comfort that they now outnumber Republicans in this traditionally Republican county. And for the first time in generations, they have a solid chance to win the county's top two posts. Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican County Executive for the last 11 years, is vulnerable. And Carl A. Vergari, the District Attorney for 25 years, is retiring. B5.
 
FIRST TROOPER CASE GOES TO TRIAL
A New York State Police investigator charged with faking evidence in two criminal cases goes on trial today in Binghamton, becoming the first of five investigators to challenge the charges in a growing scandal. Prosecutors say the investigators waited for their colleagues to identify suspects, then claimed to have found evidence linking those suspects to crime scenes, thus earning respect and praise on the job. B5.

HEADLINE: Confusion Ruled First Tests For Asbestos, Workers Say

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
It started with a growing public panic over the dangers of asbestos -- fears that led a jumpy Congress to pass a law in 1986 requiring asbestos inspections of schools nationwide.
But the Federal rules putting the law into effect were sloppily written and confusing. And the New York City Board of Education soon made a bad situation worse, jury-rigging a plan for inspections and hiring a consulting firm with no track record in the field. 
 In the end, New York's inspection effort careered into a complete debacle, with gangs of inexperienced workers racing frantically through the city's 1,069 schools, collecting only a fraction of the asbestos samples needed and dashing off reports that turned out to be totally unreliable.
That is the picture that emerges from interviews with members of the school board's Asbestos Task Force -- none of whom have spoken publicly of their work before -- and from inspection records at several city schools and interviews with city, state and Federal officials.
 
'An Accumulation of Problems'
 "There was an accumulation of problems," said an engineer who was a member of the city's task force when it carried out the federally mandated survey. "Grab 100 people off the street, make them inspectors after a few days' training, give them no supervision, and they won't do the job right. I never felt comfortable that the work would be of good quality."
After inspections this summer turned up asbestos in buildings reported to be clean in the original surveys, Mayor David N. Dinkins on Aug. 6 ordered all the city's schools reinspected immediately. That enormous undertaking has delayed the opening of schools, disrupted the families of a million schoolchildren, cost tens of millions of dollars and further weakened public faith in the nation's largest public school system.
Some experts have questioned whether the dangers from asbestos are as critical or widespread as Congress believed when the 1986 law was passed. And other school districts nationwide have apparently also had trouble complying with the Federal regulations. A 1991 study by the Environmental Protection Agency found that nationwide, inspectors missed about 11 percent of all the asbestos in schools, and that in 82 percent of the 85,000 buildings inspected, inspectors missed at least one asbestos deposit.
Since Aug. 6, the 53 members of the Asbestos Task Force have been reassigned to temporary duties unrelated to asbestos and barred by supervisors and by their union from speaking publicly. Until now, none have.
But in recent weeks, three of them, speaking on the condition of anonymity in separate interviews, offered the first direct accounts of the original troubled effort. They said it was marred by staff discord, equipment that malfunctioned and, perhaps most important, fundamental confusion over how to carry out the inspections.
"At that time, nobody knew what they were doing," said one inspector who helped survey some 70 schools. "We had to learn everything as we went along." Investigators from six different agencies are seeking to determine whether fraud or other crimes also played a role. So far, no one has been charged. But even if the officials or consultants involved in the original inspections are found to have engaged in intentional wrongdoing, the effort was doomed from the start as error piled upon error.
 
A Challenging Inspection
 After Congress passed the Asbestos Hazard Emergency Response Act of 1986, known as Ahera, all of the nation's 40,000 school districts were required to designate one local official to oversee a complete inventory of the asbestos in their buildings and to develop plans to eliminate hazards.
In New York City, that official was Robert Pardi, an architect from the board's division of school buildings. Appointed just months earlier to head the asbestos task force, Mr. Pardi had virtually no background with asbestos inspections and only limited administrative experience. Yet the asbestos-testing effort required him, almost overnight, to quintuple the size of his staff and to administer one of the most challenging building inspections in city history.
Mr. Pardi rejected repeated requests for an interview delivered by telephone and in person to his Long Island home in recent weeks.
In 1988 board officials signed a $1.4 million contract with a company then known as Envirosafe Corporation -- now called Envirospan Safety Corporation -- to design the survey and to train and supervise the inspectors. Envirosafe was a small asbestos-cleanup company that until then had no experience in conducting large, complex inspections. An investigator said choosing Envirosafe was like hiring a carpenter instead of an architect to draw the blueprints for a building.
In early 1988 Mr. Pardi interviewed hundreds of applicants for the inspector jobs, and hired 26 men. Most were foreign-born and unemployed, though many had training as engineers; virtually none had asbestos experience. One inspector said his starting salary was about $26,000.
 
A Five-Day Workshop
 The training came at Envirosafe's Manhattan headquarters on West 39th Street, where an official lectured for three days on sampling techniques and for two more on how to draw up plans for managing hazardous asbestos found in schools.
The training appears to have been similar to that offered to inspectors elsewhere in the country, and the Environmental Protection Agency approved the course. But some asbestos experts have questioned how well prepared inspectors certified in a five-day workshop could be.
"To come up with an asbestos inventory for a school building is a tremendously complex task," said Dwight E. Brown, a former regional coordinator in Atlanta for the Environmental Protection Agency who now runs his own asbestos consulting concern. "The suggestion that a person with a few days of training can go out and do this work is completely laughable. It ain't for novices."
In fact, the inspectors said that they learned most of their techniques on the job once the survey got under way in the summer of 1988. One inspector said his first experience came at a Manhattan high school, where he joined five other novices working under the supervision of another, slightly more experienced inspector hired weeks earlier.
 
Learning to Collect Samples
 Working through classrooms and hallways, he learned how to collect samples, using a brass core-bore and other tools to gouge or burrow into plaster, lathe or other building materials. He would patch the resulting holes with glue or duct tape once the sample was taken. The samples were put into plastic bags, labeled and sent to laboratories for analysis.
But many of the workers appeared to misunderstand the purpose of the sampling, the inspector said. Asbestos is found in hundreds of building materials, from boiler insulation to roofing tiles to the fireproofing sprayed onto ceiling ducts. Collecting samples from many of these is relatively straightforward, but plaster walls and ceilings -- where much of the asbestos is being found in the current inspection -- present complications. Just knowing where to sample, so that an accurate map of the hidden asbestos emerges, is not easy.
For decades, wall masons added asbestos to wall and ceiling plaster as a bonding agent, in concentrations that often varied widely from batch to batch. So the asbestos content of plaster at one end of a corridor wall may be well below the Federal limit of 1 percent while concentrations at the other end may be far higher. Remodeled schools pose special challenges, because although walls in old and new wings may look identical beneath a new paint job, their asbestos content may differ greatly.
 
Sampling Method Faulted
 The process is so tricky that experienced asbestos technicians recommend that any methodical inspection begin with a study of building plans and interviews with custodians or others who may know the structure's construction history.
Many Ahera inspectors, however, saw the project as a simple harvesting of samples, a member of the task force said. "They would go into a school, just grab a few rooms and take some wall samples," the task force member said. "If there was any single thing that went wrong with this program, it was the sampling method."
Part of the misunderstanding appears to have arisen from the 1987 E.P.A. regulations themselves, which required that a legal minimum of seven samples be collected from any wall, ceiling, or other surface area that was "uniform in color and texture" and was larger than 5,000 square feet. In scores of city schools, many of which have been rebuilt one or more times and may have 300,000 square feet or more of wall space, inspectors collected the legal minimum of just seven plaster wall samples, the records show.
 
Not Enough Samples
 Joseph S. Carra, a deputy director at the E.P.A., said in an interview that only a misreading of the regulations could have led to the routine collection of so few samples in such large schools. But the procedure appears to have been codified in the board's contract with Envirosafe, which set the average number of samples to be collected -- from all building materials that might contain asbestos in each school -- at just 30.
"That would be about right for Little House on the Prairie," said Bernard P. Orlan, the top asbestos expert at the School Construction Authority. In contrast, inspectors working on the authority's reinspection effort have collected as many as 300 samples in some schools.
Even those original inspectors who understood the process often had trouble, however. In each report, inspectors were supposed to pinpoint locations of the samples they took, using X-Y coordinates on a diagram. But the cheap compasses issued to them frequently didn't work. Some inspectors sought to orient themselves with street maps, and there was plenty of margin for confusion.
"A guy might call a wall north, and it might be south," one inspector said. That may explain why investigators in June found some Ahera reports in which the coordinates intersected in illogical places, even outside of buildings.
 
Insufficient Supervision
 Competent supervision might have prevented such errors, but inspectors said the project never had any. The contract required Envirosafe to "supervise (with three industrial hygienists) a thorough and complete asbestos survey of all spaces within each school building."
But Philip E. Klein, a lawyer for Envirospan Safety Corporation, the company's current name, argued that the company's responsibilities did not include supervision.
Mr. Pardi also offered little direct supervision, the inspectors said. The headquarters for the survey were set up at 49 Flatbush Extension in Brooklyn, but Mr. Pardi maintained his office at building division headquarters in Long Island City, visited the Brooklyn offices only occasionally and never went to schools, the inspectors said.
"Pardi came over sometimes," one said. "He'd stop by the office to lend us some support, to tell us we were doing a good job."
The inspectors said it was difficult to tell who was in charge at the Ahera offices during much of the project, partly because of staff turnover. The top Envirosafe official at the Brooklyn offices quit in a salary dispute before the project was finished, the inspectors said, and Mr. Pardi's top aide was often absent, caring for an ailing wife.
The last months of the project were dominated by a frantic rush to meet the May 1989 deadline. Inspection crews worked 14-hour days for several months, earning tremendous amounts of overtime. Entire high schools, with 300 or more rooms, were "inspected" in as little as one day.
"There was panic," one task force member recalled. "Everybody was running like crazy."
The enormousness of the current reinspection effort has raised concerns that errors made during the original survey could be repeated. But Meyer S. Frucher, a trustee of the School Construction Authority, the state agency leading it, said: "We too are working under extraordinary pressure, but we've thrown enormous resources into this up front, and we have built major quality controls into our process."

HEADLINE: A Killer in Law School: Admirable or Abominable?

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz., Sept. 10

 BODY:
If ever there was a model prisoner it was James J. Hamm, who mortally shot a man during a drug deal in 1974, pleaded guilty against the advice of his lawyer and spent the next 18 years in state prison "shaken to my moral core and determined to build a new way of looking at myself and the world."
While others lifted weights and fashioned zip guns, Mr. Hamm studied Jungian psychology, sociology and Taoism. He enrolled in stress management classes and meditation groups and every other self-improvement program the Department of Corrections had to offer. 
 He earned a summa cum laude college degree while in prison, passed the law boards with a score in the top 4 percent and won the admiration of professors who count him among their best students ever and guards who had never urged early release for anyone else before or since.
Now, a year after his life sentence was commuted, Mr. Hamm, 45, is a first-year law student at Arizona State University, an exemplar to some and an abomination to others. And his presence at the College of Law here has stirred a debate about whether a convicted first-degree murderer has any right to attend a tax-supported law school or has any real hope of admission to the state bar.
But the debate is less about Mr. Hamm's worthiness, experts say, than about America's frustration with the criminal justice system and ambivalence regarding crime and punishment, vengeance and mercy.
Mr. Hamm is a "lightning rod" for these issues, said John M. Johnson, a professor of justice studies at the university here, who taught Mr. Hamm inside the prison a decade ago. And the case, he said, "reflects a millenium-old conflict in our culture, between the idea of unforgiving punishment as expressed in the Old Testament and the hope of rebirth as expressed in the New Testament."
 
What Should Society Do?
 Mr. Hamm is composed amid the clamor and convinced that his situation is raising important questions.
"What does our society want to do with people who have served their sentences?" he asked. "Do we block them and frustrate them? And what about rehabilitation? Do we believe in it? And how do we accomplish it?"
Arizona, like all but six other states, does not bar convicted felons, murderers among them, from admission to the bar. But they face a higher-than-average hurdle when they go before the Character and Fitness Committee.
"I understand up front I'll have a more difficult time meeting their standard, but I'm not daunted by that at all," said Mr. Hamm, who cannot vote, own a gun or work as a stockbroker or a barber in Arizona because he is a felon on lifetime parole. "And if I can't be a lawyer I'll do something else, because what I'm about now is doing something with my life."
A half-dozen convicted felons are members of the Arizona bar, officials say, although none are murderers. But even murderers practice law elsewhere, one of them before the Federal bar in the District of Columbia.
Mr. Hamm's record, including a 3.964 grade-point average, won him admission here, one of 161 first-year students chosen from 2,300 applications. "He had every right to apply to our law school and then every right to a meaningful consideration of his application," said the law school dean, Richard J. Morgan.
 
A 'Kinky Candidate'
 Several legislators and editorial writers in Arizona disagreed. John Greene, the president of the State Senate and a proponent of capital punishment, argued that Mr. Hamm's "precious seat should go to one of the thousands of applicants who didn't shoot somebody in the head." And The Phoenix Gazette complained in an editorial about "liberal academics" who considered it a "dangerous thrill" to admit a "kinky candidate" like Mr. Hamm.
Since Mr. Hamm's admission, Dean Morgan has faced threats from some top legislators that the law school, one of two in the Arizona system, might lose its annual $4 million in state financing or even be closed. And the dean has agreed to review admission policies regarding convicted felons, although he said he did not expect them to be disqualified.
Mr. Hamm did not hide his past on his application, which he larded with references to his time behind bars, citing awards for tutoring other prisoners and work as an inmate legal assistant. "I don't want to put it behind me," he said. "I want to bring it with me. It's who I am, the foundation on which my personality is based."
In the application, Mr. Hamm also highlighted the half dozen lawsuits against the Department of Corrections that he has researched, filed and won along with his wife of five years, Donna Leone Hamm. Mrs. Hamm is a former justice of the peace here, who met her husband during a prison tour and founded an organization that provides legal advice and counseling to inmates and their families.
Over the several years that the two courted in the prison's visiting room, Mr. Hamm told his wife-to-be of his Kansas childhood: his eight siblings; his father, an itinerant wheat cutter, and his mother, who dominated the family and whose death sent him reeling toward an emotional breakdown.
He told her of his time in Bible college, where he was indifferent about academics and later lost his faith, and of his brief, failed first marriage. He told her how he drifted out to Arizona, unemployed and irresponsible, and wound up dealing $10 bags of marijuana to college students in Tucson.
 
A Story of a Murder
 And he told her about the Saturday in September nearly two decades ago when he crossed the line from being a small-time drug dealer, who spent most of his days stoned, to a murderer who agreed to help an acquaintance rob two young men of $1,400 by luring them into a bogus drug deal.
The two victims were in the front seat of the car and the two gunmen in the back as they drove out to the barren reaches of the city. "I wanted to tell them to stop the car so I could get out, and just run away, but I'd open my mouth and nothing would come out," Mr. Hamm said.
The car grew thick with tension as it became clear that no drugs would change hands, Mr. Hamm said. In the back seat beside him, his acquaintance drew his semiautomatic pistol. Mesmerized, Mr. Hamm watched his own hand pull a .38-caliber revolver from inside his shirt. "In the next three seconds, many shots were fired," he said. "Many, many shots."
The racket of bullets deafened him and he felt "like a stick of dynamite had gone off in my mind." He remembers firing the gun but not deciding to fire it. He killed the driver with two quick bullets to the head. The other gunman, who remains in prison, wounded the second young man, then chased him from the car and finished him off in the desert.
Mr. Hamm said the horror of what he had done "shook my mental house down." He now says he had a nervous breakdown that expressed itself in "a criminal context because of the life I was living."
But he never considered an insanity plea, Mr. Hamm said, because only by acknowledging his guilt could he begin the process of self-discovery and perhaps redemption.
"This was not a legal issue to me," he said. "I had to find some meaning for the death I caused. I can only pay in the coin I have. My acts have been acts of atonement and will be for the rest of my life."
 
A Life of Self-Control
 This is the story that Mr. Hamm now tells his fellow law students, who have welcomed him. They are tentatively coming to know the soft-spoken man in their midst who does not have the tattoos or bulging muscles they expected of an ex-prisoner.
"When you hear him talk about how he feels about what he did, how it pretty much crumbled who he was, it's hard to put that together with the picture of a hardened killer," said Richard Traulsen, student body president at the law school.
Having once lost control so completely, Mr. Hamm now minds his every move. His wife describes him as "excessively meticulous," a man who mows the lawn as if his life depended on each and every blade of grass, who never fails to take his shoes off before putting his feet on the coffee table.
"I'm not dangerous today because I pay attention to what's happening in my life and my psyche," Mr. Hamm said, comparing himself to the brimming serving of iced tea in front of him. "It's like emptying the glass at the right time so it doesn't overflow."
Mr. Hamm agrees that in the annals of crime, punishment and rehabilitation he is special because he had the intellect and resourcefulness to make the most of his opportunities in prison. But he insists he is not alone.
"There are many people in prison who swim against the tide," Mr. Hamm said. "What's unusual is how far upstream I was able to swim, with the help of others."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: Jordan;
Jordan and Israel in Accord On Agenda for Negotiations

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Senior officials in Jordan have for the first time outlined the basis of planned negotiations with Israel in a detailed agenda that has been approved by both countries.
The agenda is the first step toward the establishment of diplomatic relations and a peace treaty between Israel and Jordan, according to a draft copy of the document obtained in Amman. 
 The final document, which will not be made public until Tuesday but bears a close resemblance to the draft, senior Government officials say, will be formally accepted by the Israelis and the Jordanians after the White House meeting between Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian Liberation Organization chairman, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.
Jordanian officials said that the country's delegation to Mideast peace talks in Washington would not sign any document with Israeli officials. They did say that the Jordanian delegation might be allowed to initial the agenda with their Israeli counterparts.
 
Officials 'Optimistic'
 The agenda calls for a series of agreements on water resources, boundary disputes, the plight of the 1.5 million Palestinian refugees in Jordan, and the dismantling of weapons of mass destruction.
Jordanian officials said they and the Israelis had delayed endorsing the agenda for several months until the Palestinians and Israelis concluded their own agreement.
These officials said they were "optimistic" about resolving the outstanding issues, but cautioned that it would take two or three years to bring about peace between the two neighboring countries for the first time in 45 years.
Any actual peace treaty, they said, would be signed only after the Palestinians had complete sovereignty over the territory they controlled in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
But senior Jordanian officials, while disconcerted about being left out of the secret Israeli-Palestinian talks in Norway, said that the direct talks between the P.L.O. and Israel would allow Jordan to push ahead, unencumbered by the Palestinians, to resolve a series of bilateral issues with Israel. The Palestinian representatives to the formal talks were part of the Jordanian delegation.
 
'The Toughest Issue'
 "The Israeli-Palestinian agreement is a tremendous breakthrough which will leave Jordan freer of Palestinian constraint in its policy making," said Crown Prince Hassan, the brother of King Hussein and heir to the throne. "I say this because we have held the agenda for up to a year now."
Jordanian officials said the most difficult dispute facing the two countries was the repatriation of the 1.5 million Palestinian refugees in Jordan.
"The toughest issue will be the status of the refugees," Jowad al-Anani, the Minister of State for the Prime Minister's office, said today. "The Israelis see the option of allowing the refugees to go back to Israel, to live under Israeli rule, as suicidal."
But Jordanian officials insist that they cannot be expected to continue to absorb the cost of housing and maintaining such a huge refugee population. They say that any bilateral agreement must contain some solution to the problem, especially for the one million or so Palestinians and their descendants who left homes inside Israel after the 1948 war.
"Jordan is not simply a host country for Palestinian refugees," the Crown Prince said on Saturday, seated in a small office in the palace. "We have absorbed the effect of three waves of migration and our economic and social development has been shaped by the conflict. The question of the future of Jordan's demography is a question of the future of Jordan's sovereignty."
 
'A Very Thorny Issue'
 There are other difficult issues that must be hammered out between the Israelis and Jordanians, including the Dimona nuclear power plant near the Jordanian border, the refusal to allow Jordanian exports into the occupied territories, the allocation of scarce water resources and the final demarcation of the common frontier.
"There are two or three security dimensions," Mr. Anani said. "We have to prevent infiltration across the border, discuss the positioning of troops and not intervene in each other's business. Jordan will also raise a very thorny issue as far as Israel is concerned, and that is the Dimona nuclear reactor, which is near the Jordanian border. We do not want another Chernobyl."
The Jordanians say the Israelis, however, insist that the reactor is part of Israel's defense program, established to counter a threat from countries that have advanced nuclear weapons programs, like Iraq and Iran.
"When you talk about nuclear or mass destruction weapons that Israel is producing, the Israelis expand the geographical configuration where Israeli security is concerned," Mr. Anani said. "It spreads up to Turkey and Iran and Iraq."
 
Water a Big Issue
 The Israelis and Jordanians are working on a formula that would resolve the issue by agreeing to work together to make the Middle East free of nuclear weapons of mass destruction, a Jordanian official said.
The issue of water is especially important to Jordan. The country of four million has a water shortage and has had to introduce rationing. But Jordanian officials involved in the talks said they believe that the Israelis appeared ready to accept Jordanian demands.
"I don't think we should have a great problem," Mr. Anani said, "if the Israelis are intent on solving that issue. We have agreed on the items to discuss, but we have differences over the priorities. The Israelis want to talk about regional water projects, to replenish resources, which are not going to be sufficient, given the water supply and the needs of the future. Then they want to talk about rightful riparian shares, but we insist that we should settle the issue of riparian shares first."
Finally, the Jordanians say they will call on Israel to allow them to export Jordanian products to the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

HEADLINE: Oil Prices, Plunging, May Not Have Hit Bottom

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 12

 BODY:
A steady drop in the demand for fuel and energy around the world, combined with record high oil production in the North Sea as well as by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, has pushed world oil prices down to the lowest level in three years, and many experts predict that prices may fall to a low not seen since the oil price collapse of 1986.
Since June, oil prices have dropped more than $3 a barrel, bringing the average price late last week to about $15.50 a barrel on spot markets in London and about $16.75 a barrel in the United States. 
 Industry executives and analysts say oil markets are so flooded with oil that prices might slide to about $10 a barrel in the next few months, around the low point of the mid-80's, presenting the industrial economies with a welcomed lift and consumers around the world with a windfall.
For consumers, the drop in oil prices has brought unexpected benefits. Gasoline prices have fallen to less than a dollar a gallon in some parts of the United States this summer, though in a survey taken at about 10,000 stations on Sept. 10, the price of regular unleaded gas at self-service pumps was $106.7 a gallon, according to The Lundberg Letter, which tracks prices.
 
The Past as a Guide
 Seven years ago, when oil prices were falling, the biggest beneficiaries were the industrialized nations -- nearly all of them major oil importers. If the past is any guide, lower oil prices will aid economic growth, which could give a definite lift to the weak economies in Europe and Japan and coax along the fledgling recoveries in the United States and Britain. And since energy costs are a large component of a range of goods -- from food to machinery -- lower oil prices generally hold down inflationary pressures.
And for some fuel-dependent industries, like airlines, lower oil prices have meant that fuel costs have remained at last year's level, slightly lower than had been expected.
Aviation fuel is a comparative bargain. From a systemwide average of $1.14 a gallon in October 1990, in the months leading to the Persian Gulf war, it fell steadily soon after. American Airlines said it paid an average of 77 cents a gallon in 1990, 68 cents a gallon in 1991 and 62.5 cents last year. The price has remained in the low 60's this year.
"That's a penny or two a gallon lower than we expected in 1993," said Tim Smith, a spokesman for American. He attributed the lower-than-expected price to the inability of OPEC to maintain production quotas and downward pressure on oil prices from Iraq's eagerness to export oil again.
But lower oil prices have brought problems to OPEC producers, including Saudi Arabia, the largest in the world, and Kuwait. In terms of the dollar's purchasing power today, OPEC is now collecting less than it did in 1973 from its oil sales. The current price is also far below the OPEC target of $21 a barrel.
With oil revenues shrinking steadily, the Saudi and Kuwaiti economies have gone into deficit spending that will probably get worse, experts predict, forcing hard choices like slashing welfare spending, arms purchases and foreign aid.
Poorer OPEC countries like Venezuela, a main OPEC member, have gone through significant political turmoil in the last year because of economic depression stemming from lower oil revenues. Similarly, Nigeria, which is in a severe political crisis, as well as Iran, Libya and Algeria, all of which have economies that are largely dependent on oil revenues, are coping with severe budgetary problems.
"The situation is very grave" for OPEC countries, said Waleed Khadouri, the executive editor of the Middle East Economic Survey, an influential oil industry newsletter based in Nicosia, Cyprus.
 
'Apocalyptic Terms'
 "In real terms, oil prices today are comparable, or lower, than their level 20 years ago which means virtually all of the OPEC producers are much poorer today than they have been in decades," he added. "People in the industry are speaking of the situation in apocalyptic terms, worried about a drop in prices to $10 a barrel if this chaotic situation goes on unchecked."
In Mexico, which is not an OPEC member, the drop in prices has further slowed an already weakened economy. Crude oil accounts for 30 percent of exports and 20 percent of all federal revenues in the country.
Oil affairs experts said these developments in the last year had pushed prices lower:
*Oil production in the North Sea is climbing beyond expectations, with many industry executives saying that Britain and Norway, which are the principal North Sea producers, are expected to pump 5.3 million barrels a day in Western Europe's primary oilfields. That is a million barrels a day -- or 23 percent -- more than last year, and far more than oil analysts had expected the North Sea would produce. A few years ago, the experts expected the North Sea would produce about 3 million barrels a day.
*Economic recession in Europe, the United States and Japan continues to push demand lower. The International Energy Agency, the Western watchdog on energy matters, recently cut its forecasts of global oil demand by 300,000 barrels a day over the next month, setting world oil consumption at 66.9 million barrels a day at a time when usage was widely expected to rise. Among other things, the once robust demand for oil in Asia has slowed substantially, and the depressed economies of the countries of the former Soviet Union are cutting their consumption and increasing exportable amounts of their oil.
*The production discipline of OPEC, never exemplary, has gone awry. Saudi Arabia, Iran, Kuwait, Nigeria, and the United Arab Emirates have entered into a virtual war over production, with each denying that it was selling oil at a discount to generate income. That has raised the possibility that the oil group, which has always suffered from an inability to police itself, is on the verge of losing more members. Last year Ecuador quit OPEC, and there is speculation that more members are set to follow.
*Iraq, with a potential to pump as much as two million barrels a day immediately, is widely expected to finally agree to export oil under the rules of the United Nations, a move that would add to the worldwide oil surplus.
 
Severe Dip Expected
 Oil prices are certain to take their most severe dip this year, experts say, if the bickering 12 members of OPEC fail in their meeting, scheduled for Sept. 25 in Vienna, to stem their production of 25 million barrels a day. That is at least 1.5 million barrels a day above the ceiling the group had set, and most experts said they saw little or no chance of any credible OPEC accords.
"OPEC is dysfunctional now, and the market has lost its respect for its ability to control world oil prices," Gary Ross, the chief executive of Petroleum Industry Research Associates in New York, said in a recent telephone conversation. "The problem is that no one else controls prices either except supply and demand."
He added: "Right now and into the foreseeable future, demand will be too little."
 
A Cut in Income
 Experts like Mr. Khadouri, the editor, and others estimated that each dollar drop in the price of a barrel of oil represented a cut in the income of the 12 OPEC members of $10 billion a year. Since June, oil prices have dropped about $3 a barrel, making the total loss in revenues so far this year close to $30 billion.
Worse for the oil producers, experts said, was that with more crude oil production set to enter world markets from Western Europe, the former Soviet Union and new producers like Oman, Yemen and Colombia, the general outlook was for the cheapest oil prices in several decades.
"The outlook is awful," said Peter Gignoux, the head of the London energy trading desk at Smith Barney Shearson. "This is OPEC's worst crisis. We are moving closer to the dance floor." .
Still, some oil industry executives and analysts are not too perturbed by the falling price of crude and the possibility that there will be a surplus of oil. There is also the view that the different factions in OPEC will find a way to agree on production quotas if the price of crude begins to fall well below $15 a barrel.
 
Unexpected Consumer Benefits
 For consumers, the drop in oil prices has brought unexpected benefits, allowing Western Europe to maximize the taxes it charges on oil exports without upsetting its consumers and giving industrial states, including the United States and China, the cheapest fuel prices in two decades.
Despite historically low oil prices in the past decade, production in difficult fields like those beneath the North Sea has kept growing. New technologies have been found to drill deeper and better beneath the seas. Also, technologies are improving production in jungles, mountain regions and other areas once thought too troublesome.
The North Sea's prodigious production has defied all predictions of a decade ago when many experts estimated that its producing years would be over by now. Instead, production there has increased by more than 25 percent over expectations, giving Europe a principal and less costly source of oil nearby.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Rewriting Rules for Book Sales

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
To understand something of the sea change taking place in bookselling across the country, it helps to visit the flagship store of Kroch's & Brentano's, Chicago's proud old bookstore chain, and take a look down the street.
There, on a corner in the heart of the downtown Loop, sits the new age of bookselling, a six-month-old Crown Books superstore that offers a dizzying number of titles, a no-frills feel and, most important, steep discounts on every book. "If you paid full price, you didn't buy it at Crown," is the chain's motto, and that was exactly why 33-year-old Margaret Geary of Chicago was in the store looking for a computer book recently. 
 Ms. Geary knew that Kroch's & Brentano's had closed half of its 20 stores, citing changing consumer habits and too-strong competition from national chains. "I feel bad for Kroch's because they've been around for so long," she said. "But do I feel bad about shopping here instead? No, because I want to save money."
 
A Battle for the Future
 What is happening, here and around the country, is a full-scale war over the future of bookselling -- not just over where books are sold, but very possibly over how they are published, distributed and marketed. On one side are the independent bookstores, many founded years ago by people who always seemed to know more about books than about business and who intimately understood their customers' tastes. On the other are the national chains, which offer discounts, coffee bars and reading nooks but which, in the minds of independents, care more about profits than books.
It isn't just Crown that is threatening Kroch's. Virtually every major national bookstore chain has muscled into the Chicago market, blanketing its downtown and suburbs with names like Barnes & Noble, B. Dalton, Waldenbooks, Borders and even Waterstone's, a British chain. Many new stores are superstores, which can offer more than 100,000 titles.
"I think many independents are going to find it difficult to compete with the superstores," said Walter Loeb, a retail consultant in New York. "Many of them don't have the assortment and the buying power to compete, and they're going to go out of business."
 
'The Nature of the Beast'
 The independents may hiss "predator," but Glenn E. Hemmerle, the chairman and chief executive of Crown Books, says, "We're a free-market economy; that's the nature of the beast." At the booksellers' annual convention in May, he said, he " listened carefully to the pleas and the emotional statements and the hand-wringing and the 'woe is me' attitude, and I came away thinking that if they all took the same energy and effort and emotion and put it into running their business, they'd be much better off."
Strategies vary from chain to chain, with Barnes & Noble promising that each of its stores will reflect its community and Crown seeking a McDonald's-like uniformity from store to store. But all the major chains have moved decisively, taking the example of retailers in industries like home furnishings and toys to open one-stop shopping behemoths.
Barnes & Noble, which recently announced plans for a stock offering, has opened 170 superstores and plans to open 40 this year and 75 more in each of the next three years. Crown expects to have 70 superstores by the end of January, and Borders, owned by the Kmart Corporation, plans to open 45 superstores by the end of 1993 and 25 more next year.
 
Sales Increase Cited
 Can the book-buying public, whose purchases have held relatively steady over the last five years, support a marketplace that has expanded so drastically?
Leonard Riggio, chairman and chief executive of Barnes & Noble Bookstores Inc., cites an industry study showing that book sales increased 5 percent from 1991 to 1992. "The market is expanding dramatically," he said, and "you're going to see significantly greater numbers for book sales in the next few years. We're entering what you could call the golden age of bookselling in the 1990's, where people are finding ever more interesting ways to be competitive."
But many independent booksellers say oratory about healthy competition and market forces ignores the values at the core of bookselling: a love of books and an understanding that owning a bookstore is often an idiosyncratic and highly personal venture.
"Books have gone the way of toothpaste -- who can sell more for less," said Adam Brent, whose father founded Stuart Brent Books on Michigan Avenue here. Its walls are covered with photographs of Mr. Brent, now 81, with literary figures and friends like Saul Bellow, Bennett Cerf and Studs Terkel. "You can have everything you want in the world, but if you don't have someone telling you, 'This is a really good book,' or 'This is terrible,' then you're only buying inventory."
 
A Move to Mass Appeal
 Mr. Brent and other independents say that if the chains killmany of them off, publishers will change the kind of books they publish, focusing more on lower-common-denominator best sellers and ignoring books with limited, but worthwhile, appeal.
"The long-term question that gets raised by all this is what might happen in a book business that is dominated by a handful of people," said Charles Robinson, president of the American Booksellers Association and the owner of an independent store in Bellingham, Wash.
Many publishers, of course, say that they will go on publishing what they like, that the chains have no more power than before and that the effect of the expanded marketplace has been only positive.
"I've been in publishing for over 30 years and I've heard the same concerns expressed in several different generational folds," said Bruce Harris, president of trade sales and marketing for Random House Inc. "There's sometimes a very elitist view of all this that I find very pernicious. It's hard to think of what everything would be like if we didn't have some of these chains moving in and opening up bookstores and reaching out to new readers."
But independents say the chains cannot match their passion for books.
"I think the chains have stolen or borrowed the whole concept of the independent bookstore," said Lucy Moynihan, one of three main buyers at Kroch's & Brentano's. "They've learned the style, they've learned the buzzwords, they have the newsletters and the readings. But it's a marketing ploy. They don't really hand-sell books, and a lot of the books many of us love have to be hand-sold."
 
Competition Seen as Unfair

Many independents feel they are victims of unfair competition. The chains, which buy books in bulk, qualify for enormous discounts and other financial incentives, like cooperative advertising, from publishers.
Small publishers have the same concerns, fearing that if they lose the independent stores, they lose their books' natural champions.
"I really think that the chains are reaching out and serving readers that might not be reached by the independents," said Catherine Fry, the assistant director and marketing manager at Louisiana State University Press. "But I've been here for 15 years, and my experience has been that independent booksellers take the time to read galleys from small presses and university presses. They cultivate their customers and they know which ones appreciate serious works such as literary fiction or scholarly books."
Still, the most successful independents say the competition might actually end up helping them; they may be forced to streamline their operations and to play to their strengths: organizing readings, aggressively promoting the books they love and finding new ways to woo customers.
"We get much more involved with a customer, instead of just saying, 'Here's the rack; help yourself,' " said Mitch Brown, the general manager of Kramerbooks and afterwords, an independent store in Washington. He said sales had increased 10 percent since Crown's opened a superstore nearby last April.
Instead of discounting and displaying separately the books on the New York Times best-seller list, as many chains do, Kramerbooks gives better display to its customers' and employees' favorites. "We pride ourselves on not having to consult the computer if a customer asks about a title," Mr. Brown said. "We'd rather sell 1,000 separate titles than 1,000 copies of the same book."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Books have gone the way of toothpaste -- who can sell more for less," said Adam Brent, right, whose father, left, founded Stuart Brent Books, an independent bookseller on Michigan Avenue in Chicago. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)
