HEADLINE: G.M.'s Return Signals Revival for Argentina

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Fifteen years ago General Motors left Argentina, fed up with coups, military governments and economic policies that produced only inflation and instability. For Argentina, the closing of G.M.'s two plants was more than just the departure of a giant foreign corporation. It symbolized industrial descent, a country abandoned by most international businesses.
But things change, and G.M. has now come back to Argentina. 
 Last month, President Carlos Saul Menem signed an agreement reopening the country's doors to the world's largest car maker. In a joint venture with Cidea, the local assembler and distributor of Renault cars, a $100 million plant is scheduled to start production of G.M. pickup trucks next year, eventually producing 25,000 a year.
And just as G.M.'s departure in 1978 was an emblem for Argentina's breakdown, the company's return is a sign of revival, a signal that rejuvenating policies -- open markets, low inflation, stable currencies and sales of state-run enterprises -- are here to stay.
"This is an international vote of confidence of enormous proportions, to have the world's leading industrial company come to Argentina," said Manuel F. Antelo, president of Cidea. "This without a doubt will lead to other companies' following General Motors to Argentina."
Though G.M.'s initial investment here is tiny compared with the billions the company pours into new models in the United States, Latin American sales are nevertheless creating profits at a time when the car makers are struggling to be profitable in their largest markets.
Latin sales are exploding. In 1990, fewer than 100,000 cars were sold in Argentina. Then came President Menem's economic changes and a lowering of import tariffs. Car sales rose 40 percent in 1991, then doubled in 1992 and are up 40 percent this year. Auto executives estimate sales in 1993 of almost 400,000.
Throughout Latin America the same kind of statistics are seen as these economies grow at rates faster than those of the developed countries. In Colombia, car sales will double this year. In Venezuela, they have risen 80 percent in the last two years. And in Brazil, car sales are up 50 percent this year and may reach a record 1.2 million. Some analysts are saying that sales throughout Latin America could surpass the record of 2.4 million cars and trucks set in 1980.
"If you look around the world, where are the tremendous growth opportunities?" said Steven T. Darch, general director of the Banco Mariva in Buenos Aires. "One of the few places is Latin America."
Now there is a rush of manufacturers from South Korea, Japan, Europe and the United States into these countries to get a piece of the market.
On the same day that G.M.'s return to Argentina was signed by President Menem, Mazda also signed contracts with the Menem Government to set up a $35 million pickup assembly plant. Industry executives here say unofficially that Chrysler and Honda are looking to set up operations as well.
Volkswagen has established a joint venture with Ford Motor called Autolatina. And in Peru, the South Korean company Daiwoo has announced plans to build an auto assembly plant with a capacity to produce 20,000 vehicles a year, primarily for export.
"If you are an auto maker operating in the United States, every bit of new market share you win is at the expense of another company, which means costly competition," said Leo Kunigk, president of General Motors of Argentina. "Here you can come in and capture market share and profits, and not have to take it away from anyone. The region is one of the top 10 markets in the world, and G.M. cannot afford not to be in all of those markets."
Another drawing point is that union militancy has significantly diminished here. When General Motors left in 1978, the cost of shutting down the two plants was extremely costly, in large part for severance pay to production workers.
Beginning next year, General Motors plans to begin production in a converted warehouse that now stores spare parts for Cidea. Of the $100 million investment, G.M. will put up $80 million and Cidea $20 million. The factory will produce Chevrolet pickup trucks selling for about $22,000.
Full production of 25,000 trucks a year will be reached by 1996, Mr. Kunigk said, adding that G.M. chose to form a joint venture because it meant it could start producing cars much faster.
 
Getting in at the Start
 "From a stand-alone approach, it takes too much effort and time to produce locally here," Mr. Kunigk said. "Things are moving so fast in this market that we felt that if we didn't get in now, it would be too late to get in without a big fight."
Mr. Kunigk says the relatively small number of vehicles that the plant will turn out does not justify a high degree of automation, but part of that lack of automation will be compensated by the high level of education in the Argentine work force, compared with that in other Latin American countries.
While G.M.'s entry is significant to Argentina, there are even wider implications for South America, particularly for the free-trade zone called Mercosur that is being negotiated by Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay.
Though economists and politicians at times question whether a true barrier-free regional market will be created, the plan of the four Governments is akin to the North American Free Trade Agreement, with only minimal trade barriers and effective free flow of goods.
Economists note that Mercosur, scheduled to go into full effect in early 1995, will be a market of 200 million people.
 
Trade Zone Is Centerpiece
 Mr. Kunigk said Mercosur was at the center of G.M.'s plan to move all its pickup truck operations from Brazil and center them in the central Argentine city of Cordoba, some 450 miles northwest of Buenos Aires. From Argentina it will ship trucks duty free to Brazil and from Brazil it will send passenger cars duty free to Argentina.
Though many companies have been preparing for the opening of Mercosur, G.M.'s actions are seen as among the most important signals yet sent to the governments and markets that such a regional free-trade zone has the confidence of the world business community.
"We may be one of the events that makes Mercosur happen," Mr. Kunigk said.
And for Argentina, the added 500 jobs the plant will produce are only part of the benefit. Last week, Cidea signed an agreement with E.D.S., the computer services company of General Motors, to handle Cidea's technology and information systems.
Also, according to Mr. Antelo of Cidea, the company is planning on bringing in the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the auto maker's financial subsidiary, to provide credit to auto buyers.
 
'Broad Ripple Effects'
 "These are arrivals of very important companies in the country that will have broad ripple effects," Mr. Antelo said. "These not only bring in more jobs, but add to modernization of Argentine business."
He estimated that while the current market was for 400,000 cars and light trucks a year, it could easily reach 500,000 or more. For one thing, the average life of a car in Argentina is 10 years, compared with 6 to 7 years in the United States. There has been no real financing of auto purchases. And demand is now so high car buyers have to wait months for delivery.
Amid the rosy projections, Mr. Kunigk concedes there may be some risks, like the collapse of Mercosur and a return to a form of political instability of the past.
"If Mercosur fails, there will be some sort of alternative program of free trade put in place, and there is less political risk than before," he said. "I would say they are minor risks, compared with the potential of this market."

HEADLINE: As Mayor of 20 Years Retires, Detroit Faces a New Kind of Election

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Detroit voters go to the polls on Tuesday in the first round of a nonpartisan Mayoral election that all 23 candidates seem to agree is this troubled city's most interesting and important contest in two decades.
Not coincidentally, it is also the first time since 1969 that the incumbent, Coleman A. Young, will not be on the ballot. Battling emphysema and declining political support, Mr. Young, 75, who built a powerful political machine in 20 years as Mayor, announced on the very last filing day, June 22, that he would not seek a sixth four-year term in the office he first won in 1973. 
 His retirement ends an era in which Detroit politics had been overwhelmingly dominated by the Mayor, and in which most of the levers of power came to be controlled by blacks, who now make up 76 percent of the city's population of one million.
But most of Mr. Young's years have also been grim ones for the city. The auto industry withered, white and affluent voters fled from the city, and the number of jobs and people both fell by about a third.
 
Looking for Consensus
 Mayor Young maintained power and popularity despite economic decline, however, partly by giving blacks a sense of pride and partly by seeking to rally city residents against the mostly white surrounding communities, calling them the "hostile suburbs."
But in this election things are different. All the leading candidates are black; the leader contender to succeed Mr. Young, Dennis Archer, a 51-year-old former State Supreme Court Justice, has run on a platform of consensus and cooperation with the surrounding communities. He has earned the Mayor's wrath by conceding that concerns about crime, drugs and inadequate city services have made it hard for Detroit to lure new residents and businesses.
Mr. Archer, a soft-spoken, buttoned-down partner in one of Detroit's more prominent law firms, pledges a "well-run, well-managed city."
"We will pick up our garbage on time, our police officers will be in the neighborhoods, and we will have a master plan," he vowed. "Detroit is a $2 billion a year business without a business plan."
 
Leader Pulls Away
 Mr. Archer stepped down from the State Supreme Court two years ago to explore running for Mayor. He had previously managed a number of political campaigns, including Mr. Young's in 1977, and has now built an impressive campaign organization that raised $1.6 million, far more than any other candidate.
Every poll shows he is likely to win one of the two run-off spots on Tuesday. A survey conducted on Labor Day for WDIV television found Mr. Archer the strong favorite among likely voters. Trailing well behind him were Sharon McPhail, an assistant Wayne County prosecutor, and Arthur B. Blackwell 2d, chairman of the Wayne County Board of Commissioners. Representative John Conyers Jr., who has run a somewhat mercurial campaign, ranked fourth.
The surprise of the campaign so far has been the strength of Ms. McPhail, a 44-year-old native of Cambridge, Mass., who was not taken seriously by many when she began campaigning last year. "This is a big industrial town, and a lot of people were hostile to the idea of a woman candidate," she says. Despite raising little money, she has been a strenuous campaigner and has been very effective in televised debates.
Ms. McPhail's positions are difficult to categorize. She talks tough on crime and says she would repeal the city's corporate income tax to attract new businesses. But she has also expressed concern for the homeless and wants to establish a network of child-care centers. Some questions have been raised about her ethics in handling private legal cases while employed full time as a county prosecutor, and she has been criticized for having failed to vote in many city elections, but these matters have so far had little effect.
 
The Mayor's Man
 Her main challenger for the second run-off position, Mr. Blackwell, is the only candidate running as the Mayor's man. Mr. Blackwell, 40, does pledge to do more for the city's crumbling neighborhoods than did Mr. Young, but he has otherwise run as a consummate Young loyalist. Though the Mayor has not made a formal endorsement, he did give $500,000 from his own campaign fund to two groups that have endorsed Mr. Blackwell, and the Blackwell campaign has been able to afford numerous television and radio advertisements that Ms. McPhail has not.
Mr. Blackwell has been the subject of an avalanche of news reports hinting at financial irregularities. The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press have detailed how he built a recreational area onto his house with a political expense fund, which he also used to pay an array of consultants, including his sister, father and teen-age son.
Questions have also been raised about some of Mr. Blackwell's travel at public expense, for his voting to give county business to companies he served as a consultant and for accepting a $42,000-a-year second job, at the Detroit Fire Department. Some fire fighters said he was never seen at the office. Mr. Blackwell has denied any impropriety.
Mr. Conyers, who helped found the Congressional Black Caucus and is now one of the most senior members of the House, has run a campaign with peculiar lapses. He sometimes does not show up for scheduled speeches and at one point arrived for a televised debate wearing a three-piece suit but without socks. In response to questions about such things he has replied, "I don't have to explain myself to the voters; the know who I am."
Mr. Conyers married three years ago for the first time, at age 62, and has said he is running for Mayor to make Detroit a better place to live for his infant son.
Other candidates include Paul Hubbard, the former president of New Detroit Inc., a civic action group; George Cushingberry Jr., a Wayne County Commissioner, and Charles Costa, a paint store owner who is the only well-known white candidate.
Even if one candidate gets more than half the vote on Tuesday, a nonpartisan runoff will be held on Nov. 2. Ms. McPhail and Mr. Blackwell have pledged to back whichever of them survives the primary, and Mr. Young is expected to work to defeat Mr. Archer.
Mr. Archer says: "In my own mind I have no opponents. I am not running against anybody; what I am running for is the vision of what Detroit can be."

HEADLINE: Prayers and Pleas for Action Mingle at Baptist Gathering

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
The annual gathering of the National Baptist Convention, which brought almost 50,000 pastors and church members to New York City last week, had the mood of a gigantic family reunion. But it was a family burdened with a sense of urgency.
With a membership estimated at about three million, the National Baptist Convention is the nation's largest organization of black Americans. Virtually no session or sermon at the meeting, which opened on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden and closed yesterday with a worship service at the New York Hilton, passed without pleas for action on the ills troubling black America: inner-city crime, drugs, AIDS, teen-age pregnancies and unemployment. 
 Sometimes those pleas for action clashed uneasily with the personal style and relaxed pace of the meeting.
But there were also signs that the National Baptist Convention is edging steadily toward a more nationally coordinated program and a higher visibility in the national news media.
 
Signaling Change
 The change was signaled by the denomination's very decision to meet in New York City for the first time in almost 60 years. One aim was to offer moral support to Mayor David N. Dinkins in his campaign for re-election. But clearly another was to send a message through news coverage.
Juxtaposing prayer and politics, the convocation preached a message that should have suited the Clinton presidency -- a blend of traditional moral discipline with support for government programs.
"We are intelligent, decent, attractive citizens, and that is different from the way that African-Americans are portrayed in the media," said the Rev. W. Franklyn Richardson, the general secretary of the convention and pastor of Grace Baptist Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y.
"We pray, we have our children, we have our spouses. We understand the other images -- we're not denying that there are people on drugs and grabbing bags -- but we want the whole story told."
The evolution in the convention began a decade ago when the Rev. Theodore J. Jemison was elected president. Under his conservative predecessor, the Rev. J. H. Jackson, many socially active black clergymen and supporters of the civil rights movement formed a separate group, the Progressive National Baptist Convention, in 1961.
 
Healing the Breach
 Dr. Jemison, who is pastor of Mount Zion Baptist Church in Baton Rouge, La., moved quickly to heal the breach. He honored the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. He became one of the earliest supporters of Jesse Jackson's presidential campaign in 1984, and this year, as in preceding ones, he embraced the head of the Progressive National Baptists on the podium.
But Dr. Jemison, whose own father headed the denomination before 1952, also personifies a kind of old-fashioned church leadership featuring personal charisma and loyalty.
Dr. Jemison presided over the convention in a manner mixing the authority and prerogatives of a pope -- the Rev. Al Sharpton, a guest at the convention, actually called him the "black pontiff" -- with the familiar manner of a grandfather at the family dinner table.
Dr. Jemison verbally patted every speaker and musician on the head: "Wasn't that wonderful? Aren't you all having a good time? Amen." His introductions of dozens of church leaders, frequently embellished with information about whose son, daughter or nephew they were, reinforced the sense of the denomination as an extended family.
Indeed it often seemed that introductions were not preludes to the meeting's business; they were the meeting's business.
Discontent and rivalries were not absent from the meeting, but as at regular family reunions they tended to be acknowledged obliquely.
Most obvious were the declarations defending the construction of a $12 billion world headquarters in Nashville, a point of pride for Dr. Jemison but also a subject of criticism by some others in the church.
Beyond questions of expense, the Nashville building represents the movement toward a stronger centralized program for the denomination. "We're going to put some programs in it like black people have not seen before," Dr. Jemison said at the closing service yesterday.
Local black Baptist churches, like other Baptist churches, are independent, self-governing bodies. Their pastors have often wielded political and economic as well as spiritual influence on the local scene but made a mark nationally only when they entered politics.
Dr. Richardson strongly endorsed the growth of a central program on Friday when he announced his own candidacy to head the denomination.
Dr. Richardson has been a loyal lieutenant to Dr. Jemison, who has endorsed him as a successor and, at the Sunday service, underlined the importance of loyalty in the organization.
Just before Dr. Jemison adjourned this year's meeting of the National Baptist Convention, Dr. Richardson announced a forthcoming conference on AIDS. In no uncertain terms, he warned the delegates that "we've got to rid ourselves of any biblical notion that AIDS is some kind of plague that God has put on the unrighteous."
The question of AIDS "is not an issue that the church can walk away from," he said. "It is an issue the church has to walk toward."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Matthews, vice president of the National Baptist Convention, joining members during a prayer service last week at the Hilton Hotel. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: At 32, He Bows Out;
A Connecticut Whiz Quits Politics

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANSFIELD, Conn., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Jonathan Pelto won his spurs as a certified wunderkind of Connecticut politics at age 23 when, as Gary Hart's state campaign manager, he led a kiddie corps of Hart zealots to a victory over Walter F. Mondale in the 1984 presidential primary.
Elected to the state Legislature that same year, appointed statewide strategist for the Democratic Party at 25, his track seemed set and ever-upward. The young Congressman from Connecticut, maybe? With a top-loaded resume and a resonant if nasal baritone, who could tell? 
 Now, in political retirement, if not exile, at the ripe age of 32, Mr. Pelto sits in the wooded silence of his family's hilltop home here in sandals and torn jeans, nursing a handful of grudges, but also savoring, he said, the small joys and worries for which he never had time. Politics is out. Life is in. These days, he worries about simpler matters, such as whether his 8-week-old daughter, Mara, has an ear infection. He is negotiating for his first job ever in private industry. His resignation from the General Assembly, the last mooring to his old life, takes effect on Monday.
Twenty-one years after he stuffed his first envelope as an 11-year-old volunteer for George McGovern's 1972 presidential campaign, Mr. Pelto is officially out of the game.
"So many of my colleagues that I watched through the years would go home at the end of a legislative session and find out that their kid had learned to walk or talk, or graduated from high school while they were away," Mr. Pelto said. "Or worse, you go home at the end of the session and there's nobody there, which happened to one person. As important as the Legislature was, as important as politics is, that's not a price I was willing to pay."
Should this story really be called, "Mr. Pelto Gets a Life?" Or perhaps more aptly, "Another One Bites the Dust?" Did the prodigy who at age 18 ran United States Representative Sam Gejdenson's first come-from-nowhere race for Congress walk away from politics, or was he pushed?
 
Stress in High Places
 Over the last 18 months, his career has read like a how-to manual for inducing a midlife crisis, even if he is a bit young for the role: He was shoved aside from his leadership role in the state House of Representatives, fired from his job as political director of the Democratic Party, and rejected by many of his own constituents when he tried and failed to get the nomination for a state Senate seat.
The prospect of becoming a parent, Mr. Pelto said, also drove home the reality that Connecticut's Legislature, which pays rank-and-file members only $16,760 a year, is no place to save for college.
His friends say he was the victim of a new, more conservative regime in the Democratic Party that simply no longer needed -- or could tolerate -- the presence of a liberal firebrand like Mr. Pelto, and that stories like his probably litter the landscape in other parts of the country as local Democrats recast themselves to conform with President Bill Clinton's moderate New Democrat vision.
Moreover, much of the legislative agenda Mr. Pelto espoused in Hartford -- gay rights, abortion rights, a progressive income tax -- had been either achieved or left behind as public and legislative attention turned during the recession to bread-and-butter issues of jobs and of economic development.
And there is the question of personality. The state Democratic Party chairman, who dismissed Mr. Pelto from his party job last year, says it is a case of a boy wonder being too smart for his own good.
"Jonathan's demise, though part of it is voluntary, is something caused by Jon Pelto," said the party state chairman, Edward L. Marcus. "I think that Jonathan tended to act as if he indeed were the Speaker of the House and the Majority Leader and the party chairman all in one, and it all came back to haunt him.
"To be part of leadership and secure nominations for higher office, you have to be somewhat of a team player," Mr. Marcus added. "I really think that's more the issue than anything else."
So is Mr. Pelto bitter?
At first he said no, just "disappointed a little bit," Only later in the conversation did he confess to "maybe a little bit of bitterness."
Bitter enough perhaps that he might be pulled back into politics, say, to work for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s re-election as a third-party independent if the Governor decides to run for a second term?
"Probably not," Mr. Pelto said.
Only later, in response to another question, did he equivocate again, just enough to make a reporter's head dance with the possibility of a "cast-out-son-wreaks-vengeance," angle in next year's gubernatorial election: If William J. Cibes Jr., Mr. Weicker's budget director and one of Mr. Pelto's oldest friends in the Legislature, personally called and said, ' "I know it's for the Governor, but I need your help,' " Mr. Pelto said, "I'd have a tough time saying I really can't do it -- I probably would."
 
Building Coalitions
 In any case, Mr. Pelto, still courted by some in his party like a 32-year-old wiseman, and now free to counsel and kibitz as he chooses, believes that the Democrats could easily go down in flames next year if Governor Weicker does run, regardless of who does or doesn't help the Governor.
The Democrats polled barely 20 percent of the vote for governor in 1990, when Governor Weicker, a former Republican, ran for the first time as a third-party independent candidate in a three-way race against a Democrat, Bruce A. Morrison, and a Republican John G. Rowland.
The political reality, Mr. Pelto said, was demonstrated in that election, and again last year with Ross Perot's Presidential campaign, is that coalition building among the shifting fragments of the two major parties will be the only way to win or govern both on the state and Federal levels.
"What got Lowell Weicker over the top last time -- should he run again -- is not the same coalition that will get him over the top this time," he said. "The Democratic Party doesn't realize that, and certainly the Ed Marcuses of the world don't realize that."
Then of course, there are new challenges of life that preoccupy Mr. Pelto: like his daughter, there in his arms. Did someone say politics was important?
"Not to be melodramatic, but I'd always thought the way to save the world was to go out there and be a politician and do your part," he said. "But I'm not really so sure that doing your part isn't just making sure your kid grows up the right way, and that's saving the world. I wouldn't have been able to imagine saying that before we had the baby."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Move by Patriots Will Involve Taxes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 12

 BODY:
A move by the New England Patriots to Hartford would benefit Connecticut, but require millions of dollars in tax increases, according to a study commissioned by the state more than a year ago.
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s administration released the report on Friday. It was conducted by the University of Connecticut's Center for Economic Analysis at the direction of the Department of Economic Development. 
 The department would help finance a $252 million stadium in Hartford for the Patriots if they relocated here from Foxboro, Mass.
Legislative leaders have endorsed Weicker's attempts to bring the Patriots to Connecticut if the stadium can be built without massive public subsidies.

HEADLINE: Review/City Opera;
A Renovated 'Turandot,' With New Choreography

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
At their best, the standard repertory productions at the New York City Opera are economically staged, yet without an unreasonable sacrifice of detail or even, in some cases, the appearance of lavishness. This can be a difficult balancing act, but one way the company has made it work is by creating hybrids: productions in which the sets and costumes are retained, but which are reworked, sometimes considerably, by new directors.
The company's "Turandot" has had three directorial renovations since it opened in 1976, the latest being Jonathan Eaton's 1991 restaging, with new choreography by Shi Zheng Chen. Mr. Eaton's version returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday evening. 
 Mr. Eaton revitalized what had become a sagging production, sharpening its dramatic edges and building wisely on the dark, hazy atmosphere suggested by Beni Montresor's impressionistic sets. Exoticism, color and spectacle, all essential elements in "Turandot," are retained, but they never overpower the work, as they do in Franco Zeffirelli's production at the Metropolitan Opera.
The company has assembled a cast of competent, conscientious singers, but the vocal thrills a "Turandot" should provide were in short supply. A few were provided by Oksana Krovytska, in her company debut as Liu. Her sound is appealingly rounded, and fairly consistent through her range. And if her first contributions led one to doubt the strength of her upper voice, her sweetly phrased, delicate account of "Signore, ascolta" put those doubts to rest. More crucially, in the last act Miss Krovytska made Liu's combination of pain and dignity tangible.
Paul Lyon, also making his house debut, was a solid but generally unexciting Calaf. At his best, he moved through the role with confidence and command, and he gave an entirely respectable account of "Nessun dorma." But he was not always able to make himself heard over the orchestra, even at key moments.
It can be tempting to blame that on the orchestration or the conductor, and Guido Ajmone-Marsan did not seem particularly inclined to suppress Puccini's waves of densely textured coloration. But a tenor needs more power for Calaf than Mr. Lyon had available.
Catherine Kelly's portrayal of Turandot has grown noticeably since she made her company debut in the role last season. The main innovation was in the finale, in which she now conveys the power and emotional context of Turandot's transformation, crucial elements one missed in her performance last year. There is still a slight stridency in her voice when the music demands volume, and moments that sounded forced tarnished an otherwise gripping "In questa reggia."
There was some fine singing in the smaller roles. Eugene Perry, Michael Hayes and Gordon Gietz made the music of Ping, Pang and Pong into something more than the window dressing it often seems to be. And Philip Cokorinos, as Timur, and Don Yule, as the Emperor Altoum, brought a touching emotional resonance to their characters' few moments in the spotlight.
 
TURANDOT
 
Opera in three acts by Giacomo Puccini, libretto by Giuseppe Adami and Renato Simoni after a fable by Carlo Gozzi; conductor, Guido Ajmone-Marsan; director, Jonathan Eaton; stage director, Paul L. King; sets and costumes by Beni Montresor; lighting by Jeff Davis; choreography by Shi Zheng Chen. Performed by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Missed Opportunities As Time Speeds By

 BODY:
"Later Life," initially produced by Playwrights Horizons, has reopened at the Westside Theater, 407 West 43d Street, Clinton. Following are excerpts from Frank Rich's review, which appeared in The New York Times on May 24. Josef Sommer has succeeded Charles Kimbrough in the role of Austin.
In the multicultural American theater, A. R. Gurney may be the last playwright who writes full time about that quaint old bird, the New England WASP. Maybe it's an unfashionable calling, but Mr. Gurney's view of his terrain is so objective that his plays often fill in the missing pieces of the fractured American social puzzle. When you meet the economically rarefied yet often emotionally disadvantaged characters in Gurney plays, you remember just why the rest of the country has spent 25 or so years fleeing in the opposite direction. 
 Austin, the Boston banker at the center of "Later Life," Mr. Gurney's enjoyable new 80-minute comedy, is one of the playwright's saddest creations. (Or half-creations. In the Playbill, Mr. Gurney acknowledges a debt to Henry James, whose tale "The Beast in the Jungle" seems the play's point of departure.) A smart and genial preppie in late middle age, Austin rather resembles the President he voted for in the last election. He's likable and polite, and he puts in his time at the office, but what exactly is he doing with his life? His children grown, his marriage ended by divorce, he is an empty suit longing to breathe free.
"Later Life" tells what happens when Austin is unexpectedly thrown together at a cocktail party with Ruth (a mysterious and alluring Maureen Anderman), a woman he met as a serviceman one night in Capri 30-odd years ago. Still young, single and "relatively free and clear," the pair almost spent the night together. But Austin was seized by the premonition that "something terrible was going to happen" to him in later life and dismissed Ruth with a kiss rather than risk ensnaring her in his cloudy future.
Now later life is accelerating, and the plot question of Mr. Gurney's play is whether Austin and Ruth will seize the second chance for happiness they have been handed. But that question cannot be answered until they resolve the question that hangs over the decades separating their brief encounters: Did something terrible ever happen to Austin? Apparently not. He has gone on to what he considers a lucky life, notwithstanding his divorce and his current need for Prozac. Ruth, by contrast, lost a child to leukemia and is now trying to flee her fourth marriage, to an abusive gambler in Las Vegas. It's almost as if she had been given the terrible future Austin once imagined for himself.
Or so it might seem. The drama in Mr. Gurney's plays can never take place on the surface because it is the very nature of his characters that their surface remains impeccably civilized while all hell breaks loose underneath. It is also typical of Mr. Gurney's writing that he strips down his reticent WASP's to the sound of laughter, not sentimental strings. "Later Life" is no exception, offering more than a few lines worthy of New Yorker cartoon captions.
Many of the funniest passages belong to Anthony Heald and Carole Shelley, two of our best comic actors, who are here given the delightful task of playing all the revelers who wander onto the high-rise terrace where Ruth and Austin are trying to have their quiet tete-a-tete. Although some of their roles are one-joke stereotypes that reveal the limits of Mr. Gurney's range -- a Route 128 computer nerd, an acerbic lesbian, a Jewish earth mother -- the performers' own range seems limitless. And they are unexpectedly moving as two old friends who preside over the party: a Harvard professor's widow who is the hostess and a prematurely retired Brandeis professor who has channeled all sorts of disturbing rage into his doomed effort to quit smoking.
True to form, Mr. Gurney sometimes uses the various interlopers to spell out his themes, a tic that mars most of his plays. There are far too many lines reminding the audience that a literal and figurative twilight (and autumn) is at hand, that vulgar Southern and Western new money has overtaken Eastern old money, and that it is now or never if Austin is to follow the example of many of the party guests and break out of his Brahmin rut. This congenital refusal to let the audience discover his plays' characters and themes for itself is in part what often reduces Mr. Gurney's Jamesian and Cheeveresque esthetic designs to facile boulevard comedy.
But Mr. Gurney's boulevard comedy is of a high order, at times achieving the luster of Philip Barry and S. N. Behrman even in this one-act piece. "Later Life" has been directed in the appropriately elegant, old-school Broadway style by Don Scardino on a starry romantic set by Ben Edwards.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
TV, by Its Very Nature, Can Stack the Deck

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
In its exertions to dredge up support for the North American Free Trade Agreement in Congress, which will receive all 2,000 pages of it tomorrow, the Administration may have failed to notice that the battle of the tube is well on its way to being lost. The weeks of battering are not the work of conspiring news producers or reporters; one imagines that this cadre, sympathetic to ideals like breaking down barriers among neighbors and in no danger of having their jobs shipped to Mexico, would be favorably inclined to the proposed treaty. The problem for the Administration is with television itself.
Discussions of the agreement, like those on the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour," have been performed through a glass dimly. It takes a powerful dose of civic responsibility to sit through the opposing predictions and predilections; the screen turns as smoggy as Mexico City. When these encounters are not incomprehensible, they are inconclusive. Talk show interviewers must be forgiven for fleeing the details of the pact for the good old question of how many votes it will get in the House of Representatives. 
 But clear and strong signals about the agreement, particularly regarding Mexico, have come in other forms, and they have been predominantly negative: reports of companies moving across the Rio Grande accompanied by pictures of shut-down factories and interviews with shut-out American workers; stories about goods produced by low-paid foreigners being sent north to replace those with made-in-America labels; scenes of smoke and sludge pouring from Mexican factories untroubled by environmental busybodies.
Any accounting of the television balance finds the Administration with a heavy deficit. The main argument in behalf of the pact seems to be that as the appeal of living in the United States diminishes, so will illegal immigration.
The Administration has run up against some abiding rules of television: pictures stay with one longer than words; specifics hit harder than abstractions; victims touch hearts more deeply than ideas touch minds; a moment of reality has more force than a world of prophecy.
If that were not enough, featured among opponents of the agreement are some of the most picturesque public figures ever to enliven the screen: the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Patrick J. Buchanan, Ralph Nader, and, pre-eminently, Ross Perot. Showboats every one. They have been joined by clean-air advocates and other avatars of righteousness. What can such ineffably colorless and creaky Washington artifacts as Representative Thomas S. Foley do against this dazzling ecumenical alliance? How many testimonials to the pact from Nobel Prize-winning economists does it take to counter one sarcastic crack by Mr. Perot on the "Tonight" show?
If a nation still afflicted by high unemployment has not risen in more clamorous opposition to the trade agreement, it may simply be because many people just cannot get excited about anything known as Nafta. (Didn't it used to be a laundry detergent?)
Perhaps the White House will be able, as it was with its budget package, to eke out a victory of sorts in Congress, where free trade in North America may benefit from some private trades around Capitol Hill. But if the Administration needs to rouse enough national enthusiasm to impress a resistant Congress, it will have to confront its television problem.
President Clinton is to present his case for the agreement in a talk to the nation, but even with graphs, he will be hard put to make the promise of long-term benefits as vivid to viewers as the short-term costs have already been made. Replacing the images of certain loss tomorrow with the might-bes of gains the day after will strain the know-how of David R. Gergen, the talents of Bill Clinton and the imaginations of their audience.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: PULSE: Livestock

 BODY:
Better breeding and management in animal agriculture, dominated by the dairy industry, has pushed up production in the New York metropolitan region in the last two years, while the number of livestock actually fell. Dairy operations, which account for more than 50 percent of New York's $3 billion-a-year farming industry, put the state in the third ranking among milk producers nationally and continue to be the strongest form of animal agriculture in Connecticut and New Jersey. But while allowing farms to increase production, better management has also led to consolidation. There are about half as many diary farms in the region as 10 years ago. The beef industry in all three states occupies a small niche in the agricultural economy. (Sources: U.S. Dept. of Agriculture, N.Y. State Agricultural Statistics Service, Departments of Agriculture in each state.)

HEADLINE: Essay;
A Talk With Clinton

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What does President Clinton think of the muttering on the right in Israel that when Likud comes back into power, today's agreement with the P.L.O. would be abrogated?
"It concerns me, although our information is that Mr. [Benjamin] Netanyahu has been quite careful about his comments. Israel is a democracy, and historically democracies have honored the commitments that their governments have made with others along their borders, even with a transition government," President Clinton said in an interview on the eve of the signing of the first pact between Israel and the P.L.O. 
 "But I think to insure that, what we have to do is make this agreement as popular as possible in Israel," he added, "and I mean popular in the deep sense. I don't mean some fleeting poll numbers. The people of Israel need to feel this agreement enhances rather than undermines their security."
He is not troubled by Prime Minister Rabin's unwillingness to put his name on the treaty. "I think the fact that he's coming is a major step. I don't want to put myself in his mind," he said, and then did: "First he wants to give the Foreign Minister [Shimon Peres] credit for the work he did. . . . And secondly this has psychologically got to be still a difficult thing in Israel. So I'm not troubled."
I am. Perhaps Rabin personally thinks Peres deserves the honor; maybe he doesn't want to upset Israelis politically by going all the way; or it could be he doesn't want to put Yasir Arafat diplomatically on the same level as a head of state. Whatever the reasons, this is Rabin's historic deal and his name belongs on it. He cannot take everyone else overboard unless he jumps himself.
The gamble on the new Arafat will succeed if Israeli public opinion believes it is succeeding, which depends on (1) future P.L.O. discipline, (2) new treaties with Israel's neighbors and (3) strong new American military, economic and diplomatic support. Clinton is asserting the third.
Question: When the world clamors for the U.S. to pressure Israel to make concessions, will he -- as George Bush did -- use economic aid as a lever on Israel?
Answer: "I do not believe we can get from here to where we want to have to go to wrap this whole thing up by trying to weaken the position of the Israeli Government. The answer to that is yes, I'm not going to do that."
How about asking King Fahd to stop the boycott, asking the Pope to expedite Vatican recognition of Israel, extending the present "strategic cooperation" to a defense alliance, removing restrictions on the sale of supercomputers to Israel to give them a technological edge, pressing ahead with missile defense aid?
"When I have a strategy for what happens next in countries outside, I'll be glad to announce it; I m not trying to be fuzzy. . . . When I talked with Prime Minister Rabin . . . we agreed we would have to get through Monday first, and then we would talk about that, so I would be interested in knowing from the Israelis what they believe we ought to do next. . . . I'm going to develop a whole strategy and I just haven't had time to do it yet, and I can't do it in the course of this interview."
Though a bit behind the power curve, Clinton believes his refusal to criticize Rabin after the Hamas expulsion and the Lebanon raid "helped set the conditions in which this agreement could occur." I think the replacement of Bush with a President disinclined to pressure Israel helped push Arafat into direct negotiations.
In inducing American support for risk-taking, Rabin has clearly not been saying we'll-do-this-if-you-do-that; his more trusting approach makes good sense. In first forging his daring (if personally unsigned) agreement with his lifelong foe today, the Israeli leader challenges the rest of the world to pitch in tomorrow.
Clinton's message to Americans who identify with the Israeli settlers who feel abandoned and endangered?
"This agreement, if we do it right . . . will make the people of Israel safer and more secure and it's worth taking some risks for peace. . . . I'm going to do everything I can to minimize those risks. That's what I believe the obligation of the United States is. . . . We've only said if you believe it's worth it, to take risks for peace, we're going to be there for you. That's what I would say to them, not only to the Israelis, but to their supporters in the United States."

HEADLINE: Indonesia Still Caught In Population Squeeze

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Aug. 27 front-page article on Indonesia states that "Indonesia averted a population disaster" by dropping its annual growth rate from 2.4 percent to 1.8 percent. 
 This drop only means that the population will double in 38 years, rather than 31. The island of Java is the size of New York State and has 120 million people -- one of the densest populations on earth. At its current rate of growth, Java will have 160 million people by the turn of the century.
World Bank optimism for Indonesia contrasts starkly with the World Health Organization's bleak population forecast. Can a doubling of the per capita income be sustained if the population doubles in 40 years?
The population program of President Suharto has failed because Indonesians perceive the central government as less the governing force than customary village law.
My experience is that most Indonesians still regard a large family as status symbol and social security. Their "cooperation" with government family planning programs is mainly a put-on.
 
WARREN HAYS
Moraga, Calif., Aug. 30, 1993

HEADLINE: Thinking the Unthinkable, Japan May Curb Its Bureaucrats' Power

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Like most countries, Japan works best when it is closing ranks to battle a perceived foe. When they were struggling to rebuild after World War II, the Japanese seized on the threat of Communism. As the cold war faded, overtaking the United States in world markets spurred workers to toil selflessly.
Now, with a new Government and a new generation in charge, Japan has found a new demon, this time from within -- the Government bureaucracy. 
 Talk of change is everywhere in Japan these days. Since the coalition Government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa took office last month, ending 38 years of one-party rule by the Liberal Democrats, nearly every aspect of the old system has been blasted as corrupt and in need of rejuvenation.
 
Criticism From Top Officials
 The minister responsible for Japan's industrial policy has denounced the tendency to create industrial cartels, which his ministry helped foster. The new Finance Minister criticized a recent optimistic economic report not just as wrong, but as bureaucratic obfuscation.
"One of the driving forces behind the advent of coalition government in Japan is the view that the nation's highly centralized bureaucracy has acquired too much power," Eiji Suzuki, the chairman of the Mitsubishi Kasei Corporation, Japan's largest chemical company, wrote recently. The new Government, he added, "should take a sledgehammer" to the collusive "iron triangle" of politicians, bureaucrats and industrialists that for decades sacrificed consumer interests for industrial competitiveness.
Indeed, if words were stones, the Government district in the heart of Tokyo would now be buried under a Mount Fuji of wrath. A country that once rejected foreigners who made these same criticisms as "Japan bashers," or "revisionists," has suddenly embraced at least part of the revisionist agenda -- which also happens to be part of the Clinton Administration's agenda for opening Japanese markets.
"Kisei kanwa," or deregulation, has become the latest buzzword.
"It is perfectly acceptable to say things now that five years ago were not acceptable at all," said Karel Van Wolferen, a Dutch journalist whose influential book, "The Enigma of Japanese Power," argued that bureaucrats had long ago seized control of the policy-making apparatus from politicians.
 
Regaining the Initiative
 A key tenet of the seven-party coalition Government, for instance, is that politicians must retake the policy initiative back from the bureaucracy. There is even talk of giving the Prime Minister's office something it has never had, a large staff of independent policy experts.
Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former United States trade negotiator, has long been reviled by many officials here for advocating that Japan be forced to meet targets for reducing its trade surpluses. But last week Takeshi Nagano, the powerful president of the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations, exhorted Mr. Hosokawa to agree to slash Japan's current account surplus, the broadest measure of trade, to a level equal to 2 percent of the gross national product, or almost half its current level.
Responding to the new mood, the Prime Minister and his Cabinet have put forward a dizzying array of proposals. As his first priority, Mr. Hosokawa has promised to remake the discredited electoral system, creating a new kind of election district and tightening laws on political contributions.
His Government has also said it will stimulate the flagging economy, which is threatening to slip back into recession after brief signs of a recovery; restructure the tax system; deregulate the economy; lower what are some of the world's highest consumer prices, and reduce the yawning trade surplus.
 
List of Rules to Be Scrapped
 At Mr. Hosokawa's insistence, the bureaucrats recently put forward a list of 60 regulations that could be scrapped or eased, a sort of deregulatory downpayment. These ranged from lowering the minimum production levels before a beer brewery can obtain a license to permitting the sale, rather than the mere leasing, of cellular telephones. They would also ease restrictions on trucking and taxi fares and making it easier to import construction materials.
But the list was quickly denounced as trivial. "We cannot remove the impression that the ministries are loafing on the job by offering piecemeal proposals," snapped Kozo Uchida, an official of the Keidanren, a trade group that represents Japan's largest corporations.
So the Keidanren responded with its own list of 30 regulations it proposed changing, from ending restrictions on department store hours to reducing the price of wheat and cutting electricity and gas rates.
Although popular sentiment has traditionally had only slight impact on Government policies, the Hosokawa Government is drawing on the growing recognition that the benefits of Japan's extraordinary economic success have not been shared with consumers, who pay astronomical prices, live in relatively small homes that are long commutes from their workplaces and enjoy few amenities like public parks and efficient sewerage systems. For instance, only 47 percent of Japanese live in homes connected to sewage treatment plants, with the rest relying on septic tanks or other facilities.
 
Few Say Life Has Improved
 In a recent Government survey, a minuscule 4.8 percent of those queried said their lives had improved over the last year, and only 17.7 percent said they expected a better life in the future.
Despite the frailty of Mr. Hosokawa's coalition, his clean image and boldness in speaking out have earned him the highest approval ratings in the postwar era, about 70 percent, according to several newspaper opinion polls published on Wednesday.
And he and other recent converts to his populist vision leave no doubt whom they see as the enemy in their struggle to turn the situation around: the bureaucrats.
"I personally have had more than enough of the resistance from this group," said Yotaro Kobayashi, chairman of the Fuji Xerox Company and a member of a commission Mr. Hosokawa has just named to trim bureaucratic powers and improve stunted living conditions.
"On the other hand, these people are finding out a number of things from this new Government," Mr. Kobayashi added. "The bureaucrats are sensing that the air is different."
Kazuo Ogura, the Deputy Foreign Minister for Economic Affairs, conceded, "I sense tremendous hostility toward the bureaucracy by members of the coalition, which I can understand very well."
 
Who Will Benefit?
 Whether the new Government can fulfill the soaring expectations remains an open question. Skepticism abounds, even among people like Mr. Kobayashi, who said he expected real change to take years. Mr. Van Wolferen said he saw little substance behind the oratory. And almost no Japanese analysts believe that the deregulation campaign, even if it succeeds, would help the United States lower the trade surplus much.
Some members of the new Government are encouraging the idea that foreign companies will benefit from the removal of barriers. In fact, some of the proposals would ease the way for imports like construction materials and autos. But Japanese experts make it clear that such benefits will be limited at best. These proposals, they say, are aimed at Japanese interests first.
"This is not for the United States," said Mr. Kobayashi. "This is part of a Japanese effort to improve the quality of life in Japan as much as possible."
The lingering question is which Japanese interests should be served. Few here doubt that the bureaucracy has a different agenda and that it will resist many of the proposals. That is one point on which many bureaucrats agree, since they insist they will frustrate what they see as attempts to set a dangerous new course for the country.
The bureaucrats argue that this is just a matter of maintaining balance and fairness in the system; the growing ranks of critics counter that the bureaucrats are simply struggling to hold on to their power.
 
Opposition to Tax Cut
 For instance, bureaucrats at the Finance Ministry, the most powerful and conservative of the ministries, have insisted they will fight any attempt to stimulate the economy through a tax cut that would create a budget deficit.
"We won't accommodate them, I assure you," a top Finance Ministry official said. "They will accommodate us."
The new commission has been informally dubbed the second Maekawa commission, after a similarly high-minded group of Government officials, academics and business leaders that proposed sweeping deregulation and a restructuring of the economy in 1986.
The original report's aim was to reduce the soaring trade surplus by making consumer demand rather than exports the engine of economic growth, and to improve the quality of life.
The Prime Minister at the time, Yasuhiro Nakasone, hailed the report during a trip to Washington as marking a "historic change," and the Reagan Administration agreed. Seven years later, the trade surplus has more than doubled after a brief decline -- it is expected to come to more than $150 billion this year -- and personal consumption accounts for 56.9 percent of the annual gross national product, less than the 58.7 percent in 1985.
"The course the Japanese economy has taken since then was a little different from the one we had hoped for," said Takao Akabane, a former top bureaucrat at the Economic Planning Agency, who was a key staff member and supporter of the original commission. "The Japanese Government quickly became less serious about pushing the original scheme."
 
The Japanese Power Elite
 Speaking of the new commission, he added: "I would like to be optimistic, but I'm not. The bureaucrats will resist this too."
While in most developed countries the word "bureaucrat" carries a negative connotation, suggesting a petty official who obstructs because of a preoccupation with form over substance, the term has stirred respect among most Japanese.
Young Japanese who excel on the grueling exams toward which the education system is pointed tend to go to Tokyo University, and the most accomplished graduates of the university generally enter the bureaucracy. The bureaucrats, who are overwhelmingly male, often marry the daughters of other bureaucrats or of bankers and industrialists, adding to the sense that Japan is run by a new aristocracy.
There are just 19,000 of these mandarins, but they administer a system that influences nearly every economic decision in Japan, from the way banks operate and how much doctors can charge to how businesses grow or shrink. Even regional and local governments are subservient to central Government dictates. The Government now has nearly 11,000 business regulations, and the number is growing.
 
'Guidance' Is Potent
 Even that does not give the whole picture, since bureaucrats also have the power to issue informal dictates known as "guidance." Bureaucrats can retaliate against companies that resist these informal orders, making guidance a more potent weapon for regulating businesses than the law. Bureaucrats also write legislation on behalf of Parliament and staff committees exploring new policies.
That is why many experts are pessimistic, or at best guarded in their hopes for lasting change.
"The bureaucrats may just want to throw away the paper a day after it is completed," Mr. Kobayashi conceded, speaking of the report his commission will produce.
Yukio Noguchi, a former Finance Ministry official who is now a professor of economics at Hitotsubashi University, said: "I am rather pessimistic. I expect the same kind of abstract recommendations as we had the last time, partly because the present Government is a coalition. It will be hard to harmonize all the different opinions."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 24, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sept. 13 about curbs on the Japanese bureaucracy omitted a word from a remark by Kazuo Ogura, a senior Foreign Ministry official. He said "some" members of the governing coalition -- not all -- were hostile to the country's career civil servants.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Lowering Economic Barriers in Japan"
 
Government Ministry Proposals
 Under the new government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, there has been a blizzard of proposals to deregulate the economy. Some of the proposed measures:
 -- Lower the minimum amount of beer a brewery must produce to obtain a license.
 -- Lower prices on electricity and natural gas.
 -- Introduce a system to sell, rather than just lease, cellular telephones.
 -- Make it easier to obtain licenses to enter the cable television business.
 -- Lower the high costs of auto safety inspections.
 -- Ease restrictions on imports of construction materials.
 -- Make it easier to use satellite broadcasts across borders.
 -- Revise the system for dating perishable foods to the last date food can be consumed from the current system, stamping the date of production, which is believed to discriminate against imports.
 -- Ease restrictions on trucking and taxi fares.
 
Business Proposals
 Following are some of the deregulation measures proposed by Keidanren, The Japan Federation of Economic Organizations, which represents Japan's largest corporations:
 -- Ease restrictions on department store hours.
 -- Reduce prices on government-controlled wheat supplies.
 -- Simplify standards on imported autos.
 -- Reduce regulations on shipping within Japan.
 -- Ease local regulations on construction of housing.
 -- Permit convenience stores and other retailers to sell rice.
 -- Ease restrictions on buying and selling television programming. (pg. A3)

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: The Overview;
RABIN AND ARAFAT SEAL THEIR ACCORD AS CLINTON APPLAUDS 'BRAVE GAMBLE'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
In a triumph of hope over history, Yitzhak Rabin, the Prime Minister of Israel, and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O., shook hands today on the White House lawn, sealing the first agreement between Jews and Palestinians to end their conflict and share the holy land along the River Jordan that they both call home.
At 11:43 A.M. on the sun-splashed South Lawn of the White House, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel and Mahmoud Abbas, the foreign policy aide for the Palestine Liberation Organization, signed a Declaration of Principles on Palestinian self-government in Israeli-occupied Gaza and the West Bank. Three thousand witnesses watched in amazement, including former Presidents Jimmy Carter and George Bush. 
 Mr. Rabin, whose face is etched with the memories of every Arab-Israeli war, captured in his remarks the exhaustion of all parties with the centuries-old conflict. "We the soldiers who have returned from the battle stained with blood," he said, "we who have fought against you, the Palestinians, we say to you today in a loud and clear voice: 'Enough of blood and tears! Enough!' "
Mr. Arafat, relishing his moment of acceptance on the White House lawn, strove to give Mr. Rabin the appropriate response, declaring in Arabic: "Our two peoples are awaiting today this historic hope, and they want to give peace a real chance."
 
An Awkward Moment
 And President Clinton, who gracefully shepherded Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin through their awkward moment of public reconciliation, hailed them both for their "brave gamble that the future can be better than the past." [Transcripts of the leaders' remarks are on page A12.]
The agreement, which will eventually allow Palestinians to run their own affairs as Israeli troops pull back within months from the Gaza Strip and Jericho in a first step, was reached during secret negotiations over the past few months between Israelis and Palestinians, under the direction of Mr. Peres and Mr. Abbas, through the mediation of Norway.
The documents were signed on the same wooden table on which the Peace Treaty between Egypt and Israel was signed in 1979. That table stood today as a silent memorial to the assassinated Egyptian President, Anwar el-Sadat, whose path-breaking visit to Israel in 1977 and subsequent agreements at Camp David brought him denunciations as a traitor by Mr. Arafat.
But the audience in attendance, and perhaps the millions more watching back in the Middle East, seemed less interested in the formal signing than in the visual moment that would somehow make this tentative peace real: the handshake between the two old warriors who personified the conflict between their peoples.
 
A Nudge, a Hand, a Smile
 Moments after the documents were signed, Mr. Clinton took Mr. Arafat in his left arm and Mr. Rabin in his right arm and gently coaxed them together, needing to give Mr. Rabin just a little extra nudge in the back. Mr. Arafat reached out his hand first, and then Mr. Rabin, after a split second of hesitation and with a wan smile on his face, received Mr. Arafat's hand. The audience let out a simultaneous sigh of relief and peal of joy, as a misty-eyed Mr. Clinton beamed away.
Two hands that had written the battle orders for so many young men, two fists that had been raised in anger at one another so many times in the past, locked together for a fleeting moment of reconciliation.
But much difficult work, many more compromises, will now have to be performed by these same two men to make it a lasting moment.
That reality was underscored by the fact that both Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat invoked their peoples' undying attachment to Jerusalem in their respective speeches.
[Later in Jerusalem, Israeli Radio reported that Mr. Rabin, accompanied by Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, was traveling to Morocco on Tuesday for a surprise meeting with King Hassan to discuss establishing diplomatic relations. The report said said Tunisia was among several Muslim and Arab countries now ready to establish ties with Israel. ]
In an opening speech that was both eloquent and moving, Mr. Clinton described the history of the effort to make peace in the Middle East and paid tribute to Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat. He also pledged United States support for their effort.
"The United States is committed to insuring that the people who are affected by this agreement will be made more secure by it and to leading the world in marshaling the resources necessary to implement the difficult details that will make real the principles to which you commit yourselves today," President Clinton said.
"Together let us imagine what can be accomplished if all the energy and ability the Israelis and the Palestinians have invested into your struggle can now be channeled into cultivating the land and freshening the waters; into ending the boycotts and creating new industry; into building a land as bountiful and peaceful as it is holy.
"Above all, let us dedicate ourselves today to your region's next generation. In this entire assembly, no one is more important than the group of Israeli and Arab children who are seated here with us today."
 
Meeting in White House
 Before the ceremony, the Israeli and Palestinian leaders did not shake hands as they came together for the first time in the White House, officials said. They both walked to the Blue Room, where several people were already drinking coffee and orange juice, including Vice President Al Gore, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and diplomats from Russia and Norway. The Israelis clustered at the southern end of the oval room, with Mr. Arafat and Mr. Abbas gravitating to the west end, about 15 feet away.
After all the other dignitaries filed out of the Blue Room to be introduced, Mr. Clinton, Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin were left alone together for a minute in the Diplomatic Entrance and it was then that the two old antagonists exchanged their first words.
"You know, we have a lot of work to do," Mr. Rabin said somberly, according to a Clinton aide.
"I know and I am prepared to do my part," Mr. Arafat answered.
Once they reached the podium, the contrast in demeanor between Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin was striking. Mr. Arafat was relaxed and ebullient -- a man who had spent a lifetime in the political wilderness suddenly finding himself at the pinnacle of power on the White House lawn. Mr. Rabin, the general-turned statesman, was nervous and palpably uncomfortable -- staring down at his shoes, never applauding anyone, shifting nervously and taking his speech in and out of his pocket.
When he delivered that speech, though, Mr. Rabin was both eloquent and frank. He articulated the deep ambivalence that he and so many Israelis felt about this reconciliation with a man they have only known by the name "terrorist" for 30 years. Mr. Rabin made clear that this was a moment he came to not out of some soaring vision of peace, but out of a grudging acknowledgement of reality: that Israel could no longer go on ignoring the P.L.O., the organization that represents the Palestinian people.
"This signing of the Israeli-Palestinian declaration of principles here today, it's not so easy, neither for myself as a soldier in Israel's war, nor for the people of Israel, nor for the Jewish people in the diaspora who are watching us now with great hope mixed with apprehension," the 71-year-old Israeli Prime Minister said.
"It is certainly not easy for the families of the victims of the wars, violence, terror, whose pain will never heal; for the many thousands who defended our lives in their own and have even sacrificed their lives for our own. For them, this ceremony has come too late."
Mr. Arafat's speech was delivered with a resonant timbre and in a flowing, classical Arabic, translated by the official State Department interpreter. It was less memorable for its substance than for the simple sight of Mr. Arafat, dressed in his familiar khaki uniform and black-and-white-checked Arab headdress, framed between the President of the United States and the Secretary of State.
 
Appeal to American Public
 Mr. Arafat, whose face was painted throughout with the broad smile of a man living a dream, actually addressed himself as much to the Americans as to the Israelis, seeking to remind Washington that he will expect -- and need -- its continued involvement as he negotiates the details of today's peace accord with Israel.
"Mr. President, I am taking this opportunity to assure you and to assure the great American people that we share your values for freedom, justice and human rights -- values for which my people have been striving," Mr. Arafat said. "We are relying on your role, Mr. President, and on the role of all the countries which believe that without peace in the Middle East, peace in the world will not be complete."
In an overture to Israelis, though, Mr. Arafat refrained from articulating his goal of creating an independent Palestinian state, and stressed that Palestinian self-determination should not come at the expense of Israeli security.
"Our people do not consider that exercising the right to self-determination could violate the rights of their neighbors or infringe on their security," he said. "Rather, putting an end to their feelings of being wronged and of having suffered a historic injustice is the strongest guarantee to achieve coexistence and openness between our two peoples and future generations.'
Mr. Arafat received warm applause from the audience, which was made up of all the members of Congress, former Secretaries of State, including Henry Kissinger and James A. Baker 3d, who organized the Madrid peace talks, the ambassadors from key countries, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, as well as hundreds of Jewish and Arab Americans, who seemed to waver between enthusiasm and expressions of disbelief.
 
Last-Minute Dispute
 A last-minute dispute over the wording of the peace agreement between Israel and the P.L.O. resulted in a small, but crucial, alteration in the text. A White House official said that in a Blue Room reception just before the signing ceremony, the word "Palestinian" was changed to "P.L.O." in the preamble of the agreement, at the insistence of Mr. Arafat, who wanted to make sure that his organization was being acknowledged as the representative of the Palestinian people.
The Israeli-Palestinian accord in many ways grows out of the 1978 Camp David accords, with its emphasis on an interim stage of Palestinian autonomy before the two sides negotiate a final status for the West Bank and Gaza Strip. But today's agreement goes beyond Camp David by accepting the notion that Israeli troops have to actually withdraw from some territory on the West Bank, and to give Palestinians far broader control so that the agreement would have credibility with Palestinians.
It also goes beyond Camp David in its recognition that such a deal could only be struck between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, not with Jordan or the Palestinians of the occupied territories, both of whom are the relevant parties of the Camp David accords.
The parties now must move into negotiations that will translate today's declaration of principles into an detailed, working plan for carrying them out. That will include deciding exactly where Israeli troops withdraw, not only from Gaza and Jericho, but from all Palestinian population centers in the West Bank, by the end of next summer. The parties also have to agree on such matters as how the Palestinians will establish their own police force and either elect or appoint a self-governing council.
 
Clinton Defines U.S. Role
 The United States role, Mr. Clinton said in an interview on Saturday, will be to help the parties work out these details, while also generating financial support for the new Palestinian homelands in Gaza and Jericho.
Mr. Clinton seemed to see his role today as creating the emotional space for Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin to come together. With the biblical allusions of his remarks and his politician's natural instinct for conciliation, the President seemed at ease in his role -- even introducing Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin to his daughter, Chelsea, who was seated with a group of Israeli and Palestinian schoolchildren.
"Today we bear witness to an extraordinary act in one of history's defining dramas, a drama that began in a time of our ancestors when the word went forth from a sliver of land between the River Jordan and the Mediterranean Sea," said Mr. Clinton.
After the ceremony, Mr. Clinton held a brief, unscheduled 10-minute, one-on-one meeting with Mr. Arafat in the White House map room, urging him to work quickly with Israel to implement the new peace agreement, and to remember that Israelis must feel confident of their security if this deal is to work, aides said. From there, Mr. Clinton met with a group of Jewish and Arab Americans.
"I think this is a very big deal," he told them, adding that everyone now had to work to insure that the Rabin-Arafat handshake, "instead of being a magic moment in history will truly be a turning point."

Chart: "TheAccord: What Comes Next"
 Highlights of the agreement signed yesterday in Washington.
 
OCT. 13
 
The Declaration of Principles on Palestinian self-rule enters into force.
 
Authority for education and culture, health, social welfare, direct taxation, and tourism is transferred from Israel to "authorized Palestinians" in the West Bank and Gaza, but it is not clear what authority they will have in East Jerusalem.
 
Palestinians start building police force based on Palestine Liberation Organization fighters from outside West Bank and Gaza.
 
Joint Israeli-Palestinian Liaison Committee formed.
 
Israeli-Palestinian Economic Cooperation Committee established to work on: water, electricity, energy, finance, transport and communications including Gaza seaport, trade, industry, labor relations, training, environmental protection, and the media; an internationally-supported economic development program for the West Bank and Gaza and a regional economic development program.
 
Jordan and Egypt invited to join Continuing Committee to decide on procedures for admission of Palestinians displaced from West Bank and Gaza in 1967 (estimated at about 800,000 people including dependents) and measures to prevent "disruption and disorder."
 
DEC. 13, 1993
 
Israel and Palestinians sign agreement on Israeli withdrawal from Gaza Strip and Jericho area and detailed arrangements for Palestinian control of the two areas.
 
Israelis begin withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho.
 
Five-year interim period of Palestinian self-rule officially begins.
 
APRIL 13, 1994
 
Latest date for Israelis to complete withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho.
 
JULY 13, 1994
 
Latest date for elections for Palestinian Council, which will operate under an as-yet undetermined interim agreement. Palestinians from East Jerusalem will be able to vote and perhaps run in the elections.
 
Israeli military forces, already withdrawn from Gaza and Jericho, will redeploy outside populated areas in the rest of the West Bank by the eve of elections at the latest. Israeli forces will remain responsible for security of Israeli settlers.
 
Israeli military government withdrawn and Civil Administration dissolved.
 
DEC. 13, 1995
 
Latest date for talks to start on permanent settlement.
 
DEC. 13, 1998
 
Permanent settlement takes effect.
