HEADLINE: SALINAS ATTACKED ON ELECTION BILLS

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, September 13

 BODY:
In what was to be the central political reform effort of Carlos Salinas de Gortari's presidency, the governing party is pushing to change electoral laws over the objections of opposition parties. The effort is drawing much criticism and clouding the outlook for the presidential election next year.
After a run of elections in which victories by the governing party were mired in allegations by the opposition of fraud or unfair advantage the proposed laws and changes to the constitution this month are supposed to smooth the way to a cleaner, less contentious vote in August. The proposed changes, which were approved on Sunday by the governing party's majority in the lower house, or Chamber of Deputies, would include some limits on campaign contributions and spending, Government control of election officials and the governing party's traditional dominance of the press. 
 Opposition groups and others said the changes would be paltry and, in some cases, might perpetuate the power of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has governed Mexico since 1928.
"Democracy cannot be built on cowardice!" the leader of the conservative National Action Party in the lower house, Diego Fernandez de Cevallos, bellowed at legislators from the governing party on Sunday. "The law is yours. Do with it what you wish!"
 
Issue in Debate on Trade
 The outcome of the push is crucial for the Government, because it is quite likely to determine whether the election of a successor to Mr. Salinas, who cannot be re-elected, will be viewed as legitimate here and abroad. In 1988 the vote that brought Mr. Salinas to power was widely considered fraudulent, and he has worked to dispel the authoritarian image of Mexico. The pressure for change has also increased as the shortcomings of the political system here have become an issue in the debate in Washington over the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Members of Congress from the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party walked out of the Chamber last week to protest what they said was the Government's refusal to discuss meaningful changes. By contrast, Mr. Fernandez and his colleagues negotiated the new measures with the governing party and had agreed to vote for them.
As passed, the revised code would set the first limits on campaign contributions, but it would still allow for contributions that critics of the Government call unreasonable for a developing country where, according to the World Bank, the per capita gross national product was $2,870 in 1991. Under the law, every Mexican would be allowed to give a party up to 1 percent of the total public financing for all parties. This year the maximum would be $436,051. Next year, officials said, the ceiling would rise, to $654,077 or more.
 
Appeal to Wealthy Industrialists
 After a scandal in March over a direct request by Mr. Salinas to wealthy industrialists for contributions of $25 million to the ruling party, the party promised to limit voluntarily contributions to its activities fund to one million Mexican pesos, or $322,000. By comparison, individual contributions to parties in the United States cannot exceed $20,000 a year.
The new laws would prohibit corporations from contributing, but they would continue to allow each union, nonprofit organization and semi-independent group, which corporations might form, to give up to five times the limit for individuals. Anonymous donations would also be permitted, although the total of such contributions to all parties would not be allowed to exceed 10 percent of all public financing.
As 16 hours of floor debate was ending the conservatives accused the governing party of repudiating critical agreements. Despite its pledge of support, Mr. Fernandez's party, known by its Spanish initials as PAN, voted against the entire package. The measures can be modified by the Senate, which is expected to vote on them this week. Major changes are unlikely, however, because the governing party holds 61 of the 64 Senate seats.
 
Defense From Governing Party
 No sooner did criticism of the new measures erupt than the governing party moved vigorously in their defense. Articles today in pro-Government newspapers were full of complaints by legislators from the party that it had given away too much. A party member, Maria de los Angeles Moreno, president of the Chamber, denied that commitments had been broken, saying, "In no way does this frustrate the electoral reform."
National Action leaders said although they had been criticized for supporting the changes they had fought for an even higher limit, saying anonymous contributions were crucial to the opposition parties because they allowed for the support of people who were afraid to let their opposition to the Government be known.
In interviews today party leaders said that they had initially agreed to the high ceilings on contributions under the assumption that strict limits would be set on spending. Yet almost a year after Mr. Salinas issued a broad commitment to spending limits, the changes include no limits. Rather, the revision specifies that the Federal Electoral Institute would set the limits.
But a National Action leader, Felipe Calderon Hinojosa, said the complaints were far broader. "There really is no will here to establish a democratic system," he said. "That would be too dangerous for the P.R.I."

HEADLINE: In Auto-Making Country, Trade Accord Is the Enemy

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., Sept. 11

 BODY:
If there is an emotional heart to the movement against the North American Free Trade Agreement, it may be here, among the auto workers who fear that the agreement would be one more devastating blow to a way of life.
The attitudes are clear-cut, concrete, utterly removed from the theoretical debates of Washington and from the certitude of the pact's advocates that free trade is inevitable and good for the American economy over the long term. 
 Scott Herrick, a 35-year-old auto worker, simply terms the agreement a bad deal. "I'm of the belief," he said, "that most of our jobs are going to follow it." John Klutts, another auto worker, flatly said of Mexican workers, "There's no way we can compete with them on their wages."
It is Ross Perot who has captured the nightmare of auto workers -- an economy drained of well-paying manufacturing jobs, an economy with no place for people like them, where their jobs simply disappear across the border. Greg Klingler, a skilled tradesman in a General Motors engine plant, quoted Mr. Perot with a smile: "The big sucking sound, right?"
 
Political Mixed Bag
 The prospect of an agreement that would gradually eliminate tariffs and other trade and investment barriers among the United States, Mexico and Canada is scrambling politics here in the way that only a visceral issue like abortion usually does.
Mr. Perot's popularity among Michigan auto workers has soared, according to a poll released this weekend by The Detroit Free Press. He will stand shoulder to shoulder with labor leaders and prominent Democrats like Senator Donald W. Riegle of Michigan on Saturday at an anti-trade agreement rally at the Michigan State Capitol in Lansing. "He's a pretty good watchdog," said Jay Varvel, another auto worker, an opinion of Mr. Perot echoed again and again in three days of interviews in a city that has already seen more than its share of job losses.
The attitudes toward President Clinton are troubled. He carried this district in November, with 44 percent of the vote to President Bush's 35 percent and Mr. Perot's 21 percent, and many of the people who voted for him then are reluctant to turn on him now.
"I don't like it," Earl Henry, who retired after "34.7 years" with General Motors, said of the trade pact. "But if every time I had a disagreement with my wife, I kicked her out, she'd be gone a lot."
Many auto workers remember that Mr. Clinton supported the concept of the trade agreement during the campaign; during the Michigan primary campaign, in fact, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California had a boomlet of support here, fueled, in part, by auto workers looking for someone they perceived to be friendlier to labor.
 
Straddling and Finessing
 But Mr. Clinton tried to finesse the issue for much of last year, ultimately promising to negotiate tough side agreements to ease the anxieties of environmentalists and organized labor. And perhaps because of all the straddling and finessing, many of these auto workers said they did not expect him to end up pushing an agreement that they said would be, despite the side agreements, so hurtful to them.
Tom Nethaway, a 53-year-old toolmaker, struggled for an explanation: "I don't know if it was the lobbyists -- or who -- got a hold of him," he said.
Frank Garrison, the president of the Michigan A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "We need to save this President from himself."
William M. Daley, the Chicago lawyer who is heading the Administration's campaign on behalf of the trade pact, contends that the agreement is an attempt to change a system that has already seen jobs moved from the United States to Mexico.
Americans will have more jobs from the trade agreement, which will open new markets in Mexico, Mr. Daley asserted. Moreover, he said, "The notion that they can't compete is absolutely wrong."
He cited a study by the Congressional Office of Technological Assessment that showed that despite the disparity in labor costs, it was still cheaper to produce a car in the United States than in Mexico because of variables like transportation costs.
Still, the anxiety is strong here, given an added edge from the contract talks for the auto industry. It is no accident that Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the majority whip, is leading the opposition to the trade agreement.
 
Reality in Midwest
 Representative Dale E. Kildee, a Democrat and former Latin teacher who has represented Flint since 1976, said he had tried to explain to this Administration the political realities of selling the agreement in the industrial Midwest.
At the Labor Day Parade in Detroit, for instance, he said he ran into former Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston who was recently named Ambassador to the Vatican and who is the Administration's informal envoy to traditional Democrats. "Ray said, 'The President sent me here to try to calm things down about Nafta,' " Mr. Kildee said.
"I said, 'Ray, go down to Reedy's Bar, get yourself a pint, and don't even talk about Nafta,' " Mr. Kildee said.
Context is everything in politics, and the context for Nafta in this region is more than a decade of sagging employment in the auto industry. Dave Yettaw, president of the United Automobile Workers Local 599, which covers the Buick complex in Flint, says the average age of his membership is now 46, with 25 years of seniority.
Around Flint, workers talk worriedly about "getting my 30 years," the term necessary for a full pension. The days when young men and women could expect to be hired off the street for an auto industry job are an ever-more-distant memory, local union officials say.
 
Loss of 'the Good Job'
 Mr. Kildee agrees: "For about the last 12 years, G.M. has hired virtually no new hourly workers here. So anyone under the age of 30 basically does not have what was always considered the good job, the General Motors job. And for so many in this age group, these are the years when families are started.
"So you have a generation here, even without the Mexican Free Trade Agreement, as they call it here, that's suffered a great deal already," Mr. Kildee said amid the Saturday morning rush at Angelo's Coney Island restaurant in Flint. "And they worry that the agreement will only accelerate the loss of jobs."
So the strange brew of trade politics simmers. Mr. Kildee was asked to speak to the Flint branch of the Perot group, United We Stand America, the other night; the members of the group asked how they could help in the fight against the agreement. (Mr. Kildee urged them to concentrate on swaying the wavering members of the House.)
Mr. Garrison said, "We are working with anybody who will work with us to defeat Nafta." About Mr. Perot, he said, "God knows what his future plans are, but he's right on this issue."
And Charlie Coy, president of Local 598 of the U.A.W., says, "Back in the 60's, there was a guy named Ralph Nader, who brought a lot of attention to a lot of problems that were going on. I see Ross Perot in the same kind of light, but on a different scale. He's going to bring attention to issues the country has to deal with. I mean, Ross Perot is for America. Who couldn't like that?"
Those are, some Democrats say, some troublesome signs for a President who proudly carried this state 10 months ago.

HEADLINE: Israel Files Bond Offering

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Government of Israel sought clearance from American securities regulators yesterday to sell $400 million in bonds, saying it would use the proceeds to pay for projects like absorbing immigrants and building houses.
Israel's filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission coincided with the signing of the peace pact between Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. 
 A spokesman for the Development Corporation for Israel, the New York-based underwriter for Israeli Government bonds, said the bond sale was not timed to benefit from the good feelings over peace. But the spokesman, Mark Benson, said the publicity would help bond sales, which have been increasing over the last few years. Israel sold $712 million in bonds in global financial markets so far this year.
"More people have been inquiring about purchases of state of Israel bonds since discussions of the peace process were in the media," he said. "More people are inclined to inquire about an area of peace than an area of war." .
Israel, in its S.E.C. filing, said the $400 million in bonds involves two types of securities, each ranging in maturity from 10 to 12 years with yields from 4 percent to 6 percent.
Half the offering are "zero coupon" bonds, which do not pay regular interest but instead pay a lump sum upon maturity. Another $200 million of bonds would pay regular interest.
The proceeds will be used to help pay for absorbing immigrants, housing projects, infrastructure development and other economic development purposes, the filing said.

HEADLINE: Transportation Stocks Surge; Dow Up 12.58

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
The lowest oil prices in three years propelled transportation stocks to strong gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, as the stock market posted modest advances on the strength of a few blue chips.
The Dow Jones transportation index surged 23.30 points, to 1,634.76, while the Dow Jones industrials gained 12.58 points, to 3,634.21. 
 The big story of the day was the "huge gain" in the transportation average, said Lawrence R. Rice, chief market strategist for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "But the breadth is poor," he said of the overall market. "The advance today is very narrow, which is something to watch."
Mr. Rice also noted further evidence that the stock and bond markets were not necessarily moving in lockstep, at least for the time being. Bond prices were up again early yesterday, but the rally fizzled in late trading, leaving the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond unchanged at 5.87 percent.
 
Nasdaq Index Down
 Other market indicators were mostly flat. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.34 point, to 462.06. But the American Stock Exchange composite index slipped 1.76 points, to 454.30, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 3.99 points, to 740.32. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 245 million shares, down from 270 million on Friday.
Oil prices hit three-year lows on Friday, although they rebounded slightly yesterday. But with oil prices possibly heading even lower, airlines and other companies that stand to gain from cheap energy did well.
Among the airlines, UAL, the parent of United, jumped 3 1/2, to 146 1/2;, AMR, the parent of American, rose 1 5/8, to 64 3/4, and Delta Air Lines gained 1 3/8, to 54 1/4. Among the railroads, Norfolk Southern picked up 1 1/2, to 68 3/8, and Union Pacific rose 1 5/8, to 63 1/4. And American President Companies, the shipping line, rose 1 1/8, to 50 1/8.
Shares of auto makers were among the blue-chip stocks that rose. General Motors was up 3/4, to 47 1/2; Ford was up 1 3/8, to 55, and Chrysler was up 1 1/4, to 45 1/2.
Drug stocks were broadly lower on concern over President Clinton's health plan. Pfizer was down 1, to 60 3/8; Eli Lilly was down 7/8, to 47 3/8, and Bristol-Myers Squibb was down 7/8, to 56 3/8.
 
Gain for Paramount
 One of the day's biggest gainers was Paramount Communications, up 3 3/8, to 64 1/2, on news that it is about to be acquired by Viacom. The prospective buyer did not fare as well; Viacom class A shares closed down 1 7/8, at 64 1/8, while class B shares were down 2 5/8, to 56 3/4.
Du Pont was up 1 5/8, to 49 1/2, on the news that it would cut 4,500 jobs. Caterpillar, the construction equipment maker, was up 1/2, to 80 1/4, on news that it expects a $350 million tax refund from the Internal Revenue Service.
Broderbund Software rose again yesterday on last week's news that it would join with Random House to publish multimedia children's software. Broderbund shares were up 3 1/8, to 44 1/8.
I.I.S. Intelligent Information Systems, an Israeli company that makes networking and communications equipment, closed down 7 1/4, to 25, a decline of 22.5 percent. The company announced late Friday that its third-quarter revenue would be poor.
Middleby, a maker of food-service equipment, closed up 3/4, to 2 3/4, for a gain of 37.5 percent. Middleby announced Friday that it would get a $19.5 million settlement in a lawsuit.
Gold mining stocks also fell yesterday, following a continuing selloff in the metal. Gold for October delivery dropped $7.60 an ounce, to $343.10, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, reflecting confidence that inflation would not return. Among the gold losers were Pegasus Gold, down 1, to 18 3/4; Newmont Gold, down 1 7/8, to 38 1/2, and Placer Dome, down 1 1/8 to 16 7/8.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Continue Their Low-Inflation Slide

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gold and silver prices continued to slide yesterday amid expectations of continuing low inflation and slow economic growth.
On other commodity markets, oil prices rebounded from their three-year lows on Friday. 
 The precious metals markets have been shaken by the increasing signs that inflation is under control, especially since the Government reported on Friday that its Producer Price Index in August fell for the fourth straight month.
Investors buy gold when rising inflation threatens the value of other assets, and low inflation often leads to lower gold prices.
"The precious metals are just a disaster area," said Daniel Weissman, head of precious metals trading at MTB Bank in New York. The Producer Price Index, he said, "just reinforced the fact that the economies of the world are growing slowly, without inflation."
 
Lowest Level Since April
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for October delivery fell $7.60, to $343.10 an ounce, gold's lowest level since late April. December gold, the most actively traded futures contract, also lost $7.60, settling at $344.80. December silver dropped 16.2 cents to settle at $3.938 an ounce, its first drop below $4 an ounce in five months.
"There's the expectation of a deflationary environment," said Michael Spriggs, an analyst with S. G. Warburg in London, and "the sentiment has certainly turned negative toward gold."
Gold could even fall back to its lowest price this year -- $326 an ounce -- this week, Mr. Weissman said.
Elsewhere, crude oil futures rebounded on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a decline of about 11 percent over the last two weeks. Light sweet crude oil for October delivery gained 19 cents, to $16.95 a barrel. October heating oil edged up 0.4 cent, to 51.39 cents a gallon, and October unleaded gasoline rose 0.1 cent, to 48.57 cents a gallon.
Traders attributed the weakness in oil to heavy OPEC production and sagging worldwide demand. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Geneva on Sept. 25 in an attempt to bolster prices.
"The preliminary uncertainty going into the OPEC meeting is helping to lift prices," said Roger Voltz, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group in New York.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD;
Statements by Leaders at the Signing of the Middle East Pact

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of remarks by President Clinton, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Mahmoud Abbas, a P.L.O. negotiator, at the signing of the Israeli-Palestinian agreement yesterday in Washington, as recorded by the New York Times. Mr. Arafat and Mr. Abbas spoke in Arabic, and portions of remarks by Mr. Rabin and Mr. Peres were in Hebrew. Mr. Clinton's closing remarks were recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service, and provided by Reuters.
"For too long the young of the Middle East have been caught in a web of hatred not of their own making. For too long they have been taught from the chronicles of war; now we can give them the chance to know the season of peace." -- PRESIDENT CLINTON 
 PRIME Minister Rabin, Chairman Arafat, Foreign Minister Peres, Mr. Abbas, President Carter, President Bush, distinguished guests. On behalf of the United States and Russia, co-sponsors of the Middle East peace process, welcome to this great occasion of history and hope. Today we bear witness to an extraordinary act in one of history's defining dramas -- a drama that began in a time of our ancestors when the word went forth from a sliver of land between the River Jordan and the Mediterranean Sea. That hallowed piece of earth, that land of light and revelation, is the home to the memories and dreams of Jews, Muslims and Christians throughout the world.
As we all know, devotion to that land has also been the source of conflict and bloodshed for too long. Throughout this century bitterness between the Palestinian and Jewish people has robbed the entire region of its resources, its potential and too many of its sons and daughters. The land has been so drenched in warfare and hatred, the conflicting claims of history etched so deeply in the souls of the combatants there, that many believe the past would always have the upper hand. Then, 14 years ago, the past began to give way when, at this place and upon this desk, three men of great vision signed their names to the Camp David accords. Today we honor the memories of Menachem Begin and Anwar Sadat. And we salute the wise leadership of President Jimmy Carter.
Then, as now, we heard from those who said that conflict would come again soon, but the peace between Egypt and Israel has endured. Just so this bold new venture today, this brave gamble that the future can be better than the past, must endure.
Two years ago in Madrid another President took a major step on the road to peace by bringing Israel and all her neighbors together to launch direct negotiations, and today we also express our deep thanks for the skillful leadership of President George Bush.
Ever since Harry Truman first recognized Israel, every American President, Democrat and Republican, has worked for peace between Israel and her neighbors. Now the efforts of all who have labored before us bring us to this moment -- a moment when we dare to pledge what for so long seemed difficult even to imagine: that the security of the Israeli people will be reconciled with the hopes of the Palestinian people, and there will be more security and more hope for all.
Today the leadership of Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization will sign a declaration of principles on interim Palestinian self-government. It charts a course toward reconciliation, between two peoples who have both known the bitterness of exile. Now both pledge to put old sorrows and antagonisms behind them and to work for a shared future shaped by the values of the Torah, the Koran and the Bible. Let us salute also today the Government of Norway, for its remarkable role in nurturing this agreement.
But above all, let us today pay tribute to the leaders who had the courage to lead their people toward peace, away from the scars of battle, the wounds and the losses of the past, toward a brighter tomorrow. The world today thanks Prime Minister Rabin, Foreign Minister Peres and Chairman Arafat.
That tenacity and vision has given us the promise of a new beginning. What these leaders have done now must be done by others. Their achievement must be a catalyst for progress in all aspects of the peace process. And those of us who support them must be there to help in all aspects, for the peace must render the people who make it more secure. A peace of the brave is within our reach. Throughout the Middle East there is a great yearning for the quiet miracle of a normal life. We know a difficult road lies ahead. Every peace has its enemies, those who still prefer the easy habits of hatred to the hard labors of reconciliation, but Prime Minister Rabin has reminded us that you do not have to make peace with your friends, and the Koran teaches that if the enemy inclines toward peace, do thou also incline toward peace.
Therefore, let us resolve that this new mutual recognition will be a continuing process in which the parties transform the very way they see and understand each other. Let the skeptics of this peace recall what once existed among these people. There was a time when the traffic of ideas and commerce and pilgrims flowed uninterrupted among the cities of the fertile crescent. In Spain, in the Middle East, Muslims and Jews once worked together to write brilliant chapters in the history of literature and science. All this can come to pass again.
Mr. Prime Minister, Mr. Chairman, I pledge the active support of the United States of America to the difficult work that lies ahead.
The United States is committed to insuring that the people who are affected by this agreement will be made more secure by it and to leading the world in marshaling the resources necessary to implement the difficult details that will make real the principles to which you commit yourselves today. Together let us imagine what can be accomplished if all the energy and ability the Israelis and the Palestinians have invested into your struggle can now be channeled into cultivating the land and freshening the waters; into ending the boycotts and creating new industry; into building a land as bountiful and peaceful as it is holy. Above all, let us dedicate ourselves today to your region's next generation. In this entire assembly, no one is more important than the group of Israeli and Arab children who are seated here with us today.
Mr. Prime Minister, Mr. Chairman, this day belongs to you. And because of what you have done, tomorrow belongs to them. We must not leave them prey to the politics of extremism and despair, to those who would derail this process because they cannot overcome the fears and hatreds of the past. We must not betray their future.
For too long the young of the Middle East have been caught in a web of hatred not of their own making. For too long they have been taught from the chronicles of war; now we can give them the chance to know the season of peace. For them we must realize the prophecy of Isaiah, that the cry of violence shall no more be heard in your land, nor wrack nor ruin within your borders. The children of Abraham, the descendants of Isaac and Ishmael, have embarked together on a bold journey. Together today with all our hearts and all our souls, we bid them Shalom. Salaam. Peace.

SHIMON PERES
Foreign Minister of Israel
MR. President, your excellencies, ladies and gentlemen:
 Mr. President, I would like to thank you and the great American people for peace and support. Indeed I would like to thank all those who have made this day possible. What we are doing today is more than signing an agreement; it is a revolution. Yesterday a dream, today a commitment.
The Israeli and the Palestinian peoples who fought each other for almost a century have agreed to move decisively on the path of dialogue, understanding and cooperation. We live in an ancient land and as our land is small, so must our reconciliation be great. As our wars have been long, so must our healing be swift. Deep gaps call for lofty breezes. I want to tell the Palestinian delegation that we are sincere, that we mean business. We do not seek to shape your lives or determine your destiny. Let all of us turn from bullets to ballots, from guns to shovels. We shall pray with you. We shall offer you our help in making Gaza prosper and Jericho blossom again.
As we have promised, we shall negotiate with you a permanent settlement and with all our neighbors a comprehensive peace, peace for all. We shall support the agreement with an economic structure. We shall convert the bitter triangle of Jordanians, Palestinians and Israelis into a triangle of political triumph and economic prosperity.
We shall lower our barriers and widen our roads so goods and guests will be able to move freely all about the places holy and other places. This should be another Genesis. We have to build a new commonwealth on our old soil: a Middle East of the people and a Middle East for their children. For their sake we must put an end to the waste of arms races and invest our resources in education.
Ladies and gentlemen, two parallel tragedies have unfolded. Let us become a civic community. Let us bid once and for all farewell to wars, to tricks, to human misery, let us bid farewell to enmity and may there be no more victims on either side.
Let us build a Middle East of hope where today's food is produced and tomorrow's prosperity is guaranteed, a region with a common market, a Near East with a long-range agenda. We owe it to our own soldiers, to the memories of the victims of the Holocaust. Our hearts today grieve for the lost lives of young and innocent people yesterday in our own country. Let their memory be our foundation we are establishing today, a memory of peace on fresh and old tombs.
Suffering is first of all human. We also feel for the innocent loss of Palestinian lives. We begin a new day. The day may be long and the challenges enormous. Our calendar must meet an intensive schedule.
Mr. President, historically you are presiding over a most promising day in the very long history of our region, of our people. I thank all of you ladies and gentlemen, and let's pray together. Let's add hope to determination as all of us since Abraham believe in freedom, in peace, in the blessing of our great land and great spirit.
[Speaking in Hebrew]. From the eternal city of Jerusalem, from this green, promising lawn of the White House, let's say together in the language of our Bible: "Peace, peace to him that is far off and to him that is near," sayeth the Lord, "and I will hear."
Thank you.

MAHMOUD ABBAS
P.L.O. Negotiator
MR. President, ladies and gentlemen: In these historic moments with feelings of joy that are mixed with a maximum sense of responsibility regarding events that are affecting our entire region, I greet you and I greet this distinguished gathering. I hope that this meeting in Washington will prove to be the onset of a positive and constructive change that will serve the interests of the Palestinian and Israeli peoples.
We have come to this point because we believe that peaceful coexistence and cooperation are the only means for reaching understanding and for realizing the hopes of the Palestinians and the Israelis. The agreement we will sign reflects the decision we made in the Palestine Liberation Organization to turn a new page in our relationship with Israel.
We know quite well that this is merely the beginning of a journey that is surrounded by numerous dangers and difficulties and yet our mutual determination to overcome everything that stands in the way of the cause for peace, our common belief that peace is the only means to security and stability and our mutual aspiration for a secure peace characterized by cooperation -- all this will enable us to overcome all obstacles with the support of the international community. And here I would like to mention, in particular, the United States Government, which will shoulder the responsibility of continuing to play an effective and distinct role in the next stage so that this great achievement may be completed.
In this regard, it is important to me to affirm that we are looking forward with a great deal of hope and optimism to a date that is two years from today, when negotiations over the final status of our country are set to begin. We will then settle the remaining fundamental issues, especially those of Jerusalem, the refugees and the settlements. At that time, we will be laying the last brick in the edifice of peace whose foundation has been established today.
Economic development is the principal challenge facing the Palestinian people after years of struggle during which our national infrastructure and institutions were overburdened and drained. We are looking to the world for its support and encouragement in our struggle for growth and development, which begins today.
I thank the Government of the United States of America and the Government of the Russian Federation for the part they played and for their efforts and their sponsorship of the peace process. I also appreciate the role played by the Government of Norway in bringing about this agreement. And I look forward to seeing positive results soon on the remaining Arab-Israeli tracks so we can proceed together with our Arab brothers on this comprehensive quest for peace.
Thank you.

YITZHAK RABIN
Prime Minister of Israel
PRESIDENT of the United States, your excellencies, ladies and gentlemen: This signing of the Israeli-Palestinian declaration of principle here today -- it's not so easy -- neither for myself as a soldier in Israel's war nor for the people of Israel, not to the Jewish people in the diaspora, who are watching us now with great hope mixed with apprehension. It is certainly not easy for the families of the victims of the war's violence, terror, whose pain will never heal, for the many thousands who defended our lives in their own and have even sacrificed their lives for our own. For them this ceremony has come too late.
Today on the eve of an opportunity, opportunity for peace and perhaps end of violence and war, we remember each and every one of them with everlasting love. We have come from Jerusalem, the ancient and eternal capital of the Jewish people. We have come from an anguished and grieving land. We have come from a people, a home, a family that has not known a single year, not a single month, in which mothers have not wept for their sons. We have come to try and put an end to the hostilities so that our children, our children's children, will no longer experience the painful cost of war: violence and terror. We have come to secure their lives and to ease the soul and the painful memories of the past -- to hope and pray for peace.
Let me say to you, the Palestinians, we are destined to live together on the same soil in the same land. We, the soldiers who have returned from battles stained with blood; we who have seen our relatives and friends killed before our eyes; we who have attended their funerals and cannot look in the eyes of their parents; we who have come from a land where parents bury their children; we who have fought against you, the Palestinians -- we say to you today, in a loud and a clear voice: enough of blood and tears. Enough.
We have no desire for revenge. We harbor no hatred towards you. We, like you, are people -- people who want to build a home. To plant a tree. To love -- live side by side with you. In dignity. In empathy. As human beings. As free men. We are today giving peace a chance -- and saying to you and saying again to you: enough. Let us pray that a day will come when we all will say farewell to the arms. We wish to open a new chapter in the sad book of our lives together -- a chapter of mutual recognition, of good neighborliness, of mutual respect, of understanding. We hope to embark on a new era in the history of the Middle East. Today here in Washington at the White House, we will begin a new reckoning in the relations between peoples, between parents tired of war, between children who will not know war.
President of the United States, ladies and gentlemen, our inner strength, our high moral values, have been the right for thousands of years, from the book of the books. In one of which, we read: To everything there is a season and a time to every purpose under heaven: a time to be born and a time to die, a time to kill and a time to heal, a time to weep and a time to laugh, a time to love and a time to hate, a time of war and a time of peace. Ladies and gentlemen, the time for peace has come.
In two days the Jewish people will celebrate the beginning of a new year. I believe, I hope, I pray that the new year will bring a message of redemption for all peoples-- a good year for you, for all of you; a good year for Israelis and Palestinians; a good year for all the peoples of the Middle East; a good year for our American friends who so want peace and are helping to achieve it.
For Presidents and members of previous Administrations, especially for you, President Clinton, and your staff, for all citizens of the world, may peace come to all your homes. In the Jewish tradition it is customary to conclude our prayers with the word Amen. With your permission, men of peace, I shall conclude with the words taken from the prayer recited by Jews daily, and whoever of you who volunteer, I would ask the entire audience to join me in saying Amen. [Speaking in Hebrew]. May He who brings peace to His universe bring peace to us and to all Israel. Amen.
 
YASIR ARAFAT
P.L.O. Chairman
IN the name of God the most merciful, the passionate. Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen: I would like to express our tremendous appreciation to President Clinton and to his Administration for sponsoring this historic event, which the entire world has been waiting for. Mr. President, I am taking this opportunity to assure you and to assure the great American people that we share your values for freedom, justice, and human rights -- values for which my people have been striving.
My people are hoping that this agreement, which we are signing today, marks the beginning of the end of a chapter of pain and suffering which has lasted throughout this century. My people are hoping that this agreement which we are signing today will usher in an age of peace, coexistence and equal rights. We are relying on your role, Mr. President, and on the role of all the countries which believe that without peace in the Middle East, peace in the world will not be complete.
Enforcing the agreements and moving toward the final settlement, after two years to implement all aspects of U.N. resolutions 242 and 338 in all of their aspects, and resolve all the issues of Jerusalem, the settlements, the refugees and the boundaries, will be a Palestinian and an Israeli responsibility. It is also the responsibility of the international community in its entirety to help the parties overcome the tremendous difficulties which are still standing in the way of reaching a final and comprehensive settlement.
Now, as we stand on the threshold of this new historic era, let me address the people of Israel and their leaders, with whom we are meeting today for the first time. And let me assure them that the difficult decision we reached together was one that required great and exceptional courage.
We will need more courage and determination to continue the course of building coexistence and peace between us. This is possible. And it will happen with mutual determination and with the effort that will be made with all parties on all the tracks to establish the foundations of a just and comprehensive peace. Our people do not consider that exercising the right to self-determination could violate the rights of their neighbors or infringe on their security. Rather, putting an end to their feelings of being wronged and of having suffered an historic injustice is the strongest guarantee to achieve coexistence and openness between our two peoples and future generations.
Our two peoples are awaiting today this historic hope. And they want to give peace a real chance.
Such a shift will give us an opportunity to embark upon the process of economic, social and cultural growth and development. And we hope that international participation in that process will be as extensive as it can be. This shift will also provide an opportunity for all forms of cooperation on a broad scale and in all fields.
I thank you, Mr. President. We hope that our meeting will be a new beginning for fruitful and effective relations between the American people and the Palestinian people.
I wish to thank the Russian Federation and President Boris Yeltsin. Our thanks also go to Secretary [of State Warren] Christopher and Foreign Minister [Andrei V.] Kozyrev [of Russia] to the Government of Norway and to the Foreign Minister of Norway, for the positive part they played in bringing about this major achievement.
I extend greetings to all the Arab leaders, our brothers, and to all the world leaders who contributed to this achievement.
Ladies and gentlemen, the battle for peace is the most difficult battle of our lives. It deserves our utmost efforts because the land of peace, the land of peace yearns for a just and comprehensive peace.
[Speaking in English] Mr. President, thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

PRESIDENT CLINTON
 WE have been granted the great privilege of witnessing this victory for peace. Just as the Jewish people this week celebrate the dawn of a new year, let us all go from this place to celebrate the dawn of a new era, not only for the Middle East but for the entire world.
The sound we heard today, once again as in ancient Jericho, was of trumpets toppling walls, the walls of anger and suspicion between Israeli and Palestinian, between Arab and Jew. This time, praise God, the trumpets herald not the destruction of that city but its new beginning.
Now let each of us here today return to our portion of that effort, uplifted by the spirit of the moment, refreshed in our hopes and guided by the wisdom of the Almighty, who has brought us to this joyous day. Go in peace. Go as peacemakers.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: News Analysis;
The Next Challenge for the U.S.

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
As he himself said, this was not Bill Clinton's day. It was not he who brought together the sober old soldier and the grinning guerrilla fighter in the leafy calm of the South Lawn of the White House, far from the battlefields of the Middle East, for a paean to peace.
However deft, however sagacious, he was but the master of ceremonies. He thanked those who had labored to bring about the latest in a series of once-inconceivable changes that have remade the world in five short years. He bestowed the congratulations of the world's only superpower. And he gave Yitzhak Rabin a timely little nudge when he seemed reluctant to grasp the outstretched hand of Yasir Arafat. 
 Now, though, President Clinton will have to assume the central role if the momentum toward a comprehensive peace settlement is not to be lost. That is likely to be a long, messy job of diplomatic donkey work in the dark corners of history -- a much less gratifying chapter than today's carefully scripted pageant of good intentions.
Israel and Jordan are poised to move forward tomorrow. But the other Arab nations whose representatives watched today's ceremony from the front rows know that only the United States can provide the impetus needed for the next round of negotiations. Mr. Arafat spoke for them, too, when he said his people "are relying on your role, Mr. President" to "usher in an age of peace."
So this President, who so longs to concentrate on problems at home, is thrust like so many of his predecessors into an international arena not of his choosing. Along with the rest of the world, the United States has a new ward, the inchoate entity called Palestine, and it has the main responsibility for fostering Israeli settlements with its other neighbors while deepening the one with the Palestinians.
It will be up to Mr. Clinton, who does not much like doing so, to butt heads between the Israelis and the Syrians, and perhaps take considerable heat from American Jews in the process, which he did not have to endure this time.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor any other American President has ever wanted to do business with Mr. Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization. As Mr. Rabin, the Israeli Prime Minister, said in one of his many moments of eloquence this morning, "It's not so easy," swallowing all this change.
But in the end even as stiff-necked a leader as Charles de Gaulle had to deal with the National Liberation Front in Algeria. Henry A. Kissinger had to deal with the Vietcong, South Africa's white leaders had to deal with Nelson Mandela and now the United States must deal with the P.L.O. If rebellions succeed, or even end in stalemate, the rebels win a place at the table.
The United States will have to do its utmost to make this accord work. That means, first and foremost, helping to persuade ordinary Israelis and Palestinians that their self-interest lies in its working, not in its failing. The nay-sayers among both peoples will have to be answered with accomplishments -- Benjamin Netanyahu and his followers, settlers and others, in Israel, and the prophets of continuing violence both inside and outside the P.L.O.
Much will depend on building viable economies in the areas that the Palestinians are to take over. Waxing poetic, the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, promised to help them in "making Gaza prosper and Jericho bloom again." Arab countries will also help, and so will Japan, but some of the money will have to come from the overburdened United States Treasury.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher has suggested that at some point American troops will probably have to play a role in keeping the peace, perhaps replacing the Israelis who now man the Golan Heights overlooking Syria.
After this week, perhaps even by Wednesday or Thursday, the attention of the capital will turn back to the twin domestic issues that Mr. Clinton has put atop his agenda, the North American Free Trade Agreement and reform of the nation's health-care system. They will once again be viewed as the prime measures of the President's success over the next 12 months or so.
 
Clinton Accepts New Role
 But to them, and not far below them, must now be added the Middle East.
Mr. Clinton accepted his new role in his speech, asserting that "the United States is committed to insuring that the people who are affected by this agreement will be made more secure by it, and to leading the world in marshaling the resources necessary to implement the difficult details."
No doubt the details are difficult. Such questions as the nature and borders of any Palestinian state, whether the Israeli settlers are to remain on the West Bank, and especially the question of Jerusalem have been put aside. Mr. Arafat continued to promise that the Palestinian flag will fly over Jerusalem in the next two years; Mr. Rabin replies curtly, "Forget it."
Moreover, Mr. Clinton concedes that he does not know quite how to proceed. In an interview over the weekend, he said, "I'm going to develop a whole strategy; I just haven't had time to do it yet." Much will depend on whether he gets it right when he does.
For this is a part of the world where the United States has vital interests, economic as well as political. It is also a part of the world where the United States has a long if not always successful record of involvement.
If the United Nations operation in Somalia fails, and United States policy fails with it, that is embarrassing. The President, according to his aides, rebukes himself for the failure of the Western nations to end the suffering in Bosnia. But he is unlikely to suffer politically, even if the United States suffers strategically, for miscalculations in the Balkans or in Africa.
The Middle East is another matter. If Mr. Clinton bungles there -- if he shows an unsure touch or fails to follow through -- his reputation and that of his country will suffer.
Not that success will guarantee a second term. When Jimmy Carter pulled off the Camp David agreement between Egypt and Israel, one of his top aides asked another, "If this doesn't get us re-elected, what will?" It did not, of course, in large part because of trouble in another part of the Middle East.
There was plenty of euphoria at the White House today, but not that kind; the lesson of 1992, when George Bush won in the Persian Gulf but lost at the ballot box, is far too fresh.
By all accounts, a settlement between Syria and Israel, which once seemed far more likely than what was achieved in recent days, now seems the most difficult item on the agenda. A senior White House official said that a lot of low-level talking would be necessary before President Clinton could take a more direct role in talks with President Hafez al-Assad and the Israelis.
Because of the difficult road ahead, there was a concerted effort by the participants in today's drama to diminish expectations. But that was hard to do, when something everyone had considered impossible -- even Mr. Kissinger, by his own account -- was unfolding there on the Lawn, bigger than life.

HEADLINE: Fleet Securities Officials Say They Lobbied Holtzman

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Executives of Fleet Securities met with New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman at a fund-raising breakfast to lobby for a greater share of the city's underwriting 10 months before Ms. Holtzman claims she first became aware the firm was seeking city business, bank and law-enforcement officials said.
Ms. Holtzman has maintained that she was unaware Fleet was vying to become a member of the syndicate of firms that sells city bonds until a reporter told her in April that the firm had been selected. She said her deputy, Darcy Bradbury, selected Fleet in March. 
 Fleet's selection has become the focus of a city investigation because seven months earlier, Ms. Holtzman's Senate campaign borrowed $450,000 at a favorable interest rate from Fleet Bank, which is part of the same Rhode Island financial conglomerate.
Ms. Holtzman said she did not promise the firm anything. "I have never promised anybody any city business in return for any campaign contributions," she said, through her spokeswoman, Maerwydd McFarland. "I am outraged that on the eve of a primary these smear tactics and allegations continue."
In an interview on New York 1 News last night, Ms. Holtzman declined to say whether city business had come up at the breakfast. But asked later what she would have done had it come up, she said, "I would say there are ways of applying for it or terminate the conversation immediately."
 
Not Waiving Confidentiality
 The timing of the disclosure, on the eve of the Democratic primary, left Ms. Holtzman with little time to counter it. The information was reported by bank executives and law-enforcement officials, and it was not clear whether any of them had specific political motives against Ms. Holtzman.
Last night, Ms. Holtzman again refused to allow the release of a report by the city Department of Investigation about the loan. The report has been forwarded to the city Conflicts of Interest Board, which is reviewing it and could release it if Ms. Holtzman waives her right to confidentiality.
Bank officials and investigators said Ms. Holtzman received about $3,000 in campaign contributions from executives of Fleet Securities at a breakfast meeting with her on June 11 last year, just moments after the officials had pitched the firm's desire to obtain a greater share of the city's bond underwriting. Such fund-raising events are routine in New York and both the city and the state comptrollers have held them.
The 45-minute meeting between Ms. Holtzman and the firm's president, John O'Brien, took place about 8 A.M. in the Vista Hotel in the World Trade Center, participants said. The other Fleet officials at the meeting were Brigitt Jandreau-Smith, Joseph Bosch and Gregory Licalzi. The meeting was also attended by Sheila Levin, the Holtzman campaign's finance director.
Over breakfast, the executives tried to convince Ms. Holtzman that Fleet should be given a greater share of city bonds to sell, participants in the meeting said. They specifically mentioned that Fleet was interested in being promoted to co-manager, a coveted status in municipal bond underwriting, bank officials said.
Senior managers and co-managers, which are selected jointly by the Mayor and the Comptroller, are guaranteed a larger share of the city's $5 billion-a-year bond business than other firms, which sell bonds on a free-lance basis.
 
$3,000 in Contributions
 At the end of the meeting, as the group stood to leave, Mr. Bosch handed Ms. Levin an envelope containing about $3,000 worth of campaign contributions from Fleet executives, some of whom were not at the meeting, according to participants and Federal Election Commission records. The records show that Ms. Jandreau-Smith contributed $500; two other Fleet vice presidents, John Flynn and Robert Speer, gave $1,000 each, and a fourth executive, William Homann, contributed $500.
Thomas Lavelle, a spokesman for Fleet Bank, confirmed that the meeting had occurred and said Fleet wanted to call attention to "its interest in expanding business within the city."

HEADLINE: Questions Linger in Explosion Case;
Trial of Four of Seven Suspects in Bombing of World Trade Center Opens Today

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Under extraordinary security, the trial of four of the seven men charged in the World Trade Center bombing opens today in Federal Court in Manhattan, promising the first comprehensive picture of a crime that shook American complacency about terrorism. After almost seven months of investigation, prosecutors have concluded that the plotters had sought to collapse a 110-story trade center tower, killing thousands.
The defendants -- Mahmud Abouhalima, a 33-year-old Egyptian cabdriver, and three men with Palestinian roots, Ahmad M. Ajaj, 27, Nidal A. Ayyad, 25, and Mohammed A. Salameh, 25 -- contend that the charges are flawed by false identifications and that the Government is putting Islam on trial. 
 For all the attention the case has generated, many questions linger: How did the scheme come together? Did the bombers act alone or with the help of a foreign power or international terrorist group? Why did they strike? The riddles may not be solved at the trial. But here is what has come to light on some of the key points.
 
Motives and Clues
 Why the plotters picked the World Trade Center as a target and what they hoped to gain through the attack remains unclear. Some evidence suggests political motives but lawyers close to the case say the plot was propelled by religious fervor. Some experts believe the trade center was chosen as a symbol of Western power. Others believe it was simply chosen at random from a list of possible targets.
Perhaps one of the most explicit pieces of evidence is a letter sent to The New York Times four days after the blast and signed by the Liberation Army Fifth Battalion that claimed responsibility for the bombing that killed six people. It said that unless the United States cut ties with Israel and met other demands involving Middle East policy, more attacks would follow.
The letter, which Federal agents described as authentic, also claimed that "more than 150 suicidal soldiers" were ready to attack other United States targets.
Investigators said that by retrieving an erased computer file and comparing saliva samples, they were able to trace the letter to the personal computer of Mr. Ayyad, a Kuwaiti-born chemical engineer, who worked at Allied-Signal in Morristown, N.J.
Later in March, United States officials said they were given a report of an alleged confession by another defendant, Mr. Abouhalima, during his detention in Egypt.
Egyptian officials told the United States that Mr. Abouhalima had said the blast was to punish the United States for meddling in Middle Eastern affairs. Mr. Abouhalima, they said, told them that the plotting had been done in Afghanistan among veterans of the anti-Soviet war, that two self-described Iranian intelligence agents had approved the plan and that two Iraqis who disappeared before the blast had aided in the crime.
Mr. Abouhalima also reportedly said that the plotters had been sent money collected by the militant Islamic Group, whose spiritual leader is Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, and the Muslim Brotherhood. They were also financed, the Egyptians say he told them, by Iranian businesses and Islamic institutions from Saudi Arabia and Europe.
 
Disavows Confession
 Mr. Abouhalima was returned to United States custody on March 24 and was found to have burn marks on his groin. He later disavowed making a confession, saying any statements were extracted under torture and were unreliable. They will not be introduced in the trial.
Nevertheless, the other two suspects in the case, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, 25, and Abdul Rahman Yasin, 33, are both missing and believed to have fled to Iraq. Federal officials have offered $2 million rewards for each of them. Another man, Bilal Alkaisi, 27, a Jordanian, is charged in the case, but was set aside for later trial.
Investigators, meanwhile, have tried to trace hints of international involvement through bank and telephone records. Early reports cited transfers of large sums of money from abroad into some of the defendants' bank accounts and telephone records show numerous calls from their homes to Germany, Iraq and Egypt.
But without more evidence, prosecutors are not expected to tie the attack to foreign sponsorship.
The Government has, however, through an indictment in another bombing case, linked the trade center bombing to a larger terrorist conspiracy, centered on a group that it says is headed by Mr. Abdel Rahman, the Egyptian cleric who was tried and acquitted in the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat.
Members of that group, they say, including Mr. Abouhalima, El Sayyid A. Nosair and Clement Rodney Hampton-El, met as early as January 1990 at Kennedy International Airport and later gathered at mosques and homes in Brooklyn and Jersey City. Mr. Nosair was charged but acquitted in the killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane, the militant Jewish leader, later that year. Mr. Hampton-El, Mr. Nosair and others are now charged with belonging to a terrorist group that is accused of plotting not only the trade center blast, but also the bombing of the United Nations and the Hudson and Lincoln tunnels and the murder and kidnapping of civilians and officials.
Transcripts from the second case, made from secretly taped meetings with a Government informer, also indicate that the trade center bombers may have believed that attacking the Lower Manhattan landmark dominating the city's skyline would deal a crippling economic blow to New Yorkers, while striking at an important symbol of the Western world.
But lawyers close to the case suggest the 110-story tower may also have been chosen at random from several New York City landmarks.
Mr. Ayyad's lawyer, Atiq Ahmed, has challenged the Government's evidence on the letter from the Liberation Army to The Times, claiming that the retrieved computer file does not match the letter.
As for the financing, defense lawyers say that the Government's evidence suggests that the sums expended in the plot were negligible, conflicting with Mr. Abouhalima's reported statements about major foreign contributions.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks to Keep World Trade Talks on Track

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
With France waging a strenuous campaign to overturn last winter's trans-Atlantic deal on farm subsidies, top American and European officials met here today in an effort to prevent the dispute from tearing apart seven-year-old world trade talks.
Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's vice president for external economic affairs, met twice today with Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, in search of concessions to offer the French without actually renegotiating the farm subsidy deal. 
 But Mr. Kantor, who expressed skepticism at his Senate confirmation hearing in January about previous American concessions, said in a telephone interview afterward that he offered nothing new on the deal, which the Bush Administration completed last November at Blair House, the White House guest quarters.
"We're not going to reopen Blair House -- we made that quite clear to Sir Leon," Mr. Kantor said.
A European official who insisted on anonymity said that the community still hoped to complete world trade talks that began seven years ago this month in Punta del Este, Uruguay. "Sir Leon remains optimistic that the Uruguay Round will be completed by the Dec. 15 deadline and will include the Blair House accord," said the official, who declined to elaborate.
The goal of the global talks is to put trade in agriculture and services under the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Bentsen Expresses Concern
 Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said this afternoon that he had warned European leaders against any effort to change the farm subsidy deal. "I'm deeply concerned about any possibility of opening up the Blair agreement," Mr. Bentsen told a small group of reporters. "I strongly urged a number of the European leaders not to do that, that I thought it would endanger GATT and the Dec. 15 deadline."
Reuters reported from Brussels today that Spain had aligned itself with France in opposing the Blair House agreement.
Mr. Kantor said that the United States had recently sent letters to a number of European capitals warning them against any retreat from the agreement. He said he was not surprised by the current frictions within the community and remained hopeful that the global trade talks could be completed.
"Any time you come to an end of a negotiation as important as the Uruguay Round, with as many diverse interests, there are a number of parties who will begin to negotiate strongly," he said.
The Bush Administration's farm subsidy agreement headed off planned American tariffs of 200 percent on white wine and oilseed from the European Community. The Bush and Clinton Administrations have never taken the legal steps to end the threat of retaliation, and American officials are discussing the possibility of reviving it if the community retreats from last year's deal, Washington trade experts said.
But Mr. Kantor said that he never raised this possibility during his conversations today with Mr. Brittan, and that neither side made any threats at all.
The Blair House Agreement was actually two pacts. One pact resolved a long-simmering trade dispute over the community's subsidized production of soybeans and other oilseeds. The other pact was a deal to set limits on subsidized grain exports as part of ongoing global trade talks.
Officials involved in the deal have said that the United States made large concessions in the oilseeds talks while the European Community made concessions on grain exports. France has since expressed a willingness to accept the oilseed deal but not the grain export pact.
The French strategy has infuriated Clinton Administration officials and amused trade analysts. "They're trying to treat Blair House like salami, where you can cut off one piece, when it's really a pot au feu," a stew, said Carol L. Brookins, the president of World Perspectives Inc., a Washington agriculture consulting firm.
"This really is typical French negotiating strategy -- they love to negotiate a deal and then keep what they want out of it and renegotiate the rest," she said.
French officials have contended in recent weeks that the Blair House Agreement is not final because the community's member governments have not formally endorsed it. So they say they want further negotiations, not renegotiation.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury bonds and intermediate Treasury notes rallied most of yesterday as traders and investors seemed to be betting that today's inflation report will be moderate. But late in the afternoon, as traders and investors seemed to lose some of their nerve, prices fell and the market wound up little changed on the day.
"Traders were reluctant to stay with this thing in front of a high-risk number," said Joel Marver, the chief technical analyst at Technical Data in Boston. 
 It is not that forecasters expect bad news when the Labor Department releases the Consumer Price Index for August this morning. But with prices so high and yields so low, they fear there could be some sharp selling either today or later this week as the market finally takes a break after one of its sharpest rallies in recent years.
"Say the number is bullish and the market moves up but not sharply," Mr. Marver said. "That is where you could look for the correction to begin."
The price of the 30-year bond finished unchanged with the yield at Friday's 5.87 percent, just above the 25-year low of 5.86 percent reached last Wednesday.
The prices of the 10-year and seven-year notes each inched higher, rising by 1/32 . The yield on the 10-year note remained unchanged at 5.27 percent, while the yield on the seven-year note slipped to 4.86 percent from 4.87 percent. These yields are still a little above their recent lows.
But as the prices of longer-term securities were unchanged or slightly higher, the prices of shorter-term securities fell. The price of the two-year note was off 2/32 as the yield, which moves in the oppositie direction, rose to 3.81 percent, from 3.77 percent Friday. The price of the three-year note slipped 3/32 , with the yield rising to 4.10 percent from 4.07 percent.
In the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rate on the three-month bill was 2.98 percent, up from 2.95 percent a week ago, while the average discount rate on the six-month bill was 3.06 percent, up from 3.03 percent.
On Wall Street the consensus for the Conseumer Price Index is for no change to a slight increase of just one-tenth of 1 percent.
At the same time, the Commerce Derpartment will release the retail sales data for the last month. The consensus forecast here is no increase in sales.
If the forecasts are correct, both pieces of data should reinforce the beliefs that underly the recent bond market rally: that inflation will remain moderate, with prices possibly rising this year at a slightly slower rate than in 1992. And the economy continues to be sluggish, defying expectations that growth would pick up in the second half of the year.
But the market may have set itself up for a little disappointment. The reason is that the unexpectedly sharp decline in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which was reported Friday, raised expectations for the consumer price report due out today.
The producer index dropped six-tenths of 1 percent last month because of a 25 percent decline in tobacco prices. After the report, many forecasters revised their predictions for the Consumer Price Index, generally reducing their forecasts by about one-tenth of one percentage point.
Before Friday, the consensus for the Consumer Price Index had been an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent. Now if the report shows an increase of two-tenths, it could prompt some selling.
The continuation in the decline in the price of gold seemed to add to the feeling that inflation, which is the bond market's biggest headache, is well in check. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the price of gold dropped $7.60, to $343.10 an ounce. The price of gold is now down 16 percent since it reached a recent high of $408.10 an ounce on Aug. 2.
While gold is often seen as a barometer of inflation, it is probably not as significant right now as the decline in oil prices. A drop in demand and record production levels have combined to push the price of oil to its lowest level in three years. Some analysts now believe the price of oil could reach its lowest levels since the price collapse of 1986, when the price of a barrel of oil dropped below $10 and the Consumer Price Index rose just 1.1 percent for the year.
Following are the results from the Treasury auction yesterday of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Judge Names Panel to Study Life on Juries

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Concerned that for many people, jury service is unpleasant and a financial burden, and that juries may not adequately reflect the ethnic makeup of their areas, two of New York State's top judges yesterday named a panel to propose an overhaul of the jury system.
The marching orders that Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye gave the committee include looking into the use of unemployment rolls or other lists to broaden the pool of potential jurors, improving the chances that a person called up for a pool of potential jurors will actually serve on a panel, eliminating some exemptions from jury service, and increasing the $15 a day jurors are now paid. She also asked the panel to look into the possibility of providing child care and work areas for potential jurors. 
 Her suggestions for obtaining candidates from untapped sources and raising their pay would require action by the state Legislature. But with others, like speeding up the system for calling and processing jurors, she has the authority to order changes.
New York jurors are now drawn from voter-registration, motor-vehicle and tax rolls, which together include about 90 percent of the people, but which tend to miss transients and many of the poorest.
Judge Kaye made the announcement along with the state's Chief Administrative Judge, E. Leo Milonas. The 30-member committee -- made up of judges, lawyers, executives and academics -- was told to report its recommendations by Jan. 1.
Colleen McMahon, the panel's presiding officer and a partner at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, said that "half of all the jury questionnaires sent out get thrown away." To many jurors, she added, "it seems like everything is done for the lawyer's convenience or the judge's convenience, and nothing for their convenience."
Judge Kaye said a matter of particular concern was how much time the members of jury pools spend doing nothing. "When people are brought in and have to wait a great deal, sometimes in uncomfortable places, and don't ever get to serve on juries, I think that feeds a negative perception of the system," she said.
If jurors' time could be used efficiently, she said, fewer jurors would have to be called, service could be shorter, and there would be a greater chance of hearing cases.
The panel will also address concerns raised two years ago by the state's Judicial Commission on Minorities, which concluded that blacks and Hispanics were generally underrepresented on juries.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Both Sides Voice Optimism About Avoiding Ford Strike

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 13

 BODY:
With the deadline closing in on them, officials on both sides continued to predict today that the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers union would sign a new labor contract by Tuesday night, avoiding a strike.
Even if they miss the deadline, which falls at 11:59 P.M. Tuesday, negotiators are likely to continue talking, officials said, since they have not reached an impasse. 
 Such 11th-hour bargaining is not unusual in automobile talks. If the two sides settled early, it would be harder for the company to convince its shareholders, and the union to convince its members, that they achieved, respectively, the scrawniest or the fattest deal possible.
"They're working hard, and they'll work into the night," said David M. Caplan, a Ford spokesman.
 
Separate Situation in Canada
 In Canada, where the Canadian Automobile Workers are facing a Tuesday deadline on a separate agreement with the Big Three auto makers, talks appeared to be making progress today. After making an initial offer that displeased the union, the Chrysler Corporation, the lead company in the Canadian negotiations, made a richer offer over the weekend. The Canadian auto workers are seeking wage increases and more holidays.
Chances of avoiding a strike had improved, said Miriam Edelson, a spokeswoman for the Canadian union, but she added, "There is still a long way to go."
Investors appeared to be optimistic about settlements. Ford stock gained $1.375 a share, to $55, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today. Chrysler rose $1.25, to $45.50, and the General Motors Corporation was up 75 cents, to $47.50.
In the bargaining at Ford, the top negotiators -- Jack Hall, a Ford vice president, and Owen F. Bieber, president of the U.A.W. -- did not plan to meet today, instead directing bargaining by several subcommittees of representatives.
The negotiations are occurring at Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, just west of Detroit. A strike against Ford has been authorized by the U.A.W. membership.
The most contested issues, including how to cut health care costs and insure greater job security, have not yet been settled, but such matters are traditionally not settled one by one. Instead, each subcommittee determines the cost of the benefits, and then the lead negotiators total them up to perform their last-minute horse-trading on the basis of a total economic package.
Under the current contract, an assembly line worker at full scale earns $17.01 and hour, with 35 paid days off each year.
Once finished at Ford, the union will use the agreement as a pattern in bargaining with Chrysler and the General Motors, where the current three-year contracts have been extended indefinitely.
Once ratified by the U.A.W. membership at the Big Three, the contracts will cover about 400,000 active workers and 390,000 retirees and surviving spouses.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Zen of First Impressions About Being in College

BYLINE: By George Judson

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
FOR more than an hour, the students in English 101 had wrestled with an essay seemingly written not merely to challenge them, but to defeat them. Now the instructor, Monica Marciczkiewicz, urged them to reflect on the author's argument. "It's so much in the air," she said, "that it's very easy for us to agree with what she is proposing." She added, "You can think about it at home."
Home? An abstract concept if there is one, on the campus of Rutgers University in the first weeks of the fall semester. Several thousand 18-year-olds have left home to come here, and finding a new one in this academic community of 33,000 is likely to take a while. They are assumed to be stunned, dazed and overwhelmed, even those who couldn't wait to get away, who endured high school like the line in a Morrissey song, "I'm just passing through here on my way to somewhere civilized." 
 Do they miss home?, ask parents, for whom sending a child off to college holds all the thrills and anxieties of launching a rocket. In Tinsley Hall, a dormitory for first-year students on College Avenue, the answer is a qualified yes from those gathered on a recent afternoon.
What do they miss? "The food." "Security." "My mom." "A bathroom around the corner." "Towels in the bathroom." "Soap." What don't they miss? "Parents." "Brothers." "Sisters." "Having to say where you're going."
Suddenly they lead communal lives, young men and women passing each other in the hallway in bathrobes each morning, open doors inviting unexpected visitors, dinner served not at their seat in a dining room, but at the end of a long line in a dining hall.
"The worst thing is just adjusting to the lack of privacy, to having a roommate," said Bil Curran, from Berkeley Heights. "To your roommate's music," someone added.
"I'm more adjusted than I thought I'd be," said Amy Smith of Anderson, S.C. "But we're all lost together," said Joanna Lindenbaum, of Paramus.
Rutgers' mission may be research and education, but its first order of business each fall is getting everyone settled. The first-year students ("freshmen," to older, less correct generations) arrive early for three days of orientation. Workshops and discussion groups explain how to use the library and the computer center, how to avoid sexual assault, how to get along with classmates who don't look like the neighbors back home.
Registering for courses offers a first lesson in bureaucracy. Crowding onto the buses that shuttle students and professors between classes on the four campuses here offers a first lesson in commuting. At night, fraternity parties serve free beer, and the "grease trucks" parked near the fraternities are still selling gyros and burgers at 3 A.M. Education can strike anywhere, anytime.
"I'll speak for everyone," said Thomas Grimaldi, also of Paramus, taking on the subject of drinking. "I don't do it, but all my friends do." His friends all laughed.
In the 1980's, when New Jersey had money, Rutgers spent hundreds of millions on its research centers, leading to complaints that undergraduates were being neglected. In his three years as president, Francis L. Lawrence, a scholar of 17th-century French literature, has worked to address those complaints, even as recession has eroded the Legislature's support, requiring both higher tuition and larger classes.
He celebrates the liberal arts, while his deans try to open up the immense university to students who sometimes sit in lecture sections larger than their entire high school class.
"The professors want to interact, but a student has to take the initiative," said Susan G. Forman, the dean of undergraduate studies. "The individual attention is there if they want it."
At midday in the student center on College Avenue, students -- nearly all of them male -- fed quarters into video games in an arcade. But across the hall, every terminal in the computer center was taken.
In English 101, Ms. Marciczkiewicz guided students through the killer essay, an appeal for multicultural education by Mary Louise Pratt, a Stanford University professor. A few buildings away, a political scientist lectured on dead white males named Hobbes and Locke and Jefferson.
A new, all-embracing way of life was taking shape. "You're not part of the world," said Theresa LeComte, of Lenox, Mass. "You're just part of the Rutgers world."
Yet what a world. In Mattia Hall, other students talked about their new home. "In high school, it's total routine," said Kristen Tahan, of Kinnelon. "It's the same exact thing every day. Here, it's something different every day."
Robert Skinner leaned forward and held out his wrist. "It's true," he said. "I never owned a watch before. I had to buy one to know what time it is."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
