HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Slow Trading Before Price and Sales Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies in light trading yesterday in anticipation of fresh reports on the American economy.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6085 German marks, up from 1.5975 marks on Friday. It also rose to 106.27 Japanese yen, from 106.10. 
 Traders said the dollar strengthened against the German mark as investors positioned themselves for the economic reports scheduled today on consumer prices and retail sales for August. In addition, they said, investors locked in profits by selling currencies that had recently gained against the dollar.
 
See Dollar Advancing
 Some traders also appeared optimistic that the dollar would strengthen further as European central banks pay off loans they had taken from the Bundesbank of Germany to defend their currencies during the monetary turmoil in Europe in July.
In recent weeks, the European central banks have been selling dollars and buying marks to repay their loans, causing the dollar to decline.
Albert Soria, a vice president at Kansallis Osake Pankki, a Finnish bank, said the strengthening of the dollar was "partly a correction to a serious downtrend established in conjunction with the replenishment of Deutsche mark reserves."
The dollar also gained on the yen as traders anticipated an interest rate cut and other measures to stimulate Japan's economy and shrink the Japanese trade surplus.
The head of the Bank of Japan, Yasushi Mieno, said at a news conference yesterday that the central bank was not considering a rate cut. Such cuts, however, are not normally disclosed in advance.
"The market is still expecting a cut" in the Japanese discount rate, said Margaret Kudarauskas, a foreign exchange specialist with Technical Data in Boston. A lower interest rate would be likely to push the yen down because yen-denominated investments would earn less and therefore be less popular.
Among other currencies, the British pound fell to $1.5455 in New York yesterday, from $1.5520 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Buffalo Election Finds Troubled City at Crossroads

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
There is a sense in this city of aging factories and corner taverns that things are at a turning point, and not only because the man who has been Mayor for 16 years is not seeking re-election this year.
Crime is more widespread and more violent. City finances are increasingly desperate. The schools are struggling. And the middle class is fleeing. 
 With 73 percent of the city's voters registered Democrats, there is a good chance that the winner of Tuesday's Democratic primary will become the Mayor who has to deal with it all.
In the view of Henry L. Taylor Jr., director of the Center for Applied Public Affairs Studies at the State University of New York at Buffalo, voters will choose "a leader who will guide Buffalo through one of the most complex and difficult periods in its history."
 
A Difference in Spending
 The Democratic candidates are Anthony M. Masiello, 46, a state senator who is also running on the Liberal Party line, and Eugene M. Fahey, 42, majority leader of the city's Common Council, also running on the Conservative line.
The Erie County Democratic party and a number of unions, black lawmakers and community leaders and others have endorsed Mr. Masiello, and he is ahead in the polls. Mr. Fahey has fewer endorsements, which he says proves his independence.
Mr. Masiello said he would spend $400,000 to $500,000 on the primary, and Mr. Fahey said he expects to spend about $150,000.
There is no Republican mayoral primary since no one is challenging the party's endorsed candidate, Richard A. Grimm 3d, a 32-year-old lawyer in his first run for office. Though Mr. Grimm has been waging an active campaign, Republicans constitute only about 15 percent of the city's 165,000 registered voters.
 
A Focus on Crime
 The new Mayor will replace James D. Griffin, the independent Democrat who announced his retirement in May. During 16 years in office, Mr. Griffin presided over redevelopment of the city's downtown and waterfront, but his relations with the Common Council, minorities, businesses and other groups have grown increasingly antagonistic.
As the Democratic primary campaign has unfolded in this city of 328,000 people, crime has been by far the hottest issue.
Buffalo had a larger increase in property crime last year than 14 other cities of similar size, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Buffalo also posted the second-largest increase in murders among those cities.
Both Mr. Fahey and Mr. Masiello say they would put more officers on the streets by reorganizing the Police Department, a plan that includes closing some precinct station houses to reduce desk jobs.
 
Concern About Deficit
 Mr. Fahey, the son of a retired Buffalo police captain, said he would add 150 officers to the current police roster of about 920. He said he would get the $4.3 million to pay for it by finding savings in other city operations. Mr. Fahey also advocates a youth curfew.
Mr. Masiello, whose father is a retired city streets department foreman, said the city could not afford to hire more police officers. He dismissed a curfew as unworkable, instead suggesting more recreation programs to keep youths off the streets.
The candidates also have focused on Buffalo's fiscal problems. The city raised property taxes 20 percent last year, but it still faces projected deficits of more than $20 million a year for the next four years. Both candidates said they would consider reorganization of city agencies and employee concessions to save money. Both say they want to avoid tax increases but will not rule them out.
Andrew J. Rudnick, president of the city's Chamber of Commerce, said Mr. Fahey and Mr. Masiello have done a good job of discussing the issues. Rather than endorse either candidate, the chamber announced this week that it considered the two equally qualified.
Mr. Taylor, from the State University of New York at Buffalo, said he has been disappointed by the campaign. He said the focus on crime, for which he blamed polls and the media as much as the candidates, has crowded out a more visionary debate that could have helped develop a new consensus among the city's fragmented constituencies.
 
Backgrounds in Politics
 "I know both candidates well, and this campaign has not reflected the depth of their understanding," Mr. Taylor said.
"Crime and police enforcement is a problem," he added, "but it's not nearly as big a problem as economic development and neighborhoods in decay."
Mr. Fahey said the issues were all tied together, but crime must be a priority. "It's affecting our ability to do anything else," he said. "Neighborhood preservation, education, it's all being undermined by crime."
For his part, Mr. Masiello said his many endorsements show that he can forge consensus. "I'm the candidate who can bring all the factions of the city together," he said.
A Buffalo News poll of 1,000 Democrats, published on Sunday, found that 51.1 percent of respondents supported Mr. Masiello and 21.8 percent supported Mr. Fahey, with a margin of error of 3 percentage points. But Mr. Fahey said his own most recent poll shows that 44 percent of voters were still undecided.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anthony M. Masiello, left, and Eugene M. Fahey are the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Buffalo. (Photographs by Dan Capellazzo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Some Doubts On Economy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
A leading Administration economist said today that there were substantial risks that economic growth over the next year would fall short of the 3 percent rate the Administration has forecast.
The economist, Alan Blinder, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, also said that the unemployment rate, currently 6.7 percent, would probably remain stuck near 6.5 percent at the end of 1994, helping to make life difficult for Democrats in next year's Congressional elections. 
 Just last month, the Administration lowered its economic forecast for the year, and Mr. Blinder's remarks indicated that more reductions might be forthcoming. He said factors that could keep growth lower than forecast were a delay in the expected pickup in housing construction and the deeper-than-anticipated recession overseas.
Speaking at an economic conference here, Mr. Blinder said the Administration did not need a cut in short-term rates by the Federal Reserve to maintain the economic recovery, but he also seemed to warn the Fed against raising rates. He said that because of recent good inflation news, he thought the Federal Reserve was no longer thinking of raising short-term interest rates soon.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said in July that he was uneasy about having short-term interest rates so low because those rates, after subtracting inflation, are around zero. But Mr. Blinder said he saw no reason for the Fed to raise rates, arguing that inflation remains under control and that it is not at all unusual for inflation-adjusted interest rates to remain near zero during periods of economic sluggishness.

HEADLINE: Compaq Disputes Japan Ministry's Bid Procedure

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
In what could be the start of another dispute between the United States and Japan, the Compaq Computer Corporation has complained about a recent decision of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry to obtain more than 2,000 notebook computers from the NEC Corporation of Japan.
In a letter sent earlier this month to Hideaki Kumano, vice minister of the trade agency, Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's president, raised questions about NEC's low bid, which was half that of Compaq's. Mr. Pfeiffer also said the agency's emphasis on price alone, rather than on machine abilities, made it difficult for foreign companies to participate in Japanese Government procurements, according to a Compaq spokeswoman. 
 Mr. Pfeiffer's letter comes as the United States and Japan are beginning negotiations to flesh out a new trade framework agreed to in July. Procurement of foreign products by Japan's Government is one of the major areas to be covered by the framework.
 
Procedure Called Fair
 Any dispute with a procurement by the ministry itself would be particularly embarrassing because it is the agency that negotiates trade agreements and because it has assumed the mantle of promoting imports to Japan.
A ministry official involved in the computer procurement, who asked that his name not be used, said the procedure was fair. "Among the proposals that met the requirements, we picked the lowest-priced bid," he said. An NEC spokesman said the company's bid was not unfairly low.
Mr. Pfeiffer's letter also comes as Japan's Government is preparing to buy 11 new supercomputers and thousands of personal computers as part of an effort to stimulate Japan's slumping economy. The American computer industry and the American Government have been pressing Japan to make sure that American companies have a fair chance to compete for the orders.
American computer companies have long complained that while they have competed successfully in selling to Japanese companies and individuals, they have been virtually locked out of the public sector market.
"If there was truly a transparent and open and clear bidding system, these questions wouldn't be coming up over and over again," said David Pollack, director of Japan market development for the American Electronics Association, a trade group.
 
Accord Signed in 1992
 To address these concerns, an agreement calling for increases in Japan's procurement of foreign computers was signed by the United States and Japan in 1992. But the agreement has not been carried out because the two countries cannot agree on whether a foreign computer means a computer made by a non-Japanese company, as the United States contends, or a computer made outside of Japan, even by a Japanese-owned company, as Japan contends.
Still, Mr. Pfeiffer's letter apparently is relatively mild and might not escalate into a big dispute. There is an argument to be made that Compaq offered machines that were more powerful and therefore more expensive than was required.
The ministry asked for bids to supply 2,250 notebook computers using chips that process information 32 bits at a time along with software and maintenance. Compaq offered computers based on the Intel Corporation's powerful 486 microprocessor. NEC offered machines based on the less powerful 386 microprocessor, which is becoming obsolete.
NEC proposed to rent its machines to the ministry for 4,750 yen, or roughly $45, a month for each machine. Compaq's bid was 10,500 yen, while Fujitsu bid 7,250 yen and Toshiba 10,300 yen.
Yukiko Nemoto, a spokeswoman for Compaq's Japanese subsidiary, agreed that NEC's computers met the ministry's requirements. But Compaq was questioning why the ministry did not pay more attention to its future needs and buy a more powerful machine. She also said Compaq suspected that NEC's bid was extremely low because the company was clearing its inventory of machines that have little market life left.
 
The 'Compaq Shock'
 Compaq itself is no stranger to competing on price. The Houston company broke into Japan's personal computer market last October by introducing machines selling for half the price being charged by Japanese companies. The resulting "Compaq Shock" set in motion a restructuring of Japan's insular personal computer market.
Cray Research, the leading American manufacturer of supercomputers, complained last year of unfair procedures when it lost a bid to NEC to supply a machine to a Japanese Government research institute. A Japanese review panel, however, upheld the award.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
At Last, a Game That Counts (for the Phillies, That Is)

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
The Phillies had come, and so there was significance, if not electricity, at Shea Stadium last night. Oh, the sounds of individual vendors could be heard, and almost any seat in absolutely every section was available. But there was meaning in the innings, and a passion about the final result.
And when the game was over, the Phillies had reduced their magic number to 14 because the blind magic of the schedule had made the Mets their opponents. The Phillies, with an economy of effort and a mimimum of drama, beat the Mets, 5-0. 
 No runs, no more damage, one more reason to believe that the immense lead the Phillies had constructed early on in the National League East was going to survive. The Montreal Expos, on fire but on hold last night, fell to five and a half games back.
The Phillies, profiting from six walks and casually overcoming the minor mental strain of having stranded eight men in the first six innings, outwaited and outmaneuvered Bobby Jones. Against the rookie right-hander, who was alternately unhittable and uncertain, the Phillies took a 1-0 lead on Lenny Dykstra's run-scoring single in the third. A sacrifice fly by Pete Incaviglia in the sixth increased the lead to 2-0, and a pair of runs off Jones in the seventh sealed the deal.
"This club does what it has to do," said Manager Jim Fregosi.
Tommy Greene, hardly indomitable, was too much for the Mets. The right-hander struck out six and allowed only six hits, and he kept a serene Shea perfectly silent.
The evening began with plenty of noise, all of it coming from the clubhouse of the Phillies. Clubhouse noise. It is baseball's great September insulation -- from fear, from reporters, from thinking too much.
And so, the radios, television sets, air conditioners, music and talk in the visitors' clubhouse at Shea was all vibrating, with all dials turned up. The footsteps of the Expos couldn't be heard -- at least not as loudly as they had been.
"Mood? You're asking my mood?" Dykstra said in answer to a question. "Hey, man, I just walked in."
The mood was one of cocky arrogance, and the question had nothing to do with Lenny's afternoon cup of coffee. The idea was to get a handle on a club that has lost most of its grip on the N.L. East. The Phillies, nine and a half games up a week ago, began last night only five games ahead of the Expos.
"As long as you have a lead," said Milt Thompson, the outfielder for the Phillies, "you don't have a worry."
And so Darren Daulton and Incaviglia, shirtless and profane, sat and played cards in the clubhouse. Dave Hollins, the third baseman with the noted game face, sunk into his personal existential exile in front of his locker. Dykstra, who long ago lost his limberness because of injury and his inflated pectorals, awkwardly muscled his way into his unirform.
"Worried? Do I look worried?" asked Dykstra. "Man, worried. That's a big word."
 
Kruk Human, Mulholland Hurt
 Big and bad, a lot like the Phillies looked for most of the season. But then the Expos went 18-4 and first baseman John Kruk went from machine (.340 for the season's first half) to mortal (he has hit barely .260 over the second half). The Phillies went 2-5 at Veterans Stadium recently against the Cubs and the Astros. And the status of Terry Mulholland, who went out with a hip flexor injury in his last start, is uncertain for the rest of the season. The city of Philadelphia, with the collapse of 1964 etched forever in its memory, made the worst sort of September noise. It doubted out loud.
"It'd be kind of messed up to lead the whole season and then blow it at the end," said Thompson.
"Hey, the fans are knowledgeable in Philly," said Dykstra. "They expect good things to happen at home. What happened wasn't good."
 
Please, Not to Worry
 What will have to happen for the Phillies to fold is still extraordinary. For example, the Phillies, who have played .602 baseball for more than five months, could go 8-10 and the Expos would have to post a 14-5 mark to finish dead even at the top. And the Phillies, who will play their final three games against the Expos in Montreal this weekend, play five of their next eight games against the Mets and Marlins, clubs that are a combined 67 1/2 games out of first place.
"We can turn it around right here," said Hollins. "Look, the Expos are a good club that's played unbelievably. They would have made up ground on anyone."
The Expos, though, might have made up as much ground as they are going to. After all, they don't get to play the Mets again until later in the month. The Phillies might have played the Mets just enough to have put the race out of reach by then.

LENGTH: 570 words

HEADLINE: Illiterate Americans

 BODY:
Half the adults in the United States can't read or do simple math, according to an Education Department study. Pretty shocking; but what does it really tell us about America's ability to function as a society?
First of all, things are not getting worse. As the study observes, "Today we are a better educated and more literate society than at any time in our history." Second, even those who do have problems with sentences and sums don't seem to feel at a disadvantage. Most of the respondents at the two lowest levels of proficiency (respondents were divided into five levels) said they could read or write English "well" or "very well." 
 What has changed -- and it's a recent change -- -- are our expectations. Only in the last 20-odd years, for instance, have colleges and universities become truly serious about increasing the diversity of their student bodies. Only in that period have we begun to expect anything like truly equal opportunity at success for all Americans.
As a nation, we are still shedding the durable assumption that a literate elite would make the decisions for a less educated majority. The kind of egalitarianism that demands truly equal opportunity is still in its infancy, a struggling legacy of the civil rights movement and idealism of the 1960's.
Another change during the last two decades is in the nature of work in America. Well-paying jobs requiring little education have been disappearing. At the same time, the growth of the suburbs has depleted the cities of their middle-class residents, the people who pay property taxes to finance schools and who protest most effectively when schools don't deliver. Just as it becomes harder to get good work without a good education, good education itself is becoming more elusive for the increasingly isolated children of the cities.
The survey, conducted by the people who also conduct the Scholastic Aptitude Tests for college admission, confirms conventional wisdom: The more literate you are, the less likely you are to depend on food stamps or to be in prison, and the more likely you are to have a decent income.
But it's almost certain that the same things could have been said at any point in our history. The difference now is that our sensibilities have changed, and so has the job market. In earlier decades Americans were more accepting of social inequities, while the economy was kinder to those without much learning.
For those who can read it, the lesson is pretty clear. Disinvestment in American cities, and particularly in their public schools, is dangerous. While more Americans expect a fair shot at success, the gap between skilled and unskilled workers' income, particularly between those with and without college degrees, gets wider.
A large percentage of people who scored in the bottom group on this survey were older, or were immigrants, or had physical, mental or health problems. But that still leaves many who couldn't solve everyday problems such as reading a pay stub or a bus schedule. The workplace of the 21st century will have very few places for such people.
Such a message tests another kind of literacy: Americans' ability to read the message in conflicting social and economic trends, and to act accordingly. Reading this survey, it's hard to escape the conclusion that we are badly undereducated for our times and that the United States needs to invest widely in public education.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Now, What Arabs Can Do

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
So now it is up to the Arabs, Arabs in the new Palestine being created, and Arabs far beyond.
On Feb. 15, 1993, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel said that the more the Palestine Liberation Organization lost its authority the better it would be for progress toward peace. 
 Two weeks later he said Yasir Arafat himself was a big obstacle to peace. And on May 3, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres wrote a letter to the American Zionist Organization: "Supported by hard evidence we believe the P.L.O. is engaged in terrorist activities and is therefore no partner for any negotiations or dialogue."
But six months later, in a day that would move a stone to hope, the two Israelis stood with Mr. Arafat at the White House. They had opened its doors to him by recognizing him and his organization as the representatives of the Palestinian people. And they had agreed to a peace plan that is bound to lead to an independent Palestine, sooner than later.
For Mr. Arafat it was sudden pinnacle -- recognition, world applause, immediate control over Gaza and Jericho, and the clear road to Palestine.
In exchange, he had only to repeat earlier commitments -- to kindly recognize Israel's right to exist, and to end terrorism and violence. He forgot to say that last part at the White House.
As The Jerusalem Post has asked, what happened in the past six months to make the Israeli leaders change their minds about the worthiness of Mr. Arafat and the P.L.O. as partners in creating peace? Labor gives no clear reply I can find. But in the logical answer lie the clues as to whether the hopes will live or die.
The P.L.O. was staggering, bankrupt, abandoned by most of its Arab allies because of Mr. Arafat's adoration of Saddam Hussein during the gulf war as the true hope of the Palestinian cause.
The fundamentalists were growing in power on the West Bank. Recognition of the P.L.O. by Israel can cut either way -- reduce fundamentalists' influence or put them in position to take over an independent Palestine, perhaps by ballot. Israel will not be able to send in the army when it does not like a change in the new Palestine's government.
It was not a sudden burst of confidence in Mr. Arafat that was the key to the Labor Government's decision. It was the belief that the Arab nations, bereft of Soviet support and fearful of the fundamentalists they helped create, were ready for peace with Israel and that a deal with the Palestinians would speed the day.
So now it is up to the Arabs in and beyond Palestine.
If they will it, peace can happen. But they will have to reach for it, stretch for it, accept risks -- as has the current Government of Israel in its own desire for an end to fear and killing.
As Mr. Rabin said about his decision on the P.L.O., it will not be easy. For a half-century, officials, intellectuals, journalists, teachers and clergymen have supported and sustained the war against Israel.
In their press, preaching and in broadcasts beamed to the world they vilified Israel not just as their own enemy but as the agent of imperialism, the enemy of all peoples newly come to freedom.
In countries in Africa and Asia where Jews had never lived they came to be seen as evil. The line between Arab anti-Israeli propaganda and anti-Semitism is often impossible to find because often it does not exist.
Foreigners who have an Israeli visa in their passports are barred at Arab borders. For a half-century, Israel has been boycotted politically and economically without protest from most of the world.
A declared end to boycotts, to ceaseless hate propaganda, not as the price of treaties but now simply as acceptable international conduct -- is that asking too much too early, as I am often told? No -- it is a half-century overdue.
Geography has not changed for Israel. Mr. Rabin, like his predecessors, once believed that the West Bank was essential to give Israel the needed mobilization hours if war came. Now he believes security lies more in peace arrangements than in time and space. Many Israelis and foreign friends of Israel, including me, are nervous about that.
Having committed itself, as is its right, the Labor Government can say or do little to assuage those fears. From now on, it is up to the Arabs to do that, Arabs in Palestine and far beyond.

HEADLINE: Scientists Confront Renewed Backlash on Global Warming

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
AS the Clinton Administration prepares to announce in the next few weeks a plan for controlling waste industrial gases that trap heat in the atmosphere, conservatives and industry groups have mounted a renewed assault on the idea that global warming is a serious and possibly catastrophic threat.
In a drum roll of criticism over the last few months they have characterized the thesis of global warming as a "flash in the pan," "hysteria," "scare talk" and a ploy by socialists to justify controls on the economy. 
 The rhetoric is the mirror image of some that was heard five years ago, at the height of the 1988 North American heat wave, when some environmentalists and politicians warned of climatic apocalypse on the basis of assertions by a minority of scientists that global warming was already under way.
The evidence that warming or harm from warming will occur in the foreseeable future is "ludicrously small," argues a 1993 book published by the Cato Institute, a free-market research organization in Washington. Reining in global warming "will require a degree of bureaucratic control over economic affairs previously unknown in the West," wrote Ben W. Bolch and Robert D. McCallum, professors of economics and chemistry at Rhodes College in Memphis, in the book, "Apocalypse Not: Science, Economics and Environmentalism."
Dr. Dixy Lee Ray, the former Governor of Washington and a former chairwoman of the Atomic Energy Commission, called carbon dioxide "an unlikely candidate for causing any significant worldwide temperature changes" in another 1993 book, "Environmental Overkill: Whatever Happened to Common Sense?"
In recent months, a number of newspapers, including The Washington Times and The Wall Street Journal, have published articles debunking global warming. In the July issue of Commentary, Jeffrey Salmon, executive director of the George C. Marshall Institute in Washington, stated categorically that there is "no solid scientific evidence to support the theory that the earth is warming because of man-made greenhouse gases."
In the midst of this revisionist onslaught, whom is the public to believe?
Global warming is not a cut and dried issue, and scientific experts are still debating most of its aspects. But few scientists are to be found at either of the extremes that have characterized the political debate. A substantial number of highly regarded climate researchers have long believed that global warming set off by industrial and automotive emissions is a real possibility that could have serious consequences sooner or later. But they cannot say exactly how severe the effects of the warming will be or when it will come. And very few climatologists are ready to declare that global warming has begun. Most believe that no clear sign of human-induced change has yet made itself apparent amid the wide natural fluctuations of the earth's climate.
There are two undisputed facts about global warming: first, carbon dioxide, the waste gas produced by burning coal, oil and wood, has been accumulating in the earth's atmosphere over the last century; and second, the gas traps heat that is produced when the sun's energy is absorbed by the earth and then re-radiated.
Given those physical facts, the practical question of interest is how much the earth's climate will heat up after injection of a given amount of carbon dioxide. Since no experiment can answer that question, other than the global one now in progress, scientists have turned to their next best method, which is to simulate the earth's climate system in a series of equations that are run on a supercomputer. This exercise, known as computer modeling, is somewhat contentious because the models are far from perfect and represent a simpler, stripped-down version of the earth's real climate.
After examining results from the best computer models, a scientific advisory committee to the United Nations concluded in 1990, and again in 1992, that a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide -- expected to occur by the year 2100 without remedial action -- will raise the average global temperature by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit. In comparison, the earth has warmed by only 5 to 9 degrees since the last ice age.
The United Nations panel and various committees of the National Academy of Sciences, made up of leading experts in the field, have consistently found merit in the global warming theory. Still, the issue is far from settled and critics of global warming continue to attack the models' predictions on various grounds.
One, Dr. Richard Lindzen, a meteorologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, argues that the computer models fail to account accurately for the role of water vapor, a heat-trapping gas which by its sheer quantity exerts a far stronger greenhouse effect than carbon dioxide.
Most climatologists believe carbon dioxide is pivotal because the warming it induces, though quite small in itself, causes more water to evaporate from land and sea. The water vapor in turn traps more heat, thus amplifying the effect of the carbon dioxide.
Dr. Lindzen denies that this amplification takes place, and if he is right, then a doubling of carbon dioxide would indeed cause little or no greenhouse problem. But other climate researchers dismiss his argument as speculation, whereas the amplifying role of water vapor is well documented, in their view.
Critics of global warming say that the computer models cannot be trusted because they fail to reproduce the exact pattern of warming actually experienced over the last century. The models predict that in response to a 25 percent rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide over the last century, average global temperature should have risen by 2 degrees. In fact the climate has warmed by 1 degree.
Defenders of the models counter that with an extra refinement -- taking into account the fact that industrially emitted sulfate aerosols reflect sunlight -- the models' forecasts match the historical record much better.
Besides the imperfections of computer models, critics point out an apparent anomaly in global warming theory: that over the last century the chief rise in global temperature occurred before 1940, though most of the carbon dioxide has been spewed out since then. Defenders respond that the climate is an erratic system and that a neat, constant relationship between gas input and temperature rise should not be expected.
The critics go on to say that the small temperature spike seen so far could easily be nothing but another jiggle in the zigzag course of the climate's normal variability. Climatologists almost universally agree that this is indeed possible. The United Nations panel said it was equally possible, however, that a natural cooling trend could be masking an even larger greenhouse warming than what has been observed.
 
Estimates of Global Warming
 Conservative columnists and industry groups have jumped on another apparent discrepancy, that the models predict greater warming in the arctic than seems to be the case. Defenders say the measurements were not made in places where the warming would be most manifest, and that many observations have borne out the greater warming predicted for northern latitudes.
The models appeared to gain some important empirical support last December when Martin I. Hoffert of New York University and Curt Covey of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory reconstructed two ancient climates, one much warmer than today's and one much colder. Since they were able to estimate temperature changes and prevailing carbon dioxide levels from evidence in the geological record, they were then in a position to answer the critical question -- at least for those two periods -- of how much warming is produced by a given rise in carbon dioxide levels.
Their answer was that when carbon dioxide levels double, the temperature of the atmosphere rises by about 4 degrees. This figure agrees well with the best estimate from the computer models which, in the view of the United Nations panel, is that a doubling of carbon dioxide induces a 4.5-degree rise in average global temperature. Some scientists believe the Hoffert-Covey findings rule out a warming in the lower end of the panel's broader range of 3 to 8 degrees. A climate system that responds so sluggishly to external forces could not have produced the great temperature swings of the past, they say.
Dr. Lindzen, on the other hand, questions the Hoffert-Covey study's utility in predicting future climate change on the ground that the climate may have behaved differently in the remote past.
Critics note that evidence for the observed global warming trend ofthe 1980's depends on ground-based measurements of temperature, which amount to only a sampling of the whole earth. These measurements are also suspect, in the critics' view, because many of the measuring sites are near cities, which are warmer than the surrounding countryside. Satellite observations that started in 1979 failed to see any warming trend. Defenders say the satellite measurements could be distorted by atmospheric factors, that their record is too short to support any generalization and that the ground-based temperature measurements have been correctly calibrated to discount warmth from cities.
Some critics contend that even if the atmosphere does heat up, the warming will be benign. Dr. Patrick J. Michaels, a meteorologist at the University of Virginia, points out that the warming seen so far has made itself evident mostly at night and in winter. If that continues, he argues, global warming will be a boon, not a catastrophe. Growing seasons will be longer, winters less harsh and plants invigorated by rising carbon dioxide will grow faster.
But Thomas R. Karl, chief of the global climate laboratory at the National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C., responds that the warmer nights may have other causes, possibly natural, quite apart from greenhouse gases. James E. Hansen, a climatologist at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Goddard Institute for Space Studies in New York, notes that warmer winters, far from being welcome, could disrupt the chilling that many plant seeds must experience to germinate properly in the spring. Botanists have found that carbon dioxide does spur plant growth, but also that the plants can then outgrow their nutrient supply, making them less nutritious as food.
As for other effects of the predicted warming, the United Nations panel estimated that an average global warming of 4.5 degrees would cause sea level to rise by two feet by the year 2100 and would make heat waves more frequent and cold spells rarer. Model simulations have suggested that although average global rainfall would increase, the interiors of continents would become drier, droughts more common and tropical storms more violent. Some climatologists also believe that climatic zones would shift and regional weather patterns would be dislocated, disrupting agricultural production and natural ecosystems. But these effects are regarded by climatologists as being uncertain.
Where does all this leave the debate?
Issues in science are not decided by taking votes, but polls of climate researchers show that most believe there is a better than even chance that the climate will warm by at least 3.5 degrees over the next century.
Climatologists also know that once in the atmosphere, carbon dioxide stays there for centuries; whatever climatic effect it has will not be reversed in several human lifetimes. This may partly explain why the weight of opinion among climate scientists, as measured by polls, is that lack of certainty should not stand in the way of prudent steps to control greenhouse gas emissions.
Indeed, a panel of the National Research Council -- the Government's chief source of scientific advice -- concluded in 1991 that "despite the great uncertainties, greenhouse warming is a potential threat sufficient to justify action now."
How much action, what kind and how soon is an economic and political issue of great consequence in a world that runs on the burning of fossil fuels. Proponents of the greenhouse theory therefore need not be surprised at the intense fire now being rained down on their ideas.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: The Overview;
JORDAN AND ISRAEL AGREE ON A BASIS FOR FINDING PEACE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Basking in the afterglow of the accord on Monday between Israel and the Palestinians, Israel and Jordan signed an agreement today that provides the basis for resolving 45 years of hostility between them.
Although on paper the Israeli-Jordanian agreement merely sets out a formal agenda for negotiations, it represents the most important step the two countries have taken toward making peace. 
 Some of the issues described in the document have essentially been resolved in negotiations in Washington over the past year. But the accord gives both sides the ability to put some of these agreements into effect, a process that could lead to normal relations between the two one-time foes even without formal diplomatic ties and a peace treaty.
 
First Steps
 Within weeks, the ban on travelers with Israeli stamps in their passports could be lifted, phone and communications links set up, water resources allocated, boundary disputes settled and joint industrial and maritime projects begun, Jordan's Prime Minister, Abdel Salem Al-Majali, told foreign journalists today.
The breakthrough between Israelis and Palestinians has created a palpable sense of momentum toward peace in the Middle East, tearing down formidable barriers with breathtaking swiftness.
En route home from Washington, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel made a surprise visit to Morocco today for talks with King Hassan, an important move toward establishing relations with Morocco as well as with a number of other Arab countries. [Page A16.]
 
Arafat on Capitol Hill
 In Washington, Yasir Arafat courted Congress, appealing during a breakfast with 20 Senators for loan guarantees for the Palestinians and winning a promise that the Senators will review American laws that bar financial aid to the P.L.O. As part of a media blitz to convince skeptics here and in Israel that he will be a responsible partner in peacemaking, Mr. Arafat said over lunch at the National Press Club that he believed that even the status of Jerusalem could be resolved.
But in a grim reminder that the process of peacemaking is only beginning, a Palestinian in the Gaza Strip died in a suicide attack on an Israeli police station and another tried to stab a soldier before being shot to death.
 
Jordan Under Constraints
 For Jordan, it is one thing to sign an agenda and quite another to make a formal peace with Israel. King Hussein, by tradition and temperment a cautious man, for years has functioned under internal constraints that include the presence of a large Palestinian refugee population and demands for increasing democratization; there are also external constraints, including the fact that he is flanked on part of his border by an important financial power, Saudi Arabia, and on other parts by two militarily superior countries, Iraq and Syria.
Although the King has met Israeli leaders in secret at times during his 41-year reign, he has not so far indicated any willingness to follow the lead of King Hassan by welcoming Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, to Amman.
Caught off guard by the secret negotiations between the P.L.O. and Israel, he has a major stake in how the Israeli-Palestinian agreement is implemented and for geographic and demographic reasons cannot take himself out of the Palestinian equation.
His brother, King Crown Prince Hassan, said last week that Jordan was concerned that the creation of an autonomous Palestinian enclave, as envisioned by the Palestinains and Israelis, could unleash factional violence in the occupied territories that could spill over into Jordan, home to 1.5 million Palestinian refugees. Jordanian officials have said they will try to prevent a new influx of Palestinian refugees if security in the territories deteriorates.
Compared to the celebration on the White House lawn on Monday, today's moment of contact between Israel and Jordan in the State Department's Jefferson Room was brief, subdued and anti-climactic. Only a few dozen Administration officials, Israeli and Jordanian officials and journalists looked on as Elyakim Rubinstein, Israel's chief negotiator, and Jordan's Ambassador, Fayez Tarawneh, sat at a table covered in cranberry-colored cloth and initialed what is called an "agenda for peace."
 
'Another Step'
 "Today we are making yet another step in the long road to peace between Israel and Jordan," Mr. Rubinstein said. Mr. Tarawneh expressed hope that it will produce "a comprehensive peace that will transform the lives of all peoples in the area."
In one of the many ironies of the rush to peace, Mr. Rubinstein, who opposed the P.L.O. agreement, boycotted the White House ceremony on Monday and flew to Washington only to sign the Jordanian agreement he helped broker.
Despite today's agreement, it could take a number of years before Jordan and Israel sign a formal peace treaty. Just as Jordan's agreement with Israel was ready to be formally announced early this year, but put on hold because the King wanted progress on the Palestinian front, Jordan has made clear that it will only sign a peace treaty with Israel as part of a comprehensive Middle East peace. "When we talk about the demarcation of borders of any kind or normalization of relations, they would have to be in the context of the comprehensiveness of the peace process," Mr. Taranweh said in an interview. "Normalization should follow a peace treaty. We have to keep balance with our other partners."
Jordan and Israel are expected to begin negotiations on the agenda signed today in a new round of talks in Washington in October, he added.
Until now Jordan, as well as Syria, has refused to agree individually to any settlement with Israel comparable to the step Egypt took at Camp David in 1978, when it negotiated the return of the Sinai Peninsula.
 
A State of War
 Technically, Jordan and Israel, whose armies clashed in 1967 and again in 1973, are in a state of war. In 1990, the tacit support King Hussein of Jordan gave to Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait and his opposition to the deployment of American troops in Saudi Arabia enraged Israel.
But the two countries have cooperated for more than a decade to stop guerrilla attacks along their common border and are in a de facto state of peace. In the American-led peace talks in Washington over the last year, they have made progress toward resolving many of their differences.
But in response to a question after the ceremony, Mr. Tarawneh stressed that any final peace treaty would depend on agreements between Israel and its other Arab neighbors.
The Jordanian-Israeli agreement could lead to settlement of their joint border, guarantees for Jordan's security and joint efforts to harness water resources, protect the environment and develop the Dead Sea region. But the most divisive issue between the two countries is the future status of the 1.5 million Palestinian refugees in Jordan.
 
Request for Aid
 Jordan will ask Israel for compensation for maintening such a large refugee population, Mr. al-Majali told reporters in Amman, although he declined to say how much Jordan would seek.
At the White House today, President Clinton built on the optimism left over from Monday's agreement, saying, "I'm looking forward to beginning work immediately on the United States' part of implementing this agreement." One illustration of the Administration's commitment, and concern, was a cable sent Monday night by Secretary of State Warren Christopher to about a dozen American embassies in Europe, Asia and the Arab world instructing them to raise money from their host governments for an American-led fund for Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho.
Mr. Clinton also praised King Hassan of Morocco for receiving Mr. Rabin today, predicting that other Arab countries will follow suit. Morocco and Tunisia are expected to formalize diplomatic ties with Israel within weeks.
Now that a day has passed, some of the mysteries surrounding Monday's events have been solved. Asked on the MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour on Monday night why he had shaken Mr. Arafat's hand, Mr. Rabin replied, "I couldn't in front of the President of the United States and enormous number of people, dignitaries that were invited from the Arab World, from the United States, from Israel, from Europe, when he offered his hand, to say no in front of all the cameras of the world."

HEADLINE: Tourist Killed in Florida, Prompting New Patrols

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 14

 BODY:
A British tourist driving in Florida was shot to death in an apparent robbery attempt today, the second such slaying in less than a week. Hours later Gov. Lawton Chiles, facing reports that frightened vacationers are canceling their travel plans, ordered state law-enforcement agencies to begin guarding all Interstate highway rest areas across Florida.
The Governor's action came only hours after a British tourist, 34-year-old Gary Colley, was shot to death at a rest stop on Interstate 10, about 35 miles east of Tallahassee, becoming the ninth foreign tourist killed in Florida in the last year. His companion, Margaret Ann Jagger, 35, was wounded in the early morning attack. 
 Officials also announced that because of the rash of attacks on foreign visitors in recent months, the state was indefinitely suspending its tourism advertising in the United States and abroad. Greg Farmer, Secretary of the Florida Department of Commerce, described the twin killings as "catastrophic" for tourism and said the percentage of vacation cancellations from abroad was reaching double digits.
 
Huge Losses Feared
 "Right now there is a great amount of interest in these unfortunate incidents," Mr. Farmer, whose office oversees the $31 billion-a-year industry that is the backbone of the state's economy, said this afternoon. "To be running ads saying everything is wonderful, come on down, only highlights the problem and is counterproductive."
That decision means an advertising campaign begun in July and based on the slogan "One Florida, Many Faces" will be canceled. About $2 million was to be spent in the United States and abroad for those print and television ads, officials said.
Mr. Farmer said that it would be several days before the full economic impact of the killings could be measured but that losses "could be in billions" of dollars. He and other officials said calls to European tour operators and Florida tourism offices abroad indicated that canceled reservations might reach 30 percent.
 
500 Officers Deployed
 Governor Chiles deployed more than 500 auxiliary highway patrol officers for temporary patrol duty at the 76 rest stops along the state's main highways, and he said several hundred more may be summoned. The round-the-clock patrols will continue, he vowed, until a permanent private security force can be hired.
"We are not going to tolerate these kinds of offenses against our citizens or against our visitors," Mr. Chiles said at an afternoon news conference in Tallahassee, the state capital.
Since last October, nine foreigners, two of them Britons, have been killed during robbery attempts while vacationing in Florida. Mr. Colley's death comes six days after a German tourist, Uwe-Wilhelm Rakebrand, was shot to death in Miami as he was driving from the airport to a hotel.
Mr. Rakebrand's killing was widely publicized in Europe, which has been the fastest-growing market for Florida tourism in recent years, and raised questions about the safety of the 42 million people who visit the state each year. There has been a series of break-ins at hotels frequented by tourists in the Orlando area, and a black visitor from New York was kidnapped and set on fire in a racially motivated attack near Tampa in January.
In addition, the Jacksonville area was plagued last year by random sniper attacks on motorists on Interstate 95, the main highway connecting Florida to the Northeast. The three dozen attacks led to one death, several automobile accidents, a blizzard of negative publicity and a rare travel alert by the American Automobile Association. The attacks ended after Mr. Chiles called out the Florida National Guard and the police arrested gang members and charged them with the crimes. The patrols have also ceased.
 
National Problem?
 Today's killing, coming barely a month after the father of the basketball star Michael Jordan was discovered slain in similar circumstances in North Carolina, seemed likely to add to fears about highway safety in Florida and beyond. Some state officials here, arguing that the problem is national in scope, called for legislation to make any criminal attack on tourists a Federal offense.
Sheriff Ken Fortune of Jefferson County, where the attack occurred, said Mr. Colley and Ms. Jagger, both from Yorkshire, in northern England, were attacked shortly after pulling into a rest area on a remote stretch of the highway, which runs from Los Angeles to Jacksonville. He said the couple were preparing to sleep in the car about 2:25 A.M. when two men on foot approached the vehicle on both sides and tapped on the windows.
"I think the motive was robbery," Mr. Fortune said during a telephone interview. "When the couple began to pull out in the car, these fellows cut loose shooting at them."
Mr. Fortune said they had only a sketchy description of the assailants, provided by a rest stop attendant. They were described as young black males, possibly teen-agers, and were last seen heading east on Interstate 10 in a red car. A car matching that description was found late today in nearby Monticello.
The police said Mr. Colley and Ms. Jagger rented a red Chevrolet Cavalier in Orlando on Thursday and drove to New Orleans, where they remained until Monday. They were apparently on their way to the Tampa Bay area, where they were scheduled to return the car later this week, when they were set upon.
Sheriff Fortune said nothing about the attack indicated that Mr. Colley and Ms. Jagger were preyed upon because they were foreigners or tourists. He noted that their car had no stickers or corporate logos that would identify it as a rental vehicle and that it bore ordinary Florida license plates without the prefix formerly used to identify rental cars.
"There's nothing there" to reveal to criminals that they were not native Floridians, he said.
Last year, 1,263 homicides were reported in the state, but Sheriff Fortune said they were rare in his rural county and that this was the first of the year.
Nearly 1.1 million Britons visited Florida last year. In Britain, Mr. Colley's death was treated as major news on radio and television newscasts tonight and by afternoon national newspapers. The Evening Standard ran a front-page headline that proclaimed "Florida Gang Shoot Britons," and the BBC broadcast a tape recording of Ms. Jagger's frantic 911 phone call to police.
"He's dying, he's really dying," she could be heard crying. "Please help."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: News Analysis;
Dividing a Homeland

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
And now for the hard part.
The importance of Monday's handshake between Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel is that with one gesture it transformed the problem between them from an ideological struggle over who is the rightful owner of historic Palestine into a practical one over how to share the same living space. 
 Indeed, the document they signed was less about how they should live separately -- that won't happen for a while -- and more about how they are going to live together for an interim period of five years while Israel tests the P.L.O. as a secure and stable neighbor. Only after the P.L.O. proves it can live with Israelis might it be allowed to live entirely without them.
The reason that this sharing will prove difficult is that up to now Israel has physically controlled it all, and not simply in military terms, but also in functional ones: from education text books, to the number of oranges that a Gaza farmer can export, to taxation, tourism, and even permission to dig for archeological artifacts.
 
'He Needs Space'
 "For us to finally recognize Arafat from the outside is one thing," said Meron Benvenisti, an Israeli historian. "I can say hello to him on the street. But that is not all. Now he is coming into my house. We are going to share some of the rooms. And he needs space, and that is going to be the difficulty at all levels. Because we are not just talking about physical space. We are talking about everything. It is much more complicated than the peace treaty with Egypt. There, space was being divided. Here it is being shared."
At least for a few years.
The agreement between Israel and the P.L.O. sets a timetable for the two sides to negotiate the details of their coexistence. Their quick calendar looks like this: Within 30 days Israel and the P.L.O. begin negotiations over the details of Israel's troop withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho. Within two months those negotiations are supposed to be completed, and a Palestinian police force, made up mostly of pro-Arafat P.L.O. fighters from abroad, will be imported to keep order in Gaza and Jericho. Quietly, Israeli and P.L.O. intelligence services will then have to begin cooperating to protect Mr. Arafat and to contain the militants who oppose the agreement.
At the same time, elsewhere in the West Bank, the Israeli military government and civil administration will transfer power to "authorized Palestinians" in five spheres: education and culture, health, social welfare, direct taxation and tourism.
 
Completion of Withdrawal
 Four months after that, Israeli troops are supposed to be fully out of Gaza and Jericho, although they will just be down the road, surrounding both places. Within 10 months of today, Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza are to hold elections for a self-governing council, the exact powers of which Israel and the P.L.O. still have to define.
Two issues will be critical: who will control water resources and who will control land-use zoning. Both are now in Israeli hands. Somehow they will have to share, because Israel draws water, for instance, from under the West Bank to irrigate fields as far away as Tel Aviv.
Also in the 10th month, by the eve of the Palestinian elections at the latest, Israeli military forces, by then already withdrawn from Gaza and Jericho, will redeploy outside populated areas in the rest of the West Bank. Israeli forces will remain responsible for protecting Israeli settlers and the roads they use, as well as the external borders.
 
Talks on Final Status
 In two years, negotiations between Israel and the P.L.O. over final status of the territories are to begin, and within five years the final status of who will control what is to be resolved. Only then will real, and total, separation be theoretically possible.
Until then, the Israelis will be doing most of the giving, and Mr. Arafat will be doing most of the taking.
Consider a few examples:
*It is very difficult in Israel to get mobile telephones because the army controls so much of the air waves for its own communications. How many channels will the Palestinians get? In such a small space, everyone has to share.
*Israel now tightly controls the exports of fruits and vegetables to different markets, always making sure that lower-cost Palestinian farmers are limited in what they can sell to Israel's prized markets in Europe. Now they will have to share those markets.
*The accord speaks about the possibility of Israel granting Palestinians a broadcasting license and television station. Again, space will have to be found on the air waves to accommodate them. Will Palestinian broadcasts be subject to Israeli military censorship?
*The vast majority of males in the Gaza Strip work in Israel. Mr. Arafat cannot afford for Israel to seal its border with the Arab populated areas of the Gaza Strip; otherwise, his population will not have enough work, at least in the near future.
*Territorial boundaries remain to be determined. Jericho, for instance, is both a town and a governmental district. Jericho town is a few square blocks that can be traversed by car in five minutes. The Jericho district is almost as big as the Gaza Strip. Which area the Palestinians will control -- the town or the district -- still has to be negotiated.
Whatever the outcome, Israel will still need free civilian access to Jericho, which sits astride a main north-south highway and the bridges over the Jordan River.
These negotiations, and the degree of sharing between Israelis and Palestinians, are going to be influenced by several factors.
The most important is money. It is no accident that Mr. Arafat's influence in the West Bank has fallen since Saudi Arabia and the other Persian Gulf states cut off his money two years ago because he supported Iraq in the gulf war. Iran stepped into the vacuum and began giving money to the Hamas Muslim organization, which then began to dominate politics in Gaza.
 
Money Brings Power
 If Mr. Arafat can begin to pour money into Gaza, Jericho and the rest of the West Bank, he can enlarge the pie that he and the Israelis will have to share and thereby get a bigger slice for himself. The less dependent he is on Israelis for creating jobs, the more he is able to improve roads, sewers and communications in Gaza and Jericho, the more popular he is going to be; if there is no money, he will be in trouble.
The second factor that will influence the negotiations is the interplay of Arab politics on the Israeli psyche. It was a breakthrough for Prime Minister Rabin to go to Morocco on his way home from Israel, and a critically important overture by King Hassan II to receive him.
For the message it sends to the Israeli public is that reconciliation with Mr. Arafat means more than just getting him as a neighbor, which doesn't exactly thrill most Israelis. It also means opening up the Middle East to Israelis, for travel and commerce. Again it comes down to space. It is a lot easier for Israelis to share their limited home with Mr. Arafat if they feel a neighborhood that previously shunned them was now ready to embrace them.
 
The Syrian Factor
 But there is a wild card in this inter-Arab game and it is called Syria. Although President Hafez al-Assad's Ambassador in Washington attended Monday's signing ceremony, Mr. Assad cannot be happy that Mr. Arafat, his old rival, has stolen a march on him. The Clinton Administration and Mr. Rabin's Government have only so many economic and political resources they can devote to peacemaking at one time, and it is likely that the P.L.O. is now going to take up most of them.
Mr. Arafat needs space not only from Israel, but from the Arabs as well. If Mr. Assad is unhappy, he can use his surrogates in the Palestinian community to shrink Mr. Arafat's political space, by challenging his legitimacy, forcing him to drive unrealistic bargains with Israel and even threatening his life.
Neither Israeli nor American officials have an answer yet as to how they intend to keep Mr. Assad interested enough to leave Mr. Arafat alone, but not so interested that Mr. Rabin feels pressured to withdraw on both the Syrian and Palestinian fronts at once.
But if Mr. Assad is unhappy, the region will know about it. As one Syrian official put it: "How do you think President Assad felt watching Yasir Arafat received at the White House while Syria is still on the State Department terrorism list?"

HEADLINE: U.A.W. and Ford Bargain Past Deadline for a Strike

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Wednesday, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Unable to resolve issues that have dogged labor negotiations for months, leaders of the United Automobile Workers continued talking with the Ford Motor Company early today as they passed a midnight deadline, rather than striking its plants.
For days, union and company officials had predicted they would sign a new labor agreement before the deadline. But in a marathon session on Tuesday negotiators found they still could not agree on answers to such thorny questions as how to control health care costs, how long the contract should run and how to preserve and create more jobs at Ford. 
 The 96,000 U.A.W. members who work for Ford had authorized the union to call a strike. An hour after their deadline had past, U.A.W. leaders still had not indicated whether a strike would be necessary.
During the 1990 negotiations with the General Motors Corporation, bargainers continued their talks for 44 hours past the deadline. Fatigue, union officials said, can make both sides more reasonable.
Meanwhile, negotiators for the Canadian Auto Workers said they had reached a tentative agreement with the Chrysler Corporation on a three-year contract covering about 10,500 workers in Canada. Details of the agreement were not disclosed. In both the United States and Canada, the unions negotiate an agreement with one of the Big Three auto makers that then serves as a pattern in bargaining with the other two.
Here at Ford's headquarters, the company continued to press the union for concessions on health care, seeking to erect a two-tier system whereby newly hired workers would have a less generous benefits plan than current workers, whose health care costs are fully paid. Ford plants are operating at full capacity, and the company is expected to hire thousands of new workers in coming years.
While opposing such permanent changes between the compensation for current and new workers, the union has left open the possibility of letting the companies pay new workers lower wages, provided they eventually "grow in" -- that is, catch up with current workers. The U.A.W.'s firm position made the company's continued insistence surprising, and raised the possibility of a strike that both sides had repeatedly predicted would not come.
"They are playing a game of very hard bargaining close to the wire, which means neither side can fully predict the outcome," said Harley Shaiken, a visiting professor at the University of California at Berkeley who specializes in labor relations. "When you have the ability to settle, and yet some tough issues involving matters of principle are still on the table, that means there's still some uncertainty."
The U.A.W. began negotiating with Ford, Chrysler and G.M. on June 26 -- a month earlier than usual, because, union officials said, the issues this year are so complex. On Aug. 30, the union selected Ford, the No. 2 auto maker with 96,000 workers, as the lead company in negotiating a pattern agreement.
 
Intense Bargaining at Ford
 Since then, negotiators have been bargaining intensely on the second floor of Ford's headquarters here. At a less frenzied pace, bargaining has continued at G.M. and Chrysler, where the existing contracts have been extended indefinitely. Once signed, the contracts will cover 400,000 active workers and 390,000 retirees and surviving spouses.
Leaders of U.A.W. locals around the country said Tuesday that they were preparing to strike, but did not expect to. "You always have to prepare, just in case," said Al Kent, vice president of Local 882 in Hapeville, Ga., who was rounding up people to walk picket lines.
At Local 182 in Livonia, Mich., leaders prepared to set up a strike fund. "If Ford wants a strike over the issues, we should," said E. A. Bundoff, the local's recording secretary. Mr. Bundoff rejected the idea of paying new workers less. "I don't buy it," he said. "I'm ready to hit the bricks for it and shut Ford down."
Cutting wages or benefits for new hires, some U.A.W. members argued, could pit workers against one another and jeopardize the benefits of retirees down the road, when the new workers collectively have enough votes to strike back.
 
Warning by Union
 For days, company and union officials had been predicting a settlement by the deadline. The first sign of a snag came Tuesday morning, when Owen F. Bieber, the U.A.W. president, who had avoided reporters during negotiations, strode into the press bivouac on the first floor here and called a briefing. Mr. Bieber criticized news reports earlier Tuesday that he said suggested the contract was "an automatic fix" and that negotiators were merely marking time until the deadline.
"The process better speed up, or the clock will catch up with us," Mr. Bieber said. He said there were "major problems that have to be resolved."
Despite that warning, Mr. Bieber went on to sound the same grimly optimistic tone that union officials have been striking in recent days: "We can get a settlement, in my opinion, by the deadline, but it's going to take a lot of tough work to get there."
The statement, carried live by some Detroit television stations, may have been intended as a signal to reassure the membership, and warn the company, that union negotiators were still pushing for an agreement on their terms.
 
Length of Pact at Issue
 Among other issues still on the table Tuesday night was the length of the contract itself. Normally, the contracts run for three years, but this time Ford is trying to extend its life to six. In 1950, G.M. negotiated a five-year contract.
"For a prosperous firm like Ford, it makes some sense, because it gives them stability," said Richard N. Block, a professor at the School of Labor and Industrial Relations at Michigan State University. Communication between the union and Ford is so good, he said, that "the need for the three-year get-together to check up on each other is less now."
While a six-year term would probably also be good for Chrysler, he said, the benefits to G.M., the industry's ailing giant, are less clear. "I think that it would make less sense at G.M. -- it would be less attractive to lock something in for six years," Mr. Block said.
Late in the bargaining, officials on both sides assign economic costs to each of the changes they are seeking to make. By adding those costs together, they arrive at the total package they consider acceptable. As a result, issues are not resolved one by one and taken off the table, and negotiators can still find themselves trading a concession on one issue for a gain on another at the 11th hour.
In Canada, workers had been seeking improved pension and higher wages from their target company, Chrysler. In addition, the union wanted more holidays and limits on overtime, changes that officials argued would force the companies to hire new workers.
"We've reached a tentative settlement, and it's a very good agreement," said Miriam Edelson, a spokeswoman for the C.A.W., in a telephone interview from Toronto. "It includes wage increases, some movement on pensions, and some movement on reduced work time that we were looking for."

HEADLINE: THE 1993 PRIMARY;
Turnout Is Low For the Primary

 BODY:
Fewer people voted in yesterday's Democratic primary then in any other Democratic primary since World War II. Only about 520,000 voters bothered to vote, or 23 percent of the city's 2.3 million registered Democrats.
That was fewer even than in 1981, when 578,000 Democrats, or 32 percent of those registered, voted in a race between then-Mayor Edward I. Koch and Frank J. Barbaro that was confused by a 12-day delay in the primary caused by court actions over a re-districting plan for the City Council. 
 In the last mayoral primary in 1989, when David N. Dinkins beat out Mr. Koch, more than 1 million voters went to the polls, or about 50 percent of registered Democrats.

The Economy
Retail spending and consumer prices rose more vigorously in August than had been expected. Retail sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent and consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, signaling a spurt of inflation and hurting bond prices. [Page D1.]
President Clinton's health care plan would cause a vast shift in financial burdens among American corporations. [A1.] 
 Legislation to complete the savings and loan cleanup narrowly passed the House of Representatives. [D18.]

Japan's output fell five-tenths of a percent, confirming fears that the country was heading back into recession. [D2.]
Grupo Televisa of Mexico plans a 3-for-1 stock split that could provide an opportunity for greater foreign ownership. [D21.]
Israel's economy is expected to undergo a growth spurt because of the peace settlement with the Palestinians. [A17.]

HEADLINE: THE 1993 PRIMARY: BUFFALO;
As Expected, State Senator Wins Democratic Mayoral Primary

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Sept. 14

 BODY:
State Senator Anthony Masiello, endorsed by the Democratic Party for Mayor of Buffalo, easily fended off a challenge today from City Councilman Eugene Fahey.
Polls that showed Mr. Masiello leading Mr. Fahey by a more than 2-to-1 margin going into the primary proved fairly accurate: with 94 percent of the vote in, Mr. Masiello had 63 percent of the vote and Mr. Fahey had 37 percent. 
 "It teaches me a few lessons," Mr. Fahey said in his concession speech an hour after the polls closed at 9 P.M. "Maybe I'll start believing in polls before I announce for another office."
Mr. Masiello called Mr. Fahey "a worthy opponent" and said he wanted him in his campaign.
"As a fellow Democrat, I extend my hand to Eugene Fahey to join our campaign of inclusion," Mr. Masiello said.
Buffalo is overwhelmingly Democratic, and a primary win should virtually assure Mr. Masiello a victory in the November election to succeed Mayor James D. Griffin, who is stepping down after 16 years.
The Republican candidate, Richard Grimm 3d, does not see it that way.
"When people see how hard we're running, I don't think people are going to think that for very long," he said.
The main issues in the campaign have been economic development, housing, rising crime and poverty in Buffalo's minority neighborhoods.
Mr. Fahey had proposed creating local economic development zones to spur business, including one along Buffalo's waterfront, which the city is trying to redevelop. He also favors converting empty retail space in downtown Buffalo into housing.
Mr. Masiello wants to open a city commerce office to coordinate Buffalo's economic development strategies. Buffalo's economy has been hurt by the loss of major manufacturing employers, but Mr. Masiello said future job growth in the city rests with small businesses.
In the Albany mayoral race, Alderman Gerald Jennings narrowly defeated Harold Joyce, chairman of the county legislature, in the city's Democratic primary.
Mr. Jennings had gained support with calls to open up and diversify city government after decades in which party insiders had handpicked their candidate for mayor, who was then swept into office by the party faithful.
Incumbent Mayor Thomas M. Whalen 3d has been nominated to a Federal judgeship for the Northern District of New York and is not seeking re-election.

HEADLINE: THE 1993 PRIMARY: WESTCHESTER;
Democrats Pick Brodsky To Challenge O'Rourke

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Richard L. Brodsky, an outspoken six-term assemblyman, captured the Democratic nomination for Westchester county executive today and with it a chance to topple the Republican incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke.
After weeks of nasty crossfire over personal ethics and tax policy, the 47-year-old Mr. Brodsky defeated Andrew J. Spano, County Clerk for the last 11 years. His victory, by 51 percent to 49 percent, came even though the county's Democratic leaders supported the 57-year-old Mr. Spano. He immediately turned his fire on Mr. O'Rourke. 
 In declaring victory tonight, Mr. Brodsky, who lost to Mr. O'Rourke four years ago, said: "Andy O'Rourke is a tired, self-contented politician who cannot face the future with a clean slate or a clean plan."
The Democrats believe they have their best chance in years to win the county executive contest because Mr. O'Rourke is considered vulnerable. He admitted earlier this year that three people close to him -- his daughter, the woman he lives with and her son -- all obtained work with county contractors. An investigation by Mr. Vergari found that none of these transactions violated state laws.
Mr. O'Rourke tonight dismissed Mr. Brodsky as a "hack politican from Albany" and said his frequent votes to raise taxes in Albany would make him an easier opponent to defeat than Mr. Spano.
At 10:45 P.M., Mr. Spano refused to concede victory, saying he wanted to take a closer look at the possibility that mistakes were made in transmitting results. But he acknowledged: "I'm not ecstatic."
With 97 percent of the votes counted, these were the results:
Brodsky 16,010 (51.5%)
Spano 15,068 (48.5%)
In a second closely watched race, Michael G. Cherkasky, a longtime Manhattan prosecutor, easily beat back a lackadaisical challenge by Paul W. Pickelle, a criminal lawyer, to win the Democratic nomination for district attorney.
With 97 percent of the votes counted, these were the results:
Cherkasky 17,397 (67.5%)
Pickelle 8,378 (32.5%)
"The Democrats of Westchester have overwhelmingly endorsed our vision of the D.A.'s office where merit and experience matter and political connections and family influence do not," Mr. Cherkasky declared tonight.
For the first time in a quarter of a century, the Democratic desigation means something because the popular Republican incumbent, Carl A. Vergari, is retiring and his successor, Jeanine Pirro, may not be as invincible in the Nov. 2 election.
There were also several municipal races in Westchester.
In Greenburgh, the largest town in the county, Supervisor Peter J. Feiner easily won renomination in the Democratic primary. His defeat of Susan P. Tolchin, the Town Clerk, removes the biggest obstacle to winning a second term in the town, which is overwhelmingly Democratic.
In Mount Pleasant, Robert F. Meehan, the Republican incumbent, easily won a third term over Phillip A. Grimaldi, a former grants coordinator. Mr. Meehan will face M. Gail Grimaldi, a Democrat not related to Philip Grimaldi, in November.
Election officials said it appeared that roughly 20 percent of Westchester's 178,000 registered Democrats cast ballots. In last year's Presidential primary about 31 percent of the Democrats voted.
The low turnout had been expected to help Mr. Spano and Mr. Cherkasky, the candidates supported by Democratic leaders. But there was a sizable vote in Mr. Brodsky's hometown of Greenburgh, where voter interest was quickened by a race for town supervisor, and a light turnout in Yonkers, where Mr. Spano was said to have many supporters.
With Republicans dominating the county government, there has not been a Democratic primary for countywide office in more than a decade and many of county's 178,753 registered Democrats have lost the habit of primary voting. Still, many Democrats and Republicans were drawn today by local primaries for positions ranging from mayor to highway superintendent in which the candidates were often their neighbors.
Mr. Brodsky kept Mr. Spano on the defensive, sounding the theme of the "two Andys" to liken Mr. Spano to the incumbent, Mr. O'Rourke, on issues like personal ethics and high taxes.
Mr. Brodksy said Mr. Spano had staffed the top tiers of his clerk's office with his wife, Brenda Resnick, and party functionaries and had hired low-level staff members in secret deals with Republican leaders.
Mr. Spano responded that Mr. Brodsky, as chairman of the Assembly's environmental committee, had taken donations from power and waste management companies disciplined for pollution. He also said his "arrogant" opponent lacked the consensus-building temperament needed to run the county government.
Grappling with Westchester's floundering economy, Mr. Brodsky proposed retraining and entrepreneurial advice for laid-off white-collar workers. Mr. Spano stressed a partnership between government and private industry to invigorate the county's economy and proposed a re-engineering of county government, much as he did when he computerized the clerk's office.
Of the two candidates for district attorney, the 43-year-old Mr. Cherkasky ran a far more aggressive campaign. Mr. Cherkasky stressed his record as the chief of the Investigations Division of the Manhattan District Attorney's office and his legal attacks against such organized crime figures as John Gotti and the sons of Carlo Gambino.
The 54-year-old Mr. Pickelle, a former assistant district attorney in Queens who twice lost to Mr. Vergari, portrayed Mr. Cherkasky as a "Johnny-come-lately Democrat" and a carpetbagger who had no experience in Westchester courtrooms.
