HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: The Economy;
Israelis Expect Peace in Mideast Would Bring Big Dividends

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Many Israeli economists and business analysts are confident that a settlement with the Palestinians and normalization of relations with the more conservative Arab countries will lead to a burst of growth not experienced by Israel since the 1960's.
Their aplomb is unrelated to any immediate opportunity to beat swords into plowshares. Nor is it linked to visions of oil wealth flowing from the Persian Gulf. The most important peace dividend, experts widely agree, is probably the least tangible: an end to the outcast status that has blocked closer trade and investment links with the advanced industrial powers. 
 "Watch what the multinational corporations do," said Pinchas Landau, the editor of The Telegraph, Israel's business daily. Mr. Landau expects the collapse of the Arab economic boycott and the fading prospect of military conflict to yield "tremendous changes in attitude, particularly in Europe and Japan."
 
Military Aid Could Decline
 A reduction in tensions with Israel's neighbors and an end to the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip might be expected to reduce Israeli military spending and thus allow Israel's economic resources to shift to investment to increase productivity. But economists dismiss the idea, at least for the immediate future.
The military challenge will change, as Israel prepares to defend a smaller territory and cope with a Palestinian authority over which it has no direct control. But "it wouldn't surprise me if the redeployment of the army actually cost money," said Ephraim Kleiman, an economist at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
The pullback from Sinai generated parallel costs after the Camp David accord. And as with the Egyptian settlement, the financial burden may be offset by one-time gifts from Israel's foreign friends. But dependence on foreign military aid is a double-edged sword, noted Herbert Stein, an economic adviser to Republican Presidents who is a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
A substantial part of Israel's military budget is now covered by grants and loans from Washington. The Pentagon trims the cost of Israel's military spending in many other ways, ranging from procurement of Israeli military equipment to the licensing of advanced technology.
Thus as the diminished Arab threat leaves America less inclined to subsidize the Israeli military, a shekel saved on defense in the long run may not prove to be a shekel earned. "The Israelis ought to plan to phase out this aid," Mr. Stein said.
Economists are also doubtful that Israel could soon become a Middle Eastern trading center.
True, Israeli businesses familiar with Arab culture are already eyeing the market. Benjamin Gaon, the chief executive of Koor Industries, Israel's largest private corporation, is exploring the idea of minority participation in joint ventures for manufacturing in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Moreover, Leonard Hausman, the director of the Institute for Social and Economic Policy in the Middle East at the Kennedy School at Harvard, believes that the smaller Persian Gulf nations are open to trade with Israel -- indeed, eager for it. "Dubai is the new Hong Kong of the Mideast," he said, a place where the only ideology is selling the most for the highest price.
But Israel's regional prospects must be put in perspective, said Stanley Fischer, formerly the chief economist for the World Bank. "The economy of the entire Arab world is smaller than Canada's," he pointed out. And at least partly in response to half a century of Arab boycott, Israeli industry makes little that the Arab economies lack.
Mr. Landau concurred. "Why would Saudi Arabia buy computers from Israel that they now get from America, Japan or Taiwan?" he asked.
There is another area in which economists believe the conventional wisdom exaggerates the benefits of peace. The five-and-half-year-old Palestinian uprising has hurt Israeli tourism, and the Persian Gulf war of 1991 was also a blow to the multibillion-dollar industry. But the Economist Intelligence Unit, part of the Economist Magazine group, says the Israeli airline and hotel industries also share the blame for stagnant tourism. Winter vacations for Europeans have been hindered by a failure to encourage air charter competition.
The uprising further disrupted the economy by limiting both the supply and reliability of low-cost Palestinian day labor in Israel. Today, just 45,000 residents of the occupied territories, less than half the number of the mid-1980's and only 2 percent of the total Israeli labor force, commute to Israel.
But with the exception of farming, Israel has largely adjusted to the scarcity of Palestinian labor. Mr. Kleiman pointed out that chronic double-digit unemployment, increased by the flow of Jewish immigrants from the former Soviet Union, has made Israelis willing to do jobs they once refused.
Given these diluted expectations, what explains the widespread optimism that peace would make a big economic difference? The hope that it will enable Israel to complete its transition from an inefficient if self-reliant siege economy to a full-fledged member of the technological elite.
Israel has the educated work force, particularly in the sciences. And it has a fair share of domestic and foreign companies operating at the technological edge. Israel is a low-cost producer of chemicals and a world leader in specialized electronics. Intel, Motorola and I.B.M. are among the American companies doing research as well as manufacturing in the country.
But Howard Rosen, an economist at the Competitiveness Policy Council in Washington, argues that Israel's economic opportunities have been deeply handicapped by the Arab boycott and the uncertainty of investing in a country permanently at war. Peace could quickly change that, particularly with Japanese and European companies that have longstanding business arrangements with the gulf nations.
Mr. Fischer agrees, noting that Israeli business and Government leaders who could barely get the time of day from their counterparts in Europe and Japan can no longer accommodate all the requests for appointments.
 
Tensions Could Stay High
 Israelis remember the high economic hopes dashed by a cold peace with Egypt. And this time, too, events short of an outright collapse in the peace efforts could curdle the outlook.
The obvious worry is that tensions will remain high enough to cancel out the advantages of the deal on paper. Sporadic terrorism, sustained by Palestinian militants, is a serious risk. So is a breakdown in negotiations over water rights, import duties and Palestinian access to Israeli markets.
Still, optimism remains the order of the day. "This is the external shock the Israeli economy has been waiting for," Mr. Rosen said.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST ACCORD: Arafat;
Arafat Shifts Quest From Peace to Funds

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Visiting old haunts like the United Nations and new, previously forbidden ones like the halls of Congress, Yasir Arafat today appealed to the United States and the world community to provide funds to help build the new entity he says will lead to a Palestinian State.
"We are in need of the help," Mr. Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said during an appearance at the National Press Club in Washington. "Our infrastructure has been completely destroyed." He said that unemployment in some areas of the West Bank and Gaza was about 56 percent and that "there is real starvation in Gaza." 
 But so far, Mr. Arafat has received more compliments on his willingness to make peace than cash for him to construct a Palestinian state. "We have to wait and see," he said at the United Nations when asked whether he was getting enough financial support from the West. "We have promises."
P.L.O. officials estimate that they will need about $11.2 billion over 10 years to create an economically viable entity in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. While talk of reconciliation fills the air, firm commitments of cash have yet to follow. The Clinton Administration is trying to put together a $590 million start-up fund, but has yet to obtain solid commitments from other important donors.
Administration officials have stressed that most of the financial aid would have to come from other countries, like the Persian Gulf states and Japan. In meetings with Congressional leaders today, Mr. Arafat said he understood the fiscal limitations on the United States.
"He understands that we are under great constraints because of budgetary problems," said Senator Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, who along with 20 other senators met with Mr. Arafat for about an hour this morning. "But he expressed the hope that the United States would participate as a signal to other countries."
Mr. Arafat sought a promise from Congressional leaders to repeal laws prohibiting the United States from giving any funds to the P.L.O. or requiring it to vote against any loans for the organization from international financial institutions like the World Bank.
Many laws contain such amendments. After meeting with Mr. Arafat, George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, promised that he and Mr. Dole would "review and assess" such legislation."
 
Stressed Stability Factor
 In seeking financial commitments from major donors for his new governing authority in Gaza and Jericho, Mr. Arafat stressed the importance of stability in a region that still has the world's largest oil reserves. He also put on a charm offensive that would make him the envy of many an American Presidential candidate.
He sought to allay Israeli concerns about the establishment of a Palestinian nation by saying that once such a state is created, he would seek a confederation with Jordan -- a long-held Israeli position. At the same time, he defiantly refused to back away from his claim to East Jerusalem.
He chided rejectionists like Iran. "Slogans, slogans," he said of Iranian criticism of negotiations with Israel. "What we have achieved from slogans?"
He played down differences with Saudi Arabia, spoke of his solidarity with Libya and Iraq and strummed the chords of militant Palestinian pride by declaring that he would not turn in his familiar khaki-colored uniform and kaffiyeh for a business suit, now that he supposedly had changed from guerrilla leader to head of state.
"I am not a lizard," Mr. Arafat said, then realizing that that was not the right word, fumbled for the correct one. "Lizard. Lizard? I am not a chameleon. I am commander and chief of our army, and I am proud to have this dress."
At 7:10 P.M. Mr. Arafat strode into the United Nations to meet with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. It was the first time in 19 years that the P.L.O. chairman had set foot inside the United Nations headquarters.
In 1974 Mr. Arafat addressed the General Assembly, but his appearance sparked criticism when photographs showed that he wore a pistol holster beneath his shirt. Five years ago, Mr. Arafat was again scheduled to speak to the General Assembly, but his entry visa was denied by the United States.
In his appearances today he displayed a wit that at times won over his audience. At one point, Clayton Boyce, president of the National Press Club, who read Mr. Arafat questions submitted by the audience, asked him to name his enemies, now that he had made peace with Israel. The P.L.O. chief answered quickly, "You."
As he grabbed Mr. Boyce's hand, Mr. Arafat told the crowd, "He is quizzing me too much with his questions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, center, with Secretary General Boutros-Boutros Ghali, right, before meetings at the United Nations. At left is Mahmoud Abbas, a P.L.O. negotiator. It was the first time in 19 years that Mr. Arafat had been inside the U.N. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Splintered on Trade;
2 Unusual Political Alliances Reflect Long-Term Gain and Short-Term Fear

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Seldom in American politics have there been such strange bedfellows.
Bill Clinton, George Bush, Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter stand together in favor of the North American Free Trade Agreement. Ross Perot, Jesse Jackson, Patrick J. Buchanan and Ralph Nader are lined up against it. 
 The Republicans in Congress, who were united just last month in their opposition to President Clinton's budget, are generally on his side on Nafta. Democrats in Congress are mostly opposed.
Thomas S. Foley, Newt Gingrich, George J. Mitchell and Bob Dole are working together on behalf of the pact. Greer, Margolis, Mitchell & Associates, the political consulting concern that handled Mr. Clinton's advertising in the Presidential campaign last year, is now running the advertising campaign against the agreement.
The scrambled politics are grounded in this fundamental precept: The benefits of the trade agreement, like those of free trade generally, would be diffuse and would accumulate gradually. The dislocations and disruptions, while probably smaller than the benefits in the aggregate, would be immediate and concentrated.
 
'People Will Blame Nafta'
 Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist, put the matter this way: "Boosting trade with Mexico will create a few jobs in this machine tool factory and a job in that advertising agency. Circulation in this magazine will rise, and the financial district of New York will have a new job here and there. It will all largely be invisible. But when the glass factory in Toledo closes or the textile plant in South Carolina or the furniture manufacturer in North Carolina because those low-wage jobs move to Mexico, it will be highly visible, and it will be attributable to Nafta. Or at least people will blame Nafta for it."
What that means first of all is that the pact's opponents are much more passionate than its supporters. "They feel their livelihoods are at stake," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "The supporters tend to deal with Nafta on a more intellectual level."
It also means that for many politicians, a vote against the trade agreement is the safer vote. If the trade pact goes into effect, it is sure to be blamed, fairly or not, for every factory that closes over the next few years, and the politicians who voted for it will be held accountable.
The way the benefits are spread thin explains why the larger a politician's constituency is, the more likely he or she is to support the trade agreement. Every President since Herbert Hoover has been an advocate of free trade, presumably because they have represented the overall interest of the entire country rather than the interests of narrower segments. Governors and senators are more likely to be in favor of the trade pact than are members of the House of Representatives.
And the way the drawbacks are concentrated explains the ferocious opposition from organized labor. Some union leaders have threatened to work against any politician who votes for the agreement, regardless of where the politician stands on other issues.
These are tough times for the unions. The industries where they are strongest are shrinking, and the places where jobs are expanding tend not to be unionized. Nafta seems to symbolize the frustration blue-collar workers feel about the changing world economy, and the issue is the first in Congress on which this frustration is really framed.
 
Democratic Party Fissure
 "I don't think there is an issue," Mr. Garin said, "that quite so distinctly separates those who think they will succeed in the new world order from those who see themselves as victims of the changing economic structure."
This has created a fissure in the Democratic Party. Labor unions are a relatively small element in the national economy nowadays, representing only 16 percent of the work force. But they are an important aspect of the Democratic constituency, central to the party's financing and organization.
Some party leaders with close labor connections like Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip in the House, are actively opposing the trade agreement. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, may announce his position this week. The best the White House can hope for is that he will not lead the fight against it.
David Mitchell, a partner in the firm that produced Mr. Clinton's campaign advertising, said he was working against the trade agreement because of his strong ties to the labor movement.
The official view at the White House is that the unusual political lineup on the trade pact will actually help Mr. Clinton when it comes to other issues like health care because it shows how, in contrast to the battle over the budget, the President can operate in a bipartisan fashion.
In Congress, the trade agreement is put in the same category as gun control: an issue on which little effort is made to enforce party discipline, leaving legislators free to vote their political instincts.
 
Negative House View
 As matters stand today, a small but solid majority of senators seems to be in favor of the trade agreement. But the legislation may never get to the Senate. Under the rules, the House must vote first, and at last count, the Administration was well shy of the 100 or so Democrats (out of 258) needed to form a majority with about 120 Republicans (out of 175) who appear to be in favor.
Mr. Perot is presenting the Administration with a serious obstacle. He is back on the talk shows with his charts and homilies. His new paperback is titled "Save Your Job, Save Our Country," and has the subtitle, "Why Nafta Must Be Stopped -- Now!"
His hyperbole is unrelenting. On NBC's "Tonight Show" last week, he showed a photograph of Mexicans living in cardboard shacks and suggested that this was what could happen to American workers. His estimate that 5.9 million American jobs would be threatened by the trade pact is not accepted by any mainstream economist.
But it is hard to answer specific charges like that with academic theory. So the proponents of the trade agreement have raised the stakes themselves. In the televised White House ceremony today, Mr. Clinton said that one million new jobs would be created by the pact over the next five years. (The White House later backed off the assertion, attributing the mistake to "a staff error.")
The dominant view of economists is that the effect on the trade pact on the total number of jobs in the United States over the next few years would be negligible -- nowhere near the two million jobs that might be lost from cuts in military spending or the 360,000 jobs that stand to be generated if long-term interest rates fall another half a percentage point. The net jobs gained or lost probably would not even reach the 252,000 that Vice President Al Gore said last week should be cut from the Federal Government.
Still, as the political debate wears on, the exaggerations of benefits and drawbacks will surely increase. "In this town," said Mr. Reischauer, the Congressional economist, "if one person shouts at a high decibel level, the only way to counter it is to shout in the other direction at a similarly high level."

HEADLINE: Data Spur Inflation Concerns

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Government reports today showed that both retail spending and consumer prices were a bit more vigorous in August than had generally been expected and the bond market promptly seized on the figures as an excuse to sell.
The Commerce Department reported that $173.5 billion passed across retail counters last month, two-tenths of 1 percent more than in July, as merchants racked up their fifth consecutive advance since the late-winter blizzard that crippled much of the East Coast. A large part of the gain reflected the automotive sector, though the contribution was less than in July. 
 Meanwhile, the Labor Department calculated that prices at the retail, or consumer, level rose three-tenths of 1 percent as sharp deceleration in medical inflation and hefty declines in the price of gasoline and tobacco products were more than offset by increases for clothing, food and shelter.
 
 
Bond Market Selling Spree
 Although neither set of figures was far from what had been anticipated, they -- together with modest upward revisions for sales in earlier months -- combined to touch off a selling spree in the bond market that pushed long-term interest rates sharply higher, to 5.97 percent.
"I think the train overshot the station at 6 percent," said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank in Pittsburgh, referring to the fact that the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond had tumbled to a 5.86 percent close last Wednesday.
"The market is very sensitive" even to "shadings" in economic prospects, Mr. Hoffman said.
According to John R. Williams, chief economist for the Bankers Trust Company, the August rise in retail sales showed "the consumer is doing O.K. in the third quarter" and apparently more willing to spend than suggested by surveys of consumer confidence.
Indeed, a related report from the Labor Department today showed that average weekly earnings jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent last month after adjustment for inflation and seasonal variation.
This resulted from a longer workweek and higher hourly earnings partly offset by a small rise in prices.
Retail sales, which account for one-third of the entire economy, continued to show considerably more strength in typically big-ticket, long-lasting goods like lawn mowers than in perishables like restaurant meals. For August, in fact, durable goods jumped six-tenths of 1 percent to account for the entire sales gain.
Economists suggested that at a time of insecurity about jobs, interest rates have fallen low enough to induce consumers to make commitments for expensive goods.
Automotive dealers had a seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in receipts last month while merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes gained 1.8 percent -- with the help of extra demand caused by the rebuilding from Midwest floods.
Sales of furniture and other equipment for the home, on the other hand, slumped 1.7 percent, the Commerce Department report showed.
Excluding the automotive sector, retail sales edged up 1 percent last month after being unchanged in July.
 
 
Gasoline Declines
 Among nondurables, gains of 1.1 percent in food stores, eight-tenths of 1 percent in stores selling apparel and accessories, and four-tenths of 1 percent in general merchandise stores were offset by declines of 2.5 percent at gasoline service stations, seven-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars, and two-tenths of 1 percent at drug and proprietary stores.
Lower prices for gasoline contributed to the decline.
So far this year, sales of durable goods are running 12.1 percent above the 1992 pace, compared with a 3.1 percent gain for nondurables.
Today's report of a three-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer prices was to an unusual extent a result of big swings in various items, including a rebound in the cost of shelter, a category accounting for 28 percent of the Consumer Price Index and two-thirds of the August acceleration.
Housing, which includes utilities and other housekeeping costs as well as shelter, rose three-tenths of 1 percent after showing no change in July, the Bureau of Labor Statistics report showed.
Clothing jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, the first rise since February, mainly reflecting an earlier than usual introduction of women's autumn and winter clothing.
 
 
Surge in New York Area
 It also contributed -- along with meats and poultry and entertainment -- to a six-tenths of 1 percent surge in consumer prices in the New York City metropolitan area last month. This rise, raising the area's inflation rate over the latest 12 months to 3 percent, was the largest for any of the five metropolitan areas for which figures were published today.
Food prices advanced three-tenths of 1 percent nationally after an unchanged July, with fresh fruits and vegetables up 2.7 percent, causing most of the acceleration in groceries.
Medical inflation, however, eased two-tenths of 1 percent, the weakest monthly showing since March 1984. The change was concentrated in drugs and supplies but inflation in medical services also slowed.
"It's not bad -- but it could be better," Lawrence Lindsey, a Federal Reserve Board governor, said of today's inflation figures. Many analysts expect the central bank to make no overt shift when its chief policy body meets Tuesday, but to abandon its inclination to tighten in favor of neutrality.
During the first eight months of this year, consumer inflation was running at a pace of 2.9 percent, the same as for all of 1992.

HEADLINE: Mexican Shifts Tone on Trade Accord

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 14

 BODY:
After months of promoting the virtues of a free trade agreement with the United States and Canada, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari shifted his tone today, telling Mexicans that the troubled accord is not "a panacea."
Moments after President Clinton used his signing of side agreements to the pact as the occasion to launch his uphill campaign for Congressional approval, Mr. Salinas took the same opportunity to deflate expectations that until now he has steadily pumped up. 
 "The Mexicans know that the agreements and treaties will not by themselves solve our problems," Mr. Salinas told an audience of Government officials, legislators, and foreign diplomats at the presidential residence, Los Pinos. "That depends on our internal effort, which, without doubt, we will redouble."
 
Focus on Ties With U.S.
 The 45-year-old leader's new caution was not a matter of saying things he has not said before. Domestic critics of his Administration's focus on the North American Free Trade Agreement say that he has sacrificed Mexican independence to improve ties with the United States and their complaints prompted him long ago to describe the pact as part of a broader process of economic change in Mexico.
Until now, however, Mr. Salinas has virtually ignored the possiblity that the agreement might not go into effect as scheduled on Jan. 1.
Even today, his acknowledgement that American legislators could delay or defeat the accord was no more than tacit. But with Mexican officials privately expressing growing concern about the accord's prospects in Washington, aides to Mr. Salinas confirmed a change in his message.
 
Expectations 'Too High'
 "The signal is that the expectations around Nafta have been built too high," one senior official said after the President's speech, referring to the agreement by its intials. "Everyone thinks they are going to get a new house when the treaty goes into effect."
Mr. Salinas's stake in the trade agreement, high from the outset, has risen significantly over the last year.
The Government has brought inflation down below 10 percent for the first time in years, but economic growth has slowed from 4.4 percent in 1990 to 1.3 percent for the first half of this year.
Supporters of the trade agreement say that by dropping barriers to trade and investment, it will draw enough new capital to Mexico to increase the growth rate by about one percentage point a year.
 
Pressure for Devaluation
 The agreement's impact on foreign investment is critical to the Government's ability to cover the huge deficit in its current account, the broadest measure of trade. Last year, Mexico imported $22.8 billion more in goods and services than it exported. The trend has increased the pressure for a devaluation of the Mexican peso that would almost certainly raise memories of Mexico's past economic instability.
The trade agreement is supposed to be put into effect by Jan. 1, but lately some American Congressional leaders have said that a vote might have to be delayed until after the first of the year.
While economists here say an American Congressional delay of the agreement for a few months would probably not have a drastic impact on the Mexican economy, many political analysts say a delay could complicate the process by which Mr. Salinas will choose among his aides for the governing party's candidate to succeed him. The election is set for Aug. 21.
 
A Setback for Salinas
 In the hope of limiting political conflict next year, officials said that the governing party renewed its efforts today to gain opposition support for changes in the country's electoral laws to make them more democratic.
In the last couple of days, the Government has come under sharp criticism as the ruling party's large majority in the lower house of Congress forced through a series of changes in the laws over the objections of the conservative National Action Party.
The National Action legislators had initially negotiated the changes with the governing party, whereas the country's main leftist party quit the Congressional debate to protest what it said was the Government's unwillingness to allow real democracy.
 
Election Change Delayed
 Later, however, the National Action Party accused the governing party of backing away from some of their agreements, and turned against the new laws. The criticism centered on the ruling party's move to delay until after next year's election a measure that would limit Government influence over 300 district electoral boards.

President Clinton and Prime Minister Kim Campbell of Canada had simultaneous signings of the trade pact yesterday in Washington and Ottawa. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Start of School in Doubt After Review of Asbestos

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
A portrait of a school system in disarray emerged yesterday as teams surveyed all of New York City's public schools, leading several superintendents and the teacher's union to question whether schools could open on Monday as planned.
But the new Schools Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, said in an interview that he would recommend again in a Board of Education meeting today that the schools open on Sept. 20. 
 "I'm sticking to that date," Mr. Cortines said. "We've just got to open. I don't think we have any choice."
During the citywide surveys -- carried out yesterday by teams of principals, teachers, custodians and parents at Mr. Cortines's request -- yesterday sealed off hundreds of rooms that had not been closed, making a bad space shortage even worse. Some of the district superintendents flatly called for a delay.
Eight of the 25 schools in District 30 in Queens, for instance, must remain closed, and three others have most of their rooms sealed because of wall damage, said Dr. Angelo Gimondo, the superintendent in the district, which includes Jackson Heights.
"Based on today's findings, the situation is much worse than it was yesterday. I just don't have any room," he said, urging that school be delayed "even a couple of days -- some time to do some planning."
Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the United Federation of Teachers, said, "If the opening of the schools depends on the results of the surveys taken today, they clearly cannot open on Monday."
Mr. Cortines ordered yesterday's survey by the school-based committees to help the city's 39 superintendents make last-minute contingency plans for the city's one million schoolchildren, who were to have reported on Sept. 9. The request came after the agency that has been leading the emergency asbestos inspections failed on Monday to report which schools were ready to open.
During yesterday's inspections, the school committees unexpectedly closed off hundreds of additional rooms after finding widespread wall and ceiling damage that had gone unreported. For example, at Murry Bergtraum High School, at 411 Pearl Street in Manhattan, where just five rooms had been closed previously, the committee closed 25 more rooms yesterday, Ms. Amlung said, based on reports from teachers union representatives who participated in the surveys. At the High School for the Humanities, at 351 West 18th Street, also in Manhattan, the committee closed 25 more rooms, Ms. Amlung said. On Staten Island, so many rooms have been closed that less than half the schools could open today, the union said.
In many cases, the rooms closed by the committees have been inspected and cleared, and the local districts lack only the inspection reports from the School Construction Authority, the agency that has been conducting the emergency inspections, to reopen the rooms, Ms. Amlung said.
A spokesman for the authority, Jacques DeGraff, said the agency was working hard to prepare for today's Board of Education meeting a list of what classrooms within what schools will be safe for school opening. "We are working as diligently as we can," Mr. DeGraff said.
Time is especially short because the Rosh ha-Shanah holiday begins tomorrow. And several superintendents said they were simply unable to make contingency plans to deal with such sweeping dislocation on such short notice.
 
District in Bronx
 "Somebody tells me that I have to make contingency plans when I just received a report," said Joseph Kovaly, the superintendent of District 11 in the Bronx, which includes Co-op City, Morris Park, Parkchester and Williamsbridge and is one of the city' most overcrowded districts. "I don't see how it can be done."
Mr. Kovaly said that in his district of 26,000 students, at least three of the 31 schools would not open and several others would have many rooms and corridors sealed off. "Where am I going to shift 2,600 students in a district that is at 130 percent of capacity right now?"
In District 1, on Manhattan's Lower East Side, William Ubinas, the superintendent, said 6 of 18 schools would not open. In District 2, in lower Manhattan and the Upper East Side, Andrew Lachman, a spokesman for Superintendent Anthony Alvarado, said 7 of 31 buildings would be unavailable. And in District 16, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, the superintendent, Mildred Jones, said at least 4 of 16 schools would not open unless she receives results from asbestos tests indicating that numerous damaged areas are free of asbestos.

HEADLINE: Shifting Burdens: Business and the Health Plan - A special report.;
Companies Big and Small Tally Effects of Clinton Health Plan

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
President Clinton's plan for reshaping the health care system would cause a vast shift in financial burdens among American corporations. Health costs would ease for companies, most of them manufacturers, that now offer generous benefits, and rise for those that do not, among them not only small neighborhood shops but also corporate giants like Wal-Mart, Sears and Wendy's.
How those burdens would be reapportioned emerges from a look at insurance costs and prospects at four companies representing the variety of corporate experiences: Ford Motor Company, an older manufacturer; Apple Computer, a young high-tech company; Lehigh Valley Racquet and Fitness Centers, a small Pennsylvania business that uses part-time instructors, and Manpower Inc., the nation's biggest supplier of temporary workers. 
 Once the President's plan is in place, "the variation in burdens among firms is going to be much less," said Paul Starr, a senior White House adviser and an architect of the plan.
 
Favorable Glances
 For Ford, the Clinton plan holds out great promise of slowing the steady rise in the company's health care expenses. At last, Ford says, it will not have to pay a disproportionate share of the nation's medical bills, in effect picking up payments to treat the indigent and the uninsured. What the company really wants, though, is to shift to the Government its huge outlay for retirees' health care, and the White House has not yet said how it would handle that issue.
Apple, another big manufacturer, also looks favorably on the Clinton plan, which would set a national standard for health insurance that would cost the company less than it now pays for the same, or better, coverage.
But Manpower and Lehigh Valley Racquet are worried. Lehigh Valley Racquet pays nothing for its part-time employees' health coverage, and Manpower pays very little for its temporary workers. Under the Clinton plan, each company would have to contribute for each of those employees. Lehigh Valley Racquet, among other companies, is strongly lobbying against any health plan that would give the Government a larger role.
 
No Plans on the Job
 The uninsured employees at Lehigh Valley Racquet and at Manpower are among the nearly 48 million workers -- nearly 40 percent of all employed Americans -- who hold jobs at companies that do not offer them health insurance, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington. While some of those workers are at small companies that say they cannot afford to give benefits to anyone, the majority are part-time employees, temporary workers and contract workers at giant corporations as well as neighborhood businesses.
A great majority of these workers are in fact insured, under a spouse's or parent's policy or a personal policy. The Clinton plan would have all employers share the cost of insuring their workers and their families, no matter what other arrangements an employee might have.
At present, Ford often pays for health insurance for the family of a worker, although the worker's spouse might have a job at a Wal-Mart or a Manpower. Under the Clinton plan, Ford's obligation would be reduced, while the spouse's employer would have to help pay for the family's coverage.
 
Ford
Where Retirees Are the Issue
 To hold down rising costs, Ford is slowly drawing its workers to plans that are less expensive than the company's traditional fee-for-service coverage, in which a worker goes to a doctor of his choice and the Ford health plan pays the bill, whatever it might be. The less expensive plans, called preferred provider networks or health maintenance organizations, in effect require workers to use groups of doctors and hospitals with whom the company has negotiated set fees.
Even with the migration to networks, Ford is paying more for health care -- $5,000 on average for each active and retired worker in 1992 -- than the Clinton plan would require for its standardized coverage, which is less comprehensive than Ford's.
What's more, while the Clinton plan would require an employer to pay at least 80 percent of the insurance premiums of its workers, Ford now picks up the entire bill, using a standard negotiated with the United Auto Workers. That standard of fully paid health insurance might be revised for newly hired workers, a possibility arising this week in Ford's negotiations with the union.
When it comes to retirees, Ford has a problem. Apple Computer and many other nonunion companies founded in recent decades have no retirees yet, and no intention of giving them health insurance when they materialize. Ford, on the other hand, has 125,000 retirees, a number almost as large as the company's active work force of 145,000. And all have the same coverage as the active workers.
Nothing seems to strike Robert L. Ozment, Ford's director of corporate and employee insurance, as more important than lowering, or eliminating, the cost of retiree health care, which is currently more than $600 million a year, or 40 percent of Ford's total health cost. "Any company that is successful for many years and provides health care for its growing corps of retirees is at a competitive disadvantage," Mr. Ozment said.
And then he expressed a fervent hope: "We think that Clinton should do what other countries do: anyone unemployed or uninsured, including retirees, should get health coverage fully paid from general tax revenues."
Such an arrangement would hold not only for retirees under 65, who now are fully covered by a company-paid medical plan at Ford, but also those 65 and older who qualify for Medicare and also receive a company-sponsored supplemental policy.
 
Cost-Saving Proposals
 The Clinton plan offers to help pay insurance costs for retirees under 65 and ineligible for Medicare, covering 38,000 of Ford's retirees. How to deal with older retirees, beyond Medicare, is still being debated. The Clinton plan would add a new prescription drug benefit to Medicare, relieving Ford of a big current cost. "We would favor that, absolutely," Mr. Ozment said.
Ford is also happy with Clinton proposals to reduce the cost of health care generally. Mr. Ozment endorses provisions that would limit malpractice claims and set national standards for treating specific ailments to help eliminate excess care and overcharging. "We think Ford has done well in controlling costs," Mr. Ozment said, "but our rate of cost increase is still 8 percent a year, and that is more than double the inflation rate."
One way to cut this growth rate further, Mr. Ozment said, is to reduce the cost of hospital construction, an outlay that ends up in Ford's health bill. Mr. Ozment, for example, would like to prevent construction of a new hospital in Pontiac, Mich., which already has three hospitals and not enough patients to fill them. Nevertheless, one hospital, occupying an old building, is planning a new structure, despite the efforts of Ford and other companies to stop the project.
"The construction cost will show up as higher hospital charges to care for Ford workers, and, eventually, higher costs for our health insurance," Mr. Ozment said. If the Government could help solve this problem, he added, Ford might go along with a payroll tax to pay for the Clinton plan.
"If the Government called for, say, a 4 percent payroll tax, we would, like most companies, say that is evil," Mr. Ozment said. "But if the Government said that with a payroll tax 'we guarantee that costs will go from an 8 percent annual growth rate to a 2 percent rate,' we would say hallelujah."
 
Apple
Where Choice Is Mandated
 The big effort at Apple has been to reduce the cost of company-sponsored health insurance for its 8,000 American workers. With the cost of premiums rising 18 percent a year, the computer company announced in 1987 that instead of having only one form of insurance, its employees would be able to choose from four types of plans, each involving a different cost to the employees themselves and different levels of coverage.
"We proceeded gradually," said Sally Gottlieb, benefits manager at Apple. "We did not jack up charges overnight. By 1989, the difference between the most expensive and least expensive plans was only $300 in annual premium cost to the employee. That was not enough, so we have changed the pricing to represent different values. Now the difference is $800."
Like most companies, Apple had relied for years on a fee-for-service health plan that paid 80 percent or more of medical costs after the employee and his or her family covered an annual deductible. The company now also offers two preferred provider networks in which employees are charged only small amounts for care, once an annual deductible is covered, as long as they stay within their networks. Apple also does business with three health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, which in effect provide full medical and hospital care at a fixed annual premium per employee.
H.M.O.'s offer the best opportunity for Apple to control costs. But the company, like most of corporate America, has been reluctant to force its employees into the cheapest plan. While 19 percent of Apple workers have joined an H.M.O., 49 percent have chosen one of the preferred provider plans. Partly as a result, the increase in Apple's annual health care costs fell to 12 percent last year and 10 percent so far this year, Ms. Gottlieb said. While that represents an improvement over past years, it remains a much steeper rise than the President's plan calls for.
 
Two-Wage Households
 The Clinton plan might also help Apple lower costs. A number of Apple employees -- the company will not say how many -- have working spouses but get their entire family coverage through Apple, driving up the company's total costs.
In the formula the White House proposes for handling two-earner families, a spouse's employer would also have to pay. Each employer, in fact, would pay 80 percent of a family premium for the Administration's standard coverage, or roughly $2,300 apiece. That in effect overcharges for some families and undercharges for families with only one jobholder. But the Administration justifies this practice by arguing that to try to keep track of who works and who does not would be a bookkeeping nightmare. It assumes instead that the average American family has more than one worker.
While each employer pays an 80 percent share for a two-earner family, the family pays the remaining 20 percent, or $560, only once. For single people, the average required employer contribution would be $1,440.
Apple now pays $3,600 a year, on average, for each worker's coverage, much more than the Clinton approach would require. The Apple plan is somewhat more generous in doctor and hospital coverage than the Clinton minimum standard, and that raises the possibility that Apple could gradually adjust its health coverage to the Federal standard, assuming it survives Congress. Or the company could pay additional sums for extras, to maintain health insurance as a recruiting lure. "These options are too speculative to consider now," Ms. Gottlieb said.
 
Lehigh Valley Racquet
Where Part-Time Is the Rule
 For John F. Brinson, president of Lehigh Valley Racquet, costs would rise by what he considered an unbearable amount if Mr. Clinton's plan was adopted. He distinguished between voluntarily deciding to let his 121 part-time employees participate in the company's plan at their expense -- a step he said he would consider -- and being ordered to do so by the Government and at rates mandated by the Government.
"I would not mind if the Government said, 'All right, we think employers have to make health coverage available to their employees,' " Mr. Brinson said. "I can live with that. But they can't come in and tell me how much I have to pay for it."
Forty people work full-time at the company's fitness centers in Allentown and Bethlehem; they are the administrators, clerks and maintenance workers. For each, Mr. Brinson pays $1,200 a year toward the cost of his company's group policies, either fee for service or H.M.O. Each of the 40 pays the rest of the premium, which averages $415 a year for single coverage and $3,882 for a family.
The company's plan offers more coverage to his core staff, Mr. Brinson said, than the Clinton plan does. But at Government-mandated premiums of $2,300 for family coverage, Mr. Brinson would almost double his cost for employees with families, while adding $600 a year for those who are single.
"It would not be fair to pay more for a married person than a single person," he said. "Most companies disagree with me on that point; they think married people are better employees. I don't think that is true." Only 10 of his full-time staff members are married.
 
Government Subsidies
 Many of his full-time employees earn less than $24,000 a year, and below that level the Government, under the Clinton plan, would subsidize part of the premium expense. Such subsidies would also apply to the part-time employees, since their average pay is only $7 an hour. A part-time employee would have to earn $15 an hour to disqualify the company for the subsidy.
Without the subsidy, Mr. Brinson would find himself paying an extra 50 cents an hour to cover employees earning $7 an hour; with it, the Government would pick up half of that amount. This would help, he said, but the subsidy is also an incentive to hold down wages to qualify for the Government aid.
Mr. Brinson insisted that any additional company expense for health insurance -- subsidized or not -- could not be offset by charging his customers more. "In this weak economy, our members are very sensitive to price," he said. "I don't mind being required to make coverage available to part-timers. But they should pay the entire cost."
Mr. Brinson's first reaction to published details of the Clinton plan was to declare that he would dismiss all of his part-time employees and replace them with 40 or 50 full-time workers, even though he said that would be less efficient than the present system. But a few days later, he suggested he would keep the part-time workers.
Mr. Brinson is speculating about ways to absorb the cost. Perhaps, he suggested, he can cancel raises, which have averaged 3 percent a year. "The marketplace will figure out a way to make this as painless as possible," he said. "But I can't raise my prices."
 
Manpower
Where 'Temps' Stand to Gain
 No one would benefit more from the Clinton plan than the nation's nearly two million temporary workers, people who sign up with agencies like Manpower, which in turn rents them to work for a day or for weeks as secretaries, clerks, administrators and factory workers.
The rate covers the wage for the "temp" -- averaging $8.50 an hour -- plus a sum paid to the Government for workmen's compensation, in case the employee is injured, plus an amount to cover Manpower's costs and profit. The temporary agencies will now have to add another sum for health insurance.
"It is devastating economics," said Douglas Long, director of compensation and benefits at Norrell Services, an Atlanta-based "temp" agency. "Ultimately it will force us to raise our rates by 7 to 9 percent."
Mitchell Fromstein, Manpower's chairman, is more sanguine, saying, "We are supporting the reform effort, as we know it so far."
Like Lehigh Valley Racquet, Manpower pays all or most of the cost of the health insurance that it makes available to its 6,000 permanent employees. But the "temps" get no help, except for a small percentage of them who work 400 hours over 10 weeks. If they continue after that, Manpower will pay half the premium of a company policy.
 
Reasons for Optimism
 Mr. Fromstein bases his optimism on three points. First, he said, all the temporary-help companies faced roughly the same new costs, so their rental rates would rise by similar amounts. In addition, under the Clinton plan, some of the cost of health insurance for low-wage "temps" will be subsidized by the Government, even at profitable companies like Manpower.
Finally, Mr. Fromstein said he hoped that hoped the Administration would reduce his cost for workmen's compensation. While the Clinton plan would not take over the costs of treating workplace injuries, it would bring the treatment provided under workmen's compensation into the system of managed care.
But Mr. Fromstein is lobbying for folding all costs of medical treatment under workmen's compensation into the Federal health insurance program. "It does not make any sense to have a health care plan and not cover in it the medical portion of workmen's compensation," he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Aims to Redirect School Aid to the Poor From Wealthy Districts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration proposed today to redirect Federal aid from prosperous school districts to poorer ones, which would have to raise mathematics and reading standards to qualify for the extra money. The renewed effort to rescue students considered most likely to fail by providing them with concentrated daily tutoring is a central feature of the Administration's plan to overhaul the Government's principal school program for poor children.
Tens of millions of dollars in additional education aid would be diverted to cities like New York, Los Angeles and Detroit, where poverty, crime and the breakdown of families have led to delinquency and poor study habits, putting extra burdens on local schools. 
 "When you are in deep water, you need a long rope to pull you in," said Secretary of Education Richard W. Riley as he announced the details of the Improving America's School Act of 1993, which was introduced to Congress today. That 1 in 5 of the nation's children live in poverty is "a scandal of increasing proportion," he said, adding that the Government could no longer "be shy about sticking our necks out to help these children."
The Administration plans to increase the money spent through the program, known as Chapter 1, to $7 billion for the 1995 fiscal year from $6.3 billion for 1994. In a tradeoff that is likely to upset many legislators, suburban areas and rural regions with lower concentrations of poor children would get less money.
 
Rise in New York State
 New York State would receive an increase of $74.5 million, or 12 percent, in its Chapter 1 money for 1995. In comparison, New Jersey's 1995 allocation of $126.6 million represents a 12.2 percent decrease from 1994. Connecticut would receive a 4.6 percent increase in money to $51.7 million in 1995. Puerto Rico would get a 32.2 percent increase, of $72.6 million, for a total of $297.8 million in Federal money in 1995.
In addition to giving the poor districts more money, the proposal would hold them to higher standards of progress for students in the Chapter 1 program. "We cannot continue to give children who are poor a watered-down curriculum," Mr. Reilly said. "It does us no good to continue a conspiracy of low expectations, to dumb down another generation."
Chapter 1 has long been criticized by education experts as holding students in the program to the lowest standards. At present, their progress is measured against the classroom performance of failing students who do not receive extra tutoring help. Under the Administration plan, Chapter 1 students would be compared with more prosperous students. Schools making progress would be rewarded.
To achieve the higher standards, both the amount of time for tutoring and the curriculum for Chapter 1 students would be expanded. Testing based on multiple-choice questions that encourage rote learning would be altered to encourage problem-solving, independent thinking and writing skills. The proposal would prohibit schools receiving Chapter 1 money from limiting the tutoring to teaching rudimentary skills through repetitious drills.
The proposal mixes traditional liberal prescriptions with moderate proposals intended to give states and localities more autonomy in carrying out Government programs, a theme of the Administration.
The increase in money for Chapter 1, which provides extra tutoring for 5.5 million disadvantaged students from kindergarten through high school, represents a restoration of confidence in a Federal educational initiative introduced with fanfare in the Johnson Administration's War on Poverty. During the Reagan years, the programs suffered cuts.
In the past, the schools that failed to lift the performance of poor students were frequently the ones to receive the most new money. The policy overhaul includes rewards for schools that make the most progress, but it would also streamline Federal regulations that force schools to tailor curriculums to national rather than local goals.
 
Plan Is Praised
 Several education experts voiced support for the Administration's initiative. "I think the notion of concentrating resources makes all kinds of sense," said Michael Usdan, president of the Institute for Educational Leadership, a private nonprofit policy group. "There has been a dilution of these dollars as the economic polarization has taken place."
The Administration program would also direct literacy programs to impoverished families, provide seed money to upgrade the training of teachers and provide Chapter 1 services to homeless children.
At the core of the Administration's strategy to fortify the Chapter 1 program is a politically difficult balancing act, setting up a potentially wrenching clash in Congress based on regional and class rivalries.
Sixteen states would lose money: Idaho, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Maine, Maryland, Minnesota, Montana, Nebraska, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Virginia and Wisconsin.
Some Congressional supporters expressed concern that the loss suffered by Maine -- $6.7 million from 1994 to 1995 -- could cost needed support from the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, who represents the state.
Mr. Mitchell put out a measured statement today saying, "I will weigh all recommendations, but I also will work to provide critical assistance to poor children regardless of their geographic location."
"Anything less," he added, "would short-change families in the State of Maine as well as throughout the country."
 
The Big Winners
 The biggest winning states, along with New York, are California, Texas, Mississippi and Louisiana.
Representative Dale E. Kildee, a Michigan Democrat who heads the House Subcommittee on Elementary, Secondary and Vocational Education, said, "The problem is there are many school districts that have effective programs right now that may not qualify for Chapter 1 dollars under the new formula because they don't have a concentration of poverty."
Mr. Kildee said the solution to that political problem would be to increase financing so that the more prosperous school districts did not lose out. The legislation will first be taken up by the House, but the Administration does not expect it to pass until next summer.
At present, schools are automatically eligible for Chapter 1 instruction for all their students if 75 percent of their students are poor. That figure would be lowered to 65 percent so that 12,000 schools would be added to the 8,000 that now participate in campuswide programs.
